title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There is a sweep and grandeur to "Pride and Prejudice," which gives the movie an instant appeal.  Based on the Jane Austin classic, the scenes move forward at a brisk pace to keep our interest, but it is the portrayals that make the movie continually engaging.The Bennet family is of small means.  The father, and, particularly, the mother, are interested in seeking suitors for each of their five daughters.  Focus is primarily on Elizabeth (Keira Knightly), or "Lizzie," the protagonist, who is treated like the ugly duckling of the five.  She is captivating for her wit and intelligence. We immediately have an affinity to her, for she never suffers fools gladly, and she has the brazenness to confront those of higher standing who may belittle her.  So, the situation is ripe when an aristocrat, Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyed) and his friend, Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), pay a visit to the household.  After some social invitations and gatherings, Mr. Bingley takes a fancy to Jane, her favored elder sister, but it provides opportunities for Lizzie to mingle with the seemingly cold and aloof, Mr. Darcy.  There are many instances when the two meet and work out their desires and distastes for one another.  He regards her as saucy; she finds  him to be arrogant.  Many partial disclosures of his past help to make a portrait of him that she increasingly detests.  There is a diversion when a guest suitor, Mr. Collins, a respectable and scrupulous moral figure, visits the household and forces his affections upon her.  There is also a key crisis when the youngest daughter is taken by a suitor in a situation that may be described as compromising.  Once affections are fully realized, Lizzie is confronted by Mr. Darcy's aunt, the indomitable Lady Catherine de Bourg (Judi[th] Dench).The new production of "Pride and Prejudice" has many merits.  The scenes unfold with a grace and movement that is instantly appealing.  Especially the dancing and mingling scenes are choreographed with finesse.  Similar British movies with great acclaim are sometimes tedious affairs, but this one is winning.  The characters, including the nervous mother, the affectionate father, and the likable Mr. Bingley, are exemplary draws.  The portrayals, especially by Knightly, MacFadyed, and Dench are enthralling.  The novel, which I confess I've never read, is probably followed closely--it would be hard to imagine otherwise--but I don't wish to put up pretenses or consult other reviews.  However, it is easy to appreciate the skillfulness that Austin uses through her mouthpiece, Elizabeth, to confront the attitudes and mores of the upper classes.  Maintaining her charm and dignity, she is able to answer to the impossible standards suitors make upon their chosen mistresses for courtship.  Like "Lady Chatterly's Lover" and "Jude, the Obscure," which I have read, "Pride and Prejudice" overthrows the mores and conventions of aristocratic arrogance with style and skill.  The movie captures the spirit well.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a sweeping romance that will leave you  almost breathless and wanting more of Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy!  This is one of my absolute favorite movies made after Jane Austin's classic tale.  The acting is superb and very moving.  It is a modern day take on a classic story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Alright, so where do I begin?  Well, overall I thought this was a great movie which followed along with Austen's story quite well (in light of the time constraints which movies must adhere to).  I loved all the characters- each was true to the nature that Austen intended them for.  I thought the chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy was great, just enough romance but not too overpowering.  Clearly the people that made this movie read the story.  I only wish that the story continued on, alas Austen never wrote the sequel so I am kinda glad a second movie hasn't been made (it just wouldn't be the same).  I only gave this four stars because something was wanting, I just can't put my hand on what (possibly the ending scene- could have been better).  Anyhow, if you loved the book let me assure you, you'll like the movie, if not love it (I watched in three times the day it came out)!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My wife made me go see it the first time and I was not very excited.  It actually turned out to be a great movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really enjoyed this telling of the classic tale. Sure, if glosses over some parts as films must; but the setting and costumes looked so much more authentic than any other film I can recall which depicts life in this era. Plus it's just a classic story in general. Highly recommended.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This adaptation seems more like Emily Bronte than Jane Austen but it's one of the few films which have motivated me to go to a movie theater this year. I was surprised at how well Keira Knightley interpreted Elizabeth Bennett and though Matthew MacFadyen isn't as perfect as Colin Firth was as Fitzwilliam Darcy, this may just be "prejudice" on my part. Even my Anglophobe husband enjoyed this film but I think that it may be because of lovely Rosamund Pike who plays Jane Bennett. Donald Sutherland is a nice surprise as Mr. Bennett and Dame Judy Dench is magnificent as always in her role as Lady Catherine De Bourg. Go see it if only for the scenery and the feel of the Regency period. You won't be sorry.
summary: Not Entirely True to the Book but Entrancing None the Less

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While this is a decent version of the movie and I did buy a copy; it is really like owning the "Cliff Notes" version for evenings when I don't have time to see the whole spectacular movie that was by A&E; starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Erhle. The characters in this version, directed by Joe Wright are not well developed, you do not have a chance to fall in love and understand them. The portrayl and development of the rest of the Bennet family, aside from Elizabeth, is rushed and mediocre.  Elizabeth herself swings in her moods from giggly girl to proud woman; yet no constancy of character.  Mr Darcy (Macfadyen) is a saving grace in this film. His facial expressions and delivery save his character and he does the part justice.  You just wish for more scenes with Mr. Darcy.Overall, I like the movie for a dose of Pride & Prejudice on a night when I don't have time for the "real thing". But for those of you who really love the book and love this genre of film...treat yourself to the A&E;/BBC version.  You will not be disappointed.
summary: Doesn't measure up to the A&E/BBC Version

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Once again, I have had the pleasure of finding one of Jane Austen's classic novels brought to the big screen -- and once more I couldn't fancy myself happier.  Ah- would that there were hundreds of such renderings!Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is amongst all in the whole vast world of literature the dearest to my heart.  Therefore, even a version that deigns tamper with a decade-old perfection serves to excite my interest.  Indeed- for I was simply ecstatic when, in 1995, A&E; and the BBC collaborated to create a grand and brilliantly performed portrayal of that book.  At a length of nearly 6 hours, no aspect of this wonderful story had been neglected - and I knew that such a true commitment to the literature, combined with such passion for the tale, is a precious rarity in film. Now, years hence, that 1995 picture still resonates.  Comparisons are to be inevitable, no doubt.  I'd already been well reconciled to the fact that a two-hour version of the story, no matter how well done, could only suffer in the comparison to that A&E; production.  I therefore resolved to judge this movie by its own qualities -- And what fine qualities they turned out being!  Brilliantly directed by Joe Wright, this sensual and earthy interpretation just warms my soul.Keira Knightley takes on the role of our heroine: Elizabeth Bennet, the 2nd oldest of the five daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Bennet (Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn).  Matthew MacFadyen plays our hero: Mr. Darcy, the handsome and aloof owner of a great estate in the north of England.  The two go down the dance, waltzing through misunderstanding and mischance - wit and romance, dexterously stepping along fine lines of social propriety and distinction of class, through rejection and redemption, conjuring the many diversions of country life in Regency England. Yes, we Janeites all know the story.The casting herein is essentially very agreeable.  Knightly is lovely and makes for a fine Elizabeth, and the camera adores her- though when Darcy finds her appearance only "tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me," it strikes one as rather unbelievable.  She effortlessly captures Lizzy's wry spirit and spark of humor, though I must admit I found her a little bit wanting in that quiet depth or the brilliance of mind that role calls for.MacFadyen's take on Darcy is more dark and brooding than actors in the past have portrayed him.  And though I enjoyed watching him, I cannot say that he did very well in expressing the changes Mr. Darcy undergoes:  I did not see an aristocrat stuffed with pride, whose passion for Elizabeth blossoms as he becomes transformed by her spirited influence.  Rather, he just seems to convey the same brooding manner all along - and his only problem appears to be that he is misunderstood.As for the supporting players, I think Sutherland was excellent as the bemused Mr. Bennet - and his scene with Lizzy at the end was exquisitely drawn.  Blethyn played her part very well, too - her Mrs. Bennet was every bit as laughable and endearing as Austen wrote her.  Judi Dench was wonderfully formidable as Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  The roles of Mr. Collins, Jane Bennet, Mr. Bingley and Wickham were also excellently played.Visually, this film is just stunning.  I've rarely, if ever, seen more exquisite scenery in a movie. The camera work is mesmerizing.  The cinematography here is certainly Oscar-worthy.  I can even forgive the overly rusticated state (complete with chickens, pigs, & all manner of livestock traipsing throughout the house) of Longbourn, the Bennet family home.  This, in fact, only serves to give charm to this beautiful and totally unique rendition of a most beloved story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In this latest version of Pride and Prejudice, Director Joe Wright uses impressive visuals and sumptuous period locales to create an exquisite wide-screen spectacle, filling it with details that illustrate important sociological information about its central family, the Bennets. From the movie's mist-filled and dream-like opening moments to its marvelous ball sequence and the predictable but nonetheless glorious ending, Pride & Prejudice is an absolutely sumptuous evocation of Jane Austen's milieu, and is a captivatingly youthful spin without compromising the novel's late-eighteenth-century manners; it also deserves to be remembered as one of the very best screen adaptations of this book so far.Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) is fraught with worry. The mother of five daughters has proved to be a little bit much for her and if they don't start marrying soon, the family will be ruined. The father (Donald Sutherland) stays out of the way, hoping his daughters somehow overcome societal prejudice against their gender and make something of their minds.  Headstrong Elizabeth (Kira Knightley) has done just that. Smart, feisty, and fiercely independent, Lizzie promises herself that she won't be one to settle.When Lizzie's older sister, Jane (Rosamund Pike), meets the wealthy Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods) at a dance, their future as a couple seems predetermined. But when Lizzie is introduced to the gloomy and standoffish Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen), an instant dislike is established. Lizzie and Mr. Darcy must overcome quite a few obstacles before they can transcend their dislike of each other, not the least of which is unsuitable suitor Mr. Collins (a wonderfully comic Tom Hollander) and Darcy's formidable aunt Lady Catherine (Dame Judi Dench) who tells Lizzie that she is of an "inferior class." Of course, Lizzie's frosty rejection of Darcy eventually thaws when he confesses his passion for her one evening on a misty moor.Pride and Prejudice really works because of the marvelously impassioned performances from its two sexy leads. As the strong-willed Elizabeth, Knightley is tantalizing and seductive, so perfectly fitting into her 19th century Austen surroundings; she catches Elizabeth's essential skittishness and youthful braggadocio, making her final conversion with Darcy all the more moving. Macfadyen as Darcy is a more conflicted, softer figure than Colin Firth's indelibly etched performance, but Macfadyen is much earthier and sexier, and his portrayal is one that fits the movie's more realistic mood.Pride and Prejudice benefits from Wright's intensely visual approach that manages to meld realism with romance in a canny balance. The movie has a youthful essence, as well as providing a richly detailed setting. Scenes barely sketched in Austen's dialogue-heavy, description-light prose leap fully detailed onto the screen, thanks to Sarah Greenwood's terrific production design and Jacqueline Durran's textured costumes. This is a unique, gorgeously evocative, and quite accomplished film, which should satisfy even the most rabid Austen-ophiles - just lovely. Mike Leonard March 06.
summary: "She is tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me."

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My daughter and I were very much disappointed with this movie.  We might have been more impressed had we not seen Colin Firth's and Jennifer Ehle's version of Pride and Prejudice first.  The movie seemed rushed. Sometimes the characters spoke far too fast so you had no clue as to what they were saying. Some of the essential characters were cut from the story. Mr. Bingley was a real goofball. The only noteworthy enhancements  from the Firth & Ehle version were Jane and Mr. Wickham characters. This is not a slight against Keira Knightley because she is as beautiful as I would expect Elizabeth Bennett to be.  However, Jennifer Ehle was perfection as Elizabeth Bennett, and Colin Firth is the sexiest.  Had I seen this movie before I purchased it, I would have saved my money.  I'm not saying that the acting was terrible because the actors worked very will with what they had.  However, some things are better left alone and not attempted.  That is, the mold was absolutely broken after Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle version of Pride and Prejudice was made.
summary: The mold was absolutely broken after Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I can't believe how badly this movie got Jane Austen's seminal work. The plot is so thin, and the whole point of the book, the mutual transformation of both Lizzy and Darcy, which is the only thing that allows them to be so happy is all but missing. If you don't have time for all the plot then cut the whole Wickham and Lydia side plot out so you can do justice to at least one part of this story. UGH. If you want Pride and Prejudice the 1995 BBC version is still the best option.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For the sake of time, much was cut from the novel. But the language for the most part was Jane Austen's. Quite an efficient presentation of a thoughtful story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice is a great movie! Both Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen give great performances. Rosamund Pike as the elder sister, Jane, is a delight. Simon Woods as Bingley is wrongly portrayed as rather foolish, but he is absolutely cute and adorable about Jane, so it's all good. Claudie Blakely (Charlotte Lucas/Collins) gives a much more sympathetic performance than any other Charlotte before her. The friendship between Lizzy and Charlotte feels totally right and believable.I feel it is my duty to warn you that the ending scenes are very close to horrendous, at least to Janeites. The dialogue is cheesy, and the second proposal is in the early morning, with both Lizzy and Darcy in their nightclothes. Darcy especially made me cringe. When the movie all of a sudden jumps from Mr. Bennet's consent to Pemberley, you have to cringe again. And then grit your teeth when Darcy and Lizzy are again in their nightclothes, and saying lines that are so syrupy you want to laugh, but have to cry b/c it's P+P that this crew is messing up.There are many things wrong with the movie, but I love a lot of things in it too. For instance, when Lizzy sees Darcy at Rosings. The scene when Bingley and Darcy practice Bingley's proposal to Jane. The scene when, in church, Fitzwilliam tells Lizzy about Darcy's separation of Bingley and Jane.A must for die-hard Janeites, just ignore the ending.
summary: Loved it, but BEWARE of cheesy ending!! (spoilers)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Joe Wright did a stunning job with this magnificent version of Pride & Prejudice. Keira Knightley shines as Elizabeth Bennet, and the supporting cast, including Donald Sutherland as the kind, softspoken Mr. Bennet, Jena Malone as the silly Lydia, and stunning Rosamund Pike as Jane, is delightful as well; but it is the gorgeous Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy who truly captures. There's not a slow moment in this film; it is steady, enchanting, and worth a thousand views.The enchanting melodies used for this film's score did much to enhance the tone of the film; the piano solo Dawn is exceptionally haunting, as is Liz On Top of the World. It's inspiring me to sit myself down on a piano again, although I'm sure I would ruin the music rather than do justice to it.Filmed almost entirely on location, the only set built for the production was the ballroom in which Darcy and Lizzie first meet. The use of Chatsworth House, Wilton House, and Basildon Park, as well as other grand, stately homes, provided a beautiful setting for this extraordinary adaptation.SPOILER/ENDING ALERT:  Here's an interesting bit: my favorite part of the movie - the ending - features Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy outside, enjoying a moment together under starlight, sharing one of my favorite film conversations:Darcy: "And what am I to call you when I am cross? Mrs. Darcy?"Elizabeth: "No, you may only call me 'Mrs. Darcy' when you are completely, perfectly and incandescently happy."Darcy: "And how are you this evening... Mrs. Darcy? Mrs. Darcy... Mrs. Darcy... Mrs. Darcy."This ending, not in the novel, is apparently also not included in the UK and international versions of the film, having not gone over well with British audiences. As a North American audience member, I'm particularly glad this ended up in the release on this side of the globe - it is truly one of the most tender endings I've had the pleasure of watching. (It's also two more minutes of Matthew Macfadyen, which is so not a terrible thing.)For any woman who loves the Jane Austen classic, I'm sure she feels she owns Elizabeth Bennet, or sees herself in Elizabeth in one way or another, so obviously casting the role well was of great importance. Lizzie is strong, insightful, capable and witty - the model heroine - and Kiera Knightley was arguably the best choice for this role. There was effortless chemistry between her and each of the actors with whom she shared the screen.It's rare a book translates to film as exquisitely as this.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film does take liberties with the book but keeps true to the spirit of the story and the characters.  A lovely movie and worth adding to your collection.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The screenplay writer did an excellent job of compressing Austen's long book into a cogent and entertaining two hour movie. The acting was excellent and the cinematography absolutely gorgeous.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen a total of three different adaptations of this book.  By far, this was absolutely the WORST version of Pride and Prejudice I have ever seen.Keira Knightly is a HORRIBLE Elizabeth Bennett.  She makes Lizzie seem ridiculous and senseless.  She removes all the intellect that Elizabeth Bennett is known of having.  I do not know how she was nominated for an Oscar for this role.  The members of the academy must not have read the book before voting.The screenwriters should be ashamed of the hack job they performed on such a wonderful masterpiece.  There are major parts of the book that are missing form this version.  None of the characters are shown in a proper light.  Furthermore, it neither shows the bond between Lizzie and her father nor the bond between Lizzie and her sister, Jane.It took me two different occasions to try and make it through an entire viewing of this movie because I couldn't take the awfulness.  This version is not for a person whom considers himself/herself a Jane Austen fan.  If I could, I would rank this movie a negative five stars.If you want to watch a WONDERFUL version of P&P;, please watch A&E; version with Colin Firth.  This is by far the best version I have seen and I would recommend it to any Jane Austen fan.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Most of the major points of the book come across in this film. The DVD looks good and as a film it has a good feel to it for the period. The acting is top notch and the photography is beautiful. A good effort all around.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you are looking for an exact play of the book, this isn't quite it.  The characters are slightly different than what you may have imagined while reading and while Jane Austen's book is quoted all throughout, the story line was changed a bit.  However, this movie does a pretty good job of condensing 122,618 words into 129 minutes of pleasing, albeit fast paced, visual entertainment.  The Blu-ray quality is lovely, I haven't had a need to use the DVD yet and the digital copy I will probably access via iTunes since I never managed to get my digital copy (which is a piece of paper with a code on it) of Tangled to work via Windows Media Center - and once you use those codes they are apparently lost to you forever.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of the worst adaptations of Austen's novels I've ever seen.  The characters (specially Elizabeth) look and behave like XXI century people in costume. All the cleverness of Austen's novel is gone.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Very good acting and beautiful scenary. Set in eary 1800's this is my favarite version, this movie made me like Kyra and this is my favarite Mr. Darsy. I have watched this movie many times, and so have my friends.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Of the four versions of "Pride and Prejudice" I have seen (1940, 1980, 1995, 2005), this one is definitely the nadir. To begin with, it's astonishingly ugly. It looks like the Middle Ages in Asia rather than like England of the early nineteenth century. Even after making the usual allowances for omissions and changes during the adaptation, the screenplay departs from Jane's original in a most deplorable way. It is this version, not the 1940 one, which is the real travesty, if not in terms of plot at all events in terms of characters.Whoever had the bright idea of casting Keira Knightley as Lizzy did a great disservice to the future generations. I shudder to think how many people will see this movie without any prior knowledge of the novel and will think, quite mistakenly, that Keira's portrayal has anything to do with Jane's; if they ever come to read the book later, they would probably be too full of pride and prejudice to really appreciate it. Keira's vapid performance, rife with hideous grins that apparently pass for smiles, is fully matched by the worst Darcy imaginable. The proud and conceited gentleman has been scaled down to a timid and tedious creature.The supporting cast, despite the presence of such illustrious names like Donald Sutherland (Mr Bennet who speaks his generally witty lines with a funereal air) and Judi Dench (Lady Catherine who sounds much more like Lady Macbeth), is no improvement over the weak principals. There is not a trace of Mr Collins' trademark pomposity or Mrs Bennet's equally typical (and fake) hysteria. Jane is supposed to be a placid creature, but is this one entirely devoid of life! The whole cast speak their lines in the most contrived and unnatural manner. All grace, charm and vivacity of the original have been lost.There is nothing redeeming about this movie (except, perhaps, Lydia and the interlude with the marble statues). In addition to the fabulous vapidity of the acting, this includes the mediocre production, the clumsy direction, the clipped and simplified dialogue. It's all matter of taste of course. But my idea of Pride and Prejudice has nothing to do with anorexic Lizzy, moronic Darcy and a bunch of talking mannequins who seem to have no idea what their lines mean. The praise lavished on this movie, by both critics and audience, is something I really don't understand.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have always looked forward to movies interpreting Jane Austen's classic novels. When I learned that there might be a new P & P movie, I wonder how can this movie provide a new perspective to the acclaimed BBC production which starred an excellent and competent cast led by Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. But here comes Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFayden, both goodlooking actors who provided the conflict, the feelings unspoken but sizzling through the screen, the fiery, passionate dialogue and the blissful happy ending that two people in love deserve so much. Excellent movie. More excellent script. Most excellent cast!
summary: When you think the BBC/A&E special couldn't be topped, this film brings in a new fresh interpretation

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Oddly enough the BBC version features a more lavish production than this movie. Also, trying to condense the book into 2 hrs  cuts the characters into 2 dimesionals. This movie feels more like a stage production with the acting. Donald Sutherland and Judi Dench are the sole exceptions. Kiera Knightley does a good job but when compared to Jennifer Ehle - well no one compares to her acting. The Mr. Darcy in this movie looks incredible as does the handsome actor who plays Mr. Wickham yet even their acting is stiff though Darcy's gets better towards the middle half. This whole movie feels rushed - in a matter of 10 minutes we are introduced to Mr. Collins and then Mr. Wickham. We also only get one Bingley sister instead of 2.This could've been an incredible version but it was very disappointing. My sole gripe is not being as faithful to  the classic book as it should. I could overlook the acting and the sets if only this movie didn't cut and rearrange the book.
summary: Looks pretty but cuts out much of the book, Not enough Details

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, this film has its flaws, as all remakes do, but it sticks to the main story, and that is what attracts Austen lovers to it.  If you are a real fan, then you will gobble this one up just as you have done the other ones that came out.  At first I did not see Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet either, and the fact that Hollywood could see anyone else as Darcy nearly made me go crazy, but these actors did a great job.  It's a different take and a very well done version for a new audience.  And yes, I have read the book ten million times and own the BBC A&E version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride And Prejudice is an exuberant celebration of what movies do best.  In one meticulously constructed scene after another it showers viewers with eye candy and in so doing, transports them to a distant, fascinating place and time.  In a cynical age such as ours, where every image is suspect, this is more difficult than one might imagine; director Joe Wright's success is complete.Jane Austen's Pride And Prejudice has demonstrated Rocky-esque box office endurance.  Were she alive today, Austen might marvel at our attraction to this tale of marriage as business, crushing social stratification, and nuanced mannerisms - told with precision, wit, and irony - considering that our own society, though bloated with both pride and prejudice, possesses none of the refined subtleties she described.Apart from our Anglophile obsession, born of the indebtedness we feel for providing our culture, such as it is, this attraction is most easily traced to the character of Elizabeth (Keira Knightly), a smart, beautiful, and appealingly feisty young woman who holds out for love over financially-motivated marriage.  (Heresy!)  While older sister Jane (Rosamund Pike) may be lovelier, we root for Liz as she battles uphill. Her triumph does not seem facile, Liz is tested and must grow - indeed, we cheer her victory because we sense she will not abuse it.Superb performances abound, led by Judi Dench as Lady Catherine.  From her comfy chair on top of the food chain, Dench embodies the full force of social pressure as you've never seen it before - terrifying.  Matthew MacFadyen is compelling as Mr. Darcy, he has on-screen presence and commands attention with his quiet, thoughtful demeanor.  Keira Knightly carries the picture admirably, mischievous without being obnoxious, self-absorbed without being narcissistic, sharp-witted without being needlessly cynical.  Brenda Blethyn (Mrs. Bennet) is wonderfully nutty, ambitious, and calculating while Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennet), workmanlike as ever, should have been told that a Canadian accent is not an English accent.  Tom Hollander, as Reverend Collins, isn't on camera much but is simply brilliant.Pride And Prejudice reveals a world where function follows form, not vice versa.  In one glorious scene the five Bennet sisters dance at a ball and Liz scrupulously avoids the advances of Reverend Collins while attempting to attract Darcy.  This is the carefully delineated atmosphere of Jane Austen; it's a wonderful place to visit.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In 1 word, Inaccurate ~ they did NOT have Pigs running in and out of thier house!  The Bennett family wanted to be upper-class and would have died before they had live stock running through their home!  This is 100% Inaccurate/Unfaithful to the novel Jane Austen wrote.  30-40 minutes into the movie, I turned it off... Not to mention the colors they used in this movie - BLEGH!  Greys, Browns, Whites and Blacks ~ it makes everything look dirty and even dirtier.  Which is also why, I HATE this version. And don't even get me started on the acting ~ it's just as bad.  I made the mistake buying it without having seen it first, a mistake I will never repeat.  I WILL NEVER BUY THIS VERSION AGAIN - EVER!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Directed by Joe Wright, Pride and Prejudice (2005), is a remake of the original film from 1940 that tells a love story of a most unlikely couple that constantly battle against being together. In the end, they realize they are perfect for each other (sorry for ruining it). And of course, one cannot forget the classic scene of Mr. Darcy confessing his love to Elizabeth in the pouring rain, which is my favorite part. This film is for all the romantics, and the fans of the distinguished Jane Austen.It boasts a completely innovative soundtrack that fits the film perfectly. Dario Marianelli composed a beautiful assortment of piano pieces as well as full orchestration sequences that complete the film and allows the audience to feel immersed in the Victorian time period. Another aspect that is effectively conveyed by the music is how it asserts how the audience should be feeling throughout the film.The cast is especially impressive, including Keira Knightly as Elizabeth Bennett, and Matthew Macfayden as the timeless Mr. Darcy. The sweet and witty demeanor of the characters creates an atmosphere that is sure to impress any audience. Vitality and life are strong influences that create a sense of happiness in practically every scene.Classiness is overwhelming in this film, and the story is basically the same as the book, which I find refreshing, despite the trend of changing the movie entirely from the way things are originally in the book. This film is a perfectly crafted ingenious production, and is definitely my favorite movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I heard that a new version of Pride & Prejudice was being filmed, I doubted that it could ever meet the standard set by the 1995 BBC miniseries starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth, a fantastic adaptation of a book I've re-read too many times to count. It ended up being my favorite movie of 2005.Pride & Prejudice is a story that requires great performances in order to be fully effective. I originally didn't understand the choice of Keira Knightley for the role of Elizabeth Bennett, but she proved me wrong and did an absolutely wonderful job. Her Oscar nomination is well deserved. (But if she is "plain" looking, we're all screwed.) I LOVED Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy. Rather than imitating Colin Firth's well adored performance, he gave a new interpretation of the role that fit in perfectly. As Roger Ebert said in his review, it's "well cast from top to bottom."I'm normally a complete book snob. But despite the fact that it's not a entirely faithful adaptation (if it were, we'd have been sitting in the theater the entire day), I think it ultimately captures the essence of Jane Austen's novel. I don't know why some are getting so worked up over minute historical details that do not effect the quality of the film whatsoever. I liked the more "modern" additions made to the movie and the more rugged feel it has. Who wants to see a rehash of something that has already been done with the novel?I know the story like the back of my hand, but the way it was presented made me feel the same delight as when I read the book for the first time. I walked out of it on cloud nine. Watch it with an open mind, and you will too. Can't wait to own it on DVD.
summary: Don't listen to the book/miniseries snobs!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: At first, you might be thinking, "Why do we need yet another remake of Pride & Prejudice?"  It's a valid question.  I mean, it hasn't been that long since the BBC remade the famous story; however, this version of the Jane Austen classic is, in my opinion, the best one yet.  From the casting, to the adaptation, to the beautiful cinematography this is a far superior film.  If you loved Austen's novel, then you will love this film.  It stays true to the book better than any version I've seen and the casting is nearly perfect.  I'm not a huge fan of Kiera Knightley, but she was wonderful as Elizabeth Bennett.  Equally as good is Rosamund Pike as the lovelorn older Bennett sister, Jane.  Whenever she is on screen she far outshines any of the other actors around her.  Of course, there's Mr. Darcy as played by Matthew Macfadyen.  Throughout the film he has to play the sourpuss and condescending Darcy who is unwilling and unable to show true emotion; however, if you really watch Macfadyen's performance you can see so much just by looking at his eyes, which convey so much that is left unsaid.  When Darcy finally does let his guard down it's almost alarming.  The entire cast of this film, which is mostly British, but with some Americans thrown in for good measure, is just wonderful.  Director Joe Wright assembled the perfect group of people to play these roles.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I absolutely love Jane Austen and this movie did not do justice to the story.  There were so many historical inaccuracies I don't know where to begin.The Bennetts did not live on a dirty farm.  Mr. Bennett was a Gentleman part of the upper middle class and would have had property supporting that status.  He wouldn't have lived on a farm and he wouldn't have had a dog in the house.  They would have had a carriage.Mr. Wickham was almost nonexistent.Miss Bingley looked like she was wearing a corset at the Netherfield Ball  The costuming was wrong all around.Lizzy never was intentionally mean in her teasing.  There was one spot in the movie where I was wanting to scream because they changed the dialog from the book.  Where she's at Netherfield and she and Darcy are having one of many verbal sparing matches and he's talking about pride being a failing in the movie they have her saying, "I love to laugh, but I cannot"  Howeverin the book she says, "That is a failing indeed, but I cannot laugh at it".Mr. Darcy walks into the Collins' home in the middle of the night into her bedroom without anyone hearing him?  Outside of that being a no-no particularly back then, The Collins' at least had a servant.Lady Catherine Jeudi Dench was a great Lady Cathrine.  Which is why I don't mind paying the rental fee.  However she wouldn't have come to the Bennett's house in the middle of the night to have it out with Lizzy.  What's the point of mentioning the Bennett's have a small park on one side of the house if you're not going to walk in it.  The argument between Lady Cathrine and Lizzy is one of the best cat fights in literature and they ruin it.Mr. Bingley is portrayed as a bumbling idiot and Darcy has to work with him to get the nerve up to ask Jane.  When he had his mind made up in the first place and was a bit upset when Darcy concealed Jane being in town.Georgiana Darcy was not outgoing.  In fact she was rather shy.There are so many more things I could mention, but I think I've made my point.  I have no problems with modernized versions of Pride and Prejudice, but if your going to do it within a period piece that's where I draw the line.  Either do the proper research of the period and get it right or don't do it at all.
summary: This movie made me want to cry

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love-love-love the BBC miniseries P & P.  I could not wait for the new P & P to come out in theatres.  When it did, I was surprised to find that I love-love-love the new P & P as well.  I had people ask "Which do you like better?" and I could not answer because I loved both so much.  I recently ordered the new P & P on DVD and watched it back-to-back with the BBC miniseries to see if there was ANY way to determine if I had a preference.  In the end, I decided that I do like the BBC one a teeny-tiny bit more because I enjoy how much more exaggerated the characters are.  In the BBC version, Mrs. Bennett is more of an annoying drama queen and Mr. Collins is more repulsive (nearly impossible to imagine that "old maid" Charlotte would consent to marrying him - ugggh!).  In the new P & P, it seems more believable that Elizabeth would "come around" to Mr. Darcy because he is less "standoffish" than Colin Firth's character in the BBC version.  I enjoyed Keira Knightly in the new version but there was something about what I call Jennifer Ehle's "secret amused smile" in the BBC version that I feel really helps define Elizabeth's character.  All in all, if you're a P & P fan - you should own both.  If you are a person pressed for time - watch the shorter (new) version and if you have the time - watch the miniseries!  Above all - enjoy!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a fabulous movie.  I saw it 11 times in the theater.  Then I bought two DVDs just in case one wears out.  I keep it in the DVD player at all times.  I had not seen the A&E miniseries but I watched it right after I saw the new movie and I liked it, too. Then I read the book--I think I know everything there is to know about Pride and Prejudice. The 2005 movie is just gorgeous!  The music is awe-inspiring--buy the CD! The cinematography is breathtaking--the beauty of England shines through. It is the epitome of a great love story. I don't understand the negative reviews.  I would give it a dozen stars if I could.
summary: I love this movie, most ardently!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The scenery in this version of Pride and Prejudice was absolutely gorgeous. That is the one positive comment I can give this film.But a coyly giggling Elizabeth? When did Jane Austen ever intend the strongest female character she's ever written to be reduced to a girlish and immature giggler? Elizabeth is supposed to stand out among all the other girls as clever and quick witted, not a vapid silly girl the way her sisters are depicted. After all, is Jane Austen's Elizabeth the prettiest? No. Is the the smartest? No. Is she even the most talented? No. But that was the point! She stil has so much confidence and gumption that she can tell Darcy and his aunt off with skill and articulation.And Darcy? He's supposed to be proud. Not bland and boring.The proposal scene was an utter sham. How could the makers of this movie change the articulate monologues Elizabeth and Darcy recite and cut them up into dialogues to suit the modern audience's short attention span. Couldn't they sit through the monologues and feel the full punch of the words instead of having to have them disected into a back and forth dialogue which Austen clearly did not intend for them to be.I felt like the movie was trying to shout the entire time "Look at this zoom in of the pig, look at this interesting angle of the Pemberly House from the ceiling! Look at me! There is a director for this movie! Forget about the timeless dialogue. There is a director in this movie and I won't be ignored!"

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Just for fun, I watched the Director's commentary with the film and now understand why watching this film is like looking through a broken kaleidoscope. It starts with birds chirping on a beautiful landscape, moves to an odd close up, over the shoulder, of a book Lizzie is reading, but you can't see the title of, then has her walking over a FILTHY duck pond into a working farm house, eavesdropping on her parents.The whole movie goes back and forth between modern use of cameras against a backdrop of regency styles. The family, the costumes, the houses, are all regency, while the camera work fractures the story-telling with its movement from harshly lit close ups to single hand held shots. In the commentary, even the director admits Dame Judy Dench looks awful in her close ups when she comes to visit Lizzie in the middle of the night to confront her about Darcy's proposal. He talks about getting ideas on the way to filming different scenes - like the sunlit close up of Lizzie when she travels to Derbyshire with her aunt and uncle came to him when he put his head out the car door in the sunlight when he was going to a film location.This story seems filmed a bit off the hip, or off the cuff - improvised!I still love it. The unspoiled landscapes are gorgeous. From the Longbourne house with its moat and surrounding wildlife and even the farm life to the gorgeous grecian temple in Wiltshire - I will try to go there now that I know where it is - where Darcy proposes makes me melt to the cadence of Matthew MacFadyen's voice. I want to go there just to listen to the echoes of the scene - in the rain, of course. He is a revelation as Darcy, although I can also picture him in modern terms as a spy in his series Spooks. But he is fun and sexy. The close up of his hand after he touches Elizabeth helping her into the carriage is glorious.I would recommend listening to the directors comments about ALL  his casting choices, what he feels about their performances, the design of the sets, and how he made his decisions in telling the story.  (the ribbon dyeing scene is wonderful).So I would recommend this film to anyone. But I would caution them that it is a clash of sensibilities - modern and regency.Thanks for making it.Emily Linden, RN, BA.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved this movie from beginning to end. Keira Knightley plays the beautiful and stubborn Eliza Bennet in this stirring film, while Matthew Macfadyen acts as the proud Mr. Darcy. A great rendition of the story that stays true to the original tale. I've watched this movie a thousand times and highly recommend it to others!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is good, directed more for today's audience but still enjoyable. I don't like that several parts of the book are missing-but that's creativity for you. Acting is fine.  My favorites and truer to the book are the BBC versions from the 80's and 90's. (David Rintoul and Colin Firth playing Darcy).

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's a movie for pity sake!  I am probably one of the newest Elizabeth and Darcy fans, and most likely one of the oldest.  I had never seen the black and white version, the BBC version, nor had I ever picked up the book to read it.I was loaned this movie by my daughter during recovery from surgery.  After having viewed it once, I think I watched it on a daily basis during my six weeks at home, and I try to watch it at least a few times a month.I ABSOLUTELY LOVE this movie, but it didn't stop there.  Amazon.com and I have become very good friends, seeing how I now own the original P&P; story and the BBC version, (which I've not watched yet) but I have also bought or ordered every book there is on Elizabeth and Darcy.  Yes, so they don't all follow Jane Austen's lead, but these are two characters to wonderful to be left alone in one story.I don't care that the movie doesn't follow the book to the letter, what adaptation does, very few.  My advice is if you are so smitten with the book or any book; DON'T ever go see the movie version.This is a wonderful "love" story (pft, who said it's not a love story?).

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride & Prejudice is by far my favorite! The music. The chemistry between the characters. The scenery. It's magical! :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a wonderful movie and goes along perfectly with the novel by jane austen. I would rate this movie over any other pride and prejudice movies i have seen.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just love this movie.  I watched it without a clue of what it was going to be like.  I fell madly in love with Mr. Darcy.  He is very passionate and intense.  I just love his whole character.  After, I had to watch the Colin Firth version.  Although I'm a Mr. Darcy fan of Bridge Jones's Diary, I have to say I prefer this newer Mr. Darcy over Firth.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Lovely movie artfully done. But not Jane Austen. This a gothic novel with Austen characters. This is an adaptation of Jane Eyre, or Wuthering Heights, or Rebecca. Overwrought, dark and brooding. Where Austen novels are wry and clever, and always understated. If I had never read Austen I would have enjoyed it. But I have and it is  jarring. It certainly is better than the 1940 version with Greer Garson, but barely.
summary: Pride and Prejudice as written by Charlotte Bronte

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a serious fan of the 1995 BBC version. It's still the best P&P adaptation to date. That said, Joe Wright's updated version is the one that gets the most play in my house. The characters have been given a free run of the house. There's plenty of dancing, laughter, running about. It's Austen on hormones. The emotions are pumped up and the drama heightened. The cinematography is just gorgeous but the best element is the soundtrack, hauntingly beautiful and difficult to get out of your head. Whatever your preference, there's always room for more Jane Austen. And the sight of Darcy striding over the hill at sunrise .. a jaw-dropper.
summary: You can be a fan of both!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For those of us who are rabid Jane Austen fans, like myself, who went in to watch this looking forward to it but not expecting much after watching the superb and nearly-flawless BBC miniseries with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth countless times, this movie was a joyous and exhilerating shock. I admit that after watching the preview and reading everything there was to read about it before it  came out, I wasn't expecting much.I was still crazy-wild to see it-it looked very romantic and come on, its Pride and Prejudice-but Matthew MacFadyen as Darcy looked plain and boring, and some of the changes to the handling of the atmostphere and everything sounded very dubious. Having said that, I went in and came out stunned. The new movie is gorgeous, tender, passionate, lovely, fun. But mostly it brought back to me a feeling of what love is really like-that understanding that we've lost so completely after hordes of mediocre and wishy-washy romantic comedies and soap operas. The only thing that has come close to re-creating that feeling is Titanic,and I thought that Pride and Prejudice did a better job. And Matthew MacFadyen was superb as Darcy. He is Darcy-he captures a different version, a different part of him than Colin Firth, but he is as utterly him as Firth was. The man was perfect-by the end of the movie you are utterly in love with him. He starts out, like the movie,a little bit of a nonentity-you're not sure whether you like him or not. Then both he and the movie pick up speed and from there it just gets better and better until the ending, which is as nearly perfect as a movie ending can be. Don't mistake me-the old Pride and Prejudice will always in the end be the quintessential one, and Colin Firth's Darcy remains at the peak-but this movie is very nearly as good and MacFadyen's Darcy is really just as good, in a very different way(I never thought I would say that). MacFadyen played him with shyness, intensity, subtlety, warmth, idiocy, humour, and charm by turns,and by doing so turns out a very human and completely-perfect man. And his chemistry with Keira Knightley is exquisite-a miracle. In the end that is what makes up the movie-they light up the screen together. I haven't seen anything like it since-well-Titanic, and this movie shows it up in that area as well. Like the producers said after it was released,when they got the two actors together on the set something happened and they became their characters-two characters madly in love with each other.(Keira Knightley is just as good as MacFadyen-another mild surprise-she plays her with a delicacy and warmth completely lacking in most of her other performances.The moment when she steps down from the carriage and looks up at Pemberley and releases a quick bubble of laughter made up of equal part irony, delicious laughter,regret, and a sense of the ridiculous, is a cinematic moment that won't come again, and only she could have produced it).After watching it,I came out of the theater poised between sheer joy and hysterical laughter, and feeling an intense desire to be in love with someone-that is what the movie did to me.It is flawed-Jane and Bingley are pretty much ruined and several very important plot points are brushed over or ignored-the producers seemed to feel about two-thirds of the way throught the movie that they'd better speed it up,and so they rush through several major events at breakneck speed-but other things make you forgive them for it.Lady Catherine and Mr. Collins, while very different versions than in the BBC one, are good once you get used to them, and this is pretty much the case for all the minor characters with the exception perhaps of Bingley and his sister. Watch it, not really expecting it to be as good as the old one and definitely not hoping for the book, because it's not that-but it stands on its own as shining movie masterpiece of romanctic dramas.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I can't even say that I was disappointed. That would insinuate some great expectation from the film in the first place. It is nearly impossible to convey this Jane Austin novel within two hours. Plus, going up against the predecessor, A&E; version, with Colin Firth and Jennifer Eyle, is suicide. Given the perameters that Keira Knightly had to work within, her performance was marginal at best that only reflected a marginal interpretation on the writer's part.For those who have read the novel or seen any of the preceeding renditions you will know that the Bennett's were not poor in the sense that they lived on a filthy farm and had not a pot to piss in. The Bennett's were lacking in wealth due to having so many daughters,but they were by no means destitute. The writer of this version makes the Bennetts out to be filthy poor by making the family have greasy hair and tatered clothes. The writer again gave no regards to the relationship between each of the family members. How witty Elizabeth was or how much her father doted on her, or how close she was to her older sister, of how the mother favored Lydia most, and how everything vexxed her mother and everything that vexxed her was her husbands fault. Some of the best deliverence comes from the sarcasm that comes from the fathers remarks to the behavior of the younger daughters and that of the mother. These senitments are completely ignored and delivered to the screen, was the exact opposite, a happy loving couple.The next issue was the complete lack of sexual tension between Elizabeth and Darsey. Which in turn takes away from the climax of the film, when he asks her to marry him. If you cannot deliver that part of the story, you have no movie to put on screen.If you want to see a great Jane Austin novel, go to the people that do it the best. Get the A&E; version, take an afternoon and get lost in the world of the Bennett's and old society England. Don't waste your time and money on a half assed interpretation.
summary: The worst rendition of novel ever

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie...Have seen it more times than I can count...Keira Knightley is amazing as per usual...Movie makes you want to fall in love.
summary: You Have Bewitched Me Body and Soul

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of the greatest movies of all times.I could watch it over and over again. Also, great distribution. Love it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I will confess upfront that I am a huge fan of the A&E;/BBC version of P&P.; No production, when compared to that version, will measure up. That having been said, this version is so poorly written and cast that I find it difficult to sit through. After watching the short documentary on the making of the film on the DVD, it is obvious that no one connected with this film did any serious study of Austen or the novel. The director comments on this being about an 18th century family--no, it's early 19th century-- and about how Mr. and Mrs. Bennet loved one another and their daughters so deeply. Again, not really.Keira Knightley is awful in the role of Elizabeth Bennet who was a sophisticated and witty young woman, of scrupulous manners. Knightley's portrayal of a giggly, silly, tempermental girl is absurd.Matthew Macfayden's Darcy is depressed, laconic and stutteringly shy. Austen's Darcy was well-spoken, proud and elegant, not in need of a Prozac.Rather than showing the development of Darcy as a character, he is a mere caricature.The Bennets come across like a 19th century version of the Beverly Hillbillys with a manor house crumbling around their ears, greasy hair, dirty clothes and hogs roaming about the house. Austen would have been agast!If you are an Austen devotee, you will be distressed by this film. So many unpleasant liberties are taken that I cannot begin to enumerate them. The tone and meaning are completely lost.
summary: Hello? Did you even read the book?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of my favorite movies, it came in the package I expected and is a great movie. I am very pleased.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I could watch this movie over and over again. Beautiful soundtrack, beautiful acting, beautiful scenery, beautiful everything!
summary: One of the best period pieces of the century!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although this movie is good as far as it goes, the story has been cut down to fit into a typical 2 hour movie theater time slot. And unfortunately, the story was butchered to do it. The part of George Wickham was almost entirely cut out of this version. He is one of the original central characters not only for the famous elopement but also because he fools Lizzy as to his true character so completely and helps to form her prejudice against Mr. Darcey. We see Wickham maker a couple of brief appearances in this movie and that's it: very disappointing. Go see the BBC version if you want a better version of the story. See this one if you want the Hollywood version!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There are movies girls watch when they are alone in their apartment, just after a break up or a very VERY long day, that they use to not feel so alone, rejected, down in the dumps, what have you. This movie is my movie. I swoon and giggle like a wee school girl during this movie. I cry every time and I love it. I light candles, turn down the lights, set up a plate of my favorite food, some popcorn, and a glass of red wine, and watch Mr. Darcy and Elisabeth fall in the most wonderful love. <3 I giggle at Mr. Bingly's love at first sight for Jane and face palm for the weirdness and creepiness that is Mr. Collins. It just a beautiful movie. The cinematography is breath taking and it sends you to the wonderful place. <3 I adore it. I simply adore it.
summary: This movie is my girly movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The 2006 production of Pride and Prejudice is a work of photographic art. Breathtaking scenery, creative and graceful camera movements, and smooth transitions make this film a visual pleasure. A romantic and sweeping score carries you along through the classic story.The actors in this film, provided that they had a limited amount of time to develop their characters on screen, did a remarkable job, although sometimes some spoke too quickly, almost rushed, as if trying to get it over with. There is, however, a wonderful chemistry between all of them. Two thumbs up for the casting director, as well as the actors themselves.I personally love Jane Austen's classic story, and while I am a huge fan of the BBC version (starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle as Darcy and Elizabeth), I can say that I really do enjoy this new film. It certainly is much shorter and easier to watch in one sitting, although bits of the storyline are lost in the shortness of it.Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone. If you haven't seen it, I recommend renting it, to see if you like it. If you end up liking it as much as I do, you just may end up purchasing it like me, too.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was very disappointed with this movie and surprised by my disappointment. I had been looking forward to a big screen version for a long time.But the screenwriter took too many liberties with her script, adding lines that were both out of character and out of place. There's really no need to embellish when you have a book as good as Pride and Prejudice. The departures from the text not only distracted me, some of them actually made me cringe! "You have bewitched me body and soul," Darcy whispers at one point. It sounds as if the writer is attempting to write like Austen (or any author, for that matter, pre-1900), but she doesn't know how! And it gets even worse when Elizabeth explains to her father (and I'm paraphrasing as I don't plan on watching the film again soon), "We are SO similar! He and I are both stubborn." Clearly, the screenwriter has abandoned all attempts to even sound like Austen. And "goddess divine?" - she cut some of P&P;'s best lines to add THAT!The quality of the acting is okay, but Keira Knightley doesn't exude the grace and wisdom that her predecessors, Jennifer Ehle and Greer Garson, did. She looks lovely but too fierce. I think it may be her jaw. She delivers her lines as if she may bite at any moment. I never envisioned Elizabeth Bennet as an angry sort of girl - spirited, yes, but not spit-in-your-face angry like she is in this movie. I think Rachel Weisz would have made a great Elizabeth (although she might be considered too old for the part - hey, if Emma Thompson can play Elinor Dashwood...)Rosamund Pike, on the other hand, is perfect as Jane - much better than the actress in the A&E; version. Matthew MacFadyen is appropriately swoonworthy with an impressively deep voice (and tall enough, too, as Mr. Darcy should always be). Brenda Blethlyn is good, but I had this strange deja vu watching the film, as if she had played this role before. One more thing: what's up with Bingley's hair? He looked like Conan O'Brien or the villain in The Incredibles and acted like a buffoon. It doesn't make much plot sense b/c he should be worthy of Jane's affection and admiration.For fans of the novel, I can't recommend this film. The filmmakers have played too fast and loose with the details that make Austen distinctly Austen. Instead, check out Sense and Sensibility for how an adaptation should be done.
summary: Main Problems With This Film: Screenplay and Knightley

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Highly Disappointing!!!  Do yourself a favor and save that $20 bill for a lofty purpose.  Don't buy this movie.  You may like this new version "ONLY" if you have not watched the A&E;'s (T.V mini series) of Pride and Prejudice by Simon Langton.I've an ardent admirer of Jane Austen's novels and have watched the mini series and it has been a priceless possession of my video library for years. I fell in love with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, the first time I watched the movie. Watching it, you transcend into the realms of English Aristocracy and get mesmerized by the characters in the movie.... Mrs. Bennet a lovable woman, Mr. Colins, Caroline Bingley and Mr. Wickham. You name it - "ALL" the characters are adorable and the beauty of it is, one tends to identify with the characters.BUT this NEW Pride and Prejudice, starring Knightly is a "SOUR GRAPE"! Immature, Poorly portrayed, Emotional blunder. Does not do justice to the 18th Century England. Characters in the movie are annoying, including - Mr. Darcy, who is expressionless and knows not, how to hold himself! Colin Firth on the other hand was elegant and charming. Elizabeth Bennet (Knightley) has this unwanted, weird smile on her face, at times, that bothers me. Mr. & Mrs. Gardiner are worthless. Mr. Bingley is funny with a horrible hair-do and weak gestures. Basically EVERY single character looks fake. The costumes are no where close to tolerable. There is no bond between sisters in this movie like you could see in the previous Jennifer Ehle version of it.  I could go ON& ON ...Sorry, but I have Nothing good to say, about this remake of Pride and Prejudice!
summary: Totally Vexing : Have mercy on your Poor Nerves  !!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First of all, no film adaptation can ever compare to the book itself. If you enjoyed whichever film version you've seen, including this one, read the book! You'll love it.I have read the book countless times. The 1980 BBC production starring Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul is the most accurate and thorough adaptation in my opinion. I don't care for the newer and more popular 1996 A&E; version because of the MANY liberties it takes, although the visuals are gorgeous. (You can read my comparison review of those two on their product listing pages:Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980)andPride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)).When I saw the preview for this new version, it just looked very "Hollywood-ish" -- over-emotive, mangled dialogue, too sappy and dramatic. And it seemed that Darcy, who is supposed to be handsome on the Adonis level, looked way too plain for the role. But I knew I had to watch it anyway, and I was pleasantly surprised. Although a lot of the book's scenes were left out to fit into the 2-hour time frame, the dialogue and scenes were well-chosen and more faithful to the book than I expected. Despite the shorter length, this newest movie version still captured the spirit of the novel. Each actor did wonderfully in his or her role... including wonderful appearances from Donald Sutherland as the droll yet affectionate Mr. Bennett, and Dame Judi Dench as the odious Lady Catherine De Burgh.My husband who likes to avoid sappy `chick flicks' even walked in the room while I was watching it, and sat down and watched the rest of it with me and really enjoyed it. (He had also enjoyed the 1980 BBC version).My complaints about it are:1) Mr. Bingley's hair looks utterly ridiculous (it's like a furry red dog sitting on top of his head) and I had to laugh every time he appeared on the scene.2) Speaking of hair, many characters did seem undergroomed, with very messy hair, no jewelry and very plain, drab-looking outfits; especially Elizabeth. I hated that brown dress! I guess they had to find a way to make Kiera Knightley seem less pretty than the actress playing Jane, which is certainly difficult since Kiera is considered one of the most beautiful women in the world. Add to that the messy scenes of pigs and farming and laundry hanging out to dry at the Bennett home, the whole family seemed perhaps of a lower class than they actually were... as if the director wanted to 'gritty' them up a bit.3) Mr. Darcy does not acknowledge to Elizabeth how much she helped him change to be more humble and considerate of others. One of the best lines in the book is when he says to her: "... dearest, loveliest Elizabeth! What do I not owe you? You taught me a lesson... by you I was properly humbled." This is an important point, because one foundation of their love is their gratitude to each other for the changes each brought about in the other. In this version, the impression is given that it was only Elizabeth who was ever in the wrong and needing to change.4) Some liberties were of course taken with dialogue and the timing of events, and there were some contrived/invented scenes, including things that were not in the book at all, and things that would not have been appropriate for that time period. (Hollywood has never learned to leave well enough alone.) Examples include: family members hovering over every closed door to hear the conversations therein, and giggling and gawking at the people who had been conversing as they come out of the door; the 'rejected proposal' scene happening outside in the rain and them almost kissing (??!!??) during it; Lady Catherine visiting late at night; the `married' scene at the end; Mr. Bingley appearing in Jane's sickroom; a room of mostly naked statues in the Darcy home instead of the book's wall portraits (guess they had to get SOME sensuality in there somewhere); a sleepless Darcy and Elizabeth meeting up in the fog in the wee morning hours. Some of these were cool things in and of themselves; just not Austen. Bronte, maybe?But for some reason, those discrepancies did not bother me as much as they might have, and I think it is because they were so well offset by the positives of the film that had me really enjoying it and appreciating what I felt it DID pull out of the novel well. I had complaints of a similar nature about the 1995 A&E; version, but there wasn't enough `good' to offset my annoyance at what I considered `bad' in that version, whereas in this version the good outweighed the bad for me by more than enough. I think it's certainly a great introduction for anyone who is new to Austen.I did not think I would say this, but I will definitely buy this movie. It is an obviously romanticized version, but the added romanticism didn't bother me like I thought it would, and I found myself enjoying it.
summary: Greatly exceeded the expectations of this die-hard Austen book fan!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a completely ridiculous retelling of the classic story. Stick with the BBC version; you'll be much happier. Knightly's Elizabeth Bennett is totally unbelievable, and the Darcy is even less so. The shortened version of the story is totally unacceptable!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I already owned this movie and adored it. I ordered another one for my grandmother. I had let her watch mine because I loved it so much and knew she would too. Well she did so I ordered her one for Christmas. I would highly recommend MovieMars to anyone. When I am planning to order a DVD on Amazon I always try to order from them. They are great.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I own the mini-series version of Pride and Prejudice with Colin Firth, which is more true to the book, but I think this is the more entertaining film. Other reviewers have discussed the difference in performances by actors who are closer to the actual ages of the characters in the book and the more realistic setting. One difference between book and movie that I appreciated was the director's take on the relationship between the Bennet parents and his expansion of the minor characters. Here, Mr. Bennet is both exasperated by and in love with Mrs. Bennet; Mr. Collins is as annoying as ever, but we also sympathize with his vulnerability and social awkwardness. Elizabeth's sister Mary is still a preachy bluestocking, but the film doesn't just make fun of her; we also her as the awkward teenage girl who sobs in her father's arms after being embarrassed at the ball. The five girls are very convincing as sisers and their embarassing mama loves them dearly. Bingley is as shy as Jane and here we see Darcy helping him rehearse his marriage proposal to her. Darcy and Elizabeth seem a little more raw and REAL here. The director has really gotten at the humanity of all of the characters here in a way that adds a lot to the film. That, and it's not six hours long, which should appeal to anyone who doesn't have the patience to sit through the mini-series.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a great love story ...great acting that does the classic novel some justice! I definitely recommend!!! If you haven't seen this movie... you are missing out!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I don't know if I'll every truly know why, but I absolutely LOVE this movie.It's not as brilliant as `Sense and Sensibility' (mostly because it lacks the splendor that is Kate Winslet) but `Pride and Prejudice' is a perfect family film that builds off its subject to create a beautifully crafted masterpiece.  The performances match the surroundings and the direction by newcomer Joe Wright is astoundingly accurate and beautiful to look at.  Keira Knightley rightfully earned that Oscar nomination, for her portrayal of Elizabeth Bennet is the best by far of anyone attempting at the coveted role.  The fact remains that `Pride and Prejudice' has been done and redone and supposedly mastered by BBC (and Colin Firth) in 1995.  While that is the case this beautiful reimagining of the classic Austen novel is, in my humble opinion, the best film adaptation, by far.The film, aside from being splendidly acted, is above and beyond a beauty to look at.  Each frame is astounding in its visual flare.  The camera pans out over the surroundings with beautiful precision.  Just watch the fog scene with Darcy and know that a picture speaks a thousand words.  It's graceful and mesmerizing.The film follows the love affair (or lack there of) between Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy, a pair made in Hollywood heaven.  She's strong-willed and opinionated as is he and they seem to butt-heads more than steal hearts but in the end there is no denying they are perfect for one another.  What makes this movie so brilliant is that it is in affect the catalysts for almost every other love story out there for these two characters seem to pop up in almost every teen film produced as of late.  These are the originals though, and with splendid performances by Knightley and Macfadyen are so effortless and uplifting in their impish immaturity that they breathe a whole new life to the classic tale.The supporting cast all hold their weight as well, especially the likes of Donald Sutherland who is perfectly cast as Elizabeth's father and Brenda Blethyn who plays her mother, but it's Dame Judi Dench who stole the show for me with her few moments of screen time.  She plays Lady Catherine de Bourg with such ferocity that her confrontation with Elizabeth was the highlight of the film for me.In the end I can only say good things for this film for I cannot find a single flaw.  Watching Keira chew up the scenery is orgasmic for me, especially when you think that this is the same girl who fights pirates and hunts criminals.  Under that action hero exterior is a giggly teenage girl who becomes so real to her audience that you can't help but fall madly in love with her.  `Pride and Prejudice' is a wonder of a film, a beautifully magnificent cinematic experience that brings nothing but joy and warmth to my heart.So I guess I do know why I love this film after all...go figure.
summary: Beautiful, mesmerizing and, simply put, utter perfection...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The film arrived quickly and was just as advertised. The movie is lovely and it is good to have it in multiple formats!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you rent this movie for the car chases, you will be very disappointed...there are none.Besides that point, there were several things I didn't like. For one, the special effects were terrible. The CG teacups looked COMPLETELY fake. Also, I couldn't understand a word that was said, as it was all spoken very quickly, in whispers and in heavy accents. The dance numbers were terribly choreographed, and frankly unimpressive. They looked nothing like the dancing in "Step Up"The only thing I liked was Darcy. The actor who played him was marvelous, conveying all the emotions you could think of in both his voice, and his expression.Another bad thing is the plot. It didn't even make sense. It's no wonder the author who wrote the book isn't well known or anything...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have only read the book one time, after getting completely hooked on the 1995 A&E; version of Pride and Prejudice and watching it about six times this year alone, so I am probably not the most qualified person to write my objections to the 2005 piece of filth, but after reading what everyone else had to say, I could not keep silent either. Here are my objections as follows:1. Kiera Knightley- Hollywood clearly cannot tell the difference between a great actress better suited to the role of the intelligent Elizabeth Bennett (as in, almost anybody but K.K.) and a walking, talking, beanpole who claims to have read the book, but I don't think she did because if she had she would not have fudged this role up so badly with all the excessive giggling, outspokenness to her parents that was more or less non-existant during that time period, and for goodness sakes, somebody tell her to please close her mouth. Sexiness is appropriate in modern-day romantic comedies, but NOT in period pieces such as this one, or at least not the kind K.K. displayed. A woman from that time certainly did not run around outside with her hair down, or in her nightgown, and they almost never went outside without a hat or bonnet of some sort, which, I can't recall seeing K.K. wearing one, even after forcing myself to watch this film three times. Also, somebody please tell that girl to eat once in a while! I find it hard to believe that somebody from that time period, who did no housework and clearly had time to kill by making the audience sick by spinning on a swing, could be that skinny, when a typical daily diet from back then included a great consumption of whole milk, cheese, butter, bread, and eggs. Fattening fare that would have made a person look at least healthy, not like somebody who had not even seen puberty. Kiera Knightley was totally wrong for that role, having too modern of a face, and too thin a figure. I'm sorry Kiera, but you should stick with modern flicks. As a final irritation on this subject, I might add that she rattled her lines off so fast in some scenes that I hardly knew what she said, which is pretty sad for a person like me who is more than familiar with the dialogue. I believe that in a film with language that is as old as this, the lines should be spoken more slowly, to give our modern minds time to translate and understand what was said.2. Fitzwilliam Darcy- I felt absolutely nothing for this film's portrayal of the character whatsoever. There was nothing in him that made him the least bit likeable or desireable, and that haunted look that was constantly plastered to his face just depressed me.3. Charlotte Lucas- '"Don't judge me, Lizzy!"' Pul-eeeze. The film portrayed Charlotte's acceptance of Mr. Collins as being that she was unhappy to be marrying him, like she was trapped. In the book, she was actually in persuit of a comfortable home, and wasted no time in securing Mr. Collins for herself, even though he was not necessarily her first choice. But being older than the typical marrying age back then, beggars cannot be choosers, as the saying goes, and she may have become one eventually had she remained a spinster.4. The Costumes- I thought they were completely inaccurate for the time period, and terribly boring and colorless, especially the one Knightley wore in her first scene. Yuck, and I don't know what was up with her hair, but it just did not go with her modern-looking face. Speaking of hair, I didn't know that Marie Antoinette was cast to play Lady Catherine de Burgh. And could anybody honestly tell Lydia and Kitty apart with their identical pigtail/ringlet combinations?I honestly do not know how in the world this movie received four stars from the critics, who quite obviously have never read this book. I am sorry for the hordes of disappointed fans out there who were expecting something great (as I did), only to get spoon-fed this '"barely tolerable"' adaptation, only to choke on it after the credits rolled. Congratulations Hollywood, on ruining yet another (what could have been a) great film (just like Eragon got ruined) by attempting to 'modernize' it and change it to what you think the audience would want. Well, if it isn't broken, don't fix it! This is one of those stories in which everything was perfectly fine just the way it was. But (surprise!) some idiot out there had to open their mouth and suggest 'changes.' Well, would it be too much of a 'change' to get it right? If you are watching Pride and Prejudice for the first time, watch the A&E; Firth and Ehle version. I haven't seen the one that was made in the 1980's yet, but I am willing to bet that it totally blows away the 2005 version.Anecdote: I eventually did view the 1980's version of Pride and Prejudice, and it WAS way better than the 2005 version! Still not as good as the 1995 one, but still worth seeing and better represented.
summary: It was UNtolerable, I suppose: not handsome enough to tempt me!

title: Pride & Prejudice
