title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just watched this for the millionth time, and I loved it all over again. The cinematography is fantastic and artfully done. The classical music score is so soothing and perfectly suits the story. The whole movie gives you a sense of life with the Bennets that is so real. They are a family whose quirks and charms are immediately evident, and you fall in love with them all. I like that the Bennetts house is so well lived-in and even a little dirty looking. There is a lovely contrast between their poorer household to the richer settings of Mr. Bingley's temporary residence and especially Mr. Darcy's home at Pemberly.Keira Knightley is such a wonderful Elizabeth Bennett. She is natural and witty and somewhat angelic, but she's still a little rough around the egdes and down to earth. I like how she seems silly at times but still knows how to conduct herself properly without coming off as a snob. She's confident but still maintains an innocent quality.Matthew Macfadyen is the hottest Darcy to walk the planet, in my opinion. At first, I wasn't sure about him, because he looked so much like a sourpuss when he made his entrance to the film, but, as his character transforms, he becomes more handsome and eventually just completely sexy - this is where I can see why Jane Austen first titled the book First Impressions. If that title had stuck, it would certainly still work for this story. All the little nuances of Darcy's - the stolen glances, the tension in his hands, etc. - were all captured perfectly on camera and really brought his secret longing for Elizabeth into focus for the audience.I have to add that there were moments when I wanted to jump through the screen and bite Darcy's bottom lip. For example, the rainy day scene was so intense...if I were Elizabeth, I'd be tempted to just say screw pride, I'm yours! And she almost looks like she will. But seriously...Matthew Macfadyen is exactly how I would want my own Darcy to be. The scene where he walks through the dew-covered field at dawn in his flowing coat and his boots and high-waisted pants, YUM! I'm so glad they kept that shot in real time so the audience can watch every single sway of his hips. Wow. Oh, and this is my favorite line of his, "You have bewitched me, body and soul." Who talks like that anymore?! I love it!I like the BBC version...Colin Firth is such an awesome, sexy Darcy, too, and now we have this modern, more sexually tense P&P.; Wow, two great P&P; versions, Austen fans should rejoice about that!
summary: Amazing...and another hot Darcy! Yes, please!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: That is, after seeing this version, no other can hold up.  Yes it is not as detailed as some longer movies and there are a few changes, but I don't believe they are anything that take away from the story, but rather the setting and terrific - perfectly chosen actors blow everything else away.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was shocked at the 3.5 cumulative rating here, but realized even after a quick glance that there's a rather understandable division between the BBC watchers and those who loved this later film.  However, it's really not necessary.But why choose?  Sure, they took liberties with this adaptation, but to me that makes sense -- it was the only direction to go after the definitive "traditional" rendition with the gorgeous BBC miniseries.  They did it all beautifully in that one.The 2005 version, it's grittier, faster, a little more brutal and sad too. I personally loved it -- it's fresh and fast and a new and lovely view of the story.  It's surprisingly swift-moving, very energetic, and a gorgeously made movie.  The acting is superb and the writing is great. It is not paced at all the way you expect these things, and I love the fact that (thanks to a few liberties with the book's time period) it looks and feels somehow very vibrant and real and just a little grungy.  The homes, the clothes, everything looks so real and lived-in (not frilly and clean and perfect the way these things usually are).  Even the dashing hero, who is quite hot, has terrible hair. And Kiera Knightley, who is not always a favorite of mine, is lovely and wonderful here. In this role, it's believable that (as beautiful as she is) that she is not fashionably beautiful or even noticeable, that her smarts and vivacity would be off-putting.  She is absolutely wonderful here, as is the entire cast (and Donald Sutherland is smashing in a scene very late in the movie as well).And yes, I still love Colin Firth.  But newcomers will find this Darcy terrific as well, in spite of his bad hair. ;-)
summary: Superb (3.5 Cumulative Rating is Way too Low...), Even for Firth Lovers

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The first time I watched this movie I compared it to the BBC mini-series with Colin Firth, the ultimate Darcy. Firth is a  handsome man even without saying a word.  Matthew MacSpayden looks like a normal person who could use a haircut.  Then I started googling and reading interviews with the actors and directors and came to an appreciation of this work.  Matthew MacSpayden had not read P&P or seen the BBC version before he played the role.  His Darcy isn't as arrogant as Firth's although he is still proud and prejudiced!  Keira Knightley does a wonderful job.  Her Lizzy is full of energy and life!  The story is not followed EXACTLY as the book was written but I found the differences acceptable and reasonable.  The ending is a little weird---it was written for the American audience apparently.  The directing is fast-paced and dramatic (they had to squeeze the whole thing into 2 hours, unlike the 6 hour mini-series) and I love the music.  Several scenes weren't even planned, they just came about---the solo ballroom scene and the proposal-practicing scene with Darcy and Bingley.  And the sculpture gallery at Pemberley, especially the veiled woman, was amazing.
summary: Just as good as the Firth version but in a different way

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I find that I was quite mistaken in my first impression of the new (now out on DVD) P & P movie with Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen. When I saw it in the theatre I was distressed by what I then considered the squalidness of the Bennet household. After viewing the Keira Knightley/Matthew Macfadyen DVD version a number of times, my opinion now is quite the opposite from my first impression. My delight in this movie comes from the complex and complete portrayal of the Bennet family; and after all, that entire family is the protagonist in the Austen novel. Austen created a love story about Lizzie and Darcy, but she also beautifully creates for us the texture of real 19th century country life as lived by the Bennet family. While I have loved the A & E version for many years, I must admit that I have always been a little perplexed by it because I do not think that the A & E version portrays so great a difference between the Bennet and Darcy circumstances as to cause the least amount of doubt in Darcy's mind about whether he should marry Lizzie. This new version puts it out there, unmistakably. It definitively and masterfully portrays the differences between town and country life, so skillfully written about by Jane Austen. Bravo!
summary: My feelings are quite the opposite!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Except for the ending, I have few problems with the adaptaiton. Even these issues were slight, falling under the "not how I would have done it" category rather than the "what were they thinking?" heading. But then, a faithful translation would run far too long for a feature film (c.f. the A&E version, which runs to six hours). And in spite of the absence of Colin Firth, it was well-acted -- Keira Knightly's Elizabeth in particular. My only real issue with this adaptation, and the only thing in the way of a fourth star, is the complete elimination of Jane Austen's original ending in favor of one that is overly Hollywoodized.
summary: Good, but could have been better

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off, I'm a BIG fan of Colin Firth, and I've loved the BBC miniseries for many years.But.I think that Matthew Macfayden is, honestly, the best Darcy. Hands down.  Kiera Knightley did a great job (I wish she hadn't been quite so belligerent at the end of his first proposal), and the liveliness and sparkle to this version really outshines all others.  It reminds me of Kenneth Branaugh's Shakespeare works . . . which I have long loved.  People are people are people . . . have been, and always will be . . . and I loved how this version really allowed us to see what the characters felt.  One of my favorite things about this version is seeing how startled Darcy is by his attraction to Elisabeth; and how he struggles against it, but can't keep himself from doing small things like taking her hand as she steps into the carriage when leaving Bingley's.  Elisabeth, shocked, looks down, and we see his hand grasping hers for a second . . . and then him stretching and closing his fist as he walks away, his hand full of electricity from her touch.  I mean, really . . . it's superb.  And the way Macfayden's face opens and turns so tender and vulnerable when he speaks to Elizabeth simply melts you.  He goes so well from icy pride to elecctrified yearning.  I really wish that this version predated the BBC series, as some of the elements here would have really improved the other.  (I think it would have a feel more like the BBC Emma series, which is next on my list.)The director did a masterful job of filling nearly every minute of this film (which I wish was four hours long!) with so many things that let us into the whole story, instead of seeing it from the outside.  You feel the exuberance and love and annoyance that accompanies a household of five girls, and I dearly, dearly love Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett.Hate this version as you may, but I love it tremendously!Now, if there was only a director's cut edition . . . if anyone is listening, please make one!
summary: Wonderful addition to Pride & Prejudice Tradition.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've watched the Sir Lawrence Olivier version, 1980 BBC miniseries, the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle and then this version.  The Firth/Ehle adaptation is the most faithful to the book in terms of preserving events and accuracy with the times but even then, scenes and characters were cut.  Adaptation is just that an adaptation otherwise for heaven sake's read the novel.  In an adaptation, the idea is to capture the essence of what Austen presents.  I feel this version fails on many accounts.  P&P is a romance.  In this movie, there is absolutely no chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy.  You can't root for them to get together because you wonder why they would want to be together at all.  P&P is also a comedy of manners.  Austen was the master of social satire.  In P&P, she critiques the aristocracy, the church, the army, the intelligentia and the frivolous with dry wit.  I saw very little of that in the movie. When you do a period movie, you have to get the feeling that you've gone away from the here and now and to another place.  The language is too modern such that when the actors utter a real line straight out of the novel, it seems very jarring.  It's ashame really because you have excellent actors like Brenda Blethyn(Mrs. Bennet), Tom Hollander(Mr. Collins), Penelope Wilton(Mrs. Gardiner)and Claudie Blakely(Charlotte Lucas).  The script and the direction are just subpar.  Many events occur in P&P but the book spans a year in the life of the Bennets.  All the events are smashed up next to one another.  You have no sense at all that the passage of time has occured.  You would think the story happened within two months.  I give this movie two stars because there were some good attempts to make this movie interesting.  Village life is not glamorous or clean.  The ages of the Bennet daughters are the most accurate with regard to faithfulness to the book.  Jenna Malone's performance as Lydia Bennet is lively and fun.  The sets and costume design were very good however the wind-blown hair on everyone was a bit too much for me.  In the end, all could have been forgiven for this movie if there had been excellent performances from the actors who played Lizzie and Darcy but they were hemmed in by a pedestrian script and mediocre direction.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I had never read the book and did not know anything about the story.  This was a completely haunting, intense love story.  Keira Knightly and Mathew MacFayden were superb as Elizabeth Bennett and Mr. Darcy.  The musical score was so rich and beautiful.  I have watched this movie once or twice a week since I got it on DVD.  The cinematography was gorgeous.  The whole movie was so well cast. I have always loved beautiful period-piece love stories.  I was delightfully haunted by this beautifully done love story.  I highly recommend this movie.  Even my husband liked it!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My husband and I love the Firth movie and just about every Austen film we've seen. Sadly, we found this remake a vulgar version of a truly gracious story.The earthy, lust-filled movie left no reason for the bland, distant, dull father to even own the dusty books in his hovel library. There was no reason for this Darcy to choose THIS Elizabeth - no reason at all.This movie was emptied - stripped - of all we love about Austen. Austen without the winsomeness of intellect; Austen without wisdom and compassion of good, ennobling character; Austen without highly refined interpersonal drama; Austen without the loveliness and intricacies we've grown to expect. Finally we laughed and laughed: this was Austen without Austen!We would not recommend this to anyone. Save your money. Use your time for better things.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While Kira Knightly exceaded my expectations, the film was, to its core, unfaithful to the victorian society that Jane Auston wrote about and critiqued. Jane Austen, i would argue, did not write romance novels so much as commentaries on the world around her. This film was not at all faithful to that society. A young woman would NEVER go about in the dark in her night gown and coat. She would NEVER kiss a man before they were married. Yes she was an upstart and a spit fire... but these basic diversions from societal norms were not Elizabeths... they were a product of modern romantic folly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Item arrived on time and in great condition!I will use this company again for future purchases of dvds or other movies.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Austen and have read the book and seen the BBC adaptation more than once. Since this movie is so much shorter, I knew there would be compromises, but I had still hoped that the film would bring Austen's loving, amused, witty and razor sharp view of the British society in the late 1700's across. The book is not just about two people who go through personal changes and external adversities to find each other in the end. Their romance is a case in point of the silliness, pretentiousness, the pride and the class-orientation of those times and how its inhabitants struggle with or submit to it.This film is a rounded romance that the American audience will love, fast-paced, with strong characters and a satisfying plot, dialog and ending - I appreciate it for that. Compared to the BBC version it also brought welcome realism and grit to the imagery with plainer costumes, dustier scenery and sweatier faces. But to be called an Austen adaptation I would have needed the characters to be much truer to Austen's originals:Lizzy is fun-loving, caring, witty and confident. But society calls for gentle females that know and appreciate their station - which of course is below that of men. Lizzy knows that and keeps her intellect hidden, bowing to society's  expectations and revealing her insights only to Jane or her father, not to the public. Knightley's version of Lizzy is still a delightful individual, but too self-assured, candid and rebellious.Jane, according to Austen is very sweet and good-natured, always trying to believe the best of people. She is also very delicate and coy, keeping her public dialog completely innocuous and her eyes mostly downcast.  Rosamund Pike makes Jane by far too confident and strong. Her deep suffering from Bingley's supposed rejection doesn't come across at all.Mr. Bennet's chief entertainment is his private amusement with his' wife's and his three younger daughter's silly preoccupation with men, fashion and gossip  plus his delight in his two older daughter's beauty and sense. He is truly funny, but that is appreciated only by Lizzy and Jane, the rest of the family either doesn't catch his quips or misinterprets them. Donald Sutherland only gets to play a kind but boring head of family, resigned to his life in an all-female household.The BBC version of Mr. Collins is wonderfully oily.  His stilted but eloquent dialog, his complete acceptance of the rules of societal ranks (total submission to Lady de Bourg and belief in superiority over the Bennets) are satisfyingly repulsive. Tom Hollander's version is only that of an ignorant idiot.I love Judy Dench as an actor, but here she is too regal, too charismatic. Austin gives Lady Catherine de Bourg superiority only through her riches, position and through a strong enough  intellect and inbred confidence to manipulate everyone around her. Austin makes her meddling and truly undeserving of the reverence offered her, especially by Collins.Finally Darcy. According to Austen he is smart, brooding, very proud but caring and generous. He is genuinely struggling with his own affection for Lizzy. His sense of propriety doesn't allow this connection especially in light of the disastrous impressions he gets from the rest of the Bennets. But his emotions are too strong to ignore. Colin Firth brought Darcy's contradicting feelings brilliantly to life in the BBC production, particularly in the key scene where he proposes and Lizzy rejects him. He is uncharacteristically nervous and fidgeting; he is hopeful, and vulnerable but also angry and confused. Matthew Macfadyen doesn't bring more than the anxiety that would be part of any marriage proposal - none of the underlying battle shows. The rest of the film doesn't see many emotions from Darcy beyond superiority and boredom - way too flat for what Austin had in mind.In summary, if you expect a delightful romance, you'll be satisfied, if you want Jane Austen's vivid and multi-layered  characters, social insights and scathing dialogs, you'll be disappointed.
summary: A fine romance, but not an 'Austen adaptation'

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen and she knows how to make a point.......I watch this movie over and.  over again ..

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I heard that Pride and Prejudice was going to be made into a big screen production, I'll admit to having my doubts. After all, Hollywood and all its international affiliates have a notorious record of dumbing down everything they can get their little gold lam? hands on. But I never expected it to be quite as bad as this. Watching as both a theatre and historical preservation student, this movie had several deep flaws which kept it from being enjoyable.The film had four major problems in terms of theater: filmography, characterization, script and level of acting ability. The editing was just plain sloppy. This can be forgiven in a low budget film, but not one with so many famous names and so much funding as this film.And even the poor editing could be forgiven, had it not interfered with the characterization. As beautiful as the countryside may be, by the fifth-hundred shot of it, I am no longer enthralled. How about showing some character interaction that could further the plot, instead of Elizabeth merrily traipsing across a field? Truth be told, there seemed to be no time allotted to characterization in the absence of fields and the trotting over of.The plot moved along but the basic motivations of the characters were never understood. It seems that Lizzy abhors Darcy and then WHAM! THEY'RE IN LOVE! WHAM! THEY'RE SNOGGING! WHAM! THEY'RE MARRIED! WHAM! ROLL CREDITS! In the aftermath, you're still wondering why, how and when exactly she fell in love with him. I had a friend watch this with me, who had never read the book. At the end of the film, she turned to me and said, "Wait, so Lizzy married Darcy because he was rich?" And I really can't blame her, there was really no other indication as to why she suddenly became enamored of him.I come now to the most painful subject of this movie: the acting. Keira Knightley has one, and one role that she always MUST play in order to make her acting believable, Keira Knightley. In all her films she has played the in-your-face-fear-me-I'm-a-spunky-British-chick-rara feminism girl and it works for her in those other movies, because that is who she had to play. Here it does not work. While vivacious, certainly, she does not play the part of the witty "connoisseur of human folly" that is Lizzy Bennett. She does not have the depth or the grounding to do so. Her solution for difficult scenes is to put extra energy into her words. So Lizzy's confrontation with Darcy, instead a meeting of  tension filled, barely-civil clash between two headstrong individuals bent on their own way, becomes a pedantic shouting match between two children. Honestly, I was waiting for a "I know you are, but what am I?" to be thrown in there at any moment. This does not bode well, for Lizzy carries the entire plot.Matthew MacFadyen does a solid, though not spectacular, job as Darcy. He is able to convey both of Darcy's sides, however, his transition between them is often clumsy. The tension between Darcy and Lizzy is practically non-existent, and when it does manage to rear its head, it feels awakward and very formulated. Even wonderful actors such as Donald Sutherland and Dame Judi Dench do not act to the best of their abilitiesThen again, how could they pull off a stellar with the script they were given? The writers appeared the think it necessary to exclude some of Jane Austen's most famous lines (e.g. "fine eyes," "You must allow me to tell you how much I ardently love and admire you") for their own. The language is very modern and often very corny. The end scene is almost embarrassing to watch, I actually felt bad for the actors having to spew that nonsense(Then I remembered what they were being paid TO say that). When they attempt Regency-era speech is laughable at best, painful at worst.The historical inaccuracies are glaringly bad and almost. For one, the clothing. While sleeveless gowns were all the rage during the Regency period, wearing something that very much resembles a slip was not. Caroline Bingley would most likely be banished from good society forever if she chose to wear the dress, if it may be called that, at the Meryton Assembly.The Bennet girls always appeared much too ragged for Regency middle-class women. This is not the 21st century where you roll out of bed, take a quick shower and rush out. No, a girl had at least one maid working on her appearance for at least an hour and a half every morning.Then again, the directors would have you believe that the Bennets are the 19th century equivalent of the Jodes. They are not so. Mr. Bennet is a middle-class gentleman farmer with an estate, which means he is not badly off. His main problem lies that with five daughter, he cannot generate a large dowry for any of them. Not the wealthiest of people, but the Bennets would not have a pig wandering through their house.Meanwhile, Darcy is apparently managed to secure the dukedom of Derbyshire for himself and issued some marble statues. WHEN A PORTRAIT WOULD HAVE BEEN FINE! Completely unnecessary.As a Jane-Austen adaption it is entirely off. It has none of Austen's charm and wit. In fact, it completely loses the satirical edge which Austen included in all her novels. It degrades into something dangerously resembling a Barbara Cartland-style bodice ripper novel than a Jane Austen.So, as a movie,  it's alright for a rainy day or when one is in desperate need for a chick flick. As an adaption of what is considered one of the most important novels in the history of female literature, do not get your hopes to high. If you're watching this to avoid reading the novel for a lit. class assignment, may I recommend the Wishbone version?
summary: I'd watch the Wishbone version, if I were you.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love this book and the movie. I think this 2005 version of the movie was very well done and would recommend it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The best ever film i ever watched, I've watched it like hundred times and counting!...Keira is amazing in this movie, every characters are wonderfullyacted! I will recommend this to anybody!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have not seen the A&E; version of P and P, but I have read the book, and I love the book!  That being said, I know that some things have to be changed or rearranged, but for me this missed the special feel, the spirit, if you will, of the book.I didn't care for most of the casting choices, but I'm not sure if that dislike was added to by the poor script.  The lead, Knightly, seemed very shallow and as others have said, did a lot of grinning and snarling.  I found it very distracting, almost like she was trying too hard.  She was also making googly eyes at Darcy very early on.  This was an odd choice.  Part of the point of the whole thing was her dislike, almost disgust really, for Darcy.  I'm not sure what they were trying to do with making her eyeing him like that.  I never got the idea she disliked him, so that was a big failing.  She wasn't really much different than her younger sisters.  Her character was the most disappointing for me.  Caroline Bingley was uninspired, and looked like she was wearing her undies or a nightgown during the ball.  Bingley was just silly, Darcy was just boring, and Collins wasn't really that bad and not nearly as irritating as he should be.  The characters in the book are quirky and wonderful, all with depth and layers totally overlooked for this movie.I won't mention some of the other things people have complained about, though I do agree with some of them.  The biggest problem I have with this movie, not even considering the above, it that it bored me.  It was all I could do to sit and watch it.  It was very dull.  That is why I can't understand why they changed so much.  Thankfully I had snacks to occupy me or I would have just turned it off.  I didn't see any magic in it, nothing that made my heart flutter.  I guess I will try the A&E; version and hope that it is better.  Thankfully I got this from the library, so I am not out anything.  I am going to buy one when I find one I enjoy, and I hope I do.
summary: Boring, and for me missed the "spirit" of Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love this movie.  Great artistry.  The actors are wonderful.  The characters are endearing.  One to watch over and over again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really enjoyed this movie. From the acting, to the clothing to the scenery all was done well. This movie respects the book quite well.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I found this adaptation to race along from beginning to end, and in the process I believe it sacraficed some much-needed build-up that we find in the BBC/A&E version. We don't get a sense of the time that has passed during which characters are ruminating on what is happening and their feelings about it. We just get scene by scene thrown at us and we are expected to be carried along and believe it. The cinematography is excellent in many parts. The acting is good, but Keira Knightly always has that smirk on her face and after awhile I wonder why it is there so much. Although she holds her own, I was not always drawn in to her performance...or I was drawn in but wasn't sure what I found there. This definitely had a more romantic and sensual feel that other versions have not. I do wish there had been more build-up of the relationship between Elizabeth and Darcy that would make their falling in love more believable. I always feel that on Darcy's part there is not enough conveyance of what he is attracted to when he is attracted to justify the passion in the end. I did find Mrs. Bennet to be far less shrill and irritating than in other adaptations which was a big plus. I also liked the character of Charlotte here very well. All of the laughing and giggling at the Bennet house was a bit over the top.
summary: Fast but still hits the spot

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Very disappointed this will not play in dvd. A different type of player is required. This was a waste of time and money.
summary: Need to warn will not play in dvd

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie does not stick perfectly to the book. It is more like Pride and Prejudice as our imagination might see if someone was telling it to us. Or like the scenes we've all changed in our minds eye to how we would like them to look, or scenes we've added. Many things are changed slightly. Characters personalities, with the exception of Lizzie and Darcy, are more what you would expect to find in real life. Mrs. Bennet claims more of our sympthy. Mr. Bennet seems more of an eccentric old man who loves his family but greatly values peace. Everyone else does not seems so whole bad or good, and I've never felt so bad for Darcy from the book or any movie.It's a short. Only two hours and nine minutes. It seems a little rushed at first, but everytime you watch it seems less so. It only gets four star because of this. The time also made it hard for the characters to really be delved into, but still very nice movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've watched this movie three times. I've read the novel twice and seen the A&E; version (which this film is unfairly compared with). Therefore I am fully aware of the story and characters and all that diddle-dee-do. So I guess I can be considered informed of the material and what it is about.Now I should mention to people who have this idea that movies based on books should remain faithful to the point of thinking the source as sacred text: the screenwriter did take liberties with the story. A leap in time here. A missing episode there. A sudden visit here. And a hussy fit there.But it is an "adaptation" and not a "translation" of the original novel by dear Miss Austen. The changes are not drastically uncalled for. They are actually refreshing. As is the mood that the director (Wright) set for the film. The film moves at a swift pace but the mood is always down-to-earth and emotionally focused. Normally when people do Austen adaptations they have this image of the whole movie being focused around drawing rooms with the etiquettes associated with the Regency period. They put so much emphasis into the details of the setting and situations that they neglect the characters humanity and hope that the actors are up to code. This version actually looked at the material in the opposite direction and focused more on the main characters (especially Elizabeth or "Lizzy" as she is well known).Oh well I must talk about the acting. It was good.For more info notice the academy award nomination Keira Knightley received for her portrayal of Lizzy. Even though the Academy Awards relativity to cinematic excellence has lessened, please be assured that the notice placed towards Ms. Knightley's performance was well deserved. The whole cast was pretty good with the other standout being Donald Sutherland. But if I must say something more about Ms. Knightley, it is that she fitted who Elizabeth was as a young opinionated woman. She plays Lizzy with the conviction that I felt was missing in other P&P; adaptations. It one thing to say the lines, it's another to say the lines like it's something you would actually say.This movie puts the "passion" aspect into the romance of Austen's creation. A true Romantic (of the literary kind) would think of this adaptation as a triumph. And if dear Miss Austen were alive she would probably giggle (of the hushed kind) with delight at the unabashed joy this movies gives in spades.Well RecommendedNote: For the strict Austen fans who believe that Austen would spin in her grave at the supposed blasphemy of the movie, I will say this. You forget that Miss Austen (the writer of gothic-satire Northanger Abbey) probably did not think so much of herself that she wouldn't have wanted other people to look at her work in different ways. Stop being narrow-minded. Miss Austen wasn't! Now enjoy the movie.(Off the soap box)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: English and pastoral... Countryside was captured with extreme authenticity and delicacy!I was stuned by this wonderful adaption of the Jane Austen novel. With a spontaneous direction from Joe Wright, Pride & Prejudice leaves you happy!Keira Knightley and Donald Sutherland are wonderfully casted for this brilliant romance. Also Brenda Blethyn and Judi Dench portrayed extremelly well their charachters. Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy and Jena Malone as Lydia, Elizabeth's younger sister, are also good. I must say that they all portrayed their charachters with gusto!Dario Marianelli creates a wonderful score wich fits with the rural England scenario. I think - that is my opinion - Dario found a great inspiration on the famous Virginia Astley's 'From Gardens Where We Feel Secure' CD. It evokes the England countryside easily.I have my DVD copy now and if you like a great romance please add this new one.With my eyes wide open I'm dreaming...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A beautifully made film. Transports the viewer to another time and place. Passionate and delightful performances by all the actors.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It would have been nice to have been able to give this half a star becasue that is about all this movie deserves and that was for a scene and a half: the proposal in the rain - the rain was a nice touch, and the last tender scene between husband and wife.A worse adaptation could not have been made.  By the time they reached the first ball - 5 minutes into the movie, I was sick.Keira Knightly as Elizabeth. She made Elizabeth into a giggly, silly girl who Darcy would never have fallen in love with.  All the gilrs looked greasy, unkempt, and illiterate.  i cannot believe the behavior.  Particularly when Elizabeth comes to Netherfield after hearing that Jane is sick, she just walks in the door, looks at everyone and then walks out like a petulant child.  Elizabeth Bennet would never have behaved like that, maybe Lydia.Matthew Macfayden as Darcy.  Well at least he looks the part better than Colin Firth did seeing as how Darcy was only 26.The dialogue and the story is stilted because its been chopped up. Unless you've read the book you won't know what they're talking about half the time. They talk about Darcy breaking up Jane and Bingley and yet all they show is the two of them dancing once, never more.And Wickham?  you never truly get the essence of his evil.I have to say Donald Sutherland as a loving husband to Mrs Bennet, just turned my stomach.  Where was the sarcasm, where was the dry wit, where was the disdain?I have seen Brenda Blethyn in many movies and she is just way too nice to be Mrs Bennet.Georgiana Darcy is so forward. In the book, she is so shy she can barely say two words together.All the girls are way too thin.  That style of dress was designed to show off your bosom. Keira Knightley has the chest of a 12 year old and the dress does not help one bit.  you could see that none of the girls were wearing corsets.  It would have helped.Don't waste a penny to see this movie.  if you get to see it free, go for it.  At least you'll have a good time seeing all the things that were done wrong.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie makes my wife cry everytime and any serious movie critic can enjoy the scenery, cinematography, and music.  This was a gift for my mother.  She loves it and she cries also.  One of the better movies I've seen in awhile.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I first heard there was going to be another version, my first thoughts were that nothing could top the BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle!  Especially since that one was 5 hrs., and followed the book to the tee!Well, of course the new one was cut down to a measly 2 hrs.!!  Because of the time constraint- they had to rush the story along, almost at a fast-forward pace (or as someone aptly put it: "didn't allow the story to breathe").  Surprisingly, I didn't find it that big of an issue.There were a few notable changes however... *SPOILER* First, the part where Mr. Darcy first proclaims his love to Elizabeth is a bit different than it was in the book (the setting that is).  Second, the confrontation between Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lizzy is customized (for the sake of time).  Also, (towards the end) the part where Elizabeth confesses her changed feelings towards Mr. Darcy is different than in the book; and the end was also tweaked a bit.Despite these changes, I think the original story was still able to shine through!For the most part I was pleased with their choice of actors.  Dame Judi Dench was a perfect Lady Catherine; and I really enjoyed Rosamond Pike (as Jane), possibly even more-so than the actress in the '95 version.  Mr. Bingly, a tad naive and silly at times is nonetheless endearing!However, Keira Knightley just isn't selling Elizabeth for me (as Jennifer Ehle did).  I don't sense much emotional depth, or connection in and to her character.  KK's roles- at least the ones I've seen her in- all seem to blend together.As for Matthew Macfadyen, my only experience of him prior to this, was a smaller role in the miniseries based on Anthony Trollope's "The Way We Live Now".Instead of coming off quite as cold and haughty as CF's Darcy; Matthew's portrayal gave a somewhat new dimension to this enigmatic character!  He really did a fine job in showcasing the more introverted/introspective side of Fitzwilliam (possibly an INTJ temperament). And truth be told, it was a little too easy to get lost in his "fine eyes"!  Needless to say, he is now my second favorite "Mr. Darcy"!  (If you haven't already, check him out in the latest BBC adaptation of Charles Dickens "Little Dorrit" - he's absolutely brilliant in his role as "Arthur Clennam"!)All in all it's a good movie- especially for those who don't have the patience to sit through the 5 hr. one.I'm also really pleased with the "special edition"!  While there's not a whole lot more DVD extras than on the original; the added book, and soundtrack make the purchase worthwhile!**Last edited 2013**

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a great movie. It is romantic, humorous, attention grabbing, and heart warming all at the same time! The actors are casted really well and play the parts realistically. The only charecter I didn't like was Elizabeth's mother. The soundtrack is exquisite and the photography is beautiful.  If Jane Austen's novel is as good as the movie then I want to read it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I simply love this movie. I also like the BBC version with Colin Firth and J.Ehle but honestly this version is my favourite. Although the adaptation of the novel is not really faithful to the novel(unlike the BBC one) I think that Joe Wright, the director, still did an amazing job by making a two-hour movie with all the major passages of the book. The first thing I noticed about this movie is the unique, wonderful atmosphere that the director and his assistants managed to create, with a beautiful-yet-down-to-earth setting, the movement of the camera (I was impressed by the way the camera moves, turns or follows the characters through the ballroom at Netherfield) the long shots mingling with close-views of the actors. Even the sounds are perfect -you can hear birds singing in the morning, rain pattering down- and just for that, the movie is a pure joy for me because it feels somewhat real. The atmosphere in the Bennett's house is so familiar and pleasant that you feel almost immediately a connection with this family. I just love every moment of the movie, I love the dialogues even if they don't correspond to the ones in the book (the Darcy's proposal is a moment of anthology! as this `lovers' spat'- kind of argument between Darcy and Lizzie gets more and more intense) The pace of the movie is fast, the good thing is that you don't have time to get bored, there is always something going on in every scene, the bad thing is that there are not enough scenes with these wonderful characters and I don't want the movie to end!!!Right from the start, you feel so close to the characters that you don't want to leave them. They seem so alive (Lizzie Bennet has never been so flamboyant!)I couldn't help feeling as emotionally charged as them. All the actors are great, not only the leading ones but also the minor ones: the younger Bennet sisters -Jena Malone is so funny-and R. Pike is perfect as serene, beautiful Jane -.It is a pity though that we don't see some characters like Caroline Bingley or Charles Bingley or Wickham very often.And of course Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen are really perfect for me as Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy. Keira Knightley gives energy and a mix of wit and mischievousness to the heroine. MacFadyen's Darcy is different from the book, I grant you, but this shy, love-struck and vulnerable is simply irresistible!! OK, maybe you don't have Colin Firth's wet shirt but you can still see MacFadyen drenched to the skin at one point while he is proposing to Lizzie and he is downright sexy too. Plus, his deep voice gives me the shivers! Knightley and Macfadyen have powerful chemistry, and when Darcy proposes to Lizzie in the rain, you can feel the heat, the passion growing more intense between them. The long stares between them, the way they passionately spar and their near-kisses are so sexually charged that they make me almost swoon with delight. One particular moment that I like too is when he helps her getting into a carriage and by doing so, he touches her hand. This is such a magical moment because it is not something you would do at the time especially when you've just met. And the climactic scene , oh boy, this scene in which Macfadyen appears in the misty dawn, desperately seeking Lizzie is so beautiful and rich with sensuality that it always makes me sigh just as it does Lizzie. At that point, I always feel the urge to tell Lizzie that she would be crazy to say 'no' to him now! I think that for once there is the perfect combination between Lizzie and Darcy: (They are both young), he is shy, reserved and socially ill-at-ease while she is free-spirited, flamboyant, lively, always speaking a mind of her own, and so they seem to complete each other very well.The DVD, the English version,is worth the money because the special features are very interesting and ...there is also THE ALTERNATE US ENDING with the balcony kiss. About this US ending, I still think that they could have made a better scene although it is downright sweet. I can feel that Wright wasn't a 100% behind this last conversation between Lizzie and Darcy. Not that I am really complaining, it is still very nice to see them together one last time. One regret, where are the cut-off scenes? I am probably asking too much since the DVD features are already excellent but I 'd love to see the deleted scenes. And I am sure that Joe Wright must have deleted some scenes... Let's hope that there will be one day a special edition with two DVDs. This 'Pride&Prejudice;'movie has become one of my favourites (I think that I must have seen it 4 times in the movie theater before buying the DVD.)I am definitely a big fan because not only I have the book and the music but I 've also been to England just to visit Chatsworth/Pemberley,the Peak District and Burgley House/Lady Catherine De Bourgh's house!!!
summary: This movie has bewitched me body& soul!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is a true romance movie! My family loves it! Keira's acting ability is top-notched, and she pulls you into this movie..I am going to go and watch it again! This movie is definitely a keeper, and one to be watched continuously without boredom!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I probably would have enjoyed this presentation of Pride and Prejudice if I hadn't first seen the "Special Edition" starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.  I couldn't help but compare the two films as I was watching this one, and the Knightley/Macfadyen film was inferior in every respect.  I was so disgusted, after all the hype surrounding this film, that I almost turned it off at several points, but I decided to see it through just once.  If you must see this film, rent it (I wish I had).  Buy the Special Edition.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a travesty!  Some much that was not true to the book, the times, the characters and anything else you could name.  I call it "Pride and Prejudice" as written by Emily Bronte. I expected to see Heathcliff coming around the corner in the barnyard where "Elizabeth" was on the swing! (That strange sound you hear is J.A. coming out of her grave to catch everyone by the scruff of the neck, to give them lessons in deportment in Regency England.)
summary: Not Pride and Prejudice, but Ignominy and Stupidity

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: To begin the movie with sensual and swelling music that makes your heart sinks at the sound of it, kept all of us on the edge of our seats for the whole time we were in the theater. I never thought it could happen; another adaptation that tops A&E;'s Pride and Prejudice and here it is! Though, there aren't as many words spoken within some scenes, but just by looking at the emotions spreading through the characters' faces and listening to that music was just enough!The filmmakers didn't go overboard with any effects that would break away from the true focal points of the movie. There were a few dramatic shots, but it was for the good of the movie; we all can understand that. Just let the music and actors do their job of equaling it out. What I loved the most was how they've paid attention to the little details that just makes a difference in a shot: how they've kept capturing Macfadyen (Darcy) from a far angle, watching Lizzy; the servants and farm animals in the background; and the differentiation behind the make up and hair in each scenes to say that: Lizzy Bennett did love to walk.Keira Knightley is a lovely actress who played her role magnificently, but to my idea, she could have been a little more into her character instead of letting the cameras do all of the work; nonetheless, she'd played well enough to convince us that she WAS a worthy Lizzy Bennett.Matthew Macfadyen gave me second thoughts about Colin Firth, who was my favorite Darcy, until now. Macfadyen is a charming actor (not to mention, a heartthrob, for some of the girls) on screen; who made the situation even worst by playing the tall, dark, handsome, and mysterious, Mr. Darcy. I was blown away by his talent of being so much in character that I WAS convinced that he WAS Mr. Darcy. When he proposed for the first time to Lizzy Bennett (Knightley) nearly everyone in the theater gasped; not only for his confession, but how he had said it. Now, at this point, I was falling out of my seat.Those two, with the combination of the brilliant casting made the movie complete.You don't need to read the book to understand what the heck is going on; you don't need to know every details of the characters' life to like it; and you don't need to worry about any details to look for. Just enjoy this movie, for it will lift you away, keep you at the edge of your seats and your hearts will never cease to stop fluttering until two hours after the movie. Definitely a must see!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Upon first viewing of the film, I thought the scenery was lovely and the soundtrack was amazing.  Jean-Yves makes us all wish we had practiced the piano like our parents advised.  The problem I had with the film was the complete lack of subtlety.  For instance, the Bennets are uber-rural in this version.  I didn't need to see a parading pig's backside and undercarriage to get that.  Little things, like the clap of thunder when Darcy oversteps his critique of the Bennets by adding Lizzie's dad into the mix, were like unnecessary punctuation marks. Talk all you want about Mrs. Bennet and the three younger sisters, but face the wrath of mother nature when you diss a girl's dad.  Other annoyances: Lizzie must be as free as the blackbird, who's forever warbling in the distance.  She's dark and mysterious and wild, with plenty of dark frocks and contoured eye makeup.  Got it.  Didn't need the constant face time that was spent zooming in on Keira Knightley's dark eyes and pursed lips.  Don't even get me started with the obsessive attention to her jawline.  And Mr. Darcy is more s-s-s-socially in-n-n-ept as opposed to morally superior in this current release.  Matthew Macfayden excels at dark, dishy, and intense.  He didn't need to stumble on his words to emphasize Darcy's vulnerabilities or to make us like Darcy more.  Darcy is supposed to be a pompous jerk, who is seldom checked by others and changes only when he meets his match in Elizabeth.  So much of this film feels spoon fed and dumbed down.  I wish I could get past these things to enjoy the lovely locations and the superb acting.  However, the ending was so silly, with its paperback, bodice-ripper vibe, that it cannot be ignored.  The "swans at night" made me think of that beer commercial that spoofs the old chocolate ad, you know the one with guy sampling the foam off the woman's face?.  The actors seemed to struggle to get through the ending without laughing at the absurdity of what they were saying.  That should won them an award.  "Goddess divine"?  "My pearl"?  Blech!  To tack that on was poor judgment, even if it were to appease the American audience.  I recommend stopping the film before you get to this part.  If you're better at overlooking these flaws, then you will enjoy the other parts of the film.  If anything, it ill make you want to take up the piano forte.
summary: Subtle as a kick in the teeth

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I found this adaptation to be appallingly bad.I have a strong attachment to the 1995 BBC miniseries, and of course to the actual book.One would think, that in a movie length film, where they must understandably condense the story, that they would make the most of the precious few minutes they DO have to work with.  Instead they choose to botch it up as badly as they can.Kiera Knightley's Lizzy:  Not the respectable Elizabeth Bennet who has for the longest time been my favorite heroine of literature.  She giggles, and lets her chin, collarbone and lips do most of the work.In the marriage proposal which takes place in the rain, (for heightened dramatics I suppose), Mr Darcy defends himself on the spot, rather than saving that dialog for the letter he is supposed to write to her.  After his explanation, Elizabeth goes towards him and nearly kisses him, and the whole time she looks like she is fighting the urge to drag him to bed then and there.When Lydia takes off with Mr Wickham, its effect on the Bennet family is seen as but a minor inconvenience rather than the disgrace it threatens to be in the book.And in the final scene, when Elizabeth is explaining to her father that she does indeed love mr Darcy, she spills the beans about everything he did for her family rather than keep it discreet.And I search in vain in Jane Austen's book for the part where Elizabeth asks Mr Darcy to call her his "goddess".

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride and Prejudice was not my favorite, but Rosamund Pike was the best Jane Bennet. In my opinion the best adaptation of P&P; is so far the 1995 BBC version with Colin Firth and Jenifer Ehle, however the most accurate to the book is the 1980 version with David Rintoul and Elizabeth Garvie.Perhaps the thing that I disliked the most about this movie was the fact that they made Mr. Bingley look so goofy, almost like an idiot, and Mr. Darcy was to shy. He did not had the dominant masculine strength that I found so appealing in P&P.; I watch just about every adaptation of Pride and Prejudice and it took me a while to warm up to the 2005 version, but after several times watching the movie I learn to enjoy it. I think this adaptation appeals more to the younger generation. Even thought the characters were not very accurate to the book, they all had a charm of their own. My favorite character was Rosamund Pike, she was by far the best Jane Bennet.This was a more modern adaptation of P&P;, where the strict rules of the time were not follow as they have should. The fashion was a little bit to sloppy for me, it did not had the clean and tidy look as I would want to see. Usually when I see a modern adaptation of an period novel, I prefer to see it "separated" from the novel, even when it has the same story line and the same characters. I like to see it with it's own independence, like: "Bridget Jones Diary" or "Bride and Prejudice" or a more funny adaptation, like "Lost in Austen", but when they put that modern feel to the "period" it makes me feel like they have butchered the book.With all this said, I still enjoyed the movie (eventually), and I'm sure the 2005 version with Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen inspire the love, and curiosity for Jane Austen novels to many of the younger generation, who perhaps before were looking at Jane Austen as nothing more than just another high school boring assignment.
summary: This version is more appealing to the younger generation

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Arleisha "I love to read. I enjoy Jane Austen...
review_text: This movie is timelessly romantic! I love Pride and Prejudice and would encourage anyone to read all of Austen's books! This movie is so enjoyable and witty and I think this version of Pride and Prejudice by far has the best ending of all the movies ever.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Excellent casting, story, acting, and photography. The HD format made the English country side and castle interiors magical.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a wonderfully condensed adaptation of the book (which I've read).  I've also recently seen the BBC version of P&P; and though I did enjoy the five hour version, I believe this two hour version tells the gist of the story very well.  Keira Knightly is a bit "cuter" than the book describes Lizzy, but she does an excellent job of being feisty and strong-willed.  Matthew McFayden is a brooding Darcy and portrays the character very well.In this movie version, I believe there are a few scenes that are very touching and set it apart from the miniseries.  The first is when Darcy assists Lizzy into the carriage when she and Jane are leaving Netherfield.  It's as if Lizzie and Darcy immediately feel a spark when their hands touch and when Darcy walks away and has to flex his hand from the touch - wow, it's great.Also, when he proposes to her in the rain and she rejects him.  Before he leaves, he looks at her and his eyes reflect the pain, hurt and anger that he's feeling and he burns a stare right at her for a split second, as he turns to leave, it's heart wrenching.The one scene I definitely enjoyed more than the miniseries (and the book for that matter) was the ending.  I found it very touching and preferred it to the miniseries.  In the miniseries, yes, they kiss at the end, but it's almost casual, there's no spark.  In this version, they playfully caress each other, as Lizzie is suggesting terms of endearment, that Darcy can refer to her.  I was happy with the ending.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This moviie was oustanding in several ways. The cinemaphotography was stunning and always contributed to further interest in the film. Dialog was delightful making us always wonder what is going to be said next. But most of all I enjoyed the music. Absolutely breathtaking! Fabulous compositions played impecably. What a wonderful three-way marriage. Film, words, music. A dream come true! Oh, by the way, it is a great story too.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Really disappointing in comparison to the A&E production. Read the book and you'll realize the difference. A&E was faithful to the book and to the time period; an excellent series. This might appeal to some but is nowhere near the quality interpretation of the A&E/Colin Firth series.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have a great love of Jane Austen and especially Pride and Prejudice, but I don't like this adaptation. For me, it is simply far too rushed and incomplete to do justice to the great novel. To draw audiences into the wonderful romance of Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy, a film has to be well-paced to allow for their character development and their witty bantering, to draw you into their love story, and to see the changes that take place as the two of them recognize their own shortcomings. I just didn't think this film succeeded in that way, so it didn't move me romantically. Plus, the actors spoke so softly and muffled it was almost impossible to understand them, and the whole film came across as dark in color, rather than the brightness and beauty that I associate with Austen.I didn't think this film truly captured the wit and humor or told the story fully enough. The pacing was bizarre, and I wouldn't have even been able to really follow it or "get" the storyline at all if I hadn't already known it well before I watched this movie.I  must admit: Although I've since read and loved the book, I was first introduced to Pride and Prejudice through the incredible 1995 BBC/A&E; miniseries (with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle) when it was first shown  here in the U.S. I absolutely fell in love with it. That adaptation is a complete delight, and it faithfully portrays the novel in so much depth, that it possibly affected how I looked at this version. On the other hand, if I had seen only THIS movie as my P&P; introduction, I probably would never have even wanted to read the book. It's certainly possible to love more than one adaptation of a book, which I do with Little Women and some others; I'm not usually a "purist" about these kinds of things. But this is how I feel about this particular movie. It just didn't work for me at all.
summary: Too Rushed to Do Jane Austen Justice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My favorite Jane Austen movie BY FAR, and the picture quality on BluRay is impeccably clear, must buy for sure!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of my all time favorites! I would suggest reading the book first, as with most books-made-movie. I have lent to to so many of my friends. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you want a story of a timeless romance that captures your heart just watch this. The breath taking photography will leave you stunned and your mouth agape staring at this movie. The acting is not bad, I much preferred the original with Colin Firth. Yet when you watch this version of P&P you become glued to your set. Definately worth your time.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Well done adaptation of the Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice". The cinematography and performances are excellent, and the details regarding life in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries (manor houses with peeling paint and dirty floors, muddy yards with pigs and chickens about, etc.) give the film a realistic dimension.However, because this is a feature film, it, by necessity, omits much of the story and nuance of the execptional BBC version. However, for those without the time to invest in the longer version, this is a great consolation prize.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I somehow didn't feel the magic and electricity that I got from the 1995 mini series and Sense and Sensibility; which is a shame because I was all ready to adore this one too.  The reason I loved the mini series is because there was no stone unturned; every nuance of emotion was true to Austen's book. Even the narrations as Elizabeth read the letters. Too much goes on to gloss over the things that make you fall in love with the story.  There is no possible way to get the complete feel of the novel unless you have the time to do so.  Much like the Lonesome Dove mini series.  Although totally different genres, the characters felt real and were full-bodied.  The book had a light air to it much like the novel and the movie/novel Sense and Sensibility although both had their sad moments but I can't say this movie did that for me.The only characters that I thought did complete justice to the novel and the mini series were that of Dame Dench's de Bourgh and Tom Hollander as Mr. Collins. I connected also from time to time with Knightly's rendition of  Elizabeth particularly when she overheard Darcy's opinion of her at the dance. Yet Blethens and Sutherland both of whose acting I adore just missed (more so Donald Sutherland) I don't blame the actors for this, mostly the director.  (I especially didn't care to Jena Malone's rendition of Lydia, which was slyer than it was totally oblivious, immature and childlike).  I just feel that this is such a beloved and full novel that leaving the small things that make it so wonderful isn't as satisfyingI'm far from a novel purist but you just miss so much if all of it isn't shown.  If only Hollywood was brave enough to gamble on making something that length, this may have worked better for me.  But we know that will never happen.  I found it somewhat lacking and far from the BBC mini series caliber.  Maybe the extraordinary classics should all be mini-series.  For those who think this is good.... take some time over a weekend to see the mini series with an open mind.  You'll be hooked!
summary: Not enough character development for me.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley does an excellent job. The whole Bennett family seems to be having a very good time. This movie has the friendliest take on Mr. and Mrs. Bennett's marriage. Very watchable, more enjoyable even after multiple viewings. Only rivaled by the BBC/Colin Firth adaptation, but this one is less of a time investment.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I read Pride and Prejudice and Zombies and now after watching Pride and Prejudice, i'm finally reading the regular book itself. Anyway, this film stuck to the book. The cast was well choosen and the whole of the film was entertaining. I enjoy the story of Eliza Bennet and Mr. Darcy. I must watch the film again though since i can't recall certain parts that i'm readin from the book right now. The book is easier to read than Sense and Sensibility but watching the film first does help you with understanding the plot and characters for sure.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a acction and comedy movie guy, but this movie stay at another standard. I saw it every month just for the fun and one of the best ending of a movie ever.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, I guess I'll be saying what most have said, but I'll say it again... NO COLIN FIRTH !This movie is really splendid visually, and very great acting by all the cast; I think if I'd never seen Colin Firth as Darcy, I'd never be in a position to compare or miss something/someone in this movie... But unfortunately, once you've seen Darcy played by Colin, you just can't help it !Maybe someone could tell me if the part in this movie was ever even proposed to him????Apart from all that, I find the movie is of course SUPERIOUR in every way to the BBC mini-series, not only visually, but in the choice of actors, apart from Colin Firth of course ! hehe...The performances are much more "natural" and subtle, and it's filmed in such a vivacious and beautifully romantic way, that you won't find it hard to be swept away...Even though I've never thought Keira Knightley to be good enough for such a part, I was very pleased, and even Darcy is good, if you don't keep reminding yourself about Colin Firth ! And Donald Sutherland doesn't need to say much to give a very very powerful performance.My all-time favourite Jane Austen movie adaptation is Sense & Sensibility with great Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet and etc... If you haven't seen it, it's a must !
summary: 4 STARS BECAUSE NO COLIN FIRTH ! LOL (but still it deserves 5 stars)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version has beautiful scenery, costumes, actors and has great film quality! The acting is marvelous. Mr. Dacy does such a wonderful job being tormented inside and portraying that torment without a word, only showing it in his guarded expressions. Lizzie and Jane are both beautiful and great actresses. Mr. Bingly is a bit overly enthusiastic and air headed, but pleasing. It had the potential to be a great version of Pride and Prejudice.....but it wasn't!I was confused most of the time and at the end felt like I was rushed through a beautiful love story. I have been a fan of Pride and Prejudice ever since watching the 1996 version starring Colin Firth and have since watched it so many times I have it memorized! Perhaps that is the problem. The 1996 version was a wonderful story. I always knew what each character was feeling and what was going on. There were no gaps in the story and I fell in love with it. I was excited to learn there was an updated version being released this year because I hoped for a better film quality than the 1996 one. It at least had that much going for it. It was a beautiful picture but with a hurried story. They should have lengthened the film so the viewer knew all the characters and details of the story. Instead the movie felt rushed, like a summary to the real thing. A good movie, perhaps if you haven't watched the 1996 version already, but I strongly suggest you only rent this one and then buy the other =-).
summary: It had the potential to be great....but what happened??!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was looking forward to this version of my favorite novel because I wanted to see how they would slice it down to two hours runtime.  I was delighted with some of it.  Miss Knightley's performance is quite good and she seems to possess all the fire of Elizabeth Bennet.  Brenda Blethyn and Dame Judy Dench (perfection itself) were also standouts, although Miss Dench's important final scene with Miss Knightley was abridged.  And why does she mention a pretty sort of garden (taken from the novel), when they play this scene inside the house at night?I found quite a few more flaws in the production.  The best dialogue is taken directly from the book.  When Miss Austen speaks, the film and the actors are just fine.  When the dialogue is newly invented, it doesn't seem to fly along.  I found Matthew McFadyen rather wooden and not as attractive as the characters say Mr. Darcy is.  Also, the family relationships are not correctly delineated as Miss Austen wrote them.  In the novel, Mr. Bennet favors Elizabeth for her wit.  Of all his daughters, she is the only one, he confides in the book, that he can converse with on an intelligent level.  Also, Lydia (in the novel) is an exact replica of her mother -- which is not apparent in this film.  Also, Mrs. Bennet favors Lydia above her other daughters in the book.  This is nowhere apparent in the film.  It seems that the daughters are all lumped together as one by their parents.  Mr. Bennet's financial concerns are barely brought to light and Lydia's scandalous elopement with Wycham, which is so important to the denoument, is reduced to little more than a trifling matter and is over with in less than three to four minutes.  The ending is like a fast-forward (obviously they were running out of time), and we get a tacked on coda that has Darcy and Elizabeth at Pemberley in a love scene.  Miss Austen's "psychology" is missing nearly throughout this film.The DVD supplies us with the actors being interviewed as well as screenwriter and director, and here is where we find where they went wrong.  It seems that all of the information they are giving us is not at all what Miss Austen intended.  Donald Sutherland himself (Mr. Bennet), constantly speaks of how much his character loves his daughters.  Maybe he should try re-reading the book.  Mr. Bennet spent nearly all his time in his library wishing to be undisturbed by the noise of his wife and the household in general.I am forever grateful to the BBC for having taken the novel, one of the finest in the English language, and giving it the royal treatment in 1995 with superlative actors and a screenwriter who knew how to aptly recreate Miss Austen's world.  How fastidious they were with every detail and Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth seem to be the quintessential leading players in this beautiful production.  We have it for as long as DVDs and film last.This new production, even though it is sliced down, seems slow, oddly enough, and I could not wait for it to be over.  I look forward to sitting down with the 1995 version soon.
summary: When it's Austen talking, it comes alive.

So much so, that a great deal of the original dialogue is retained.  Jane herself would have been proud to see her masterpiece brought to the masses so wonderfully!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Bummer, I bought this hd dvd thinking I could watch it on my new hd tv, but could not because my dvd player is not hd!  So now I have this dvd I cannot use.  I re-bought the regular version and of course the story is fantastic, which I already knew.
