title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being a Pride & Prejudice novel fan, I found myself totally in love with the A&E; mini-series which I believe gets everything "just right."  However, being that it is a 5- hour long drama, it's not one that you can pop into the DVD player and watch just any time.  So, naturally, when I discovered that a shorter, newer film was being made I was very excited. I felt  Sense & Sensibility came off wonderfully in Hollywood, so I was very keen to see how the most beloved of Austen's novels would rate.I must admit I was sorely disappointed.  I felt that Darcy was portrayed as more shy than proud and Elizabeth more of a sass than a quick wit.  In the book and in the A&E; version, Elizabeth's role as her father's favorite makes her charcter more of an intellectual than her sisters.  In this new movie, Elizabeth doesn't have much of a connection with her father - and comes off as silly as the rest of her sisters (although a little more outspoken).  I also couldn't get past the squalor in which the Bennett family was living or the costuming for that matter.  The Bennetts looked like the dirtiest family I had ever seen and I couldn't imagine how Mr. Darcy (in all of his pride) could fall in love with Elizabeth.  (To those of you who could get past this, I commend you.)  While in the A&E; version, the Bennetts certainly aren't as rich as the Bingley's or the Darcy's but they are a respectable family and CLEAN.  The viewers also see the subtle transformation of a proud Darcy to one that is strugglling with his feelings for Elizabeth, and then finally to the great hero that he becomes in the end.I understand that with time restrictions such transformations are not always possible and so I give this movie credit for the effort.  Matthew Macfadyen was a good Darcy, but when compared to Colin Firth - there is no contest.  I thought that Judi Dench gave a marvelous performance as Lady Catherine and I liked this movie's version of Mr. Collins a smidge more than the A&E; version (it may be that he is more attractive than the other one.)  When it comes to Elizabeth - Jennifer Ehle owns the part.  Her performance seemed to have jumped right off the pages of the book.  I know that this new movie should stand alone and shouldn't be compared to a longer, more accurate adaption of the book - but it's very difficult not to compare the two. So I must state that this new film, while good in capturing the basics of the story, left much to be desired in everything else.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My daughters were enchanted with this movie as well as the sound track.  So romantic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A&E did a wonderful version of this, and all I can say is that anyone who loved this never saw the Collin Firth version.  Kiera Knightly is not one of my favorite actresses, so I may be biased, but the other Elizabeth, played by Jennifer had a lot more class.  Take the time to see the classic, and don't bother with the inferior remake.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Author Donna Marie Johnson "Donna Marie Johns...
review_text: I loved the fact that this movie stuck to the most important themes of the story ... the main hero and heroine's love story ... and didn't dwell too much on anything else, except if it was related to the main love affair.I absolutely loved the cinematography. They did a great job in showing the beauty of Great Britain. I visited when I was a teen, and I haven't been back to visit again. I almost felt like I could feel and smell it while watching the outdoor / nature shots in this well-crafted film.Pride & Prejudicedeserves every bit of attention it has gotten in these reviews. Check it out for yourself to see if you like it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Firstly, if you have already seen the Pride and Prejudice miniseries with Colin Firth, don't expect too much from this movie or you will be disappointed, as I was.It seemed that the dialogue was "dumbed down" for the general audience.This film is one of the worst adaptations of Pride and Prejudice ever filmed and if Jane Austen were alive, she would demand that her name be removed from the film. Austen's novel is only superficially a story of the development of true love between Elizabeth Bennet and Fitzwilliam Darcy.  If one is making a period movie, one must be true to the period. The best thing that can be said about this film is that it contains many pretty scenes of the English countryside.I guess the main flaw of this new version is Darcy himself, a role played by Matthew MacFadyen. In the story he is rather dull and generally uninterested in what's going on. It must be difficult to replace Colin Firth as leading man and the Darcy of the miniseries of course had more screen time to show his inner struggle. But the new Darcy is so dull that frankly you don't care if he ends up winning Elizabeth's heart or not. There is absolutely no spark between Knightly and MacFadyen. At the end of the move they don't even kiss and as an audience you couldn't care less.I don't recommend this movie to anyone.  Go rent the miniseries with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle if you want a real Jane Austen story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of the best love stories ever! The characters were perfect; believable!  The cinematography and soundtrack is mesmorizing.  This is the type of movie I love to watch repeatedly and thanks to Amazon I WILL BE!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: OK, I'll admit it: I've gone to the theater to see this 6 or 7 times already--I've lost count; I'm thrilled that the DVD is coming out sooner rather than later.No, this is not the much-loved 1995 multi-hour A&E; version. And no, MacFaydan is not Firth, and Knightly is not Ehle. And some liberties were taken with the original storyline (sometimes a bit disconcerting like Lady Catherine's night time visit?? and Bingley entering Jane's sickroom, even before knocking?? "simply not done" in those days!).But I very much agree with the positive reviewers below --this version is MOST enjoyable on its own. The scenery, photography, and music are gorgeous (you must buy the CD!). Darcy and Elizabeth are still wonderfully Darcy and Elizabeth. It was a little disconcerting at first to see so much mud, livestock, and plain gowns--but you get past that fairly quickly. And it seems maybe a bit more realistic for country gentry.BTW--if you're a P&P; addict like me, don't miss Pamela Aiden's Darcy trilogy--it tells the entire story from Darcy's viewpoint and fills in a lot of what I think is missing. Also, if you have wondered what might have happened after the wedding and like a "spicier" novel, read Linda Berdoll's "Mr. Darcy Takes a Wife" (Austen meets Bronte and Sandra Brown).
summary: Enjoy for what it is--not Firth but wonderful!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Well, first, I must identify myself as a Colin Firth/BBC version fan. That is the best adaptation of P&P.; For a two hour version though this version can grab readers and non-readers alike. It is well done in terms of scenery and casting. It also has the necessary butterfly-in-the-stomach moments that make it a good romance whether or not you have read the book.I did however, not need to see the last scene after they are already married. I thought it was the definite sign of a Hollywood movie trying to be everything to everyone. I didn't need it and I am a huge romance movie fan. After such a beautiful walk in the fog, the last scene seemed too out of place and cheesy/embarrassing.Another complaint is that people who have not read the book might be confused by some people's relationships or personalities because there simply isn't enough time to flush all this out. Bottom line, true P&P; fans will notice some glaring issues, but everyone can find something in this movie that is worth the watch. I had to own it, as a companion for the ultimate BBC version (please watch it if you like this movie).

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The first time I saw this version, I really did not like it at all.  My biggest complaint is the pace.  The dialogue is usually rushed, yet so much time is taken to show Lizzy twirling in a swing.  If you don't know the scene by heart already, you will need to replay the first proposal repeatedly before you catch all of the dialogue.Knightley just can't compare to Ehle.  She doesn't convey the intelligence that appealed to Darcy, the wit and attitude yes, but not the book-reading.  While the mother is less annoying than the 95 version, most of the family appears slothful and careless in this film.  Can you really imagine Darcy visiting a home with paint peeling and pigs traipsing?  While this Whickham has it in looks, his acting was lacking.  Definitely splashed with too many improprieties.  I also recommend turning it off before you get to the sappy balcony scene ending.With all that said, it is still a beautiful, entertaining, standard-length film.  What it lacks in Austen authenticity, it makes up for in cinematography and a memorable score.  (My hubby brought home a copy and we regularly watch it.)  Just keep in mind that this is a whole different feel to the brilliant favorite, 95 Firth/Ehle version.
summary: Entertaining, but not true to Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For those of you who are avid Jane Austen fans, this a is a refreshing recent adaptation of the novel. I would recommend anyone who owns the A&E version to also buy this one, as it offers a different take, but one that is equal in value and quality. Also, this one is several hours shorter, so it offers the same great punch in a smaller dose. The actors do a fabulous job, and the cinematography is breathtaking.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The acting in this version is wonderful and spot on. To begin  Jane and Mr Bingley are a perfect fit for their characters and each other. Both actors show a goodness and quietness in their manners so that one has trouble imagining them together and the issues that this couple faces along the way. The biggest issue no doubt is sharing their heartfelt emotions and love for each other.Elizabeth and Mr Darcy are also a perfect match. Elizabeth is just the right amount of independence and vulnerability that her character comes alive. Elizabeth shows that she is sensitive to others opinions, as when Darcy comments on her appearance and behavior at village dance, after his cutting comments she seeks out her best friend to help confirm her beliefs that he is wrong and has a great prejudice. She assumes and exhibits an attitude that she has everything figured out and as a result judges things much to quickly - including Darcy. The development of the character throughout the movie is played so expertly! You really do see her character grow and her opinions rendered incorrect - she too has prejudices.To me this is the best acting of Mr Darcy's character that I have seen. I found it easy to see the shyness in Darcy hiding behind his pride. To me I found this portrayal so right on with what I imagined in from the book. He is quiet and aloof, yet you find yourself drawn to him, much like Elizabeth does as she gets to know him. Darcy does not seem as harshly played in this production as he is in others. It is not as hard to imagine Elizabeth falling for him as in other films. In other productions his change from "bad" guy to "good" guy seems too fast, here the character has time to grow and we see glimpses of his true self - small in the beginning and then revealed more throughout the film.The scenery of the English Countryside from the village to the residences is beautiful - with incredible scenic shots that will make you want to pick up and move directly to the English countryside.The costumes are simple for the country ladies - One of the greatest examples is the scene in which Elizabeth comes to check on her ailing sister Jane, at the Bingley residence. Elizabeth appears as if she has had a terrible journey to arrive there. Standing in front of the proper ladies and Darcy she is a sight to behold - and so believable.This is definitely worth purchasing and if you love Jane Austen's works or simply a good period piece you will no doubt return to this film again and again.In a word beautiful.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wonderful love story - and the use of the English language is superb!Brings up a lot of questions that make me want to know more about British law in the 1800's.AZSandie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The Acting is superb for this cinematic masterpiece. The director was true to the novel and Austen's piece shines in this movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, I was VERY skeptical of this remaking of P&P.; First off, feature films rarely do a good job of interpreting a book into a 2 hour film (I thought Zefferelli's Jane Eyre was just dreadful!). I also questioned the casting of Keira Knightley as one of literature's most beloved heroines, Elizabeth Bennett. I really didn't think she could pull it off. But she really did.I'm one of those fans that hold up the BBC/A&E; mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle as the gold standard as adaptations go. It wasn't perfect, but it was the best I'd seen to-date and I treasure my DVD copy. And so, it was with fairly low expectations that I went to see this film. But I must say that I was pretty impressed. The setting, as others have pointed out, was of a much more rural world where people got dirty and farm animals wander about in the front yard. I thought the depictions of the Bennett sisters were well done particularly Jena Malone's silly Lydia, Rosamund Pike just luminescent as Jane and Ms Knightly's fine job as Elizabeth. Brenda Blethyn was a much less flighty Mrs Bennett from the BBC version which was welcome. But I was not that wild about Donald Sutherland's portrayal of Mr Bennett. He seemed more willfully neglectful of his daughters than the more benign neglect depicted in the BBC version.As for the men, I know that for many Colin Firth IS Fitzwilliam Darcy (he's played him twice after all) but I found Matthew MacFadyen's portrayal more nuanced and sensitive, almost vulnerable than the more cool and haughty Firth version. I loved him! MacFadyen interprets Darcy's reserve not as superior hauteur so much as a sort of shyness. MacFadyen's Darcy seems to be a shy man who is uncomfortable with strangers and, perhaps, in his own skin. He's attracted to Elizabeth because she is everything he's not. She's totally comfortable with who she is and her place in the world even if she is often stifled by the social strictures of her day. Charles Bingley was portrayed as a boyish innocent and one could see why Darcy felt he had to look out for him. I really felt that the Caroline Bingley character was pretty inconsequential seemingly only there to give Jane the excuse to visit. But one never got the impression that Caroline even liked Jane in this version so that part was not very well done. I must confess that the portrayal of Mr Collins had me smiling with serious bemusement! He wasn't the buffoonish comic relief so much as a bit of an oddity! But the biggest surprise was what a small part George Wickham played in this story.And that is my biggest issue with the film. Other than Mr MacFadyen, Ms Knightly is the star around which everyone else orbits and as a result, everyone else comes off as fairly minor secondary characters. As expected, some events are missing or time periods compressed to fit the time requirements of the film. I suppose it's as faithful as a feature film could be, but it does sort of boil the book down to just the romance between Lizzie and Darcy. Other issues I had were some of the costuming which would have been inappropriate at the time. The almost slip dress that Caroline Bingley wears to the Netherfield ball would have been positively scandalous in the day (a night gown would have shown less skin!). And gloves would have been worn by both ladies and gentlemen at any social occasion. And there was also a scene where Lizzie and her sister are shopping in the village and her hair is down around her shoulders. A young lady of the day would never appear in public without her hair being put up! And I was very disappointed in the lackluster Lady Catherine DeBurgh this version offered. Judi Dench is fine, but she lacks the amusingly pompous condescension Lady Catherine had in the book and in the BBC version. She plays her too regally as my sister pointed out!Ah well, nothing in life is perfect, but bottom line, I enjoyed this adaptation and have added the DVD to my shopping card.  Highly recommended!
summary: 4 1/2 stars - probably as good as a feature film could be

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: "And how are you this evening, Mrs. Darcy?"One of the reasons I started this project of reading the original books from which these movies sprung is so that I can find out whether my favorite bits are in the original. The above line, the last in the movie, I sincerely hope is from the book. It's so perfect. But of course, you have to know how it came to be so perfect, don't you?Keira Knightley is a beautiful woman, a superb actress, and could probably make any role a fine thing. But this is only the beginning. I love period pieces with great costumes and sets, and the old-fashioned dignity of the King's English, and those lush landscapes. And I do love Jane Austen. This movie not only has all that, but some sweet special touches, like Donald Sutherland in a role unlike any he has ever played before, with gentle humor and just exactly what's wanted in the father of five girls.The humor is gentle all through this movie, such as when the two oldest sisters giggle together under the covers over their reactions to the gentlemen at the rustic country ball. The contrast when an elegant upper crust ball is later held so gently illustrates that only those two eldest girls have the kind of class required to be at home in both circles. Yes, their mother is ridiculous, but she loves her girls sincerely, and did not manage to ruin their chances by being rather too obvious in attempting to marry them off.There are difficulties, of course, but the only tragedy comes when the youngest sister proves too eager to be married and runs off with a soldier. Yet rich relations can smooth things over, and she returns to the family a smug married woman, if not exactly a lady.
summary: A Beautiful Movie About a Beautiful Book

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Can't really add anything insightful or original to some of the other reviews already provided for this movie.  I can't say the other postivie reviews helped me, since I fell in love with this movie the first time I saw it.  The reviews in favor of this move just explain how I feel better than I can.Yes, the story is shortened for the purpose of this movie and some of the characters are not as fully developed as in the book.  However, in the time alloted for a feature film, the director and actors stayed true to the spirit of the book and this is a great representation of the book.Matthew Macfadyen - what a performance!!!  He conveys so much with his eyes and facial expressions.  The most internally tortured Darcy I have ever seen.  While many seem to think Keira Knightley can't act,  I disagree.  A perfect Lizzie in my opinion.I haven't had a chance to see the BBC mini-series, which many seem to prefer, so I can't compare or contrast to this film.  All I can say, as I did in the beginning, is that I love this film.  Great photography, great adaptation, great acting, great film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There are many good aspects to this version of P&P--the performances and the production values make the film enjoyable to watch. But the ridiculous notion to attempt to edit P&P down to a 2 hr film just kills it. The story has been edited to death. Frankly, if you weren't already familiar with the story, I think so much has been cut out that it would be extremely difficult even to follow the plot. But more importantly, this version leaves zero room for the development of the characters' emotional attachments, and makes the alteration in Darcy's and Elizabeth's feelings toward each other seem completely unbelievable. It was a very unfortunate choice that mars what could have been a lovely production.
summary: some good points, but edited to death

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've alwasy liked Keira but now I love her! It's great to see a young star that can do more than rely on special effects to support their career. Dialogue is what I'm about & Keira is obviously capable! She needs to take on more projects of this kind.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Of the novels of Jane Austen this is the best.  I first became acquainted with this work about 52 years ago, have read the novel many times and seen this and other film adaptations so often I can recite the dialogue from memory.  This review is not on the book but the movie.I shall not destroy your enjoyment of the film by telling the story.You should read the book and see the movie for yourself.  Regarding the movies this is much better than the BBC version which is broken up into parts.  The acting is superb.  If you don't believe me listen to the actors and director on the special section of the dvd.  When I bought this dvd it was twice as expensive and I felt it was well worth it.  You can have it at a bargain price now and if you are a Prime member have it delivered in a short time postage free.  If you know Austen or are totally unaware of her work you owe it to yourself to buy and watch this movie.Enjoy yourself!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've read Pride and Prejudice a couple of times, and loved the story, the characters (especially Elizabeth and Darcy), and Austen's humor. The miniseries from the mid 1990s with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle was fantastic too, with Firth as a perfect a Darcy as could be, and the whole thing capturing the spirit of the book. I heard a couple rave reviews of this adaptation, so I thought I'd check it out. Let's just say I want my two hours back. It's horrible. It's chopped way down so you just get a shell of the story, perhaps a cliff's notes version. You know what's going on, but you never get much of the wit and development. I didn't give a damn about any of the characters, like I did in the book and the miniseries. In those I was falling for Mr. Darcy right along with Elizabeth and wanting them together. In this version the characters just don't come to life. I didn't care what happened. And on top of that, despite the editing down of a classic to bare bones story, they still tossed in a lot of filler, lots of shots with some piano music tinkling away, and it's like, you couldn't have put a few more good lines of dialogue, explain more of the goings on? Anything? It just doesn't capture the spirit of the book; it's a lazy man's Austen. Bridget Jones' Diary (the movie, anyways, I didn't read the book), better caught the spirit of 'Pride and Prejudice,' with Firth as Darcy  (naturally) and Hugh Grant as Wickham, the crazy mom being the crazy mom with a bit of Lydia's drama thrown in. Rent that instead if you want a lighter version, or give the book and the miniseries a chance. It'll take longer to get through, but it's worth the time.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie. It is my favorite.  I watch this movie a least once a week.  It's an excellent movie. Classic love story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love this movie. I received this DVD in short order and have watch it a number of times already.  I love period pieces.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wow, what can I say that hasn't already been said by so many disappointed viewers. Knightly plays Lizzy like some rude, self-absorbed teenager. I think a majority of the people that loved this movie must be under the age of 21 or something (Note that I said a majority and not all). This is really nothing like the real Pride and Prejudice--why did the director even bother--just to make a name for himself by directing a classic in his own stylized way? Wow, I am still in shock at the liberties the screewriter and director took with this novel--it's really quite awful! Please read the book before you defend this film as being an accurate adaptation of P&P!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I tried to approach this movie with an open mind, which was difficult since I've loved the book and the BBC Firth/Ehle version for years.  I found the new movie enjoyable with some things being better than the BBC version.Kiera Knightley and Judi Dench's performances are outstanding.  Almost all of the acting was very good.  My problems were with how characters were changed and thus I didn't like their portrayal.  Elizabeth's father as portrayed by Donald Sutherland was much more sentimental and lacked the appropriate humor.  Both the Darcy and Wickham characters are barely known and thus essential aspects of the story can barely be comprehended.If you're familiar with the BBC version, the lines Darcy says to Elizabeth in the Knightley version are appallingly laughable.  They make Darcy out to be an idiotic geek rather than an intelligent yet shy man.  When it comes right down to it, the only way I can watch the Knightley version is if I skip any scenes with Darcy in them.  His lines are awful, the actor plays him like a sick lost puppy.  Ok my prejudice towards the BBC version is now coming out.  Colin Firth plays a far more believable Darcy, with dialogue fitting of the character.So I'd only recommend if you a)skip scenes with Darcy or b)have never read the book or seen the BBC version
summary: Fine if you skip Darcy scenes

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I could have dealt with a giggly Elizabeth (though it was hard).  I could have handled the romance novel ending, but for me, it was the changing of Jane Austen's words -- in particular the romantic words of Mr. Darcy.  What screenplay writer could possibly think they could improve on Ms. Austen's words after a few centuries?  It's unfathomable.  If you're not a huge fan of the book, or the BBC version, this is a fine rendition.  But truly, I think you'll wonder what all the hype is about on the book after just seeing this version.There's a lot of book to be condensed in two hours, so I will give them credit for that -- but if you're going to change the book, do it with style -- like the BBC did with Colin Firth diving into the pond on his visit back to Pemberley.  There's a change I can live with.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is the best shortened adaption available. I've read all Jane Austen books and a number multiple times. Love this story. The only better one is the BBC one, but that's +6 hours, so if you want to just do a movie night or don't have 6 hours to spare in your busy schedule like tends to happen with me, then this is the one to see. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was actually looking forward to see this movie. The result was bottomless disappointment. My honest opinion is there is just no way to shorten a book so considerably and then expect it to be anything else than lacking! There is only one true Darcy: Colin Firth. I won't even get into Ms Bennett ... My advice, if you love Jane Austen: Buy the set with Colin Firth, do yourself a favour here!! I know it is very long but I'm not kidding, it is so worth it!!! title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I never like to compare different versions of films, but I just couldn't help but do so after watching this adaptation. I have seen other P&P; films in the past, and the one that blew me away was the 1996 A&E; version. This new film doesn't measure up.1) Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle defined the story's characters beyond belief; in fact, the whole cast was superior (you felt as if Jane Austen's characters jumped off the pages). There was chemistry, subtlety, passion, etc. Here, the characters seemed undeveloped/undimensional and lacked all the qualities of the book's characters.2) The length of the 1996 movie gave a lot of detail and was well-developed; the story made much more sense in terms of why and how everything was happening. Here, they just took out all the main parts from the plot and pasted them together, leaving you to wonder if more was supposed to happen. Also, in the 1996 movie, Elizabeth and Darcy saw each other quite often, and each interaction contributed to the overall progression of their relationship; you can see why Elizabeth disliked Darcy and how she slowly started changing her mind. Here, one minute she hates him, and then, after hearing a couple of nice sentences from people, she, all of a sudden, "magically" loves him. The two characters barely saw each other and have not even held a real conversation, except for the scene where Darcy makes his first proposal, and is turned down, yet they somehow fell madly in love with each other...?3) 1996: Manners, etiquette, and traditions of the elite British class were captured quite well. You really saw how courtship was intended to be, and how marriage was looked upon. Here:too much Americanization going on ("Hollywood BS" I call it!). Certain parts were ridiculous (Lady Catherine's night visit, Mr.Bennett's dialogue, Charles Bingley's moron personality, Elizabeth's nightgown run, and the list goes on.......)Basically, a bunch of Americans (with exceptions, of course) pretending to know about British culture.I could go on forever with a list of complaints, but I don't want to bore the readers! If you're going to make a romantic film, make it about anything else, but don't take a classic novel and pretend that you can pull it off with good cinematography.Overall, if you have no idea what the book is about and have never read it (like this version's filmmakers), you might enjoy see this P&P; movie because it's a "romance". Just watch it as it is and don't give a second thought to what Jane Austen's story really stood for. Enjoy the costumes, music, etc, but don't pay attention to the plot. Just be glad that everyone lives happily ever after.
summary: Has difficulty in overcoming its predecessor....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a movie for romantics--there's no other way to put it.  It is aesthetically amazing and the acting is top-shelf.  It does a wonderful job using the lines directly from the book but not making it 6 hours ;-)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The Tagline of the Movie: "The one man she cannot stand, may be the one man she can't live without."The new version of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is a must own for lovers at heart. Wonderfully casted by Jina Jay, she brings the story of the prideful Elizabeth Bennett and the prejudiced Mr. Darcy to life in this updated classic. Starring in the lead roles Keira Knightly,Matthew Macfadyen, and along with other well known actors Donald Sutherland, Brenda Blethyn and Judi Dench.This remake blends the unique acting of today with the glorius scenery of the past. Keira Knightly proudly shows that she is a very powerful Elizabeth Bennett, especially in a wonderful night scene shot with Judi Dench along with the scene's shot with the gentle Donald Sutherland. Matthew Macfadyen positively shines in his role as a tormented and shy man trying to overcome his prejudice to win the woman of his heart.Yet I will remark that for those that see this, try not to compare it with the wondefully done BBC miniseries version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle done in 1995. Now while I enjoyed this film and found it exhilarating from beggining to end, it does go very fast at certain parts and slow it seems at others, but overall a wonderful remake of the famous book, and a version for any true lover at heart.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is perhaps one of the best adatations of Pride & Prejudice I've seen yet. From the opening scenes to the last I was absolutly captivated. I can't explain it any other way then that. Though some liberties have been taken, it still makes for a wonderful love story, though it does help if you've read the book to follow along sometimes. It is perhaps on of the best movies I've seen in a long long time.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: THIS is a devine movie brought about Jane Austen. The romance of the era is no less than perfection. One of my favorite movies ever.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While obviously abridged compared to the A&E; mini series, this P&P; is dead-on accurate.  Though I still appreciate the A&E; version, Wright captured the 'everyday-ness' of Austin's time: the dirt, the dress, the deportment, and Austin's well crafted satire.Compared to Wright's P&P;,  A&E;'s characters are wooden while Mrs. Bennett, Mr. Collins and, Mr. Wickham are nearly cartoonish.  On the other hand, Wright's Lady Catherine seems overblown though in the capable hands of Dame Dench, and Donald Sutherland's physicality doesn't quite fit Mr. Bennett though he does capture the character's charm & sense of humor.Wright's costuming & sets were well researched exemplified by older women wearing less fashionable gowns and younger women dressing more stylishly within their particularsocial rank.  In the A&E; P&P;, there is little variation in dress with so much pure white linen which could lead one to wonder if Longbourne was a suburb of Heaven.Wright's choreography and camera work really 'raised the bar' for historical dramas, too.  A&E;'s comes across as overly reheased & rigidely exacting while the camera remains static.  All of this results in scenes that are "not so much like a ball".With the luxury of time, the A&E; P&P; does include the entire Wickham subplot, one which Wrightwas required to  abridge but did so fairly elegantly.  Both versions exclude the novel's postscript-like conclusion.Enjoy both, and a read of Austen's novel.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley butchered what could have been a refreshing adaption to a beautiful story. Knightley appears oblivious to whom her character is. Again her constant posing and trying to be sexy by hanging her mouth open, is distracting and obnoxious.And, once again, it falls to the other actors to carry her and fill in the gaps in her performance.I dont' know what her agent had to pull to get her this role, but it's a waste of time, talent, and money. Only a miracle worker like Johnny Depp can cover for her like he did in "Pirates".
summary: Am I the only one who think Knightley can't act?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm not sure why the script writers turned the Bennets into poorly dressed, groomed and behaved...slobs, really...living in an unkempt farm house. Or Lizzie Bennet twirling around on a swing in the barn, _barefoot_? The pig walking through their house was just too much. Lowering the family in this manner made the film very objectionable to me.So much of Jane Austen's wonderful, witty dialogue is omitted, and occasionally handed off to someone else to suit the scenes. The story had a casual, Colonial American feel to it rather than the prim and proper English flavor as it was written. Darcy, Lady Katherine and Mrs. Bennet were very dull. Bingly was very miscast as a dolt. Jane Bennet, Mr. Wickam and troublesome Lydia were practically invisible. So much of the rich romantic tension between Elizabeth and Darcy was lost by cutting out so much of the story.If you're looking for a more accurate adaptation of Jane Austen's novel, you'll be pleased with the 1995 miniseries. You'll see the Bennets careful to behave within the social politics of their society. They aren't wealthy, but they still dress, groom and carry themselves well. Mrs. Bennet is an obnoxious, gossipy social climber. Mr. Darcy is proud and unlikeable until Lizzie sets him straight during his rude marriage proposal. Mr. Bingly is intelligent and kindhearted. Lady Katherine gives Lizzie a hard time with her pious prejudice. Mr. Collins is amusing in his cluelessness. Mr. Wickam is a rake you'll love to hate.I know a 2 hour movie can't compare to a 6 hour miniseries. Perhaps if I hadn't seen the miniseries first, I would've liked the theater version. But I really didn't enjoy it at all because so much of the story was cut out and/or changed.
summary: A Pig Walking Through the Bennet House?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Of all the movies on my Top 10 list, this adaptation of Jane Austen's classic was the one I was the most reluctant to include because it's light and airy, it's a story that I've seen done before and because I knew a lot of Austen fans don't like it because it takes liberties with her apparently sacred text. But then I thought about the movie itself and how I felt swept up in it while it played in front of me. This new PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is a thoroughly engaging, lushly romantic time at the movies, presenting us with two brilliant, headstrong characters who are too stubborn to admit that they love each other. In this year of surprisingly strong performances that seem to come out-of-nowhere, Keira Knightley achieves the nearly impossible by making the role of Elizabeth Bennet entirely her own. By minimizing every part of the story that didn't deal directly with Elizabeth, director Joe Wright and screenwriter Deborah Moggach have created a swift, fun adaptation of the work that just keeps building momentum. It's thoroughly charming.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Compared to the Colin Firth Jennifer Ehle version, this movie has better casting and better camera work. The problem is, of course, the duration. They try to fit into a 2 hour movie, and it just won't work. It doesn't capture the subtlety of many events, and the character building is ignored. However, if you haven't watched any other versions,you will love this one. I definitely love the casts, as they are more real, the age of the actors match the book, and Matthew McFadyen is a better cast for Darcy than Colin.
summary: Very well made, and very good casts

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved the book Pride and Prejudice and this movie follows the book beautifully, it flows great, and Kiera Knightly is such a belivable rendition of the character in the book. Mathew Mcfayden also is good as Mr. Darcy, could be a little better, but works wonderfully with Kiera Knightly. The movie definitly does justice to the book.
summary: this movie is awsome, i loved it. more than the original. Kiera Knightly makes the perfect Elizabeth Bennet.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a total disappointment.  Everything from script, set and costume design, to actual filming angles and editing FLAWED. Who ever heard of the British Army wearing BLUE COATS?  And all of the FRENCH set design elements?  And where was the wit and intelligence which was and is JANE AUSTIN?  If you are looking for the best contemporary version of Pride and Prejudice, look no further than the mini-series starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.  All the elements were correct and the acting was leaps and bounds better than this latest attempt!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Joe Wright does an amazing job presenting the victorian age on screen, giving  us that Jane Austin satire of the civility in the age. His direction in terms of segway to scenes as well as the scenes themselves are very moving and seem to put you in the world of Austin. It is a thoroughly enjoyable period piece, with truly colorful imagery, and a good tension between Elizabeth & Mr. Darcy...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I guess I am spoiled by the Colin Firth version or presentation. This presentation they plow through, talk fast and spend more time making faces. However the wide long shots of the country side are impressive (especially in Blu-ray). I have seen some to the houses in a TV production on "Great Houses of Britain". However Donald Sutherland is a good contributor as Mr. Benet.Oh Great Scott, forget about what I said in the first paragraph as the presentation finally picks up as everyone gets over the initial deceptions. So do not give up on this movie too early. Finally we get the highs and lows that we planned on.It is not the easiest thing to tell the story as by the time you view this presentation you should already be familiar with Jane Austen. If not we do not eat to give too many things away. To say that the Bennet family of all daughters will lose their meager estate at the passing of the father. Only a male can inherit property.So it is time to marry off the daughters. As the story unfolds you will understand the title of the story. The main focus is on the banter between Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy surrounded by others that are also posturing. Is there opportunity that all well be well in the end or will the whole thing unravel?For people not acquainted with Jane Austin you will see that she is not an obscure writer of only a hand full of novels but someone that was taken from us too soon.Screenplay by Deborah Moggach. We have not heard the last from her yet.
summary: At first they walking through the motions

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I saw that there was yet another version of Pride and Prejudice being released, I was a bit skeptical that anything new could be done to bring Austen's book alive on screen.  I loved the book, and I loved the old Olivier version of the film.  My skepticism disappeared as I watched the film, however.Yes, the script departs from the novel, but that's to be expected.  What I truly enjoyed was that the characters were portrayed in a way that I'd always imagined.  Mr. Bennett is long-suffering and sweet, with a wry wit.  Mrs. Bennett is a hilarious busybody, who really does love her daughters.  Jane is beautiful and dignified.  Elizabeth is sassy, smart, and stubborn.  Mr. Darcy is (very) handsome and dashing, while still being endearingly socially awkward.  Mr. Collins is wonderfully icky.Another thing I enjoyed was that many of the scenes were beautifully shot. Mr. Darcy's quick doubletake when he sees Elizabeth at the party, and the close shot of him flexing his hand after helping Elizabeth from the carriage are wonderful.  The near-kiss scene during the rainstorm could make even very sensible women feel a bit fluttery.  The gorgeous scenery-- magnificent old houses, gnarled old trees, foggy meadows-- add to the romance of the film.I do have two quarrels with the film, however.  The two youngest Bennett sisters are a bit too giddy, and their giggling becomes tiresome after a while.  Also, the ending was more sappy than romantic.I first watched the film last night, ordered it today, and can't wait to watch it again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm so glad I saw this. One liners like, 'I'm bewitched with you mind, body and soul' just TOTALLY inspire! SEE THIS!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I first read the original P&P in high school and fell in love. Named my daughter after Austen. Own every BBC adaptation of her work, including the 1995 Firth version. I love it, of course (isn't it sacrilegious to say otherwise?) but felt the characters were sometimes miscast--they seemed older in that version...and though it kept somewhat close to the text, there were some things that fell flat to me. In this version, there are obviously adaptations and changes--but I love the casting. I think the casting, music and visuals are perfections. The dancing scenes? You can feel the energy. I love Caroline Bingley in this--perfection! And Mrs./Mr. Bennet? I love the interaction. I feel like I can see the "family" part of the Bennets in this--the relationships feel extraordinarily real. And I think that Jane Austen would approve of that. Yes it's not perfect. Yes, there are things changed/left out. But I'm okay with that. Each adaptation has its strengths--and I love this one as much as any!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: On the one hand, the music, the costumes, the hair, and the scenery are all very well done; and the movie does have a good fast pace to it.  The designers showed great perception in having different levels of up-to-dateness and fashion among the various characters; the visuals are almost without fault, and the soundtrack is not bad at all.On the other hand, Jane Austen should never seem fast-paced, even within the limitations of cutting a novel down to fit within 2 hours or so (there's a reason why there's a mystery series where the detective is Jane Austen herself) and there is also lacking in the movie a sense of Jane Austen's ineffable good humor.  People are all to willing to tell their secrets, and constantly saying "Oh, didn't you know? . . ."  and, for example, when Charlotte announces that she is to marry Mr. Collins, she exclaims, "Don't you dare judge me, Lizzie!" when there was no question of Elizabeth judging Charlotte in the book at all, only questioning her future happiness.So you'll probably enjoy the movie more if you're not a Jane Austen fan to begin with than if you are.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I like that this version of the story is well done, but still lets the nuances of the time the story was set in come through.  Great choices for actresses and actors!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is perhaps my favorite tale of society culture and men and young women finding love. It is also my favorite Jane Austin book and movie and series.  It is set at just about the turn of the century in around 1800.  It must have been a naughty kind of a read because Austin really does use the book to poke fun at the Aristocracy and the way they turn their noses down at everyone.  There is one slightly superior BBC version made up of several episodes where the young lady who played Elizabeth is just as pretty as Keira Knightly with long and beautiful black hair and an ivory complexion, but I so enjoyed this one too.  How indifference becomes irritation and then almost hate before we see an perfect partner as who he or she really is must be the most endearing story of romance.  They each see a reflection of each other in their stubborn pride and it's what each dislike about themselves.  Well, they have to get over that because there is a lot they share in common.  Darcy is very handsome, but shy.  Elizabeth is very beautiful and used to speaking her mind.  Her father encourages that a great deal.  Her mom is pushing all the girls to get married and Elizabeth will not be married just to obtain a better station in life for herself.  The poor and lower aristocracy is represented in the Bennetts with Elizabeth as one of many daughters.  They are intelligent and spirited and have a good opinion of themselves.  Mr Darcy and his friend Mr. Bingley come to stay in their own grand homes.  They are high aristocracy.  Can rich fall in love with poor? Does wealth matter very much when love is what matters.  We shall see and you will enjoy the whole funny, tender, and mishap filled road to romance.  Very, very enjoyable and really quite hopeful and upbeat overall.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Great film when you want to snuggle up with your partner with a bowl of popcorn, or a little wine and cheese. Funny, well written, well acted and thoroughly entertaining.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: An excellent cast is almost completely wasted in this production, in which Austen's rich characters, social commentary, ascerbic wit, and wonderful language are stripped away to make room for a banal, brooding romance.For the Austen reader the film's main attraction is the intellectual appeal of its attempt to present a different interpretation of the novel. (Warning... be prepared for some really, really, really clumsy editing, writing and adaptation.) In addition to that, and to its lush, if greasy, production values, there is consolation in the wonderful form of Judi Dench, the first actress to create a truly intimidating Lady Catherine - hence the two-star, rather than a one-star, rating.To the non-Austen reader, in search of a cute movie, this is likely just the ticket.If you're thinking of buying it, though, I'd wait for a year or so... by then the novelty should have worn off and the price cut by quite a bit.
summary: A comic book version of a Harlequin romance edition of Pride and Prejudice the way Charlotte Bronte might  have written it

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride and Prejudice is pretty bad.  It is more like a poorly produced junior high play than a movie.  Not even Judi Dench and Donald Sutherland can rescue this one.  The main actors are so flat.  They seem to want to rush through the movie to get it overwith and do not have any stage presence at all.  Only the camera angle and choreography of the scenes keeps your attention.  The acting of the main characters just isn't up to snuff - at all.  Buy the A&E Version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle from Amazon. It is an exquisite version that is exceptionally well done.  The "Americanized" air of this modern version leaves you wanting to watch the A&E version, even if it is much longer.
summary: Don't waste your money - buy the A&E Version!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was cativated by this movie.  After watching the mini-series with Colin Firth, I didn't think a remake could come close to it.  I was wrong.  This movie had my attention from beginning to end.  Yes, you can turn a five hour mini-series into a two hour movie without losing anything.  The chemistry between Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen brought a new freshness to Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy.  I still can't get enough of it even after seeing it five times.  I can't wait to add it to my Pride and Predjuice collection.  But until then, I just be content with seeing it 10 or 15 more times at least.
summary: Great Movie.  It Bewitched Me Body And Soul.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I may be the only person in the world to not like the 1995 BBC version of P&P.; I was cringing inside right before I started watching this one terrified they were going to butcher Austen's language like that adaptation. But I was pleasantly surprised to hear the good old words I know and love. The screenplay is wonderful. Thank you, thank you, thank you! They have chopped out a lot of scenes from the book and shortened a lot of speeches, but what they have retained is mostly verbatim and/or sounds just like Austen and will not offend.What else is there to say? Everything about it is fantastic. Music, acting, direction. As an art historian, I was especially enraptured with the cinematography, scenery and use of art. It was amazing. I love the genre scenes around her house with the hay bales, man with pipe, pigs.This is without a doubt the sexiest P&P; I've ever seen. Its all about the passions that are exploding beneath the surface. Matthew MacFadyen is especially good at conveying this.Notice what the director does with the theme of eyes and looking. Jane says, "One of these days someone is going to catch your eye and then you'll have to watch your tongue!" In the very next scene Darcy appears and when he's walking down the room at the first ball he does the smallest of double takes when he sees her. Its all about the glances towards and away from each other. Keira is wonderful with her eyes, especially in the last scene.Brenda Blethyn = hilarious. The best Mrs. Bennett I've seen. Rosamund Pike = perfect. Keira Knightly = brilliant. I liked Donald Sutherland, but please. That was not the Mr. Bennet. They've sweetened him to a ridiculous degree. Doesn't bother me, but its a flagrant departure from the book. I greatly missed Elizabeth and Darcy sparring at Netherfield. "Your defect is a propensity to hate everybody!" That was the only scene that I really did miss, though, and they cut out a lot. Otherwise I hardly noticed it. Best scene = the "car crash" proposal in the thunderstorm.This is a gorgeous, romantic film. Absolutely loved it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my favorite love story and this version is fantastic. The score is amazing. The tension between Elizabeth and Darcy is electric.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although I believed the A&E version could never be replaced in my heart due to its true-to-the-book writing, this is a wonderful sweetened condensed version and sparks a great romantic chord.  Though I still adore the A&E version and would recommend it to anyone who's never read the book or is, like myself, a purist, this is a great little flick.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved this movie. Up until now I've been a fan of the BBC/A & E version. Honestly I don't understand the people who are almost religious about having the novel match up the film 100%. You can't always do that on film, especially if you want to have a good movie, and what is it with people being picky about historical accuracies, come on its a movie, not a history book. The film is pretty loyal to Austen's novel and its not like it tries to intentionally mess up on the period that its set in. In short, don't be religious about things. Get over it. This movie is perfect as it is and I love it, its even better than the BBC/A & E version. Keira Knightley is an excellent actress and one that I look forward to watching over the years.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I own the BBC version of "Pride and Prejudice" and I must say that both films were good in their own rights.  I do believe that anyone viewing either of these two fine films must judge them as such instead of comparing the two.I will admit that this version has proven to be a favorite of mine between the two (I watch it at least once a week - gotta have my dose of Darcy *grin).  For one, this version was more "romantic" to me - Darcy helping Lizzie into the carriage, Darcy watching Lizzie on the ballroom floor, etc.  This really assisted in making Darcy's sudden proposal to Lizzie more believable whereas in the A & E version (not comparing, merely pointing out) - I was surprised by the declaration of love because I didn't see it coming.  There were no obvious signs that Darcy held any affections for Lizzie other than an occassional glance here and there.  In short, Firth and Eahle lacked the chemistry that Knightley and McFayden had in this version of the film.  Although I absolutely adore Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy - it took me a minute to warm up to him as he initially came off as a snob.  Matthew Macfayden portrays Darcy as more of a man who although he possesses great wealth, he lacks simple social skills.  I fell in love with the sweetness of his face and the scene with him walking across the field as his long coat blows in the breeze accompanied by that gorgeous music...*fanning self frantically  His walk, his voice, and his magnificent physique combined have made me stand up and unashamedly declare that MATTHEW MCFAYDEN IS "THE" MR. DARCY!!!Also, the fact that this film was slightly over 2 hours as opposed to the other, longer versions of the story was a definite plus to me.For those reviewers who wish to harp about the clothing being wrong for the time period or certain behaviors being unacceptable and unheard of for that era...give it a rest, please!  I am an avid reader of historical romances and an avid viewer of period pieces, most with romantic themes, and I'm here to tell you that when I'm in the mood for a good romance - I could care less if the heroe's cravat is knotted incorrectly for that time of the evening during that particular time period - I'm more concerned with a good romance!  And this version of "Pride and Prejudice" delivers just that!  A beautiful and romantic tale!  Now if Mr. Darcy had decided to deal with Lizzie's rejection by flopping in front of the t.v. to watch reruns of "The Golden Girls" I might have had issues.  *laugh  You get my point though - those details are minor.  In the end, it's the story that counts.I would DEFINITELY recommend to anyone looking for a sweet romance and a wonderful film.p.s. I mistakenly hit four stars when I meant to hit five!  Amazon doesn't allow you to change your rating for some odd reason.  *shrug  Trust me when I say - this film is all of 5 stars!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice has been translated to film several times now - from Robert Leonard's 1940 "attempt" starring Laurence Olivier, to the 1980 and 1995 TV miniseries', and now on to a new theatrical release here. Having read the book and seen all of these adaptations, I feel I can comment objectively on what does and doesn't work with regards to director Joe Wright's newest version.Let's start with the positives. It's beautifully filmed (from gnarled old trees to stunning sunsets against old English mansions) and the cast performs well. I even liked Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods, FOYLE'S WAR TV series) and the rest of the actors. They seemed to be able to grasp the internal dynamics of their respective characters and pulled in fine performances. Keira Knightley (BEND IT LIKE BECKHAM, 2002) does a good job as Lizzie Bennett but appears upbeat far too often during a time when love and loss went hand in hand. Matthew Macfayden (WUTHERING HEIGHTS TV series) does an admirable Mr. Darcy but being up against a giant of the English acting world from a previous adaptation made his character representation a bit tougher when it came to comparisons.Now let's get into my main problem: the pacing. I usually don't mind fast-paced films, but Jane Austen's book is anything but quick (checking in at around 500 pages depending on which publisher you choose). Books of this size tend to be difficult to translate to the silver screen (or TV) because of their scope, and this was the big "ouch" for this film. Clocking in at 129 minutes, condensing the book in such a drastic manner meant clipping out chapters and causing a bit of confusion. The confusion comes from the lack of understanding a new viewer might have IF they've never seen any of the previous TV/movie versions or IF they've never read the novel. When Lydia runs off with "the wrong man" it is a vital portion of the story that is only touched on and could seem disorienting to the new Pride and Prejudice viewer. We never see what happens to Lydia in London, nor do we see the wedding and where Mr. Darcy's pressure exerts itself.Comparisons will obviously be made between this theatrical release and the 1995 miniseries (which many, including myself, feel is the penultimate adaptation of Mrs. Austen's book). Some might complain that it isn't fair to make such comparisons because one was designed for television while the other was meant for theater. I'll grant that. But with the lengthy films that've come out of Hollywood lately (Lord of the Rings, King Kong, etc.), I don't feel that this new version would've suffered in the slightest by lengthening its running time and thus adding a better sense of coherency to many of the side stories. The 1995 miniseries also had an incredible benefit in that Mr. Darcy was played by the estimable Colin Firth (SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE, 1998), and it is THIS Mr. Darcy that many hold as the high standard for such work. Try putting Matthew Macfayden up against Mr. Firth and you'll see what I mean; there's just no comparing them.I did give this film a positive review because a) I liked the cinematography, and b) the acting was generally well done. But for emotional impact and excellent character portrayals look to the 1995 miniseries.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This adaption of the book is STUNNING.  Please stop reading this review and purchase it.  The intelligence, beauty and grace of the people and scenery are unparalleled.  I thought I had seen every possible version.  I was wrong.  It is so amazing to see how our society today has degraded.  In this period and time, there was just a "knowing" of your social manners, graces and the Art of Conversation.When you purchase this, just sit back and absorb the time period and let this movie take you away and enjoy the fantasy.  It is all good from the very first frame to the last credit.Enjoy!!~

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie adaptation does a surprisingly good job of slimming down Ms. Austen's original by somewhat reinterpreting it.  Movies do have to vigorously cut a book down to size, and Ms. Moggach (with a little help from Emma Thompson) did a right fine job. In fact, in some ways the changes actually improve upon the book.  Heresy, I know, but supportable.  For instance, Mrs. Bennett seems less a caricature and more an actual human.  Her annoying proclivities and her relationship to Mr. Bennett are less condescendingly (in the modern sense) drawn.  Also, the relationship between Elizabeth and her friend Ms. Lucas captures real warmth not really present in the book.  Some characters are less well drawn and the movie suffers as a result.  I’m thinking principally of Mr. Wickham.  In any case, as with any movie based on a beloved book, it is difficult to properly capture the writer’s language, and it is Austen’s use of the English language that causes me to return to the novel with regularity.  Thus, I give this movie four stars.  That said, the writer did some fine cherry picking to retain some favorite lines.  By the way, as others have noted, if you want a more complete and excellent visual production of Ms. Austen’s masterpiece, seek the 1995 Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle BBC television version.  It has multiple episodes to work with and takes full advantage of the extra time.The leads in this movie version are quite good.  Ms. Knightly shines brilliantly.  All of the supporting cast, with the possible exception of Bingley’s sister and Mr. Wickham, are also outstanding.  Even here I am admittedly quibbling because I am not sure the writer or director gave (or could give) them much to work with.  The casting of Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourgh was, frankly, perfect.  That woman is amazing.Now having watched this movie version, I know I will watch it again.  I broke down and bought the BD/DVD combo from Amazon.  I certainly recommend it, even to the strongest of Ms. Austen's fans.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Someone next to you on an airplane says, "I'm studying filmmaking and cinematography."  I would say, "When are you going to get a real job?"This version of P&P; shows people like me what craftspeople can do who are at the height of the film making profession.  This is occasionally (not always - thus four stars) a visually stunning film, and I don't mean Keira's face (Austen must have rolled over in her grave with that casting.)The version I like to think Jane A. would have preferred is of course the fabulous BBC version with Colin Firth as Darcy, and the wonderful Jennifer Ehle, who was born to play Elizabeth.Anyway, the camera people and the screenplay people made certain moments of this P&P; as visually moving as any I've seen in a long time.  The scene with Liz on the swing as the seasons change; the early morning scene when Darcy and Liz meet in the ...fog; the camera movement at the second ball, the confrontation in the rain; etc., these I could watch a thousand times.  Offsetting these, are the terrible ending, the family scene at the beginning, and several other weak moments (the statue admiration scene at Darcy's mansion...is she staring at what I think she's staring at?!)  Had I directed, I would have added more "edge."  More humor, more angst, more terror.But I enjoyed this latest interpretation of this masterpiece. I think you will too.  But don't see it without also seeing the BBC production.  You'll enjoy comparing the two.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not the type of a viewer who sees a movie over and over. But on the next day after I first saw this Pride and Prejudice, I couldn't help me from thinking of the beatiful scenes, reruning the whole thing, the words spoken by Mr. Darcy and Lizzie. I kept on searching for more and more of this movie on the Internet. And I had to come home earlier than I usually do to see this movie again. I had to finish this movie again without a single pause. Still so fresh, I just wanted to remember every bit of this movie. This movie "bewitched my body and soul". Not to mention the charm of Matthew MacFadyen who played Mr. Darcy, now I am planning on trip to Chatsworth in England where Pemberly, the house of Mr. Dacy, is.
summary: BEST FILM EVER - saw three times already, but not enough!!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Was one of the best movies I have ever seen!Keira Knightley is a great actress. Like her in everything I have seen of her.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being an avid fan of this Jane Austen classic, I must say that this version is just lovely!  I have read the book, seen both the black & white version with Laurence Olivier and watched the BBC version with Colin Firth several times. Now after watching this newest version for about the 12th time I think it is by far the best adaptation!  Though it doesn't cover all the intricate details of the story and the characters the way the BBC version does, this new version offers so much more in the way of such spectacular scenery and breathtaking scenes of vivid emotion between Elizabeth and Darcy. With this version you really feel as though you were there witnessing how the Bennets really lived in a way that's easier to visualize and relate to.  Further more, it was quite refreshing to see Keira put so much feeling and personality into her role like I have never seen "Elizabeth" portrayed before. No matter how many times I see this splendid film it never ceases to make my heart skip a beat!  To anyone that's read the book or seen the BBC version, I hope you find this version as heartwarming and romantic as I do!
