title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yet another Jane Austen movie?  You could say that this stinker is an Austen-INSPIRED movie.  But any inspiration was all on Miss Austen's side.  Any movie adaptation must take some artistic license even with a literary classic, but this dreadful production takes too many unforgiveable liberties.  This is for the crowd that reads Austen and thinks, "Great story, but where's the sex?"The movie goes off course in very basic ways--plot, theme, characters and setting.  The principal characters are prominent people of means.  Why do they all look as though they need a hairbrush and a bath?  Mr. Bennet is a solitary bookworm with an acerbic wit.  How did he become become a disheveled hick?  Miss Austen writes that Elizabeth had a lively air of sportive playfulness that made it difficult for her to offend anybody.  So why are we treated to so many views of Keira Knightley's bared, vampiric teeth as she bites off her sadly abridged lines?  Matthew Fayden is an equally unsatisfactory Darcy, so far removed from the handsome, elegant, arrogance of the original that we keep waiting for the hero to show up and get the story going.  Lady Catherine is all sweaty vitriol, too vituperative to be as ridiculous as she should be.The change of setting to the Georgian period is a poor fit, as is the barnyard the Bennets appear to occupy.  Mr. Bennet is a gentleman, not a gentleman farmer.  The Elizabeth-Darcy romance is better attuned to the early age of romanticism, particularly in the relationship of the characters to nature.  Austen heroines like to be outdoors, and many pivotal scenes take place in a garden.  This aspect was far better treated in the films "Sense and Sensibility" and "Persuasion," and the BBC's Austen productions, which are more appropriately set in the Regency period.Worst of all is that final scene!  Like so many dimwitted authors who spin off Austen's novels into hot steaming garbage, someone tacked a jarring final scene onto this film that feels all the more coarse for bringing such an elegant tale to a tasteless conclusion.  Not that all the scenes that precede it are much better; but they merely distort the story.  Its clumsy ending hammers it into a cynical, profit-seeking uber-anachronism.
summary: Mr. and Mrs. Bennet as Ma and Pa Kettle

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off, I am an avid lover of the BBC P&P; with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. That being said, when I first watched this movie, I could not help but compare Matthew and Keira to the two actors I loved.  I had decidedly hated it before it was even completed!I watched it again and enjoyed it a bit more.  The actors who portray Jane and Bingley do a great job.  I loved Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet and Dame Judi as Lady Catherine...After a third viewing (thanks to my DVR), I have bought it.  I like that I can get the story in 2 hours instead of 6, if I am in a "hurry" for some Austen.  :)  Matthew's Darcy talks a bit to fast for me at some times and Keira's Elizabeth can be a bit wooden, but there are times where their sparks do outshine Colin and Jennifer's.  If watched with an open mind, maybe it will grow on you as well.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My all-time favorite novel! Jane Austin at her best. A great story about love and misunderstanding. If you haven't read it yet, get it!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a classic romance story that is not a tear jerker. I can watch it over and over. It is about breaking the mold of a class consious society. There are some good values in this movie. It has become my favorite movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I purchased this on a friend's recommendation, but I wish I had read more of the reviews first. An earlier reviewer described this as P&P as written by Charlotte Bronte and that about sums it up. Austen's sly social commentary and witty observations on human nature have been replaced by atmospheric shots of rain-drenched, fog-filled gloom and wavering shadows in candle-lit rooms. Elizabeth comes across as shrewish and broody, with none of the vivacity and quick wit of the original. Darcy seems dull and socially backward instead of a man restrained by his own rigid view of propriety and his place in the social caste. The secondary cast get only one or two pertinent lines from the novel to establish their character and motives, which reduces the circumstances that drive the plot to a one-dimensional Cliff Notes version of P&P.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was certain it was impossible to improve upon the BBC's stellar interpretation of P&P.;  I was sure that no one could improve upon Jennifer Ehle and I was certain that Colin Firth was the penultimate Darcy.  This movie proved me wrong.Firstly, I want to address Keira Knightley's interpretation of my all-time favorite literary heroine.  She had the spark and fire and quick wit that is so characteristic of Elizabeth.  I thought her performance was pitch perfect and I give her the edge of Ehle.  While I do really like Ehle's rather more sedate Elizabeth, I really liked Knightley's more impetuous version.  Her outbursts sprang from her with such passion and impatience that I felt she had really nailed the character.As for Darcy, I love Firth's arrogant but socially awkward portrayal.  Because of this, I was glad to see Matthew Macfadyen play Darcy as something of a nerd.  It was an interpretation of Darcy that I'd never pictured but I think it worked splendidly.  Rather than being overtly haughty as Firth's Darcy was, Macfadyen's Darcy was painfully socially awkward and who came across as arrogant because of it.  His Darcy was intensely private and unwilling to give up his family secrets and yet all the more pained for how he knew it made him seem to Elizabeth.The rest of the cast is stellar as well, though I won't go into great depth or I'll risk running on for pages.  I particularly liked Elizabeth's warm relationship with her father and the way his eyes teared over when he wished Elizabeth happiness in her betrothal.  I also liked the way Mrs. Bennett was made more complex and her motivations made more clear.  After all, what did a woman of that social standing have to do other than ensure her daughters made prosperous marriages?  Mrs. Bennett seems so silly until one considers just how stressful it must have been to have to worry about the welfare of so many girls and to be constantly conscious of how quickly they'd sink into poverty and oblivion if their father--the sole breadwinner--were to become ill or die.The film itself is wonderfully layered and I find that with each viewing I see subtle things I had not before noticed.  It certainly bears repeat viewings not just for the wonderful story, gorgeous scenery, and stellar acting but also for the subtle background touches that become apparent once one focuses on them rather than the action occurring in the foreground.  This version is rife with small gestures and looks that speak volumes about what is occurring in the story.  Simply put, I adore this film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie does just what a classic love story should.  It takes two headstrong people with (very) different backgrounds and throws them together against the backdrop of an over-polite society and social prejudice.Each and every actor in this film is perfect and thoroughly believable.Kiera Knightley, though playing a character with limited opportunity to show her evident quickness of tongue, managed to jut her chin and give back-handed insults just enough to flaunt the independent spirit of Elizabeth Bennet.Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy was an interesting casting choice.  What I particularly like about this man was that he isn't your average pretty boy.  Macfadyen gave the character (and audience) something more than just the gorgeous smile and perfectly placed hair so often seen on Hollywood screens.Rosamund Pike, playing Elizabeth's sister Jane, shone in a supporting role.  Her short scenes were beautiful, full of hope, tears-on-cue, and occasional self-doubt.And it's not just Rosamund either.  The other supporting characters, in all their glory, delivered just enough giggling or disdain or awkwardness as was required.I definitely enjoyed this movie.  It made me think.Just a warning: you may be initially caught off guard by a certain important protestation of love from one character to another, but, upon review, you will discover that significant looks and the like were evident throughout the earlier bits of the film.Rent or buy this ASAP - you won't regret it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have to say that I am a huge fan of the book and the BBC version with Colin Firth. Sadly, I absolutely despise this version of Pride and Prejudice. Of course, I expected much of the story line to be abbreviated given the 2 hr running time, but I did not expect the blatant disregard for the integrity of Austen's characters. It was bad enough to see Jane's sweet disposition misrepresented, but the oversimplification and shallowness of the Eliza and Mr. Darcy characters is unforgivable.Eliza was silly and flip without any of the depth, thoughtfulness, and complexity that her character merits. Mr. Darcy was sullen, brooding, and dull instead of being aloof and reserved. Neither character demonstrated the depth and range of character portrayed in the book, perhaps because the movie doesn't ring true with the formality and strictness of British society during that time that is conveyed in Austen's novel. Instead, the movie overly glamorizes the period and indulges the characters with glitzy, unrestrained, and sappy romantic conversational tripe. I couldn't even finish the last ten minutes of the movie!If you have any love or respect for Austen's story, I would not watch this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: ..I still was able to find the charm in this one. I dare say I enjoyed it very much!  I like both the Firth and the Knightley versions. Funny how when we think of the BBC we think more of Mr. Darcy (Firth) and when we think of this one we think more of Elizabeth (Knightley).There are many scenes from each of the P&Ps; that I can say I like over the other, so I can't pick a true favorite version. Even with significant script downsizing and tweaking in this version, overall you still get the many *SIGH* moments between Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth and the laugh out loud moments with Mr. Collins (I'm forever a fan of the Hollander actor who played him in this rendition!). You sympathize and adore Charlotte (who is very believable as the plain "spinster-in-the-making" than the other versions) and WHO can bring aristocracy to the screen like the dame Judi?  This role was made for her and out of all P&P; ladyships, she is by far my favorite portrayal. I was also happy with the Lydia casting - her portrayal was the perfect comedic silly and selfish.LOVED Donald Sutherland's Mr. Bennett!  You get an idea of why they aren't in the best financial shape with his laid back and resigned attitude - the go-getter he is not. The scene between he and Lizzie at the end is very touching.  Any daddy's little girl will be moved when they watch it.  I know I was and still am every time I see it.Matthew MacFayden did a fine job with his portrayal of the handsome and initially stoic and snobbish Mr. Darcy.  I think his emotions and tenderness really trasmitted itself well across the screen as his feelings grew for Elizabeth.  Truly FINE performances from all of the cast.Some have brought up the discrepancies in this P&P;, yet I do not remember Mr. Darcy swimming in a lake and coming out of it sexy and dripping wet in the book like he did in the Firth version - yet we do not complain about it. That's because it was a GREAT scene (for the ladies) and it didn't take away from the movie.  There are going to be changes in each one, as long as it doesn't take away from the romance of the two and the gist of the story (again many only have 2 hours), I think when given a chance, P&P; lovers will really enjoy this one.I would have loved to have seen more effort with the costume designs, but overall I really LOVED the movie and occasionally when I have 2 hours on a rainy day, I'll pop it in. It's one of my rainy day favorites!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I find making comparisons to the BBC miniseries pointless--this film has to do the book in two hours, and so the 'compression' is necessary and somewhat works in this adaptation's favor. Further, I give Joe Wright a great deal of credit for building the film as much around Keira Knightly as her character; she's way too attractive to be playing Elizabeth, so he made the right call in turning the dynamic of the story and the pace of the film more suitable to modern-day "hopeless romantics" than a Regency period piece. I wanted to quibble at first, but I think it makes a superior film: while not all the compromises worked, the film was shot and edited so well that many of the changes were extremely moving (I particularly liked the obvious symbolism of the sculptures in the Pemberly estate)...and I actually thought the characterization of Bingley was perfect. Besides, Keira Knightly has arguably the best smile I've ever seen; I could spend hours just looking at it. And if she wants to spout a few of Austen's lines while looking purty, I'm all eyes and ears.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've been meaning to buy this movie for the longest. I'm so glad they have on Blu ray and with the digital copy I can download it onto my iPad.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The rating was for certain a 5! My package was received nice and wrapped! (no scratches or scrapes)The only disappointment I found was that I had made a trip to Wal Mart soon after I ordered and saw that the movie was only $5.00!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I know this is not a new movie, but I only recently purchased it.  This is one of my all-time favorite Jane Austin novels and the movie lives up to the book in every way!  What I love about Austin is her ingenius plots and think about it: you don't realize she's hooked you completely until the end of the movie/book when you're on the edge of your seat.  Now THAT is brilliance.  I would recommend this movie to anyone.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I suppose if you've never read Pride and Prejudice this may be a fine film (that's why I gave it two stars instead of just one), but it in NO way does any justice to Jane Austen's novel. Perhaps it's impossible to build the depth of character the way Austen does in a 2 hour movie, but it's because it was only 2 hours long that I was able to even sit through this movie. From the start I was sceptical of Kiera Knightly as Elizabeth Bennett, but in the end it wasn't her performance that disappointed - the whole movie was seriously lacking. Maybe Austen just can't be satisfied in 2 hours, but I was left thinking, That's it? What a sorry tribute to a classic.This version is FAR inferior to the A&E; miniseries (about 5 hours of Eliza and Mr. Darcy) which aired on Masterpiece Theatre and, I felt, illustrated the novel as beautifully as an on-screen adaptation can. If you'd like to see this classic on the screen, make time for the A&E; version and forget this one.
summary: Don't read the book, you'll just be disappointed in this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Another example of the contemporary inability to render a classic in anything like its original intent, sense or form. Here we have a parade of third millennium anachronisms almost as preposterous as those on display in the equally absurd current rendering of "Tristan and Isolde." Thus, our heroine Kiera Knightley sails through the whole film with a saucy, feminist tinged, "cat that swallowed the canary," facial expression and vocal delivery, that suggest that she has been watching a great deal of Katie Couric and Elizabeth Vargas, and is dying to drop the word "empowerment," somewhere into her dialogue.Then there's the "incomparable," Judi Dench--(as the publicity breathlessly assures us). For some incomprehensible reason, contemporary casting directors' are under the lamentable delusion that Miss Dench, (like Maggie Smith) is somehow suited to grande dame roles--when nothing could be further from the truth.Having seen Miss Dench on stage in a five hour production of "Cymbeline," at Stratford on Avon, I can personally attest to her range and power as an actress. However, whatever her qualifications for Shakespeare, there is nothing in her appearance or deportment that is remotely aristocratic in the 18th/19th century sense of the term.Indeed, if anything, her persona is pronouncedly proletariat.Add to that her coarse and rubicund complexion, (un-pancaked in the current naturalistic mode) and her Lady Catherine appears more like a refugee from a Hogarthian gin palace than the daunting and imperious creature Miss Austen intended.Martita Hunt where are you now that we need you?There is little to say about Donald Sutherland in the role of Mr. Bennet, inasmuch as he has built a successful career out of being miscast--a feat he continues with this role. And his wife in the picture, (far from the lavender, rose silk and cream Mary Boland of yore) looks like a blowsy, overage bawd from the cast of a backwoods dinner theater production of "Moll Flanders," who has somehow wandered onto the wrong movie set.But mercifully we at length arrive at the priceless (and now requisite) final clinch, where Miss Knightley and Mr. Macfadyen are depicted in the lotus position on a lake in front of their chteau, where they proceed to launch into a demonstration of mutual affection that looks like a TV promo for "The Bachelor," and makes one wonder if Brad Pitt and Julia Roberts are standing just outside of camera range whispering instructions.For now if you absolutely require a filmed alternative to the novel itself--stick with the 1940 Greer Garson or unfairly ignored 1979 British TV version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I like this newest film adaption of Jane Austen's classic "Pride and Prejudice."  I won't rehash the plot here or where the movie differs from the novel, as numerious other reviews have already done so.  I think the movie is loyal to the novel where it counts, and that is the courtship of Fitzwilliam Darcy and Elizabeth Bennett.  Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen breath new life into the characters of Elizabeth and Darcy and they truly inhabit their respective roles.  I particularly liked Macfadyen's Darcy, as he seems much more feeling and would be the kind of person who would inspire the loyalty of his close friends and family as in the novel.  The supporting cast is also excellent and has some of the most beautiful women from accross the pond, including Rosamund Pike and the underused Kelly Reilly.  I highly recommend this fresh remake of "Pride and Prejudice."

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of My favorite movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen the BBC version and this version many times. Having just completed reading the book again yesterday, I wanted to watch this movie to cap it off. For all of the doubters, it truly is a wonderful portrayal of the characters, their over-the-top strengths and weaknesses, and incredible cinematography, which captures Elizabeth Bennett very well. In the book, Elizabeth is supposed to be only 20 years old, and Kiera Knightly brings an excellent zeal and youthfulness to the character, not found in the BBC version. The angst and lovesickness seen in Mr. Darcy is accurate to the writer's wishes, and the absurdity of Lydia, Mrs. Bennett and the girls is portrayed well. The director took a little license with Mr. Bennett's character, making him a little more caring and loving than the book portrays but it adds a nice element to the movie without detracting from the true story line.I loved it! I have loved it! I will continue to love it!
summary: True Jane Austen fan, True Jane Austen Movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love stories from this era.  It was heartwarming to see a shy aristrocrat fall in love.  It is typical of mother's with all daughters to marry them off as soon as possible - hopefully to someone with money to bail the family out of financial difficulties.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a well-filmed, well-acted adaptation of P&P.  I'm not going to compare it to the '95 A&E version because this is a 2 hour and 10 minute (or so) version and there are things that couldn't be included, unlike the lengthy '95 P&P.  Keira Knightley did a wonderful job of playing a rather elfin Elizabeth Bennet.  I especially enjoyed her lifted eyebrow as she taunted Darcy.  She represents a youthful Elizabeth Bennet and her youth was a refreshing touch to the character.  Matthew Macfadyen does a good job brooding his way through most of the movie as Mr. Darcy, but he does look a bit silly when he is allowed to show his feelings toward Miss Bennet later in the film. He goes all mushy! (Stick with the glowering, Matthew!)  One of the best touches to the set was that the Bennet's house was surrounded by livestock, dirt, and everyday activities.  It made for a great contrast to Mr. Darcy's home with it's immaculate grounds and perfect furnishings.  This was a wonderful movie, though too short to do full justice to the story.  I will be buying it and I recommend it to any Pride & Prejudice fan.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If I hadn't been spolied by just discovering the 1995 BBC TV version of Pride and Prejudice with Colin Firth, I would have called the movie great, so I admit I'm spoiled. That said, the MI-5 star as Darcy actually worked well, as did lovely Keira Knightley. If you haven't seen either version, watch this one FIRST!.All said, if it had not been for the casting of Donald Sutherland as the father, I think this would have been an even  better movie than it already is.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As good as period movies get.  There is not a weak link in the cast.  The movie is full of texture and depth.  Beautifully shot. Just buy it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, gotta chime in that the point of different clothing coming from different times was the point-the eldest Bennet girl would have the newest clothing, with the younger sisters getting hand me downs along the way. The point being, that the dresses weren't meant to fit perfectly as they were usually from an older sister's, and were not necessarily the fashion of the time. And yes, even thin strapped dresses like Miss Bingley's Netherfield Ball were around for that time, and was meant to convey how fashionista forward Miss Bingley was. I mean, come on folks, costume designers for these types of movies aren't picked off the street or something! There's usually a game plan invovled that's more detailed and comprehensive than the average viewer gives them credit for.But who cares about clothing-this is a great movie. It's entertaining, enjoyable, and allows the Bennets to be seen in a more lively, grounded way as oppossed to the sentimentalized way we are more used to for Austen features. It recalls "Persuasion" in that sense, another Austen cinematic favorite of mine.
summary: The clothing was MEANT to come from different times!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The mid-90's deluge of Jane Austen adaptations left little room for improvement. The definitive versions of all six of Austen's major novels have already been made, leaving me to wonder why any new adaptations should be made. Movies like "Bride and Prejudice" and books like the "Bridget Jones" duo (based on "Pride and Prejudice" and "Persuasion", respectively) have managed to reexamine the timeless stories with modern infusions of wit, romance, and tragedy.The new "Pride and Prejudice", however, offers nothing new except its mediocrity. The fault lies mainly with those behind the cameras, who appear to have do little research into the time period, and with the two main love interests.The costumes and hairstyles are from twenty years before the movie is said to take place (in 1797) and certain musical instruments did not exist in 1797, but these glaring errors and their fellows pale before the complete failure of Matthew MacFayden and Keira Knightley to do justice to their characters. MacFayden, as Darcy, spends his time pouting and being sulky in corners of beautiful houses, and Knightley snarls her way through her scenes as Elizabeth Bennett. Her perfomance was an insult to the character -- Lizzy was never malicious, never cruel, and most of all, never a tomboy. She was firmly a woman who was resigned to her role as such, but was nonetheless clever enough to find ways around her predicted role. Keira Knightley was probably drowning in testosterone from her next abortive cinematic endeavor, "Domino".Without any interest in the two main characters, the movie must rely on its secondary characters. Rosamund Pike and Simon Woods as Jane Bennett and Charles Bingley are sweetly romantic; although their love is purposefully bland in its characterisation (the better to clash with Darcy and Lizzy!), their affection for each other is never in doubt. Pike in particular is a lovely, expressive Jane.Judi Dench is a welcome addition to the cast as Lady de Bourgh, Darcy's aristocratic aunt, and as the fluttery Mrs. Bennett, Brenda Blethyn is a quieter, more sympathetic version than the 1996 characterisation. The viewer begins to appreciate her plight: the job of making sure her five daughters make good matches is hers, and she has no money with which to do it. Is it any wonder she's a little crazy?For all intents and purposes, this movie tells the story adequately, but the lackluster, inaccurate production and the leads' lack of acting talent ruin any changes of making this an enjoyable viewing experience. The 1996 version of "Pride and Prejudice" remains the standard by which all Austen movies will be judged, and if you can't watch that version, don't believe for an instant that the new, sexed-up, Hollywood-ized version could ever be a decent replacement.
summary: Bias aside, this "Pride and Prejudice" cannot be allowed.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I won't review the movie here, but to summarize, it's a great rendition of the story (though not faithful enough for some).My complaint is with the format of the DVD. The widescreen version (16:9) should include more visual information than the fullscreen version (4:3). This DVD has less. Why?Movies are shot at a wide aspect ratio because movie theatres have screens that are quite a bit wider than conventional TV screens, relative to their height. That's why, when you buy a fullscreen version of a movie on DVD, you'll find that the right and left edges have been cut off. And that's why they have a note at the beginning that says "This presentation has been modified from the original, it has been reformatted to fit your screen".Guess what? The widescreen version of this DVD actually cuts off the top and bottom of the fullscreen version to make it fit a wider screen again!? What? Instead of going back to the original widescreen version they actually cut off more of the the (already cut off) regular TV version. What a disappointment...So, if you want to see as much of the fabulous original cinematography, get the fullscreen version. I can only hope the Blu-Ray version goes back to the original format.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I realize that time constraints often pose limits on screen writers but my disppointment with this film was not based on what was left out so much as what was put in.As others have expressed before me, the slovenly lifestyle of the Bennets portrayed in this version was a bit of a shock.  The Bennets were not well-to-do, but were comfortable in the book.  Even if those who produced this film thought it necessary to contrast the comparative wealth of Mr. Darcy with the Bennet's lack thereof, there was no need to equate poverty with mess, filth and general lack of attention to cleanliness.The dialogue of the screen writer clashed with the lines adapted from Jane Austen's work.  Elegant phrasing was painfully coupled with modern casual verbage.The characterization of Elizabeth and Jane Bennet should have stood in sharp contrast to those of their sisters and parents.  There was very little distinction between them.Elizabeth was often rude in her behaviors to others rather than spirited and witty.  She was hateful to her mother, aggressively invading Mr. Darcy's space when angry, and generally childish.Mr. Darcy seemed to be more an advertisement for the need of antidepressants than an attitude adjustment.Charlotte Lucas was desperate rather than practical.The comedy that should have been there in Lady Catherine, and Mr Collins was sadly lacking.On the plus side though, I did enjoy how the relationship between Mr. and Mrs. Bennet was portrayed with greater warmth than previous versions.  I saw them as much more sympathetic characters.I also thought the scene of Darcy and Elizabeth's awkwardness at their first meeting at his home was also well done.The music and scenery were both lovely.
summary: Could have been better but it still had a few nice moments

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I wasn't a big fan of the older versions of this story, but this one is great - worth watching several times in order to catch all of the nuances.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a huge fan of all BBC productions, particularly the Pride & Prejudice miniseries starring Colin Firth. He's one of my favorite Brits, and I'm quite an Anglophile. However, the miniseries is a six-hour event, and while there are some occasions which allow me that much time, this new version is much easier to handle in one sitting. It touches on all the highest points of the story, and displays a terrific chemistry between Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennett. In two hours, the viewer is transported to Regency England, with all the gorgeous scenery and beautiful music, where two most favored literary characters fall in love. The direction and cinematography is also much cleaner than the BBC's production, so I enjoy this version for that aspect as well. All in all, whenever I'm craving a delicious story and a unique romance, this is a terrific alternative to the six-hour miniseries. Having said that, if you haven't seen the BBC version, it's essential that you do!
summary: I love Colin Firth, but this is a great substitute!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Probably my favorite movie of all time, and when it went on sale for a very great price i had to get my own copy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is even worse than the Mormon one!  If you want to have any idea of what the novel is actually like, DO NOT watch this film.  People did not act, dress, speak, or live like this. It is truly abhorrent to me that this film has such high ratings, because it is *nothing* like the book, and the book is excellent.  That it leeched on Austen's work to be made, that a studio exec thought that this was a good idea, it's almost as bad (and successful) as "Springtime for Hitler" in THE PRODUCERS.  Completely outrageous!  The Mormon P&P was better, the Bollywood P&P was better (actually very good, BRIDE & PREJUDICE), the A&E P&P was miles better, even the WISHBONE P&P is better!  Ugh. It might be better if Keira Knightly could act, but I don't deal in fantasy.
summary: The worst P&P adaptation I've ever seen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Why people are attempting to compare a miniseries for the medium of television to a cinematic treatment? The movie should be judged on it's merits in regards to THE NOVEL it comes from---not from another adaption! And this is coming from a diehard BBC adaption fan-I have the VHS set AND the DVD set AND the special edition DVD set!And it passes with flying colors when you figure it must tell it's story economically and in a compacted timeframe. How cinematic storytelling is somehow "primitive" to the tele-storytelling is beyond me.As for the numerous complaints about pigs. Mr. Bennet was a gentleman farmer-it's right there IN THE NOVEL. The pig in the movie was not in the house. Did anyone get their knickers in a pinch similarly when the '95 version showed no signs of a farm by any chance? Where were the accuracy police for that one?As for fashions---Miss Bingley's sleeveless dress was illustrating how she was at the height of fashion---since sleeveless dresses were at the height at that time due to Russian fashion influences actually. Families tended to use hand me down dresses that were then altered as well-so that's why the Bennets dresses could look a little off and even have several styles layered on them at the same time!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have read Pride and Prejudice.  I have seen the BBC version.  I don't believe this movie is truly either.  This movie takes Jane Austen's book and runs with it.  I'm a huge fan of Austen (I have all of her novels) but I do believe that most (the exception being perhaps Persuasion) lack passion.  I believe that if Jane Austen were alive to see both versions BBC and this one--I think she would like seeing her book on tv (BBC is practically exact)and fall in love with the 2005 remake.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was curious to see this adaptation of the novel as the director chose to place it in the late 1790's when Jane Austen finished her first draft of the story rather than in 1813 when it was finally published.  It was a different time to be sure and the setting is much less pristine than other versions of this story.  However, the filmakers seem to have taken this as artistic license to insert all sorts of confusing anachronisms.For example, there are times when Lizzie publicly visits someone with her hair down.  As a young lady who is "out", her hair would  come down only at night and being seen in public with it down would make others perceive her as a little girl.  Lady Catherine the proud and haughty, would not say "thank you" to a servant upon receiving a cup of tea, she probably wouldn't even deign to nod in their direction.  And, she certainly wouldn't show up in the dead of night to visit someone.  The most glaring example is Bingly casually showing up in Jane's room while she is sick in bed.  Never, would such a thing happen!Keira Knightly herself is more than a little anachronistic as she is not an actress who hides her modernity well.  She seems entirely too smug with her jutting jaw and toothy grins to be a believable Lizzie.  I thought she was great in "Bend it Like Beckham" but she has never been convincing in a period piece, not even "Pirates".  Her thinness is painful to behold and would have seemed freakishly unhealthy for that time.Worst of all is that the film has not enough pride and not nearly enough prejudice.  Except for his first scene, Darcy seems more pathetically shy than proud.  You actually feel sorry for him.  Lizzie then, has less to react to with prejudice and with the story of Wickham being so shoddily done, her realization of the depth of her character misjudgements is weak.  There is never that moment where she says, "and then I knew myself".Still, the story is strong enough to be salvageable even with this treatment.  The cinematography is lovely too.  I'm just left with the feeling that they figured that American audiences wouldn't be sophisticated to notice all the sloppiness.  We are so often stuck with only action films and insipid comedies that we should be grateful for any substantial period piece.  With Keira Knightly, it wouldn't be languishing on the art house circuit either.  So they mucked it up and tacked on a very silly ending (not there in the British version) and sent it out for sale.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love it...it's Jane Austin and if you know her work then you'll love this movie! It's captivating, breath taking, happy, sad, and in the end....yes!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you like a melodramatic romance with beautiful scenery, you'll enjoy this. It is Pride and Prejudice done the way the Bronte sisters would have written it. But as a tribute to Jane Austen's ironic masterpiece, it falls far short. How a true Austen fan can enjoy this movie is beyond me. Lizzy is a silly, giggly schoolgirl, and Keira Knightly is badly miscast. So is Matthew MacFadyen, whose Mr. Darcy is more sad and shy than arrogant and conflicted.Major characters and events are cut down to a mere nothing, leaving the story completely undeveloped. Mrs. Bennet is a shadow of the hysterical, nagging matron from the book, while Lizzy is an overwrought, forward young woman who behaves completely outside the boundaries of propriety. Austen would be horrified.There are plenty of historical and literary anomalies for those who know their history and literature. It actually makes me angry and physically ill when I watch it. If you want to see Pride and Prejudice as it was meant to be, watch Andrew Davies' brilliant 1995 miniseries. It is the only proper way to view this story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Now, I have read a lot of the other reviews, and I can appreciate the opinions expressed there. However, I cannot---for even a second---agree that this version of "Pride and Prejudice" is better than the 1995 one. Be that as it may, I did actually like this one for some small things like:1. The scene where Darcy hands Elizabeth into the carriage as she and Jane are leaving Netherfield, and, as he walks away, he has to flex his hand because he can still feel the heat of her touching him. (Very sexy).2. The proposal in the rain, and the sensual, deep look on Darcy's face when she told him no. (Also very sexy).However, these two things do not make up for the SUPREME lack of historical homework done by the writers, producers, costumers, director, etc when coming up with some of these scenes. Knowing as much about the time period as I do, it took me out of the story when scenes would pop up that I know could not have occurred EVER. When you take away the realism of a story, you lose me. Here are a few of the glaring examples:1. Miss Bingley's dress at the Netherfield ball. It looked more like spaghetti straps than an actual ball gown is supposed to look during this time. It is so not historically acurate and I had a hard time not being shocked by it long enough to pay attention what was going on with the story.2. Elizabeth showing up at Netherfield with her hair down around her shoulders. It would not happen, and Elizabeth (the character) would have been mortified to be seen so (especially by people she detested).3. Mr. Bingley coming into Jane's bedroom at Netherfield. I don't care if she was on the verge of dying that very minute, it would never happen.4. Mr. Bennett apologizing and consoling a crying Mary after he ordered her to stop "exhibiting" on the piano. This is a serious breach of the character for him. The essence (and fun) of Mr. Bennett is that he is detached (emotionally and usually physically) from his family (except at times from Jane and Elizabeth). He laughs at his wife and younger daughters' opinions, attitudes, and actions because he knows they will always be silly no matter what and it is better laugh and get some entertainment out of it than to get angry over something he can't change. He does not apologize for his actions or caustic words. He just doesn't. Even when Lydia runs off with Wickham, his saddness over his inabilities as a father lasts for about a minute and, by the end of the book, he is back to his old self. He does not apologize. He just doesn't.4. Lady Catherine showing up to confront Elizabeth at night, and Elizabeth (as well as her entire family) receiving her in their nightclothes. Again, none of these things would happen. Not only are both of these things severe breaches of etiquette, but they also are large steps out of character for all involved. (Think of Robin Hood---dressed in MC Hammer's pants---robbing the rich to keep it all for himself. It simply wouldn't happen.)5. Elizabeth walking outside (at the end of the movie) in the dawn in her nightgown. Again, a large breach of etiquette. Elizabeth---no matter how tormented she was about Darcy---would have dressed even before going downstairs, much less outside. Not only would Elizabeth have been embarrassed to find herself this way when she sees Darcy striding over in the distance, but Darcy would have been shocked to see her that way as well.6. Darcy just walking over to her house at the end. Not only is it way too early in the morning for him to be calling, but he comes over partially dressed (with no cravat). Now, let us keep in mind people that this is the staunchest, most prideful, proper character in the history of literature. I don't care how in love he is, he is not going to show up at the house of the woman he adores without getting fully dressed first. Again, it just isn't going to happen.And I wish I could say this is all. Believe me, it isn't, but to put every issue I have on here would take me 12 hours, and I have better things to do. Only know that there are soooo many more. The point is that I do not have a problem with them leaving characters out, shortening the story, leaving out storylines, flattening down characters, etc. But, I cannot buy into a story that cannot be mostly accurate. It would be like watching "Dances With Wolves" and having a scene with the Indians stopping in the middle of the buffalo hunt to answer their cellphones. (Believe it or not, some of these breaches are that big.)Therefore, this version just doesn't work for me. I think this is a shame too, because this version could have been so much better if they had only done their homework and made it realistic.B
summary: I think we all missed a few things...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautiful cinematography and an Academy Award-nominated performance from Keira Knightley make this newest film version of Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE one to savour.  Although there is a legion of dedicated fans for whom the 1995 BBC miniseries (with Colin Firth) is still the definitive screen treatment, director Joe Wright (with a screenplay by Deborah Moggach and Emma Thompson) invests this version with a youthful feel and a slightly earthy, grittier edge.  Most importantly, Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen (as Darcy) are very close in age to what Austen describes in the novel.Headstrong and opinionated Elizabeth Bennet's rocky road to romance with the "insufferably proud" Mr Darcy plays out it's course against Austen's web of family intrigue and social mores. The colourful gallery of supporting players includes Brenda Blethyn as the social-climbing Mrs Bennet, Rosamund Pike as Jane, Jena Malone as Lydia, Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennet, Kelly Reilly as Miss Bingley, Tom Hollander as Mr Collins and Dame Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourg (a role she was born to play).While the Austen novel, with all it's incidents and well-crafted story, is better suited to the luxurious running-time of a miniseries, this new version is, on the whole, very enjoyable and fans of the Austen works will surely love it.
summary: Austen's story given the grand treatment

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride & Prejudice is one of my favorite books. Now it is one of my favorite movies! With Amazon instant video, now I can share this and watch anytime with anyone!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am an avid Jane Austen fan.  Pride and Prejudice along with Mansfield Park happen to be my favorites and thus it is important for a movie to get it right.  We all know and love the BBC 6 part version with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth and is the Austen adaptation standard but this version is a pleasant surprise.  I want to clear one thing up before I continue this review.  There have been other viewers who bemoan this version.  They do so on the belief Darcy's first proposal takes place at Pemberley instead of Rosings.  The proposal actually takes place at Rosings if you are paying attention.  Alright, I am off my horse and on to the review.  The cast is exceptional.  The characters are portrayed well  and the chemistry between them is wonderful.  Of course there are characters and subplots that are underdeveloped but you can't expect exact character and subplot representation in a 2 hour movie. Too be honest my only complaint about this version is it just isn't long enough.  I would have loved to see a 6 part version produced with this cast not to replace the BBC version but to compliment it.  I think it would have been brilliant.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I know many people will disagree with this review because I already saw the multitude of positive responses about this movie, but this is not Austen. There may be nothing wrong with the acting, but the story is too frothy and thin to do justice to the real wit and complexity of Jane Austen's novel. The main actors, especially Elizabeth and her family are two-dimensional pop versions of the novel. The family has been turned into "Little House on the Prairie" characters without richness or intricacy. In the novel (and in the A & E mini-series), the father was a man who hid from his duties and obligations to his family because he was bitterly disappointed in his choice of wife. Dazzled by her beauty and societal airs, he realised after their marriage that she was childish, superficial and self-absorbed. Although he is learned, perceptive and capable and despite the fact that he cares for his two eldest daughters, he fails to do what is right by his family; he refuses to establish rules of conduct or attempt to mould his daughters into moral adults with compassion and integrity and despite her affection for her father, is a constant source of embarrassment for Elizabeth. It is Elizabeth's shame about her parents that creates her defensive 'pride' which clashes with Darcy's proud demeanour. It is really Darcy's stiffness and lack of easy social skills that masquerades as pride just as Elizabeth's attitude is also a cover. Both of their external facades create prejudice against perceived slights and causes the delightful sparks between the two. The father and mother in this movie are all sweetness and light. if you enjoy slight romantic comedy than I guess you might like this movie, but if you want breadth and scope of character, a revealing insight into the society and mores of 18th century Britain and a damn good read, then I suggest you start with the novel itself. If you prefer a visual version, then I would recommend the A & E  series as it is the most faithful to the original with only minor deviations. Both are extremely delightful and there is no substitute for Austen's sparkling wit.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The reviewers who gave this film low marks are entitled to their opinion as I am entitled to mine. The initial urge to criticize this film dissipated after glancing at a quick second showing. It is not required that a movie be perfect in order for it to be perfected within itself given the constraints of various limitations. Those who cry foul and point to inaccurate text mirroring or cite smidglings of literary discrepancies seem to have bones too stiff for enjoyment. Although it is possible (usually in most films it is not only possible, but probable, that different actors may have carried success to further extreme - or inversely, failure), it seems pointless to snivel about it. We have these actors - these particular combinations - no others. This film came into a life of its own and spoke well to the human condition. The acting, overall, was excellent and in several instances phenomenal. Quite a wonderful pleasure. We would certainly be the poorer without it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What can you say about this movie...if you haven't seen it, see it!  It's one of my favorite "chick flicks".  It is such a wonderful romantic story that has been told many times over and I never get bored.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must say I've watched this more times than I can count, and so it's safe to say I'm in love with this film. But there are a few details that need to be touched upon if you're considering this film.-Book to Film-For two hours of time, I think this film did a decent job of translating Austen's work into a film format. Because of everything that happens, however, I don't think I would've minded if an additional half-hour had been added. A lot more could've been touched on and explained. "What do you mean, explained?" See the next section.-Warning to P&P; Unfamiliars!-I can watch this film and see why some people who have never read P&P; or watched any other film adaptations would be wondering, "What's up with Lizzy and Darcy anyway?"Truly, you see more of everything else than you do of them, which could lead those unfamiliar with the story to wonder why Elizabeth wanted much to do with Darcy in the end. I don't think that their relationship was developed as much as it needed to be, and it might make people wonder why Lizzy and Darcy ended up in love at all.-Characters and Actors-I was skeptical about Keira Knightley, as she didn't fit my picture of Elizabeth Bennet, but she surprised me and gave Lizzy a wonderfully fiery character that I enjoyed very much. I rather liked Matthew Macfadyen as Mr Darcy, and especially loved the almost boyish aspect he brought to the character--I felt it made Darcy much more realistic and even likeable. Great talent is always needed in the role of Mr Darcy, and Macfadyen definitely has that. The actors do quite well with body language--sharp eyes notice this is a prominent thing in this film, and it indeed speaks volumes.-In Conclusion-I think this is a fresh and unique take on Pride and Prejudice, and being a great fan, I welcomed that. Small details, such as the 'grunge' feel of the Bennet household, made this film more realistic rather than giving me yet another Austen "fairy tale perfection" film. The music and imagery gave me this near-surreal or -fantastical feel that I especially love. Once again, however, I would warn someone not familiar with Pride and Prejudice to watch this film with someone who is! They'll be better able to acquaint you with the language, social behaviours, and the dynamics of the story itself.Overall, a fantastic and wonderfully novel take on Pride and Prejudice!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have an almost love/hate relationship with this movie.  I love that there is a new take on it and some of the more youthful feeling characters in this adaptation.  What I hate about it is how much they leave out.  One of the biggest and most emotional part in the book is Kitty's elopement, and in this movie it lasts for about 2 minutes and seems of almost no importance. If you have never read the book or have seen the BBC version, I highly reccomend this to you as a movie.  But if you have, this might make you heartsick to see how much of the storyline is changed and missing.  By the way, I think the soundtrack is great.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having found the 1996 BBC version of "Pride and Prejudice" (with Colin Firth; Amazon ASIN: B000F0UUT6) so comprehensively satisfactory, I was astonished to learn that somebody had set out to film the exact same material so soon (this version came out nine years later).Yes, so happy was I with that other version that I stood ready to denounce Keira Knightley as a toothy upstart who should sink back into the bog from which she arose and trouble us no more.But I can hold out no longer:  this version was so superbly acted and masterfully directed that I cannot help but pronouncing it well worth your time.  Not as good as the Colin Firth one, but still able to hold its own in every respect.Especially the directing and cinematography.  You really notice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a wonderful rendition of Austen's novel. Let me first state, many people say "watch the BBC" version. Now I think that version has more details of the book, BUT there is also a big difference when you have 6 hours to tell a story vs 2 hours. Compare apples to apples.I loved the leads in this film. Matthew & Kiera brought such a youthful, freshness to the roles of Darcy & Lizzy, which fit more with the traditional characters and their ages. I could see & feel Lizzie falling in love with Darcy rather than just accepting she was wrong about him & his character. I thought they had great chemistry on screen. I didn't mind the changes made, it is after all an adaptation. They kept all the main themes & motifs of the original tale & that's what is important to me.The other principles chewed the scenery equally well, particularily the actress who portayed Mrs. Bennet. Loved her! Donald Sutherland, Tom Hollander, & Judi Dench--no words can do these people justice.The look of the film is exquisite & the music is extraordinary. A very entertaining two hours. If you're a lover of Colin Firth as Darcy & Jennifer Ehle as Lizzy, don't be surprised to find your image of the characters changing to Macfadyen & Knightly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Just awful. The Bennett family is portrayed as low rent trash living in a grimy, disheveled house. including a pig being led through the house. Jane Austen's Bennett family was provincial but had a throughly respectable living situation. They were gentry not hillbillies. Keira Knightly uses her usual set of smirks and grimaces to portray Elizabeth Bennett's agile mind. Bendy lips do not convey wit. Matthew MacFadden is too old for Darcy and Keira Knightly. Keira Knightly acts like a spoiled and head strong young teenager not a complex, captivating and independent thinking young woman. Austen's Lizzy is nowhere to be found. It makes Darcy look like a bit of a creep when he ardently confesses his love for the adolescent acting Lizzy. Even worse is the "romantic" ending when Darcy  further expresses his love for the newly wed Elizabeth. Keira Knightly returns his coy drivel with all the giggly enthusiasm of a schoolgirl crush. The scene feels like we are eavesdropping on a teacher who has run off with his student.The technical aspects of the film are even worse. Poorly written dialoque, abrupt advances in the storyline  make the plot confusing and unconvincing. The only saving grace is the beautiful photography. Otherwise a waste of money and time.
summary: Austen Lost in Translation.Director and Writers Get It All Wrong

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Not having read the book I was skeptical of watching a movie with romance. Usually, the terrible acting and the sappiness will send me to the fridge out of boredom or leave me dead asleep on the couch. Although this may result in a good nights sleep, I can't help but to think the three dollars I invested was put to waste. But maybe through Elizabeth Bennet's (Keira Knightley) class or Mr. Darcy's sideburns, Pride and Prejudice seemed like less of a loss and more of an investment. So much so that I'll confess to owning it on amazon.The story-plot just can't go wrong. It starts out with a town dance hosting all citizens in the town. Word spreads that a certain Mr. Darcy and his friend Mr. Bingley are to attend, so the house full of excited sisters, one of them being Elizabeth Bennet make there way. Mr. Darcy, unlike what was expected is cold, standoffish, and somewhat arrogant. This results in Elizabeth being stubborn and spiteful towards him. But through time his affections change and small hints of such feelings are shown. Moments such as his nervous hand after helping her into the carriage made me squeal out of excitement. As well the scene in which he appears out of the forrest wearing a low buttoned shirt with slight chest hair popping, stuttering while professing his love to her, has me not grabbing for chips, but instead looking for a Kleenex.I love and hate this movie for it's one of my favorite films but also leaves me looking for my Mr. Darcy. Lowering my chances even more making me particular. Now all I look for in a man is his ability to be able to pull off sideburns while wearing a cape. Trust me when I say this move will change your life

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Purists may not like this version and I too am a lover of the classic version. But.....  Directed by Joe Wright and screenwritten by Deborah Moggach, this is the most visually arresting and artistic of the "Pride & Prejudice" films.  The strength of the other versions has always been the dialogue. This is the first version which trusts the camera and imagery and lets the luminosity of the story line shine through rather than talking straight through it. The actors in this version are also a who's who of British acting. There is the young and impudent incandesence of Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet. She is the prejudiced one against the wealth and position of the young man who initially finds her too inferior to even be his dance partner.  This is Mr. Darcy as played by Matthew Macfadyen.  I was used to him as the head spy on MI-5 so he is maybe the last actor I would have cast as Darcy. However, I didn't realize how versatile an actor he is.  He is fabulous as Darcy, the one who suffers from pride in his origins, his convictions, his family and his property.  Elizabeth is beneath him so how could he fall in love with her?  This is the best story for answering that question with "how indeed!" Brenda Blethyn and Judi Dench play Mrs. Bennett and Lady Catherine.  Acting doesn't get any better than this.  See it with an open mind.
summary: Excellent Adaptation of Classic--Most Visual & Artistic Version

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you like romance, English accents, and "clean" movies you will like this one. I love Jane Austens books. It is definately worth every penny you spend to purchase it. I highly recommend it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Stunning photography and highly imaginative scripting and casting: Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennet) is especially striking in his clear familial and sartorial resemblance to great-great-grandson Buddy Ebson (Jed Clampett), before the family left England (possibly due to some unspeakable behavior involving pigs) and moved to the New World where they acquired more polish and class, rising in American society to the beautiful mountains of Kentucky.The director has wisely smoothed out Austen's complex characters and overly involved plot to a level more suitable to modern sensibilities and tastes; for moderns challenged by the complexities of "The Beverly Hillbillies" or Harlequin novels, this tender tale provides all the depth, subtlety, and brilliant crafting of a Barbara Cartland Romance.Stars are subtracted from this otherwise lovely film as an issue of Truth In Labeling, with potential confusion to the consumer. It is common for artists producing a work "Based On" a classic work (but bearing little resemblance to the original) to give their work a fitting alternate name. For example, a stirring tale "based on" "Homer's Oddysey" might become "O, Brother Where Art Thou" or it might become "Cold Mountain." The novel "based on Jane Austin's "Emma" has become "Clueless" and her "Pride and Prejudice" has become "Bridget Jones' Diary." This production continues as "Pride and Prejudice" suggesting that credit belongs to Austin. Very gracious and modest of them, after putting so much of their own creativity (and so little of hers) into the movie, but really, they shouldn't have.
summary: A Tender, Beautifully-Filmed Prequel to "The Clampetts"

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved this movie.  Living in the 21st century, one appreciates period films such as this, when a woman's virtue was held in the highest esteem, and your word defined your character.  Men posed as if they portraits come to life. Women were like delicate flowers.Hidden within these gallant mannerisms and underneath the proper composure are the lies, prejudice, and pride of man.  It has followed us through the centuries of time, interacting, for better or worse, with every aspect of mankind, poor and rich alike.  In this movie, both Jane and Elizabeth Bennett manage the rare success of finding wealthy men who also are the love of their lives.  Its "dreamy."  Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden have good chemistry.The witty characters and their costumes, make each scene in this movie very entertaining.Director Joe Wright and screenwriter Deborah Moggach are to be commended for this adaptation of one of Jane Austen's finest works.A wonderful movie, buy it, it's a keeper.....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a wonderful story. Pride and Prejudice is a classic that has inspired, interested and entertained young women for years, and henceforth has been made into many movies. Amazingly, each one has tried to represent the complete and prominent beauty of this story, but none has succeeded completely, because they are either too long, or too short. Until now. In the 2005 version, (w) starring Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen, one will be swept away in the world of Jane Austen and be kept tucked away in its arms. Being the re-representation of Pride and Prejudice the book, themovie keeps close to the original and only veers away to emphasize and enhance it, since modern people are harder to please. When one watches this video they will see a wonderful and picturesque world that will fly them away from reality and into a world of romance and "Happily Ever After." Nothing beats this tale.All is quiet as Elizabeth Bennet walks through the fields in the early morning, book in hand. Unfortunately, that does not last. Even as she steps up onto the steps of her home, she hears the chattering of her sisters and the shrewish voice of her mother. "Mr. Bennet, have you not heard? Netherfield Park is let at last, do you not wish to know who has taken it?" "As you wish to tell me my dear, I doubt I have much choice in the matter." He replied tiredly. Spotting her sisters, Elizabeth hurried towards them. "Lydia, Kitty, what have we said about listening at the door." But they quickly hush her, and inform her that a young and rich man, (w) named Mr. Bingley was moving in just up the road. "He's single." They gasped, and instantly Jane, the eldest sister was pulled into the conversation. "Who's single?" the conversation continued in the other room. "How could that possibly effect them?" their father rumbled. "Oh, Mr. Bennet, how can you be so tiresome, you know he must marry one of them." Stifling giggles the four girls leaned in closer, since the conversation has just gotten interesting. Just then the door opened and Mr. Bennet himself stepped out, not at all surprised to see his daughters listening in. Then all of them pursue him through the house, because they are trying to convince him to visit the man. As they pass her, the girls pull Mary up from her piano stool and into the living room with them. "For your information," Mr. Bennet said finally, cutting them off, "I already have." "You have?" and again they began to bombard him with questions, this time about the man's character. "So will he come to the ball then Papa?" Lydia finally asks breathlessly and eagerly. "I believe so." In an instant, temperaments go from concerned to overjoyed and preparations begin immediately for creating the best appearance to catch the eye of the young man.  Elizabeth just laughs and thinks about how fast a quiet morning can turn into one of such frivolity.The ball was such a mix of sounds that it was almost impossible to hear anything, even though Elizabeth was sitting right next to her sister Jane and her best friend Charlotte. "If all of the men in the room don't end the evening in love with you then I am no judge of beauty," she told Jane, but she was only answered with a laugh and retort, "Or men." "No, they are far too easy to judge." The lady laughed, looking at the room full of middle society folk, all enjoying themselves immensely. "They're not all bad." Jane reproved scanning the faces for Mr. Bingley. "Poppycocks in my limited experience." "One of these days Lizzy, someone's going to catch your eye and then you're going to have to watch your tongue." Charlotte agreed with a knowing look, because she knew her friend well. Not much later, the doors blew open revealing three people who looked both rich and self absorbed. Instantly, the room fell silent as the figures strode through the room, since they were imposing figures. "Which one of the painted peacocks is our Mr. Bingley?" Lizzy asked her friend. "He's on the left," in secret she looked at the ginger haired young man and decided that he wasn't so bad. He was smiling at the crowd genially and nodding at different people. "And on the right is his sister." Again her eyes scanned the woman and concluded that if any words could be used for her, they would be proud, attention seeking and prejudiced. "And the person with the quizzical brow?" she finally inquired. "That is his good friend Mr. Darcy." "He looks miserable poor soul." "Miserable he may be, but poor he most certainly is not." Sweeping the crowd, his eyes found hers as she rose from her curtsy and he hastily turned his gaze back to the front. Finally, Sir William Lucus, Charlotte's father stepped forward and greeted them. Elizabeth believed he was proud. After that, chaos ensued at the party again with all its noise and clamor.The family's simple plan of uniting Mr. Bingley to Jane for an advantageous marriage becomes more and more complex as Mr. Collins, the cousin who is to inherit everything that belongs to the girls, shows up with a determination to marry one of them. At around the same time Mr. Wickham steps into the scene and practically sweeps Elizabeth off her feet in one sentence, because he is witty and charming. But Mr. Darcy isn't done with her either, since she has already caught his eye. Suddenly the stubborn Elizabeth finds herself being twirled around in a spinning love-go-round. Being young, being stubborn and being love sick she is confused with the two stories spun for her, concerning the connection of Darcy and Wickham. Who is telling the truth? When faced with the choice, which man will she eventually marry? Will her sisters end up in poverty or will they have advantageous marriages too?In order to find out, in order to learn more, and in order to see the beauty for oneself, one must watch the movie or even read the very book. Pride and Prejudice is a complex story that will be a treasure for all young ladies adding to their collection. Not only is it entertaining, but it is a sweet and clean chick flick that stands above all the rest, which is saying a lot. The directors did a wonderful job of keeping it close enough to the book that anyone can read it afterwards and still not be disappointed, but still making it appealing to the teen crowd. Many young women can watch this movie over and over again and never get tired of it, because one can catch different things when it is watched more. It is a comfort movie. Being full of wonderful music, people can buy the soundtrack or even the piano book to keep the beauty in their home. Finally, many lessons can be learned from this story since people learn never to judge on appearances and to love one's family even through thick and thin. Since it is a terrific tale of truth Pride and Prejudice is a movie a family will want to watch again and again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really really really like the 6 hour Pride and Prejudice with Colin Firth (or is it Furth?).  Anyway, I didn't have 6 hours to spend watching, so I chose this video on my Kindle Fire.  It downloaded great and was really easy to watch.  It is a bit different from the 6 hour P&P but oh so definitely good.  I have a hard time following the book.  What can I say?  Maybe it was my public education.  So the 6 hour Colin Firth series helped tremendously but this movie is a good substitute for that one. I enjoyed the actors and how they portrayed the characters.  See this movie and judge for yourself!
summary: Almost as good as P&P with Colin Firth

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice by Jane AustenThematically the story slowly builds and leaves the reader at multiple climaxes throughout the book, first with the introduction of Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley at the town ball. Then leaving the reader hanging with the decision of Mr. Bingley to hold a ball and share his feelings to Jane all to have him leave based on the advice of Mr. Darcy. The book takes the reader on a rollercoaster to keep the hope continuing and keep things interesting.The tension between Mr. Darcy and Lizzie is unremarkable, whether it be her interest for him at the ball but him clearly ignoring her because he thinks that he's too far above her socially. In the end she has too much pride to accept his love once he declares it for her. They can barley stand seeing each other after that but she misses his attention and affection and soon realizes what a good man he is and soon addresses her love for Mr. Darcy once she finds out everything he did for Lydia and also convinced Mr. Bingley to return and ask for Jane's hand in marriage.Elizabeth's obvious hatred of the privileged gives way to her pride and lets it get in the way when she realizes that she is starting to have feelings for him. Her character seems rather angry in her own way and even a little bitter that has a woman she has to marry someone in order to not be a burden on her family. This really gives the reader a window into the independence that she wants to have and how torn she is to give in to her independence if she declares her love for Mr. Darcy.I agree with all the reviews of pride and prejudice but I wish the first one would have elaborated on the two different views of Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth who both realize they love each other when the other does not at that point in time. That their pride and attitude get in the way because they don't want to give the wrong impression and she is always so witty and intellectually superior. However, they are correct in the way that Mr. Darcy still tries to show is love in secret just because he wants Elizabeth to be happy and have no problems in her life.Jane Austen still is really summed up in "let it be yourself alone. That the wish of giving happiness to you, might add force to other inducements which led me on, I shall not attempt to deny. But your family owe me nothing. Much as I respect them, I believe, I thought only of you" representing his never ending love for Elizabeth even knowing she had said she did not feel the same way prior to this discovery. I love this quote because it just shows his hope that maybe she loves him back so he must tell her how he feels. It represents his passion and shiverlious behavior in order to just make life easier for her.I highly recommend this book to anyone who loves a good romance novel, the setting of the novel and the independence of a fierce young woman fighting her own feelings is thrilling and makes the read even better.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love the book. The movie, of course, is not as good as the book but the actors really do have the characters down well.  I especially like Mr Darcy in this movie.  I was, however, irritated that they took out Mrs and Mr Hurst completely.
summary: Not the book but still a good movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, I admit it:  I went into watching Joe Wright's 2005 adaptation of PRIDE & PREJUDICE with some trepidation, for a couple of reasons. 1.) Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is one of my favorite novels, and I didn't want to see Austen's story metamorphose into something it wasn't on the big screen.  And 2.) I am a huge fan of the BBC version, so I felt I had a lot to compare this new adaptation of the film to--and could it measure up to the high standards set by Austen and the BBC film (and Colin Firth's performance, in particular)?  The answer to that question, I discovered after seeing it, is, as Jane Bennet would say, "Yes, yes, a thousand times yes!"PRIDE & PREJUDICE tells the story of the Bennet family in rural England during the late 1700s.  Mr. and Mrs. Bennet have five daughters of the marrying age and, with no son to carry on the family name, the anxious Mrs. Bennet (played brilliantly by Brenda Blethyn) is desperate to get her daughters married off to the richest, most eligible young suitors.  Enter Mr. Bingley, who has just bought a large property near the Bennet home, and who at once becomes entranced with the eldest Miss Bennet, Jane.  He brings Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfayden), his haughty and even richer friend, with him to the country.  Darcy immediately clashes with the next eldest Bennet sister, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley).  Elizabeth is strong-willed, opinionated, and prideful, and she resents Darcy's condescending air and haughty attitude. Darcy resents Elizabeth's low rank in society and lewd family.  A series of chance encounters, however, gradually begin to change their opinions of one another--but both Darcy and Elizabeth have too much "pride and prejudice" to admit to their attraction and give in to the love of their lives.Austen-ite purists beware:  Wright (and screenwriter Deborah Moggach) have taken liberties with the film.  The Elizabeth and Darcy we see on screen are younger than Austen's version of the characters.  The story takes place in the more rural England of the 1790's, rather than in the early 19th century of Austen's novel.  The roles of many characters are reduced for the purpose of moving the story along; some are left out altogether.  But an adaptation is supposed to take liberties, right?  We know the story of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE; we've read the book, we've seen the BBC adaptation (which was very faithful to the novel); in my opinion, it's about time we got a fresh take on Austen's timeless classic.And Wright does a brilliant job with this adaptation.  This version lacks the romanticized costuming and setting of the BBC film, which felt and looked like a period piece.  The presentation of this version is much more gritty, much more natural; the gowns are plain, the country is muddy and rainy.  The love between Elizabeth and Darcy is innocent, vibrant, making them even more unbalanced, and they are even more powerless to resist each other.  The music is understated and simple, the perfect compliment to a story of overwhelming, irresistable love.And the acting is absolutely superb.  Keira Knightley is a natural actress, surprisingly powerful in her portrayal of strong-willed Elizabeth Bennet.  I was a little bit concerned she'd be too young for the role (and too beautiful to play Elizabeth)--but she blew me away with her forceful performance.  It's no wonder she was nominated for an Oscar for this role!  And Matthew Macfayden--although Colin Firth he is not, but who is?--is brilliant as the haughty, decorous, discreet Mr. Darcy.  And the two have tons of chemistry.  Dame Judi Dench and Donald Sutherland are welcome additions to the cast in small but memorable roles.There are two scenes, in particular, that I thought were particularly well done.  The scene in which Elizabeth visits Pemberley and wanders around Darcy's home, touching his sculptures and admiring his beautiful belongings, is particularly telling.  You can feel Elizabeth's feelings evolving at that moment, and the score is particularly well-utilized in this scene.  The other scene is the one in the moor, early in the morning, when Darcy comes to Elizabeth out of the mist.  Sounds corny, but it's simply beautiful:  The two young actors convey so much, without really saying anything at all.  The fabricated ending is sweet and lovely, too.One thing Wright doesn't change about Austen's story is the main message her long-ago novel contained, a message that is still pertinent today:  True love transcends all boundaries of class and pride.  So I have to say my trepidation was groundless.  All in all, this version of PRIDE & PREJUDICE is a worthy update to Austen's timeless romance.  The only thing I really missed was Colin Firth in the wet white shirt--but we can't always have it all, can we?
summary: "You have bewitched me, body and soul"

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Unless it is an entirely different adaptation, I prefer  the book to stay as close to the book as possible. I hate made up dialog. I like A&E's version better for accurateness. But I think the Darcy in this version captures him better. I did not like the acting in this one.  Just my preference.
