title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Spectacular setting, characters, costume, overall depiction of late 18th / early 19th century. Of course a viewer cannot fully appreciate this film unless she has read- at length -the novel of the same name penned by Jane Austen. Take the time to read the classic, then consider this your dessert! Enjoy.
summary: Delightful film version of the classic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was not sure how I would feel about a movie version living up to the mini-series. They did an amazing job with this movie. I really enjoyed actors playing Elizabeth and Mr Darcy. It terms of looks this feels more true to the book. The scene rica is absolutely breathtaking. I love the way everything is shot. Def recommend watching if you love Pride and prejudice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Comparable in quality to the BBC production in six parts starring Colin Firth as Darcey and that was not easy to achieve.Moreover the additional treats such as Joe Wright's comments on his work are highly interesting.
summary: As good as the BBC production

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Why??  Why even attempt to remake a film that was so fantastic?  This is like remaking Gone With the Wind.  I had high hopes for the movie, with its big budget and great looking cast, but they were not met.  The movie departs from the book, and the editing and script do not give enough time or substance to fully develop the characters.  The one thing I thought they did well was to depict the country dances as being significantly more back-woods than the ones in town.  By the way, I think it's a JOKE that Kira Knightly got an Oscar nod for this performance.  P-lease.
summary: A total let-down after BBC version (and the book)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Purchased for a Christmas gift. I have watched it over and over.I own a copy of the DVD. Love it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Matthew Macfadyen was and is a perfect Darcy in this version, I could not believe the subtle nuances he used in his voice, gestures, and yes, the eyes. I really enjoyed the interplay of Elizabeth and Darcy. The public dance scene made me smile as everyone was so energetic and seemed to be having so much fun. The piano music was superb, and set the scenes.The director Joe Wright used the actors, scenery, and period era to a great advantage in presenting this movie. He should make more Austin films and use Macfadyen as he is so good in period films.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Cathy "of the band, Cathy and the Wuthering H...
review_text: I'm an Austen lover, and a big fan of Colin Firth in the original A&E; miniseries version of this novel, so I was initially hesistant to watch this film; it's always disappointing to see one of your favorite books turned into a pathetic story on film.  And honestly, I didn't think Knightley had the chops to bring Elizabeth Darcy to life.  But I'm delighted that I watched (and ended up buying) this film, because its one of the best book-to-movie adaptations I have ever seen.Not only did the actors beautifully capture the spirit of their characters and represent their internal struggles realistically, but the director clearly had a brilliant appreciation for the spirit of the original text.  The imagery of the film is often dark, and the director managed to underscore the difficulties of poverty and womanhood in 19th century England with great poignancy.  While other directors of Austen films often focus on the comedy and lighthearted romance of Austen's stories, this movie captures Austen's spirit of satire without detracting from the plot.Whether you are an Austen fan or a movie fan or both, this is a great film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I had recently read the book for the first time, and was astonished how much I loved it.  I was skeptical that this movie would be any good but surprisingly I loved it.  Though they cut out a few scenes I would really have enjoyed I thought the overall feel of the movie was akin to what I felt with the book, and it was a good way to relive the story without having to re-read the whole thing.  Overall I absolutely loved it.  The only scenes I wish they had included was more of Miss Bingley teasing Darcy, those were some of my favorites scenes in the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a beautiful version of the classic Jane Austin novel Pride and Prejudice. the actors and actresses are beautiful and the English countryside glows golden at sun rise and sun set. There are three aspects of the film that I will point out tht make it wonderful entertainment.First, Elizabeth Bennett is one of the great characters in English literature. Here she is played as more impulsive than Jennifer Ehle plays the part in the great BBC version. For example, beautiful Kiera Knightley plays Elizabeth as young, playful, and inclined to romance, as evidenced by her reactions to Mr. Darnley at the country house dance at the beginning of the film. Jennifer Ehle pays Elizabeth Bennett as more reserved, more mature, and more sphnix-like. The strength of Elizabeth Bennett is that she is witty, intelligent, considerate, and willing to change her mind. It is this last quality, the willingness to changer her mind, on which much of the film revolves. Elizabeth's first impression of Mr. Darnley was that whereas he was rich and handsome, he was also arrogant and prideful an maybe even a little cruel. Eventually, through a series of mishaps and interactions, she begins to see him differently, seeing his strenghts and compassion and convictions and most of all, his love for her despite the tensions and misunderstandings they undergo.The scene where Darnley proposes to Elizabeth despite his low regard for her wild family and her poverty was wonderfully played in this film, with Kiera Knightley firing back at him that his poorly worded proposal of marriage was the height of insult to her and her family.Yet these two weather this upsetting event and go on to love each other greatly as they further discover each other's best qualities. Isn't this what love should really be about? Shouldn't we move from erotic first impressions to deeper appreciation and understanding of each other?Second, Darnley is well played here. Colin Firth does such an exceptional job in the BBC version that it was hard for me to warm up to another Mr. Darnley, but this actor gives us a version of Darnley that is more mysterious and less aristocratic than the Firth version.Third, Jane Austin creates a charming world full of odd, delighful, endearing, and yet realistic characters. Jane Bennett is the height of beauty and sweetness, no wonder Mr. Bingley falls madly in love. Mr. Bingley is as silly as he is rich, however he is sincere and is a perfect match for Jane. Mr. Bingley's sister is wonderfully played and I loved the line she speaks at the country dance where she wonders when the guests will stop dancing and chase pigs. Lydia Bennett is such an empty headed young women, not realizing how her elopement could ruin the reputations of her sisters. Mr. Collins is such a fool, basing his self worth on the whims of his wealthy benefactor, Lady de Bourge. Judi Dench plays a great angry scheming Lady de Bourge. Mr. Bennett says in the book: "God placed us here on earth to laugh at our neighbor's folly and for our neighbor in turn to laugh at ours." This line wonderfully represents Austin's philosophy which she brings to all her characters.The acting is super and truly romantic, the English countryside is beautifuland moody, and the novel actually can be revealed in a short two hours, which I could not believe until I saw it.
summary: Very good updated version of a wonderful classic

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I absolutely love this movie! I watch it all the time. I love the time period it's placed in and the romance. Jane Austen is one of my favorite past times.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: seriously, it's an adaptation, I am sick of people reviewing it based on the book. If they wanted to make the book into a movie, they would have. This is supposed to give the director and screenwriter's view on the story, it's not meant to be exact. Study French new wave and maybe some would understand why it is done this way(basically books should not be made into movies, there should be a screenplay made for film, not the exact book because they are two seperate arts. A book cannot have the same effect on film, it needs to be changed. Look at movies like the DaVinci Code, that is how not to do it)I think the film captured the spirit of the story and characters. The front page reviews express my feelings on the film. Mcfayden was an amazing Darcy and the chemistry and passion of the film was amazing. I am OBSESSED with Pride and Prejudice, and though there are many encounters in the book that I would have enjoyed having knightly and Mcfayden act out because they were so good, I understand the vision the director had. Making it in that manner made it far more passionate then my former favorite, the A&E; version. There were scenes that could be watched over and over. The filming was beautiful, and certain scenes lookedlike paintings. Some differences from the book and Austen I believe were made to help understand the story and the feelings, such as the hug between Darcy and his sister. It shows the love between them because we have no narator.The casting was amazing, I do feel that the characters were more convincing in this version(thank god Jane was cast much better in this than in the A&E; version). I think Judi Dench was perfect along with Jena Malone, and actually every other cast member.I am happy though that many people watched it without expecting or only accepting Jane Austen's vision, because you cannot make a film from a vision that is not your own. Jane Austen is not here to make her own, so I will enjoy the adaptations not basing them on how closely they follow the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wider screen compared to the original DVD version which is cropped. Visual detail is also better as one would expect from a blu-ray version.As for comparison to the 1995 version, I love both, but there are people who claim the 1995 version is vastly superior. It seems most often that they love Colin Firth in his wet shirt which has nothing to do with the novel but it seems to incite some feminine imaginations. The BBC version is not without its faults, but the leads are very strong and the series/running time is longer and thus captures more of the Austen wit. The 2005 version's cast is uniformly stronger and being a movie, the production values are thus naturally stronger (better visually and musically). Judged on its own as a movie, the 2005 version is visually striking and its music score is worth a purchase on it's own merits.You can't go wrong with either version really.
summary: The Blu-ray version is better visually

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After reading the book I was determined to watch the movie.  This is a fantastic movie and it easily held up to my high expectations.  I fell in love with the characters and I am about to watch it for the fourth time since buying it.  I love, love, love this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I thought this was a great movie and I've seen it a couple of times now.  The only improvement would have been to make it 5-6 hours long--as is the BBC version.  This story moved so fast I'm glad I had it on DVD to pause and watch some scenes again.  If you weren't familiar with the book or BBC version, you might get lost.  I thought the character developement could have been better.  But all in all, Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen are a great couple in this movie.  Their glances and small gestures are perfect.  I love one of the very last scenes where Mr. Darcy is walking towards her and the camera stays on him the whole way.  I thought the cinematography was wonderful.  I almost want to visit Stanage Edge where Elizabeth stood looking out over the valley.  I would recommend this movie to anyone.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw the Colin Firth movie first and although I am a diehard fan of his, I didn't like the actress chosen to play Lizzie.  This movie is so wonderful, staying as close to the original script as possible. Both Keira Knightly and Matthew MacFayden are wonderful actors who bring Mr. Darcy and Miss Bennett to life in such a wonderful, beautiful way. This movie is now my all time favorite!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For those who are avid fans of the book and the A&E version you at first may not like this one.  At first one is compelled to think that it is not correct in its adaptation.  My personal thoughts are that it captures the "feelings" of the characters and allows them to portray them much more than a literal telling of the story would.  And indeed it does not add anything not in the book, it on some things rearranges the location of an event.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: IT WOULD TAKE TOO LONG FOR ME TO LIST THE MANY PROBLEMS I HAVE WITH THIS MOVIE [setting, missing scenes, character portrayals, etc.], BUT SUFFICE IT TO SAY THAT IT IS TRITE AND NOT WORTHY OF BEING CALLED "JANE AUSTEN'S P & P".  I WENT TO THE MOVIES TO WATCH IT, BUT LEFT BEFORE THE END BECAUSE IT WAS SO "untrue" TO THE NOVEL. AFTER CATCHING IT ON CABLE A FEW WEEKS AGO, MY FIRST THOUGHT WAS "I'M SORRY FOR THOSE WHO ARE UNFAMILIAR WITH THE BOOK IF THIS OSCAR-NOMINATED MOVIE IS ALL THEY HAVE TO GO BY." THE FIRTH/EHLE VERSION IS FAR SUPERIOR TO THIS. IF YOU ARE NOT AN AUSTEN FAN AND/OR HAVE NOT READ THE NOVEL, EITHER READ THE BOOK OR RENT/BUY THE FIRTH/EHLE MOVIE.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of my Favorite Movies. If you like Period Romantic movies, this is wonderful !!!I've seen the BBC mini-series, which is good, but I like this movie even more.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I dont know about others, but I love Keira Knightly! This movie has been done with others playing that role, but Knightly takes it to another level, completely. She is truly Elizabeth Bennett. If you like movies about the rich and richer, you will love this movie. The music score is enlightening and many of the scenes are set in a richer person's house. All the characters blend quite well to make this movie a must see event. The Bennett family is interesting, funny, and sometimes annoying but true to the time and circumstance of their position in life. Watch and engulf yourself in all it has to offer.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen different versions of Pride and Prejudice, including the versions with Laurence Olivier and Colin Firth.  None come close to this version.  Even though story had to be condensed to fit the runtime of the movie, the integrity of the story remains.  Keira Knightly is powerful as Elizabeth and Matthew Macfadyen IS the ultimate Darcy.  Donald Sutherland, Judi Dench and Tom Hollander as Mr. Collins are also masterful. The musical score outstanding!  This is a must see!  This is an update.  I don't know how I managed to leave out Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennett.  She was wonderful.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie was raved by so many critics that I am at a loss as to what they see in it. The movie works only if the viewer knows nothing about Jane Austen, has never seen the BBC classicc (I highly, highly, recommend this), and likes Keira Knightley. She's not an awful actress, but she is so entirely wrong for Elizabeth Bennet that I cringed through the entire movie. Her Oscar nod in unexplainable

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I watch this movie every month or two. It's my absolute favorite. I really appreciate how they handled the story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie, and even though the price was discounted, the full movie and features were on the disk, however the disk art was downgraded from a picture of Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy to a simple green disk with the movie title. Still a great buy!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I own both versions of this story and love both of them. However, if I had to choose between them, this would be the one I'd pick. The interplay between Elizabeth and Darcy is breathtakingly intense from their first glances and their inner struggles are shown clearly on their faces, unlike the greater restraint shown in the longer BBC version. The whole thing is much more cinematic than the latter, also, and the ballroom scene where everyone but Elizabeth and Darcy disappears for a moment is but one of many masterful touches throughout the movie. It does not follow the book as well as the BBC version does, but somehow it fleshes it out and redeems it for the 21st Century. Excellent in every respect except that I can't seem to get enough of watching it! :-)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love all versions of Pride and Prejudice.  This version is somewhat different from the famous series from the '90s with Ehle and Firth.  The photography is beautifully done.  The extras are interesting.  Worth buying and watching more than one time!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This 2005 adaptation of Jane Austen's novel was beautifully portrayed and characterized by a fine British cast; I highly recommend this film for the whole family.Loved Keira Knightly, whom I have seen in a few films, and thought her portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett was magnificent, with a touch of today's young, knows-her-own-mind, woman.  As for Matthew Macfayden (Mr. Darcey), whom I have never seen in film, was the dashing, brooding, romantic figure of a young girl's dream.  I much preferred his Mr. Darcey, to Colin Firth's.The music, piano solo, is especially a dream for the ears and the cinematography is breathtaking!In short, I loved this film which has made a Jane Austen fan out of me.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of my favorite love stories. A great family show. The setting is beautiful. The acting is marvelous. Loved it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a wonderful ADAPTATION of the story of Darcy and Lizzy, very well made with beautiful music, scenery and artsy segues. I would recommend anyone unfamiliar with this story to NOT watch this movie first. It is a nice, bite size version that can best be appreciated when watched with a prior understanding of the characters and the story (as it hacks the actual story to pieces). First, of course, see the '95 version (and read the book!).My praise: Artsy, artsy, artsy! If you listen to the commentary, the director really knew the story and was NOT trying to blatantly follow the book (as we all know, that has been done with perfection, so why try?). He was trying to bring fresh thought and feeling to it and, though I don't agree with a lot of the re-writing of the lines, I applaud the way he alluded to the windows being a metaphor for perception, the way the sunrise opened and closed the story, the setting being 100 years prior to the actual setting of the book, the domestic abuse of Lydia by Wickham (which we all suspected), the little character nuances and sub-plots that took place in the background of every scene (you gotta be quick!), and the romance he could achieve with scenery and music, when no action was taking place. Oo! Simply beautiful! So much more than simply telling the same old tale! And the first-proposal scene! Nice!My rant: I felt this version blew thru the actual story perhaps a little too fast. Much of the wit for which Jane Austen is so well known is NOT done justice. Lines from the book which ARE left intact are spewed with little thought or acting, especially in the beginning. Sometimes so fast that, if I wasn't familiar with the dialogue, I would've had no idea what was going on. And character development? What's that?I was not infatuated with Knightley as Miss Lizzy. She lacked the playfulness and intrigue of her character. She had some of the best lines, yet constantly disappointed me in their delivery. Plus, she always looked disheveled and sticky to the touch. And the teeth on Mr. Bennet! Such pearly, straight choppers for a poor man in 1790! They are blinding amidst all the gloom. C'mon makeup guy, try a little harder!However, Macfadyen was wonderful as Darcy and I wish he had more scenes to better explain his character. I feel he could've done it justice. And Lady Catherine? Perfection!I really expected this to throw out ALL the wit and plot and turn this into some sickly, thin love story that would appeal to idiots everywhere (the 2 hours run time scared me). However, it did not. Some wit remained, all the high points were addressed and there was many a scene where Knightley and Macfadyen had fantastic chemistry. In the end, though, it just wasn't there for me. A little cheesy/sappy perhaps.My ideal P&P; would be somewhere between this and the '95 one. I LOVE the romantic artsy-ness this one brings to the table, yet the '95 version is faultless in it's story. Oh well, maybe the next version will be better.Should you buy this one? Of course! A new take on a great story is always appreciated! However, I would recommend the WS version, as the director has a lot of shots with characters on extreme R and L, and they are uncomfortably close to the edges of the screen on the FS version. Plus, WS will do the beautiful, sweeping wide-angle scenery better justice.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I rarely enjoy a movie as much as I did this one. It is wonderful on so many levels. It is a simply lovely movie about a great love story.I have found some of the reviews posted for this movie very interesting, especially those that complain about this adaptation not being true enough to the book. I am also fascinated by the comparisons to Colin Firth's Mr. Darcy. What gives?I am, perhaps, an experienced enough movie-goer that I didn't expect to see the book visually transferred to the screen. If I want to relive the story Jane Austen wrote, verbatim, I will read the book again.And, as much as I admire Colin Firth, I am so impressed with Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy. His portrayal in this version is subtle and beautiful. Mr. Darcy seems more real than in any previous version thanks to the sensitivity and sensibilities in the portrayal. Matthew Macfadyen is a brilliant, talented actor and I very much look forward to seeing him on the screen again in the very near future.This movie is visually stunning and well-crafted. I saw it at the theatre only once and, at first viewing, was immediately taken with the choreography of the scenes. The weaving around the ball rooms and the long camera shots are amazing. It was obvious that Joe Wright had paid a great deal of attention to each scene to get it visually right. A great movie can elicit deep emotion visually and set a mood that compliments what is happening on screen between the characters. This movie certainly accomplishes this. Joe Wright appears to have a great career as a film director ahead of him based on this work.I admire the portrayal of the Bennet family in this film. I like that Joe Wright wanted to show them as a "real family" and feel it helped make the film. Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet is not nearly as annoying as the BBC version, which I greatly appreciated. She made Mrs. Bennet likable and understandable. Donald Sutherland, especially in the last scene, is wonderful. And, Keira Knightley's performance is lovely. I was very impressed and believe she deserves the all of praise she has received. She captured the essence of Elizabeth Bennet and portrayed her in a real, believable way.The music is wonderful. The locations are breathtaking.The love story between Elizabeth and Darcy is timeless and this movie lacks nothing in telling their story, even with the time constraints and missing characters and dialogue from the book.If you ask me if we needed this version of their love story, I will gladly say yes.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen both versions and like them both for different reasons. The BBC version is far superior than the 2005 version because of the detail of the screenplay. The BBC version gives background as to:(1)why Darcy and Lizzy like and dislike each other (2) how often Darcy and Lizzy were actually around each other (3) why Wickham really runs away with and then marries Lydia. I agree that some of the length of detail in the BBC version made me want to fast forward - (1)was Caroline Bingley really so dense that she continued to make so many unflattering comments about Lizzy even though Darcy made very pointed remarks as to why Lizzy was so favored by him? (2) Mrs Bennet's many hysterics (3) party at Mrs Bennet's sister's house, just to name a few.Had I not previously seen the BBC version I would be left wondering: (1) how Darcy could have fallen in love with Lizzy when only seeing her three of times - at the first dance, when Jane is sick and at the Bingley's ball - then barely saying two words to her each time!  (2) Why in the world did Wickham want to marry Lydia?  The 2005 version left me puzzled.  They had spoken to each other only once in this version - at the ribbon shop - and he runs away with her?  Really? (3) Why was Mr Bennet (Donald Sutherland) even in this version when much of his script was edited out. (4) Why in the world Lady Catherine said to the Bennet family "You have a very small garden" when she came in the middle of the night (5) Why Darcy didn't have more to say in the 2005 version (6) How did Darcy manage to walk from Rosings to Longbourne in the wee hours of the morning?Things I liked more about the 2005 version: (1) the house the Bennet's lived in.  Much more suited to their income in appearance and size; (2) the hall where the assembly was held when Darcy and the Bingley's were 1st introduced; (3) Jane (Rosamund Pike) - so beautiful (4) Mrs Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) - less hysterical and more motherly (6) Georgiana Darcy.
summary: What I did and did not like about this 2005 version. . .

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a newcomer as a Jane Austen fan...Started with Sense & sensibility with Emma Thompson a few years back and that was it. I bought this film on a whim and I'm either in great need of romance in my life or there's nothing interesting on TV cause, since I bought this movie, I think I must have watched it every night eversince, it's pathetic or not !!! I can't help myself cause I think it's such a beautiful story and I wish I could snatch a Mr Darcy of my own !!! I think these two center caracters have a certain "je ne sais quoi", an undercurrent, a chemistry that keeps me hooked...The proposal(or insulting !!!) in the outdoor monument of somekind, in the pourring rain(which says a lot of Darcy's bewichement), is incredibly electric, they're both very passionate in their debate and I think on the verge of maybe kissing but pride and prejudice keeps them from giving in into their passion about each other....My other favorite scene is the dance at the formal ball, Lizie consented to dance with Darcy against her better jugement but manages to torment and tease poor and sooooo formal Darcy...You could feel unercurrent's going on right then, already...Isn't the scene where Lizie, on a trip with her Ant & Uncle stands on the verge of the precipice beautiful ??? I think this version(Unfortunatly, haven't yet seen the version with Firth) shows such  beautifull scenary, make's me want to definitively to go to England before I die !!!), and the music is heavenly...I fell in love with ALL the caracters, especially the Bennet family which reminds me a bit of my own, nutty and funny and loving !!! And Mr Darcy, under all that frigid exterior has an most ardent core, dont you think...Well, for me this is a beautifull movie and I can hardly think to find such "amiable" qualities in the version with Mr Collin Firth(no malice intended), but I LOVE the pairing of Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen and their's is magical, funny, corky, I would say smocky but in that century passion wasn't a thing to show(some, tough, were outside the mold like Lizie was I think and Keira portrays that very convincevly).

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My satisfying first purchase, delivered on-time, great packaging that ensuring the goods arrived undamaged, and a great movie! One of my favorites actually. I loved Focus Features films because of their simplicity and mostly low budgeted movies, which often accompanied by a great storytelling and a good directing. Sometimes I have to get out of those Hollywood big budgeted films, to understand more about films.This one is a very comforting film, beautifully directed by Joe Wright, the sceneries and settings will soothe your mind and refresh your soul. Dario Marianelli is one of my favorite composer, and he's attached a more playful tone in this one rather than a much more 'serious' and 'deep' Atonement score. All in all, I'm satisfied in making this purchase.
summary: Loved the movie. Loved Focus Features. Loved Amazon.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a good version of an excellent book by Jane Austen, written almost 200 years ago.  There are several other versions on film of "Pride and Prejudice."  Although it did not stick to the book in some crucial places, overall it was well done.  It could have been longer and done a better job.One part was very anoying:  Darcy's aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourg, visited the Bennett family after they had retired.  Even though Lady Catherine was a snobish woman used to having her own way in life, she would not have visited Elizabeth's family that late in the evening.  Good manners would not have let her.  Her feelings of superiority would not have condoned it.  Her mention of a "little garden" at the Bennett home should not have been in the film at all as it served no purpose since her visit was at night and it was dark.Overall, not a bad version of a book every fan and viewer of Jane Austen's movies should read.The best version of this book-to-film was A&E;'s.  They had the time to make it almost perfect.  I think Jane Austen herself would have approved of it.However, given the time available, this is still an enjoyable movie if you like Jane Austen.
summary: Good version of an excellent book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice is a favorite novel, and I admit I'm "prejudiced" in its favor.  But this adaption won my full affection.  Keira Knightley turns in an absolutely perfect portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett.  The rest of the cast is terrific as well, including very nice portrayals by Donald Sutherland and Rosamund Pike.The scene at the dinner table where Elizabeth learns that Mr. Darcy has unexpectedly saved her sister's honor, and the library scene where she tells her father that she truly does love Mr. Darcy are just exquisitely played by Miss Knightley, and I can watch them over and over.A great DVD that I would highly recommend for all Jane Austen fans.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Matthew McFadyen's portrayal of Darcy has yet to get the credit it deserves. He was the very living vision of Jane Austen's character. He brought to life the person she described as "not having the talent to converse with strangers easily". The people who masterfully created this movie understood Jane Austen. McFaydyen made Colin Firth ( Darcy in the BBC version) look two dimensional (not an easy task). Keira Knightley as Elizabeth was inspiring. Watching this movie made you feel as though you were eavesdropping not only on the poetic unfolding of the character's lives, but even their thoughts and emotions. An enjoyable experience.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Let me just start by saying, that I had never seen the 1995 BBC mini series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, never read the book and had no real desire to see this movie.  Caught it on a plane ride home and I have to say that it took my breath away.  I loved Matthew and Keira together - there chemistry was unbelievable.  Since that plane ride home, I have bought the movie and watch it anytime I can.  I have read the book twice which gives a little more background and watched the 1995 mini series.  I have to say, and I know people are going to be quite angry, I did not feel any chemistry between Firth and Ehle.  I thought the new adaptation of Pride and Prejudice had more emotion and wish that THEY would do the 6 hour mini series because that I would definately buy.  I have told everyone I know about this movie and how fantastic Matthew played the part of Mr. Darcy.  By far my favorite movie ever and will continue to watch it faithfully any chance I get.

I had read several chapters of the book as well but did not finish it.The pace of the movie, as the book, started slowly but characters developed quickly.  My grandson fell asleep midway the movie. I, age 68, continued to watch and am so glad that I did. From the mid point  of the movie to the timeless  romantic ending, the title and the theme were  apparent.We plan to watch it again & hopefully my grandson will stay awake long enough to get to "the good parts".

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Have never felt even remotely inclined to write a review of a movie, until this one. Took me a couple of years to even consent to view this movie, felt it came out with too much saturation of Keira Knightly everywhere. And knowing the tendency for the big screen to hack up great books and slim down carefully written characters to a manageable 'just over two hours' production. Well, finally decided to give it a chance, and have rarely cringed more than in watching this version of Pride & Prejudice perhaps writing this alone will help someone else.While being a fan of Austen's, I would hardly call myself an Austenite, but after seeing so many liberties taken with her dialog, perhaps I am. Austen was rather wordy, but to chop it up and modernize it was condescending to the reader/viewer. Elizabeth's character came off a snotty and headstrong, instead of self-assured and quick witted. Jane was empty instead of kind to a fault, and Charles Bingley, although interestingly cast, was a bit of a fool instead of endlessly kind.The book and my imagination are very closely seconded to A&E; BBC version of this film with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. This version isn't anywhere near the running.I find it necessary to point out how bad or ridiculous every-bodies hair was, everyone looked as if the just tumbled of bed, or the more senior ladies were over teased so as to look like England's version of New Jersey, not a good look for Dame Judi Dench.The casting was a who's who of England's talent, with the odd exception to Donald Sutherland, who did well enough for a horrible screenplay. Carey Mulligan, a fine actress, was reduced to either crying, laughing too loud, chewing, or the odd exclamation, not her fault, again a horrible screenplay. Judi Dench was so obvious a choice and so over exhibited in this production she could have just sneered as Lady Catherine and saved uttering her few badly chosen lines. Claudie Blakley as Charlotte Lucas was made overly plain, add her character reduced to an an embarrassment as Elizabeth's much loved friend. Kelly Reilly did a great job making Miss Bingley hate-able with her few scenes and fewer lines that were as empty and mean as her poor part was limited to, Miss Bingley was as most of Austen's characters, much more complex, more cunning and conniving, and even admirable in their witty snobbery; Kelly Reilly is such an excellent actress she could have made that happen, but the writing. Matthew MacFadyen appears to have been severely limited too. He must have been instructed to smile far less than even Colin Firth would, and instructed to execute the lines as severely as you can while not moving a single facial muscle, except during the scene in the rain when he seems so intent on kissing Miss Elizabeth that he may even bite her. Oh cringe!Keira Knightly was made so plain, and her lines so devoid of a rich character that Elizabeth Bennet could and should have been. I hardly even liked her as the well beloved Elizabeth. I found myself wondering just which line she would say how, instead of feeling one way or another for her, a bit like watching a tennis match instead of a celebrated love story. He character in those Pirate movies was more deep.In all the movie appears to have been done by casting inexperienced with English talent. It comes off as if someone was given a limitless credit card and told to go shopping for fine things in a well appointed department store, and having never been in one before, gets off the plane in London, hops in a cab, asks the cabbie who his favourite English actors are and sets out to secure them like ridiculous ornaments that they are unaccustomed to. I hope this fine list of talent was paid well for such an overdone empty production.The cinematography appeared amateurish, with wide shots done so long that their length eclipsed the most rushed proposal scene. Poor Matthew MacFadyen had to utter his proposal like the techno-babble of a Dr Who episode; so the audience could view Keira Knightly's skirts billowing in the wind on the peaks at length.Chatsworth is and always will be more beloved as the previous choice for Pemberly (and for it's own merits as one of the finest houses in England, it is NOT the only one however), where it was coyly displayed in a lovely beguiling manor; instead put on display much like poor Judi Dench was. The angles were obvious and over the top, and looked more like a tacky tourist leaflet, instead of subtle showcasing of a grand, well known estate. That display and the final scene of the newly married Darcys overlooking the great estate, made it and them look cheap.The manners and customs of that deliberate era, were replaced by the theme of barging into rooms and constant eavesdropping.The division of rank and money was showcased as usual, and it was cringe-worthy for the Regency Era or any era, where money and intelligence are often mistaken as interchangeable, so kudos for hitting that altogether obvious mark, however Austen subtly rectified this in her book, this film left that issue hanging like bad drapes.The music was lovely, the costumes were good, and the diverse dancing was well represented.I give this 2 stars for the sake of the cast, each of them has such a fine record of their own, with even their TV dramas far superior to this flimsy production. IMDB some of these actors, study the body of their works overseas, watch some of the things that are being put out in UK and you'll too see the emptiness of this work for such a rich cast of fine actors, and even Donald Sutherland.I will never watch this again. And do hope another production tries to come along and eclipse this mess.
summary: My own Pride & Prejudice about this movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie "Pride and Prejudice" provides a clean, romantic, love story that one enchanted viewer could watch over and over and over again. Near the movies mesmerizing climax the viewer will be in tears of happiness. Miraculously after the movie is over one cannot stop thinking about the unexpected twists and turns the characters endured. Remaining as true to the book as it can in two hours and nine minutes the movie stayed accurate to Jane Austen's descriptions. The movie follows the book.  Elizabeth Bennet, the main character in the movie, is flawlessly played by Keira Knightley, who also played in the Pirates of the Caribbean, and Matthew Macfadyen plays the prideful, misunderstood Mr. Darcy. Since the movies title is "Pride and Prejudice" Elizabeth Bennet has prejudice and Mr. Darcy is seen as prideful, because of his reserved, publicly shy nature. "Pride and Prejudice" portrays the perfect love story and envelopes and inspires the viewer with a passion for unsoiled romance.Elizabeth Bennet has four sisters all of whom were unmarried. This presented a problem according to their mother whose goal was to marry off all of them to rich respectable gentlemen, when the opportunity presented itself. Luckily two rich men named Charles Bingley and Mr. Darcy were attending a ball which was open to the public. All five Bennet girls attended. By the end of the evening two things about the gentlemen were clear to Elizabeth, one Mr. Bingley undoubtedly fancied her older sister Jane, and two, Mr. Darcy was conceited. Decidedly, hastily, and openly Elizabeth "swore to loathe him for all eternity." Although Jane was shy Elizabeth could see that she liked Mr. Bingley. Talking periodically over the next months Jane and Bingley knew each other quite well until Jane received a letter basically stating that Bingley was returning to London. Elizabeth suspected that the despicable Darcy had convinced Bingley to leave because Darcy did not approve of Jane's relatives. After her family's farewells, Jane was sent of to London to stay with relations in hope that Bingley would learn of her presence and visit her.With her sister gone Elizabeth was bored and sad and confused fortunately she was invited to visit a friend. She welcomed the change of scenery and left. This friend lived near a rich pompous Lady who had her nephew, the Mr. Darcy, visiting her. In church all Elizabeth could do was stare at him in disgust then after the sermon she ran outside to be alone in the rain with her tears and thoughts. He had followed her. He proposed to her. She sharply rejected him. He then left her. Elizabeth's mind was spinning, the man she hated had proposed to her! Imagine that! Completely distressed Elizabeth went back to her friend's house to clean up. While staring at her reflection in the mirror, Mr. Darcy entered the house and placed a letter on the windowsill because he could not verbally explain his intentions toward Bingley and her sister. Reading the letter when he had left Elizabeth's view of Darcy had changed. Elizabeth returned home, still bewildered, and found that her aunt and uncle had delivered her sister from London.Although Elizabeth had just returned home, her heart wanted to get away from her family so she gladly accepted an invitation to go with her aunt and uncle to tour the sights of the Peak District. Despite her swirling mind Elizabeth enjoyed the trip, until she learned that they were going to tour Mr. Darcy's home. That set her off. Instantly she tried to sway her aunt and uncle not to see his house, but to no avail. Mr. Darcy's housekeeper talked of her master as a wonderful man, a man Elizabeth prejudged as proud when he was really kind and considerate. She had been wrong about him. After arriving home again, talking with Jane, and resting in the parlor with her mother and sisters, Elizabeth was surprised when Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy knocked on the door. The two gentlemen entered the parlor said a few words then Bingley left suddenly again with Darcy trailing behind because Bingley, who was nervous, did not know how to express his feelings. Reentering the room, moments later, he asked to talk to Jane in private. Elizabeth knew all to well that Bingley was proposing to her sister, and guessed that Darcy had helped him do so. All had ended well for Jane, but does it end well for Elizabeth? You will have to watch the heart wrenching ending to find out.Drawing you in like a hungry bear to food, "Pride and Prejudice's" actors and setting made the viewer feel like they were in the story. Keira Knightley did an exceptional job of playing Elizabeth because she showed the character's obvious outward emotions and internally complex emotions as well. She forced the viewer to experience, endure, and relish in happiness, disgust, and pain. Once you feel the emotions Elizabeth underwent it is easier to understand Mr. Darcy's emotions which are intricate and misunderstood. He is a complicated man. Exceptionally well written "Pride and Prejudice" is the ultimate love story. If you want a romantic and heart pumping movie, which touches your very soul, watch "Pride and Prejudice."

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Received the package much quicker than anticipated. Bravo! Have really enjoyed the film. Loved the music and the acting. What a great idea to have the characters in the film the same ages as the characters in the book. While it is very modern in its 'feel' it is also very true to the book (especially when you consider the length of the book that had to be condensed into a 2 hour film). I have read the book many times - it is my favorite- the girls were just as I had imagined them to be, while Kiera Knightly and Matthew Macfadyen were just perfect as Lizzie and Darcy.  I think Joe Wright is a different sort of director - as I watched the movie I was continually aware that some scenes reminded me of art works by Rembrandt, Vermeer etc and the colours of modern artists like Picasso. I was very impressed with the extra features on the DVD and enjoyed the directors commentary. A great feel good movie with wit and charm.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my favorite book of all time. I own the miniseries in both VCR and DVD format. While I realize it's hard to fairly compare the two, due to running time I found to be fair I'd look at a few different things.  After reading the book so many times one comes to know the dialogue and vernacular. I gave allowances for the running time on the former but the slipping in and out of period vernacular on the latter drove me a bit nuts.  Locations beautiful.  Most of the characters well cast. (Mary is the unnattractive sister and a Talulah Riley is very pretty)  Particularly liked Dame Judy Dench as Lady Catherine and Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett.  Also did not like completely deleting characters and changing the dialogue to suit.  Suddenly the Gardiners have no children?  Where was Maria Lucas?  Unmarried ladies of the time did not travel alone. The the turning-point is the trip to Pemberly. Ladies of the time would not be visiting a house touching things.  Yes I know this movie is adapted from the book, but I think I would have given it another star if it stayed truer to the book and the proper behavior of the period.  I'd watch it again, but like the title of my review states... The Colin Firth mini-series sets the bar and those are some very big shoes to fill, indeed.
summary: The Colin Firth Mini Series sets the bar

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A nostalgic piece for drama lovers looking for a story adapted from a wonderful book.  This film is very family friendly with some historic value as the viewer is transported back to another era.  I'm always in the mood for a good love story, and this one is written well.Chrissy K. McVay - Author

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen the previous version with Colin Firth and have read the book - my personal opinion of this rendition of one of history's finest pieces of literature is that Jane Austen would be turning in her grave if she were forced to sit through this tiresome and pityful movie. The actors for the principal characters ill-chosen and clearly not capable of doing justice to the complexity of their literary personalities: Keira Knightley cannot even begin to fill the shoes of the fiercely defiant and headstrong Elizabeth Bennet, and Matthew Macfadyen's ridiculously poor portrayal of Mr. Darcy pales in comparison to that of Colin Firth. Moreover, the movie completely fails to capture essential high-lights of the story, limps through the development of major relationships between characters, and in general is more tediously boring than any period drama in recent Hollywood history. A COMPLETE HIT-AND-MISS!
summary: Pride & Prejudice - an insult to Jane Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The disc set is packaged in a box cleverly designed to look like a P&P; book.  Inside is the double disc set, the amazing soundtrack, and a terrific book with lots of commentary on the filming and photos.  The book in itself is a treat as I remember similar Oscar pressbooks going on ebay for upwards of a $100.  (I in fact was able to win a French one -- and am so delighted to have the English counterpart!)  The CD is fantastic -- as the Dario Marianelli music is one of the truly magical treasures of the film.  The 1st disc is exactly like the DVD I all ready have with  the director's commentary; conversations with the cast; Jane Austen, Ahead of Her Time; A Bennett Family Portrait; and HBO First Look.  The 2nd has the new features:  1)The Politics of Dating (with a funny comment by Matthew Macfadyen quipping something like, "I fancy you; here's my number"  and cutting away to a handwritten Fitwilliam Darcy calling card with a number on it. Too funny.Enjoyable.  2)Galleries of the 19th Century which has stills of various art, furniture and fashions.  Interesting.  3)The Stately Homes of P&P; that you can use the interactive map to look at stills of the homes of the movie as well as watch film with interviews and comments about the locations.  VERY good.  4) P&P; Family Tree was something lacking.  Interesting for those that may be new to the story but for me it was just "filler."All in all, I am pleased to have it.  Was excited to get anything new about the story and this film.  Yes, I would have loved to have seen more unseen interviews with the characters, bloopers, cut scenes, etc... If that is what you are hoping for with this new release, that is not in this gift set.  However, if you are a fan of the movie, would like the sountrack, a couple extras on the 2nd DVD, and that most excellent pressbook... then buy this.  I for one am happy to have it in my collection.  Besides, it's always good to have a back-up copy of the film... god forbid, if I cannot locate my Dvd when I am in need of my P&P2005; fix! And for an added bonus, my copy came with a free movie pass to Keira Knightley's ATONEMENT.
summary: This was a delightful gift,,, to myself!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pretty good rendering of a very long book! :-) I like Mr Darcy of course. Lizzie was great too. I recommend it!
summary: Some parts a bit slow but I love it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen this one and the one with Colin Firth,and this is by far my favorite! So good,that I had to order it. Rosamund Pike makes a much more believable "beautiful" oldest sister Jane where in the Firth version,I could not stomach how the mother kept referring to the very unnatractive Susannah Harker's character Jane,as being beautiful and so much prettier than Jennifer Ehle's Elizabeth,which would be a laugh,except she is so unattractive,that it makes you dislike the very unlikeable, flaky, mother even more! I detested her,almost as much as the very shrill- trampy Lydia!The romance between Jane and Mr. Bingley is also more developed in this version,where in the Firth version,it is non-existant,so is it totally unbelievable that Elizabeth even makes a fuss over Mr. Darcy's involvement in parting them,and that Jane and Mr. Bingley would even end up marrying! Also the early relationship between Lizzy and Mr. Darcy is much more developed in this version.Everyone and everything about this version is much more attractive and likeable! I find the Firth version full of cold,unattractive people,and totally unbelievable,and unmoving.If the Firth version with it's creepy, totally/unattractive/unlikable characters is more true to the book,then I have no desire to ever read the book!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: We just purchased a blu-ray player and wanted to see one of our favorite DVD's in the new format (for us)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I never thought there could be another Mr. Darcy other than Colin Firth but I was wrong.  Matthew Macfadyen presents another perspective to a difficult personality.  Plus the images and music were lovely.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version is good, but I still prefer the BBC series from the 90's.  It's about 5 hours in length and just very well acted.  There were some good points to this movie, but it was a little too hollywood.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I finished reading Pride and Prejudice and immediately checked out the Colin Firth BBC series as well as this film from my local library.  I watched this film first since it was only slightly shorter than the BBC series from the mid 90s.The film stays pretty true to the nature of the book, with some few exceptions.  Mainly there are many moments from the book which could not possibly make it into a 2 hour film.  Several characters were cut entirely, such as Maria and Sir William Lucas.  The two visits to Catherine de Bourg's estate were condensed into one.  And there are a few added scenes where the film takes some liberty.  All in all though, the changes made were good for the pace and continuity of the film.  The only odd scene was when Lizzy confronted Darcy about Jane and Bingly and Wickham.  He actually gives half of his response there, then the other half is contained in a letter (like the book). But the half response kind of takes something away from that moment as described in the novel.The acting is very good.  I liked the casting for most of the main characters.  Donald Sutherland was an odd choice, but he worked as Mr Bennett.  Kiera Knightly is very good as Lizzy; she embodies the under appreciated attractiveness that is described in the novel, especially compared to her more obviously and classically attractive sister Jane.  Knightly embodies the fire and the tomboy style of Lizzy's character very well.I am most happy with the actor who played Darcy.  He is very good at the brooding, yet firm resolution of Darcy's character.  He has the tall, rugged handsomeness that Austen describes.The production quality is what I liked about this film over the drab and overly dark (just bad contrast, not anything with the lighting) BBC series.  Where the BBC series looks like a DVD made from one of those VHS dubbing to DVD devices, this film shines with dramatic settings, and quality film making.  Granted they had the budget to do so!  But with great cinematography, a quality soundtrack, and terrific casting, this is easily my favorite Pride and Prejudice adaptation (over the Laurence Olivier film and the BBC series).
summary: Review of the film as compared to the novel~

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wonderful story and acting.  It is a true pleasure to watch and I recommend purchasing it and adding it to your collection.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I ran to theatres when Pride and Prejudice first came out, later on bought the movie and have watched it about hundred times. Although the story doesn't exactly follow the book (otherwise the movie would be MUCH longer), the major themes and elements are put into the movie in a stunning way. As for the scenery, the countryside and Pemberley were amazing (I want to go there!), and the actors were very believable, especially Lizzy and Mr. Darcy. I'm a tiny bit disappointed that they didn't put something between Lizzy's running out the door and them together and Pemberley (like a clip of marriage?), but otherwise the film was amazing. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves soppy romance stories... like me. :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you like romance novels or films, you'll love this movie. It's romantic, funny, and realistic, without being disappointing. It's beautifully acted, too.

Although the one from 1996 describes what happened more in the book, this one touches my heart more and Elizabeth and Darcy seem to have more chemistry together.  I would recommend this movie to everyone.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: DVD arrived very quickly and was well packaged.  No complaints of any kind.  Thank you.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was a little disappointed by this version. I read the book last week, and watched this film two days afterwards. It was not be compared to the book, I knew it, but it could have been better done.During the whole film, the rythm is too rapid, it seems that the director wanted to insert as much scenes as possible and it results in a superficial treatment of the characters, in a lack of emotions. There could sometimes be more length, so that we might enter into their minds, thoughts or feelings. We are external to what happens, it isn't really moving. This film is a sort of superimposition of scenes.Moreover the light thrown on the country was too fairy-tale-ish... and the last scene (invented what's more) was the same.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I personally loved this movie. I loved its (perhaps inappropriate) use of Bronte-esque scenery, its earthiness, the boisterous country life of the Bennett family...I loved it all. I realize that the costuming and manners were not quite right for the period. In my opinion the heart of the story survives despite the film's nonconformity to these restrictions. I thought the acting was wonderful, particularly that of Kiera Knightley. Donald Sutherland made me cry. The music was lovely, the cinematography lush and sweeping. There is an unabashed romance to this film that is truly rare in movies today.Is it faithful to the book? No. But then, film is a completely different medium. A good film is not simply the source material (book) with pictures. It involves first the author, then the director, then the actors, art director, cinematographer and so on and so on. All of these people have their own visions to realize. It's a collaborative effort. Jane Austen's original vision is interpreted anew.I loved the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version, but isn't there room for more than one interpretation? Many are acting like Joe Wright stole Pride and Prejudice. If you don't like it, then there's no reason to ever watch it again. Pretend it never happened. I understand. Honest. I won't ever again watch the William Hurt/Charlotte Gainsbourg version of Jane Eyre, but I'm over it. I have a choice- to watch or not to watch. I've made mine.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I hate to review the movie in such a fashion but invariably as a fan of the TV version, I initially (and errantly) made comparisons to that version and this film version.Overall, I was rather pleased and surprised by my reaction to this film.  Granted with a listing of solid actors, I did not anticipate it being bad, but instead a bad interpretation of the book (which I have read a couple of times) especially given the time constraints that feature film provides.While the 1995 TV version is quintessential in its adaptation of the text, the 2005 film version in my humble opinion captures the spirit and the raw emotion that although not on public display must have been in the hearts and minds of the central characters.  I guess this is what many folks consider the "modern edge" given to this adaptation.  I personally found it refreshing, vibrant and alive.In terms of casting I must start by saying that I loved Keira Knightley's Lizzie - by far the best interpretation of the role.  And despite those who were blown away by the dashing Colin Firth, Matthew MacFadyen did the role of Darcy service.  His performance wonderfully gives perspective and insight into the perceived fastidiousness of the Darcy persona - I felt like in this version I understood where he is coming from.Beyond the two leads, all the supporting characters did a wonderful job.  I am almost tempted to go to the theater and see it again it was that good.  Highly recommended to all!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was enchanted by Pride and Prejudice from the first time I saw it. You watch the whole movie enthralled, waiting for the next moment to come and at the end you think back on it and realize nothing much really happened. Just some balls and a lot of conversation and yet you watch it again with enthusiasm many times over. The characters are perfectly cast. Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy is terribly charismatic and proud and just a little bit sinfully delicious with that deeply resonating voice. Keira Knightly is a delightfuly cheerful and strong-willed Lizzy. Rosamund Pike as Jane Bennet is sweet and ethereally beautiful while Simon Woods as Mr. Bingley is heart warmingly akward and charming. You constantly want to cover your ears as protection from the grating trill of Jena Malone's Lydia Bennet and if Mrs. Bennet played by Brenda Blethyn was your mother you'd want to run and hide though she obviously loves her children which makes up for her overbearing manner in some small way. Mr Bennet (Donald Sutherland) is appropriately preoccupied and Judi Dench is coldly regal as Lady Catherine de Bourg. Each and every cast member was, in my opinion, perfect for the part that they played.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, I know that it doesn't conform to the book as much as we would like, but this movie is still highly entertaining and captures the spirit of the novel.  I think the chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy is well acted by Keira Knightly and Matthew Macfadyen (especially him).  I LOVE the way Macfadyen plays Darcy.  Also, Judy Dench is brilliant (as always) as Lady Catherine. She's SO much better than the actress who played Lady Catherine in the BBC version.All in all, this is an enjoyable movie that I've watched about 5 times so far.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In fact, I have!  I've watched this movie at least 5 times and I never get sick of it.  The cinematography alone is breathtaking, but it is the acting that always blows me away.  This cast and director nailed it...I have seen every version of this story and this is by far my favorite.Great movie for a rainy or gloomy day...it's guaranteed to boost your spirits.
summary: I could watch this movie again and again....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie itself is very good and definitely worth owning. The product in general was in perfect condition and it was obviously new. Would definitely recommend.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie was a complete disaster. The first thing I found distasteful was Mrs. Bennett. She is portrayed as a hysterical woman with not an ounce of decency or proper manners. She seems to delights in behaving outrageously inappropriate, even breaching proper etiquette. Her daughters, apart from Jane, are portrayed as silly, simpering girls, with no regard for propriety or even common sense. Elizabeth Bennet, portrayed by Keira Knightly, does no credit to the character she is supposed to be portraying. She comes across as snooty, judgmental and often just as silly as Mrs. Bennett and her sisters. She shows no respect for those of superior rank, or even her own parents. Mr. Darcy is portrayed as dull, rather then proud and arrogant. The actress portraying Miss. Carline Bingley would have made a fine Mr. Darcy. In this movie, Mr. Darcy comes across as more nervous and afraid then proud. In fact, in many scenes, he almost looks as if he is about to burst into tears. The only character I actually tolerated was Jane. She, in my opinion, is the only character in this movie that shows any charm or manners. However, like the rest of the cast, she too had no depth.I found the setting of the Bennett home to be absolutely disgusting. The Bennett's are portrayed as extremely poor, so much so that they allow a pig to walk through the house. In the book, the Bennett's were upper middle class and did NOT live on a farm. They certainly would never have had barn animals in their home. Jane Austen would certainly be disgusted at this rediculous portrayal of one of her best works.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film made my trip to england even more surreal and beautiful. The peak district and the rolling english countryside is shown at its best int he movie. It was inspiring, and my trip was very emotional. The film itself is great! It's one of the few movies I can watch repeatedly! And i have a short attention span! I'm happy there was a bit more affection shown in this adaptation. I  found Macfayden and Knightley to have extraordinary chemistry. 5 stars!!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What can u say about the book? I don't believe that there are enough superlatives to do it justice. The music and performances are magical. The CD is pure heaven. Keira Knightly and Matthew Macfadyen were born to portray Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy. There are so many other extremely talented actors and actress'  in the movie. The costumes are works of art. Before the day is out tomorrow, get your hands on a copy of each.
summary: Pride and Prejudice  CD and DVD will blow you away.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I know this movie is on tv all the time, but it's usually cut so dreadfully that you want to scream. This is a lovely interpretation of a long-loved story made for today's sophisticated viewer. Keira Knightly is wonderful, but she's in just about every scene, so if you don't like her, this isn't for you.
summary: A modern production of a classic

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having watched the 1940 Pride and Prejudice (Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier) and BBC's TV version (Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle), it is simply a must for me to see this remake and compare with its predecessors.In the first 30 minutes, I have to adjust to Keira Knightley's relatively modern face and giggles. She has given such an impressive performance in Bend it Like Beckham and Love Actually that it took time to envisage her in the classic role of Elizabeth. Fortunately, the last hour of the movie saw her adding greater depth to her character, making her and Mr. Darcy a charming couple to watch.While the 1940 version revealed a more comical side of the story (such as performances of Mr. Collins and Lady Catherine de Bourg) and the BBC version was graced by the beautiful landscape and the handesome Colin Firth, I would say this one is a well balanced remake. Maybe Elizabeth (Knightley)and Darcy(Matthew MacFaydyen) on their own do not steal the scenes. Yet together they look such an attractive couple. A 20-year-old Knightley has made Elizabeth come alive on screen, intelligent and beautiful. MacFaydyen has also portrayed a handsome and vulnerable Mr. Darcy. Jane was convincingly sweet and uncalculating whereas Donald Sutherland, as the father, gave her daughter away in tears of joy.The superb cinematography, a sense of tension and urgency when Elizabeth discovered how she had wronged Darcy, a quickening of pace made possible by rearranging and rewriting (Alas, a big risk!)of some scenes have all made the movie a delight to watch. Credits must also be given to a more realistic portrayal of the Bennet family. The Bennet sisters' costumes were conspicously plainer than the Bingley's and Darcy's. The extravagant interior design of the grand mansion (Chatsworth) at Pemberly is simply awesome.As a big fan of the previous versions, to be able to finish the movie and still feel good about it, I would say this movie is a successful remake. Even for fans mesmerized by the other remakes, this movie is worth watching for including new elements which complements nicely to its predecessors.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Call me a Jane Austen Purist but i hated this movie, I did. I tried to bring myself to like it, but I feel as if the A&E; version was more closer to the time, the era, the clothing, the language, the seting, etc.And then the constant childish giggling, this is not the Lizzie I know.The more I watched of the film the more I saw characters being destroyed. For example, Mr. Bennett was just not believable to me and Mr. Colins was poorly cast. I just didn't like this film, even I did think that Mcfayden did a good job in presenting darcy but I don't know, this film just did not do it for me. I feel as if Jane AUsten would be rolling in her grave if she saw this version. I do. I dont know how else to describe my disapointment......
summary: I love Jane Austen, But I HATED it
