review_text: This is a great family movie. My wife and daughters love it and will watch it over and over again. I recommend it not only for the visual content, but also for the music.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Very well done! Classic love story. If you like Jane Austen then this movie is for you. I enjoy watching this retelling as much as reading the book!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have to agree with at least one other reviewer on this site...I could hardly understand a word of what was said in the first 20 minutes or so of this film. Admittedly I saw it at the cinema so the producers may have had chance to do something about it for the DVD release...but short of reshooting the first few scenes with another actress in Knightley's role I can't see how they can. The main problem is Keira Knightley's unwillingness to open her mouth when she speaks. She has an awful habit of sticking out her chin and speaking most of her lines through clenched teeth - it's incomprehensible for the most part and almost had me walking out of the cinema (she was exactly the same in Love Actually). Thankfully for us all her case of near terminal lock-jaw seemed to clear after 20 minutes or so after which we were treated to overall a very good film.Not as good as the BBC version but worth a watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love this version of Pride and Prejudice with Matthew Macfadyen and Keira Knightley.  Already own the widescreen format. ... had to have the full screen version too.  Love everything about the 2005 film. ... the cast is perfect and the cinematography and music score are magical.
summary: My favorite version of Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Adaptations are always tricky since condensing a large 200-500+ page book can lead to liberties and many events taken out entirely. Another thing that can happen is filmmakers tend to be too nervous of altering anything that what worked in book format doesn't work as well on film. Hence we get Pride and Prejudice, which looks great, has respectable casting, but unfortunately has poor pacing and its 19th century-esque language.The film centers around the Bennet sisters, most specifically Elizabeth(Lizzy) and Jane. They're all trying to get married, hopefully with someone with a big wallet. Jane ends up meeting someone named Mr. Bingley which takes an awful long time to resolve while Lizzy is in a love/hate mode with Mr. Darcy, a friend of Mr Bingley. The entire rest of the film follows the 2 women trying to get their respective men to marry them while the mom gets frantic about marrying them off.One thing that tends to plague adaptations is trying to match the spirit of the novel a bit too closely without making it work in a film format. As such the book resembles the language from the book, incredibly long and dictionary-laden words are throughout the film, making me ask "isn't it better to just say 'I hate you' rather than that much words"? Same thing with the modern Romeo and Juliet film except this takes place in its proper time period and still seems odd hearing it.Many actors and actresses seem to only have that in title only, as if they don't actually "act" they just do their job without doing much else. Usually they're girls with pretty faces where you watch them in a film and they don't really do much else that makes them memorable, they just read their lines. Look at Al Pacino in Godfather or Peter O' Toole in Lawrence of Arabia, perfect acting but making them transcend just lines on the page. The actresses here do their parts well, with a special nod of course to Keira Knightley who still has some awkwardness but is still capable of making a character believable.It's a period piece so you're going to expect 2 things: beautifully shot and accurate costumes and of course we have both. Colorful sharp cinematography with 18th century style clothes make the film feel believable and accurate. The music also suits the film well, largely piano-based with some orchestration peppered throughout but not enough memorable themes to make me want to buy the soundtrack.If you don't really feel like reading the novel, it's always best to check out this film although it's not exactly need to buy DVD material, unless you're a Jane Austen fan.
summary: 3.5; I merely liked it, didn't find it great

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Loved it.  Have watched it many, many times!Great characters!  Oh, the marvelous Mr. Collins!  The dancing, costumes, and scenery is excellent.  You won't be dissappointed.
summary: Beautifully made! Haunting music! Gorgeous cinematography!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In my freshman literature seminar, I was put on the spot by my professor and asked how I liked Pride and Prejudice. After a few throat clearings, I admitted that I had not been a fan and in fact found the language so dry so as to make the novel boring. I certainly am not alone in thinking this, and most who do tend to be male. That being said, this movie was incredibly entertaining. I've heard marvelous things about the long BBC version (many people watched it instead of reading the book for my seminar), but it's hard to imagine it being better than this. Knightley reminded me of Winona Ryder in Little Women and played her character splendidly. I highly recommend this for girls and guys alike. You'll love the dry British humor and the wonderful scenery. Maybe even more than the book itself.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is a wonderful remake due tothe great chemistry among the main characters! A classic romance you have to see again. Ordering on Amazon was a good experience because I got the items quickly and without any problems.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride Ampersand Prejudice (or just plain Pride and Prejudice) is a pleasant movie with nice acting by all concerned. Keira Knightley does a fine job, but for me Jennifer Ehle remains the gold standard for Lizzies. The director and writer crammed a lot into the run time. If you like the more leisurely pace of the BBC Ehle/Firth version, you might find yourself longing for more than you're getting. But with either, or the much earlier BBC version from 1980, the story is such a strong, romantic fable of manners and misunderstandings that it's hard to go wrong. Even the half-hour TV program with Wishbone as Darcy was good. If you've never seen a version of Pride and Prejudice, however, please don't start out with the Olivier-Garson movie.The only criticism I have is that I thought the movie score was overblown and there were a few too many grand scenic shots. This version is entertaining and satisfying but, for me, not especially memorable.
summary: A Pleasant Way To Spend An Afternoon

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am an avid fan of the 1995 A&E;/BBC version of Pride and Prejudice starring Colin Firth.  And so, I had my reservations about giving this one a whirl.  Most of Hollywood's literary adaptations are underdeveloped, underwhelming and downright superficial.  Emma starring Gwyneth Paltrow springs to mind.  However, this 2005 adaptation directed by Joe Wright and adapted by Deborah Moggach, while not better than the 1995 version, is definitely more enjoyable than the bunch.  (Warning: there will be more comparisons between this version and the 1995 version.  So, if you're tired of reading comparisons between those two, then I suggest you skip reading this review.)  The cinematography is gorgeous -- the scenery and sets are a major eyeful.  The film direction is one of the best I've seen.  Wright has done a splendid job.  The music score is one of the best I've heard.  I especially love "Dawn," the one played in the beginning of the movie.  It is absolutely beautiful. The wardrobe, however, is a disappointment.  The gowns (more Georgian than Regency) are not appropriate for the time.  Elizabeth Bennet would have never attended the Netherfield ball without wearing gloves and Caroline Bingley's sleeveless slip dress with a plunging neckline is downright anachronistic.  Not only does it look too modern, a noble lady would have never worn such a flimsy gown at a formal ball unless she was some sort of daring widow wanting to cause a scandal.  The gowns Mrs. Bennet and Lady Catherine de Bourgh wore were at least two decades or so out of style.  And I won't even comment on Judy Dench's hairstyle except for one expression: yikes!  That hairdo was fashionable in the 1750s -- at least sixty years before Austen wrote Pride and Prejudice.  The quality of the characterization varies from person to person. I do not like Keira Knightley's Elizabeth Bennet.  Knightley does not show the right amount of sharp wit, intelligence and conflicting emotions that makes Miss Bennet one of the most endearing heroines in literature.  The director concentrates more on Knightley's pretty face than on focusing on the character's complexities.  This Elizabeth is too petulant and giggly for my taste.  Jennifer Ehle had a better grasp of the character.  I did not like Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet.  He comes across more as a cynical, laid-back loner than the sarcastic and witty character in the book, qualities that were passed on to Elizabeth.  (By the way, I found it odd that in this film Mr. Bennet and Lizzy do not have the kind of closeness and affection that is required in their roles.)  Also, his imitation of an English accent is simply awful.  I wish Benjamin Whitrow had been cast in this version as well.  I also liked the actor who played Mr. Collins in the '95 version better than Tom Hollander.  Even though Hollander was wonderful in BBC's Wives and Daughters, I feel he was miscast as Mr. Collins.  The actors who played Mrs. Bennet, Jane, Mr. Bingley, Caroline Bingley, Lydia and Kitty do a good job, but somehow aren't as colorful as the ones in the 1995 miniseries.  And last, but definitely not least, is Matthew Macfadyen as the dark, handsome, proud and brooding Mr. Darcy.I don't think I'm being biased when I say that, while Macfadyen does some wonderful scenes in which Darcy shows his longing for Elizabeth, he in no way outshadows Colin Firth's performance.  Firth was able to transmit Mr. Darcy's complexities and conflicting emotions in almost a flawless way.  He also convinced me that Mr. Darcy was indeed rude and proud, or at least seemed that way from Elizabeth's perspective, and Macfadyen's Mr. Darcy comes across more as shy and awkward than anything else, which would have been fine, but then why would he be so against Elizabeth's poor connections and convince Mr. Bingley that Jane isn't the one for him?  The one thing Macfadyen was able to convey better than Firth was his love and desire for Elizabeth.  (Actually, I thought Firth's subtle approach to Darcy's feelings and sexual tension for Lizzy was more dead on.  Macfadyen's approach is more blatant and in-your-face.)  This film's Darcy appearing without a cravat in the last scenes has a nice, sensual touch, but it's nothing like Firth jumping on the lake and then walking back to Pemberley in wet clothes.  Anyway, as for the rest of the film, due to time constraints, many scenes are glossed over, including the whole Lydia and Mr. Wickham debacle.  In fact, Mr. Wickham, such an integral character in the story, appears only in two or three scenes! There are also some characters that are eliminated altogether, like Mr. Bingley's married sister (who was supposed to be Miss Bingley's chaperone.  Miss Bingley would have never stayed at a house alone with two single men, even if one of them was her brother).  And what can I say about this version's Miss Caroline Bingley except that all she does is scowl, purse her lips and look conceited?  Anna Chancellor of the 1995 version may not be as attractive as Kelly Reilly, but she was definitely better developed.  In fact, the characters and storyline were better developed in the 1995 version.  Then again, the miniseries had eight episodes, plenty of time to be true to the novel.  Also, this version is not as centered on humor as it should have been.  This version is more solemn and everything and everyone centers on Elizabeth.  Then there are the anachronisms.  Mr. Bingley would have never entered the private chambers of a female guest, Elizabeth would have never walked around the village with her hair undone, Mr. Darcy would have never entered Elizabeth's bedroom (without wearing a cravat) to hand her a letter, and Lady Catherine de Bourgh would never pay a visit in the middle of the night.  Perhaps these details are negligible to some, but not for me.  Period accuracy is very important to me.  All in all, despite all the flaws I mentioned regarding the cast and condensed plot due to the limited 129-minute format, this adaptation of Pride and Prejudice is still worth watching and owning, which is why I give it four stars.  The last scenes are wonderful and romantic (if a bit corny), perfect for fans of period pieces with modern-day sensitivities.  The DVD is also wonderful -- great audio and video with wonderful special features.  I highly recommend it.  And, if you haven't watched it, please get the A&E;/BBC production starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle if you long for a truer adaptation of Austen's literary classic.  That goes without saying, but I had to anyway. :-)
summary: Not perfect or quite as good as P&P '95, but still enjoyable and recommendable...

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Admittedly, I did not have high hopes for this moving knowing that it would be hard to do in 2 hours what A&E; did in 5+ hours.  But,  I had thought it would have been better--Emma and Sense and Sensibility were much better shortened Hollywood versions of Austen's books than this was.So what did I find wrong with this adaptation?1.  The Bennets looked sloppy and poor.  I immediately thought back to two lines from the book that made me think that this was not how the Bennet's should have appeared:  Jane tells Lizzy "We're not very poor." and Lizzy telling Lady Catherine "He is a gentleman and I am a gentleman's daughter, so far we are equal."  I felt that the Bennet's looked just a little better than the orphans in Oliver Twist.2.  Mr. Bennett was portrayed as a grumpy old man.  One thing I  loved about Pride and Predjudice was Austen's humor and Mr. Bennett had in my opinion some of her best lines.  These were totally lacking in this movie and didn't need to be--why change his character completely?  True, he did redeem himself a little in the end and I loved the line about sending in any beau's that may call for Kitty and Mary."3.  At the movie's beginning, Lizzy seemed to have a chip on her shoulder and hated Darcy from the moment he walked in the door.  I couldn't account for that.  She felt at liberty to make biting comments to him before she ever overheard his critical comment of her.  She really irritated me from the beginning and it was hard to get past that to enjoy the rest of the movie.4.  Mr.  Bingley appeared as a bumbling imbesole instead of a humble and likeable gentleman and I agree with one writer that the actress who played Jane would have made a better Elizabeth.  Jane seemed to have more wits about her than Lizzy.  Kitty and Lydia and sometimes Lizzy seemed to giggle for no reason.  I found them irritating as well. Georgiana Darcy's character was also altered.  The book describes her as being very shy as to appear a snob but that is not so.  This Georgiana was not a bit shy.Overall, I felt that the end of the film was better than the beginning, but I still would never buy or recommend this movie.  I wondered if I would have liked it better having known nothing of the book.  I would have preferred much more of the story cut out to develop the overall love story between Elizabeth and Darcy and give certain characters more presence.I know that my reviews will probably be unpopular, since others who have rated this movie poorly have recieved ratings to reflect that, but to be honest, I find it hard to find many things I liked about this version.I'll stick to the A&E; version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The review on the box says "Best Film of the Year" and I would agree that it's one of the best for sure.  It's beautifully done.....with fabulous acting and an outstanding screen play.  The costumes are lovely, too.  It's an in depth look into the restrictive, oppressed English life in the late 1800's. The thing i liked about it the best is that it ENDS HAPPY.  None of that "unspoken rule" from Hollywood that says if a movie doesn't end with everyone dying or suffering, it's not a good movie.  This movie fulfills all your fantasies about how injustices should be answered and reminds you that life and love really can be all you want it to be.  Rent or buy it FOR SURE.
summary: GREAT  classic drama/comedy/love story from Jane Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I went to see this in the theater,and then refreshed my memory as to its sheer awfulness by watching it again on an airplane flight. The worst feature of the film is the script, with its utterly tin-eared adaptation of Austen's brilliant dialogue. The casting, acting, costumes and attempts to represent daily life in the Regency are also really, really bad. Austen's Eliza Bennett is a rather sharp-tongued young lady, but Keira Knightley plays her as an out and out boor. Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett has to be one of the most inappropriate pieces of casting I've ever seen. The filmmakers seem to think that Regency gentlemen lived like Albanian peasants of the same era -- e.g., see the scene in which Donald Sutherland is seen following a large pig into the pigsty which is actually attached to the Bennetts' house. Elizabeth and Darcy play the climactic love scene outside, in their jammies. If you want to watch an adaptation that is true to Austen, buy the DVD of the wonderful 1980 BBC "P&P" with Elizabeth Garvie as Eliza Bennett. Everything about it -- cast, acting, script -- is perfect.
summary: This is dreadful -- don't waste your money

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In reading other reviews of this movie, I felt I just had to be one to say something nice about it! Just like every other movie, this one had strengths and weakness, here is my take on it:Strengths-This movie looked amazing, it was truely beautiful to look at! The cinematography was beautiful and more artistic than a lot of flims that have come out. The colors were very rich, and the lighting was...perfect. Location shots were wide and encompassing; when Elizabeth first saw Mr. Darcy's home, you can "feel" and see how large and impressive it is. Another seen that stands out, was when Elizabeth was being shown around Mr. Darcy's home and is shown into a room full of light, and sculptures. The feeling of coolness in the room, being full of diffused light, and pale white marble figures, was lovely!I also enjoyed a more "down to earth feel" to the family, and their looks. They may have had a richer station in the book, but the fact that the family was not swimming in silks, furniture and little lap dogs, hardly detracts from the film. Not to mention the sisters acted, well...like girls! We are not all perfectly behaved all the time, nor are we little angels.Also, the ages for Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy in the actors, were closer to the book. And I think their youth and inexperience with love/relationships, was a nice refreshing way to act their parts.Finely, I loved the big ballroom, dance! The music, wall to wall people and activity was very realistic. I felt like I was there in the room, listening to the girls talking, dancing and laughing. In our modern age of elictric lights, CD players and deodorant I think we sometimes forget what a candle light party, with a bunch of sweaty people in it would look like.Weaknesses-Yes, the story is kind of choppy. If you haven't either read the book, or seen the four hour A&E; version you might be lost. Although strangely enough, I went to see this with four other women...all fairly "girly girls", and they all felt the story went "too slow" and was almost "too long for a movie".Another thing I have to agree with, is that the different relationships could have been given more time, or better development. But still, at the end of the movie you don't leave wondering what happend to anyone, or wondering why someone was left out. You know what happens!Conclusion-In the end I really liked this movie. The twist's and a different artistic take on a good story, is always a pleasant thing. Maybe it wasn't historiclly perfect, or exact to the book...but if that is what you really want; Stick to the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The first time I watched this version of Pride and Prejudice I didn't like it at all.  I am not a n Austen purist, but have read all her work and have watched all the film versions.  I watched this version a second and third time, and to give it a real fair chance, I watched it as if it were a "Readers Digest" version and did enjoy it.  However, I still had problems with it.These are some of the mistakes that I consider unforgivable, because they could have easily been avoided.  In the scene of the first ball I found it ridiculous that everyone stopped dancing and the music stopped, when the Bingleys and Mr. Darcy entered.  In such a large party how would everyone at once realize they entered?  Why would they all stop dancing?  Like another here wrote, the Bingleys and Darcy are rich not royalty.  Then the Bennets approach them to be introduced.  This would not happen.  They would have waited to be approached and introduced by a mutual acquaintence.Keira Knightly is very cute in this version even if she acts more like a 14 year old than a 20 year old.  Keira Knightly delivers many of her lines too fast, which is the way most silly teens talk today.  Women matured early back then at least in their mind and manner.  You can see this in Jane Austen herself and what and how she wrote even before her teen years.  Mathew Macfadyen seems more depressed most of the time rather than arrogant, or proud.  I can overlook this as there seems to be not much time to develop any nuance in any of these characters in this short version as the producers were more interested in certain scenery, or their own "art" and cutting costs.  There were some very beautiful scenes.  I especially liked the gorgeous scene where Elizabeth with her aunt and uncle stopped to eat at the huge tree on their way to Pemberley.  The scene of Elizabeth standing at the edge of the cliff was beautiful, but disturbing.  Who in their right mind would stand that close to the edge of a cliff with, or without, that wind blowing?  The Longborn house was very shabby and unkempt looking.  Not at all like the home of a "Gentleman" and his family.  Donald Sutherland is a disappointment as Mr. Bennet.  As another commented here, he looks more the hobo than a gentleman.  He shows none of the wit of the mini series Mr. Bennet, but is a rather bland character.  I did not find this Mr. Collins particularly funny.  The very idea that he would interrupt everyone's breakfast to propose to Elizabeth is ridiculous. I think he would have at least waited til after breakfast.  All the comedy was taken out of Mrs. Bennet.  I did not find much humor in this version.At Rosings Elizabeth meets Darcy again.  She says, "Mr. Darcy, what are YOU doing here?"  How rude is that?  And, as if she didn't already know via Mr. Collins  that he is the nephew of Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  Later Darcy barges in on her unannounced as she is writing to Jane.  Apparently he was so bold as to let himself into the house of the Collins'.  Creepy!  Then later on, the first proposal in this version is strange.  Keira Knightly practically spits in the face of Macfayden as she almost screams out his offenses to him.  Then Macfayden comes in so close as to look as though he would kiss her.  How strange is that?!  Again Darcy creeps up behind Elizabeth to deliver his letter of explaination after his proposal has been refused by Elizabeth.  Apparently having again let himself into the house and unannounced.  Again creepy.Another thing that struck me as ridiculous was the statuary, which I thought quite over the top, at Pemberley.  but the biggest mistake was Elizabeth leaving on foot without her aunt and uncle.  For Pete's sake!  Granted she is supposed to be a great walker, but It was 5 miles back to Lambton where they were staying.  Her aunt and uncle must have been besides themselves wondering what happened to her.  Would Elizabeth be so childish as to run off like that?  I think not.Back at Longborn the letter comes from Uncle Gardiner regarding Lydia and Wickham and Elizabeth tears it out of her father's hands.  Shocking!  This is one very rude girl.  Very out of character for Austen's Elizabeth.And finally near the end Lady Catherine de Bourgh comes to the Bennet house at night waking the whole household.  This seems to me the height of impropriety, something completely out of character for this Lady considering her station in life.  She mentions the Bennet's "very small garden", but I doubt she would even be able to see it in the dark of night.  They had no outdoor lighting in the country.  In the early morning Elizabeth goes for a walk and meets Darcy walking toward the house. He is on foot yet, and in the fog three miles from where he was staying with Bingley.  This is a very rich man, who would have, if not a carriage, a horse at least.  Neither Elizabeth, nor Darcy could sleep, but Darcy doesn't know Elizabeth will be out walking. What had Darcy intended to do once he got to the Bennet's house?  Was he going to wake everyone at that early hour?  We are to believe, except for Elizabeth, they are all still asleep.Looking on all these faults with humor, I was able to still enjoy this version for what it is.  However, it is best to take the time to view the entire mini series and enjoy the great acting in it.  Colin Firth becomes the ultimate Mr. Darcy on screen and Jennifer Ehle is true to Austen's very lovely Elizabeth.  I much prefer the mini series Bingley, Mr. & Mrs Bennet and Lydia.  I loved all the actors in the mini series and think they played their roles brilliantly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This seemed like the fast forward version of the Pride and Prejudice story compared to the BBC's earlier version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. The lead actors in this version, though unquestionably attractive, lacked the depth of character known to the novel's ardent fans. I know Mr. Darcy is a snob, but Matthew Macfadyen never cracks a smile. It just felt like the story flew by with the actors running through their lines like they had to get somewhere fast; a directorial flaw I'm sure. On the other hand, Mr. Bennett's poorly articulated lines were impossible to understand without subtitles.I don't regret buying it at the $9.99 price just to have enjoyed the last scene, which, to give credit where it's due, and though a bit sugary, was more romantic than the BBC version. We wait ardently for Mr. Darcy to finally kiss his Elizabeth, and the BBC version left me longing for a more passionate visual effect. This one had a little more magic.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I suppose it could be said it was my misfortune to be introduced to Pride and Prejudice by the 1983 BBC adaption by Fay Weldon directed by Cyril Coke and starring Elizabeth Garvey and David Rintoul. Not the 1940 Leonard version with Oliver and Greer Garson, nor the later BBC adaptation with Colin Firth, and not, alas, this 2005 version measure up in tone or historical accuracy. The beauty and faithfulness of Weldon's script, the spot-on casting and attention to historical detail more than make up for the lesser production values.Keira Kneightly fails completely to project the moral character of Jane, conveying little more than a sort of morose petulance with her vacant, glazed-over expressions, colossus of a jaw and toothy mouth. Spoiled and resentful instead of spirited and principled, her emotionally constipated delivery of lines seems forced and pugnacious rather than courageous. Nothing about her invites us in--she is too stiff and self-conscious, too virginal. Sentimental music by the yard and grand landscapes are no substitute for emotional resonance with the protagonist. The thread-bear script is in part to blame for the failure to convincingly embody the moral- and class-conflicts that drive the novel. Jane is never allowed to manifest as the outspoken, head-strong, shrewd yet empathic young woman that she is. Perhaps her character was dumbed-down out of a fear that a modern-day audience, with its egalitarian prejudices (the taboo against distinguishing oneself intellectually) and despite its enlightened feminism, might be put-off by such a characterization. Elizabeth Garvey, on the other hand, managed to be alluringly feminine (warm) and intriguingly articulate--the ideal balance of head and heart.The film fails to convey the mores or the class- and sex distinctions of the period with any conviction. The minds behind this adaptation seem younger (more beholden to youth-culture) and older (wan and worn-out) at once. Judi Dench does raise the octane level with her caricature of Lady Catherine De Bourg's demonic fury. But Brenda Blithyn as Mrs. Bennett is not irritating or shrewish enough by half, and Donald Sutherland, emasculated and mumbling his way through in one continuous aside, is completely wasted. Only in the 1983 BBC adaptation has the character of the father been allowed to assert his patriarchal prerogative and provide an effective check to the over-bearing and histrionic mother, who was meant to be insufferable. Matthew MacFaydean makes a sleepy, crestfallen and disengaged Darcy, where Rintoul is authentically haughty with hidden depths. A lot was sacrificed in the characterizations of both Darcy and Jane to make them `likable' to modern day hipsters. The result is a confection of a film, hollow and without integrity, content to be a historical spectacle.By the time Darcy and Jane come together in Cyril Coke's 1983 adaptation--without as much as a kiss, just a couple strolling through a park--it's quite overwhelming. I'm hard-pressed to think of another reconciliation in all of film that could compete for impact. And it's all done with spoken dialogue--the sublimely beautiful language of Jane Austen faithfully rendered by Fay Weldon--and silence. There is an element of cosmic tragedy as the camera sweeps up over the trees, even as they emerge at long last from all their pretenses and misunderstandings ("pride and prejudice!") to bear their souls, happily surrendering to one another. It is the archtypal situation of love supervening upon hatred (envy).Kneightly and MacFaydean, by contrast, seem more like teen-agers who suddenly stop playing hard to get and find they have the house to themselves. Had they consummated their passion before our very eyes to sweeping violins we could not have cared any less. So if you want to be transported to another time and mind-set, to a pre-modern world at once more rigid and more genteel, try the Coke adaptation. It is as close as you will get to reading the novel without actually reading it.
summary: Not the Spirit or the Letter

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As many others have said, I'm a devoted van of the 1995 Colin Firth miniseries and my copy of the book is dog-eared from much reading. However, after viewing the movie several more times over the course of the weekend, I've come to like it almost as much as the 1995 miniseries, I think.  The mini-series is good if you are looking for a skillful, faithful, and more complete adaptation of the Darcy-Elizabeth romance.  This version of the story however provides an intriguing artistic take on it - which is good, because a more "literal" take could never have succeeded in the two-hour-movie format, given the 1995 precedent.  The use of music goes beyond normal soundtracking to become almost operatic in its expressiveness of the emotion.  The essentials of the emotions between Darcy and Elizabeth really come to the fore - which is fine because a two hour movie can't take the time to slowly reveal them w/ the subtlety that the book and the miniseries did.  The chemistry between the two leads is gripping, and the changes to the plot - which mostly amount to changes in the setting (Darcy proposes the first time outside in a rainstorm rather than in the parlor) rather than substance. And though the dialogue was a bit jarring at first since it departs markedly from the book, on further viewings I realize that the writers generally did an excellent job of conveying the essential meanings in fewer and more modern words.However, for those well-versed with the story bewarned - on first viewing several things about this movie were jarring: the pace (very fast - and not because they cut things out which was inevitable. . . the dialogue is delivered in rapid-fire-succession at points), Elizabeth's demeanor (aggressive independent instead of playful gentile independent), the dialogue (they didn't just modernize the language, they did subtly adapt the *meaning* of some things said in key exchanges between Elizabeth and Darcy to make the characters more palpable to modern viewers, I think), and the total evisceration of important side plots (Wickham and Elizabeth's relationship, the presence of the militia in Meryton).Still, despite these things, I think they made excellent use of the two-hour movie format.  There wouldn't have been any point in trying to make an extremely faithful but truncated version of the story, because it couldn't have held a candle to the miniseries.  Instead they chose to do something a little different with the story, and I think it works.
summary: Artistic, not literal - good for the format

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw Pride and Prejudice for the third time today, and it just gets better each time. I see a lot of movies, and it is refreshing to see a movie that is sexy without actually showing any sex. Kiera Knightly is gorgeous,and yes, I did see the Colin Firth version, and I adored him in Bridget Jones, but I'll take Matthew McFadyen in a heartbeat over Colin Firth. The first time I saw it I left the theater behind two women my age (boomers) with three teenage girls, the youngest of whom said "Mom, I want a Mr. Darcy", to which the mother replied "We all do!" I know there are many devotees of the BBC version, but I think comparing the two is like comparing apples to oranges. I may go see this again, and I have never in my life said that about any movie. Can't wait for the DVD!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen every one of the versions of P&P; that are available: 1940, 1980 and 1995.  I've seen Bride & Prejudice and Pride & Prejudice, A Latter-Day Comedy.  Each one has something to offer, and this new version is no exception.I really liked how they cast actors who were very close in age to those in the book.  Keira Knightley's youthful exuberance was endearing, and I enjoyed watching her mature before our eyes. Matthew MacFadyen's performance as Darcy was more nuanced than any I have seen before. This version doesn't need made-up fencing, bathtub and wet t-shirt scenes to show us his intensity and his sensuality.  He and Knightley both have very expressive eyes and an understanding that less is more.  They have a chemistry that is almost palpable.It's not everyone's cup of tea (especially for the Firth fangirls), but it is mine, and I love it to death.  I saw it 9 times in the theater, and have seen it twice at home (so far) via the UK edition of the DVD.  I look forward to seeing the extras on the US disc.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Well, I suppose I should be happy they didn't give it a rock soundtrack. This was a major disappointment. I'd been so excited when the director said he was giving the story more "muscle." Um, not really. Apparently, in his view, Lizzie is an inarticulate, sullen, pouty anorexic. The Bennet family are hillbillies. Wow, who knew? I detest big budget phony movies, such as this. Every scene dripped with insincerity.I actually enjoyed most of the actors, even Darcy. I found it pathetic, however, that the witty, insightful words of Austen were deemed inferior to the hack screenwriter's cliches. And wow! Talk about historical inaccuracies. The country gentry of the era were cleaner than this. They may not have bathed every day...but they were neat and presentable. Clothing was handsewn and fitted with great care (sewing machines hadn't been invented yet) and they certainly fit better than the hanging, ragged smocks worn by these actors.Oh, and the biggest laugh? Oh, my goodness! The last scene in the U.S. version was a direct steal from the 80's movie "Sixteen Candles." Unbelievable!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I recently had a P&P weekend.  I finished reading Passion & Principle by Jodie Felice so I wanted more!  I re-watched the Pride & Prejudice movie with Jennifer Erhle and Colin Firth...tough to beat.  Then the next day, I watched the remake of P& P with Keira Knightley and I was disappointed.  I may be biased because I'm not a big fan of Kiera--her acting is too affected for me.  Mr. McFadden is easy on the eyes and did a really great job with this role.  But, I think the movie was disappointing overall.  The production value was great (5 stars)--beautiful, beautiful sets.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
review_text: I'm not one for movies of this nature.  I was not a fan of Ang Lee's 'Sense and Sensibility' yet after watching this wonderful and delightful film I just might watch the latter again, you know, for a second opinion.  Based off of Jane Austins novel of the same name, Pride & Prejudice revolves around Elizabeth Bennet (Knightley) and her sisters as their mother (Brenda Blethyn) tries to marry them off.  The eldest daughter Jane (Rosamund Pike) is quickly taken fancy by a wealthy young man, yet it's his best friend Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen) who catches the eye of young Liz, but not in a good way.  While she can't deny her attraction for him, his arogance blinds her love and drives her away from him, but as events take place that uncover her eyes to the real man he is she puts her pride and pejudice aside to be with the man she loves.  The acting here is top notch, with Keira taking the top position here.  She was brilliant, lovable, likable, adorable and believable.  Donald Sutherland, who play's Liz's father, did amazing with his role and I can see why so many wanted him to recieve an oscar nomination.  I was also very impressed with the amount of power Dame Judi Dench brought to a role that recieved such little screen time.  The scene where she confronts Liz is one of the best in the film.  She truly is a star.  This film, from start to finish, was oscar worthy and theres no doubt in my mind that we'll see Keira at the awards again soon, hopfully this time she will be taking home her own little (yet heavy) man.
summary: "And how are you feeling today, Mrs. Darcy?"

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The Regency era was a time of elegance, formality and societal restrictions...the cast in this movie had the dress and manners of the age of "Tom Jones", romping out the dance floor like an 18th century bacchanal.  Elizabeth Bennett , like Jane Austen, would have never have worn a drab, olive green dress that looked like a handmade flour sack to a ball, (as was worn by Lizzy Bennett at the first local ball scene) and none of the Bennett's wore hats in this movie, afraid they would lack sex appeal, one supposes as the whole feel of this movie is a steamy bodice ripper romance.  A lady would never had gone out in public without a hat and gloves then, ever.  Everyone's hair was totally out of character of an early nineteenth century person, with loose frowsy manes from our day ( on a beach) whereas ladies then usually had short curly cuts close to the head, or formal updos with pearls etc. while  the men sported short cuts like the Brutus, as the nation was at war and a military bearing was the fashion.  The grace of Darcy was perfected by Lawrence Olivier, and no one has come close to his brilliant interpretation...why this obsession to create a hulking sex object , smoldering and glowering like a spoiled teenager?  And Donald Sutherland's teeth were so big, white and gleaming that he might as well have been wearing Adidas sneakers to proclaim he was a 21st century male!  No one had  caps and neon white teeth in the 19th century...especially if they were in their 60's. The problem with this whole production was its emphasis on the**** STARS***and pandering to their vanity and not to the story or of faithfulness to the period.  I thought the whole film a waste of time!  A meretricious, glossy, false and completely clueless Hollywood adaptation that need never have been made.  They should have stopped with "Clueless".

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Have you ever seen the "15 minute Hamlet"?  At the end, they find that they have some time left, so they do it again, but even faster.  That is this version of Pride and Prejudice.I do not understand how so many people have rated this film 5 stars.  I tried to like it, I really did, but the entire story is rushed.  The actors seemed so involved in trying to enunciate the lines at speed (to varying degrees of success) that most other aspects of performance seem to have been left out.The only reasons this movie got even two stars:Camera work was very nice, as was the lighting and background musicScenery and costuming, excellent, espeically the marriage proposal scenes - almost (but not quite) worth watching the movie just for those scant minutesThe dances were fantastic - blocking, cinematograpgy, sound, even the directing was a little better thereStill annoyed about:Liz is supposed to be pretty, but not as pretty as her elder sister:  Keira Knightley has a nice face, but is the twig thin that is popular in Hollywood and is modern high fashion - in period she would have been completely unremarkable beyond skinny.  Even so, she is a good sight better looking than Jane.Dame Judy Dench as Lady Cathrine DeBurgh was the equivalent of lighting your charcoal grill with a gallon of lighter fluid and three sticks of dynamite.  Her screen presence and intensity put the already pale performances in an even worse light.The hurried nature of this Cliff Notes version of the book ends up with mixed pacing.  The actors were all waiting hungrily to pounce on and devour their lines, leaving the audience both winded and bored.In the end, the best I can say about this show is that it is much closer to the book than the black and white version, where they tried to combine Lizzie with Jo from Little Women, not to mention turning Lady Cathrine DeBurgh into a matchmaker.  Oy.Just go watch the BBC-Colin Firth version.  This may be shorter, but it's not worth the chunk of your life which could be spent watching the first disc of a better version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must admit, when I first saw it, I was critcizing everything. I didn't like the actor they chose for Mr. Darcy, I didn't like Keira as Elizabeth. There were also some aspects of the play that irked me- technical things; things the character wouldn't do. Of course, I realize that it has been a few years since I thorougly read Pride and Prejudice but as the movie continued on I began to enjoy it.I found the actor who played Mr. Darcy very attractive. I loved the costumes, the music, I thought the acting was good and lo and behold, I loved the movie. I cannot stop watching it. I enjoy trying to catch the little mannerisms of the characters and the looks between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. The more I watch it the more I realized that I was wrong about Keira- she was really good in this.I can understand why many people may not like it. There are some movie adaptations based on some of my favorite books that I hated. Am I a purist? No! but sometimes you just want the movie to catch the magic of the book and I'm starting to realize that it can't happen. That's why you can always go back and read the book. It's more fulfilling when you can envision the characters yourself.This movie is not for everyone, Austen fans or not. I never seen the Colin Firth version but now I want to. I forgot how much I loved Jane Austen and I thank this movie for reminding me. I'm rereading the story now. All I have to say is, just rent it first or watch it on HBO since they're showing it now. It doesn't hurt to try it and then make the decision. I enjoyed it, i thought it was good. I have not seen all of the versions so I can't answer which one is better.Of course there were some differences between this and the book. But I think it's good enough to recommend to others. I had my misgivings at first but I took the chance and watched it and now I love it. Take a chance, it's not bad.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley's fine performance cannot save this poor representation of the great book by Jane Austin. The visual presentation of the Bennet home was shocking. Rather than a gentleman of moderate means we see a household where the family walks through the chickens' habitat to enter the back door, the hog is led by the open kitchen door - it's a mess. Mrs. Bennet is represented as a sometimes drunken slob instead of the proper wife, light in intelligence, seeking to fulfill her primary duty - getting 5 daughters, with little dowry, married. There is no attempt to portray the close relationship of sisters, Elizabeth and Jane.  In fact, the relationship is cast as that between sisters Eleanor and Mary Ann in "Sense and Sensibility". It was a terrible disappointment in nearly every respect. Buy the version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle - it's a treasure whose length gives hours of pleasure.
summary: A Great Performance - a Poor Film

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First things first, I have never seen the Colin Firth version of "Pride and Prejudice," which has gotten such rave reviews, and I have never read the book by Jane Austen.  With that said, I think I came into the movie unbiased and had nothing to compare it to.  I loved this movie and felt that it had several key aspects to make it a great movie.  First, Keira Knightley does an amazing job as Elizabeth and she has a face that is so captivating that you cannot keep your eyes off of her.  In every movie she is in, she steals the scene.  Matthew Macfayden does an excellent job as Mr. Darcy as he transforms himself in the movie from one type of character to another.  When you're supposed to dislike him, you do.  When you're supposed to like him, you do.  Simon Woods as Mr. Bingley also does an excellent job and is very likable throughout the movie.  "Pride and Prejudice" has great pacing, beautiful cinematography, and conflict which kept you involved in everyone's lives.  Plus, it has Donald Sutherland as the father who plays each line to perfection.  One suggestion I would make to somebody watching is to what I did.  Put the Subtitles on the DVD so you won't miss a word that is said.  It is most helpful!  So I would probably give this movie about 4 1/4 stars as it had all the elements of a great movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is the best adaptation of Pride & Prejudice -- and I have all of them.  The Greer Garson version is more of a comedy and the Colin Firth version is too broody.  I just love this one and can watch it over and over. The production is stunning and more authentic I think.  And Mr. Darcy is superb in this version.  The sunrise near the end is the perfect.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen's classic novel tells the story of the five Bennett girls and their misadventures on the way to marriage, centering, of course, on the second daughter, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley), and her great romance with Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen).  Joe Wright's fine direction and Deborah Moggach's capable adaptation are certainly indispensible elements of this excellent film, but Knightley's performance is really at the heart of it.  She brings an irresistable natural exuberance to her portrayal of a girl changing into a young woman who longs for romance.This film deserves a better rating than 3 1/2 stars, but it seems that many people compare it unfavorably to the miniseries that aired on A&E.;  I haven't seen that version yet, but I urge anyone to give this film a chance and judge it by its own merits.  The cast is uniformly excellent.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is a dumbed-down version of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice.  None of the characters are faithfully portrayed.  I would be ok with changes and creative edits if it were not for the fact that the characters have been morphed into either blubbering idiots (Mr. Bingley) or melodramatic ninnies who cry in almost every scene and physically run away from all conflict (Elizabeth Bennett).  This movie has exchanged wit for stupidity, charm with repulsive cheesiness, and even rid the thing of every piece of sarcastic humor that existed. Mr. Bennett cries in this movie for Christ sake!  It really is the antithesis of what Pride and Prejudice was all about.  I'm extremely saddened that yet another classic story has been destroyed by Hollywood.
summary: I would give it a negative million if I could!

title: Pride & Prejudice

Judy Dench does her usual 10 minutes on screen but somehow makes a major impact.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Granted the movie is very different from the book...but that's to be expected because books are always 100x more detailed than what can be allowed for a movie. HOWEVER they do a very good job at trying to keep as much as they could and keep the story strong. I know some people are Jane Austin purists and don't like this movie because it's not exactly like the book. My advice to them is to STOP WATCHING MOVIES! They're probably more resentful that a movie version was made to begin with because naturally not everything makes it into the movie. I have read the book and I still love this movie.I wasn't sure about seeing it, but I am a fan of Keira Knightley and figured I'd give it a watch as friends recommended it. Well I fell in love with the movie and bought it off of Amazon and I've watched it at least 20 times (that's probably a conservative figure). The story is beautiful, the cast is full of great actors, the scenes are well executed. I'm a HUGE fan of Keira now, she did great.Great movie...highly recommend for anyone with at least a little romantic spirit in them. :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There is no point in trying to list all of the flaws in this adaptation of Austen's classic; I would be here all day! What possessed the makers of this film to cast Keira Knightly as Elizabeth Bennet, or Donald Sutherland as her father? Knightly's Lizzy is a giggling and immature airhead, with no depth of character whatsoever. The language and behaviour of the time is ignored, the dialogue is very clumsy, and the costumes and general appearance of the characters are shabby. Macfadyen's Darcy looked as bored as I was. Did the scriptwriters read the book before setting about writing the script? Was any historical research done? I doubt both. There isn't a scene in the entire film that I can say a good thing about. So badly done. So disappointing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Well done classic. This version has a wonderful pace and gives justice to the book. Characters are believable and well acted. Attention to historic details of the settings, costumes and atmosphere is excellent.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is, IMHO, close to being a geat, classic movie. The two 'leads', Keira Knightly & Matthew Macfadyen, were really, really good. But the secondary characters made this movie.Donald Southerlin (Mr. Bennett) was superb, as always! But Tom Hollander (As Mr. Collins), Simon Woods (Bingely) and  Rosamund Pike (Jane Benntt) were very, very good.And Judi Dench (as Lady Catherine de Bourg - perhaps better known as 'M' from James Bond fame) is quite simply one of the greatest actresses of our time.I also enjoyed the costumes and the overall look of the movie.The story did stray from the book some, especially in the Bennetts fiancial situtation. But most of the changes otherwise were needed to movie the story along. Having read the book many, many moons ago I recogizied most of the changes but after re-reading the book I noticed more changes. None of them really bothered me however.I would rate this a very high 9.25 to 9.5 out of 10 - HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for fans of the book, historical romance fans and people who just like good movies!!
summary: Nearly a classic - very, very good!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This modern-day version has an aesthetically pleasing cast and set although it does not stay true to the book. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As an admirer of Jane Austen novels, I ordered this video because it was the only version of Pride and Prejudice that I could find with a Spanish soundtrack--and it did serve that purpose. The rendition of Jane Austen's novel, however, was very disappointing. I have viewed many video versions of Pride and Prejudice and have found one to excel far above the rest in accurately depicting the book. That is the BBC production starring Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul, which adheres very closely to Austen's original text. In the BBC version, the settings are authentic and realistic for the era, and the casting is excellent. For anyone who has read and enjoyed the novel Pride and Prejudice, I highly recommend the BBC video. Elizabeth Garvie becomes Elizabeth Bennett.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The mini series was so much better. This try at Pride and Prejudice was a mistake from start to finish. The characters in this version of Jane Austen's book, except for Elizabeth and Darcy and Mrs. Bennet, are card board cutouts. If a person is not familiar with the mini series or the book every other character in this movie would make very little sense. The special connection between Elizabeth and her father is missing. Donald Sutherland is a fine actor. He made a dreadful Mr. Bennet. Kiera Knightly had too many nothing closeups that didn't really develop the character of Elizabeth. Matthew MacFadyen seemed too soft to be Darcy.The dance scenes at the hall in Meryton are much too long and took away time that the movie needed for character development. Too many extras took away the feeling that this was a country dance for the gentry, and not some crowded London ball. It made me feel that because so much money was spent on these scenes the producers wanted to get their money's worth in screen time.Elizabeth's clothing was dark and dreadful. She looked like she was wearing what a servant would wear for most of her scenes. The Bennent home was shown as shabby. The Bennents had a good income they just spent it all as it came in so didn't save for the future of the Bennent daughters or Mrs Bennent. Because the estate was entailed on a male relative they would be turned out when Mr. Bennett died. That was Mrs. Bennet's biggest worry. Even then each daughter would get a small income. So why show them living like they were in such poverty?Jane Austen was making a point about society, and how circumstances could change a woman's place in it. This version of Pride and Prejudice misses the mark here too. Jane Austen expanded on this theme with Sense and Sensibility. The 1995 movie version of Sense and Sensibility is also worth seeing.This Pride and Prejudice was slow and tiresome, and I wondered how much longer? I had read good reviews and thought there must be something better ahead. The silly ending was all there was.Buy the A&E; mini series instead, and don't forget to also buy the wonderful 1995 version of Sense and Sensibility with Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet. Both the 1996 TV and movie versions of Emma are also worth buying.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: death metal and black metal "death metal and ...
review_text: So you end up at a friend's place, and they pop this in, and five minutes later you're wishing your wife would call with a sick dog or extended family crisis so you could escape. You don't believe me? Let me explain:This movie takes a classic of literature, and dumbs it down so that all traces of subtlety are lost, and even further, all depth of character is lost. These people are cardboard silhouettes walking around and reacting in really obvious ways to really obvious problems; they have no souls, or character, of their own. They're actors creating generic characters that are dressed up like Jane Austen ones.For example, the dialogue. Gone are the complex elegant sentences; they might as well have translated it into Valley Girl, Surfer or Jive for as much as these speaking parts resemble the original. With that loss of elegance goes much of what defines each character, and it is replaced by a movie that makes the worst sin of a literary re-creation, if you ask me: a talky movie in which very little is actually said because all spoken ideas have been boiled for eight hours before serving.Even worse, the action. We the audience are expected to be dumb as rocks and distracted, so every action has to be jerkily symbolic in the same way traffic signs, middle fingers, and giant explosions are symbolic -- a one-dimensional, brain-dead, spoon-fed kind of way. Characters no longer maintain a tense balance of mutual respect and competition; they fight like bickering drunks. Scenes do not crackle with many different kinds of emotion, but pound us senseless with a single one.In short, this film is awful -- and doubly so given the better alternatives just a click away. Hollywood took a literary classic, threw it in a blender, and took parts out and pasted them into a typical Hollywood plot with typical Hollywood neurotic brain-stem characters. Now they want us to buy it presumably to turn us off from literature forever, so we can watch the latest starlet vehicle and think, "Well, at least it was better than that tiresome Pride and Prejudice." Avoid avoid!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Before it was released, Joe Wright's adaptation of Jane Austen's novel seemed destined for failure.  After all, a "definitive" BBC version starring Colin Firth already existed, with a stellar cast and a faithfulness to Austen that purists adored.  This newest entry, however, is every bit as compelling as its BBC relative.  Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet is brilliant; her Elizabeth is keenly intelligent, witty, spunky, and, above all, utterly charming.  While the BBC version may be known as the "Colin Firth version" for that actor's memorable performance as Darcy, this one will be known as the "Keira Knightley version," as the emphasis here is firmly on Elizabeth, exactly what Austen would have intended.  Of course, Knightley is surrounded by excellent actors such as Mathew Macfayden (Darcy), Judi Dench (Lady Catherine), and Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennet), but her outstanding performance is responsible for this film's success.For those unfamiliar with the plot:  the Bennet family lives in a precarious situation.  With no male heirs and a household of five unmarried daughters, their future is uncertain, as the house will be inherited by the family toad, Mr. Collins, upon Mr. Bennet's death.  As in most Austen novels, the mother sets about frantically trying to match up her girls with men of social standing and wealth to ensure that they will all be cared for.  When repressed aristocrat Darcy and his foppish but eligible friend Bingley arrive in the country, Mrs. Bennet starts scheming.  In keeping with the theme, the truth of matters are often obscured by the "pride and prejudice" of the characters, lending complexity to the plot.Probably the most amazing accomplishment in this film is the transformation of Elizabeth and Darcy's relationship.  Macfayden is cold, judgmental, repressed, and glowering--and yet by the end of the film, without significant change in his countenance, his Darcy seems perfect for Knightley's radiant Elizabeth.  Likewise, Elizabeth's gradual appreciation of Darcy is completely believable, although unfortunately the film suggests that his wealth first turns her head.  Much of what transpires between these characters is expertly shown through the actors' eyes and small gestures, which then makes it equally believable that no one else suspects their growing affection for each other.This adaptation, while not entirely faithful to the novel, captures the spirit of Austen's masterpiece.  The cinematography is as accomplished as the performances, giving the film a vibrancy that puts aside any question of pretension.  The only sour note comes in the last moments of the film when Wright and screenwriter Moggach opt for sappiness over the unsentimental beauty of the rest.  This misstep can be forgiven, given the utter brilliance of everything that comes before it.  Highly recommended, even for those who would not ordinarily sit through a literary adaptation.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version has its merits.  The scenery is terrific, and the one scene in the morning mist with the sun rising is incomparably beautiful.  Mary and Anne de Bourgh are treated more sympathetically than in the BBC miniseries' version, and Jane and Wickham are very good-looking (as they're written in the novel).  Judi Dench as Lady Catherine is good.The two-hour time frame makes it difficult to develop the story very much, so basically everything that isn't Lizzy-Darcy is truncated (Lizzy-Jane, Lizzy-Mr. Bennet relationship, even Lydia and Wickham is shortened).  Some of the period stuff (another reviewer mentioned the bedroom visits, and the costuming) is a little off.  But these aren't major problems, at least for me.My main issue with it is that it feels like a twenty-first century version of the story.  It is more angsty, and it takes a very modern young person view of Lizzy and Darcy--that is, it has them behave emotionally more like us moderns would at their ages rather than the Lizzy and Darcy of the novel and of two centuries ago.  It's got a twinge of the WB teenage drama in it.The cleverness and the wit of Austen's work are minimal here, and it feels more somber.  Mr. Bennet's "sarcastic humor" is gone; his lines are delivered seriously.  Mr. Collins' servility and Mrs. Bennet's nerves and silliness are much toned down from their BBC versions, making the characters more personable, but it feels just a little less.  (Less amusing, for sure.)I had trouble caring for this movie's Lizzy and Darcy.  Austen's Elizabeth had an easy playfulness and a quickness about her.  This Elizabeth has lost most of her witty humor (albeit fitting of the more serious tone of the movie) and thus comes across a little shrill, without the lively charm to cover for her more "insolent" moments.She is emotional and flighty, swinging from smiling and giggly to crying hard, to yelling (raising her voice) at Darcy during the first proposal--which seems a little weird for the restrained manners of that time period.  This Elizabeth feels more like a modern, fiery teenager than the proper, confident but lively novel heroine.Darcy, here, instead of being proud, just comes across as sad.  He has sad puppy dog eyes the entire movie.  To me, it makes Lizzy's rejection seem a lot harsher.  Even the end scene (for American audiences?) didn't make me like them any more--it just felt hokey instead.The novel has Lizzy and Darcy as equals in intellect and in faults--Lizzy to drop her prejudice and Darcy to learn to change his pride.  In this movie version, Lizzy just comes around to where Darcy is; he doesn't change.As a movie taken by itself, not bad, and a fast way to acquaint onself with the basic storyline.  To see a much truer version of the novel, though, watch the 1995/1996 BBC/A&E; miniseries with Ehle and Firth.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I haven't read Jane Austen's book or seen the BBC series.  Sorry...kill me!!I enjoy movies and don't feel the need all the time to read the novel beforehand.I did read "No country for Old men" before seen the movie. Definitely there's a big gap between some movies and their book.I also understand that movies have only 2 hours to comprise a book.  Many fans of the book may not share the inevitable editing choices, due to time and business constraints.  That is another constant inevitable.  But also, those editing choices made it possible for an excellent book to reach a mainstream audience, that otherwise may never have had the possibility to be exposed to some part of it and/or relate to it so closely.Since this a forum to review THE MOVIE, I'll do that.  I hope some readersappreciate my review it's not biased by the novel, which I don't doubt is great.First the cinematography and photography are outstanding.  The music is beautiful, it enhances greatly every piece.  The costumes are gorgeous, may or may not be appropriate for the period on some regard.The language is striking, rolls over the tongues of the characters easily and pleasantly.Sophisticated language used to provide a richer communication than we have with our contemporary butchery of it.Reminder of a time where people read and language was enjoyed and honed to increase it's effectiveness, on societies where statements were carefully worded, because what said meant what it meant, and people were not able to hide behind sarcasm and ignorance, when honor was beheld high.  And the consequences of disrespect and/or misunderstandings were significant.A time without TV:) -if you want to save your soul smash yours with a bat-Mr. Darcy is a proud, perfectionist man.  A pose he adopts to protect himself from his insecurities.  By this device, avoiding the risk of trying to attract and be rejected.  He places unrealistic qualities on his ideal woman to avoid having again to be attracted to the real one and be rejected.The essence of shyness, which everyone can relate to.  The flawed leading man, cornerstone of every good script."I don't have the talent of conversing easily with people I have not met before", Darcy confesses to Elizabeth, revealing his flaw, disarming himself and standing naked shy before the woman he loves, as his greatest gift.  Teased by Elizabeth, he finds himself as rules of seduction will point,even more captivated by her.And rising love as a catalyst of virtuosity in men, the only force so powerful as to bring a man out of this shell of pride, and risk utter embarrassment: his deepest fear.The fear of, as The great Lebanese poet/philosopher Kahlil Gibram says on  "The Prophet" in his essay about Love:"...To know the pain of too much tenderness.To be wounded by your own understanding of love;And to bleed willingly and joyfully..."Darcy Places too much importance and pride on his intellect.  Hence, protecting himself of the "foolishness" of emotions, and all spontaneous crazyness that comes with strong states of emotion as love, with all the revelations of your true self it entails.  All that could lead to unexpected acts,  and to uncharted territory.  That is dreaded, thus avoided by the one inclined to control out of fear of failure or rejection.The first time he touches Elizabeth's hand to help her into the carriage and feels that unequivocal heat of great chemistry, punishes himself for his warmth and the possibility of having disclosed his emotions.  You can witness that on the shot of the tensing of his hand afterward.  Those subtleties punctuate the movie, and the detail makes the story more intriguing.Elizabeth is as many other heroines, is ahead of her time.  With a strong character and habits considered exclusively masculine is more of a modern woman.  Witty and with an acid sardonic sense of humor punishes all that she spots easily as phony.Her wit and sarcasm her are her own shell, though, as hard as Darcy's.  And also the flaw that bonds them and along with their skill with words.  Language as a an armor becomes also a game for the two, to prove who's able to penetrate the other defenses, mascaraded attraction, finallyWounding them both, with the delicious bittersweet tenderness of sexual repression liberated.And yes, ever so trite: love.She's more open to love, and so able to taunt Darcy into following her into their final "jump" into the unknown depths and heights of love and their ultimate purification.  Below the pouring rain, yes, a trite a cliche as it can be cliche, but still powerful as powerful poetry can be."A woman difficult to alarm" as Mr Darcy qualifies her, Elizabeth is, as all heroines, a malcontent, a free soul not bounded by social conventions.  Moreover, a rebel and a outspoken critic of conventions.Again, traits contemporarily all can relate strongly, and make her so attractive as a modern character.It was a time and place where women are limited by social structuring to depend in a great deal on men's favors of their beauty primarily.  Relegating education to a lesser state,On the scale of traits needed for survival and social acceptance.For men also emblematic of power, pride, honor, masculinity, etc.Marriage then was a huge deal in  their lives.  These period conditions conjure more intense romantic games.  With more at stake, with more tension, pride and prejudice keep lovers apart, through the heart wrenching twists and turns, ebbs and flows that we love to watch until the expected happens.Demoting the less physically endowed to settle to a very restricted lifestyle.The men pursuing the attractive females and the woman the powerful men is another trait  that remains until our days.  Modified  in form but not essence.  A condition we can also relate and understand it's inception better, watching this period.Donald Sutherland's character is the icing on the cake.  He's just marvelous. As a father whose daughter's can confide for support, without the fear of a backlash of chauvinism.Smart enough to grasp the female soul is refreshing, specially on this context.I suggest this movie to all romantics at heart, who dare to be mocked and fooled.For the bravest of men, who dare or even indulge and see "chick flicks" proudly, beyond the purpose of scoring some points.And for anybody who likes beautiful photography, scenery and a well written piece.
summary: A blueprint for all romance movies

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I unfortunately saw this shortened version of "Prejudice" before seeing the acclaimed BBC TV one with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle--and yes if you want to quibble--the BBC one is the winner. But I'm still keeping this one because of Joe Wright's direction and the apt casting of Keira Knightley in one of her best roles to date.  The HD DVD copy is brilliant and all the colors of the English countryside make you feel that you're there.  Though Matthew McFadden may lack the irony of Colin Firth's gem like performance as Darcy, he is acceptable.  Regardless if you still have an HD DVD unit, this one is available at a very low price since no one is manufacturing them anymore.  Also it may be quite some time when this does arrive in the Blu-ray format--and at a much higher price than $6!!  Still recommended for Austin enthusiasts and romanticists, male and female alike.
summary: A marvelous though edited version of Jane Austin classic in HD

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Ok...so I've seen the movie ten times, downloaded the screensaver from the official site, bought the soundtrack from Amazon, and I'm reading interviews and the production notes (long, but fascinating), and also reading the book for the second time.Although Colin Firth was sensational in the miniseries, I think it's unfair to compare Matthew MacFadyen with other actors who have played the part. In one of MacFadyen's interviews, he said that you can't allow yourself to be intimidated. Just because great actors have played Hamlet, doesn't mean no one else can play the same character. Each actor brings his own art and interpretation to the character. Why do we have to choose? Can't we enjoy them all? That's what Roger Moore said during an interview when he was asked who was his favorite Bond. He said they are all good. Why do we have to choose?I also read somewhere that Colin Firth was making another movie during the BBC miniseries and had no idea that he was becoming such a sex symbol. He said he tried hard NOT to be sexy in this part.I think this movie version is visually stunning, the music is wonderful, and the dancing is exciting. I thought Simon Woods (Mr. Bingley) was adorable. I read that he and Rosa Pike (Jane Bennet) had gone together for some time and broke up a couple of years ago. Joe Wright, the director, wanted them both for these parts but was afraid it would be painful for them and uncomfortable on the set. But he chose them anyway. They didn't find out until the night before the first day of the shoot. Joe Wright and Rosa are now going together.I thought all the acting was very good, and although I had never heard of Matthew MacFadyen, I fell in love with him during the course of the movie, just as Lizzy did. I really think the most inspired acting job was the character of Mr. Collins. Tom Hollander played him as ridiculous and a bit creepy. I was happy to find his bio on the imdb and see that he is actually handsome, and sexy, with blond wavy hair. If he looked like himself in the movie, she may not have turned him down.This was Tamzin Merchant's (Georgiana) first acting part. She is a huge Jane Austen fan and wrote to the casting director that she would be perfect for that part. She even learned to play the piano.I, too, wish the movie was longer...perhaps another hour, and would like to have seen Mr. Wickham's character more developed.In the production notes, they thought of Darcy as a tragic/tortured character. His parents die while he is still young and he inherits this huge estate to manage and must raise a young sister. He had to take on a lot of responsibility at an early age.Keira Knightley says that the girls socialized easily with the cast, until they got dressed up. She said the men were so sexy in their outfits that the females couldn't even put sentences together.Austen's writing is an interesting style. It's not grammatically correct and there are spelling errors. But it's difficult to put the book down. Most of the text is dialogue. It reads like script. And the book is posted online in several places. If you missed some dialogue because the British accent, just check out the book online.Also in the production notes, they mention that Austen wrote P&P; during the French Revolution, where the underclass revolted against the upper class, and American just won  independence from England. At that time, the upper class was encouraged to socialize with the middle class to avoid unrest. Bingley had no problem, but Darcy and Caroline Bingley found it difficult.All in all, I think they did a beautiful job with the movie. I love the story and the characters. I'm anxious to see all versions. I own the Greer Garson/Lawrence Olivier version, the 6-hour miniseries, both Bridget Jones movies, and I can't wait until this DVD becomes available (February 2, I think). I also own an Austen boxed set of British productions (haven't seen them yet). I just saw the P&P; movie with Orlando Seale and Kam Heskin. It's so silly that it's actually funny. Haven't seen Bride and Prejudice yet, but it's on cable this month.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have not read the book - so I am reviewing based solely on my enjoyment of the film for its own sake.  It is a lovely, whimsical, romantic tale that can be enjoyed many times over.  I appreciated the refreshing lack of profanity, crudity, and senseless violence that floods today's movies.Beautiful scenery, well acted - thoroughly enjoyable.  I highly recommend this!Update 6/18/12 - I have to be honest and say that I have seriously considered lowering this to a 4 star rating having since both read the book (Pride and Prejudice- a free kindle download) and having watchedPride and Prejudice (Restored Edition)MANY times.  The Colin Firth version truly does justice to the story, which I now realize this version did not.Additionally in this version they have really taken some liberties in modernizing both the interactions (e.g. Elizabeth's wit takes on such a sarcastic, biting tone that it REALLY stretches my suspension of disbelief that a lady could have behaved in such a manner) as well as in the actions (e.g. Darcy walking into Elizabeth's private quarters at night, unannounced and with Elizabeth unattended).All that said, I've left it at 5 stars simply because as a standalone film, it's a wonderful story and a visual feast.  One can love it in it's own right :)
summary: A breathtaking tale to watch again and again

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: (Actually 4.5 stars but I rounded up)I absolutely loved the movie! I thought it was accurate to Austen's book especially given that the movie was just about 2 hours. You cannot obviously put in everything in the book in the movie unless it's a mini-series like the Firth piece. The movie didn't stray too far from the book like a lot of books-turned-into-movies do.Even though it was a bit dirty scenic wise, it was just the take of this particular director. I didn't let it impare my enjoyment of the film.My only slight flaw with it was initially the beginning moved quickly and for some friends and family who hadn't read the book, it took them a little while to catch on to everything. There were also a few artsy type scenes that confused me (Lizzie staring into the mirror forever, her standing on a the edge of a cliff) but again nothing to impare my enjoyment.I fully plan on buying this one!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen and Pride and Prejudice.  It is probably my absolute favorite book.  I've watched the BBC production of Pride and Predjudice and it was outstanding.  It is hard to imagine a better Mr. Darcy than Colin Firth.  I wanted to share this great story with my 11 year old daughter, and she has tried to watch the BBC production... but at 5+ hours, its very difficult for her to sit through, let alone understand. This latest adaptation is perfect for the newest generation of hopeful Jane Austen fans.  It has characters they recognize and can understand and it is considerable shorter than its BBC counterpart.  The setting and musical score are gorgeous, and although the story is not "pure" Jane Austen, it comes pretty darn close.
