title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love movies and though I don't see a lot of first run films, I thought 2006 offered an unusual variety of interesting movies and made a special effort to see them in theaters.  Of all the films I saw last year, this is one of the few I felt I would want to see again and so I purchased it on DVD and have watched it a few times since my purchase.  In fact, now that it is being shown on HBO during the holiday season when I have more free time than usual, I have watched it several MORE times--which is very unusual for me.  But this has very quickly become one of my FAVORITE movies.I am a big Jane Austen fan and loved the Firth/Ehle 1995 production and also the earlier 1980 BBC production with David Rintoul which I used to introduce my daughter to Jane Austen several years ago.  I don't think it's all that relevant to this film to compare it to the TV productions since a TV miniseries can be so much more faithful to the novel itself given much longer playing time and less need for distinctive scenery and sets.In order to translate such a social novel successfully to the film screen, and in order to attract a more varied audience than those who faithfully appreciate Masterpiece Theater, dramatic visuals were needed and the sets and scenery took on much greater importance.  Also a much simpler story was imperative to fit in a two hour framework.  The choices made were admirable.  The scenery is so beautiful and so evocative of rural England, the acting is inspired, the dialogue is perfect and the drama moves quickly and holds the interest even of those highly unlikely to pick up and read a Jane Austen novel--even my husband, a comedy and adventure film fan, loves this movie.I think the relevant group to which this film should be compared are the other big award winners of 2006, and this is a FAR SUPERIOR film to many of the films which won big awards.  I was able to watch 'Walk the Line' a second time, and I HAD to watch 'Syriana' a second time to understand it all--they were both good films and I have to admit I even enjoyed Crash when I first saw it--but I would never bother to watch 'Crash' again, and I think this film gets better each time I see it.  Each time I watch it I see something new in the sets, in the performances, in the story, and in the direction.  I really cannot recommend the film more highly--it is tremendously enjoyable and can be watched by a wide variety of adults as well as older children.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I completely adored this movie adaptation of Jane Austen's classic novel.  I must admit, I was weary when first seeing the previews because I am such a huge fan of both the book and the Colin Firth movie version.  But this movie was a complete joy from start to finish.  It was both funny and it moved a little quicker than the Colin Firth version (that one's about 4 hours longer!), though I thought it covered all the important plot points.  Two thumbs way up from me!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wow. I love (LOVE) the BBC miniseries, and I adore Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy. I also detest Kiera Knightly. Consequently, I went to the theatre expecting to be disappointed. I stand (sit, actually) corrected in the most vehement manner. I never would have believed it possible, but this is better than the BBC version. Matthew Macfadyen is better (!!!) than Mr. Firth was, and I will be very disappointed if Ms. Knightly does not win the Best Actress Oscar. To think I would ever say that, especially after her insipid performance in "Pirates of the Caribbean!" But, quite frankly, she deserves all the praise she has garnered for her performance as Elizabeth.Donald Sutherland plays Mr. Bennet with a sympathy that was completely lacking in the BBC version, and he quickly became my favorite character. (I must stop comparing the two films. They really are apples and oranges, so to speak.) Rosamund Pike. Wow. I cannot imagine anyone else playing Jane. She will forever embody the roll for me. I know that every time I read the book from now on, I will see her in my mind's eye every time Jane speaks. But quite honestly, the real standout, the actor who completely made the film (for me, at least) was Mr. Macfadyen. I was disappointed the first time I saw him. The second time, I decided he was "not that bad." By the end of the film (actually, by the time he proposes so horribly), I was completely in love with him (as Darcy, not as an actor), and wondered why on earth Lizzie would have refused his first proposal. Seriously.The cinematography is also breathtaking, and the soundtrack is next on my CD purchasing list. After that, of course, I will be buying the DVD on February 28. I am so glad I don't have to wait for months!
summary: I wish I could give it six stars.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: having just a passing knowledge of the P&P book I could never figure out why this film was called P&P...never saw ANY incident of either, rather justifiable emotions...was annoyed with the Lizzy wardrobe, geez, Jane had decent gowns, why the brazen slipnot stitch overkill???  The dialogue was too sharp for a female even in this era and too witty for believability...what were the duties of all these people in even overseeing the workers, farming, cleaning, even Mr. Bennett just played with orchids and dragonflies, although loved Sutherland in the role...just rich people worried about balls n who has how much quid per year...and one last gripe, the bust of Darcy was exquisite but the back side looked hideous, did they run out of money for the most important piece in the gallery??? pithy items aside, I really fell in love with this film even tho the music score was limited and threaded simply throughout, the majestic mountain and the meeting at sunrise scenes remain in my heart n soul...they seemed very real and deep and poured through my body, wonderful feeling that compares to very few moments in film, my life, or imagination. Kiera is abs stunning except when she starts yelling after the Darcy proposal, her jaw looks too harsh and oh yes, the makeup at sunrise was waaay overdone...personally, that hottie that married  the youngest did not ever get enuff screen time IMHO ...
summary: The Overture Theme truly elevates this film beyond faults...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Friends of mine -- all of whom know my great love for the novel -- insisted I see this film, in spite of my firmly stated desire not to do so.  I finally caved this weekend.  Big mistake.  This movie bears only a vague similarity of character names and basic plotline to Austen's novel.Visually, the film was more than a disappointment, it was a calamity.  The characters looked greasy, unkempt, and dirt poor.  I thought "Am I watching Cold Comfort Farm? Are there pigs in the drawing room?  What IS this? And would someone please, PLEASE comb their hair!"  Costumes, sets, everything was far more suitable to a steampunk version of a Bronte mashup than a Regency period piece.In terms of character, one of the things everyone said to me was "OMG, it captures the passion underlying the novel!  You must see it!  Flail, flail, flail!"  Well, actually, no, it didn't -- if throbbing passion actually underlies Pride and Prejudice (which I've never noticed it to do).  I thought Darcy and Elizabeth had little to no chemistry.  She seemed peevish the entire film, and he simply looked confused and indecisive.  No less baffled was Donald Southerland -- whom I hugely admire and respect -- in his turn as Mr. Bennet: a sad, defeated, broken man...definitely not something I'd ever read in the novel.  Georgiana, to my shock, was actually pert. PERT. I was speechless.Judi Dench, god bless her, was in a completely different film.  I really wanted to see that film.  Badly.  Unfortunately, I wasn't watching it.I won't comment much on the dialogue, as I know cramming a huge novel into two hours is a fairly impossible task, but to actually have Charlotte Lucas say "Don't judge me, Lizzie, don't you dare judge me!", or Elizabeth blurt, "Mr. Darcy, what are you doing here!" when she sees him at Rosings is so far beyond the pale, that the palings aren't even in sight any longer.Perhaps I was missing the director's, the actors', the designers', and the writers' point in this film, but all I felt I was missing was "Pride and Prejudice."In a word: dreadful.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have been a longtime Jane Austen convert, for as long as I can remember.  "Pride and Prejudice," one of her most well-known and well-loved stories, has been brought to the screen a total of three times (prior to this new 2005 version).  The previous versions were made in 1940 (with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier), 1985 (with Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul), and in 1996 (with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle).This new version, with Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden, is intelligent, witty and very sensuous in its adaptation.  Elizabeth Bennett (Keira Knightley) is one of five daughters of the "have not" Bennett family, and her mother (Brenda Blethyn) is anxious to marry them off.  Once Elizabeth encounters Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfayden), a man who comes from great material wealth, but who lacks a lust for life, it is clear that the unlikely pair has been brought together for a reason, bigger than the both of them.This is an excellent character study and social commentary, on the state of the British class system and the pursuit of true love.  What's more, the actors in this film shine brightly and have great onscreen chemistry.  The photography is luscious, the story is engaging, and this is definitely NOT a chick flick.  I saw several men in the audience, and heard them chuckling warmly in the darkness of the movie theater.  Check it out!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: i adore this film, and the BBC miniseries as well.  This film is set when the book was written (Georgian England) not published (Victorian England), unlike the BBC version.  The difference is seen not just in the costumes, but in the manner of communicating.  In Georgian England, people were much more expressive.  Hence, the film is less subtle (also neccessary for a 2-hour version!) than the miniseries.  Give Macfayden a chance, he's no Colin Firth, but I think he communicates the "he's not a snob, he's just shy" aspect much better than Firth, who comes accross as simply arrogant for most of the BBC version.
summary: Loved even by a fan of the BBC version

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: 2005's "Pride and Prejudice" is a skillful adaptation of Jane Austen's classic romance novel to the big screen.  Only a bold production team would have taken on the task, given the continuing and justified popularity of the 1996 BBC television version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.  Taken on its own merits as a theatrical release, the 2005 version is visually stunning, includes wonderful location shooting and period detail, and offers two attractive leading actors with genuine on-screen chemistry.The storyline is familiar to Jane Austen fans.  The middle-class Bennet family, including its five eligible daughters and a scheming mother anxious to marry them off, learns that the wealthy Mr. Bingley will visit their small English village.  They meet Mr. Bingley at a village dance, where he is attracted to the beautiful and kind but reserved Jane Bennet.  Jane's spirited and headstrong sister Elizabeth is less impressed with Mr. Bingley's seemingly haughty friend Mr. Darcy.  Her disdain for his manners and his prejudice against Jane and against a militia officer whom she favors, will cause Elizabeth to angrily reject his surprise offer of marriage.  However, Elizabeth learns she may have been wrong about Mr. Darcy.  His generous efforts on behalf of Jane and of Elizabeth's eloped youngest sister will earn him a second chance.Keira Knightley is perfectly cast as the young and impertinent Elizabeth.  Matthew MacFadyen is very effective as the painfully shy and reserved Mr. Darcy.  Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn are a sympathetic Mr. and Mrs. Bennet.  The interaction of the Bennet sisters, including Rosamund Pike as Jane and Jena Malone as youngest sister Lydia, is authentic and by turns touching and hilarious.  Judi Dench personifies the "dragon" Lady Catherine DeBurgh.Adapting Pride and Prejudice to a two hour movie format means seriously compressing a treasured storyline. Under Director Joe Wright's sure hand, the movie steps briskly through the plot, keeping a tight focus on Elizabeth Bennet and her developing relationship with Mr. Darcy.  Among the key scenes: Elizabeth's chance encounter with Mr. Darcy at Pemberly; Mr. Bingley's proposal to Jane, reworked to bring out the humor and to make explicit Mr. Darcy's role; and Mr. Darcy's second proposal to Elizabeth.  The latter features a long atmospheric tracking shot as Mr. Darcy crosses a field at dawn to meet a surprised Elizabeth.  The next-to-last scene, in which Elizabeth requests permission to marry from her father, brings out the best in two very good actors."Pride and Prejudice" is very highly recommended to fans of Jane Austen.  The Collectors Edition DVD Set includes a music score CD, production notes, some excellent background features, and Joe Wright's fascinating director's commentary.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The notion of not comparing this version to the mostly sublime 1995 version with Jennifer Ehle, Colin Firth, et al is simply ridiculous.  Does one not constantly use comparison as a basis for all judgements in life?  If you deny it, you are deceiving yourself.That said, the music and lighting and colors (cinematography shall we say, minus some instances of jiggly camera movement and disturbing slight zooms in and out) are almost always wonderful throughout this film.  Music + Cinematography = 4.8 Stars.  Beyond that, I was alternately cringing and smiling and the sum which was null.  The Rest = -0.8 Stars.  Thus Average = 2 Stars.It is not necessary to make a movie of a book just because you can.  There are many books, and this is one of them, that require more time to have justice done to their tales.  It's impossible (at least for me) to watch this movie without becoming frustrated, and that's not entertainment.  The dialog is mostly useless, in some parts you may find yourself wondering if the actors are actually being paid for their performances (it can't all be the fault of the screenplay can it?).  I found almost nothing enlightening in this version except for the aforementioned music and cinematography.  I agree with the negative criticism in other reviews of this version of P&P; but will not take the space to repeat it here.I hardly ever write reviews, but I felt irrepressably compelled speak out and warn would-be buyers of this film (probably because I bought it because of the high average rating) - rent it first!!If you've never read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice or seen any other film versions, I encourage you to at least read the book first, and if you must watch this film version first, then afterwards see the 1995 version.  If you're also a Jane Austen-phile and sort of liked this movie, listen to the commentary - some comments will really drive you up the wall, and perhaps cool your opinion of this rendition!  Since I now own it, I'll watch it again and see if I can find any other redeeming qualities...however I sincerely doubt that I'll increase my rating...p.s.1.  The 10th Anniversary Limited Edition Collector's Set of the 1995 A&E; Pride and Prejudice will be released in late September 2006 - pre-order it now!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a magnificent production. The cinematography is pure art and can compete with the great paintings of the past: I think I have never seen the like of it. Some deviations are made from the book, all seemingly in order to obtain those stunning images - Darcy's proposal for instance is made under a solemn, late 18th century garden "temple"; in the pouring rain, rather than prosaically in the small cottage guest room she occupies at Lady de Bourgh's; the denouement is even more torn out of any convention, but it yields the strongly symbolic mage of two lovers in grassland embracing amidst haze and dew against the rising morning sun: I buy it.I cannot vouch for the story's consistency because I know both the book and the superb 1995 BBC series too well to be able to imagine learning the story by way of this motion picture. Other than that, the acting is superb; Keira Knightly (with a name like that, when is she going to do Emma???) magnificently portrays both the serious and frivolous sides of an intelligent and wise 22 year old; Matthew Macfadyen had to grow on me (and who in the world can top Colin Firth's plunge in the pond of his castle?) but convinces; Donald Sutherland, though in my view a miscast, is his superb self; and Judy Dench places a most formidable and implacable Lady Catherine. Everyone else is thoroughly enjoyable.The music is well done, fortunately with period players (the English Concert): what a chance, nowadays, for a film director to depict musicians the way they played in the time of the story! This period playing is combined with 21st century music depicting the characters' emotions, and all is amalgamated into a good whole. The costumes are very well done too, maybe a bit too upscale (difference is made though between the rich and the less so), but they blend better into the stunningly gorgeous pictures than (perhaps) simpler, more realistic clothing would.One of the most beautiful movies I have ever seen.I wonder if Keira's blowing out a candle somewhere in the middle of the movie is a small wink at Jennifer Ehle in the BBC production, who does the same, in pretty much the same way.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For those of you who loved the 1995 BBC version with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth (I'm an avid fan myself), please don't shy away from this utterly gorgeous rendition of Jane Austen's classic.  It isn't an improvement in any way on the 1995 version; it's simply a different interpretation that demonstrates how much richness Austen's book held, with which future adaptations could work.Where the 1995 version is, I believe, more faithful to the book's dignified, staid and old-fashioned but universal tone, this version sparkles with the eagerness and blunt sincerity of youth.  Miss Elizabeth Bennett still is a mature young lady, but she is much more fun-loving and a little less confident than Jennifer Ehle's portrayal of Elizabeth.  But both versions are beautiful.  Keira Knieghtly brings a suprising depth of thoughtfulness to her role, whereas Jennifer Ehle brought a maturity that was beyond maternal to hers.  Where Jennifer Ehle stressed Elizabeth as the lofty standard of reason, poise and discernment, Keira Knieghtly stresses Elizabeth's honest, refreshing, witty and intelligent manners.  Both adaptations are superbly rendered.The scenery in this version was also stunning - you should see this film for that alone.  The scenes are also very cleverly shot, with novel imagery that draws you into this by-gone period.  I walked out of the cinema feeling as though I had just landed back into the 21st century; that's how real it was.I also really appreciated the broodiness underlying this film.  There was a moody, cloudier aspect to the scenery that brought a pensive thoughtfulness to the production.  I felt as though I were really in England.  In the BBC 1995 production, every day was sunny.  The play of the natural elements in this version formed an intricate background to the tumult of inner emotions that the film portrayed so finely.  This film could be analyzed over and over for the many different threads its makers very skilfully used to weave a rich, gorgeous tapestry of an experince.You will be transported.
summary: Rich truffles for the eye and mind

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a wonderful adaptation!  I have to say I love both the BBC and the A&E versions.  I am so happy this movie has been made.  There's so much pressure on any actor playing Mr. Darcy after Collin's portrayl.  However, McFayden (sp?) has nailed this part.  Keira is a much better Elizabeth than Jen Ehle (sp?).  As much as I love Jen's acting, it's hard to pretend she's not at least 30 years old at the time of filming.  (I dont know how old she was, but she was made to look at least 30 imho).  I loved the scene under the rain, it looked like Darcy could barely contain himself from grabbing Elizabeth, and she looked like she wouldnt mind that at all  LOL.  I know, this is not a very intelligent or insightful review, but I'm so delighted with the movie...  I cant wait to buy the dvd.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Pride and Prejudice (the novel and the A&E; miniseries) most ardently. Joe Wright's adaptation will likely disturb Austenites, so consider yourselves warned and need not watch :) I believe it is also pointless to compare a 2-hr adaptation to any of the 4 1/2 hr versions. So, if you get over that and you would like  a movie to entertain you with breathtaking cinematography, adorable updated dialogues, deft acting, and a musical score that inspires without being overwhelming, then this is for you.The central cast is younger than previous adaptations but equally brilliant. Knightley truly has Elizabeth's  "fine eyes," but not distractingly beautiful, expressive but not deliberate. MacFadyen unfolded Darcy's in a compelling manner; proud but endearingly awkward, confident yet reticent, elegant yet subtly sexy (and I love, love, love his eyes).Cons: 1. the heavy reliance of the film to imagery and nuances (in the novel and in other adaptations, most of the P and P elements are presented as dialogues; follow the camera's movement and be very observant!)3. use of the napoleonic era timeline, as oppose to the more aesthetic victorian era backdrop that P and P fans have gotten used toPros: 1. use of the napoleonic era timeline; makes the film less stodgy, less pompous, more grounded2. fresh take on the classic but most romantic; the display of emotions are more intense  (a more spirited Elizabeth, a less elegant Darcy-in-love; Jane is less sedate and a fleeting scene that shows Bingley reaching for Jane's dress, desperate for any form of physical contact)3. a sense of urgency was captured without the abuse of a nattering Mrs. Bennet4. my favorite: unusual for his countenance, Mr. Darcy comes out disheveled in his night clothes and desperately seeks Elizabeth through the mist. It is a powerful show of yearning that romantics will find gratifyingI find most happy endings in romantic films to be contrived, but this is one romantic film where I found myself hoping and staying for the kiss.
summary: Not Austen but most invigorating! (contains spoilers....)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not a Kiera Knightly fan so did not expect to like this but it was awesome and excellent....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: "Pride and Prejudice," directed by Joe Wright, is a beautifully mounted version of the beloved Jane Austen classic.  Gorgeously filmed on location in England, the movie stars Keira Knightley as the spirited Elizabeth Bennet.  Knightley has luminous eyes, a wickedly mischievous smile, and a saucy manner.  The director wisely zooms in on her captivating face in a number of tight close-ups.  Matthew MacFadyen plays Mr. Darcy as an aloof and sullen gentleman, who hides his smoldering sexuality beneath a stolid facade.  Brenda Blethyn is appropriately dithery as the nervous and silly Mrs. Bennet, a mother of five daughters who is desperate to marry her children off to men of means.  Mr. Bennet, played solidly by Donald Sutherland, frequently hides in his study in order to get a respite from his noisy and high-spirited brood.  Also noteworthy are Tom Hollander as the stuffy and pompous Mr. Collins; his pursuit of Elizabeth is met with undisguised disdain.  Dame Judi Dench is formidable in her cameo as the imperious and overbearing Lady Catherine de Bourg. Less successful are the miscast Simon Woods, who turns in a nerdy performance as the carrot-topped Mr. Bingley, and Rosamund Pike, as Jane Bennet, is lovely to look at but a bit too vapid.Roman Osin, the cinematographer, captures the lush beauty of the English countryside and the glamor of Darcy's and Bingley's estates.  The camera is always in motion, panning over the dancers in a ballroom, a breathtaking sunset, a rainy field, and the expressions on the characters' faces.  There is rarely a dull moment in this film. Unfortunately, the dialogue is sometimes difficult to follow because the Wright frequently directs his actors to speak over one another.  In addition, unlike Dench, whose diction is impeccable, some of the performers speak too quickly and fail to enunciate.Another quibble is that the screenwriter, Deborah Moggach, gives short shrift to  Austen's underlying themes of snobbery, social stratification, and the constraints of women in eighteenth century England.  These issues are certainly implied, but they are peripheral to Elizabeth and Darcy's romance, which takes center stage. Still, this movie is a treat for the mind and heart. "Pride and Prejudice" is an enchanting, wildly romantic, and entertaining love story that will please all but the most finicky Austen purists.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a connoisseur of Austen books and movies, I was both thrilled and disappointed by this one.  They strayed from the text a bit too much for my taste - demerit.  They rattled off their brilliant lines too quickly - demerit (particularly Keira Knightly).  I was disappointed by her performance overall, although I do like her aesthetically and even cerebrally as Elizabeth.On the plus side - Matthew Macfadyen made a wonderful Darcy.  Also the cinematography was absolutely lovely, as was the artistic direction.  I felt I was in the right place at the right time, and the costumes and scenes were charming and realistic - not too clean for Olde England.Overall a good nights entertainment - but not up to the BBC version.  Of course...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I never thought I would understand Pride & Prejudice enough to critique the film adaptations but some unexpected leisure in the past couple of months has allowed me to see them all. The 1940 Greer Garson is good - indeed all 4 are good although widely different. The Keira Knightly is the best, however, both because of her portrayal of Elizabeth Bennet, and because of the warmth of the film maker's conception of the Bennet family.  Of course it is the portrayal of Lizzy that makes or breaks the film, and this is my favorite portrayal, and my pick of the best of the 4.  Keira Knightly is my favorite Elizabeth. She is younger than the other actresses who have played Elizabeth,  and plays a Elizabeth Bennet closer to the 20 year old we read about in the novel. I would not call her beautiful - indeed in this film Jane is the most beautiful of the 5 Bennet sisters, just as she is supposed to be. But Keira is unbelievably attractive because of her facial expressions. She has a marvelous smile and we see a lot of it, and, like Garson, her face can show her emotions and their changes so well that soon you are completely engrossed in her character and her story. As they used to say, "You'll laugh, you'll cry, but you'll never forget Keira Knightly as Elizabeth Bennet."This version also manages to allow Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) to be his sarcastic and witty self without being unpleasant. He is played too harshly in some other versions, especially the 1979 BBC adaptation.  The Bennet family holds together quite well, even Mrs. Bennet is redeemed, although with some dialog that is definitely not in the novel.  Darcy is almost impossible to cast, I suspect. Certainly in this film he is no better than acceptable. Mr. Collins, on the other hand, is very good, although his part is much cut down in the interest of getting a 2 hour film. (We do get to hear a short sample of his preaching). The only unhappy casting is that of Wickham. Wickham is a sociopath, and should have a great deal of charm when he meets Lizzy. Here he is more whiner than charmer. All 3 of the other film makers were able to find someone to fit the bill, but here Keira's boyfriend, I believe, got the part, and he is simply wrong for it. Luckily his role is also quite reduced from that in the novel so we don't see him often enough to be disturbed greatly.So, for those characters that survived the scriptwriter, this is the best cast of the 4 adaptations, and the most sympathetic to the Bennet family. Who is missing? Aunt Phillips and "broad faced stuffy Uncle Phillips, breathing port wine." Mr. and Mrs. Hurst, Maria Lucas (well really, excepting Charlotte, Sir William and all the Lucases are missing), Mr. & Mrs. Gardiner's children are gone, although the Gardiners do get to take Lizzy to Pemberly, Mrs. Hill is gone, Mrs. Young is gone, and Mrs. Ainisley is gone,  as are all of the Officers from the ____Shire militia (we see anonymous officers dancing, but no Denny,  and no Col. Forster except by mention. We do not go to London with Jane, or Ramsgate with Georgiana, and never were going to the Lakes. We do get a milita parade, quite a bit of poultry, one Wuthering Heights like view of Lizzy standing in the wind atop a cliff which they would do well to edit out of the film, Darcy's proposal in a faux-temple during a rainstorm, and absolutely the best Assembly Ball ever filmed.  The director's commentary is quite interesting, too.Do you remember the Polanski film where our heroes are pretending to be the living dead, and at a zombie ball they dance down the room until suddenly they come upon a mirror and, being alive, they are reflected in it but none of the other dancers are?  Here when Mr. Darcy dances with Lizzy their conversation becomes so intense that the other dancers vanish for a couple of minutes and we just have our couple dancing alone in the ballroom. I don't know that the scenes connect in any other way but one scene calls forth the other to me.So aside from Wickham, what problems? Everyone compresses the sequence of events at the end, but here someone piled them up and stomped on them. Bingley returns to Netherfield, proposes in the afternoon, Lady Catherine arrives around midnight, and at the next dawn Lizzy and Darcy meet in a foggy field and become engaged. Poor Mr. Collins' letter never arrives, as you can imagine. Where could it have fit in? In about 16 hours of one day, we see what took weeks in the novel. Most bothersome is the visit to Pemberly. Lizzy becomes detached from the Gardiners, wanders off alone in the house, and hearing piano playing,  peeks through a door and sees Georgiana playing, then she sees Darcy enter and his sister and he embrace, till he looks up and sees Elizabeth peeping in at them. That's bad enough, (and quite out of character)  but then she walks back to Lambton without the Gardiners and without looking for them. Is it possible that they did not realize that she was no longer with them as they went through the house?  Still, one can excuse these little things. If we put up with Caroline Bingley's "fat suit" costume in the Garson version, we can put up with almost anything.My advice? Buy all 4 versions, book a transatlantic cruise, and give each version one full sea-day to watch and consider. I think you'll find yourself agreeing with me that the Keira Knightly film is the best, and you'll be happy you watched the others.
summary: Probably the Best Film Adaptation of the 4

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: To begin with I must praise how beautiful the film was. The pictures of the English countryside and some of the pictures of Elizabeth and Darcy were breathtaking. The music was also very moving and fantastic. But that's about all the good I can get out of it. I can simply not see Kiera Knightley as Elizabeth. She doesn't have the same wit and is on the point of tears many, many times at places where a true Elizabeth would have just been laughing in her head. Another complaint is when they first arrive at Pemberly, Elizabeth lets out this quaverly laugh and then says nothing else. It looks like she's going insane, very strange. Her mother as portrayed a bit too lightly and definitely not as annoying. They parents seem to love each other, which if you have read the book, they don't. The younger sisters Kitty and Lydia are very good for their parts. Mr. Wickham looks so much like Orlando Bloom it's scary and you don't really feel as if you know him.  Charlotte Lucas has scripting problems. She is a wonderful actress and I feel she is wonderful for the part, but the scripting doesn't do her justice. It makes her seems to much like a 20-th century woman. The quote "So don't judge me" in a reference to her conversation with Elizabeth when she explains her decision to marry Mr. Collins is the main example. Matthew Macfayden is possibly the best portrayal for the whole movie, with the exclusion of Charlotte Lucas. He seems to be much more attractive in this movies, both physically and emotionally. My only complaint is that he seems almost depressed at points instead of reserved. As to what I would do with this movie is buy the dvd, put in in a computer and take screen takes out, create my own movie with the soundtrack music so I could just enjoy what I wanted too.My personal reccomendation  for a good version of Pride and Prejudice is to get the 1975 BBC version. I feel that as far as wit and age it is the best portrayl. The 1995 version has some problems, such as two scenes that wouldn't have happend in the 1800's, the age of the actors as compared with the ages of Elizabeth and Darcy and my main complaint is that every hint of wit between Elizabeth and Darcy seems calculated to wound whereas Elizabeth meant to be rude and somewhat cutting, but not the that degree. One note that may bother you is that my recommended version doesn't not contain as much scripting from the book as the 1995 version.
summary: Beautiful, but not Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For an adaptation, this is a very good movie. I've seen some other movies that practically changed the story. This one stays close to the original story, even though it skipped some details. Great scenery, great actors. Macfadyen is terrific as Darcy! He made us felt for Darcy. However, the movie failed to tell us some important things. I read the novel, and I understand that it's not possible to fit everything in a 2-hour movie. But, I think Darcy's personality was not explored enough. He was actually proud, he was, at first, looking at Lizzy only to criticize. The novel explains that he was raised to be like that. He's the only son, and for many years he was the only child. He was spoiled. He would have stayed like that had he not met Lizzy. I think this detail would help us understand his struggles even better.I am personally impressed by the music. It really works with the story. Being a piano player and singer myself, I really enjoyed the music. Bravo!I wouldn't endorse sequels. The story is beautiful as it is. Don't ruin it. Let's leave what happens next to our imagination.

For anyone that has not yet seen this movie, perhaps this version would suffice.. but my advise is to buy the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version from 1995. I think it far superior.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: You would think that Jane Austen's most famous novel is not in need of another cinematic treatment given the definitive BBC version of a decade ago and the classic 1940 MGM version starring Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier, not to mention a contemporary 2004 Bollywood-style musical and according to IMDB, at least six other versions. However, first-time feature director Joe Wright and first-time screenwriter Deborah Moggach (with uncredited assistance from Austen adaptation veteran Emma Thompson) have brought youthful vigor and a wild, Thomas Hardy-like element to the movie, and as a whole, it works very well. It almost makes the overly familiar novel feel revitalized.For those who have forgotten their required high school reading, the story focuses on the downscale Bennet family - a passive father and a domineering mother, the latter intent on marrying off their five daughters to wealthy families. Eldest daughter Jane becomes smitten with rich but somewhat weak-willed Mr. Bingley and the bookish Mary keeps to her piano, while the two youngest daughters, Kitty and Lydia, are giggly and boy-crazy. On the other hand, the headstrong Elizabeth wants marriage on her terms with an intellectual equal, and she becomes alternately repelled and drawn to the brooding Mr. Darcy. There are several plotlines that interweave precariously toward the inevitable conclusion, but Austen's witty, often insightful dialogue holds the story together organically with grace and humor.Twenty-year old Keira Knightley is the youthful embodiment of Elizabeth, as her predecessors, Garson in particular, always strike me as too mature for the role. With her beauty subdued in casual period fashion, she manages to convey all the necessary facets of her personality with a natural élan. As Darcy, Matthew Macfayden captures the moody character's insolence and growing romanticism with little affectation. Most all of the supporting players shine with Brenda Blethyn as the exasperating Mrs. Bennet, Donald Sutherland as her introspective husband, Tom Hollander as the priggish Mr. Collins, Rosamund Pike as beautiful and likable Jane, Jena Malone convincingly British as the impulsive Lydia, and of course, in all her scene stealing glory, Judi Dench lends acidic vinegar as Lady Catherine, Darcy's disapproving aunt.Parts of the film have a subtly stylized quality, such as the way the camera seems to track uninterrupted during the Assembly Hall ball sequence or when Elizabeth's head spins symbolically as she sits on a swing. There are also many well-turned tableaux-style shots that imbue the spirit of the period with vivid but unobtrusive detail. Credit should go to Roman Osin's textured and sumptuous cinematography, Jacqueline Durran's authentic-feeling costumes and Dario Marianelli's flavorful music, all of which capture a decidedly realistic though ultimately romanticized 16th-century England.The DVD package has several too-short features that provide some background into the production and Austen's characters but hardly enough to provide meaningful insight. Wright provides sometimes interesting commentary on an alternate track that borders a bit on the effusive, and there is an alternative and thankfully excised ending which spells out the plot resolutions unnecessarily. This movie is a joyous celebration of Austen's artistry as a writer whose story themes resonate today.
summary: Robust Adaptation of Familiar Austen Novel Is One First-Class Production

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you love dialogue, this movie is for you. Jane Austen is all about developing personality through dialog. If you don't want to engage your intellect, skip Jane Austen and stick with Austin Powell. Elizabeth (K. Knightly with her beauty somewhat downplayed ) personifies the triumph of intellect over beauty. Austin makes her point clear by givening Elizabeth two empty headed sisters. Here's an example of a great line, " you must choose to lose one of your parents, if you accept Mr Collin's hand, I will never speak to you again; if you reject Mr Collins hand, your mother will never speak to you again."

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although the English landscapes are beautifully portrayed, this film itself falls short of its ambitions. Elizabeth Bennet is Jane Austen's most popular heroine, and to see her portrayed so tackily is a shame. The saccharine romantics will still gush over the script that mimics Austen's story, but more discriminating viewers will not appreciate the liberties taken with the novel.Elizabeth Bennet is an intelligent woman and an astute observer of social refinements. In the novel, one is never embarrassed by her--instead, one is embarrassed on her behalf because of the indiscretions of her mother, sisters, and sometimes even father. However, in the movie, she too closely resembles her mother and Lydia, the gross embarrassments of the family and community. Where is the elevation between the two sisters? In the novel, Lydia's character is grossly ignorant of propriety, and is written that way for a reason: to show how intelligent and refined Elizabeth is, despite low family connections or lack of wealth. To see Elizabeth brought nearer Lydia's level is unforgiveable, and the movie, regardless of how beautifully filmed cannot recover from it.
summary: Sadly, a butchery of Austen's best work...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wonderful actors.  Delightful story and music.  A movie that I love to watch--over and over again. I would love to see Matthew Macfaden and Kiera Knightly paired up in other movies.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I may not be a movie critic, but I do enjoy movies and versions of Pride and Prejudice are a particular favorite.  I admit I am a Firth fan from way back but am always open to new interpretations and this one is probably the strangest and worst one I have ever seen.  Like Shakespeare, Austen's works can be easily and effectively adapted to many time periods.  I have see most if not all of the Austen-based movies and have enjoyed their charm as well as change of scenery and time periods.  The themes she utilizes are universal.That being stated, this version is down right bizarre.  I understood a two hour movie would never have all the details needed to do this novel justice, however, when you start changing the customs, dicta, societal rules of the time peroid, you have ruined a major part of the story.  Since many other reviewers have gone into detail about the plot, I will refrain from any retelling.Luckily for the audience, a lot of Lizzie's words were cut, especially her dialogue concerning being a gentleman's daughter.  Barefoot, wandering around in thin night clothes at dawn (this is cold, damp England by the way, not sunny California) and watching swine run through what looked like a part of the Bennet house, especially a house that truly needed a make over was odd enough, but Darcy apparently did not have a valet or anyone that was concerned about his grooming or public appearance.  (Neither did Mr. Bennet.)  Is this the best English society has to offer?Overall, the acting that was shown (who knows what all is on the cutting room floor) was good.  The actors worked with what they had but I wonder if any of the actors had any clue what the director's vision really was.The part that bothered me the most had to be the midnight carriage ride of Lady Catherine.  What English lady (or any member of the gentry) would take a 50 mile ride in the dark?  No street lamps between Rosings and Longbourne, never mind the robbers, beggars, and other criminals that would be out at night, leaving Lady C with no protection other than the few footmen she might of had with her(Of course, you have no way of knowing how Lady C actually got to Longbourne).  And to top all that off, Lady Catherine was not even offended that Lizzie did not change clothes to talk to her.  Oh please, the rules of English society were not lax by any means and they got even stricter as time goes by until after WWII.  Add onto that the dawn meeting between Lizzie and Darcy in a field somewhere (in night clothes and very casual attire on Darcy's part) and you have truly entered a bizarre (definitely not an English society) world.  Lizzie's visit to Pemberly and the (non-portrait)sculpture gallery with the nudes amongst the bust of Darcy would never have been tolerated by Darcy himself(for Geogianna would never have been allowed to see any of the statutes, even of her brother, but they did portraits of people, not sculpture during that time period)much less non-married visitors of Pemberly.  (Did they feel that gave them the sex they needed for the movie?)If you want to modernize P&P;, go ahead, have at it, but don't modernize it in the same time period and change all the rules, customs and dicta of the time period.  Movies in the last 20-30 years have consistently gotten better about creating accurate time portrayals when you look at movies in this genre.  The golden years of Hollywood were not very accurate, but they did not really even try, so it is not really an issue.  But in the 21st century, we have the knowledge and ability to know those rules, customs and dicta, so why trash them to make a quick buck.  The BBC series at least tried to do Austen justice.  No movie can ever totally create what we the reader are envisioning, but a movie can be accurate with known facts.This movie did an incredibly poor job at recreating this world.  The actors did a good job, but that is the only reason why I can give this two stars.
summary: Does anyone really know what time(period) this is?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film is worth watching for its beautiful picture more than for anything else. Each shot looks like it has been taken from a painting of a period. Congratulations to the director and cameraman. The acting was good, the casting was good too, with some minor exceptions.It was the interpretation of the story which made me cringe from time to time. Was it really necessary to insert quite a lot of the awkward modern dialogue and the ways of expression into the story to show that it's topical? The director could express himself and convey the social message of the story without distorting the ways and customs of the past and adapting the story to modern ways.For one, could you ever imagine a grand lady of the society bursting into somebody's house in the middle of the night even if the matter was urgent?? Is it really necessary to take such radical measures to emphasize the character's personality? Sometimes I thought there was too much explained and too vividly expressed what could have been left to understand.On the other hand, the story was not very well developed, concentrating on Lizzy alone and leaving behind some important characters. We do not fully comprehend the drama of Lydia's escape with a man as we do not see in the full the wickedness of Mr. Whickam. Concequently, untouched is the theme of the goodness and just appearance of it as well as some other important messages. The story was quckly flowing from scene to scene without allowing the spectator to be involved.Moreover, almost all of the book characters appeared in the film; some, for a second only, after disappearing forever. This only crowded the film and left the residue of unsatisfaction, for you expect the story line to develop somehow in connection with the newly introduced character. True, the director didn't have much time at his disposal, well then... I know some big volumes transferred into the film media without losing their impact. If the director wanted to introduce a new, different interpretation of the story, he succeded only in modernizing dialogue and changing visual style, but his message is quite weaker than the original.On the whole, it is a pleasant production and does deserve an apprisal (for its picture mostly). However, the impeccable version of the book has been already made - 1995 BBC miniseries, and... what's the point in remaking the perfect?!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First time I saw this a few years ago I was crazy about it and watched it twice thru. Recently after the Downton Abbey craze which I jumped fully into, I had the yearning to revisit this story because it is so similar, all about "entailed property" and women's lack of rights and social castes, which persist today. It's almost the same story. When the Downton Abbey season ended I was bereft. So I rented the Colin Firth version, the BBC miniseries, which others always compare to this movie. I fell deeply into that telling too; such a wonderful transporting viewing experience! *sigh* Lol. I got into a Jane Austen frenzy and read a lot about her and the book and so decided to see this movie yet again! And I was shocked by the difference. Suddenly I realized that this Keira Knightly version is quite untrue to the original story, while the miniseries is much closer. Ultimately the only good version of Pride and Prejudice is the book itself, truly, which I find more hypnotic than any video representation. I listen to the Audible version while walking my dog. It's great. One thing that highlights the failure in both this movie and the miniseries is that Mr. Bennet loved his wife and considered her beautiful. That is established in the very beginning. From both movies you get that Mrs. Bennet is a crazy idiot that he only tolerates! Both cast her as old, with old actresses, when actually I think she would have been in her early 40's, maybe even 39. Jane Austen pokes gentle fun at her in the book but the movies really trash her and for that reason I will only trust my own interpretation of this great story, from the book itself. But I wouldn't say don't watch this movie. Keira Knightly is luminous and fantastic and adorable. And I fell in so love with Matthew McFadyen. Definitely watch the movie, but know it is not the real Pride and Prejudice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I didn't think anyone could play Mr. Darcy as well as Colin Firth, but I will say that Matthew Macfayden pleasantly surprised me. Keira Knightley also captured the visual expressions of her character.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film takes place in rural England during the 18th century. My favorite actress Keira Knightley plays the witty and head-strong Elizabeth Bennett, the second eldest of five daughters who come from a modest family. The daughters have reached marriagable age, and when the handsome, wealthy Mr. Bingley comes to town, of course the whole household flies into an uproar. Elizabeth's older and stunningly beautiful sister Jane (who is played by Audrey Tautou look-alike Rosamund Pike) is established as the inteded for Mr. Bingley. Elizabeth meets her match in Mr. Bingley's best friend, Mr. Darcy, whose dark wit and forlorn manner somehow spark her interest, but when a series of misunderstandings arise that involve her beloved family, Elizabeth must learn to put aside her pride or else risk losing the man who completes her.This movie was exquisite and beautifully directed. The sweeping, epic shots and stunning cinematography served as the perfect backdrop for the delicate love story between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. Keira Knightley's performance as Elizabeth was so amazing that it should serve as the standard for all romantic heroines. The chemistry created by lingering glances and touches is electrifying, and conveys the love arising bewteen Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy more fully than covert displays of affection that afflict many movies made today.So utterly romantic and heart-felt. One of the best films I've seen in a very long time.
summary: One of the most romantic movies I've ever seen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Over the years, there have been different film versions of Jane Austen's novel "Pride and Prejudice." I enjoy the diverging portrayals of the House of Bennet, where the Salic Law prevails, for new insights into the array of characters can always be gleaned. It is like visiting the same family in different seasons. I must admit that to me the 1995 BBC version was so excellent that I thought nothing else could compare, which is why the viewing of the 2005 rendition was postponed until a couple of days ago. With stunning cinematography and meticulously detailed sets, it is a highly entertaining production. Keira Knightley, although she is too thin for period roles when women were more fleshy, played the part of Elizabeth quite well. The other sisters and Mrs. Bennet were very well-cast. Donald Sutherland utterly stole the show. Sutherland's Mr Bennet seems to be in his own world yet he is really more in tune with everything that is going on than poor distracted Mrs. Bennet. That is especially evident from the way he goes over and comforts poor Mary at the Netherfield ball.The musical score is quite romantic, capturing the desperation of young love obstructed by such obstacles as money and status. The attraction between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy is more palpable than ever, although they hardly ever touch except when dancing. Those days of strict boundaries and protocols certainly make for some great love stories.In the 2005 version, the Bennets seem more like yeomen farmers than landed gentry, with pigs running through the house, and shabby dresses. Were the Bennets really that poor? Maybe they were. On the other hand, Mr. Darcy is raised to the peerage, living at Chatsworth like the Duke of Devonshire. The Darcys were a distinguished and wealthy family but I doubt that they had the Elgin marbles in the parlor. This was only a minor distraction (along with the few weak attempts at vulgar humor) in a wonderful film which brings the viewer into the world of the late 1700's, the world of Jane Austen, when young men knelt to ladies when proposing marriage, and being a penniless old maid was the fate worse than death.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love love love the masterful scoring -- the piano music is a perfect touch that moves the plot forward and evokes emotions. Keira is a very good actress, but OMG -- she looks like a concentration camp survivor!! Just emaciated!  But the movie is very well done.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Can't get the movie out of my head after I watched it. The music was wonderful as well. Bought the soundtrack.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a fan of the miniseries, but come on, how can you resist this movie? It is fantastic. A good movie is faithful to the book, but a GREAT movie is one that can portray the story, characters, setting faithfully and still be an entertaining FILM that isn't 6 hours long. Keira is wonderful and both the leads capture the essence of the characters with body language and superb acting, something that Austin only succeeded in doing with a lot of dialogue. The rich scenery and music is delightful and it all comes together like a masterful painting. I absolutely recommend this movie. It is the best.
summary: I'm sorry but this is absolutely the best movie

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A beautiful portrayal for Jane Austin's amazing piece of work. Truly one of the most lovely films I have ever seen in my life.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: During my first viewing of this new adaptation, it was a little bit difficult to get over how fast they speed through the story and what a completely different movie this is, however after my first viewing, I couldn't get the movie out of my mind. The inward struggle of both Darcy and Elizabeth is portrayed so well. There are a few elements that were explained in this adaptation that were not addressed in the Firth/ Ehle adaptation. Charlotte Lucas's reasoning for marrying Mr. Collins for example and the mother's obsession with getting her daughters married off. The father was much more loving to all of his family and over all; the characters and situations were more realistic. The scenery, music, and filming were beautiful. I own and love the first movie however to get the complete story I think it is necessary to view both. If you haven't seen the Firth P&P or read the book, don't watch this until you have. You would be missing out on too much background.
summary: This is a beautiful peice of a gorgeous puzzle.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a beautifully made movie based on a classic novel.  Great acting, the story. characters, and scenery are depicted wonderfully.  I loved watching this with my sister and again with my daughter.  I even got my husband to watch it with me and he actually admitted to enjoying it, too! A great movie to have in your library, so beautiful to watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A charming, wonderful movie in its own right.  Brilliantly cast, and well acted.  I loved it.  It captures the essence of Pride and Prejudice.  I didn't want it to end when it was over.  It was filmed beautifully.  And if it wasn't my favorite book, if I didn't know the story so well, I probably wouldn't have noticed the `rushing' through the storyline.  Feelings aren't developed, can't be developed, within this kind of a short format.  Circumstances and emotions that took days, weeks, or months to develop in the book seem to transpire instantaneously in this movie.  The passage of time is not well represented.  Some characters that definitely add depth are cut out of the plot completely.  Where is Mr. Hurst, for example, eating, drinking, and sleeping to excess?  Mrs. Hurst?  Charlotte's sister Maria?  Aunt Phillips?  Mr. Collins doesn't get to develop his idiosyncracies appropriately.  And my favorite narcissist of all time, Lady Catherine De Bourgh, played by a phenomenal actress this time out (Dame Judi Dench), doesn't get to fuss, brag, and command as she ought.  If you want the nuance, the humor, and the character development, you have to read the original book or watch either the BBC or the A&E production.  However, this was a delightful movie taken alone, without comparison.  This adaption would be an especially good introduction to Pride and Prejudice.  Austen lovers, like me, will love it, too, even though it is slightly truncated.  I recommend it.  And the extras were also very interesting.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Austen lovers will take to this version of a beloved novel.  Kiera Knightley is an excellent Lizzie Bennett and the cinematograhpy is georgous.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Well done! Read the book (many times) and this film version is a great representation of this time in history.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Someone on another website (I regret that I cannot give the reference) commented aptly that in this movie, Longbourne looks  like Stella Gibbons'Cold Comfort Farm (Penguin Classics Deluxe Edition).  This was an amusing enough costume flick, but a pretty poor interpretation ofPride and Prejudice (Bantam Classics)so I recommend that Jane Austen fans tell themselves that they are not watching the Bennets, they are watching the Georgian-era Starkadders.  (I strongly recommend the offbeat Cold Comfort Farm as both a novel and a movie:Cold Comfort Farm).The problem with this movie is not so much that it is short, but that what is retained is frequently rendered inane.  Instead of handing his letter to Lizzie while she is out walking, the half-dressed Darcy breaks into the Collins' house in the middle of the night and surprises nightgown-clad Lizzie in her dark bedroom (and she doesn't even scream.)  One of the pivotal scenes in the book is Lizzie Bennet's hearing praise of Darcy from his housekeeper.  This is eliminated in favor of a dopy scene of her wandering around a collection of marble nudes, as if perhaps, the problem was with her libido and this fixed it.  The corny last scene made me glad the movie was ending.  I have read that this is not in the British edition; perhaps they are still trying to punish Americans for the revolution.  In addition, someone apparently decided that it would be hysterically funny if people were constantly interrupting the Bennets.  So instead of Mr. Collins proposing after breakfast, he starts his proposal during breakfast and Mrs. Bennet makes everyone but Lizzie leave the table.  Darcy wakes everyone up before dawn to ask for Lizzie's hand - I don't recommend this as a way to endear yourself to prospective in-laws.  Lady Catherine shows up in the middle of the night, wakes up all the Bennets, and then has it out with Lizzie in front of her family - really smooth and discreet.  People in this era avoided driving at night when they could - they didn't have halogen street lights all over the place, it was very dark at night and travelling could be very dangerous.The depiction of the period is very uneven.  I had a bad feeling about this movie when I saw the tie-in book featuring Darcy walking around half-dressed, looking a lot more like Heathcliff in Wuthering Heights.  I cannot understand the argument that this is a modern retelling when it is still set in the Regency.  Or that it is somehow more suited to a present-day audience than the A&E; (Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)) and BBC (Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980)) productions.  There are a number of novels that have rewritten Pride and Prejudice as a contemporary story - why not do one of those if modern is what one is after?CluelessandBride and Prejudicewere certainly fresh, modern retellings of Austen's work, and I loved both of them, but I don't see how those adjectives apply to this film.  I don't understand why filmmakers use material for which they obviously have little sympathy.  Something by the Brontes would probably have been more compatible.There were some things that I thought were well done.  I am not an expert, but I believe that, in this era when most clothes were custom made and relatively expensive, it was common for older people to wear the fashions of their youth, so I actually found that an interesting part of the representation.  I understand that this is supposed to be 1800, or earlier, and the typical Regency dress was originally considered to be quite shocking. As to the status of the Bennets, on the one hand, the greater sophistication of Caroline Bingley's clothing (except for that anachronistic slip dress) vice the clothing of the Bennets' and their neighbors is a realistic representation of the difference in their lifestyles.  The Bingley's are wealthier and spend more time in London; the Bennets probably rely on local seamstresses, and are just a touch behind in fashion.  Some of the Bennets' clothing was a bit grubby, but perhaps that was how country people dressed for solitary walks.  The moviemakers do seem to be a little confused as to what qualified as suitable dress for public appearances.  One can imagine that the difference in decoration at Longbourne and Netherfield partly represents the difference between landed gentry with generations of occupancy and heirlooms that no-one wants to throw out, and the nouveau riche who, starting from scratch, use the very latest fashion.  Everything about the Bennets and their neighbors ought to seem a trifle rustic and old-fashioned, just not lower class.On the other hand, the Bennets have a very good income for a "gentleman", and I sincerely doubt that the barnyard was up against the house or that the Bennets spent much time tending the livestock.  There's not much point to having pigs (which are notoriously smelly) right by the house unless one is personally slopping the hogs, and the Bennets had farmworkers.  I suppose that the filmmakers used this to indicate the precarious position of the sisters rather than explaining that in addition to the entail, their parents were too irresponsible to save money out of their income for dowries.  Earthier is not necessarily more realistic.Given the amount of material that had to be omitted, I cannot imagine why we spent so much time gazing at bushes.  If I were editting the movie, the scene of Lizzie walking across the field to the house would be the first to go.  It's cliched, a waste of time, and I've seen much better photography of the English landscape.So, I recommend this to lovers of costume drama who can keep the original novel out of their heads, or people who have never read the novel in the first place.On the entry for the movie showtimes, there is a review: "A Tender, Beautifully-Filmed Prequel to "The Clampetts"', January 1, 2006, by Carol M. Shifflett which I thought was hysterically funny and which I recommend to anyone not entirely happy with the film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My Amazon code name says it all...I'm Elizabeth Bennett! It's one of the few movies I can watch over and over again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Come on Ladies. You can't possibly tell me that after seeing the portrayal of Mr. Darcy by Matthew McFayden that you are not ready to eat this man alive!  Were Mr. Darcy to look at me the way he did Lizzy, I would die a happy woman.  I want a sequel! Guess I'll just have to keep viewing it (7 times already) or at least FF to the good parts. Na,  every scene between the two is to die for. Get this DVD & enjoy. (And I'm a fan of Colin Firth)

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The dynamic of the two characters is fascinating!  The chemistry that they bring to the movie is extraordinary and the movie it's self is funny to watch with the satire and witty comments that the character makes towards one another.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of the greatest love stories of all time.  I love the book.  I love the BBC version with Colin Firth, and I absolutely love this version!!!  The cast is amazing.  While the BBC version goes more in depth and stays a bit truer to the book this version keeps the feel of the book without some of the detail.The biggest thing that this version has going for it is the cast.  Mrs. Bennet is not nearly as annoying here - she's actually a bit endearing.  Jane Bennett is actually prettier than Elizabeth which is nice given that it is one of the key points of the plot.  The chemistry between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy is AMAZING!!!  And I really like Mr. Collins...okay I don't like him, but I like his performance.The plot moves rather quickly and I have watched this dvd maybe 80 times in the past two years.  I love it!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen many versions or shall we say productions of Pride and Prejudice and this adaptation is far off the mark IMHO. Jane Austen never depicted her characters in such a low class style. The characters are seductive and appear cheap and even whorish. If this Mr Bennett is a "gentleman" than Lady Catherine is right to consider him not one. Colin Firth depicts Mr Darcy as arrogantly prideful and in this version Mr Darcy seems angry and rather sad all the time. I do not think that this adaptation truly developed the characters as the BBC adaptation did so elegantly. You barely knew the characters at all and most of them truly had no depth. I really disliked Mrs Bennett in the BBC version but in this one she was somewhat likable. Mr Collins was barely able to be despised. Overall I think it it a poor excuse for a work so fine as Jane Austen wrote.ElizabethTrinity, AL

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of my favorite films of all time.  It has a lot of charm and brings Jane Austen's wonderful story to life. The acting was great and highly enjoyable.  Knightly plays Elizabeth perfectly and Mr. Darcy's character is also done very well.  This movie is a classic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Really enjoyed how easy Amazon's instant video was to use. Very much enjoyed Pride and Prejudice because of the choice of casting, the scenery, and the costumes. I guess much of the book had to be edited because the film would've been too lengthy, but some of the parts cut were pretty important I thought. Well worth watching!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I awaited the Nov. release of this film with impatience, after hearing about it in Bath, England last fall. I am a huge fan of Jane Austen. After viewing the film at the theatre, I was mystified - was this the same story? It seemed to venture very far from the book, which is my favorite and re-read many times. So when I saw it was coming out on DVD, I took it home and watched it again, with the same result.It wasn't until I turned on the Directors comments and heard his thoughts on the film that I understood what had happened. He obviously was looking at the story from his young, male point-of-view. In his comments I saw him repeatedly misunderstand the points of the story.I think the first issue I have with the film is it's lack of elegance. I have nothing against farms, but this was an Estate with a farm in the book. It set an uncomfortable tone for the Bennetts and made them much less genteel. How could young ladies with this up-bringing even get the attention of "Gentlemen", much less marry them? (As looked at from Jane Austen's time.)However, I must say that as a film without the historical context in mind, I thought the actors were very good and captured their characters superbly. The filming was excellent, with wonderful scenery and moody scenes with dark colors. And after that misty morning scene of Elizabeth and Darcy, I give kudos to the Director as well!Would I recommend it? YES!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It is definitely the most romantic film i have seen in a long long time.  A well directed film with stunning sets and locales.Keira knightly looks much beautiful than in the movie but her style and acting captivates the audience.Its a great movie for a nice rainy day.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: **** 3.5 Stars ****How to begin?I bought this movie because I truly enjoyed the novel, and then had the opportunity to purchase the BBC Production, which was beautifully told, and I thought, I have to see how they handle this in a very short (comparatively speaking) 2+ hour movie....As I watched the movie, I began to contemplate it in comparison with the great piece of literature that it is based upon, and found many discrepancies, and liberties taken....  And as I progressed through the movie, I had to keep reminding myself that it is not the retelling from the book, but rather an adaptation.However, even with that in mind, there were things I had a hard time looking past - most importantly, almost every characater, with the possible exception of Elizabeth and Darcy, were caricatures of their literary selves, everything they said and did appeared so (at times) over the top....As others have mentioned, there was definitely a more modern approach to propriety (i.e. Bingley entering the sick room, Lizzy and Darcy speaking in the morning hours in their bedclothes, Lady Catherine's night time visit, the various members of the Bennet family constantly eavesdropping whenever they can in such an uncircumspect manner, characters addressing each other by their Christian names, sleeveless dresses, etc.)With the costuming, and some of the locations, there were times where I felt like I was in Colonial America and not Regency England, and the actors definitely appeared less genteel than they were intended to appear in the book....The movie can be at times very melodramatic (think of the carriage ride back to Longbourn with Aunt and Uncle Gardiner and how dark and depressing it is outside - amazing how it suits her feelings... but is it really necessary?). And, can ANYBODY tell me what was up with that tree that Lizzy, her Aunt and Uncle Gardiner stopped at to rest while the carriage was being worked on prior to going to Pemberly?Having thus laid out some of my obstacles with this movie, I have to say that as an ADAPTATION from the novel, it does have its own merit...  The acting is great for the way the screenplay was written, and some of the creative things that were done, like the scene of Bingley interacting with Darcy to 'rehearse' his proposal to Jane, were fun to watch, even if it didn't 'agree' with the book.I encourage all to watch this with the full knowledge that it is MERELY AN ADAPTATION of the novel, not a retelling.... It is much easier to appreciate this as its own story, separate from the book and the BBC production of 1995.  Indeed, once I got past trying to compare it with either the book or the aforementioned BBC production, it was fun and enjoyable to watch!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie, its the best Romance movie of all times, better than any romance movie I have seen by far. Both character played by Kaira & Matthew did an excellent job, chemistry seems realisting!!!Definitely a must, I seen this movie so many times, and it gets better.
summary: Excellent Movie - Best Romance Movie of All Times

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: We absolutely love this film! It is positive and heat-warming, with a good message. Amazing acting done by Kiera Knightly! One of the best movies I've seen in a long time!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Matthew Mcfadyen's work, all of it, and I think that Keira Knightly is a fabulous actress thus I was prepared to rank this version of Pride and Prejudice with the outstanding and pitch perfect Sense and Sensibility with Emma Thomas.I was sorely let down.  I did not like 1995's version of Pride and Prejudice with Ehle and Firth because I felt it too shrill, and after a while Ehle's exaggerated facial expressions became annoying. I felt that the actors whom she was laughing at or thinking about had to be in a coma not to notice them.Having said that I watched this version twice and still I could not get past the lack of chemistry between the two leads, and the camera movements which were dizzying.  The first dance sequence, the swing sequence in the farm yard, the soldiers marching through town, I felt that something was always moving in front of the actors obscuring them, and that the eye was constantly trying to find them in the picture.When Tom Hollander showed up at the front door here was yet another scene where half an actor's face was cut off until he moves to the left.  A camera angle stolen right from Polanski's Rosemary's Baby.  Finally I felt it all too forced - especially the endless giggling and laughter.I did love Dame Judy Dench who was severe and the cinematography and locations were outstanding which makes this purchase worth while at the current price.  The Blu Ray picture is beautiful.  The Blacks are rich and showing good detail even in Dench's dark estate.  The special features about the homes and locations are very intersting.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this story, but I have never seen it so badly portrayed.  Over half the dialogue was left out, and with it much of the plot.  If I hadn't known the story so well, I wouldn't have known what was going on half the time.  There was almost no character development, and all the wonderful wit and dry humor was either left out or played completely deadpan, as if either the director or the actors didn't understand what was being said.Don't waste your time with this one -- get the BBC or PBS versions instead.  Both were far superior.

title: Pride & Prejudice

We both have a problem with the smoke and I was disappointed that it would be shipped out like that.  The actual DVD plays ok, but the packaging was very poor on this item.  Ellen Peacock

title: Pride & Prejudice
