title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love love love this movie! I would say it's the best version of Pride and Prejudice out there! You won't be disappointed.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am in the minority here and have not seen the Colin Firth version. (I suppose I will have to soon after reading several good reviews)  I am addicted to watching this movieand have seen it so many times that I cannot imagine anyone else but Matthew MacFadyen in the roll for Mr. Darcy and Keira Knightley as Elizabeth.  Matthew MacFadyen is very hot!! I could just feel and see the passion he had for Lizzie.  The scene when it was raining and Mr. Darcy was expressing his love and Elizabeth was rejecting him.  Mr. Darcy looked so hurt - yet you could tell he wanted to kiss her.  And also at the end of the film when they were kneeling and he kisses Lizzie several times calling her "Mrs. Darcy"....his voice is so deep, his kisses were so gentle, so sweet...I wish I could trade places with Lizzie!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie shows little comprehension of the book, the time, or the author.The director thought he could be edgy by making everyone seem dirty. Since Rob Roy and Braveheart, directors think they can make movies seem more historically accurate by showing filthy living conditions. This is Jane Austen. She writes about landed gentry in 19th century England, the motherland of domestic comfort, baths, and little scented soaps. The "people that don't live in the modern western world are dirty" concept is trite, inaccurate, and overdone.Major alterations are made to Austen's original characters.-Mary is given some of Elizabeth's lines, putting a spotlight on her character that was never intended.-The marital problems between Mr. and Mrs. Bennet are glossed over. There is even a scene where they chat in bed. That they are a horrible match is very important to Elizabeth's ideas of matrimony.- Mr. Bennet is shown as an all around good father who shows no preference to Elizabeth. He even hugs Mary after her embarassing piano performance.There are plenty of other problems. It is a pretty film, but in the way that a Bronte movie should be filmed, dark and gothic. Keira Knightly's portrayal of Elizabeth contains way too much Keira Knightly, Lydia is badly done, Mrs. Bennet is underdone, Mr. Darcy is awful. The best casting is Jane's character and Caroline Bingley.In conclusion, if you like the book, don't watch this. Spend the extra time with the 1995 BBC version.
summary: Shows no Respect to Jane Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Finally watched it after all these years. I loved the BBC version. Colin Firth was spectacular, but Matthew MacFadyen brought a whole new side to Mr. Darcy. Firth was every bit the Master - noble, aristocratic, confident & snooty. MacFadyen was awkward and shy. If a new version of P&P; came along, I would love to see Colin Firth's Mr. Darcy mixed with a heavy dose of MacFayden (except for the coiffure......he was worth ten thousand a year and yet he could not afford some hair gel and a comb). MacFadyen showed Mr. Darcy's struggling emotions better (and he looked good in a beaver hat and on a horse).The 2005 version strayed from canon, but it brought in some great romantic scenes: the double-take at the assembly; the sideways glance; the hand touch; the wild horse ride; the second proposal.KK was striking in the part, but BBC's more mature Lizzy was a better fit. Much of the character development was left on the cutting room floor due to time constraints, which made Lizzy's first rejection seem puzzling. How did she work up so much animosity toward Darcy? In the BBC version, there was no question why Lizzy was in a lather by the time he proposed.Overall, it was a good adaptation. I have not moved from Team Firth to Team MacFadyen-yet, but I my loyalty is wavering!
summary: I'm Torn....Team Firth or Team MacFadyen???

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautifully shot, acted, interpreted, scored, edited and nuanced.  The actors are superb and wholly alive within this screen adaption of an Austen favorite; of course, some changes were made from her book to the big screen ,they are rather slight and personally acceptable to disgard--only the scene in which Elizabeth takes to walking the park when visiting Charlotte and happens upon Darcy really should have stayed in the movie since its a huge clue to how Darcy as well as Elizabeth truly feel for each other and are attempting to show to one another, without this scene the movie remains ambiguous if you don't pay really close attention to every subtle look, gesture and tone the characters exhibit.  Besides that though it remains an excellent story to lose oneself in.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: "Are you laughing at me....are you REJECTING me?"  Nice to have on the fire because you jump to the best scenes of the movie: Mr. Darcy writing a letter, Mr. Darcy and Lizzie dancing, Lizzie's night at Mr. Darcy's aunt... and then, wait for it... the rain scene (awesome), and then Lizzie getting caught sneaking around Pemberley, and finally the wonderful fog scene.I think you can see that, on the fire, this movie can be watched many many times very very quickly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Over the years Hollywood has produced innumerable romantic comedies in which two people, obviously attracted to (and perfect for) one another, are kept apart by circumstances for a couple of hours until the artificial barriers between them are torn down and they wind up in each other's arms. Most of them have been terrible, but British director Joe Wright's new version of the Jane Austen tale which is the granddaddy of them all proves that if you only return to the source, and treat it if not with absolute fidelity at least with respect, the experience can be delightful. This is a lively, colorful, intelligent retelling of the template for all the later books and movies about two people obviously destined to be together who remain apart all too long due to misunderstandings and the machinations of others. Its sensibility is more modern than Austen's, of course, but that doesn't mean it's any less enjoyable on its own.At just a bit over two hours, this "Pride and Prejudice" can't include as much of the detail of Austen's original as the well-regarded five-hour BBC mini-series of 1995, which starred Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. But in Deborah Moggach's skillful adaptation it contains enough to convey the flavor of the book, as well as the basic plot, very successfully, though the tone is more overtly romantic; in this respect it's certainly the equal of the famous 1940 film with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier. And Wright proves remarkably adept at infusing the action not only with the serenity and charm it needs, but with lightness and vivacity as well, an effect achieved especially by his penchant for fast-moving tracking shots, beautifully managed by cinematographer Roman Osin. Osin's luscious widescreen images have the benefit of focusing on lovely locations and utterly convincing period accouterments; the production design by Sarah Greenwood, art direction by Ian Baille, Mark Swain and Nick Gottschalk, set decoration by Katie Spencer and costumes by Jacqueline Durran are all superb. One could spend one's time just luxuriating in the visual splendor on the screen, made even happier by Dario Marianelli's pleasantly evocative score.But the meat of the story is in the characters, of course, and here too the film proves outstanding. Keira Knightley makes ample amends for her dreadful performance in "Domino" by portraying the strong-willed, level-headed Elizabeth Bennet as a young woman of both (dare one say it) spunk and an undercurrent of melancholy. Matthew Macfadyen, happily not a conventionally handsome sort, matches her by capturing Darcy's aristocratic demeanor and his inner conflict nicely. Together they make a couple that emphasizes the youthfulness and relative inexperience of Austen's creations far more than was the case in any of the previous filmizations--which makes the tale not only more credible but somehow more poignant. Their excellence doesn't stand alone; the supporting cast is superb, too, with Donald Sutherland wonderfully unruffled and sardonic as the put-upon Mr. Bennet and Brenda Blethyn keeping his wife--an unsophisticated woman obsessed with finding husbands for her many daughters, and a character that can easily become an irritation--within bounds. Rosamund Pike and Simon Woods make an appealing pair as the secondary couple in the mix, Elizabeth's easily-hurt elder sister Jane and Darcy's more ebullient friend Bingley, and Jena Malone is suitably flighty as the immature Lydia, whose infatuation with the handsome but unreliable Wickham (an appropriately smooth Rupert Friend) causes not only a Bennet family crisis but an opportunity that in time will lead to the resolution of the Elizabeth-Darcy impasse. If one can raise any qualifications about the casting, they'd have to concern Tom Hollander, who gives the stiff, obsequious Collins more of a conventionally comic tone than some might wish, and Judi Dench, whose Lady de Bourgh might seem too much the usual intrusive cameo (and whose final scene isn't ideally staged). But you easily become acclimated to them, and in the end they fit Wright's conception.In fact, when looked at as a whole, there's something just a bit miraculous about how enjoyable Wright's film is. "Pride and Prejudice" may be the same old story about finding Mr. Right, but this movie shows that if your take on the familiar tale is sufficiently deft, it can be as fresh and enchanting as Austen's book itself must have been in 1813.
summary: "Sometimes the last person on earth you want to be with is the one person you can't be without."

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my favorite favorite FAVORITE movie!! It is an amazing adaptation to the original novel. I think it's hard to appreciate the movie if you haven't read the book though. Considering how they had to squeeze a 60+ chapter story into about 2 hours, it's really an amazing movie. The story and plot of the original movie is quite deep and rich so if you haven't read the book it might be a bit hard to understand the movie especially the first time through. Anyone who wants to truly appreciate this movie should definitely consider reading the book if you haven't already.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Really true to Jane Austin.  The actors are all first rate.  The cinematography is excellent.Keira Knightley, Matthew Macfadyen, Brenda Blethyn, Donald Sutherland, Tom Hollander, Rosamund Pike, Jena MaloneJudi Dench do fine jobs.  Donald Sutherland is particulary on target with Dad Bennet.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Joe Wright has done a wonderful job creating these vivid characters in the big screen from the book Pride and Prejudice. Every element of the story was conveyed in an artistic way with foremost respect to the integrity of the original piece. The eloquent portrayal of the story of Mr. Bingley, Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy was complemented with an excellent soundtrack, which served as the motif throughout the entire picture. Joe Wright perspicacious vision of this film has propagated a work of art that culminates this romantic love story in the most inspiring manner.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Many people didn't like this because it wasn't truly a "real" Pride & Prejudice remake, and because it really wasn't "period".I personally liked its airy, lighthearted feel. Extremely easy to follow and it isn't filled with things that shouldn't be there. It is perfectly shot.It is the only version of Pride & Prejudice I like enough to where I don't have to fast forward through parts I don't like. I like it in its entirety and while Keira Knightley was, MAYBE, miscast, I adored Rosamund Pike (Jane). Maybe she would have made a better Elizabeth. I don't know.I also liked Matthew Macfadyen in the role of Mr. Darcy. Of course, I know him better from MI-5, but I was able to put that role aside. He played Mr. Darcy very well. I liked him a lot.I do believe that Jenna Malone's (Lydia) "British accent" was a very bad one. She was definitely miscast in this role.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen many adaptations of Pride and Prejudice.  One in particular I am very fond of, so, I was ready not to like this version.  However, it captivated me and I loved the realism they took great pains to bring to the story.  Acting was excellent.  Cast choice, spot on.  I'm ashamed to say, I have watched it multiple times.  in one word........ Classic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I watched it when it came out in theaters and I just had to own the DVD. This version is perfectly cast. Keira(Lizzie), in this film, is not so drop dead gorgeous that nobody can see themselves in her (she's flat chested for one). And Matthew as Darcy is smolderingly hot. They captured the subtlety and nuances that a lot of romantic movies now no longer have and yet the same subtlety is what grips you, just like the book. The chemistry played in the film reminded me of first love (or infatuation) or an illicit affair.A lot of friends(fans of the book) hesitated watching the film as they didn't want the film character to ruin the image of Mr. Darcy they had in their heads. Ladies, Mcfadyen doesn't disappoint. He enhances it.He is still Darcy, yet hot hot hot. He made Darcy smolder. His acting is superb. Stiff upper lip but his eyes spoke volumes. Soulful, even. It smoldered, looked away, and light up with happiness that he couldn't help. And there were times that he looked like he was visibly swallowing eventhough you couldn't see it as his throat was covered with a cravat. And he managed to convey that he was aware of everything eventhough he wasn't even looking. Doesn't that sound like us, when we're holding ourselves back?And Keira as Lizzie, was wonderfully refreshing. Even people who haven't read the book could tell that she couldn't help herself, she was attracted to Darcy. Love could be mistaken for loathing. Throughout the film, she never said she liked him, except towards the end, yet both actors managed to play the characters as being extremely aware of each other. Isn't that how we feel, when the person we are so passionately attracted to walks into the room, we know it even without looking? That's how the film is. Perfect.The supporting cast was equally superb. Dame Dench, as Lady Catherine, can swallow you whole. Jenna was absurd and annoying (as she should be), I fast-forward her.The scenery is breathtaking. And there's always something going on in all corners of the screen, most notably, the ball scenes and the maid singing as she walked through the house.Overall, this film is delightful. Pemberly took my breath away as it did Keira Knightly. And Mcfadyen as Darcy, soaking wet and hurt? Wow. And check out the scene as he was coming out with the dawn of the sun behind him...morning dew, long coat and open shirt...wow wow. I'm in love again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie! It has just enough romantic air, humor, troublesome twists and drama to keep me on the edge of my seat! I first rented this movie, and then knew I had to buy it. While very few of my friends and family are as crazy about it as I am- I still watch it, even if by myself.

Amazing vocabulary, amazing actors and actresses, and amazing scenes.  A great family movie!!!  I bought this movie the moment it was released. I have watched it several times since them, I think it will be a timeless classic! I highly recommend that you buy this movie, you won't regret it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride & Prejudice: Two MoviesJane Austen's novel, Pride & Prejudice, is set in rural, early nineteenth century England. It centers around Elizabeth Bennet, fun-loving and analytical, the second daughter of five. Though her family lives in what today seems a mansion, and her father is a gentleman, they are considered poor in the society in which they live. Mrs. Bennet thinks of little else than having her daughters married to the finest and richest men that she contrives to know of and meet. When two such men (jovial and friendly Mr. Bingly, and distant and proud Mr. Darcy) enter the community, the Bennet household is sent into an uproar of chatter and anticipation. Pride and prejudice on both sides, however, threaten to spoil the blossoming prospects.One adaptation of the classic was made in 1995, by A&E; and the BBC, with Colin Firth (as Mr. Darcy) and Jennifer Ehle (as Elizabeth Bennet). In this version, the photography is on a grand scale, with picturesque scenery. Many of the lines leap from the pages of the book, the story and it's messages are accurately depicted, and the acting is superb. Also not to be forgotten, is the beautiful, sometimes lively, sometimes serene, musical score, which sweeps the viewer into its mood.Taking a more modern approach, the 2005 adaptation (the one on this page) casts Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy, and Keira Knightly as Elizabeth Bennet. It also stars Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourg, aunt of Mr. Darcy. The photographic angles in this version were contemporary, as opposed to the traditional drawing room style of the BBC. This version takes much more liberty with the customs and propriety of the times (i.e. characters walking miles through the countryside in their nightclothes, or bursting into rooms with no announcement). All of the actors had big shoes to fill, but Knightly, Macfadyen, and Dench did a good job at casting new, and well-executed light on their characters (where the script allowed for it). Most of the other actors/characters, however, I don't think filled those shoes hardly at all. The costumes, music, and sets in this were all much shabbier than those in the 1995 version. I think this script would be difficult for a newcomer to the story to follow, especially regarding introduction of characters. Also, in trying to make the script different from other versions, the characters simply changed their minds, instead of growing and learning throughout the narrative, and the lessons of the story were lost for the most part.All this said, I prefer the 1995 adaptation, because: it adheres to the story and times; the music, landscape, and costumes are elegant; the acting (in my opinion) is superior.Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was extremely disappointed when I got this movie because the packaging was different than I was expecting. In the reviews a customer wrote that the cover was made to look like a book and that there was a booklet inside with pictures and that it came with the soundtrack. After ordering this movie and expecting it to look the way the customer described it, I was really disappointed. After I got the movie I went on Amazon to see if I got the wrong one, but apparently the customer was reviewing a different collectors edition. I only wish that the review would be showing for that specific item that they actually purchased, whether it be like the one the customer described or the one that I bought and it wasn't the one the review was written about. I still absolutely love this movie and I will watch it over and over. But if you're like me and are expecting it to look like a book and come with a booklet inside and the soundtrack, then you will be disappointed. Not in the movie, but in the packaging.
summary: Love the movie, but disappointed in the packaging.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: How would the teens of Dawson's Creek or the recent Juno speak like if they were English in the year 1797?  Look no further than Pride and Prejudice, one of the greatest love stories ever told and the original template for essentially every modern chick-flick or romantic comedy to come henceforth.At first I thought the movie was rather talky and somewhat boring, but the more i watched and the more I paid attention, I started to realize that this is one of the most engaging and accurately lavish English period pieces I have ever seen before.But it is not for everyone.  Certainly notsomuch as Atonement is for more general audiences or more easily digestible.  This film requires a more expert level of movie watching/comprehension and a certain degree of literary aptitude.  It begs for, nay demands the viewers active participation, involvement, and a certain commitment of attention more novice pieces would dare not request.  And by literary aptitude I don't necessarily mean the source novel as much as I mean Shakespeare.  The characters relate and converse in a pseudo-Shakespearean manner minus the iambic pentameter.  If you cannot keep up with all of the double entendras, doublespeak, subliminal messages and the like you will likely have a difficult time appreciating the genius of this screenplay written by Deborah Moggach.The complicated relationships and plot are also like a Shakespearan comedy (all though at times feels like a tragedy) and it is very easy to get left behind if you are not of to task.  This is why I enjoyed the movie so much.  You need to pay full attention to fully appreciate this work of art.  Visually there were many hidden cues like actors' not-always-so-obvious facial expressions as well as unspoken hints from the brilliant, however also purposeful wardrobe and costume design.  It's very difficult to explain in a simple way, but I simply love this director's work; Joe Wright is stupid genius!What a guilty pleasure for a moviephille for me to watch.And let us not even mention the name Keira Knightley.  This is the film that finally put her on the map as a serious actress to be reckoned with and not just another pretty face.  She thoroughly shines throughout as the star and primary protagonist of the movie.Director Joe Wright's second motion picture 'Atonement' was extrmely good, a modern classic in its own right, but it was not exactly a happy story.  It did not make me smile inside as the subtle and not-so-subtle humor like P&P; did.  This one was more a romp that leaves one giddy so giddyup!note:  This was my first treatment of P&P.;  I never saw any other version or read the book, but now I have decided to gobble up all of Jane Austen's other famous works and find myself feverishly awaiting Joe Wright's forthcoming film 'The Soloist'My Addendum:I have been perusing the 1 star reviews that are speckeled among the many praising and applauding reviews of this movie and I just wanted to say something to address those naysayers.  First of all, I think you all have lost much prospective and are waging your 1 star rating for hyperbolic effect.  And second, if all of you who loathed this adaptation were in charge of all other adaptations in Hollywood, movies would just plain suck and not really be viable or marketable at all.  Thank goodness this is not the state of things.  It is more palatable movies such as this that satisfy the masses that draw in new viewers to your precious A&E;/BBC version or bring in new readers to the original novel.  Is that such a horrible thing?  I swear so many rabid Austen fans think P&P; was written only for them and belongs to them and if it isn't the approved 1995 edition of the miniseries, well then thee be damned.  Chill out already and stop trying to ruin it for the rest of us.  You should all be thanking the director Joe Wright because thanks to him (eventually) more people in the world will get to know who the heck Colin Firth even is!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Superb casting, outstanding scenery, well designed period settings and a brilliantly written novel by Jane Austen comes to life making this a block buster winner and one of the hottest films this season. The film is likely to garner several well deserved Academy Awards ... I love the realistic country scenes and the opulent wealth of the era as depicted in this film. Keira Knightly is charming and dazzling as the intelligent and articulate Lizzie who is transformed within this film, becoming the butterfly that arises from her unique chrysallis. Matthew MacFadyen is the perfect Mr. Darcy, a darkly handsome introspective, intelligent gentleman ... who is easily misunderstood.Keira Knightly is an outstandng Elizabeth (Lizzie) Bennett, with her well chiseled lovely porcelain facial features, beautiful large brown expressive eyes, lovely swan-like neck and gorgeous brown hair, often worn pulled up and back, with tendrils framing her face. Her clever articulate observations and quips are very memorable throughout the film as she challenges the quietly brooding and handsome Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen). One memorable scene is when the guests of honor, Mr. Bingley, his sister and Mr. Darcy arrive in the ballroom, the dancing and music stop as the people part to each side, like a zipper being unzipped. Mr. Bingley happily joins in the dancing and socializing but both Miss Bingley and Mr. Darcy remain aloof, quietly commenting on the differences between living in the city and country. It is quite obvious they feel  superior compared to the locals. Mr. Bingley laughs and smiles as he dances with Miss Jane Bennett (Rosamund Pike). Her mother, Mrs. Bennett (Brenda Blethyn,) is delighted by this good fortune. She is actively seeking a husband for Jane who is of marriagable age and the eldest daughter of five.During an intermission Lizzie over hears Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy discussing Jane and herself. Mr Darcy describes Lizzie as "tolerable" but essentially not his type. This phrase will eventually come to haunt him, as Lizzie repeats it to him  later during an encounter. Based on this event, she develops preconceived notions about Mr. Darcy's character and manners. She makes no secret of her feelings about him to her family.Jane pays a social visit to the Bingley's country mansion and becomes ill, requiring her to stay as an overnight guest for several days until she recovers. Mr. Bingley can not hide his joy at having such a pretty and desirable house guest. Lizzie visits her sister during the illness and encounters Mr. Darcy and Miss Bingley. She engages Mr. Darcy in several verbal duels and cleverly exchanges challenging words, demonstrating superior skill and prowess in the intellectual game of quoting poetry and verse. Both Keira Knightly and Matthew MacFadyen perfom their roles superbly ...While Mr. Bingley was falling in love with Jane and quietly making his feelings known, his sister suddenly closed the manor house and persuaded him and her entourage to return to London. It is obvious she wanted to sever the budding relationship between her brother and Jane, before it became serious. Essentially, Miss Jane Bennett was viewed as a social inferior. About this time, the Reverend Mr. Collins came calling on the Bennetts, with the intention of marrying one of the daughters. He lived on an estate owned by Lady Catherine, who required him to find a wife before she would finance a parsonage and church for him. Lizzie captured his attention but she outright rejected his proposal. Following this refusal, Mr. Collins offered marriage to Charlotte their young housekeeper, who accepted him. Lizzie could not understand why Charlotte would marry Mr. Collins until the realities of Charlotte's situation sunk in. Charlotte explained he had a stable profession and provided her a home which was a major improvement from her current situation. Lizzie slowly awakened into adulthood, recognizing many unpleasant facts of life. The scenes went from comedy to almost tragedy as different events unfolded in the lives of the Bennett family. The importance of social position and wealth in selecting a life partner was clear and evident.It never dawned on the Bennett's that the sudden departure of the Bingley's was meant as a snub, a refusal of Miss Jane Bennett as a fiance. The Bennetts had high hopes of relighting the match and sent Jane to visit an Aunt in London in hopes of meeting Mr. Bingley. About this time, Lizzie was visiting Brighton with her relatives when she took a tour of Mr. Darcy's residence which was open for public viewing. She met him unexpectedly in the garden and received a declaration of love which took her completely by surprise. She immediately dismissed it and rejected him ...Jane returned from London without having established any social connection with Mr. Bingley. Lizzie returned from Brighton, in an unusual emotional state, a totally confused frame of mind. Unknown to herself, she was battling unresolved feelings for Mr. Darcy. A family crisis arose when Lydia, the middle daughter, had run away with a soldier. This scandal would ruin the Bennett's chances for marrying off Jane and Lizzie to good families. Help came from an unexpected source: Mr. Darcy had known this soldier in the past. Mr. Darcy's father had treated the soldier nearly like a son. Due to nearly similar circumstances involving Mr. Darcy's sister Georgiana, he rescued Lydia from her shameful situation by setting them up finanacially and ensuring Lydia married her soldier. When Lizzie heard of this matter, she remained in a deep quagmire for having rejected his overtures of love, she was awakening to the true nature of his character and discovered herself attracted to him. The resolution to Lizzie's emotional conflict and the rematch between Jane and Mr. Bingley is what makes the book and this film so popular. Jane Austen's classical writing via this new film adaptation provides a creative twist to the eternal conundrum which young ladies and young gentlemen of every era and generation must face and resolve anew for themselves.Erika Borsos (erikab93)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off, I am a huge Jane Austen fan. I love this story but I didn't love this movie. If you haven't seen this movie, let me just warn you that this film strays from the book a lot. For instance...Darcy's aunt comes storming into the Lizzy's home in the middle of the night. Or the fact that Elizabeth runs outside in her nightgown...and who does she happen to come across but Mr. Darcy! And the ending? That was creative license if ever I saw it.This actually leads me to the reason why I really didn't like this film. Everything was so rushed and obvious. When you watch the film, you'll notice there's a scene when Darcy helps her into a carriage and then they get a close up on his hand clenching. Then there are scenes when they look at eachother longingly. There was no mention of him beginning to like her "fine eyes" The way the film depicts the romance between the two wasn't special. I always loved the book because of the differences the two must overcome to finally see eachother as their ultimate love. To me it seemed like the screenwriter knew the audience would want the two characters to end up together so they didn't put in all the details that make the story special.If you liked the A&E; version, you may not appreciate this adaption because they really do change things up. Scenes happen in different locations, a little dialogue has been added, the characters are depicted as really poor and shabby which in my opinion kind of took away from the magic of the story. Needless to say I wasn't happy with this version. The only thing I DID like about this film was when he finally asks her to marry him, her response was I imagined it to be because it was romantic (unlike the A&E; version where they just keep on taking their walk together).P.S. If you do decide to buy this dvd make sure you get the widescreen. I viewed the fullscreen and there were several scenes where the characters were so far away from eachother that you would hear them talking but could only see the blue sky between them on the tv.
summary: This would have been GREAT...If I hadn't read the book :(

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I went with a crowd to see this movie, in part because the other theatres were sold out. I had heard several negative comments, mostly by my British friends, and wasn't keen on seeing it.Overall, it was an enjoyable movie, but not a classic, and certainly nothing on the scale of the 1995 BBC series which I was forced to watch once or twice (it is very long).People are correct when they say that the 2005 version failed to capture the essence of Jane Austen's society. The British, living closer to history than the Americans do, were justifiable in their lukewarm reaction. Too much 21st century sensibilities were injected into 1810 or whatever the year of the story, and if you are a history buff, as I am, it can be annoying to see modern thoughts and behavior presented with regency costumes. The behavior of the Bennet family and the society at the ball in the movie would have mortified the original characters in Jane Austen's day. The ball scene, with people behaving more like country bumpkins and farmers rather than the class conscious, manners obsessive, landed gentry they actually were, was unrealistic. And even an impoverished family of any pretensions (as the Bennets were portrayed to us in this version) would not have had pigs running around just outside the back door, let alone walking through the front hall of the house. It was also a bit unfair to portray Mrs. Bennet as a boorish drunkard.As it stands, a major reason many people love Austen's work is the portrayal of a society and its mores that have long since disappeared, a society where everything one said or did was carefully examined, analyzed, and criticized by its members, and the obsession with "gentle" values and "gentle" behavior was paramount. The 1995 BBC version very much caught the essence of that society along with the portrayal of the love story, which is why it has become a classic. Emma Thompson's Sense and Sensibility also does an excellent job in capturing the feel of the period.Still, ignoring the flaws and the director's failure to capture the essence of 18th/19th century society, the movie was a fun watch. Not remarkable, and certainly not a classic, but enjoyable. The 1995 BBC version, for very good reasons, will be the one to last the ages and be watched by people fifty years down the road, long after Keira Knightly has been forgotten.
summary: Ok movie, enjoyable but not faithful

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of the many versions of Pride & Prejudice you'll find on the market, but this is my favorite.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice is one of my favorite books, and I've reread it many times. This movie is not pure, pure Austen, but it's a nice widescreen version, with beautiful homes for the wealthy and more realistic settings for Elizabeth Bennet's family. Worth it. Just don't expect  the wit and charm of Jane Austen's heroine. It isn't there. K. Knightley is pretty and young, though. McFayden is, for course, for the women to admire.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my favorite version of Pride and Prejudice.  They did an excellent job picking out the actors for this film.  I adore the music and the scenes were so beautiful.  The book in itself is just wonderful but the way they brought it to life was just great.  This movie is a must have for anyone who loves period romance.  The dialog is so witty is just a classic.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've watched the 1995 A&E; version of Pride and Prejudice many times, and I never get tired of it, mainly because of Colin Firth, whom I adored in the part. Because of that, I put off for a very long time until just recently watching this version. First, I did not think the actors could possibly measure up and second, it is an abridged version, so a great deal of the story would inevitably be sacrificed. I had also heard about the infamous kiss at the end of this version.I am happy to report that I enjoyed this film for its own sake. Relatively short though it is, Macfadyen and Knightley offer a lovely take on the romance. They are both very attractive people who are young enough to be very near the actual ages of the characters, and their chemistry is wonderful. Macfadyen especially does a wonderful job with soulful, smouldering looks that suit Darcy perfectly.I highly recommend this wonderful version of P&P; to all Austen fans.
summary: It's not Colin Firth, but I loved it anyway

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Decent film but reinterprets Austen as though she'd actually approve of young people running in the rain, clothes clinging, hearts ruling heads. In all of her novels, reason and "sense" beat emotionality. Jane Austen would never have directed this film. If you like Knightley in period pieces, watch The Duchess. If you like Austen, watch the BBC Pride & Prejudice, Emma Thompson's Sense & Sensibility, or Roger Mitchell's Persuasion.

title: Pride & Prejudice

I enjoyed watching this film sooooooo much more than the other productions carrying the same title.  This one is definitely the VERY BEST!

Stick with the BBC Colin Firth version.I gave it three stars because the actor, Matthew Macfaden who plays Mr. Darcy is a favorite of mine from MI5, and The Pillars of the Earth.Pride and Prejudice (Full Screen) (2005)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I got this for my mom as a random gift just for fun, she absolutely loves this movie, she watches it way too often even before I got her it on DVD. If only we got a dollar for each time she watched it, we'd be millionaires.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've looked at this movie and simply fell in love with it.  I've also read many reviews by Austen fans as well and I agree that this version leaves a lot out of the book and you wish there was more.  However, people must remember that the 2005 version of P&P is like any other version 'an adaptation' and can't possibly be an exact replica.  This movie in itself is great.  If you want more than what this 2-hour version had to give you must read the book or check out another version but don't discredit this version altogether.  If you had $30,000,000 and had to shrink a book into a two hour story, obviously you'd have to leave scenes and in some cases entire characters out just to get on with the story.  I think Joe Wright got it right in that this was a story about Lizzy and Darcy and everything else had to take a back seat.  Love this version, look at it with an open mind.

Keira Knightley ( who is my fav actress) shines as Elizibeth Bennett.. and as I said I love Colin but I do prefer Matthew as Mr darcy.. the costumes , the music and the cinematography are top nothch.. visually beautiful ..a must own for Austen and just movie in general fans... still my number one even 8 years later.. buy it
