title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a well-done movie, pretty much all around. In the beginning, it was a little slow, but as it went on it got better. I loved it in the end. I highly recommend for any and all who enjoy a good romance.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley is perfect as Elizabeth Bennet. Then again, I don't ever recall seeing Keira Knightley in any movie where she didn't become the part and make it her own. Matthew Macfadyen was absolutely amazing. I really didn't think anyone could top Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy, but somehow Matthew Macfadyen WAS Mr. Darcy, no doubt. Their chemistry was a perfect blend of annoyance and sparks, you were never quite sure what you would get. Rosamund Pike is perhaps one of the prettiest actors I can think of, and the most perfect Jane Bennet.Donald Sutherland & Brenda Blethyn were the perfect Mr. and Mrs Bennet. They too had a chemistry as husband and wife that was believable and loving.The best cast (IMHO) was Claudie Blakley as Charlotte Lucas. I think I liked her much better after seeing the movie. I have read the book a good maybe 25+ times (if not more) and seen the movies (both versions) many times.5 stars

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have to be honest, I didn't watch the whole thing -- why take a book that brilliantly portrays the foibles of the leisure class and turn it into a soap opera?This is the third movie made from the book.  Two of them are worth watching.  This is not one of the two.
summary: What happened to Pride and Prejudice?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although I do not consider myself a "finnicky" Austen purist, there is only so much irreverence I can take. If you want a good laugh - go see this. Although it's more likely you'll laugh AT it than with it. I realize they were extremely pressed for time, and in light of that I do give them some credit for what they tried to do. However.......My main quarrel is with Matthew Macfadyen as Mr. Darcy, who is wooden and awkward (and I don't compare him with Colin Firth - this is how he truly is without comparison)I read in a review that Mcfadyen did not read the book before they began shooting. What a mistake! Maybe if he had, he should have done more justice to the character and the movie.Secondly: Keira Knightly, who i'm afraid is just another pretty face. She cannot play Elizabeth, most of the movie she walks around with an artificial smile, and when in doubt, tries to play up Lizzy's vivacity by laughing, when nothing is really amusing. True, she was not so gratingly bad as Mr. Mcfadyen, but I think she too, missed the essence of the character.As for the rest of the Bennet clan, I think a former reviewer caught it very well: they are barnyard rustics living in a shabby house, where the daughters are seen baking - then later Mrs. bennet denies that her girls have anything to do in the kitchen! as for the other girls: Jane is lovely, but too shy. Lydia looks more like she should be playing Mary, and vice versa. Mr. Bennet is seen in the book as a sort of indolent country gentleman who is fond of books, in this version we see him taking an active role in the farm, and when he is in the house, trying vainly to be witty. Donald Sutherland was a bad choice.What is most disturbing to me though, is the closing scene, all fans of the book and the A&E; version will agree - this is weird, awkward, and completely uncalled for. What would Jane Austen think? I wonder.
summary: Tell me - is this for real?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Is  a beautiful love story  that I can see old over again. I see it every time it come in my cable.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wonderful!! Need I say more? I think that every girl that has watched the movie feels the same way as me: we def need to clone Mr. Darcys for all of us. I loved the movie and I think it was better than the Notebook by far. And I dont intend to offend those who liked the Notebook, I did like it also.The movie sticks to the book. When youre watching the movie its like youre reading the book. Most of the dialogues are exactly as in the book.I recommend the movie to everyone, especially those hopeless romantics out there. And I think guys should learn from Mr. Darcy. The movie shows sublime, real love and respect between Elizabeth and Darcy.Great movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley is a revelation here.  Watch her closely as she responds to Mr. Darcy's question about encouraging affection... amazing!  Her youth and vivacity give us as passionate an Elizabeth as Jennifer Ehle's grace and intelligence did in 1995.  Meanwhile, Matthew MacFadyen is just so much more manly and plays a more layered Darcy than Colin Firth - proud, brooding, conflicted, honorable, but also awkwardly unglued in front of Elizabeth.  And he does it ever so subtly - just a twitch of his lips, a blink of his eyes.  With his rugged good looks, strong built, and that voice... there is no need for a wet shirt scene to make women and less manly men swoon!  (By the way, I shall never understand why some complain about the extra ending scene, when MacFadyen's bare calves are far more attractive than Firth's wet shirt.  I was too young in 1995, but did anyone complain about the lake scene then?  I rest my case.)I love the 1995 version, but only because of Ehle's performance.  As much as I think Firth is one of the best actors out there, his Darcy never did stir anything for me.  He seemed too cold, too detached, and (sorry) "not handsome enough to tempt me".  I just never pictured Darcy to look like him when I read the book. I didn't see any chemistry between the two  until much later in the story, when Elizabeth visits Pemberley.  Whereas, Knightley and MacFadyen's is electrifyingly oh-so-palpable from the first moment they lay eyes on each other!Throw in the wonderful supporting cast, beautiful locations, divine editing, and that battle scene in the rain... I'm in heaven!  Five starred, albeit one gripe:  As every P&P; fan shall agree, this blu-ray does NOT meet expectations in the EXTRA FEATURES department.  We don't get the original goodies from the original DVD release: no P&P; Diaries (although the Politics of Dating is interesting).  But worst, worst, worst of all is that the highly anticipated deleted scenes are not included!!!!!  Mr. Wright, we shan't mind watching extra shots of bonnets and carriages!  I'm hoping -- nay, praying -- that they will issue a special edition at some point.  Why, I promise to pay whatever their price... if only they add the deleted scenes that we know exist!Lacking extra features it may be, the movie is still worth the blu-ray viewing.  The picture quality is very very good.  Gone is the fuzzy focus of the DVD - you could actually see lint off Knightley's shoulder and the pup at Caroline Bingley's feet (missed that one on the DVD).  If you have the DVD, donate it to some worthy cause, and pick up the blu-ray.  Pop some corn and enjoy!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Absolutely NO humor. I can't be Jane Austen without her wit. This film lacked any chemistry at all between the family and that is the foundation upon which an Austen novel is built. Lizzie & Jane barely spoke, the father (played by Sutherland) was dull and lackluster. Keira Knightly's hair was absolutely ugly with those always wet-looking bangs. It was a ghastly take on Pride & Prejudice. The scenery was gratuitous, there were contrived silences that only interrupted the cadence of the plot, and there was just nothing to write home about in this film.Keira Knightly's portrayel of Lizzie Bennet was too strong, that jutting chin and too-fighting glance was all wrong for the character. Lizzie has more grace, tact, class, and love for her family. YUCK!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I read somewhere recently that the directors/producers of this version made some intentional decisions to do unnecessary things like lowering the financial status of the Bennets to near-poverty, changing some of the dialog to sound more modern and reflective of (their own shallow experience with) teenaged girls, and changing the timeframe entirely because the director "didn't like" the fashions of the time in which Austen set her original novel. They apparently wanted this version to appeal more to a younger audience. Thus, along with the issues mentioned above, you will also find faster cuts and dialog, scenes in which the characters do things that would be completely unacceptable for the time (Lizzie with her hair completely down, or Darcy walking across fields with his shirt flapping open), and some very strange behavior from the family (Jane allowing a man in her room while she is in her nightdress). Not to mention the blatant attempt to infer sexual innuendo where there simply isn't any. (Seriously? That shot of the pig's...um...boy parts? Lizzie making a very vulgar check of Wickham's rear? ...Was the director influenced by a 13 year old boy?)Knightly's portrayal bugged me more than a little. I couldn't figure out what she was giggling at half the time, and the other half, the character was doing things blatantly out of character for Austen's heroine. I did, however, appreciate the fact that Mrs. Bennet is slightly more lovable in this version. The 1995 portrayal grates on the "nerves" and is way over done, but I thought this actress did a much more appropriate job of it.It is worth a look every once in a while, but if you want to see an adaptation that actually attempts to remain true to the story and the customs of the day (and not our narcissistic modern teenaged audience) then I, too, would recommend the Ehle/Firth BBC production.
summary: Meant to be a "teen" movie, and it succeeds

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My first impression  of Joe Wright's version was that it was barely tolerable...but decided it was probably worth a second viewing.Like Lizzie (aka Kiera K) how could I have been so blind?  The film is a masterpiece, blinded by my own prejudice of previous adaptations and the original novel. This version deserves, if not demands, a second viewing.  Keira Knightley is astounding.  Yes, she is more outwardly emotional than Austen's 18th century heroine and probably more beautiful from a 21st century perspective but  the essence of the youthful, wilful and independent Lizzie is just fantastic to watch. Oscar nomination rightly deserved -  Girl you was robbed!Joe Wright, the director, says he put his heart into this production, and OK I don't agree with all his casting decisions Donald S (mad professor with bad hairdo)and Tom Hollander, far too drippy,'sensitive'and to cap it all short which they play upon suggested by Hollander. In the book the odious Mr Collins is considered tall, well over 6ft and wonderfully pompous.  I like this so wish they hadn't changed him quite so much.However as a director, Joe Wright has created a truly beautiful, moving yet comic production.  The cinemaphotography and music further enhance the experience. For me this was only obvious on the second and subsequent viewings. It is a truly multi-layered production, as all good films should be and the opening dance scenes are so full of energy and life. Yes, there are discrepancies with the novel but you still want to be there!I know the Bennets look poverty-stricken but this helps re-inforce the differences in social standing between Lizzie and Darcy to a modern audience, in a way that the 1990 mini series and the 1980s more faithful versions can't convey.In the additional material I particularly love when the director says 'it's not about the most beautiful people in the room' because ironically it is! You can't get much more stunningly handsome couple as Keira Knightley and Mathew Macfadyen, but quite rightly so, because at the end of the day they can both act and 'the magnetism' is also there.The actors are all fantastic.  Brenda Blethyn superb, Rosamund Pike ethereal, Jenna Malone and Carey... silly and annoying but at 15 and 16/17? so they should be - great. Mary was far too beautiful but I give the director leave on this as our Mary gets such a raw deal usually. On the downside Bingley and the Gardiners were disappointing:When Lizzie says to Jane re Bingley,  'I give you leave to like him, you have liked far stupider a person.' I thought, Really? Is that possible!!! However, his gaucheness grows on you.The Gardiners are supposed to be the refined, elegant relations but here we get Penelope Wilton (who can look elegant) and her portly husband are continually munching pies! Can't find any redeeming features here...Not sure about the Titanicesque sequence on the cliffs as I always want to stand up and shout - LIZZIE DON'T DO IT!Inspite of these interpretations it's still a fantastic film with or without 2 endings.Overall I prefer the UK version ending (thank you Joe Wright and UK audiences) as it reflects the ending in the book and the author would have approved.At heart I am a true purist but it is fun to watch the syrupy yuky USA ending. Bare ankles, Divine Goddess!! My God - snogging! All that is missing in the USA ending was the dreaded wedding. I would like to think Jane would have approved but fear she would not. Will no doubt hopefully appeal to a younger generation though.  So, if that means more people will read and enjoy Jane Austen as much as I have over the years then what more can one ask for.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: !  Having seen "Pride&Prejudice"Many times before by various different actors ,including Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle(whom I adored)this version with lovely Keira Knightley and Matthew McFayden its sublime,she's the face of innocense,loveliness and beauty.McFayden plays the romantic hero to perfeccion.Miss Austen has once more given me inmense pleasure.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: To my suprise, in this adaptation of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice", besides Elizabeth Bennet, the most likable person, in my opinion is Mr. Darcy.  And, I'll say that it is definitively a wonderful surprise!  At last, after years of puzzlement I can see why Lizzie would fall in love with this guy.  Good work and thank you, Mr. Macfaden and Mr. Wright.
summary: Most likabke Mr. Darcy in the history

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I bought this widescreen DVD for my wife, who absolutely loves this movie. She has watched it on VHS many, many times, and knows almost every scene by heart. I looked forward to watching it with her on our home theater system consisting of a hi-def front projector displaying on a 96" diagonal screen, and a Dolby Digital 5.1 surround system using a Denon receiver and Definitive Tech speakers (BP2002 towers, CLR2002 center, BP2X surrounds and PF15 sub). Anyway, the audio quality is outstanding, as was expected. The music is a highlight of this film and I enjoy it immensely. However, my wife commented that the top and bottom of the image was cut off. I told her that this widescreen image was simply wider and she was mistaken, but she insisted that she was right, so she popped in her VHS tape and we compared identical scenes, and surprisingly, she was right. In one scene, the father is sitting in a chair and you could see his hands folded in his lap. In the DVD version, you can not see his hands at all. A minor detail for sure, but my wife says that she likes her version better. Oh well, I'm hoping that the hi-def version scheduled to be released in November will have the entire picture without any cropping. Other than that, I can recommend this movie as a lush, well told love story.
summary: Great "chick flick", but video is cropped

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not a big fan of these type of movies.  They are usually boring but well acted.  I liked this one alot.  It has alot of drama but still keeps a light tone about it.  Kiera Knightley does a great job in this film, (much better in my opinion than Reese Witherspoon did in Walk the Line).  It is sometimes hard to understand what they are saying because they speak so fast.  Although this movieis much shorter than the BBC 9 hour version it still packs a punch.  I would see it if i were you.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautiful scenery!  Classic story is always wonderful and Keira Knightley is perfect in the starring role. ( I just wish Colin Firth was Mr. Darcy in this film too)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A truly awful version of a wonderful novel,  that clings to thenotion (from the 80's maybe) that gritty is good.I think it would leave Miss Austen amused, bored, maybea little disgusted. I'm sorry, too, because I'm afraid a lotof people will get their idea of the sublime Pride and Prejudice fromthis oh so pedestrian, somewhat nasty movie.Ick!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My sister warned not to watch this version as it would only upset me and she was right. As it is, it's taken four attempts to get all the way through. I can understand the difficulties in turning a detailed book into a movie but surely you can remain true to the characters? Emma Thompson did it with style, an obvious love for the story and great actors. Jane has a following guaranteed to bring a crowd, and Hollywood took advantage. If you love BBC's version you'll hate this.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: what i like about this P&P; adaptation is that even if it departs quite liberally from the book, any liberties taken fit into this particular assembly of cast & different perspective taken by the film makers. it is the P&P; story told with lots of emotion which makes it very real. though initially dismayed by the shabbiness of the bennet household, the rustic grittiness of longbourn & its occupants grew on me. all of the characters are familiar yet they took on added personalities that, though not faithful to the book, are nevertheless fascinating, hilarious, endearing & so genuine. i got so drawn into the film like i was a part of it.i never really visualized lizzy as fierce & as giggly as keira's lizzy is but somehow knightley's youthful vitality works in the movie's context. macfadyen gives a fresh dimension to darcy. his soulful eyes & deep timbre of voice are so effective in matthew's darcy who, beneath the sullen & aloof exterior, is shy, vulnerable & so unsettled by his instant attraction to lizzy. you absolutely get that sense in matthew's boyish & understated performance. it is not the mature, reserved, confident darcy from the book but macfadyen makes his darcy work (i expect to see more films from this brilliant `spooks/perfect strangers' actor). above all, macfadyen & knightley have a wicked chemistry, with a youthful passion that just seem to fit right into the overall thread of the movie.with the fireworks lurking beneath the two protagonists, the movie certainly did not disappoint in delivering a tickle-me-pink finale. the misty dawn `proposal' scene & even the ridiculously romantic `american' ending gave this version a wishfully fulfilling end. so outrageously melodramatic but again, it feels right in this rendition.i think it was wise for the film makers of this P&P; to take the story into a different direction. i loved all previous adaptations but it's refreshing to see how a fresh spin on an enduring novel can still delight & entertain. i just simply adore this film.
summary: not pure austen ... but with dynamic young leads, great chemistry, gritty look

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It was just too youngly Hollywood. I understand that to make this into a big screen picture, they had to take a much longer work and condense it into a 2 hour and change length movie.  Wow, did the story line fly.  And it was a shame that the characters weren't developed more, particularly Mr. Bennet.  They had Mr. Bennet mumbling through most of the movie. Mr. Darcy seemed sulky, not snobby.  I also think Keira Knightly really tried too hard on her accent (and she's English!).What happened to the Hursts?  What was up with the Bennet's house - did anyone else notice that it looked really run down and messy?  Did the set hairdresser quit? And the clothes - the styles seemed inconsistient.I admit, I have seen the A&E; version (and hold it as the standard).  If you want to see an adaptation of P&P; that is made my people who truly loved the book, rent the A&E; version.  The characters are so much better developed, and they really picked excellent actors who really fit the role.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I thought this was going to be even better than the BBC version (which I love) it was horrible!!!!  I was speechless at the end .. and not in the good way! They left so many parts out and what was most annoying was the literally hated each other and the next minute they were madly in love ( I can only guess due to time constraints?) it was painful to watch. BBC's Pride & Prejudice with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle cannot be topped.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The high quality of this films production values and the stellar cast, help make this version of the beloved "Pride and Prejudice" a certified masterpiece.  The 1939 version, starring Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier, is still charming and holds that nostalgic class that practically all of the films of that period in time seem to hold.  However, Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden have taken this material to new heights.  I was glad for Reese Witherspoon's win at the Academy awards, for her portrayal of June Carter Cash  in "Walk The Line," was very well done.  But after having seen Keira Knightley's performance here in this enduring tale, I couldn't believe such an injustice could have been done.  This movie would not have flowed so beautifully without her.  I highly recommend "Pride & Prejudice," for it is one of those rare films that can both lift the spirits and challenge them to respond to life's ups and downs.  It is the `best winner" of 2006 in my book and holds a special place of honor in my dvd library.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw the new Pride & Prejudice last night, and just as I hoped it is soooooooooooo romantic! Somehow this movie also manages to be hilarious, but in an understated, un-American sort of way.Keira Knightly did an outstanding job of being her usual independent, outspoken, beautiful self in the part of Lizzy, she certainly re-defined the role from the A&E; version, a little less refined and more earthy.Matthew MacFayden did a fantastic job of minimizing Mr. Darcy's flaws to simply being shy. He hardly ever seems really pompous or prideful and is altogether quite adorable.Donald Southerland was Mr. Bennett and though I didn't like him quite as much as the father in the A&E; version he still did an outstanding job.One of the flaws in this movie is that everyone but Kiera Knightly is so plain! Even Jane (played by Rosamund Pike - isn't that a beautiful name?), who is my favorite character in the story, seemed like she was trying to look like the A&E; Jane. She was very sweet but also silly.The costumes are extremely well done, each character's wardrobe helps to further define his or her character - for instance moody Lizzy wears earth tones and sweet Jane wears pastels, Caroline Bingly wears fancy dresses made of rich looking material in much brighter colors and sleeker styles whereas the Bennetts wear simple dresses of rougher material.The cinematography is fantastic, there are several scenes that are just amazing, I'm thinking especially of the scenes after Lizzy has rejected Mr. Darcy, the mirror scene, the walking through the mist scene and the viewing the landscape scene. This movie was filmed at some wonderful locations and we are given a few moments here and there to enjoy it.Of course when turning a novel into a movie there has to be an enormous amount of editing, paring the book down into a manageable 2 hour long movie, so one or two characters have been cut out (I especially noticed Mr. Bingly's other sister & husband were missing) and others marginalized (Mr. Wickham's character especially) or under-developed (as in Mr. & Miss Bingly) but one would expect that. On the other hand there were some wonderful interpretations of scenes, especially during Mr. Darcy's proposals.There were also a couple of additional lines that were stuck in as sort of an explanation for modern viewers as to what's going on, like when Miss Lucas accepts Mr. Collins proposal or another time when Lizzy and Mrs. Bennett are together, talking about Lydia's upcoming marriage, Lizzy says "Is that (marriage) all you think about?" and Mrs. Bennett says to Lizzy "Wait until you have five daughters." It was quite comical.Thankfully, the movie remains pure and honorable. The flirts get themselves into awful trouble, the passive father receives his cupful of due shame, the aggressive silly mother, as silly as ever and never justified. The state of marriage is honored and physical affection between couples are, amazingly, kept sacred - they don't even kiss until after they are married! Marriage and family are honored, rather than belittled, and portrayed frankly but beautifully.On the whole, this movie is just lovely! My husnbad even watched it with me and enjoyed it. I am sure I will watch it over and over.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: One of the best books from the last century.  I also love the movie which is very close to the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: very pleased with this video;  I had seen the movie and I'm pleased to be able to see it at home

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Both my wife and I loved this movie very much.  She has watched it over 20 times.  I've watched it several times and I almost never do that!  Beautiful soundtrack.  The soundtrack itself is probably worth buying.  Great scenery in England, excellent cast, great sets and costumes.  Donald Sutherland as the father of the young girls is outstanding, as is Keira Knightley (as Elizabeth) and her older sister in the movie.  One suggestion: turn on the English subtitles.  That will greatly enhance your appreciation of the movie, because the actors speak rapidly in an English dialect.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have to start off saying that i am a very big Jane Austen fan. Also my fav is Sense and Sensibility so i can give an fairly neutral review.First of all i have to say there was much more sexual tension in this one. I love the scene where Mr Darcy helped Lizzy in the carriage. I loved how he moved his hand.The most surprising and best scene is the almost kiss. I thought this was appropriate of two people who did not care the actions but still had some feelings for one another. I do feel that the on screen chemistry was good.Did the movie take huge liberties with the book. Yes.I think the thing that most bothered me was when Elizabeth walked in with her hair down. That would not have happened ever. Hair down was only meant for bed and your husband. That would not have happened.Overall all it was o.k.  It was an o.k. modern rendition.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is, by far, the worst adaptation of a Jane Austen novel that I have ever seen.  The reason Jane Austen works are so beloved is that she gives her characters such depth and subtlety, all of which is lost in this incredibly shallow, hollywood-ized piece of garbage.  The characters were poorly cast and even more poorly developed by the actors playing them.  I have never hated a screen adaptation of any novel more than I despise this.  I have to believe that the people giving this 4 and 5 stars have either not read the novel, or just don't "get it".

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having read the praises of some of the earlier reviewers, I had to add my two cents. This is the fourth version of the Jane Austen classic that I have seen and this one is the worst version. None of the actors were even competent in pulling off their roles, the screenplay was not at all faithful to Ms Austen's fine dialogue, the direction was lackluster and the art direction left a lot to be desired. Even the the 1940 version with its MGM/Hollywood treatment surpasses this atrocity. I was glad to have the thing over with in the end. What a waste of Judi Dench....
summary: The Worst Adaptation of Austen EVER!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have read this classic Jane Austen story so many times. I have seen so many versions of this classic. But, when I saw this version, I was appalled. The interpretation was modernized and failed in its attempt to remake an adaptation; it proved to be disastrous. First, the setting for the Bennet home depicted them as extremely vulgar. Second, Darcy appeared weak and stupid. Third, the screenwriters completely changed the storyline thus it was not an adaptation of the Jane Austen classic, but a distasteful, unresearched film about a silly girl in a messed up fantasy world that did not depict the 1800's in our world and then a weak and confused, immature male that falls in love with her. It was disgusting.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautiful production values enhance the entertainment value of this latest adaptation of Jane Austen's classic novel. The storyline itself will win over any moviegoer, even those who usually balk at period pieces and classic literature. The characters are likeable and the sets are exquisite.Elizabeth and her sisters, from an impoverished family, are even more eager to make the "great marriage" that all young laides of the time were expected to find. Elizabeth, however, just can't bring herself to marry a man she doesn't respect no matter how much it helps her needy family. She surprises herself when she finds love and fortune with the man she least likes.Fine performances as well as a great story make this movie one not to be missed for those unfamiliar with the novels, and fans of Ms. Austen won't be disappointed with this newest remake.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My class and I LOVE the romance and the twists of this classic Austen story!  We LOVE it!  People actually cry at the end!  Fun.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Thank you for the Movie! It is my wife's favorite, and it was a lovely surprise for her.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I enjoyed this version of Pride and Prejudice. The story moves quickly, so my husband will watch it with me, but sometimes I miss the full development of the relationships and situations that are explored more in other versions of this story.However, the views and landscapes are breathtaking! The whole movie has the feeling of art through the cinematography and the lighting and the shots used. This is a gorgeous movie and I enjoy watching it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Poor adaptation, it really does not do any justice to the book! The portrayal of Eliza Bennett was shallow and besides the cinematography and Dame Judy's portrayal of Lady Catherine, I found it really tedious. It felt like it had been made in a hurry with poor attention to detail. Would recommend the 1985 version and the Colin Firth version to anyone who wants to watch a good adaptation.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: To think a story like Pride and Prejudice can be improved on, that one can write its dialogue better than Jane Austen, and that a story such as this needs help before it can become accessible is a case of hubris.  The appeal of Pride and Prejudice is universal and its characters are timeless.  The creators of this movie, however, took major liberties in their translation of this classic onto the big screen.I had high hopes for this movie, and I anxiously awaited for its release, but it fell completely short of my expectations.  Most of its characters were poorly cast, and the scriptwriters blundered many parts of the plot, re-writing it into nonsense that wouldn't have fit the sentiments and protocols of the era.Mr. Bingley was portrayed like a goofy boy rather than a respectable, good natured gentleman; Caroline Bingley looked more like a runway model on a perpetual high as opposed to a keen, manipulative social climber; Georgiana Darcy was bubbly and extrovert instead of being painfully shy; Mr. Collins was wooden and dull as opposed to being an obsequiously wily toadie (he was funny, though, I'll give him that); Darcy was portrayed as utterly misunderstood without pride, when we know that Darcy was definitely proud; and, though Keira Knightley is definitely spirited, she played Lizzie with liveliness and fire, but without the undeniable charm that tempered her faults and compelled us to forgive her trespasses.  Knightley's performance is also a little too forward and she is unable to subdue herself when necessary--basically, it's too modern a portrayal.Other reviewers have already poured over the script blunders, and I agree with most of them, but the ones that really stood out to me were:- Georgiana's wild hair, which was loose and looked absolutely unbrushed, along with her being portrayed as an extrovert.- Lady Catherine's late-night visit, with the entire Bennett clan standing around in their nightwear.- The rainstorm scene where Darcy proposes in clothes that are utterly drenched.- The inconsistencies with the costumes, particularly Lady Catherine's throwbacks and Caroline Bingley's modern, sleeveless numbers.- The inconsistencies with Longbourn.  It was rustic, dingy, and dirty--no doubt to make the Bennett's surroundings look more 'raw'--but they had servants at the ready in nearly every Longbourn scene.This isn't Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice; it's entirely someone else's vision of Pride and Prejudice.  Often times, I would wonder if the creators of the movie and I had even read the same book.  The scriptwriters thought that they had to help the story, that the story the way it is wouldn't work with audiences.  In the end, what was preserved of the original story was the only saving grace, with all the changes made with the plot done in poor taste.I understand that films and books are two entirely different creatures, and that there would be tremendous challenges for any movie seeking to portray a book's worth of material into a 2-hour film.  That, however, still does not excuse the dumbing down of the plot and dialogue.  One reviewer said that the film was too "obvious," and I'm apt to agree.  Even my husband says that the movie was "P&P; for Dummies."  The movie was more of a typical romance novel featuring P&P; characters rather than a movie version of our beloved novel.In the end, the A&E; version is still vastly superior.
summary: Hit and miss, but misses more often than hits

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Awesome movie about social status and the love that overcomes those boundaries. Excellent film! Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen have a magic chemistry!! One of my favorites!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have read the novel four times, watched the 1995 A&E; production numerous times, even seen the 1980 miniseries. But for me, this big screen adaptation is the best. True, it takes some liberties with the story: No way Elizabeth will go around Meryton without her bonnet, no way will Bingley come to visit Jane in her sick bed, no way Darcy will come into Lizzy's room when she is in her nightgown; Lady Catherine won't come in the middle of the night or Darcy won't propose in an ancient temple but these are not the important points. The important points are the realistic approach to the story, the gorgeous visuals, the great performances (especially by the lead actors) and the liveliness of the production.The film may seem a bit too hurried to those not familiar with the story. There is a lot going on and scenes go rushing along but the film does a good job of squeezing as many scenes and characters as possible in a 2 hour time frame. Mr Wickham is a bit left out, he just comes and goes but to tell the truth the actor's performance is so bad, it is better not to see more of him.Having considered Colin Firth as the ultimate Darcy for years, I am totally converted now. Matthew Macfadyen is the ultimate Darcy. His face conveys a whole lot of emotions and although Darcy was not supposed to be so expressive of her admiration of Elizabeth, I think there is no better way to convince the audience that he IS "most ardently" in love with Lizzy in around 2 hours. Keira Knightley is very good too. Although she giggles a little bit too much, her eyes and her voice express her emotions very well.Tom Hollander interprets Mr Collins differently here. In the 1995 version, Mr Collins was merely servile; here he comes across as quite cunning.Joe Wright directs the film brilliantly. The Assembly dance is so  exhilarating; you can almost smell the sweat. The ball scene is really superb.If you are a Jane Austen purist and like some Lord Of the Rings fanatics who think Sam's donkey shouldn't be excluded from the story in Lord of the Rings because the relationship between the man and the donkey was very important, you may find a lot of faults with this film. If not, you will certainly love it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I won't compare this movie much with the Colin Firth version because it's so different; rather, it needs to be compared against the book. And there are some things to really like in this version of the movie. First, it is the best short version I have seen. It would be extremely difficult to fit all of the book into a feature-length movie, and they do it very well. Unlike other versions, it doesn't leave out or alter many major parts. One technique that I was impressed with involved combining scenes (I am thinking primarily of the dinner party with Elizabeth speaking to Wickham) so that they were able to include most of the important story line points without requiring time-consuming additional scenes. I thought that was well-done.I also believe their version of Mr. Darcy better than any other characterization that I have seen. I have never believed that the "Pride" in Austen's title really referred to Mr. Darcy as he really was - only to him as Lizzy saw him. I have long felt that his apparent pride was due to lack of social skills and being ill at ease in the company of relative strangers. This hypothesis explains his amazing "change" that people often attribute to Lizzy's influence: I think it's obvious that what changed is her view of him, not his nature. This movie apparently agrees with my view - Mr. Darcy is shown, not prideful as Colin Firth sometimes was, but very vulnerable right from the beginning. I count that as a very strong point of this version.It's not perfect, of course. In some cases, I do think they cut out important elements. Wickham, for example, disappears from Lizzy's life without a trace (no mention of the Mary King affair, and not playing out his involvement with Georgeanna). Overall, he didn't come off as evil yet initially pleasing as he should have. As a Christian, Austen was well aware of how her characters related to beings in the spiritual realm, and I think Wickham should be a picture of Satan himself; in the movie he was just a somewhat bad man.I also do not like how they changed some lines around without any apparent reason. The worst example is from chapter 11 in the drawing room at Netherfield where Carolyn is trying to impress Mr. Darcy. In the book she says "I should like balls infinitely better if ... conversation rather than dancing were made the order of the day." To which Bingley replies, "Much more rational ... but it would not be near so much like a ball." This is a perfect example of Austen showing up Caroline for the ridiculous poser she was; but the movie has Lizzy's sister Mary saying it instead and Caroline, of all people, correcting her. This pretty much ruined the whole effect of what I think is one of the best lines of the book.Additionally, I have never thought that any representation of the relationship between Charlotte and Mr. Collins was true to the book; one of initial convenience on Charlotte's part, but which eventually turned into fondness for Collins' quirks, and finally into love. (The book admittedly does not lay this out clearly, but I believe it supports this view.)Finally, I think that one of the most negative characters in the entire book (next to Wickham, of course) is Mr. Bennet. Through his jokes, he never pays any attention to doing what is his primary job: providing (materially, emotionally, and spiritually) for his family. He's constantly in his library reading when he ought to be doing his real job. I don't think this came through at all. True, there was the one scene where he refused to stop Lydia from going to Brighton because he was tired of her whining; but that was it. In his final scene in the book, for example, he is relieved that Mr. Darcy paid for Lydia's wedding because that way he wouldn't have to worry about paying him back, and makes a little joke of it. In the movie, he seemed genuinely concerned about paying back Darcy, which was not at all true to his character.So, overall it is a good movie; and a good adaptation of the book, the best short one I have seen, but lacking in certain areas. I recommend that you see it, but you may want to have somebody well-acquainted with the book with you to point out the differences.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie for last night was "Pride & Prejudice." I found the DVD in our shelves and apparently it was something that my wife picked up and we failed to watch. Well, its a "best-film-of-the-year" type of movie no matter what year it might occur in. Without question. What can I possibly say? This movie already has over 1300 Amazon reviews and about 60% of them are five stars. And a lot of the reviews are exceptionally good. Well, it's a quite touching love story, actually two love stories, but I'm not going to dwell upon it. I'm just going to make a few remarks about things that especially impressed me.One was the setting. Magnificent! Where do they ever find such places in this modern world? The buildings and grounds were just immaculate! It was like being in the best park you could ever imagine. Everything was done to perfection and the photography was amazing. How do they ever manage to get big sweeping panoramic views with out a single power line, roadway or cars showing? Amazing! It really felt as if they had taken you way back to that pre-modern time. Does England have "preserves" like this just for the purpose of making classic movies?Secondly, the costumes were excellent! And so elaborate! And no doubt correct for the time. This movie paid attention to the details, believe me. And the interiors of some of the living quarters were just magnificent. Do the Brits really live like this? Well, I guess these were all upper-crust Brits, so I'll let this one pass by. However, any fancier of interior decorations and antiques is just going to be awe-struck by this movie. No expense was spared, and it's not some computer animation trick.Finally, the acting is just first rate. It always takes me a while to adjust to the stiff British methods, but it wasn't long before I felt like a part of the set and I laughed and suffered right along with the members of the cast. Well done! Also, the movie had an exceptionally good musical score. I thought the sound was a little too intrusive and interfered with the dialog here and there, but that's probably because it was set in surround sound and I watched it using a stereo sound system. In any case, this is just an exceptional movie. Five Stars!Gary Peterson

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was extremely disappointed with this version of Pride and Prejudice. The director/writer (I don't know who) obviously felt that Jane Austen didn't write enough drama and "real" life into her book.  In a movie about a gentlemen and his wife who need to marry off 5 daughters within the limited confines of their small village, why is there a shot of a boar's testicles 5 minutes into the production?  It didn't add anything to the production and wasted time needed for the story.  Mr. Bennett was a gentlemen, so why didn't he ever shave?  Donald Sutherland just looked scruffy throughout the movie! The costumes were not true to any period in English history. If it was Georgian, all the ladies should have been wearing fitted to the waist dresses with full skirts, as Mrs. Bennett did.  Instead we get Lizzie in drab not quite high waisted (was it Empire?) dresses. Keira Knightly is flat chested and the Empire style of the time was very flattering to such a figure. Why was she not costumed well?  The dance scenes were chaotic.  These were assemblies and house parties held by and for the gentlemen's class, not the servants.  In this village and its surrounds there weren't that many people who would have been invited.  This wasn't Brighton or Bath at the height of the season! Just too much drama!  Lizzie out in the rain in the gazebo during her big confrontation with Mr. Darcy--where was that scene in the book? And people didn't travel very far in the dark!  So why on earth would Lady Catherine de Burg be calling on the Bennetts at midnight or later just to confront one of the daughters about her relationship with her nephew?  Lady Catherine de Burg was very strict on proper conduct and even enraged as she was, she would still have observed the proprieties. And where was Lydia's story?  This movie seemed to have been written by someone who hadn't read the original book and/or believed they could do a better job of telling the story!  The director/writer forgot that there were many threads woven together to tell the story of Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. And Lydia's elopement with a seducer was integral to getting Darcy and Lizzie together!  All in all a big disappointment!  And it could have been so much better!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is an amazing movie.  Joe Wright, the director, did a great job selecting the actors and with the cinematography.  He managed to capture the story in a two hour time frame and so this one shouldn't be compared to the 1995 BBC mini-series version.  If Wright took another 15-20 minutes, I'm sure the audience would not have minded.  Knightley and MacFadyen had wonderful chemistry, and there would have been more time for dialogue between them.  MacFadyen had much less screen time than you'd expect for this story, but he was convincing and filled the role of Darcy extremely well.  This movie definitely belongs in the video library for the romantics, and Jane Austen fans.I've had a DVD copy of this movie since it's original release, and recently decided it was worth it to have a Blu-Ray/ digital version too.  The Blu-Ray version looks great and there were a couple more bonus features compared to the original DVD release.  Amazon delivered it quickly.
summary: Pride and Prejudice 2005 blu-ray, dvd, digital copy

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I wanted to like this movie, and I was prepared to accept a less than strict adaptation of the book, but I couldn't forgive the ridiculously indecorous little additions to a work based so heavily on the complexities of manner and conduct in Austenian society.  I didn't mind the family's poorness being enhanced to bring understanding to a modern audience of the wide breach between Bennett and Darcy, but I thought Knightly's coarse, greasy banged version of the subtle and witty Elizabeth went beyond the boundaries of "youthful" or "exuberant" and marched straight into the realms of the just plain inelegant.  For example, who thought it would be cute for Knightly to smack her food and lick her fingers at the breakfast table?  That kind of thing has nothing to do with youth or a modern adaptation--it's rude even today.  A main part of the original story was that Elizabeth and Jane had manners far superior to their family's, and were not themselves the objectionable ones.  Darcy even says as much at one point, a comment which was included in the movie's dialogue but hardly demonstrated in its acting.Elizabeth Bennett is one of my favorite literary characters, but all the things I like the most about her, her careful cleverness, her grace under fire, her classy superiority to the huffy rudeness dealt out to her by the upper class, were all but lost in this 'sassy farm girl meets stuck up rich dude' version of Austen's infinitely more subtle work.  In truth, this movie had a lot to live up to given the success of the BBC version (a fact which can be seen in its complete omission of that now famous scene where a dripping Darcy meets a shocked Elizabeth at his estate), but in my opinion, in its effort to do so, it simply overplayed its hand.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After reading Jane Austen's novel, I have had many arguments with myself over the judgements placed upon Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy. I have decided that in thinking of a title for her book, Austen was not assigning one characteristic to each character but instead she was assigning two equal qualities to both of the main characters. I used to think that Mr. Darcy, with his wealth and prominent upbringing, was too PROUD to be in the presence of commoners like the Bennets. Elizabeth on the other hand, after first witnessing Darcy's poor attitude and pride, made that her first and last impression of him. Ever since that moment, Lizzy became PREJUDICED toward Mr. Darcy and others like him. These qualities can also be switched; Darcy shows prejudice against people of lower rank or standing in society when he comments on Elizabeth's appearance or when later he addresses the entire Bennet family and their inappropriate behavior in public. Elizabeth could be considered proud in that she stands up for her family, her friends, and her way of life.After being able to support both characters under either quality, I still wonder whether or not these qualities are upheld at the end of the story. Interestingly enough, the characters didn't necessarily show prejudice against eachother, but against eachother's company and also against their own. Their union seems an obvious way to allow them both to continue to be negative toward eachother's relations and their own in the privacy of their shared home. I also believe that they both continue to be proud individuals because with confidence and self esteem comes pride in one's self. Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet sis not change at all throughout the story, they simply found in eachother the perfect match, both proud and prejudiced to the core.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must confess that I have not yet read the book, but watching this movie has persuaded me to.Though some do not approve of this film version of the novel, I have to say that I understand them. I am not fond of period movies, so the idea of watching this film was far from my thoughts. One boring afternoon, with nothing else to do, I decided to view the film. I did not pay attention at first, but little by little, I began watching it. By the end, I was crying because of the last scene.(Note: There are two endings to this film. The US version has Lizzie and Darcy kissing. The UK version ends with the intimate moment with Lizzie and her father. I cried at the UK ending.)A few days later, I decided to watch the movie once more. This time, I enjoyed it more than I thought I would. So far, I've viewed the film 5 times and counting.It is a masterpiece on its own. With its spectacular scenery, Colorful imagery, and moving score, one has to view this film more than twice to fully enjoy what this movie really has to offer. As I watched the film, I felt as if I was reading a piece of literature: fluid in motion as if from your own imagination.The symbolisms in this film are abundant (Take note: The film aims to depict the film as if from the  POV of Lizzie. Notice the constant shoot where we are able to see what Lizzie sees, like viewing herself in the mirror or viewing Lydia's departure from the window.) Whats more is the set designers characterization of the settings to complement the characters living in them (Example: The Bennet house possessed vibrant colors similar to the Bennet family. Darcy's home gives a mysterious, great but modest grandeur similar to Darcy himself.) Then the Music... OH MY... the music is heavenly! Enough said.The story flows quick and well. It does not drag in certain parts, allows full coverage of the main story without making the film too long.I have viewed the BBC 1995 TV series of the novel upon recommendation my many. For me, I did enjoy the TV version seeing as it seemed appropriate for television. But to be honest, I prefer this version better. One notable thing about this version is that you don't go hating any of the dislikable characters like Mrs Bennet, Mr Collins, etc. The film gives them depth and so in the end, instead of hating them totally, you tend to understand them.The well-rounded characters, the breath-taking scenery, the emotionally moving score, and the vibrant colors of the imagery makes this film a work of art.To add to this: as a guy, I did not expect to appreciate the intensity of the crucial romantic scenes, but I did. It surprised me but I was actually able to relate to Mr Darcy's character during those moments. I felt the moment.The humor of the film is also something to behold. It takes careful attention in order to catch many of its humor (Such as Ms Bingley's line "For God's sake, Are we to receive every Bennet in the county?!" or Lizzie's reaction as she enters the room after reading Jane's letter about Kitty) Some jokes are not so obvious at first, but when you understand the situation, you laugh so hard. It's very witty and sarcastic.The Acting... Keira being nominated for BEST ACTRESS at the Oscars says enough. Matthew is a great actor (Why wasn't he nominated?!). I've seen some of his work and I dare say that this is best work (For me that is). Playing a grown man who falls in love like a little boy is not an easy thing to do.For those who dislike this film, may I ask you to take another look. For those who liked it, view it again so you would love it more.As my Literature teacher once said "A good piece of literature is one which you have to read or view more than once in order to enjoy the various layers of the work". This is what this version offers.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Here's a challenge for you: Try watching this movie *without* comparing it to the 1995 miniseries. While the miniseries was fabulous, there's much to love in this movie.The chemistry between the two leads is remarkable. Matthew MacFadyen's Mr. Darcy smolders and suffers with his love for Elizabeth Bennet. He literally made me sigh (and nearly swoon). And Keira Knightley is fresh, energetic and lovely in the role of Miss Bennet.The scenery made me want to catch a flight to England and find a misty moor to wander. The soundtrack strikes a perfect note throughout. The supporting cast is everything it should be.So forget for a second the 1995 version. Forget for a moment more the ways the screenplay strays from Miss Austen's words. And then enjoy a sweet, rich, heart-warming love story that stands the test of time.
summary: Wonderful, fresh version of an old favorite!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Loved the movie and I don't even like Jane Austen's stories.This interpretation was completely honest and surprisingly contemporary while still using Austen's words to effectively portray the emotions of the characters.  Keira, for such a tiny thing, is surpringly forceful and powerful in her prideful portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett.  Her acting style is so natural that you wonder if she was acting at all.  If Reese Witherspoon hadn't won the Oscar, it clearly would have gone to Keira Knightly.  I haven't seen the Colin Firth version of Pride and Prejudice, but this was well done, straighforward yet still cinematically beautiful and pleasant.I'd love to see more of Keira in strong roles which is what she's clearly suited for.  English Rose she may be, but dainty dame she is not.  Clearly a lovely tomboy who can hang with the boys...which acocunts for her solid performance in Bend it Like Beckham. Her off screen persona is not too far off.  When interviewed on the Red Carpet by Isaac Mizrahi, she told him with quick frankness she didn't think she would win.  Mizrahi responded that she needed a plan when her name was called.Keira:  Whether or not I win, I'm going to party afterwards.Mizrahi:  Great!  Who are you going with to the party?Keira: I don't know...I'm just going to...follow people.Now that's how a 20 year old talks.  You could tell she was clearly there to have fun and wasn't taking herself too seriously.Star in the making.  She's got plenty of time for Oscars.  Might as well enjoy herself.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie had all the ingredient of a great film but one. It is the script.  I mean the acting was perfect. Keira gave a brilliant performance as Elizabeth, and Matthew grew on me as Darcy. But the script readers the script!!....It really suck..The writers too much  poetic license when they try to modernize the story.  In doing so they alienated the core fan of P&P.; I liked the 1995 version but always thought some of the character were miscast and too old to play the part(ie Jenifer Erhle as Elizabeth, Wickham, Caroline Bingley, The Gardiners). This time around I like the cast and hate the story line.  I only pray that the next attempt will be the correct one.I still recommend the purchase of that movie. In fact I have pre-odered it myself.  If one can get over the imperfection of the story  and its failed attempt at modernization ( Elizabeth not wearing gloves at the Netherfield ball, the new version of Georgiana dealing with Wickham, Elizabeth getting even with Darcy at the Meryton assembly, The Rosing proposal...), you will find it quite a delightful tale.In a world where movies seemed to be laced with violence, questionable take on morality, this  movie is one of best family friendly film made.  So support this film by buying  the DVD

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wow!  I've seen nearly all the film versions of Pride and Prejudice, and this one is by far my favourite.  Here, viewers are treated to gorgeous cinematography showing off amazing English vistas.  Of course, I realize that this film is not a verbatim play by play of the book, but it certainly caught my attention and kept me interested straight to the end.  Keira Knightly is perfect as Elizabeth ("Lizzie") Bennett.  She plays Lizzie just as I imagine her, headstrong and passionate.  I also love Matthew McFadden as Mr. Darcy.  He is very sexy!  Plus he doesn't play as stoic a Mr. Darcy as Colin Firth in the BBC version.  In this version of Pride and Prejudice, Mr. Darcy is visibly affected and thrown off by his attraction to Lizzie from the very beginning.  Some reviewers may object to this lack of subtlety and nuance, but I found it appealing.  Overall, I think this film was aimed at a younger audience.  The dialogue was less 19th century English, but more of today's plain language (note, the use of "divine goddess" etc.).  The film also focused more on the Bennett family and the romance between Lizzie and Mr. Darcy rather than the broader scope of the book which focuses on social structure among other things.  While this Pride and Prejudice may not appeal to Austen purists, I was thoroughly entertained!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I cannot add much to the many wonderful well documented reviews of this movie that I have read. I just wanted to add my one star to theirs. This adaptation of Pride and Prejudice is terrible.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: PRIDE & PREJUDICE is a handsomely mounted production, moodily filmed with a pervasive dark texture of visual expression about it. It is quite a visual presentation of the story where dialogue is left unspoken and the power of the images both animate and inanimate speak for themselves. That is not to say that the film goes on without dialogue, but rather quite the opposite. The many exchanges of dialogue are witty, brilliantly structured, eloquently spoken and presented with an economy of style that is concisely intelligent. This film with its intricately mounted visuals and words does an admirable job of bringing this literary work to the screen with all the constraints inherent in the medium of the cinema. Director Joe Wright also did a more than commendable job of representing the two main characters. Keira Knightley gives an awe-inspiring performance as Lizzie giving her great insight of the human condition. Lizzie though impetuous at times has a gift of rationalizing human behavior with a certain sense of reality offsetting loftier romantic ideals thus making her a young woman of keen intelligence. I truly enjoyed Matthew MacFadyen's performance as Darcy. He seems a young man tired and perplexed by convention but knows no other way to conduct himself and is trapped by his by his social status but more importantly by his own upbringing. Matthew MacFadyen's does an exceptional job conveying this. Awkwardly trying to emote his inner feelings he does more to alienate Lizzie than win her affections. MacFadyen's Darcy is truly a man misunderstood. Only through good and anonymous deeds can the true nature of the man prevail. I think this is a very good film rich with artistic fervor yet embracing all that is good of the human spirit. The DVD extras are very good.
summary: Concise and Exquisitely Beautiful Production and DVD

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I couldn't quite determine the initial feelings I had regarding this version right when the end credits started rolling...So I watched it again... This film will have that effect on a person.. Especially if the person had sat through the more detailed and finely done BBC version and, let's not forget, someone who has read the book too.I didn't like the ending.."Divine goddess?""..Bewitched me body and soul?"  What was that? That really sugar-coated the much anticipated coming together of Lizzy and Darcy.. It was "gaggifying" and elementary...This isn't comparing apples and oranges. 10 years later another remake is made of this popular story and is put out in the market for people to devour. I know some of us will stay allied with the miniseries and/or novel, but this current remake is just a story for people to be entertained by. Some won't understand how important it is for a woman to get married, in Elizabeth Bennet's time frame. It is mentioned of course, but the key points in this film are about love concerning Lizzy and Jane. The story is cut and pasted together while we can't appreciate the worlds of the other characters. There isn't a way to tell this story in under two hours though, is there?The acting isn't bad at all. The actors/actresses get into character and don't leave us yawning. I know females tend to wish to be beautiful and in love. They wish to be in some sort of romantic tension with some dashing man. It's all fun and games. This adaptation serves those people. "Awww!"The scenery and costumes aren't overdone. I am glad to see them NOT wearing ball gowns.  "Lizzy" is quite lean though, but none-the-less confident looking. "Darcy" looks like what a stubborn, handsome man in that era should look like. He softens up too much towards the end, wearing that "love struck" daze on his face. He isn't supposed to be a bitter,pompous man in the end. I just wasn't expecting him to be a a creme puff either. Give Darcy some dignity. "Jane" looked like as humble as she should be. She wore a lot of innocense on her face. She was beautiful though.The Characters were adapted as accurate as this film can limit it, but in the end, we could all pinpoint who's who in the film even if they remaind nameless through the whole performance.Watch the film or don't. It's really a matter of choice. It's a nice adaptation, but it might leave one wondering more about the story.Here's an idea!Read the novel.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Some will ask "how many versions of Jane Austen's read-to-the-point-of-fraying 'Pride and Prejudice' do we need?"  The current film archives show no fewer than ten versions and growing.  But for this viewer the current P & P du jour is as satisfying as any, edited and distilled to its main story lines without diminishing the main message from the author. Deborah Moggach can be thanked for the screenplay (with some subtle revisions by Emma Thompson) and Joe Wright  for his sensitive and forward momentum directing approach.So what make this version different and successful?  First, the placement of the Bennet family in the pig and mud friendly country home that sets the scene properly for the driver of the film - finding proper husbands for the five daughters whose well placed marriages will assure the lower class Bennet family a future stability.  Yes, it is a bit untidy, this household, but that makes it a family more dependent on the land and more prone to dreams of 'marrying up' in a country ruled by class system. Second, the casting of the Bennnet family with five truly young actresses (Keira Knightly, Rosamund Pike, Talulah Riley, Jena Malone, Carey Mulligan) instead of older types trying to appear like teenagers; a mother (Brenda Blethyn) who indeed shows her desperation of class; and a father (Donald Sutherland) who epitomizes Austen's father figure mold.  Add to the Bennets the credible men characters of Simon Woods, Matthew Macfadyen, Tom Hollander, and  Cornelius Booth and top it all off with a pivotal Lady Catherine de Bourg of Judi Dench and all players are in place for a fine cast.  The dialogue is crisp and sharp and the usual diversions into lineage names and sidebars are eliminated, bringing this long story down to just over two hours.The scenery and costumes are superb as is the cinematography by Roman Oshin and the musical score by Dario Marianelli  with a lot of help from Henry Purcell.  Is it one of the best movies of the year?  Perhaps, perhaps not, depending on taste. But it is nice to see Keira Knightly shine in a role more challenging than any she has had to date.  She inhabits Elizabeth Bennet luminously.  Grady Harp, March 06
summary: Distilled Austen Makes for a Fine Brew

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not British, I haven't seen the BBC version and have no idea of the minutiae of aristocratic surroundings in the UK to be too distressed about the Bennett house. I read the book, but not recently, so I cannot offer a detailed comparison of what was altered. Perhaps because of these factors I was surprised about the mixed reviews this film has gotten.I really liked this film for its emotional intensity, social commentary and beautiful cinematography. Love is unique enough today, when most people's choices are far less circumscribed than in the 19th century. At the time, it was the exception many dreamed about and few experienced, at least in their marriage. Pride and Prejudice is about women's lives, where compromise rules and the rational decision of Charlotte is the order of the day. The necessity of marrying for financial security gives even the most unsuitable men the pick of quite adequate women.The social hierarchy is clear and oppressive and all of us romantics watching it :) root for love to upset it. The pacing of the film allows us to understand the way Lizzy's and Darcy's feelings develop (by contrast, we are told of Jane's and Bingley's feelings, but do not experience them) and although we may know what comes next, we can still hold our breath. When at the end of the film, for example, Darcy comes to visit early in the morning, we watch him approach, rather than cut to him appearing and then talking to Lizzy. An important conversation is given weight by editing. These are the details that give the film its intensity. The actors are wonderful, a complex mixture of well-bred manners and uncontrollable emotion.Finally, the images of the countryside are striking in their beauty and rich detail rules even the indoor scenes. I actually regret that I haven't seen this film in the theater and I am seriously considering buying it. As this rarely happens to me, I can strongly recommend this movie :)
summary: I am thinking of buying this

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, it's true.  A two-hour movie can't cover as much ground as a five-hour mini-series, and it may be unfair to expect it to.  What is a reasonable demand, however, would be expect the filmmakers to make judicious cuts in the narrative and not to rush, rush, rush through a fairly complex storyline and to run roughshod over the elegant dialogue that the story's original author provided her flawed, but self-aware and articulate characters.This film's failings--when compared to the artistic success of the 1995 BBC series--begs the question as to whether or not a novel this rich and this subtle doesn't deserve a full five or more hours to unfold on film.  Maybe that's the only real way to translate Austen's literary genius successfully to a visual medium.For the first half hour or so, I thought the problem may have just been me.  But when we got to the "Mr. Collins" scenes, I knew something internal to the film had gone awry.  The equivalent passages in the book--as well as the equivalent scenes in the 1995 production--make for masterful comic moments.  In this film, it's BING (Collins arrives) BANG (he proposes to Elizabeth, who rejects him completely) and BOOM (he marries Charlotte).  The acting is fine--especially Tom Hollander, who has some fine comic moments as Collins.  But the timing is way off.I will give director Joe Wright and his collaborators credit for coming up with a top flight ensemble cast overall.  There has been considerable attention payed to the casting of Keira Knightley, who is somewhat closer in age to her character than previous Elizabeths had been, and there is something to be said for that kind of "age appropriateness."  All well and good.  She's a fine young actress.  But her dialogue--like so much else in the movie--is too rushed and therefore almost awkward.  Elizabeth should speak with a kind of regal self-confidence.  That she doesn't quite manage that may not be Knightley's fault.  It's hard to be a witty and spirited conversationalist when you're obliged to dash through your lines.Matthew McFadyen as the more taciturn Darcy has it somewhat easier.  Like most educated young men of his class and of his era--and like any proper Austen hero--he is supremely well-spoken when he chooses to speak. McFadyen is an appealing actor, and certainly not a bad Darcy (he will have his camp followers, just as Colin Firth has his), but just about all he has time for is a furrowed brow here, a wounded look there.Probably the only really bad casting is that of Judi Dench as the Queen of the Night--I mean, Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  In British cinema, Dench is, of course, an institution.  Here unfortunately, she's more of a mental institution.  Her moments onscreen are almost painful to watch.  Someone on this site (perhaps the Amazon critic?) has kindly described her performanceas "full throttle."  That's polite for "overkill."Well, she does liven things up a bit.  But what we really need and what we really expect from any production of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is a certain esprit,  a sense of narrative driven by intelligent, incisive dialogue.  That's where the subtle social satire comes in.  Do away with that and you have a romantic 19th Century love story.  Not bad, but not all it could be.  And not really what it's supposed to be either.PS--I notice I received a number of "non-helpful" votes within less than 24 hours of posting this qualified (not actually NEGATIVE) review.  Well, people are certainly entitled to their opinions (just as I am entitled to mine).  However, I do wish readers of these reviews would learn to make the distinction between "non-helpful" and  "I disagree with this."  If a negative (or mixed) review gets you to THINK about why you liked the work in question, then, kids, it is HELPFUL.  You just happen to disagree with it.  I sometimes get the impression that some readers out there want nothing more than to see their own biases confirmed.  Which begs the question: why even BOTHER to read what anybody else thinks.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, loved it, as I didn't really know it and only read the book and watched other earlier versions as a result. Knightley is perfect in the part, and the rest are well placed as well, though the girls should've looked a little different in age to be precise. The only problem, once you know the book and Austin's life/material is that the director, which did such an excellent job in the first half, only did an average job in the second. That mirror scene failed, and should have been cut in the editting room if not later before release. The feel of the book was changed too much in the second half from the man's sister to the lack of walking scenes, so that the sense of history is lost in an attempt to 'modernize' the storyline, forgetting that the essence can be lost in the same process.All that said, I feel it is the best version I've seen. Others have had a better sense of historical accuracy but the female leads just weren't 'right' for the part in my opinion. Knightley seemed to be made up as Austin at times and the feel of the characters seemed more true, even if so many changes were made by the end. She is the only actress that 'was' the character in all the version's I've seen, the others either didn't have the look or the feel or age to play the part... again, in my opinion, as today's 'taste' has changed over the past few decades. I just wish the second half of the script could've been rewritten and reshot, a couple of great 'walking' scenes would have made better adaptations to film drama/comedy than what the director/writer choose for whatever reason they had at the time, but again, if I had to point to one, I'd take this shortened version over the other longer ones, that seemed so dull by comparison, some of which is a statement of British tv production values or lack of, at the time. The quality has improved to 'Hollywood' standards of production and presentation, for better and for worse, that's life here in Purgatory.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While this movie doesn't always stay true to the book or the attitudes of the time, it is still a very well done love story.  It skips some of the most interesting things in the book, but overall the story plays out well.  If you are use to watching the mini-series version with Colin Firth, you may be disappointed, but I found if you keep watching it it really grows on you.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've always loved Pride and Prejudice. More so, when I discovered the BBC version, most fondly known as the Colin Firth version. I have nothing but praised for that mini-series, and I have fallen in love with the story even more. I love how repressed and snooty Darcy is, how charmingly snarky Lizzie can be. There was also a sense of maturity in the mini-series, and most probably, it was influenced by the casting of older actors that resulted in that. It worked well for them. All in all, the numerous times that I have watched it in entirety is a testament to my love for it. And then I hear there's a new version coming out with Keira Knightley as Lizzie and some guy as Darcy. How dare they attempt to remake it, when possibly the definitive version has already been done?!I have heard that many Austen purists are in uproar over this and I can see why. It's not your mother's Jane Austen, for one thing -- while some may think that's an insult, I mean it as a compliment. This new version is less polite, less genteel; it's also less repressed and more in-your-face, well, as in-your-face one can be in breeches and cravats. Whereas the BBC version used its 6 hours to meet and match and flirt and separate the characters, the movie has less of that luxury so it makes up for it by being more fiery and earthier, more emotional and even more confrontational. It's also very young,in the best sense of the word.  It's fresh and new, and I would have love to see this version fleshed out to its full width and breadth, rather than just the abbrieviated version that I watched. But even then, the experience is wonderfully involving.  Here, emotions are always on the verge of breaking through the surface, making the passions more heightened and the anguish more excuciating. And love is felt in all its giddy, painful, confusing glory. A lot has to be said for Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen taking on roles that have been done (and brilliantly before). Yet I actually like their new takes on the characters: Knightley's Lizzie is less polished but equally as witty and charming, while MacFadyen's Darcy is less self-possesed and more vulnerable but equally as snooty (and later adorably, meltingly romantic).I love the touches that made this movie fresh:1) The characters of Jane and Bingley are more defined, and that's something that is better than the mini-series. There, she comes out as bland while he seems almost retarded while here, Jane's more animated and self-possessed while Bingley is charmingly nervous, adorably shy and sweet-tempered.2) During the dance, when they were arguing and suddenly, only the two of them are left dancing and sniping at each other -- this is a very imaginative take on the whole cliche of having eyes for only one person, even in the midst of a dance and in the middle of an argument.3) The almost kiss after Lizzie rejected Darcy. The look on his face was so wonderful, seeing as we can view how much it was hurting him to turn away while she was surprised at her seeming to want him to kiss her. *sigh*  They are so attracted to one another depite hating each other's guts. Lovely...and soooo hot. (p.s. I so wanted to hug and kiss him for that little boy lost look when he realzied that she said no to him).I thought I would never see anyone else fill Darcy's shoes but Colin Firth but in this version, Matthew MacFadyen acquits himself wonderfully and so deos Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennett.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: By far the best movie version of Jane Austen's wonderful book.  Very low priced.  Great gift for the romantic in your life.  I bought it for myself.
summary: Great Price for a Classic Must Have DVD

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My friend recommended this movie--"Pride and Prejudice" with Keira Knightley--and I watched it twice that evening! My heart soared toward the end of the film as Darcy and Elizabeth make their way toward each other.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While not perfect, it was a well-done adaptation.  I am a purist, so I am never pleased by having bits left out or changed.I did not like the foppish, stupid appearance of Bingly, but I did think that the choices for Elizabeth, Darcy and Wickham were excellent.  Mr and Mrs Bennett were entirely too old (as is so often the case in Pride and Prejudice adaptations) but were wonderful actors.It was an enjoyable movie, and I do recommend it, while I still found it flawed.
