title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is not the best adaptation of Pride and Prejudice. They are a bit too stuck on themselves, too impressed with their own talents. It bespeaks arrogance rather than quality. The characters in the Pride and Prejudice with Colin Firth have a sweetness that is complimented by intelligence. Even the bonus features betray that the actors are more impressed with themselves than they are interested in delivering a great performance. I fault the director to a degree. He shifts many lines that were meant for the young ladies' father in the story to Keira Knightly. She comes off as pompous rather than intelligent. A failing strung throughout the entire showing.
summary: Not as great as the first one!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley is one of the most beautiful women of this generation, as well as a terrific actress ("STAR WARS Episode I," the wildly successful"Pirates Of The Caribbean" films) and is a natural choice for the role of Elizabeth Bennet in what seems to be the 200th film version of Jane Austen's classic romantic comedy. Sir Laurence Olivier, Greer Garson, Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle have starred in wonderful adaptations of this novel. I highly recommend those versions, though they may seem old and dated to the uneducated rabble. Trust me, they are so worth it.The all-star cast is simply amazing.My only complaint is the casting of Donald Sutherland. His American accent was distracting, as the story is set in England, during the 19th century, and all the other actors had British accents. Fortunately, his screen time is limited.
summary: Terrific Version Of Jane Austen's Timeless Classic Romantic Comedy, Keira Knightley Shines.

Read it! enjoy it....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is ridiculous!  Although visually pleasing, this movie fails to develop any of the characters and plods along like a bad high-school production.  The drama of the story is completely lost and the sentiment of the film is not true to Jane Austen's novel.  All of the characters are dull stereotypes and the acting by Keira Knightly is laughable to say the least.  She is not capable to conveying the wit, passion, and complexity of Elizabeth Bennett.See this movie if you must but don't expect it to replace the Colin Firth version by BBC

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen this movie a dozen times or more.  I love looking at it over and over again so I bought it.  I would recommend this movie to anyone who wants to sit in front of the TV and watch a romantic movie on a cold wet day.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is not bad but I prefer the other versions much better.  It still has its own little twist on the story which makes it interesting enough to watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Charming retelling of the Jane Austen classic. The rustic look of the Bennett estate suggests "class" differences more than previous versions between the have and have not people in the story. This film was nicely produced and well acted and has special qualities of its own to recommend it. And while the BBC PRIDE AND PREJUDICE with Colin Firth is a more complete telling of the Austen tale and I have a special fondness for the 1940 MGM Garson/Olivier film which took liberties with the story, this Keira Knightly version has a warmth that makes it utterly appealing. It's definitely worth a look see. I recommend it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I rarely give reviews, but seriously, this is a movie, not a history lesson. It had two hours to tell a story. The director and his posse did their homework in many ways, but they also used the medium of cinema to help move along the story as well.Take the sculpture part of the story-it was a very important part of the storytelling because of the compacted timeframe here. Lizzy in this version just got back from turning down Darcy's proposal when swoop! The aunt and uncle take her off to Derbyshire country and Darcy's pad. Hmmm, within a space of 5 minutes we have Lizzy telling Darcy he sucks, to being affected by him. If we didn't use the sculpture vehicle, she would have looked mercenary-"oh, look at Darcy's hot estate, I think I like him now." But that's the NOT the storyline-she isn't mercenary. How is a director suppossed to convey this?I think Joe Wright took advantage of the medium of cinema and bridged the timeframe gap by allowing the sculptures to convey Lizzy's realization of her prejudice, her blindness, and her awakening feelings for Darcy(look at the statues used--- a "veiled" woman, Achilles "the heel guy" statue, etc. and finally Darcy's statue.)And how long did that bridge scene take to convery regret,hindsight, self awareness, and true feelings? Like a minute! Clever if you ask me.I mean, the point is that with a compacted timeframe to tell the story, sometimes you take liberties in conveying the spirit of the story, if not the plotpoints.I thought this was a great adaption for the medium used here.
summary: oh, lighten up folks! It's a movie-it has to tell the story differently!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The opening scenes of this adaption had me thinking I was watching The Woodlanders or Tess ( and Keira Knightly would make such a beautiful Tess) and continued Hardy style to the ending scene whereupon "Heathcliff"/ Darcy is seen striding across the misty moors to a dark "Cathy"/Eliza.It is however a very enjoyable film and a good romp despite its lacking in Austen's precise prose and witty dialogue. Like a good Shakespeare, I don't see why there cannot exist many adaptations; in the last 10 years or so there have been 3 Hamlets put on film. And why not, when we enjoy them so much?The performances in this film are wonderful - although I blame the director for allowing Knightly's 'wild behaviour' as Eliza, which put her in the same basket as her 3 silly sisters and has you wondering why on earth Darcy would fall for such a reckless woman when she has nothing else to recommend her.Does Working Title pictures understand the meaning of IRONY? The Bennets were by no means poor people simply because they had no heir to Longbourne Estate. (Just as Briget Jones, fussing over her weight all the time, was not a heffalump - as portrayed by Ms. Zellweger in the second installment). Estate may have been a key word to hint at their postion in society.One Bingley sister on her own doesn't carry the capacity for the nastiness of two, so that was a shame.I really appreciated this film giving Mary a pretty face. Why sould a fondness for reading scripture and being alone make you unattractive? I should have liked to have seen more of her character giving her unwanted quotations.A pity also that Charlotte Lucas was made to look like a girl who feeds pigs for a living. No self important sychophant like Mr. Collins would marry such a girl.I know it is a long way from Austen's Pride and Prejudice but it is still highly enjoyable and has some great performances from Dame Judi Dench, Brenda Blethyn, and Tom Hallander, to name a few. The music is gorgeous and so are the dance scenes.I look forward to another adaption in a few years. Who knows...maybe someone will be brave enough to do the film in two parts as with the brilliant french double feature "Joan of Arc -the battles" and "Joan of Arc - the prisons", starring Sandrine Bonnaire. It could be done and it could be brilliant!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved this version the actors made the characters come to life and appear human.  While this version is not completely in line with the novel itself it completely captured me.  I would absolutely LOVE to see this same group of actors take the novel in it entirety to the screen.  They put the other versions to shame in the ability of the cast alone.If you are a fan of the novel itself I highly recommend this version to you.  If you are expecting it to play out exactly as the book you will be highly disappointed but highly satisfied with the acting in itself.  Very loveable and endearing just as the novel itself.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you're a longtime Austen fan and you love P&P; then, yes, this movie may be disappointing for you.  But if you can take this movie as it is, without comparing it to the literary work too much, you will simply fall in love.Everything about this movie is enchanting. Kiera Knightly does a fabulous job of playing the spirited Elizabeth Bennet, completely unaware of her own beauty for in society it does not compare to her sisters.  But the person that really makes this movie is Matthew MacFadyen, who plays Mr. Darcy.  He truly captures all of the unlikeable traits of Mr. Darcy in the beginning, and has you completely in love with him at the end.Tom Hollander is Mr. Collins and he captures him completely.  The dance scene between he and Lizzie alone is worth the price of the movie.Visually entertaining, it's like taking a peek through a magical looking glass and catching the smallest glimpse of what life must have been like in England near 1800.  Austen was truly a master of writing about the kind of love that would escape her.  Every girl should have a Mr. Darcy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: People actually like this ridiculous, sorry version of P&P;?? Some people actually call this an accurate adaptation??Huh.But then again, that's why the work of Britney Spears is called music, and the likes of Paris Hilton are seen as icons, right? And scores of females actually want to be them....Trash. Pathetic lack of knowledge and lack of good sense rule the globe today. Thank you, the trash generator that is Hollywood.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is incredible.  Almost every review will mention the 1995 mini series with Colin Firth, and who wouldn't, Colin Firth is a peach.  But Matthew MacFadyan is an amazing actor, and he has this craggy, rough, gorgeous nature.  He was excellent in the series "spooks," Stateside it was called MI-5 and its available on A&E.com.;  Kiera is a sweetheart and she shows a different side in this movie, as opposed to Bend it like Beckham and Pirates of the Caribbean, she is more intense, and she is the perfect Elizabeth.  All other characters are cast well, especially the mother.  And though Judi Dench has a small appearence she is magnificant as usual.I was surprised at how much they squeezed into this movie.  The mini-series covered everything, and the older version from the 70's I think did a fine job at sticking to the novel quite well.  It does move fast, and perhaps if you've never ever heard of Pride and Prejudice, and you don't know the storyline, or you can't quite catch the brit. accent, you might have difficulty keeping up.  But its beautifully done, a fresh new view, with all shots blasting color at the audience.  The clothes have a traditional, yet, less formal feel...the sets are also less...itchy, less form-fitting, like the pinch of a over-starched shirt perhaps?  And Pemberly, oh my heavens, Pemberly is gorgeous, the houses are gorgeous.This review, I gaurantee you, won't do the movie justice...see it, watch it, buy it..you'll love it.
summary: In Love with Elizabeth and Darcy

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you are a Jane Austen fan rather than a Pride and Prejudice fan steer clear of the film.The film does have it merits such as Knightley's performance and the first propsal scence.The problem with the film is the liberties that screenwriter and director have taken. Proper decorum and standards of that time period are not observed. The interaction between characters have much more modern sensibilities than that of Austen's 19th century work. Additionaly hair styles and costumes where not of the correct time period as well. Even those who have not read the book but enjoy period dramas will find this annoying.There are mistakes in relationships between characters. Additionally scence and interactions towards the end are completely changed from the book. Also in general the time frame. Pride and Prejudice took place over 18 months.The relationship between Darcy and Wickham was never fully explained and I had to explain to others the full extent of that relationship.The biggest problem for this purist is the relationship between Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet is not fully built. One of the key points of this relationship is built during the days at Pemberly and when Lizzy gets the letter from Jane. We do not see the relationship build at Pemberly. But the worst part is that when she gets the letters from Jane and tells Darcy the Aunt and Uncle are present.This is the moment in the book where you see the most tenderness from Darcy and in this movie it is interupted by other relations being present.Overall it is entertaining for those who have not read the book and a fun diversion. If your a purist the fun would be in spotting the numerious mistake that are made.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of my favorite movies! I  can watch it on repeat. Jane Austen at her finest. must watch this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride & Prejudice is one of my favorite books and in my opinion this version was an excellent rendition. :) I tried watching the BBC version, but I just could not plough through it... The scenery and soundtrack in this version was beautiful, and all the characters fitted their roles perfectly. Keira Knightley was a great Elizabeth Bennet and Matthew McFayden was a great Mr. Darcy! They seem perfect in this time era!Excellent cast + scenery + soundtrack = excellence!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I heard the reviews that this version was not even close to BBC series. I believed and didn't even bother to watch. Than I saw MacFadyen in Little Dorrit (Charles Dickens story) and I was left absolutely astonished by his work. Wanting more of his acting I purchased this one. What a disappointment! Everything is great in this movie EXCEPT for the actors or their portrayal of Austin's characters by the makers. Knightley made Lizzie look stupid with her out of place grins and smirks. Macfadyen's Darcy is too soft. Mr. Collins is not funny. Authors mocked his height. Is it all that you can laugh at in this character?!! I don't think so. They also made Bingley look absolutely dumb. Although I loved the cinematography, music, and costumes, I didn't enjoy the movie at all. Irritated most of the time. Sorry. Don't understand some exalted reviews posted here. As for MacFadyen - watch "Little Dorrit" BBC series, he is absolutely adorable there. Darcy is not for him for sure.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was wary of watching this edition of "Pride and Prejudice" because I was absolutely convinced that it was going to be horrible, either because of the acting, or because it wouldn't stay true to the story as it is presented in the novel. But I definitely ate some humble pie after watching this film because it turned out to be absolutely wonderful, and did Jane Austen's novel adequate justice.While the movie is not as detailed as the novel - or the original BBC series - due to time constraints, the creators of the movie did a good job of choosing the important points of the story to focus on. While you don't want the movie to end when it does, you can at least feel like you've been given a complete and well rounded story before placing the DVD back in its case.The actors selected to portray such timeless literary characters were also well chosen; while I doubted Keira Knightley's ability to pull off the role of Elizabeth, I came away with a new respect for her acting ability after watching this film. The choice of Matthew MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy was also a good one; he played the brooding, but genuinely kind-hearted Mr. Darcy very convincingly. The online chemistry between Knightley and MacFadyen was also evident, enhancing the believability of Elizabeth and Darcy's romance when it was portrayed onscreen.While the cinematography in this movie varied greatly from the original BBC series, it was for the better. Some of the most crucial moments in the book - when Darcy professes his feelings for Elizabeth, and the ending where they meet in the early morning - were beautifully filmed. For those who are not interested in romantic movies, but appreciate good cinematography, watch this movie for that reason alone; you will not be disappointed.Though this film was wonderful, if you are comparing it to the book, or are a diehard fan of the original BBC series, you might come away disappointed. But for those who have never read the book, or ever seen the original BBC series, this is definitely a film that you need to add to your must-watch list.

review_text: This is a beautiful film neatly told. The production design is vividly and visually realistic adding a rare authenticity to this beloved tale. The characters have much more depth than normally would have been expected and made the viewing of this film a delightful experience.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This classic adaptation of Jane Austen, calibers with rigorous accuracy, the emotional barriers, masked of social conventions and no sense prejudices nestled in the Victorian ages (and still on) around the meaning of the real nature of the human being despoiled of so many rigid mental schemes that prison our minds, and souls. Fortunately our min personages visualized these taboos and could surpass it to find their bliss. The film is extremely slow until the first half, then it revitalizes through smart dialogues and unavoidable confrontations. Standard performances and splendid landscapes make of this movie a recommendable ocassion. The best of the cast were Judi Dench and Donald Shutherland, by far.The nature invented the pride to avoid us the pain of recognizing our imperfections.
summary: Two huge bunkers made of pride and surrounded of prejudice!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride and Prejudice was disappointing. It gave you no reason to care about the characters, or want them to fall in love. Everything happened so quickly, you couldn't keep up. I had to turn on the subtitles and rewind several times to figure out what was going on. The characters were skimmed over and unbelievable. The lighting was nice, but that was the high point of the film. My advice: Stick with the BBC mini series version. It makes more sense and is true to the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am completely "prejudiced" because I LOVE the A&E; version.  I did at least hope to find Mr. Darcy handsome. Unfortunately this movie was a very big disappointment.Elizabeth Bennet: Played by Keira Knightly, she lacked... spirit. When talking with Mr. Darcy at the ball, she's supposed to be enjoying this clever and witty word play, but she just talks like anyone else would. And why does it seem like she's attracted to Darcy before he even proposes? She's supposed to find him insufferable. While many reviewers said they felt they could relate to Knightly better than Jennifer Ehle of the A&E; version, I didn't feel any connection at all. She showed very little emotion at all when she wasn't ranting angrily, and I simply didn't find her performance entrancing.Mr. Darcy: Someone told me that they thought Matthew Macfadyen cuter than Colin Firth, so I may have had my expectations too high, but... I thought Macfadyen rather ugly! I'm sorry, and I think he's very nice-looking in real life. But as Mr. Darcy... ugh! Also, he didn't make a convincing "insufferable" Mr. Darcy. Darcy is supposed to be rather rude, cold, and arrogant. Macfadyen simply looked either bored or sleepy.Mr. Collins: Oh, what a travesty! He's hardly even in the movie, and he didn't really seem to care a twopence about Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  This Mr. Collins was incredibly dull, his only advantage being his shortness.Mr. Bennet: Donald Sutherland lacks Mr. Bennet's dry wit and sarcasm, much too quiet and beaten down to be interesting. Also, it looked like he hardly ever shaved. With his long hair and scruffy chin, I kept thinking he looked like a cross between Benjamin Franklin and a pirate.Dialogue: Choppy, rushed, and SO watered down from Austen's original. They talked so fast that it was like they were afraid of running out of time and had to spit out every line as fast as they could.Costuming: Although a bit more attractive to our 21st century eyes than that of A&E;, it does not feel as authentic. Miss Bingley's dress in particular is ridiculous, having no sleeves and only very thin straps.Music: The one area in which this movie shines, although the music is not as authentic to the time period as that in A&E.;I had fairly low expectations when I started this movie, but I really tried to like it. Unfortunately, I found the events rushed and chopped, the characters cast quite poorly, and the over-all movie pretty lame. I was more bored in two hours than I've ever been in the five hour-long version. If you're looking for a good one, I would recommend the 1995 A&E; TV serial.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love love love this movie! My kids get irritated everytime it comes on tv, because I have to watch it even though I own it on DVD. I watched the BBC version and, although I agree that it sticks closer to the book, I just prefer the acting in this movie so much better. I know the mother/sisters are supposed to be annoying, but the ones in the BBC version I couldn't even watch. I did like Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy, probably the only reason I watched because I love Colin Firth. But Matthew MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy is splendid! I LOVE his big blue eyes (you get to really see them in the rainy scene where he proposes to Elizabeth). And my favorite quote from him is, "You have bewitched me in body and soul, and I love, I love, I love you."Keira Knightley is one of my fave actresses, just loved her in Love Actually and the Pirates of the Caribbean movies (ironically, she plays an Elizabeth in the Pirates movies too). I loved Judi Dench's role in the movie. And really loved the interaction between Keira and Donald as daughter and father. Donald Sutherland played his part well! I could see that he loved Elizabeth above his other daughters. And Brenda Blethyn was so annoying as her mother. And her sisters Kitty and Lydia were just downright silly. Jane was the beautiful one, of course. And Elizabeth's confidante and best friend.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This set consists of:1 Widescreen version DVD1 Full-screen version DVD1 Full Soundtrack CD1 64-Page Production Photo Book (Previously only available in the UK)Exclusive to this set:1) The Politics of Dating- find out the differences between modern dating and dating in Austen's time through delightful interviews and film footage.2) Galleries of the 19th Century-Interactive photo galleries3) The Stately Homes of P&P-Explore; the film's beautiful homes and locations thru this interactive map.4) P&P; Family Tree-Discover more about the family links in P&P.;Special Features (also available on the single DVD version)-Commentary with Director Joe Wright-Conversations with the cast-Jane Austen-ahead of her time-A Bennett Family Portrait-HBO First Look: Pride and PrejudiceI bought the Widescreen DVD and the soundtrack when they first came out but someimtes I wished I had the full-screen version for some of the shots.  The CD was also purchased many times for Christmas gifts and my friends loved it, so this set would be a great gift for a P&P; Fan or for yourself.Personally, this is my favorite film version.  None of the acting is over the top.  Although it is not always accurate it will not dissapoint.  I am very pleased with each actor and how they viewed the character and their portrayl of each role.If you enjoyed the movie you will love this Collector's Edition!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Pride and Prejudice the book. I've read it a dozen times, so like most true fans, I would like movies about to stick true to the real story. But I appreciate this movie a lot. I've seen four different Pride and Prejudice movies and in all of them, I think Keira Knightley is just the perfect Elizabeth. She's the right age, the right look and seems to have the right spunk. I enjoyed the unraveling of Matthew MacFadyen's Darcy. I felt he did all he could with the character, given the time constraints. I did like Colin Firth's version but I felt Jennifer Ehle was way too old to be Elizabeth. Did I love Colin Firth's Darcy? Sure but he had the luxury of a mini-series to make women understand him better.Anyway, this movie is a quick P&P; fix, using some creative liberties to meet the challenge of a movie. But the cinematography is breathtaking, the music excellent and the cast is brilliant. I loved it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley's performance as Elizabeth is Feisty and Headstrong, as well as overall beautiful.This is a lovely version of this story on film, with terrific performances by Knightley, as well as  Matthew Macfadyen as Darcy, plus both the long suffering Brenda Blethyn, and Donald Sutherland as her parents... Sutherland's performance is positively awesome, especially very near the end, when he indeed brought tears to my eyes.Matthew Macfadyen is a wonderfully fine and always believable actor, making you feel his emotions as Darcy, in what is a near flawless performance.  Although some might say he's not as totally overall physically ''attractive'' as Colin Firth's earlier performance in the same role, in very many ways Macfadyen is.. indeed Darcy.See this film... If for nothing else to admire the ''rapid fire speed of speech'', and downright emotion packed scene that takes place between Knightley's and Macfadyen's characters in the pouring rain.Overall, a pure pleasure to watch, as I've done again and again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie must have been made quickly to make some fast money as it was so poorly thought out.  Darcy was the biggest disappointment as he looked half dead during the first half of the movie. Bingley was a very flat character and seemed more or less a deadbeat.  Mrs Bennet was not comical, but more bothersome and irritating. Mr. Bennett looked like a dirty old man.  My question is did the producer even read the book? I was so bored.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I own this DVD and the 1995 BBC TV production DVD with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.  The latter is superior in all respects IF you have actually read and appreciate Jane Austen and prefer authentic period detail and actors who resemble people from that period (not models).  That generally means those over 30 with some literary sophistication.  If you are under 30 and have not read Jane Austen, you will probably enjoy the Keira Knightley adaptation, which dummies down Jane Austen for the modern mass audience, features a cast that is prettier than talented, uses contemporary catch phrases and cliches, adds an element of sexuality not found in the novel, and completely misses the 19th century elegance of the landed gentry (pigs in the parlor, chickens on the front stoop? -- really!).  If you really want this travesty, I'll send you my copy for the price of postage.  Or better yet, read the novel -- and discover the difference between Hollywood melodrama and classic literature.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Ok, so here's the deal.  This movie is not completely true to the book.  If you are looking for that, I do suggest A&E's version.  However, this movie I don't think could have been totally faithful without also being 5 hours long, which is impossible for a theatrical release.  Also, many people have issues with the costumes, because they are not the traditional Regency clothes...but, this movie was set in the time that Jane Austen actually wrote Pride and Prejudice...not the years later when it was finally published, and certain characters are in fact in the true regency clothing such as Caroline Bingley to show how "en vogue" she is.  And yes, Elizabeth Bennet wears no bonnet and Aunt Catherine visits in the dead of night and not in the garden...but come on!  The same essential story is being told.  And of course the book is better, I should hope so.  If you want a bad version of Pride and Prejudice than look no further than the celebrated 1940 version starring Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier.  Not only do they change events from the book for no other reason than to make it more "Hollywood" (not, in fact, to consolidate a lengthy tale into a reasonable viewing time) but they also seem to change the time period to about 70 years later...to the late 1800's so that they could re-use Gone With the Wind costumes.  I am obsessed with Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice and have read all of her books repeatedly and I still love this movie, although I admit there are some things that they changed that were not just simply for time sake...such as Mrs. Bennet being made to be a much more tolerable character in the movie  and also the esteem of her husband, which in the book is not so favorable...but other than that I think it is one of the best remakes made for theatrical release.  Oh, and Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen) is brilliant in this role.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Ingrid Heyn "No man is an Iland, intire of it...
review_text: There is no denying that turning a book as rich in characterisation and plot as "Pride and Prejudice" into a film is a dicey proposition. It's no potboiler with forgettable dialogue. Its characters are not two-dimensional. The story threads interweave and there is delicious wit and rather wicked social commentary from the pen of Jane Austen. How can a film adaptation hope to capture all of that?Of course, it cannot.But need a film adaptation transgress as heinously and thoroughly as this one does against the intentions of the author?There were some inexplicable blunders that don't make sense at all: Darcy actually CAME INTO ELIZABETH BENNET'S BEDROOM to give her the letter he wrote (inexcusable blunder - this is simply inconceivable); the Bennet dining room had servants serving the food in far too small a room (English country houses do not have dining rooms of such miniature dimensions, and certainly a normal meal rather than a grand occasion for a family of the straitened circumstances the film attempts to portray would not include servants standing at the ready to serve. It seems as though the director has melded the serving practises of larger country houses with the idea of a poorer yet still genteel family, but that is entirely historically inaccurate); Darcy was wandering about with his shirt undone and no cravat (as sexy-looking as that is, it's so inauthentic as to constitute an unforgivable faux pas); the ball held by Bingley had far too many people to constitute a country ball held to get to know his neighbours (again, it seems the director is going by vaguely and inaccurately held ideas of English country habits - could some real research not have been done?); the entire embarrassing and ridiculous scene with Elizabeth Bennet lasciviously viewing and caressing naked statues could only strike a 20th or 21st century American audience as appropriate; and Darcy proposing in the rain... (as anachronistic as a watch on the wrist of Michelangel's David); and an utterly bewildering moment occurs when Lady Catherine de Bourgh arrives at the Bennet's house in the middle of the night. Unless she came with urgent news, she would have been neither heard nor admitted at such an hour, nor would a gentleman have dreamed of appearing in front of a lady in his nightclothes. Those are only some of the ill-conceived and inappropriate moments.Let us pass over the strange family dynamics - clearly neither the director nor the actors bothered to read the novel in order to discover the complex relationships involved. For one thing, Mr and Mrs Bennet's marital relationship was clearly written by Jane Austen to be the worst mismatch in history; Mr Bennet is intended to be so disgusted and bored by most of his family (wife and daughters, except for Elizabeth and Jane) that he can find refuge only in perceiving them as amusing, and hiding in his study to avoid having to deal with them.Let us pass then to the casting. Keira Knightley is a lovely-looking young actress, but the character of Elizabeth Bennet is beyond her. She does not have the complexity to understand such a character, and her acting skills are not at present sufficient to convey the depth of such a richly drawn character. However, for the purpose of this film, the characters are completely altered anyway. In terms, then, of this film, within its confines (and not in respect of Jane Austen's Elizabeth Bennet), Ms Knightley was perfectly adequate, although she looked odd at times. Partly this is because her thinness was highlighted rather than flattered, and partly it's because her hair was so very strangely arranged. I could not understand the "washerwoman" hairdo, I confess - it is historically inappropriate for the period. If the purpose was to make Elizabeth Bennet look less beautiful than Jane Bennet, a very strange idea has occurred. Elizabeth is certainly not plain in the novel. She has a loveliness that is characterised more by her liveliness than feature-by-feature, but she is considered by all who know her to be one of the prettiest girls in the county. Jane is considered by the regularity of her features to be the most beautiful, but the whole Bennet family is known for their beauty (save for Mary). How has this been translated to mean that Elizabeth is not lovely-looking? Why the insistence in this film on downplaying Keira Knightley's looks? Simply because Mr Darcy does not instantly find Elizabeth Bennet beautiful...? And because Miss Caroline Bingley and her sister will not do justice to her looks? The difference between Elizabeth and Jane is one of kind, not of quantity. Both the director and some of the viewers seem not to have realised that.The Darcy looked beautiful, and it's not really the actor's fault that he was not conveying Jane Austen's Darcy. Again, really I blame the scriptwriter who did such an appalling hatchet job, and the director who seems to have thought of this film in terms of making the cinematography look beautiful but eschewed any care with regard to historical detail or the requirements of the story itself.The dialogue flip-flops from modern "I'm writing an historical novel" style to authentic Jane Austen - and the difference between the two styles is embarrassing. Unless a scriptwriter is prepared to enmesh him/herself into the writing style of the period, complete with an understanding of the grammar of the English language as spoken at the time, and specifically the style employed by Jane Austen, such an obvious clash is bound to occur. And furthermore, a modern idea of dialogue can only create further flaws in the style of the dialogue. It simply doesn't work unless the scriptwriter is prepared to let go of a 21st century idea of how the characters OUGHT to be. If he/she isn't prepared to do that, the scriptwriter had better stick to modern dramas.What a pity that the scriptwriter felt it necessary to make Darcy "misunderstood" rather than truly "proud". This reduces the title of the book (and thus the title of the film) to meaningless drivel. In the novel, Darcy really WAS a proud man - he acknowledges it, and through his love for Elizabeth and the travails in their relationship, he found within himself a more proper understanding of how he could maintain his sense of self yet become more approachable. Elizabeth, too, acknowleged in the novel that her prejudices led her astray, and she, through knowing Darcy and through the troubles of her own family, comes to learn herself more thoroughly. "Until this moment I never knew myself", she says - but she does not say it in the film. Indeed, she could not - for in the film, she too is just "misunderstood". The characters do not grow and develop in this film - because, like a Mills & Boon romance novel, they don't need to. The characters are two-dimensional - but most viewers don't seem to notice that.To compare this film to the splendid 6-part adaptation with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth is to compare a somewhat battered meringue with a superb full-sized gateau. The BBC series had everything right; this film sadly does not.I suppose the main flaw of this film was its obviousness. Moments such as "sexy open-shirted man strides through the mist, his cloak flapping in the wind behind him" abound. Oh dear. Very, very Mills-and-Boonish. The lack of subtlety is everywhere... and the same holds true for the character dynamics. Instead of the subtle 18th century character interplay, the audience is served with lashings of modernised ideas of love sans any of the biting social judgements that add spice to Jane Austen's excellent writing.By the end of this film (indeed, fifteen minutes into the film), I no longer cared whether Darcy and Elizabeth ever married. I could not consider them real. They had no claim upon my sympathy. What a contrast to my emotional involvement in the BBC series!I recommend this only for viewers who enjoy soap operas, or for people who don't care about historical accuracy or subtle performances. Oh, and it may also please those who find Jane Austen's actual novel too difficult to read.
summary: The Harlequin Mills & Boon version of Pride And Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is one of the best period pieces and adaptations that I have seen.  I loved every moment of it-- almost more than reading the book.  Not only is the movie wonderful, the soundtrack and score are so appropriate and serene.  I downloaded the soundtrack because of the energy and peace that the score evokes in every scene of the movie.  This film is well done, well acted, and should be an essential in every video library.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I admit it.  I'm totally biased to the BBC miniseries with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle as well.  But I've also read the book enough times (more than 20 times over less than 10 years) to feel this version of Jane Austen's book is a terrible reflection of her work.  I felt the casting of almost everyone in the movie was completely wrong - something that perhaps might not have appeared so bad if the actors in question had bothered to read the book themselves to know how they should be portraying their part.Matthew MacFadyen was rather unlikeable - he spent the entire time sneering at everyone and everything and by the end of the movie, one was left wondering how on earth Elizabeth decided he was a nice person.  Apart from the one scene between Elizabeth and Darcy where he proposes to her the first time, there was absolutely no chemistry between them whatsoever.  Keira played Elizabeth kind of OK, but her speedy change from hate of Darcy to love was just bizarre.  I'm not a big fan of Keira's anyway, and I felt that she was very wrong for the part.  And Mr Bingley, who was portrayed as a kind of moron... I was horrified.All relationships that were so well defined in the novel were completely underdone in this movie version; the story did not flow at all well.  It's like the writers closed their eyes, flicked through the book, and randomly pointed their finger at a page to decide the storyline.  As someone who has read the book so many times, at least I knew what happened in the "missing" sections of the movie so my mind could make sense of what it WASN'T seeing - I can't imagine anyone who has never read the book would understand why Elizabeth and Darcy got together in the end.  They had very few scenes together and again, no chemistry at all.At the end of the day, one must consider that this IS a Hollywood flick after all - you can't expect much from them and have to take it all with a grain of salt. As a big Austen fan, it was a hard thing to do with this movie (as it was with Gwyneth Paltrow's "Emma").  As a relatively entertaining flick, I give it the thumbs up - while Pride and Prejudice is my favourite Austen novel and this version is... well, terrible... I'm always a sucker for a romantic film!!  As a good adaptation of Jane Austen's novel however, I give it two big thumbs down.If you're into light entertainment - buy it.  If you're a hardcore Austen fan expecting anything even remotely as breathtakingly awesome as the BBC Firth/Ehle version - stay well away from this one!
summary: Not as good as it could have been...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a review of the 2010 blu ray release.  I also own this movie on DVD, but decided to upgrade when the blu ray went on sale.  All I can say is I am glad I did not pay any more for the blu ray.  The title menu is a disaster.  The graphics and sound effects annoyingly remind one of powerpoint templates.  Who wants to feel like they are in the middle of a conference when watching a movie?  Whoever orchestrated the menu is not an artist, which stands in obvious contrast with the film. I would recommend waiting for the next blu ray release, if you are simply upgrading from DVD to blu ray.  Yes, the menu is that annoying!!! The film itself is excellent and keeps me from deducting more than 1 whole star.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this film and saw it several times at the cinema. The cast is wonderful, the music, everything but THAT ending.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Would Jane Austen approve of this use of her book?  Ask a silly question.  In the protracted pre-dawn of the audio-visual age that we call the nineteenth century, literature, as in our day, could be conceived as a means of making people think, but never could it guarantee where thoughts might wander.  The whole idea was to set thoughts in motion, to stir the imagination into creating self-styled images that reflected the author's words as readers experienced them.  A do-it-yourself motion picture.I think that Jane Austen would find our reflections every bit as entertaining as her own.  As ever, the character of human nature is timeless, much as we delightin exploring the nature of her characters, and have done for generations, beyond anything that she could have anticipated.I am impressed with this film at all levels.  The cinematography is outstanding, and beautifully understated, as is the acting.  Historically, it is as true to the period as anything I've seen.  It's also a product of its own time, and the pace runs accordingly.  Parts of the original book are suggested more than played outon screen.  Still, there is something to be said for brevity in telling a story, especially if it's a good one.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Is it possible for a film to get better and better with repeated viewings? I originially caught Pride and Prejudice in the theaters when released, and was surprisingly delighted at the adaptation presented before me. Then, I promptly forgot it with the Caoptes and Brokeback Mountains of the world. Upon it's release on DVD, I absolutely fell in love with this movie, and again and again, and now regard it as a mere masterpiece; a cinematic feast.I'm not an Austen purest. In fact, I shudder to admit on Amazon.com that I have not even read her. So any comparison of the book to the movie would be lost on me. I also have not witnessed the BBC comprehensive version of Pride, to which many compare this movie. So the disruptive ending of the movie, which sometimes seems to upset the Austen purests, and the wonderful performance of Colin Firth, which dominates the BBC version, are unknown to me. I watch this with virgin eyes.And of course, I delight in what I see. A story of a young woman, one of four girls, destined in early 1800's England to marry, but with strong will and mind of her own. She bristles against the bristle-y Mr. Darcy, hard edged, unsocial (much like me, minus the money), and like flint and steel, tremendously spark and start a fire which burns through the film, brightly, intensely, passionately. The moments of confrontation, and lack thereof, between Elizabeth and Darcy are juicy, palpable, and true, and thus drive this plot honestly.The performances astound. I've caught all of the leading actress roles this year, and I must say, Kiera Knightly's performance ranks as superior. She is the film; simply put. Should another actress play Elizabeth, the film would have lost its soulforce. By all rights, she should have marched up to the stage to claim her reward (possibly only surpassed by the comparable Felicity Huffman's role in Transamerica). In turn, Matthew Macfadyen's harsh Mr. Darcy melts before our eyes and on the screen before Elizabeth, and the glacial melt is amazing. Where was his nomination? Supporting actors Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn were born to play Elizabeth's honest, supportive parents. And Tom Hollander as the bumbling, ill-fated suitor Mr. Collins almost steals the movie with his comic pathos. Fine performances from all.Adding to this mix, Joe Wright's amazing, amazing, amazing direction. Most of the film's enjoyment comes from his camera placement and work. Just watch the scene at the second party, where the camera moves throughout the party, and manages to tell several parts of the story seemlessly at once. Wright tells on the commentary how it took hours to set up the shot; the results impress and delight. He shaped this movie, which could have been another bland period piece, into something rich, delightful, multi-layered, and dare I say.... modern?Pride and Prejudice is a film that in many years, people will be popping into their video players of the future; to study fine filmmaking, to learn from solid performances, to watch young love, and to enjoy the exploits of Elizabeth and Darcy, their machinations of love, and the persistance of desire.Bravo!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having watched the movie, read the book and watched the movie again all in the same week I am pleased to say that the movie did the book justice; which is not a compliment I often bestow on such movies.  Each actor was perfect in their representation and I will certainly enjoy watching this movie again and again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: 1. This movie is much better than my wife and I expected.  To be sure, there are big departures from Jane Austen's book and the tale seems tailored to a modern audience.  Nevertheless, we're giving this production five stars, because of its overall impact and flow.  The acting and location shots are first-rate and key scenes are so beautifully done.  We particularly liked the scene near the end where Elizabeth entreats her father so she might marry Mr. Darcy.  She reveals how Darcy is the one who bailed out the Bennett family from Mr. Wickham's debts and also arranged for sister Lydia's marriage. This ending seems more convincing than other versions we've seen because it registers with Mr. Bennett that Darcy is the one who saved the family.  If you look it up, the bail-out revelation is in the book.2. Viewers may want to turn on English subtitles in places so as to get all the dialogue.  This is a British production making it hard for we Americans to follow at times.  An idea raised by another reviewer is also a good one, namely, to turn on the director's commentary when you have time to re-view the movie.  A lot of things come out you would not know otherwise, making this a deeper film than what you first saw.  Not all the director's comments are profound but when he tells you he devoted 2 years of his life to the film (morning, noon, and night) you need to pay attention.  Also, we're told why Elizabeth and her aunt and uncle are given a tour of sculptures at Pemberley rather than seeing portraits of the Darcy family.  Sure, the scene departs from the book, as so many other things do, but it's awfully well done.3. This movie runs only 2 hours, so its character development pales in comparison with miniseries that were done by the BBC in 1979 and by A&E; in 1995.  On DVD, these productions run 4 and 5 hours, respectively.  To really understand the story line most viewers should see one or both of these and even read the book.  Key characters like Wickham and Mr. & Mrs. Collins barely have cameo roles in the 2005 movie which is a pity.  Also, time constraints may have precluded showing more on the special relationship between Mr. Bennett and his second daughter, Elizabeth, who may really be his alter ego.4. In other respects, it's apparent that the producer and director wanted to stage this movie a lot differently than previous versions.  The Bennett family is seen living a very rustic life with pigs, geese, and dogs underfoot.  This is a major departure from life discussed in the book and depicted in other film and TV versions.  This movie is set in the year, 1797, not 1813, as previously understood.  In another departure, the opening ballroom scene is far more informal and earthy than what we've seen before. But it has an infectious energy that prepares you for the rest of the show.  Yes, this version is going to be different from other ones!5. For most of the movie, Elizabeth runs around in very casual attire with her hair wild and unkempt.  All the while she states her opinions freely and is not bashful about offending others, including her poor mother.  In many ways, Lizzy seems like a wild animal that may appeal to Darcy's basic instincts. This is another big departure from the book and from past productions where the eldest Bennett girls are seen as well-dressed and presentable, desperate as they are to find good husbands.  The "car wreck" scene where Elizabeth rejects Darcy and his first marriage proposal may be the most powerful moment in the movie.  Darcy, despite his imposing size and presence, appears lucky Elizabeth didn't have a club nearby when she rejected him.  What a contrast to the second proposal where Darcy stammers out his love for her and Elizabeth accepts him while gently taking his hand.  Brilliantly done!6. Music has been an important element in past productions of Pride and Prejudice and it is here, as well.  The Baroque-era music played at the balls is our favorite kind.  Also, the haunting piano theme heard throughout the show is extremely well done and played.  Bravo!7. Although the casting of Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett may have raised some eyebrows we thought he did quite well, especially at the end where he talks to Elizabeth about Darcy's second proposal.  Keira Knightley is marvelous as the untamed Elizabeth, Mr. Bennett's favorite daughter.  Matthew MacFadyen is a revelation as Darcy.  In truth, Matthew looks like such a physical specimen he might have playing linebacker for the Green Bay Packers.  What's just as amazing is that when he speaks he sounds like an educated, British gentleman.  Actors portraying Mrs. Bennett, Jane Bennett, Mr. & Mrs. Collins, Lady Catherine DeBourgh, Mr. & Miss Bingley, and the other Bennett sisters were fine, too.  Mr. Bingley did seem a bit foppish at times, but in contrast to MacFadyen's Darcy, it's not surprising.8. At the end, Elizabeth seems to blame herself completely for misjudging Darcy.  He comes off then as pride-free and irresistible.  Some might feel this is taking one too many liberties with Jane Austen's message.  Actually, Darcy has been changed and humbled by Elizabeth's rejection of his first proposal.  It takes several months for a transformation to be completed and for Darcy to do heroic deeds.  He then becomes acceptable to her and us.  The movie's producer and director may have been aware of this fact but with only 2 hours to work with simply couldn't show it.  Or, maybe they just wanted to stress that rich people have their problems, too?9. Comparisons to the other versions of Pride and Prejudice are difficult.  For us, the wit and elegance of the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version from 1995, may never be surpassed.  Also, the 1979 miniseries with Elizabeth Garvie, David Rintoul, and Judy Parfitt has special moments.  The 1940 version with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier deserves attention as well, even though it takes even more liberties with Jane Austen's story than the others.  In style and substance, the 2005 version is quite different from earlier ones but it is effective and entertaining.  Our sense is to get and study them all.  The timeless story and characters make for a masterpiece in English literature and a study of human nature.  If nothing else, the happy ending of the 2005 version is classic.10. Special features on the 2005, DVD include interviews with the producer, the director, and the main characters.  There is some repetition, but their comments offer more insights into why this story is so appealing. Too bad other productions haven't offered interviews of the leading stars in this way.  Maybe we'll see them some day in a super-gold, Nth anniversary, collectors' edition?
summary: Not the 1995 version, but still very well done

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The parts are greater than the whole with this film. Heaps of fun, a young tone as if Miss Marianne Dashwood had read the novel and dreamt over it. I appreciated the late 18th century setting, and the rustic genteel poverty of the Bennett family. Putting Mr Bennett and Eliza under a sharper light, and Darcy under a softer one was also appreciated. Everyone else were treated like people, and not caricatures. M McFayden's every movement and gesture, every flinch and flicker across his face tells us about Darcy's striving rationality, and its shift towards Elizabeth's person. K Knightly's radiance plays Eliza Bennett's nascent rationality; womanly and in danger of being deformed by her father's sardonic view of life and people, and stunted by her mother's limited views, with the air of an over ripe snarky middle schooler who is brought to adulthood by real love. The rest of the cast is superb, and supports the couple's story wonderfully. The scrambled, and sometime garbled text is annoying, and Knightly's tendency towards model face can be distracting. Very enjoyable dancing and dining scenes as per Austen. Pax,jb.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not giving this film two stars because it is a terrible movie, but rather for its lack of devotion towards the novel.  I am a lover of the BBC version and book, not only because its well-acted but thoroughly sticks to the story.  In this film,The language and monologues are so altered, and I'm afraid to admit that this is a result of our lack of appreciation for the old english language, and a yearning for a less intricate way of speaking.  It's as if our generation needs subtitles for our own language! And This is coming from a youth. In this new version of Pride and Prejudice I couldn't help but be diverted from the manner in which Kiera Knighlty delivers her lines.  That's the thing...they are just lines.  Not only are they rushed, but lack any substance that would induce me to love her as a character.  Elizabeth Bennet is supposed to be bold, smart, witty, and admirable.  Kiera Knightly sort of betrays her as a girl who can't hold her tongue. I surmise that is why i was surprised to see how Darcy falls in love with her so quickly.  Don't get me wrong, there are some good elements that this movie has to offer.  The scenery and music are exquisite, in fact I believe that these two very things tell the story more the actors do, and that's swell.  This movie is loved by everyone, understandably so, because it gives a more romantic approach.  I have to admit, it is appealing, and beautiful to watch, but it is not Austin.
summary: A Classic Novel Turned into a Contemporary CROWD Pleaser

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It was hard to buy the DVD in stone stores so I was happy to find it in here.DVD came in perfect condition. No problems.I read the book recently and I heard that the movie is great as well. And it is true. I enjoyed it very much!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being an annual reader of Pride and Prejudice and a lover of Jane Austen's humor and insight, I found this film to be at best disappointing. Austen's humor was lost in translation to say the least. Elizabeth Bennet was morphed into a dreamy eyed, slightly naughty, tousled haired temptress. Her father, Mr. Bennet, was, despite the acting talents of Donald Sutherland, transformed into a frousled, woolly, bumbling father who simply didn't know how to be a parent. All that aside, the photography is lovely, the costumes are beautiful, and the soundtrack is delightful, but this simply isn't Jane Austen. For a proper film version of this wonderful book try the A&E version starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle or the BBC. The A&E version may six one-hour episodes, but, with minor alterations, it's magnificently produced, witty, beautifully acted, and absolutely true to the book and entirely in keeping with Austen's writing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: From the first moment I saw this film I loved it. Kiera Knightley is fantastic and so convincing. This version of the Jane Austen classic gives such a fresh view of the story and the music was so lovely and enchanting. This film was the first time I ever heard of Jane Austen. I loved it so much, I became a fan of all of Jane Austen's stories. I can absolutlely say this is my favorite movie of all. It's such a deeply moving love story and I like how it reflects a lot of the things we feel in real life. This film was so visually and audibly beautiful and I never get tired of watching it. The colors, the lighting, the costumes, and the English countryside were lovely. I highly recommend it. It's clean and yet deals with a very adult issue: never judge your true love by his or her cover.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I first read P&P in college and some years later was thrilled to see the wonderful adaptation starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth.  It was so good and followed the book so well that I wondered what was the purpose of remaking this story and in such an inferior way. I do not believe that I am being nitpicking when I say that at the time of the story, women would never have been seen with such messy hair and clothing.  Even the poorer class ones (which the Bennets most certainly were NOT) would never have lived and dressed the way they are depicted in this ridiculous film.  Pigs in the yard and such dirty surroundings!  Really!  It looked more like Tobacco Road than the home of British gentry!  The characters also were badly interpreted especially Mr. Bingley who was a real wuss and one wonders what did Jane see in him besides his money.  Did screen writers or director even crack the book? They certainly did not study the history and social customs of the time. I thought this movie might at least be passable, but I found it abysmal and stupid!
summary: Why was this movie even made?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I absolutely love this movie. I watch it literally every time it comes on tv. My friend just so happened to need to watch it for a school project so I rented it for him. It worked out perfectly. It was soo easy to do !

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, I'm a total Janeite who adores Austen and all her work. I probably re-read each of her novels at least once a year, and I'm a high school English teacher. So I find the 1995 BBC mini-series to be the Holy Grail of Austen movies. But this one has its charms. I am not a big Keira Knightley fan, and I found her Lizzy to be less spunky and more moody than in the novel. (The director keeps showing Lizzy alone, staring into space. I suppose that should make us think she's deep.She's much more cheerful and sociable in the book.) Also the director went for a "grubby" look in this movie. Everybody has greasy hair and appears to need a shower. I guess he figures nobody bathed much in those days. The story is a bare bones version of the book that hits the high points quickly, but the movie is clearly more interested in being beautiful and poetic, and there it succeeds. The piano music in this film is lyrical and moving, and the movie has lots of interesting visual images. The director does a nifty thing with the characters' hands that I really liked. And this Darcy (while no Colin Firth) is not too shabby. Matthew Macfadyen seems to be portraying a "kinder, gentler" Darcy who seems more shy that gruff, but he's such a handsome guy and has such a gorgeous, deep voice, that I enjoyed looking at him and listening to him. So my overall impression is that I liked it for what it was, a quicker more stylized version of a wonderful story. As a footnote, I'll add that my students fall into two camps when I show them this movie: girls who fall in love with Darcy and adore the film, and kids of both genders who say they hated it because the story moved so fast they couldn't tell what was happening.
summary: Lovely but not that true to the novel

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While I thoroughly enjoyed the A&E version, I always felt that the actress who played Charlotte seemed too pretty to be stuck with Mr. Collins. In this version, Charlotte's speech really was in accordance with the time period. I felt her desperation and relief when she told Lizzie the news of her engagement. I thought that was an extremely enlightening scene and telling of the time.
summary: Poor Charlotte, if only she was more handsome

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a huge fan of Jane Austen. I also read numerous books on Regency/Historical and Scottish Historical Romance. Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth are featured by many authors in sequels to Pride and Prejudice of which have given many insights to what different could have been a possible future for them if Ms. Austen had had a longer life to write such sequels herself. All were most enjoyable.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a fantastic movie that I have seen over and over again. This version of Pride and Prejudice is on my list of the best movies I have ever seen.  Even my 15 year old son liked this movie! Pride and Prejudice is a period romance set in the 1700's in England. You will see incredible houses, beautiful scenery, and the sights and sounds as they may have been witnessed in the 1700's.  The acting by Kiera Knightley as Elizabeth Bennett and Matthew MacFayden as Mr. Darcy is awesome.  The supporting cast does a fantastic job of carrying the story line too.  I already have this version of Pride and Prejudice on DVD as well as the music CD from the movie.  I can't wait until this movie is available for download onto my IPOD!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really detest Knightley. I've never liked her even though I've desperately wanted to. Her quirks and mannerism's all seem to scream "Look at me! Look at me!" in almost a Lydia like fashion, pardon the pun. The Darcy in this one was good, loved his eyes, but I just couldn't get past Knightley. There were redeeming qualities about this though. Donald Sutherland as her father was excellent and I especially enjoyed the final scene between he and his daughter when he's asking her if she really likes Darcy. He tears up and it's entirely believable. I did not like the scene at the end when Darcy and Lizzie finally declare their love for each other. Instead of answering, in this version, Knightly takes his hand and kisses it. I'm very much convinced, after reading several Jane Austen's and books during this era, that this would not have happened. There is just too much propriety here during this age for that. Took me out of the story, and because of it, can't recommend it.[...]
summary: This Movie is Only for Knightly Fans...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I ended the year 2005 reading "Pride & Prejudice" for the first time, and I completely loved the novel. While I was reading it, I was waiting to see when the movie would come to a nearby theater. Much to my disappointment, it did not come, though it was promised to appear.So instead, as I finished the novel, I preordered  the movie from Amazon.com, since I anticipated truly enjoying this film.I loved it. Having just read the book, it felt like walking into the novel itself and seeing the characters come to life.I highly recommend this movie for all Jane Austen fans!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: We swore not to compare it to the BBC miniseries. You can't improve on perfection. So, after hearing the rave reviews, we decided to throw caution to the wind and watch it, after swearing never, not once, to compare between the two.All in all, it wasn't a bad movie. The main problem lies in the confusing storyline which simply cannot be covered in such a short time. If I hadn't such an intimate knowledge of P&P; before the movie, I would have been quite lost. This affects character developement and relationships. There are moments of quiet and pretty music but very little interaction between Elizabeth and Darcy.The feel of old-England society was lost, which leads to a lot of confusion. Why is it so terrible that Darcy won't dance with Elizabeth? Why are her sisters such an embarrasment when the parties they are in are as raucus as themselves? Being familiar with the book, I already knew, but the impact of the embarassing and moving moments were lost because the society that made them embarassing and moving were gone. Also, Elizabeth going out into the rain to get herself a towel off the line? *shakes head* The Bennets are not poor; they happen to be quite well-to-do, the only thing they don't have is dowries for the girls. You can have a huge income and not any money saved up. And admiring nude statues in Darcy's home? Uhh.. that's not right.The society portrayed in this movie was not the stuffy, prissy life of the upper-middle class, but more suited to the lower. Perhaps they meant to liven it up a bit by showing us the nitty-gritty side to life, but instead they spoiled the feeling of the whole society. Elizabeth and Jane giggling in bed? I don't know.. that's just not.. English.Keira Knightly is not a bad Elizabeth Bennet. She did justice to the role. Darcy talked to fast and was more quiet and laid back than arrogant and imposing. Also, he wasn't good-looking at all. Part of his personna is his hot animal attraction! Wickham was not only very likeable but gorgeous! That's not right! Darcy should be more cute! (Ok, enough juvenile complaints) Mr.Collins was.. not stupid. He was almost.. conniving. And handsome, too, if short. I really couldn't understand why Elizabeth could object so strongly to marry him especially considering her family's condition. It seemed.. selfish of her. Again, this is only looking at the movie as though I had never read the book before.THe movie was pretty, with beautiful music and nice acting. It had its good parts and carried the essence of the story pretty well. However, it left much to be desired and the characters weren't Jane Austen's own. I would have to recommend the BBC version.. the book there is played to perfection. But this is a good movie for your weekends as well.
summary: Meh.. nothing spectacular.. beautiful music, though..

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have not had the pleasure of watching the mini series but i dare say i found the movie riveting and was left asking for more.I will definately look out for the mini series.It is a fantatic movie,had me twirling my hair and blushing watching the tension between Mr Darcy and Lizzy.You can tell am a sap for love stories.I particularly like this one for its Lord bless the lack of non-sensical scenes and parts that more often riddle a film making them rather tiresome to watch or follow.This is a must watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I still consider the 1995 miniseries to be THE definitive version of Pride & Prejudice.Still, this new version does have things about it I prefer to any other version. Donald Sutherland in this version I find to be the best Mr. Bennet of all versions.No matter what version you watch, you hear Mrs. Bennet repeatedly comment on how much prettier Jane is than Lizzy. In the '95 version Lizzy is 10 times prettier than Jane and therefore Mrs. Bennet's comments just make you scratch your head and say "what!?". The Jane in the new version is such a beauty that you can accept these comments even though you may not agree with them. The Jane in this version is also more fitting in age. The Jane in the '95 version seems to old for the part, even though Susannah Harker acted the part with perfection.I like the new Wickham a bit better too since in the new one he is much more handsome. Someone could indeed picture Lizzy choosing him over Darcy for looks alone and therefore could indeed be considered a threat. The Wickham in the '95 version isn't nearly as good-looking as Mr. Darcy and therefore less of a threat.As far as Mr. Bingley goes, I loved both the new and old '95 versions of him. Unlike most people I like the new Mr. Bingley better. He is more shy and timid in the new version and this to me makes him more endearingAs far as comparing the 2 Lizzies, I think that Keira Knightley is every bit as a talented actress as Jennifer Ehle is in the '95 version. With that said every now and then an actor or actress comes along who was born to play a part. As much as Keanu Reeves isn't the best actor out there , he was born to play the part of Neo in The Matrix. Nobody could have done it better. I feel the same way about Jennifer Ehle in the mini series. While Miss Knightley is just as talented and did a great job in the remake, Jennifer Ehle was simply born for this part and truly embodies Lizzy. I don't think anyone could have done a better job than her.The same goes for Colin Firth as Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy. While Matthew Macfadyen did a WONDERFUL job in the remake, Colin Firth was simply born the part. He IS Darcy.All-in-all as a whole there is no version that can compare to the '95 mini series, which is truly a masterpiece. Still, the new version is well worth buying and offers a refreshing take on this story. I would even go as far as saying that the new version is my favorite movie of the year !I rate the '95 version 10 stars out of 10 , and this new version 9 stars out of 10. Buy them both!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have watched this movie at least 6 times and still cry at the ending. Though very different from the beloved miniseries, this is a powerful blend of cinematography, a lovely story, strong characters and beautiful music. Donald Sutherland's Mr. Bennet has got to be my favorite of his roles ever. I love Brenda Blethyn as Mrs Bennet; and Tom Hollander is suitably annoying as Mr. Collins. Kelly Reilly is almost snakelike as Caroline Bingley. Of course, the two principle characters are very good. Keira Knightley is saucy, and I love the scenes with Judi Dench. Matthew Macfadyen is a haughty and yummy, Mr. Darcy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After 310 reviews already posted here, I doubt you want one more.  But as an avid A&E; miniseries P&P; fan I felt I needed to add my own positive review about this brisk adaptation.  The pacing was certainly quick (when Charlotte announced that she was marrying Collins after only 30 minutes I knew this was going to be a quicker ride than I was used to!), but the writers kept all the highlights and were able to piece together a refreshing version.  It's kind of like the Cliff's Notes version for those that want a quick taste of Austen without having to settle in for the 6-hour Firth/Ehle miniseries.A quick note about MacFadyen, portraying Darcy.  I was prepared to dislike him entirely as Darcy, given my propensity for Firth's portrayal.  However, I discovered that my two favorite scenes in this version were the very two scenes that are the most important to the Darcy/Lizzy relationship:  His first declaration of love and eventual insult of her family followed by his second declaration in the meadow.  In both of those scenes MacFadyen was brilliant and I much preferred his awkward announcements over Colin Firth's brashness (sacrilege for most, I know).Very well done!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Many may find my review "prejudiced" due to my being an avid fan of the book, the 1939 version and the BBC 1995 version - but I urge you to carefully consider the reasons for my EXTREMELY LOW opinion of the 2005 production below:1. I call it a "production" rather than an "adaptation" because this movie in no way resembles the spirit, the cleverness, nor the principle of the book. Jane Austen wrote a story based on the social conventions of her day and interlaced her descriptions of the setting, the characters and their behaviors with the amused observations of a woman who sharply recognizes the dynamics of human interaction shrouded behind the cloak of manners. This book, in fact, is described as being a masterful "comedy of manners", and is celebrated as such along with all Jane Austen works. Pride and Prejudice (the book) is a triumphant social commentary of what lies beneath the manners of upper and middle class English people - the comedic, the sweet, the nasty, the ambitious, the heart-broken...and the passionate. This production took liberties with the time period (changing it from late 19th century to the late 18th century), thereby taking Austen's nuanced observations of social mores during her time completely out of the equation. Then, to add insult to injury, the film makers did not bother to make any commentary of their own regarding the social dynamics of that time. With this, they completely broke the spirit of the book.2. Elizabeth Bennett as a character in the book represents the intelligence, the spirit and the liveliness of Jane Austen herself during her time. Many of the witty observations of the character were completely lost in translation within the 2005 production. Keira Knightly did a fine job at playing the character she was given, but this Elizabeth Bennett is decidedly NOT the beloved character that was so finely crafted by its original author. I wouldn't be surprised if the actress eventually admits to playing this version with a heavy heart (not to mention Brenda Blethyn, Donald Sutherland, Jena Malone and Judi Dench - if they, as any truly literary person, read the original story, they would be scandalized with this production's one-note view of their characters as well).3. The dialogue was atrociously tampered with within this production. Much of the important, clever, witty and profound dialogue found within the book was ruthlessly cut in favor of the film makers desire to present sweeping landscapes of the pristine English countryside. Is this the commentary that they longed to make in this film? That the cinematography (along with the swells of music as the stags ran by) is even more beautiful and more noteworthy than the characters themselves?!!! If I took the time to count the frames of film that were allocated towards such non-consequential footage, I'm sure I'd find that a good 70% of the movie was spent staring at the sun over a mountainside. Capital offense! Then, the film makers presumed to add their own dialogue - and it was an inept attempt at that. The dialogue added was flat, simple and inartistic - designed to "spell out" the unfolding of the story's events. This was a clear indication of the film makers lack of confidence in the literary sensibilities of today's moviegoers - instead of presenting a witty, masterful and intelligent version we can all get behind, they delivered a watered-down, dreary version that is pumped full of romantic, visual imagery.4. This production, quite simply, dishonors the spirit of Jane Austen. The film makers had no intention of honoring, or celebrating the brilliance of this author's work - instead they sought to exploit it to pack as many Austen fans (through the shameless promotion of this film as being an "adaptation") and Keira Knightly fans into the theaters as possible. They repackaged the original story as a sweeping romantic drama in a veiled attempt to capitalize on the "Titanic" angle, and put their own "youthful" spin on a classic by making the characters exhibit attitudes and behaviors that are more like the young people of today. Rather than mannerly and dignified, the youthful characters in this production are sullen, caustic, petulant and self-absorbed. There was absolutely no room for subtlety when conveying their thoughts, opinions and emotions. Yet another unforgivable digression from the classic Austen version.I could go on and on about the dissatisfaction with this 2005 production, but I think the points made above will do. Those who truly want to learn more about the fantastic story upon which this production is supposedly based, I recommend reading the reviews of the Jane Austen book and eventually, when time allows, reading the book itself. And as far as a film adaptation goes, you absolutely cannot go wrong with the BBC production - one that truly honors Jane Austen and is in keeping with the spirit of the book...and the spirit of the author.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a very attractive film.  Attractive stars, attractive sets, attractive story.  As a period romance it is a fine and entertaining film.  But it is not Jane Austen.  In fact, if you weren't already well versed in the plot of Pride and Prejudice, I don't know that you'd get it from this film.  Austen wrote with an 18th century sensibility, not a Romantic Age one.  And although the film has an 18th c. setting feel - a bit of the country raunch of Tom Jones - it is not the setting Austen wrote. Her characters did not wallow in pig slop.  Most of her wit is swamped by misty morning ramblings of the young stars, caught in glowing close-ups - time better spent on the plot and dialogue.  Classic comic characters are given short shrift and played with far too much seriousness or sympathy.  The all important sub-plot, which explains the sisters dilemma, flashes by so fast that many may miss its significance, particularly in light of today's mores. But then adequate development might detract from the time needed for all those misty close-ups.  Knightley is attractive but this is NOT her Academy Award star turn - or rather, shouldn't have been.  If Austen doesn't matter to you, you'll enjoy the film.  If Austen does, stick with the BBC mini-series.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off, let me say that I'm not a huge Jane Austin fan, nor am I a fan of most 'romantic' movies (because they suck!).  But I absolutely adore this movie.  For all you purists out there who complain it leaves too much of the details out, it's a movie not a mini-series.  I also have the 4 disc BBC production, which is lovely, but who has time to watch 8 hrs. of movie on a regular basis?  Visually this movie is stunning, and so is Kierra.  It looked awesome in DVD and is even better in Blu-ray.  It's a much 'fresher' version of the original, the actors are just as good (Mathew MacFayden is just as good a Mr. Darcy as Colin Firth, just different)and the photography will simply blow you away.  Just a beautiful, beautiful film.
