title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This a terrible adaptation of an excellent book. I'm not denying that the movie is entertaining to watch, since it is. But it does no justice to the actual book. Granted, I'm comparing with A&E;'s brilliant adaptation, so it would be hard for any movie to stand up to that. Obviously, this is a shorter movie and necessarily cannot follow the book as closely, which I don't necessarily have a problem with. The real issue that I have with this movie is the incorrect portrayal of the characters, particularly that of Mr. Darcy and Mr. Bingley. Mr. Darcy looks like scruffy slob in much of the movie, which is ridiculous. The worst though is Mr. Bingley. His character is portrayed as stupid throughout the whole movie. While Mr. Bingley is certainly a bit goofy in the book, he is anything but stupid. Here though, the directors or whoever else have made him seem like a bumbling idiot. This is such a shallow interpretation of his character, as if he serves no other purpose in the story besides comedic value, which is preposterous.Realistically though, this movie was created purely for entertainment and they did do that. I guess I just love A&E;'s version too much to be satisfied with anything else :) But if you don't have 6+ hours to devote to watching all of that and just want to curl up on the couch and watch a good love story, this one works well :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Though beautifully shot and ably acted, there is too much story in "Pride and Prejudice" to fit into 2 hours. The film skimps on the relationship between Elizabeth and her father, and flattens the differences between the sisters until they are nearly indistinguishable. Mister Collins, the fusty pastor, is only marginally dull; fiendish Mr. Wickham seems incapable of guile; Lydia Bennet insufficiently silly. The movie gives us little background to appreciate the country-vs-city issues, such as why Darcy and Miss Bingley considered walking so bizarre a mode of transport. And not for a moment did I consider Keira Knightley as someone who could be taken as plain-looking.The sets are quite splendid, however. Even the Bennet's "poor" country manor, for all its faded and peeling glory, is rendered with great detail. The sountrack however, was so loud and lush and hardworking that it bordered on cliché -- when it wasn't actually masking important dialog. So much of the film is hurried, with machine-gun dialog that I could not understand. And compensatory touches -- like providing the characters with different outfits or outsized personalities -- were ignored for some reason, perhaps to focus more on the main characters. If so, this was a huge mistake. The charm of P&P; is the interplay between the book's many characters and the norms that governed them. To streamline the characters and plot is to take away the story's soul.And no amount of loud music can make up for that.I highly recommend the 1995 miniseries, starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. It's more than twice as long as this movie, but has to be.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Second best adaptation of this great novel.  Love Matthew MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy. Although this movie was only a couple of hours long, the screenplay adopted a lot of the story in a rather compact version. Unlike the 1995 six part series on BBC which cover 90% of the story, I thought this newer version held it's own. The beauty of the scenery on location leaves you breathless. I loved the way they ended the story in a very surprising sequence...(will not give it away).

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you like to watch movies that are full of love, chaos, nature, english accents, ballroom dancing and horse and carriages then this is a good movie to see. When I  stumbled upon this movie I was entranced; I am now a Jane Austen fan.Watching Pride & Prejudice, for the first time, I can't help but want to steer the characters in the right path and want to be Elizabeth Bennetts friend and help her along in finding love with dear Mr.Darcy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley was a wonderful Elizabeth, a bit younger and more spirited than in some of the older beloved productions, and Matthew MacFadyen played Mr Darcy to perfection. Rosamund Pike as Jane and Simon Woods as Mr Bingley both exuded a sweet, innocent sort of romance that was exactly right for the characters. In fact, all of the casting was excellent, which made for an enjoyable transition from book to screen. The story has, of course, been truncated to a certain degree, but the trimming was skillfully done. The cinematography is gorgeous. All told, a lovely adaptation of the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I know many of you are fans of the BBC version and I liked it too. And although this remake had its flaws (acting, costuming, some details incorrect), there is one thing that this remake had that, in my opinion, BBC lacked - emotion.  By the end of the movie, I felt that these characters were in love, I felt that Jane was truly happy after her proposal.  I didn't feel any of that during the BBC version.  The story here may not have been told as thoroughly as other versions of this story, but I thought it was told better.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The earlier BBC version of Pride and Prejudice starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth has compelling characterizations, coherence, continuity, charm, sensitivity and moving music and visuals. This one lacks most of those qualities. With this newer Universal Studios remake, it's as if someone took a finished puzzle, pulled apart the pieces and threw them across the room, then tried randomly to put them back together. If I had watched this production without ever having seen the BBC's earlier one, I would have barely understood what was transpiring. Circumstances occur too rapidly, are never substantively developed, fall into an abyss and then are replaced by other events that demonstrate no depth or development either...My wife and I have viewed the BBC presentation many times, and each time we have experienced a wonderful sense of emotional fulfillment. We watched this Universal version just once---that was more than enough. The most satisfying thing was getting rid of the dvd as soon as possible.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The challenge of adapting any previous standing work is cited by screenwriters as notoriously difficult, perhaps the most so. It's especially encouraging, then, to see such a well-made, engaging translation to the big screen. It's no small feat, as for many Austenites (including my wife), the 1995 BBC-TV miniseries is the definitive one.While that version has six hours to gently unfold the romance of the quick-witted, independent Elizabeth Bennett (Keira Knightley) and the imperious, remote Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen), this new film only has two. It's a fine telescoping and shuffling of locales and events, nicely paced without feeling rushed. Both performers warm to each other in increments well-suited for the story's shape. It's believable, tender and touching.The casting choices are strong, but purists may find themselves longing for the BBC cast at times. Especially missed are Benjamin Whitrow's Mr. Bennett, and David Bamber's Mr. Collins. Mr. Whitrow's Bennett is a flinty delight, but Mr. Sutherland's final scene is so warm and emotional that it rescues his far softer interpretation. Tom Hollander's Mr. Collins suffers the most in comparison with his predecessor, whose hilarious take on the character bordered on the reptilian. Of course, Colin Firth's Mr. Darcy is in no danger of being eclipsed, but Mr. MacFadyen more than holds his own with a subtly rendered performance. Ms. Knightley defies the "pretty girl" casting with very strong acting as well, proving herself to be convincing in a period drama.This is a great stand-alone version of the story, drawing viewers in and engaging their hearts and minds. While the miniseries is ultimately superior, this new film also preserves the story's charms through a new lens.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is most marvelous marriage of music and great literature I have ever experienced.  The acting is perfect in every way, bringing to life one of the great masterpieces of literature.Having seen Keira Knightley in both Domino and Pirates of the Carribean, this is her most accomplished performance.The music is perfectly sublime, bringing the tempo of the age and experience not possible in any other medium.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While it would be tough for any adaptation of Pride and Prejudice to stand up to the quality of the BBC production starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, this production does not even come close.  The quality of the casting and the liberties taken with the story line made it difficult for me to even stay to see the end of the movie.  Very disappointing!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've never seen the BBC mini-series version, so I can only compare this to the book.  Naturally, large parts were cut or reduced (such as Wickham and Collins' parts).  All that information cannot be faithfully reproduced in the short time span of a movie, as it can in a miniseries.  However, the filmakers hit all the right notes in what they chose to include and how well it was rendered.  The movie focused on Lizzie and Darcy, which is of course the heart of the novel.The acting was top notch, especially Keira Knightly.  She deserved the Best Actress nomination as she fully embodied Lizzie.  I disagree with the reviewer below about Darcy's "deadpan eyes."  They lit up like the sun in the closing of the movie when his love was embraced by Lizzie--he was a misunderstood person and Matthew Macfadyen conveyed that.  Additionally, it was nice that for once Darcy didn't have to be a "pretty boy."  Rugged good looks can be just as dashing!  Donald Sutherland was a delight as Mr. Bennett, conveying his love and exasperation for a family of women with charm and dry wit.  He is a superb actor, and you could see that he truly cared about these women (and the actresses who played them).While the movie was spectacular, the DVD leaves a lot to be desired.  There are four main featurettes, but there is a lot of repetition between them.  The viewer need only watch "Behind the Scenes at the Ball."  The interviews with the cast in it are repeated for "HBO First Look" and "A Bennet Family Portrait."  The small biopic on Jane Austen was nice, but not very informative--focusing mainly on her home and where she wrote her novel.  Why not a complete biography?  And where are the deleted scenes?  Filmakers are notorious for filming more than they could ever include.  During the commentary, the filmakers mention that the dancing scene at the Ball between Darcy and Lizzie was completely recut and edited.  Why not show the original cut vis a vis the theatrical cut?  This film deserved the two-disk treatment--no doubt we'll get that in a year or two after we've all bought this version.  Hollywood sure knows how to treat the fans.
summary: 5 stars for the film, 2 for the DVD.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a great movie, and thoroughly entertaining (even if you are not a 'pure' Austen fan).  It is just not entirely true to the 'true' Pride & Prejudice story, but quite a bit of 'artistic license' was used by the screenwriter and director.  You WILL recognize it as P&P for the first half of the movie, but the second half shows a nice (simplified) ending.  In summary:  A great love story movie - just not pure P&P

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: With a great cast and a great story,how can you possibly go wrong? Easy if you don't understand the period in which the story is set.  This could have been great with better direction. Try the BBC'S NORTH and SOUTH for a wonderful English period film. It's a masterpiece!!!!!
summary: With a story like this how can you go wrong?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: They did a great job converting the book into a movie. Many times a lot is lost, but that wasn't the case here.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film was almost perfect.  While not completely true to every detail of the book, it captured the emotional essence of it.  What I remember loving the most about the book is Elizabeth's independence and wit, which Keira Knightly puts forth in spades.  In this movie Darcy becomes much more of a passionate man than in previous adaptations where his sexiest feature was his house.  Bingley also turns from a lout into a sweetly awkward and humble young man.  The scenery was great, and the dialogue cut for modern ears (again a good thing) so that every sentence that remained was essential.If I didn't love this movie so, I'd dock it one half star for the excruciating, tacked-on ending (why not listen to the British viewership that rejected it).  Another complaint: not enough Miss Bingley!  She was such an interestingly horrendous human being, and played to new, icy lows by Kelly Reilly.  In the book, Elizabeth and Darcy's takedowns of Caroline Bingley are some of the most delicious gotchas ever.  That storyline is great, and fairly central to the Elizabeth-Darcy relationship; it could have been preserved.In any case, it's the most spirited adaptation yet, and the one that, I believe, most deserved to be committed to film, because it retold the story most vividly.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Horrible. Over acted. Bad adaptation.Knightley's overacting ruins the movie. She is too forceful and too thin, two characteristics which would never have occurred during that time period. In addition, the removal of pride and prejudice from the characters action, completely alters the original intentions of the novel.I did however enjoy the acting by the woman who played Jane and the woman who played Mrs. Bennett; I wish I could transport them into the A&E; version, which by the way is far superior to this movie.I would not waste your money on this film and instead purchase the A&E; version. You will thank me afterwards.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightly is just an appallingly bad actress nowhere near up to this role.  She is hauled along through this along with Matthew Macfadyen (Mr. Darcy) and Kelly Reilly (Caroline Bingley), slightly better actors but weak overall.  Actually, part of what disappoints one in Kelly is simply bad costuming - she dresses and gives the impression she's walking out of a rather elegant party sometime in the 20th century versus the 19th - her hair's wrong, too.  The rest of the cast is somewhat amazing in establishing a sense of authenticity and picking up their roles - the costuming and photography, the settings will suck you in and make you watch!  A heavy Hollywood thumbprint is unfortunately highly visible in a few scenes: the `Titanic' ending someone thought was a good idea! (Bull!) - and the Church `joke' that dared to take a perfectly respectable 19th century word and serve it up on a platter for modern sensibilities so that a hip-hop audience could giggle at it.  Sorry - you've just walked past the proscenium, it doesn't work - it murders the historical authenticity you've invested so much to establish!  Excellent performances: Donald Sutherland (Mr. Bennett - so perfect but unexpected for this role), Tom Hollander! (Mr. Collins), Simon Woods (he glows), Brenda Blethyn (Mrs. Bennett - this is such an easy role to steal!).  Amazing scenery.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie.  The acting, the cinimatography, the music, the script, costumes, set direction...Cinimatography: The sweeping landscapes, the close-ups of Mr. Darcy's hand, the continuous shots at the Netherfield Ball are amazing.  The way the camera follows the different characters through multiple rooms in the sweeping mantion without edits.  I think they used some cg to piece a few of the shots together seamlessly, but a lot of it clearly depended on plentiful rehearsal and organization.  Beautiful.I could go on and on, but I won't.  Just see this movie, or not I don't really care as long as I can continue to watch it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have to respectfully disagree with the first reviewer.While the comparison is inevitable, I fear the wrong conclusion has been drawn. While the 1995 version is groundbreaking, the modern update is breathtaking. The scenery, the costumes, the dialouge, the casting all work cohesively with only another.Keira Knightly's potrayl of perhaps the most poignant fictional heroine in "romantic" literature is flawless. I like, many other people, was not impressed by Matthew MacFadyen when I saw the preview; however, he was the perfect Fitzwilliam Darcy. Dark, mysterious and brooding in a more love struck fashion than Mr. Firth plays him. (Though, let it be said, I will ALWAYS love Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy).This film felt more like a continual thought than nthe 1995 version which, after all, is meant as a mini series. I loved every minute of it, and have seen it in the theater 3 times. As a lover of Jane Austen and the beauty of Pride & Prejudice this is a must own film.
summary: Pride & Prejudice for a new generation

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you've never seen or read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, this latest Pride and Prejudice re-make starring Keira Knightley  is an okay introduction.If you're a huge Jane Austen fan, then this movie is still okay for you. It's not nearly as disappointing as might have feared.I had concerns going into this movie, but none of them were borne out. The pace was rushed, but not too rushed; it jam-pack the story into 2 short hours, and unfortunately, certain storylines & characters were condensed to make them fit (Wickham-gasp!-was but a sidenote! ). Keira knightly brilliantly played Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth Bennett. The plot and spirit stayed more-or less true to the book. I guess cliff notes are sufficient sometimes.Also, this remake adds something new to the Jane Austen cannon: verisimilitude to true 1700'ss life. Unlike other period remakes, which always show immaculate parlors, tidy living, and impeccably coiffed Young Ladies, this world was dirty and messy. Dogs roamed free through the Bennett home, food was grabbed and gobbled at the table, gentlemen weren't clean-shaven, and ladies obviously did not have the advantage of shampoo, hairspray, or styling products. The set felt more like noisy, dirty Colonial Williamsburg come to life, and not the hushed, immaculate parlors of BBC fantasy.But the best thing about this remake was the dance scenes. "I do lore a ball" is something Austen characters are wont to matter, and that passion comes off well on-screen here. Steady-cam images put you in the action, and the constant movement makes it fun to follow the intrigue. There is, however, too much of a good thing, and by the end of the second ball scene, I really wanted the cinematographer to go find a tripod!Overall, I enjoyed this movie. While it's not the triumph of the BBC remake, it's also not the disaster I feared it would be. The sweetness that appealed to me when I first read it, of characters who long for love but don't hook up til they get married, as well as the sarcasm & humor that only struck me later, all comes across on this movie screen. And probably will on DVD, too (no rush to the theater for this one).
summary: This P&P remake is dirty, but not disappointing

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Normally, I am a fan of reading the book first, then watching the movie.  In this case, I caught Pride and Prejudice on TV one Saturday afternoon, and got sucked into it within minutes.  It prompted me to pull the book off my shelf, which I had owned for 15 years or so, but just never made it past the first few pages because if the 18th century English it is written in.  I am glad I caught this on TV, I am happy I have finally read the book cover to cover, and delighted that I finally understand all of the references to Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Let's start off saying: you should watch the 1995 version with Collin Firth, it is a must for any P&P/Jane Austen fan.  The 1980 version is also decent.  They both give you the longer version of the story, which is definately worth seeing.  All that being said, this is still my favorite P&P - and probably my favorite movie of all time.  It renewed my love of period films, shows, and novels.  I can watch it over & over and still notice little things about it each time.  The attention to detail is wonderful.  It is shorted to 127 minutes, so you wont get the same scenes you got in the mini series, but they had almost 4 & 1/2 hours to go into the story.  But this does not take away from my love of this film.  It is beautifully shot, the scenery is so amazing to look at, the music is wonderful.  And the chemestry between Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen is undeniable.  They build such emotion with just a look.  Funny for me to remember seeing the advertisement and wondering who Matthew Macfadyen was and why they chose him.  After watching the film and falling in love with his version of Darcy, I am now a huge fan.  Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn are wonderful as Mr & Mrs Bennet.  Great performances by: Judi Dench, Simon Woods, Rupert Friend, Carey Mulligan and Tom Hollander as well.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The best version and the best representation of a Jane Austin classic. I can watch this movie over & over again & never get bored with it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was excited to see this condensed version of P&P; and relied on friend reviews. Previous to receiving reviews, I had planned not to see this version, because to me the BBC version was definitive. I was extremely sorry to find that this version is noisy, busy, and much less good than the BBC version. The lines of dialogue are chipped out, barely said, you can hardly tell who anyone is, except for Bingley's huge head of hair, and all of the participants seem to be born in a barn. The slamped-t0-the-head hairstyle is old now and particularly unwelcome in the Georgian period. Further, Donald Sutherland fails to convince as Mr. Bennett. The whole thing struck me initially as horrid and a waste of time, upon viewing it again, scene by scene, I still think it lesser than the BBC version, but liked it better. However, if you are interested in Pride and Prejudice, watch the full BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle first.Further, this version has none of the beauty or satisfaction of the original BBC version, plus, the screenplay takes huge advantage and abuses the story. So enjoy the barnyard version of P&P.; There are beauties in this version, but not it's not quite as  satisfying as the A&E; version.
summary: sadly much worse than the BBC version

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw this movie four times in the theatre, mostly because I absolutely adored how Matthew Macfadyen portrayed Darcy. Watch it and you'll understand why all the girls in the audience go "awwww" everytime he appears. I haven't watched the BBC version, but I feel sorry for people who hold the older version on such a high pedestal and never let themselves enjoy anything else. It's called openmindedness, people!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This "adaptation" was utterly and completely useless.There was no innvation in it at all! How can you call it an adaptation when it did nothing new and moreover left out all the wit and satire that made both the book and the BBC film version wonderful?I could go on and on with the "fast forwarding" and the plot liberties and painting Elizabeth as a weak, love-struck little girl, but others have done so already. I'll just stick to the horrible casting:Keira Knightly is gorgeous. But her face and body are modern. And she is so thin in this movie that dear Lizzie looks like a POW.Darcy has absolutely no presence. He is a wet rag and has none of those magnetic qualities that he should have so as to make him attractive despite his pride and conceit.Bingley reminds me vaguely of Clay Aiken (and not in a good way) and his sister is like the Paris Hilton of Pemberly (also, not in a good way).Kitty, Lydia, and Mary have no personality, neither does Jane.Wickham, is, at least nice to look at, but too pretty to be as believably cunning and womanizing as his character should be.I understand why this movie was made - cheap romantic consumption, riding on the coat tails of better Austen adaptations etc. But please, for christ's sake, how did this get any academy award nominations? There was nothing in it! No spirit, no art at all - just copying.I'm really appalled. I hope the next generation of austen fans doesn't group this together with the wonderful adaptations that have already been made. Sense and Sensibility, Emma, et al. are in a class by themselves.Now. Ang Lee, please can you do a GOOD version of Mansfield Park or Persuasion? That is what we need.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Overall, perfect movie. I watch at least once a year after I have finished reading the book.Any romantics out there? This is a must see.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a Jane Austen fanatic, there are several things that drive me crazy in a movie:  unsuccessful attempts at "sexing up" Austen's works, a recklessness towards the culture her characters live in, and a disregard for Austen's wit.  Sadly, this movie (even more so than the awful Mansfield Park that came out a few years back), does all three.  First of all, I found the non-regency era clothing disconcerting and distracting.  It looked like "Little House on the Prairie" met Marie Antoinette.  Secondly, I got the uncomfortable feeling that the people at Harlequin romances had done the screenplay, and I actually laughed out loud when Darcy appeared across the moor with his shirt unbuttoned.  Finally, they made witty Mr. Bennett dull and mumbly (they took nearly all his humorous speeches out), and ridiculous Mr. Collins boring and sober.  I'm sure you've guessed I don't like Wuthering Heights at all, and it seems the people who filmed this version "Pride and Prejudice" do -- and perhaps wished that were the film they were making.
summary: Did they even read the book?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I put the fault with Amazon on this one - why doesn't Amazon offer closed captioning?  I'm really surprised they can get away without it, since it's an ADA requirement, and the DVD version has the captioned version.(I'm not hearing impaired, but I find the accents difficult to understand, and rely on captions to help me.  Of course for someone who is hearing impaired, the captions wouldn't be a "nice to have" but necessary!  Get with it, Amazon!)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although I am a fan of both the book and the BBC film version with Ehle and Firth I approached this version of P & P with an open mind.  It does some things very well.  The production values, landscapes, great estates, and more gritty rural feel are outstanding.  The more understated casting of Mrs. Bennett and Mr. Collins was effective.  Bingley's sister is superb.  Knightley is lovely by 21st century standards, but she is too thin to have been considered a Regency era "local beauty." Judi Dench was an inspired choice as Lady Catherine but unfortunately gets only limited screen time. The distinctions of class and gentility that separate the Bennetts, Bingleys and Darcys are clearly drawn.  Now for what went wrong:  What lifts Austen's works above the average romance genre is her character development and superlative prose.  Both are lacking in this adaptation.  Neither Lizzie nor Darcy seem to change in essentials so their growing regard and sexual attraction for one another is inexplicable.  Wickham never demonstrates any hints of his true nature; why should Lizzie believe Darcy's version of events?  However, the most objectionable aspect of this film is the dialogue.  In some cases, the wording is overly modernized: Charlotte thinks that Jane should "snap up" Bingley; Lizzie refers to her love for Darcy as "incandescent."  Words are added, changed, or eliminated in ways that do nothing to advance the plot.  And in most cases, the pace of the dialogue is so rapid that it destroys the aura of the late 18th-early 19th century.  The setting is largely preindustrial; the pace of life was slower; the characters would not have rushed through conversations.  Finally, the ending scene was so trite and saccharine that I cringed in embarassment for the screen writer and the actors.  Some reviewers have argued, with some justification, that a two hour film cannot provide the nuances of a six-hour miniseries.  That said, there have been successful adaptations of Austen's work within a standard movie format.  Persuasion and Sense and Sensibility come to mind as adaptations that conveyed the essence of Austen's world and words despite the time constraints involved.
summary: Can P & P be done well in 2 hours?  Perhaps, but not here.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I, like most P&P fans, judge all movies against the iconic BBC miniseries.  (Colin Firth will always be Mr. Darcy!)  That being said, this movie is a wonderful, much shorter, alternative.  Keira Knightly is a believable Elizabeth Bennett and Matthew Macfayden is a solid Mr. Darcy.  The film itself is beautifully set and the score is phenomenal.  There are places where it deviates from the book, either to move the story along or make it more palatable for a broader audience...some of these are okay and some are not as okay, but overall it FEELS like P&P to me.  The worse part of the movie is the ending added for the American audience...its overly sappy and not at all in the spirit of Jane Austen.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I did not care for this adaptation of Pride & Prejudice.  I think it impossible to do P&P any kind of justice in 2 hours.  I felt that they tried too hard to pack the story into too short a time.  They glossed over, skipped and condensed too many events that, in my opinion, were essential to the build up of the relationship between Elizabeth and Mr Darcy.  You get no sense of Darcy's struggle with his attraction.  You barely get any sense of his attraction at all.  Overall, I am left with a sense of meh.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must confess that I went into the theatre fully expecting to dislike this movie.  In the past one year, I have seen four literary adaptations (Charlie and the Chocolate Factory; Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire; The Sisterhood of the Travelling Pants; and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe) and none of them has come close to doing justice to the books.  The magic of the story is always lost in the director's endeavour to commercialise it.  Therefore, I was very surprised to be absolutely delighted with this movie.Having read the reviews before watching the movie, I knew that the story had been tampered with quite a bit.  But, perhaps because P & P isn't one of my favourite books, or because I've resigned myself to the liberties that screenwriters take, or maybe just due to my love for everything belonging to the Regency Period, I didn't mind that in this movie.  The setting is more rural, but that lends a more authentic feel to the film and really made it seem as if the story was coming alive on the screen.  The two lead characters - Lizzie and Darcy - carry forth the story with aplomb.  The spirited Lizzie and the proud Mr Darcy belong to each other right from the very first moment they lay eyes on one another.  Much credit goes to Knightley and Macfayden for portraying their roles so convincingly - they live their characters and so make us live them as well.  The other characters, like Jane and Mr Bingley and Mr Collins, were not perhaps quite as I imagined them, but they are relatively insignificant, as the movie belongs to Knightley and Macfayden.  The climax near the end was beautifully done.  There were also a lot of witty dialogues which made my brother - who, it must be confessed, has never read the book, because he finds it boring - enjoy the movie very much.Some of the cinematography was wonderful; for instance, when they're dancing at the ball and after they've had their little battle of words, it seems as if they're the only two people in the room.  The sets were lovely - from rambling Longbourn to magnificent Pemberley - and the scenery was quite spectacular in some places.  The costumes were authentic, though I am quite certain women did not wear 'spaghetti straps' during the Regency Period.  But, overall, the feel was authentic and the period came alive as much as the story.To conclude, I would have to say that 'Pride & Prejudice' is not on my list of favourite books - I think anything Georgette Heyer wrote beats it hollow - and I am a complete purist when it comes to literary adaptations, but, despite those two facts, I enjoyed this movie very much.  The director certainly deserves credit for managing to portray the magic of the story despite all the liberties that were taken with it.  A delight to watch - it will definitely be part of my DVD collection in the near future.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I first saw the movie (probably in a theatre when it first came out) I was entranced.  I had never seen the TV miniseries, so I had nothing to compare it to, and I'd only read the book once, years before. So I came at it fresh, and based my opinion only on what was onscreen. I thought that Knightley was brilliant, and captured the lighthearted but also serious sides of Lizzy, and that MacFadyen was, I have to say it, a dreamboat. The filming - the amazing tracking shots, the way it moves in and out of window, the character actors playing all the other roles (Blethyn, Hollander and Dench are all FANTASTIC), the incredible scenery and lively earthy settings - I loved it all. I even set some of the music as my phone ringtone!  I watched it occasionally on TV over the years, and have always loved it.I just bought the DVD (June 2012, 7 years later) and watched it all the way through in one sitting.  In the last few years, I've read all of Austen several times through, and watched many film and TV adaptations, including the Firth/Ehle P&P;, and the 2009 Emma with Jonny Lee Miller and Romola Garai. Both of those, as 4 part mini-series, can be much truer to the plot and pace of the book than a 2 hour movie can - this P&P; has to speed through the plot, especially the second half.  And I notice it more now - we miss a lot of the character development and the true friendship that develops between Darcy and Elizabeth.I still love a lot about it - it is gorgeous, the acting is mostly wonderful. But with Austen's language more fresh in my mind and ear, the departures from her words, and the made up dialogue and scenes (some of which are necessary - she never writes much dialogue for proposal scenes - and some of which are extremely unnecessary) were more jarring.  There were some cringeworthy changes - making Mr. Bennett weepy in the scene where he gives Lizzy's marriage his blessing; "Yes, a thousand times yes" spoken by Jane when she accepts Bingley's proposal, and most sadly, one of my favorite lines: "you have bewitched me, body and soul, and I never want to be parted from you again." It's just too pulpy for Austen - she would absolutely have made fun of such language.Despite these criticisms, it stands the test of time - it's one of my favorite Austen adaptations, alongside Emma (2009) and Mansfield Park (1999) by Patricia Rozema - another that's absolutely beautiful to watch but departs enough from the book to make a lot of fans angry.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: this is my favorite move hands down. Such a great period piece using great actors. Keira Knightly is perfect for these types of roles

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Who are all these negative reviewers?  Are we even talking about the same movie here?  Personally, I liked the '95 BBC version (loved Colin Firth)...I must have, I sat through hours and hours of it.BUT, this P&P; version is much, much better, it is visually exquisite!  Everything about it is supremely perfect --the cinematography (glorious), the musical score (fabulous), and the cast of actors (incomparable).  All the actors did a fantastic job -special mention for Brenda Blethyn who even made me like Mrs. Bennet (disliked Mrs. Bennet in the BBC production, she was a dingbat in that one).  Tom Hollander was great as Mr. Collins, and the Bennet girls, adorable.Kudos to Joe Wright for casting Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen in the lead roles.  FINALLY, a Lizzie and Darcy who are the ages they are SUPPOSED TO BE, and actually look it  (I couldn't say that about the BBC version, and Greer Garson was 36-yrs old when she played Lizzie in the Hollywood version...36??!!!?? OMG).The 2 lead roles I saved for last because their onscreen chemistry literally scorched the screen and they are, ultimately, what made this movie unforgettable.  Keira was amazing, luminous -she inhabited the role so completely, that she made you forget how ethereally beautiful she really is and made you believe that Lizzie's true beauty was one that came from within.Matthew MacFadyen...he turned the rain and the early morning mist into erotic scenery; the nuances he injected in playing a conflicted Darcy was phenomenal, and as stunning as Keira is, THIS Mr. Darcy will hijack your heart, and nothing will ever be the same again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If "Pride and Prejudice" is going to work, it has to be produced as a  comedy of manners, satirizing contemporary social and class mores. The first mistake in this version, was to interpret it as a drama, a problem which was compounded by leaden direction, and a script with a tin ear for the comic nuances. This is a shame, since Keira Knightley is an excellent actress, and with a better script and direction, she could have shined in the role of Elizabeth Bennet.I recommend seeing either the great 1940's movie with Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier, or the outstanding 1990's mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle instead.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have watched this movie 7 times and would love to watch it again and again. What a lovely picture. Pride and Prejudice has been my favourite novel since I was a teen and to watch the story on screen was a delight. Superb acting by every single actor and actress. Each one was perfect for their roles and very professional, but I would like to point out in particular about Mathew Macfadyen, who gave an outstanding performance and was the perfect Mr.Darcy, tall, handsome, lovely voice, beautiful stride, sexy...etc. He danced so well and the expressions in his eyes conveyed his feelings. Only a very talented and professional actor can do such an excellent job. The story flowed so well and the settings and music was so breathtaking and original. A movie worth watching. Very entertaining, romantic and funny.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The BBC version was over 6 hours and this has been squashed into nearly 2 hours.  It is for this reason that many things in the book are missed out and rushed through. The Bennets were not so poor that they will lived in a house that was substandard or had pigs and other animals living near them. Lizzie walking in the field at 4.00 am in the morning would not be the done thing. We lose a lot of the smaller characters and we do not get the time to get to know most of the characters.  Everything is rushed and the first ball was like one for the underclass and not people of this class. Jane's character is lessened in this version and Catherine De Burgh would not be travelling to see Lizie late at night either.  Some serious flaws in this version and too rushed. Keira Knightly is great but Mr Darcy lacks the conviction of the BBC version. It was a stab to make this story modern but much was lost in this version that made the BBC version a classic. I liked this version but came out feeling let down and  I would not buy it. The BBC version gets the 5/5
summary: Not bad but lacking compared to the BBC version

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've lost count of how many films have been made of Jane Austen's best-loved book, but this latest release is far from the worst. That dubious honor in my view goes to the 1942 movie that had the characters parading around in what looked like wardrobe rejects from "Gone With the Wind" and Greer Garson at age 36 trying to convincingly play a 20 year old ingenue. Give me a break.The latest film, directed by Joe Wright, is a fairly faithful retelling of Austen's plot, which almost everybody and his mother is familiar with by now, with gorgeous visuals to hook us squarely into the time and place. The visuals, in fact, are so beautiful to look at that at times they tend to overwhelm the story.For anyone out there -- if there is anyone out there -- who doesn't know the plot, "Pride and Prejudice" introduces us to the Bennet family who belong to the upper-middle-class landed gentry in late 18th century England. The second daughter, Elizabeth, sharp as a marble and pretty to boot, meets Mr. Darcy, a tall, dark, handsome and single young man with money out the wazoo. It's loathing at first sight. He despises her middle-class connections; she thinks he's a stuck-up snob with an attitude. The rest of the story has them finding out how wrong they are about each other; there are a lot of interesting plot twists and turns, but in the end, of course, almost everybody ends up living happily ever after.Jane Austen told her sister Cassandra that she thought the book was "rather too light and bright and sparkling" but that is exactly what has endeared it to generations of readers in print and on film. Who doesn't love a good love story? But there is a problem with this version; perhaps, in trying to tell the whole story in two hours, it's told too much and not enough both at once. The second and third versions of "Pride and Prejudice", on BBC in 1980 and A&E; in 1995, were serialized over four to five hours and told the story pretty much as Austen wrote it, especially the BBC version, my personal favorite. Joe Wright's film tries to tell the whole story also but there's too much story for two hours to do it justice. As a result, the film feels compressed in spots. It feels truncated. We don't see nearly enough of Elizabeth's Aunt and Uncle Gardiner, two characters who are central to the book; Bingley's married sister and her husband are left out altogether, and the whole movie has a kind of rushed quality. You won't notice it if you haven't read the book and/or seen the BBC or A&E; movies, but you'll notice it a lot if you have.Joe Wright also took some positively unsettling liberties with the Bennets. In Austen's book they are an upper-middle-class family who are the "principal inhabitants" of the neighborhood. In Wright's film, they look like they've gone to seed. The cows are mooing in the back yard, the pigs are ambling into the premises through the back door, a harried-looking Mrs. Bennet and her daughters are toiling in the kitchen (although in the book Mrs. Bennet indignantly tells the Reverend Mr. Collins that her daughters have nothing to do in the kitchen as the family is perfectly well able to afford a good cook), and a bleary-eyed Mr. Bennet sits in his library looking unwashed, uncombed and unkempt. The whole establishment looks drab and dingy, in need of a good paint job. In the earlier movies Longbourn looks like a fairly prosperous estate; this movie conjures up images of Tobacco Road.Keira Knightley is a delight to watch as Elizabeth Bennet; she's smart, sassy and easy on the eyes. She's as good as Elizabeth Garvie was in the role in the BBC version and she's an improvement over Jennifer Ehle. Belinda Blethlyn is funny and ditzy as Mrs. Bennet, an insufferable airhead whose one goal in life is to marry off her brood. Dame Judi Dench is suitably Gorgon-like as Lady Catherine DeBourgh; it's a shame we don't see enough of her in the film either.The big problem for this reviewer was Matthew McFayden's interpretation of Darcy. For a lot of people who saw the other films, the gold standard for Darcy was Colin Firth, although not for this reviewer; I thought Firth was miscast as Darcy (ducking brickbats from Firth groupies as I type this). Firth was trying to be a very 90's Darcy, sensitive and vulnerable; but his Darcy wasn't Austen's Darcy by a long shot. McFayden plays Darcy as if he were racked with inner torment over his wealth and status; he comes off almost as insecure. If there is one thing Austen's Darcy isn't, it's insecure; he's almost too full of himself to be real until Elizabeth knocks him down a few pegs. McFayden was trying to bring out Darcy's soft side -- he has one, underneath all that starched armor -- but in doing so he underplays Darcy's haughty exterior to the point that we wonder what Elizabeth found so revolting about him in the first place. Something doesn't add up.Taken as a whole, the movie delivers in the time it has to do it in. There is no way to faithfully put "Pride and Prejudice" on film in only two hours. But the essence of the story is there. It's lovely to watch and nice to listen to. Wright does a creditable job of bring Austen's best-loved book to the screen. I just wish he'd made it into a longer film.Judy Lind

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of my favorite movies.  I bought several to give as gifts.  One to a high school graduate who wants to be a director and has already won awards for his short films.  I gave him Pride and Prejudice and Atonement, both directed by Joe Wright, so he can view them from a director's perspective.  He will get a lot out of the director's comments bonus.  Joe Wright has an artists' eye.  His misses no opportunity to include beauty and sound, the chirping of birds, the flicker of a candle, etc.  The music is also beautiful and plays an important role in this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There is exceptional acting by every actor and actress.The themes are wonderful:  I appreciate how honor is emphasized and respect is duly given except when justice is required.The action moves along nicely in beautiful locations.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wow, what a movie.  I was captivated from beginning to end by the cinematography and the actors.  The chemistry between Elizabeth Bennett and Mr. Darcy was outstanding.  The book was brough to life and I enjoyed it.  Yes, it deviated in some areas but it was worth it.  The concept of the book was not lost but enhanced.  After I saw the movie, I re-read the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is fabulous.  I have seen many film versions of the book.  Beginning with the old Hollywood version with Sir Lawrence Olivier.  That movie was glossed and everything was pretty and shiny.  This movie was realistic...at least to me....I did not live during that time but i imagine it wasn't all shiny and glossy...I imagine it was much like this film.  It was so great Keira Knightly's Elizabeth was full of passion and life.  Matthew McFadden is not the typically handsome Darcy you would expect...he was raw and sensuous and his maleness just popped off the screen.  Their obvious attraction to one another is tactile and fertile with energy.I have watched this film dozens of times.  A must see.
summary: The Best Pride and Prejudice movie ever

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a very loyal Jane Austen fan, I am unsure of how to even begin my discourse of the faults that abound in this pathetic display of complete disregard for periodic pieces!  I agree with the previously posted review that stated that were Jane Austen alive today she would be grieved...yes, and for her sake, many of her loyal fans certainly are!  How could Keira Knightley think she was portraying Elizabeth Bennet correctly?  How, for that matter, could ANY of the cast find their performances even adequate, much less outstanding?  Besides the problems already listed, and despite the fact that there are many, there is one in particular which stands out in my mind and causes me to cringe:  the scene near the very end of the film where Elizabeth and Darcy have married and are seen back at Pemberley.  Elizabeth comes out onto the terrace at night, wearing Mr. Darcy's oversize nightshirt!  This would never have been done, and certainly not out in the open where anyone might see!  Then, to make matters worse, she proceeds to sling herself up on a nearby table and sit cross-legged...a position no well-bred woman would have assumed, and certainly not on a table!  The final horror that adds to this parade of miserable mistakes is when Darcy actually joins her on the table, sitting behind her and holding her in a way which would seem sweet in the modern setting of a chick flick, but which is grossly out of tune with what is supposed to be a period piece.In fact, it is not just this one scene which so scathingly grates on the nerves of loyal Austen fans, but the overall lack of any understanding of time period!  The actors all seem just that--acting (and very badly) in a story set in a completely foreign time period to them.  They seem lost the whole time, as if they aren't sure what they are supposed to be doing, and their performances keep the audience from being drawn into the story.  If the goal of the film industry was to take a wonderful, timeless classic and remake it with something modern audiences could relate to, they have failed miserably; for by trying to "modernize" this story, they take away the very essence of its timeless appeal.  This is a story which is timeless not because of its settings, but in spite of them.  What makes this book so good and so intriguing for so many generations is that it is a fabulous character study and we can all relate to the very human characters in Pride and Prejudice.  We feel their pain, embarrassment, excitement, joy, anger, and pride--we can relate to them and understand them, even if we don't know firsthand what it feels like to live in a society like theirs.  The rules of etiquette which bound them are not impressed upon us today, but we can still enjoy the story, and feel for the characters.  But take away those very rules and the story becomes completely lackluster and stupid--and certainly not worth telling!The argument may be made that audiences today don't understand the society of Jane Austen's day, so we must modernize the story somewhat.  To that I say that we should not cater to the modern audiences' lack of regard for history, but rather we should try to acquaint people with the way things were.  It doesn't have to feel like a history lesson...but it should be historically correct.  If we cannot do so without skewing the story, we should leave it be, rather than ruin a beautiful classic.The overall costumes, makeup,  and attitudes of the whole cast are outrageously misplaced.  Though we cannot be too harsh on the actors--we must lay much of, if not all, the blame at the director's feet.  After all, he has the final say in what goes into his film and how it is to be portrayed.  Obviously, no one connected with this film's production cared to consult the book or history of that period...or so we must assume by the lack of believability in the whole portrayal.Lest anyone think I am attacking Keira Knightley or any of the cast personally, let me just say that I have nothing against any of the actors when they are in their element--the kind of films they and their directors understand.  Perhaps, though, they should have taken the cast of this film and produced a modern chick flick.  They could certainly not have done any worse.If the film industry in general must produce bad romance films, they should at least confine the damage they feel must be done to stories set in this time period, so that they might have a chance at getting something right, and they should be advised to leave well enough alone in tampering with great literature which has many fans.  I feel very sorry for anyone who is introduced to Pride and Prejudice in this film version, as they will probably either hate it because it is so bad, or will think it a "cute" romance movie, without knowing the excellent taste they are missing from the original story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Been done before, but beautiful to look at, both scenery and stars. You'll like it in spite of yourself.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a review of the Blu ray release only not the film as such which has been covered elsewhere. The main problem is with the sound track. As has been pointed out by another reviewer everyone speaks so fast it is hard to catch what is being said. The subtitles which would normally help are an absolute disaster: The speaker location system is used which results in the subtitles frequently running to three lines but they also hop about - left, centre or right, even top and bottom - depending where the speaker appears on the screen. To make it more difficult, like the speech, they are displayed only fleetingly and it is too often impossible to read them before they are gone. A further issue is the balance: speech is generally overpowered by the music and one is constantly fiddling with the volume control.The picture quality is acceptable but I did not find it as sharp or as well color balanced as I had hoped. The BBC Blu ray is of course a different version of the story but it is technically very good, especially considering its age and original format, and vastly superior to this most disappointing transfer.
summary: The Blu ray is an irritating disappointment

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Saw this with my girlfriend. She cried at the end. This is a well made film. There is one breathtaking shot of Keira Knightley's character posed on the edge of a cliff, with a magnificent backdrop. I would love to have a poster sized print of it up on the wall. An excellent stay at home date movie. Very humorous too.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay that sounds harsh, and much as I liked the production design and the performances of the two leads, on the whole the entire production is undercut by a rushed pace. Obviously you can't cram the whole book into two hours, but this it seems is exactly what the director tried to do. No discredit to the screenwriter--who obviously worked hard to keep the best lines from the book in the movie--but Keira Knightley is forced to sputter most of them at such a speed that all comic timing is destroyed and the viewer is left irritated. Those who haven't read the book will probably not only feel irritated but also confused as to what is going on. The supporting cast is wasted. Donald Sutherland's Mr. Bennett seems indifferent, rather than amoral and witty as he was portayed in the magnificent BBC version. Brenda Blethyn's performance is also undercut by poor staging and dreadful editorial choices. Whole lines of exposition are lost in transition from one scene to the next, and the musical score veers from understated to over-the-top.I realize it's a tall order to follow the superb quality of the BBC version of 1995. But this production doesn't even come close.
summary: Jane Austen for the ADD generation

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The only reason I'm adding yet another review of this movie is the idiocy of people who keep comparing it to the 1995 miniseries.  Yes, the miniseries was utterly fantastic, but the movie is superior to the miniseries in at least two scenes.One is the scene in which Elizabeth first encounters Mr. Darcy at Pemberley.  According to the book, Elizabeth is so embarrassed that she "scarcely dared lift her eyes to his face."  Take a look at how the two actresses did this scene.  I am confident that everyone will agree that Keira Knightley did a better job.  Jennifer Ehle generally did a splendid job in the miniseries, but this was a rare occasion when she slipped a little.The other scene is the one in which Elizabeth explains to her father why she wants to marry Mr. Darcy.  The miniseries cuts this scene short from what we have in the book, while the movie shows the whole thing.  Isn't it important to show Elizabeth telling her father what Mr. Darcy had done for the family?  After all, it's a huge weight lifted from his shoulders.  The result is that the miniseries ends this scene with Mr. Bennet looking rather solemn, while the movie, following the book, has him laughing and joking.And why did the miniseries not give us the full scene?  It's because they insisted on spending nearly a minute and a half - it feels like half an hour - on the double wedding of Jane and Elizabeth.  This is strange because we actually learn virtually nothing about their wedding from the book; in fact, we learn more about Charlotte's wedding than we do about Jane and Elizabeth's.And this lengthy scene also prevents the miniseries from doing what I believe no version has done so far, namely show the scene in which Elizabeth tells her mother she is marrying Mr. Darcy.  It is such a shame that they didn't do it because the two actresses involved, Jennifer Ehle and Alison Steadman, were so superb.  I hope that the next time this story is filmed, we will get to see that scene.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm not a hopeless romantic, but I loved this film. THe direction and acting were solid and the cinematography were brilliant. I generally love historical fiction and though it wasn't historical when it was written, P&P takes the cake as a historical fiction film- learn about England society150 years ago and become a romantic again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I went to see Pride and Prejudice not having that high of expectations coming from a lesser known studio, but it blew them away! This may not be the best movie ever made from this Jane Austen classic, but it is a strong retelling of the story.Keira Knightley steals the show and rightly was nominated for an Oscar for her leading role.The chemistry between her and Matthew Macfayden works well. Although the movie starts off slow it picks up as Mr. Darcy enters the screen and takes you on a wonderful journey. My wife and I loved this one and it's always good to find a great chick flick to go to with your wife!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Some considerable time ago, I watched the BBC miniseries presentation of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE, a chick-flick if there ever was one starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, at the urging of a Jane Austen-obsessed female friend. When I reluctantly admitted that I thoroughly enjoyed it, I realized that I must resign my long-standing membership in the Neanderthal Male Fellowship. Now, much to my horror and apparently diminished masculinity, I have to say that this 2005 version of P & P was even more captivating and better than the BBC version in all respects, albeit much shorter in length.The plot of P & P needs no extensive recapitulation here; if you don't know it by now after many cinematic renderings, then forget it. Briefly, the story surrounds five unwed daughters of a son-less English country gentleman, Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland), in financial decline in the early 19th century (or, as in this new version, the late 18th). The girls, particularly the eldest Jane (Rosamund Pike), the second eldest, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley), and the third eldest, Lydia (Jena Malone), get caught up in a romantic tangle with a plethora of would-be suitors: the perky young gentleman Charles Bingley (Simon Woods), the darkly moody young nobleman Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen), the dashing Army officer Lt. Wickham (Rupert Friend), and the weasley cleric cousin William Collins (Tom Hollander). The girls' fear of impending spinsterhood is whipped into a froth by the maternal anxieties of their foolish and marriage-obsessed mother (Brenda Blethyn). Mr. Bennet accepts his fate as the sole male in this estrogen-driven household with a certain bemused resignation. In any case, the focus of the story is on Elizabeth ("Lizzie") and Darcy, whom the former initially despises as arrogant and boorish. It's Darcy's pride and Lizzie's prejudice that must come to terms in this comic opera of social customs and manners.This version of P & P has been criticized by purists for at least two reasons, both of which are irrelevant to me since I haven't read, nor do I intend to read, the original Austen novel. First, the financial health of the Bennet clan is, apparently, reduced from that in the book (and, indeed, from that in the BBC miniseries). Indeed, while the family still employs servants and seems to have enough food on the table, their lifestyle here is noticeably more seedy - almost grubby - than previously depicted. Well, why not? It's this desperate condition caused by an aging patriarch and lack of a male heir that has Mom and her brood worked into a frenzy about their future prospects. Indeed, cousin William, due to inherit the estate on Mr. Bennet's death, is already nosing around inspecting the goods. Second, fault has been found with Macfadyen's Darcy as less obstinate, i.e. self-assured, in his pride than Firth's version. Now, while I readily admit that Firth's Darcy is perhaps his career's best role, I find Colin generally to be a Lump in all his screen roles. Matthew's version displays an anguished vulnerability beneath the proud veneer that's tapped by his attraction to Keira's Lizzie. And what man in his right mind wouldn't be? Keira's version is a Bewitching Babe with two capital Bs. (All through the screening, I strained to remember where I'd seen Macfadyen before; he's not exactly a familiar face on American Big Screens. Afterwards, I remembered that he plays the lead in the current British telly miniseries "MI5".)This P & P, as befitting a major production, has cinematography that is, at times, positively luminous, and the camera work is more adroit and clever than anything seen previous. Three scenes were, for me, particularly memorable: the visual isolation of Lizzie and Darcy from the rest of the revelers at The Ball, Lizzie's changing view of the Bennet estate as she spins in a swing hung under an arch, and Mrs. Bennet's inclusion, white petticoats flying, in a flock of scurrying white, silly geese as she pursues a rebellious daughter across the yard. These visuals were positively inspired.There are no acting performances here anything less than superb. Special mention must be given to Judi Dench as the imperious Lady Catherine, Sutherland as the overwhelmed, gentle Mr. Bennet, and Hollander's brilliant rendition of the pathetic Collins.Yes, I like this PRIDE AND PREJUDICE more than I can adequately explain. It may, perhaps, land a place on my Ten Most Favorite Films list.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride and Prejudice is a fine renditions of Jane Austen's novel.  I'm not quite sure why a story of 19th century England, in which the heroine defies the expectation that an unmarried woman's sole occupation is to secure a well-heeled mate, is so appealing these days; but I was so satisfied with this film that I was disappointed when it ended.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The key to any great adaptation of a book is the primary character.  In this case, Kiera Knightley was born to play the part of Elizabeth Bennett.  Her natural beauty and tough demeanor makes her a duplicate of this character.There have been several adaptations of the book by Jane Austen.  Some have been quite long.  This version is an intriguing and engaging version.  One aspect that makes this version lively and entertaining are the various camera angles.  You actually feel that you are there and can hear every conversation being spoken.  You have that feel that you are "gliding around" as you hear Elizabeth talking to her best friend or Mr. Darcy secretly confiding to Charles Bingley his thoughts on the Bennetts.Great adaptation.  The ending may offend some die-hard fans of Jane Austen because...Well, you have to watch the movie.JR FelisildaAuthor of the book, "Nanay: Lessons From a Mother"
summary: Best Version of the Classic Book

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have grown to love this movie! I initially gave it 3 stars because I felt it was too long and a bit boring. A year later I watched it again and I liked it better than the first time. A year after that and I love it. I have watched it so many times now that even though I have the DVD I watch it on cable when its on.The cinematography is fantastic, as is the costuming. The actors are not just amazing to look at they really embody the characters.If you didn't like it the first time, try watching it again after a time...your opinion may change as mine did!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First I want to say, good job Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen and to all of the cast!!!  Everyday I can watch this movie (I already have almost!).  This is the best version of P&P.  Even though it's somewhat different than the book I still love it.  Joe Wright should make a sequel of Charlotte's and the Bennet girls married lives...especially Elizabeth's (Keira Knightley) and Fitzwilliam Darcy's (Macfadyen).  And to just think if Jane Austen was never born, this movie wouldn't be here or her marvelous books!  Please, you will not be sorry for purchasing this movie!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I guess I am too much of an Austin fan to enjoy this rendition very much. Not only are there many changes and additions to Austin's plot, but the setting is partially wrenched from the early 19th century to add some of today's manners.  Yet Austin's stories are all about manners!  I didn't like it that the father figure is portrayed looking like a drunk on a 5-day binge (extremely dirty and messy looking, 5-day's beard, stringy hair)rather than as an intellectual.  I didn't like that the portraits of Georgiana and Darcy were transformed into nude statues (with Jane looking pointedly at the front of the male version).  Mr. Collins I found more earnest than stupid.  Some changes were of course necessary to shorten the story, but I found many changes that didn't need to be made, that for me detracted from the whole.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My wife adores this movie so I had to give it a try. The movie was ok, but I just don't see what is supposed to be so romantic about it. The movie concerns four daughters who all get married and their mother who is obsessed with getting them to the altar. Two get married to jerks, two of them to nice guys. But the main story revolves around Elizabeth and Mr Darcy, and how they go from hating each other to falling in love. This would be romantic... if they had spent any time together! But they fall completely in hate and love after a few short sporatic conversations, with scarcely any time alone. Maybe that's how people fell in love in the early 19th century, but I just wasn't convinced. I felt like these characters still hardly even knew each other. Now I imagine to make this film a great deal was probably cut out of the book, so those who read the book may not feel like so much is missing.The scenery and costuming is very good, and the acting is top rate, although Donald Sutherland's accent sounds a little American. Definitely a woman's movie, but men can focus on Keira Knightly, who is incredibly beautiful here.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a big J.A. fan, not a purist. I am one of those people who can point out how much movie destory...well changes the original story. Trust me, there were a couple of parts that where in the book that were excluded from the film. There was even a scene was the scriptwriter should have caught( Lady Catherine de Bough came to visit Lizzy at night and made a comment about the garden then cut back to request well demand a private audience with Lizzy).I have seen many versions of the P&P; and this one is my favorite. The chemistry and acting was wonderful. I felt like for 2hrs I watching Lizzy and Mr. Darcy not Keira and Matthew.  Over all I felt like Charles Bingley was too naive and goofy. That was really the only character that I now despised. The interactions between all the characters are believible.Be warned that there is a lot of giggling in this more. A little bit more than I care for. I still think that the movie stays close to the characters' true nature(except for Charles. Read paragraph b/4 this one). I prefer not to disect everycharacter's personality. As far the extras, there aren't any deleted scenes (good thing....no confusion). They aren't the best package. Would I have bought the dvd just for the extras? Only if it was free. Out of the whole movie there is only one profane word at the end. I'm only 18 and don't have any children so I can't comment on where or not children should see this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I too was very excited to hear of a new version of this movie...I am an avid fan of the book and the 1995 A&E adaption. I could write for days, but to sum up my feelings: I didn't feel Knightley portrayed Elizabeth as she should be...Knightley's version was more pouty, angry, miffed all the time, rather than playful and teasing as she should be. I didn't feel any chemistry between Elizabeth and Darcy. Wickham was almost nonexistant, which is a major problem, since we really need to understand how awful he is to understand the storyline! I understand that in a feature length adaption, some details had to be sacrificed, but I feel that anyone who isn't familiar with the material will be lost, or at least won't appreciate all that is happening properly. That said, it had some parts that were well done, the scenery was lovely...but the end, with all the Mrs. Darcy's...ugh! I love a good romance, but that almost make me ill! CHEEESY!
summary: I love P&P, but not THIS P&P

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Julie "Give me your tired heroines , your hud...
review_text: For the sake of starting with something positive, let's throw out the very biggest problems like historical placement and accuracy. Being set a full 50 years earlier than Austen's story is entirely wrong but not worth bleating over. Oddly, the best way to portray rural dwellers of the day is deny them soap and water. There is a strange film over everyone as if they'd all been awake for a solid week and were not given time to shower before getting onto the set. Let's even try to forgive Grand Mal errors like Bingley entering the bedroom of an overnight female guest. Huh? If we can get stupid enough to ignore a boat load of other similar problems, we might at least admit that this movie was beautifully designed and very well captured. Watch this thing with the sound off, and you'll enjoy some remarkable cinematography.But no lavish castles or livid sunrises can rescue this mess.First, we'd have to cut off the head of the beast in terms of raw materials and leadership. The screenplay borders on jabberwocky, honoring only the most banal of Austen's dialog.  And despite being the epic romance, director Joe Wright isn't able to coax anything more than a lukewarm shrug from any of the key players.Speaking of key players, let's look at casting.Keira Knightley (Pirates of the Caribbean, King Arthur) reduces the smart and self-possessed Elizabeth to little more than teen petulance. She strides triumphant through the movie, always armed with some well worn leather-bound tome (we can safely assume it's not Stanislavski), looking for ways to disarm people with her aplomb. Unfortunately, Knightley has a limited number of tools with which to construct the fa?ade. One is a frightening and toothsome grin-laugh thing that turns her into a Rankin/Bass villain (a'la Burgermeister, the Bumble, HeatMiser, etc). The rest of the time, Knightley relies on her jutting jaw and droopy lip to illicit a blatant sexuality (which happens to be completely wrong for this character). However, instead of pouty sex kitten, this trick looks as if a large dose of thorazine is just kicking in. We half expect a ribbon of drool to escape down her chin at any moment.Then there is our darling Darcy. No one will ever touch the haughty torment of Colin Firth. Even if we hadn't seen Firth's Darcy, Macfadyen would seem a bit flat. We get precious little of his prickly pride (which is fairly significant to the story, being in the title and all). His too-soft underbelly is exposed the minute he sets eyes on Elizabeth, which irrevocably breaks the seal on his crusty credibility. The most powerful aspect of this romance is how it so utterly surprises Elizabeth - and us - when he makes that first proposal. Watching Macfadyen spill the beans in his first 10 seconds on screen leaves very little reason to keep watching. He could have benefited from just a bit of Caroline Bingley's over-the-top nastiness.As for the rest of the cast, they come in two flavors: shallow and boring, or giggly and squirming like cheerleaders in the back of the bus. One has to wonder if it took more than thorazine to get the rest of the cast through this project, particularly after seeing Donald Sutherland's version of Mr. Bennett. Dreamy and completely disconnected, laudanum appears to be his buffer of choice. Of course we expect Lydia and Kitty to be in the throes of an Ecstasy binge, which they are, yet still manage to disappoint us. And poor Mr. Collins (actor Tom Hollander, who also plays the deliciously neurotic and ruined Anthony Meredith in Gosford Park) is stoned out of his head and on the brink of full-on paranoia, although trying very ...hard ...not to be. He was definitely capable of giving David Bamber (the A&E; version Collins) a run for his money in this role. Unfortunately, "big eyes and stick-in-the-arse marionette movement" must have been Wright's direction for the unfortunate Hollander.Countless smaller irritations abound: The evil Mr. Wickham has roughly 9 words of dialog with which to make us first love and then despise him (a fancy trick for any actor, let alone someone with no noticeable screen time). Dame Judy Dench is cast once again as the fiery old crone (Lady Catherine de Bourg) which is exactly the same as every other role she's been saddled with for the last 10 years. What a tragic waste.  Even Charles Bingley's sunny disposition seems to be drawn in crayon. Far from the agreeable innocent we all adore, he comes off as weak and mildly retarded (and seemingly incapable of combing his particularly unruly shock of red hair). The result is some kind of love child of Liberace and Howdy Doody. Darcy would have never befriended someone like this. And not just because of the hair. Brenda Blethyn (Little Voice, Saving Grace) turns in the only enjoyable performance as the terminally squirrelly Mrs. Bennett. At least she's fun to watch, albeit in the manner of a fuzzy rodent with a firecracker tied to her tail.This is two thumbs way, way down. Down as in, to induce vomit after accidentally ingesting drain opener. The only thing that might have been slightly harder to swallow was the 2003 modernized version sent up by director Andrew Black. I'd rather see JACK Black in the director's chair. Naked.When will Hollywood learn that unless you bleed every 28 days or are named Ang Lee, you're not qualified to handle Jane Austen? Go tackle the Bronte sisters. And there must be at least a half dozen more gladiator movies waiting to be made or remade. Heck, take Dickens on another spin around the dance floor! But leave the next Austen adaptation to the BBC or PBS where they might still care more about characters and story than honoring a 5-picture deal for the latest tarted-up teen stars.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What more can be said.........Keira's Elizabeth is a one-of-a-kind:  Lizzie is a glittering star beginning to end.  Ah, but it is Matthew's Darcy who grabs this viewer throughout.  It's he I hope to see, who I watch for to appear in every scene, background....foreground....where is he?  But, why he, you may ask?  Well, it's because of the "Darcy's fall" which we begin to see that he is giving us.  And we know, if we but think of it, that from that first sidewise glance he gives Lizzie in the film's beginning ball scene, he is lost and "Darcy's fall" has begun.There are just two scenes that I can watch, watch, watch, re-watch, rewind and watch again.  In order of my passion for them, they are:  (1) The pouring rain, outdoor pavilion scene where "Darcy's fall" has neared its end and he declares his love to Lizzie (the intensity of that final moment, with their physical closeness and their seen and felt overpowering desire to kiss, is overwhelming for us).  (2)  That near-dawn, meadow scene in which each discovers the other walking, Lizzie because her fear of lost love keeps her from sleeping, Darcy because he must seek her out for one last try.  And when their approach one to the other is done, and we hear him--emotions on fire--stutter out to her:  "I love....love....I love you," we know then.....at that very moment....."Darcy's fall" into love is now complete.****

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: GREAT MOVIE ,A MUST SEE ,A LOVE STORY , SET IN THE DAYS WHEN MEN WERE MEN AND WOMEN WERE WOMEN ,WHERE VALUES WERE IMPORTANT TO A FAMILY 'S  EVERY DAY LIFE ( TELLS OF A YOUNG GIRL LOOKED DOWN ON BECAUSE OF HER FAMILY AND HOW LIFE WAS THEN IN THAT ERA ,HOW FAMILY LIFE MUST HAVE BEEN BACK THEN AND JUST A GREAT MOVIE THAT KEEP YOU THINKING WHAT MIGHT HAPPEN IN THEIR LIFE'S ) I ALREADY OWN THIS MOVIE BUT BOUGHT THIS FOR A FRIEND .IF YOU ARE INTO THIS TYPE OF MOVIES ,I THINK YOU WILL ENJOY WATCHING THIS MORE THAN ONCE .
