title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I get why people feel the need to discuss the pros and cons ofthe authentic language, costumes, actions(ie, the costumes, Longbourne,Lady Catherine's night-time visit).  I love the books too---But come on-- the admittedly over the top, sunrise walk across the fieldwith the pained, hopeful, "is this really happening to me" expressionin Darcy's eyes has to be one of the most powerful set-up scenes ever--it manages to avoid feeling cartoonish to me-- he seems both beautifully vulnerable and yet somehow strong at the same time-----If you can watch this scene and not wish the YOU had been cast as Lizzie then perhaps you are paying to see films in the wrong genre ----

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a fan of the 1995 BBC version, this P&P; had to grow on me. It took two watchings to do just that, and I now rate it higher than the older miniseries. Some purists are upset about this modern take (Just read the lower rated reviews), but I think they should at least acknowledge an original attempt at an old novel. And this P&P; does just that - breathe new life into a tale everyone knows.For starters, the imagery in this movie is breathtakingly luscious. Imagine colour so bright and vivid you can almost taste it and amazing country settings that ooze sensuality. It is a very passionate film, in its settings and actors and the chemistry between Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen (Elizabeth and Darcy) is a palpable, living entity that reflects in the scenery. (such as Elizabeth's awakening sensuality in the art gallery at Pemberley. And how gorgeous were those statues?) Really, this movie made me want to run out and buy an English country estate for a couple million pounds (which I don't have :)There are so many great things about this film. The actors are spot-on. Initially I thought Keira too giggly but then I realised that in the book she was a young woman and should act as any other young woman throughout the ages. Tom Hollander's portrayal of Collins is exciting and believable (As a clergyman, he would be very sexually frustrated indeed). Matthew MacFadyen as Darcy sometimes looks a little too sulky for my tastes but that thankfully doesn't take away from his smoldering performance (with such a gorgeous voice to boot). My favs: the scene at Charlotte's house - he literally bursts in and looks so ill at ease you feel sorry for him - the two proposals and strutting across the countryside in the early morning hours!!! Oh my beating heart!!). Mr and Mrs Bennet have a believable marriage and the family's obvious "country poverty" make it clear why Darcy would have so much difficulty in the initial stages loving Elizabeth.Unfortunately, it's not quite perfect, hence the half star. There should have been more Elizabeth/Darcy interaction which could have been achieved if they'd taken out some unnecessary shots. It felt sometimes the shot was done for the sake of looking good, rather than contributing anything meaningful to the story. (E.g. the swing scene, the ballroom tracking shot, the shot of Elizabeth standing at the edge of the cliff, the moon shot after Elizabeth and Jane talk in bed - all beautiful to look at but really not that necessary. In addition the talking in the dance scene between Elizabeth and Darcy is a little awkward since some lines are delivered when they're not face to face.Yet that doesn't take away from what is a fully fleshed out picture with real people, dealing with still relevant problems, instead of recite-lines-from-an-idealised-book characters.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw this during the holiday season because I was curious to see if it could outdo the 1995 BBC version. IMO it does not because one of the key players is sorely miscast. While Keira Knightly is luminous as Elizabeth Bennett I thought Matthew McFayden's "Mr. Darcy" was dull and and more melancholy looking than arrogant/proud. The actress who portrayed Jane appeared much older than she actually is in real life. Poor Dame Judi Dench who I love in so many other films does not have the features to pull off an aristocratic member of the peerage. She resembled a pillow that had been adorned with finery but to no avail...still unbecoming. The rest of the cast and the beautiful English countryside made it a tolerable film, however, I would much prefer to own the BBC version.
summary: Not As Good As The BBC Version

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's always a challenge to successfully adapt a beloved classic novel into a film, maintaining the plot and spirit of the story. Joe Wright's Pride & Prejudice accomplished this amazingly well. Aside from a few necessary omissions due to time constraints (and yes, a couple of small changes - which I think worked for the better on screen), this version adheres to the original story faithfully. The casting and acting was superior on all accounts. Keira Knightly and Matthew MacFadyen have scorching hot chemistry. I am typically not a huge fan of Knightly, but I think she took on the character of Lizzie superbly. Brenda Blethyn had me laughing out loud at her portrayal of Mrs. Bennet. Donald Sutherland is very touching in his role as Mr. Bennet, and the actresses rounding out the Bennet family performed flawlessly, even though two of them (Talulah Riley and Carey Mulligan) had practically no acting experience before this film was made. I don't even need to mention Judi Dench - we all know she is one hell of an actress.Beyond the story and characters, the cinemetography is absolutely breathtaking. This film is like a painting come to life. You can freeze-frame almost any shot in this entire film, put it on canvas, and hang it on your wall. It's THAT good. This film is a feast for the eyes if there ever was one. Hats off to Joe Wright and the entire crew for their work of art in motion.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a wonderfully made film, one of those well-crafted pieces where every frame could be a painting.  The performances were fantastic and as someone who has never read a Jane Austen book or seen a Jane Austen film adaptation (unless you count "Clueless (Special Whatever! Edition)") I was very new to this world.  And I liked it!  The ending of the movie is what really got me, that and the score.  The piano score was perfectly lovely, and I may have to buy it on CD.The extras on this DVD don't add much of anything.  Director Joe Wright's commentary is dull as dishwater and the interviews with the cast are repeated on different special featurettes to the point where you benefit the most from watching only one of them.  But overall, if you somehow missed this gem, I suggest renting it and catching up because it's well worth your time!
summary: I never read the book but I definitely enjoyed the movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice (Full Screen) (2005).  Love this movie and would definitely buy again if it were to get damaged.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Where do I begin here?  This version is too pretty, too theatrical and too high-budget.  Instead of beautifully portraying the characters, this movie seems more intent on showing the landscape, the nice sets, the houses, etc.  They leave out SO much!For starters, Lizzie and Jane are plain silly in this version.  The Lydia and Kitty and Mary characters aren't developed AT ALL.  They do not do justice at all to the closeness of Lizzie and Jane and they don't even TOUCH on the closeness between Lizzie and Mr. Bennett, which is a HUGE injustice to the story.  And Mr. Collins isn't silly enough; he is just dull and not an asset to the film at all.  And Mr. Bingley acts an idiot who isn't educated at all.  Very sad.Everything about it is just WRONG.  Kiera Knightley is NOT a Lizzie at all.  She doesn't have it in her.  The only remotely good thing about this film is Judi Dench as Lady Catherine.  Dench is such an excellent actress and brings a bit of quality to any film she does, no matter how bad it is otherwise.Save your time and money and watch the BBC version with Colin Firth.  This version is like Sesame Street compared to the BBC version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved this movie, the music and the way it was filmed. It was romantic from start to finish.No, it didn't follow the book a hundred percent, but I loved it anyway. It was so beautifully done that it touched the heart. And isn't that what entertainment should do? The entire book was condensed to a fraction of the time, was done with good taste and kept the essence of Jane Austen's book. And I thoroughly enjoyed Keira Knightley's and Matthew Macfadyen's portrayals of Elizabeth and Darcy.And I appreciated the director and his handling of the various scenes and emotions that go along with loving someone. Although, I have the 1995 version with Colin Firth and have seen a little of it, I will probably prefer the 2005 version over all of them. Sorry, ladies, but I prefer Matthew.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If one is not a fan of the book or the A&E;/BBC mini-series version of P&P;, then this movie might be enjoyable.  However, that being said, this movie is a poorly done version of a classic novel.Here are my problems with the film:1.  Character butchering.  Mr. Bingley was portrayed as a moron in this "adaption" of the novel.  Mr. Bingley was never stupid or insipid.  The relationship b/w Mr. and Mrs. Bennett-as  lovely-dovely when in fact, Mr. Bennett could barely tolerate Mrs. Bennett and her silliness.2. The lack of chemistry or build up for the relationship of Darcy and Elizabeth.  There was very little interaction b/w Lizzy and Darcy that would even suggest a reason why either would love each other.  It was quite sudden with absolutely no explanation.3. The Bennetts were not poor, as Mr. Bennett was a gentleman, not a field hand.  The Bennett house looked like a common persons home with pigs and animals walking in and out if it as it that was not unusal.  Additionally, the Bennett girls, especially Lizzy were always unkept and untidy.  Daughters of a gentleman do not look like rag-a-muffins. Lizzy's hair was always undone and coming out.4.  The confrontation b/w Elizabeth and Lady Catherine was extremely contrived.  Lady Catherine would never visit Elizabeth that late at night.  Judy Dench did an admirable job with Lady Catherine, however, the character was written poorly.Overall, this movie was barely tolerable.  It did not deserve any of the accolades it received, esp, the Oscar nomination for Ms. Knightley.If you are a true fan of the novel, watch the BBC mini-series, as it captures the true spirit and essence of the book.
summary: A watered-down poorly done version of a great novel

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wow. This is my favorite version. I watch it frequently. I did not believe I would like any other but A & E's version of Pride and Prejudice. I believe this version (although shorter) is truer to the emotions most likely felt by the lead characters. I also preferred the casting of the other characters overall. If you are only going to purchase one version of Pride & Prejudice then this is the one I recommend.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As with all Jane Austen works once you start watching you can't stop. I wish she was still alive to give us more.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: From the breathtaking English countryside to the finely-honed performances, this movie is a real delight.  All of Jane Austen's characters are there:  the long-suffering Mr. Bennett, the manic, matchmaking Mrs. Bennett, the lovely Jane, the feisty Elizabeth, the dour Mr. Darcy, the affable Mr. Bingley, and the imperious Lady Catherine.  Many of the lines are taken directly from the book, and the important plots and subplots are all there.  The sharp divisions between social classes are evident, as is the scheming behind who is to marry which man and receive which yearly income.  The casting is superb, from Donald Sutherland as the befuddled and very much outnumbered male in the Bennett household to Judi Dench, in the small but pivotal role of Lady Catherine.  "Pride and Prejudice" is one of my favorite books and this movie truly does it justice.
summary: Beautifully-made version of a timeless classic

I would strongly recommend the other version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle being the actors/actresses of Mr. Darcy and Ms. Bennet in the movie. I daresay, this version is very well presented.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's very difficult for me to believe that anyone associated with the making of the 2005 version of Pride and Prejudice actually read the book. I can believe that they read the Cliff notes as they got the names right anyway. Lizzy was spirited and strong willed perhaps for her time, but the constant giggles, the rudeness in Church, the lack of propriety; wandering around outside at night in her nightclothes, not wearing a hat outside, unkempt hair, gave me the impression that Keira Knightly was playing Keira Knightly, and not Elizabeth. Jane seemed more true to form but the blonde streaks in her light brown hair? Did she get those in a salon in London or just pick up hair dye in the local super market? There was so very little character development. George Wickham was supposed to be a villain but if you blinked while he was on screen or yawned while Mr. Darcy minimally described the role Mr. Wickham had in his life you certainly would not have known that. Lizzie's speech to Mr. Darcy about the downfall of her younger sister in the presence of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner was just plain bizarre. I had no idea that Mrs. Bennett drank too much in public, nor that she, and the girls did so much housework, in fact the book tells us that they did not. If the pig being escorted through the house was supposed to mean something I did not get it. Lizzy standing on the cliff was the Titanic wasn't it?  Didn't Lizzy realize that she really had been prejudiced against Mr. Darcy by listening to the very positive things about him and the very negative things about Mr. Wickham as related by the long term housekeeper? Don't look for that in this film because she is not even in it. The portrait of Mr. Darcy is now a statue placed in what looks like a museam. Would the Lady Catherine De Bourghe really descend on the Bennett household in the middle of the night and then go and visit her nephew at the home of Mr. Bingley? Was this supposed to be a joke? Is this an example of British humor and the real film is coming out next year?
summary: Did Anyone Associated With This Film Actually Read the Book?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I first heard that a cinematic version of "Pride & Prejudice" was being made, with Keira Knightley as its star, I felt the first quivers of trepidation -- but when I finally was able to view the finished product, my trepidation rapidly escalated to alarm, outrage, bewilderment and ultimately disgust.I am NOT a self-proclaimed "Janeist" or "purist" and am completely willing to believe that a great film version of one of my all-time favorite novels can be made; however, I simply cannot understand why THIS movie was made, other than as a commercial endeavor designed to capitalize on Keira Knightley's previous successful turn in "Pirates of the Caribbean."  I shudder to think of (and in fact know several of) the masses of young girls who now think of this abomination as the definitive "Pride and Prejudice" and will never go on to read the real thing, never mind see the truly definitive BBC miniseries version.Here's my point:  if you are going to significantly change aspects of a classic and beloved story (and, let's not forget, a classic story that has often been called one of the most perfectly constructed pieces of fiction in the history of English literature), do it with respect.  DON'T leave the story in its historically correct timeframe and then "dumb it down" with modern vernacular, manners (or lack thereof) and sentiments.  DON'T totally discard the mores and social graces of the time period in question (to wit:  families such as the Bennetts did NOT have pigs (!)running in and out of their house, nor was mealtime a free-for-all of reaching and grabbing.  Nor would Lady Catherine deBurgh have EVER, under any circumstances, descended upon the Bennett household in the middle of the night regardless of her outrage.)  If you feel moved to make changes, for heaven's sake, make ACCURATE changes.I also must strenously object to the way many major characters are portrayed in this version, at variance with the book.  For example, Mr. Bennett, as written by Jane Austen, is clearly unhappy in his marriage and has no respect or affection for a woman whose looks turned his head in his youth but has long since proven herself to be ill-suited in nearly every way to be his life partner.  In this film version, Mr. Bennett (as portrayed by Donald Sutherland, who is entirely capable of a more correct and acerbic interpretation) shows little real agitation or annoyance and, in fact, frequently seems fond of his wife in a somewhat benevolently distracted sort of way.  Likewise, Mrs. Bennett appears in this version to be almost reasonably distracted over the prospect of marrying off five daughters as opposed to Jane Austen's original, who is at turns irritable, giddy, indiscreet and given to dealing with the events of her life with hypochondriac swoons.  Even more notably, Darcy himself is portrayed by Daniel McFadyen not as haughty, aloof, imperious and unable to break out of the strictures of his upbringing and class but as unsure and confused.  Keira Knightley's portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett is annoyingly shrill and giddy and reminds me of nothing more than the attitude with which the first women suffragettes wore pants ("Look at me!! Look at me!! Just look at how OUTSPOKEN I am!!"), but she is not the worst culprit here.  (McFadyen, I feel moved to add, is actually quite dishy and would probably make a terrific Heathcliff -- all that silent brooding that he does would be put to much better use -- but nobody does haughty better than Colin Firth.)Beyond the aforementioned horror of putting the Bennetts' homelife on a level with the Clampetts, I also object to some of the changes in setting (most dealing with Eliza and Darcy's meetings -- in the Grecian temple, in the rain, walking across the fields at dawn) as being mawkishly, screamingly melodramatic and unoriginal.The whole point of P&P; is how two people, bound by the class restraints and social conventions of their time, managed to surmount them -- NOT cast them off wholesale.  The plot of this story is inextricably entwined with its setting in a society with very strict codes of behavior, and to impose modern manners is not only jarring but destroys its very premise.I did give the movie one star on the merit of its cinematography and soundtrack, both of which were excellent.  I would have loved to love this film and was beyond disappointed that my initial reservations were proven well founded.  One wonders:  will an "updated" retelling of Gone With the Wind be next??

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I never saw Pride & Prejudice when it was in the theaters.  In March I saw it for the first time on a cable tv program and was absolutely enthralled!  The storyline is great, the actors/actresses were all superb and the scenery was breathtaking.  I know that Keira Knightley was nominated for best actress that year and I can see why.  She is amazing. I also think that Matthew MacFadyen brought just the right touch to his portrayal of Mr. Darcy.  He was sexy, dreamy, and sensitive. I bought this DVD so that I could watch this romantic movie whenever I wanted and I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to get caught up in another era.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really enjoy this film and have watched it several times.  My only criticism is that I wish it were a little longer and included a few more scenes that I thought were important in the development of the main characters' relationship.  While faithful to the book, it has fewer scenes and characters so that the film can fit into a 2 hour time slot. For those who are familiar with the book and the BBC version, you can easily fill in the missing scenes.  However, it would have been fun to have them in the movie. Still, I really enjoy this version.  I also recommend the BBC version as well.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: All I can say is, if you like period movies, then you will love this movie.  Keira Knightley, and Matthew Macfadyen, both give an outstanding performance.  It truly is Jane Austen at her finest.  You won't regret buying this movie if period movies are something you enjoy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a concept- a movie centering on a woman whose chief concern for a mate would be his character!  Amazing in this shallow world!  Of course it did take her quite a while to figure him out.  I recommended this movie to all my kids and neices and nephews, especially the unmarried ones- since some of the sense of focusing their search for a mate should be to find one who is a truly responsible, kind and loving and this movie is bound to rub off on them as they watch.  Everyone who saw the movie absolutely loved it.  Deliciously romantic! Can't praise it enough!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have to state that I didn't really understand why there was another adaptation of P&P; done so soon after the magnificant A&E;/BBC series with Firth and Ehle. I have so much loved that version that I watched this determined not to like it. I didn't hate it but compared to Firth and Ehle (and the entire cast of that version) I just couldn't reach the same appreciation for the newer version. It probably isn't fair to compare the cast of this one to the other, however I do. Charlotte Lucas looks like she is 12 instead of 27. Col Fitzwilliam is a pudgy military officer. Georgiana Darcy is played by the same girl who was Henry VIII's 5th wife and plays her as a valley girl just like she did in The Tudors instead of the shy girl portrayed in the book and in the BBC version. Mr. and Mrs. Gardner were also portrayed as rather shabby people even though they were affluent enough through his business to have a London house, carriages etc. Their children don't exist in this version - in fact, Mrs. Bennet proclaims they have no children - even though we know that they did. Even though a two hour movie can't support the same number of characters as the 5 hour version, the omissions are really egregious.I did feel that probably this version was more historically accurate with the depiction of the Bennet house and the village...much more drab and rustic. Piles of manure on the roads and paths, sloppier animal pens etc. But it did not make for more pleasurable viewing. While the Bennet's were not of the same wealth as Darcy or Bingley, they did not reside in the hovel surrounded by pig stys shown in this version. The family all dressed very dis-shelved and drab. Mrs. Bennet would never  allow her daughters to roam around barefoot and sloppy. If anything, she was always trying to behave and live in a higher class manner than their income supported. The house is dark and shabby even though it is an estate.Perhaps if I'd never seen the A&E;/BBC version, I might have appreciated this one more, however I don't think I would have the same appreciation for the story. I don't think Jane Austin would be proud.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I absolutely love this movie. You can feel the chemistry between Elizabeth (Keira Knightly) and Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfayden)! The supporting cast is excellent as well.
summary: Excellent Interpretation of Jane Austin's Book!

review_text: I count "Pride and Prejudice" among my top-three favorite books...ever. So, I was really looking forward to this cinematic version of it. I was sorely disappointed. In all fairness, two hours just can't do justice to this wonderful novel, but this movie didn't even scratch the surface. And Keira Knightley as Lizzy? Didn't quite work for me. I say don't waste your money. The book is cheaper and will afford you greater hours upon hours of pleasure. I dare say, you'll want to read it again, which is more than I can say about viewing this film.
summary: Skip the Movie; Read the Book!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a huge P & P fan (read it countless times, own about 175 variations/ sequels on my Kindle, have watched every film adaptation, have paraphernalia declaring my adoration) and I love this movie.  The movie captures the romantic feel of P & P's essence through its cinematography, pacing, direction, music and acting.  I love the long shot of the Netherfield Park ball, the continuity of the theme song throughout the movie, and the sizzling chemistry between the protagonists.  Keira Knightley, though more giggly than I interpreted Elizabeth to be, is more youthful and refreshing than her predecessors.  Matthew McFadden, is my quintessential Mr. Darcy (sorry Firth): regal in stature, appropriately haughty, and ruggedly handsome (but not gorgeous) with crystal blue eyes that emit vulnerability and passion and a deep baritone voice exudes masculinity and sexiness.  Yes, the movie is not faithful to the book or even Regency England norms so I understand why Austen purists get annoyed but the interpretations enable the movie to capture P & P's romance in a condensed two hours.  Overall, I love this movie and need to watch it once every couple of months to get my P & P fix.
summary: This P & P fan loves it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The film has a nice score but the script is terrible and making one of the most loved characters in literature with a snarky kiera knightly is a crime

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This well-paced adaptation of Jane Austen's beloved classic is a delight.  Kiera Knightley (Bend it Like Beckham, Pirates of the Carribean) rightfully earned Oscar, BAFTA, Golden Globe and other major award nods for best actress in her portrayal of Miss Elizabeth Bennett, a girl who becomes a woman as she and her at-odds romantic interest, Mr. Darcy, overcome their pride and prejudices against each other in the backdrop of 1797 England.Joe Wright, emerging star in the world of film, conveys all the lively spirit, comedy, and romance, of the book, in this carefully crafted cinematic masterpiece.  Music lovers will find special appreciation in the soundtrack that includes many specially commissioned pieces that were written in the style of the period in which the film was set and which work as an integral part of the story.  Use of many outstanding locations around England are employed to illuminate the story.  Of particular interest to me was the actual wealthy gentleman's manor used for Longbourne, the Bennett home.  Unlike previous adaptations which portrayed the Bennetts inacurately as having great wealth, this version more closely matched the book in that the location did portray a gentleman's home, but not a notably wealthy gentleman.  Details are so carefully adhered to that subsequent viewings are necessary to take in all the interesting items in the background of many scenes.  However, because the director was working with such an excellent script and cast, the story is easy to follow even for people who may have never read the book.Casting in this film draws from the elite of British Theater with the result being strong fresh portrayals of the characters.  I had not even heard of Matthew Macfadyen prior to seeing this film but was immediately struck with how articulate he was in conveying the thoughts and emotions of Mr. Darcy with careful understated gestures, not simply relying on facial expression as many modern actors are prone to do. Tom Hollander turns in his best performance to date as Mr. Collins.  Dame Judy Dench is wonderful as the despicable Lady Catherine.Having enjoyed Austens works for years and several earlier adaptations of this book I was hopeful that this one would not disappoint.  It didn't!!!  My 1995 adaptation now sits in a corner gathering dust.  My boyfriend who NEVER liked the 1995 adaptation (far too slow...5 hours and felt like 9), actually enjoyed this adaptation very much and said it is a film he would enjoy seeing again.Watching this film I think you will quickly see why it received so much critical and audience acclaim, why it was nominated and earned so many awards, and why so many people have been pleased to add it to their DVD collections as a film they can look forward to viewing again and again.
summary: A terrific adaptation of a beloved classic!!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a horrible movie, not just because of the numerous hisorical inaccuracies, but because of the wooden, bimbo-ish acting of Kiera Knightley. I do not understand why the director chose to make the Bennetts out to be paupers. A family of such low status would NEVER have mixed with higher society such as the Bingleys or Darcys. Also, Englishmen of the time would NOT have appreciated the common, casual manners of the actors. There is one scene of Keira Knightley flopping on a couch,and while watching it I just wanted to cry. Also, in the book, Jane was the prettiest of the Bennett girls, while in the movie she looks kind of freakish. I think this is a sad example of politically correct re-writing of history to remove the sense of class differences. The dinner free for all was a total joke. Anyone even remotely familiar with proper English manners would understand that if a family ate like that they would have been on the VERY bottom rungs of society. Mr. Darcy as portrayed in this movie looks continually like he's in need of a hug, and is not the proud character that Firth so brilliantly brought to life in the BBC version. The idea of pigs and dogs running throughout the house, of the Bennetts not owning a carriage was absurd. Don't get me wrong, I could see how a modernization of this story could be quite well done, but this ain't it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my "go-to" movie when there's nothing on television. I love all the character representations in this version. You won't be disappointed.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am another long-time Austen fan of both the book and every screen adaptation available (including the much-loved Colin Firth BBC version).I couldn't imagine how they could reduce it to 2 hours -- but they have done a beautiful job of using film for it's best features. For example, the dance sequences and the roving camera-work show vignettes with key characters that would take much verbal exposition to explain.The scenery is breathtaking.  The Bennet farm is fascinating.I also didn't think anyone could be better than Colin Firth, but I am now a fan of Matthew Macfayden because of this film. He comes on slowly but intensely. I've now sought out other work he has done.
summary: a new classic with stunning photography and a fresh take

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I put off seeing this movie until just recently...I enjoy the BBC versions too much. How can a 2 hour movie possibly capture the wonder of this book? Well, it can and it can't. I enjoyed it as simply another adaption of this Jane Austen classic. It wasn't better than the BBC versions, but on its own merit, it was good. Keira Knightley makes a GREAT Elizabeth Bennett, and Darcy is a bit more sympathetic and soft than the other Darcys. I was also turned off by the "sexy" reviews, but I wouldn't have used those words. There was chemistry...that's how I'd describe it. I didn't understand the scene with the statues and their nudity...what was the point? And there were other liberties taken. But if you want a quick P & P fix, it was pretty good.
summary: Don't compare it to the others, and it's good

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The reason I purchased this dvd was for Matthew MacFadyen's performance as Mr. Darcy.  I thought he was outstanding, and I almost always enjoy Keira Knightley.  Good cast, and interesting commentary by the director.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Though many will tell you this version of Jane Austen's "Pride and Predjudice" is watered down for the American taste, they cannot deny the fast pace and appeal this movie has brought to a classic work of literature. Though true that earlier versions may have been more accurate to the original text, this production's vision has brought a fresh perspective to an earlier day that will touch younger viewers and inspire the more experienced to revisit Jane Austen's world again. Superb acting, beautiful photography, well written screenplay and sensitive directing has culminated in this very fine movie. Five Stars. KCL

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The HD DVD version was purchased.My wife is thoroughly taken with this version of "Pride & Prejudice." As I've seen with other movies the high definition becomes secondary to a moving story and you will forget until you encounter scenes with equisite detailing such as the several parties and painterly images framing the characters on the screen. The movie feels too short at the end and I would've loved to see some of the depth in the original work. I do not begrudge the effort in the cinematic translation as the pacing was excellent and the settings were quite amazing. The acting had some uneven moments but again the story particularly if you're familiar with it, will carry you to the end. Highly recommended. And if you do like this sort of thing, try viewing it with the subbing as certain lines are easily missed and sometimes misunderstood on first viewing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie file on this disc is thirty percent larger than the earlier HD DVD version and it is easy to enjoy the results on any but the smallest screens.  The audio is also superior with the lovely  piano score like crystals dancing in the background.  If you love this energetic Jane Austen effort you will have good reason to reinvest in the Blu-Ray title.
summary: Blu-Ray Remastering Outshines Earlier HD DVD Effort

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The costuming was terrible in this adaptation.  They looked so frumpy a lot of the times.  I didn't like that.  Kiera Knightley was good, but I especially liked the actress who portrayed Jane.  She did a far superior job than the Jane in the BBC miniseries.  She looked the part too.  I wish that she had played Jane in the BBC miniseries, then the masterpiece would have been complete.  I didn't like how they portrayed Mrs. Bennett as a drunkard and Mr. Bennett so seriously, not showing the sense of humor he obviously had in the book.  Donald Sutherland was the wrong choice of all actors in the movie.  But overall, it was fun to watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was prepared to hate this film.I sat down to watch it with the sole purpose of cutting it to ribbons; I found myself at the end going "wait, that was not so bad!".  I watched it again and found that I really loved it; I was pleasantly surprised!Having been an avid reader of all Jane Austen books and the happy consumer of each Jane Austen inspired film, I felt I was a moderate expert on the subject matter.  The film has a few problems, the hand holding before consent of marriage and the fact that some of the language is very "un-Austen" being a couple, but the filmmakers caught the essence of Lizzy and Mr. Darcy in a way that I have rarely seen.Kiera Knightley is actually good as Lizzy, she's a little too pretty for the part; yet it works.  And MacFadyen was amazing as Darcy.  He took a different direction than Firth and I like his better!  I can't believe I'm saying that but it's true!I think people should look at this film for what it is; an excellent interpretation of Pride and Prejudice.  No film will ever please everyone.  If you want the full, un-edited version go to your local library and check out the book.
summary: BBC version fan but this film won me over

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a firm fan of the 5 hour BBC 1995 P&P miniseries, I went to this movie version with some skepticism, but found that it was much better than I expected even while it seemed to lack somewhat for me in some respects. THE P&P is hard to live up to! All in all though, I enjoyed this movie version immensely and went back to see it again right away. In and of itself, it is a delightful version of the story and even compared, it stands up on its own as another interpretation and look at the characters and events of this prima Austen work. The more I watch this movie (as a pick me up at home alone or with family or friends, with my feet up and a favorite something to nibble or sip on), the more I adore it. Let's face it; we can get our P&P fix faster/easier: in 2 hours instead of 5! (I still MUST watch the 5 hour version regularly as well.) This film version has a grittier, lowlier feel (perhaps a more realistic one) at the Bennet's and beyond, plus a more opulent contrast at Pemberly and related. One key detail that impressed me greatly was how I did not like Darcy nor see any attraction to the man at the beginning (how could HE be Darcy?!), but over time, he became more and more sympathetic (even appearing a pathetic figure at times: pitifully sunk in unrequited love - which pulled fully at my feelings to cheer him on in Elizabeth's direction) and attractive as the character - and this was as it should be. The performance of this actor made me want to see more of his work (and I have since seen him do extremely well in another role as a spoiled drunken dandy in `The Way We Live Now'.) The world needs more of this type of `old fashioned' movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off I would like to state that I am an avid Jane Austen fan, her novels are my favourites. Secondly i would declare that I am not a person who expects a movie adaptation of a book to exceed the book itself. I believe it to be impossible to ever do a book justice on film (which is why i would always reccomend reading books before watching the films). As to this particular adaptation of Pride and Predjudice I found it to be a beautifully made film and the performances where outstanding by all. I could not help as always to love Elizabeth Bennett and could neither help but fall completely in love with Mr Darcy. At first glance Mr Darcy seems not at all as proud as expected but on further viewing I believe it to have simply been subtly done. I would reccomend this film to anyone as it is a real heart opener. Reguardless of opinions and comparisons I found that the film told the story of Pride and Predjudice most respectfully.I loved it from start to finish!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: "Pride and Prejudice" by Jane Austen has always been one of my favorite books.  So when I heard that they were going to make a new movie version, I was both worried and excited.  I ended up being extremely pleased with the casting and the movie.Keira Knightley does a wonderful job.  I remember hearing that they weren't sure whether they'd have her as Elizabeth because she was too pretty for the role, and that would have been a tragedy, b/c she's perfect in this.  As for her co-star Matthew Macfadyen who **IS** Mr. Darcy- I'm practically speechless.  I hated him at the beginning but throughout the movie I found myself falling in love with him!It's a lovely story, and Emma Thompson's version of it is something that I will never forget.  I recommend it to all!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I bought this movie because I love Jane Austen's stories and I loved the 1995 version with Colin Firthe. I had seen this movie previously and had enjoyed it enough. It is a good summary for the story, but I would not recommend setting your heart on it as the best. I do love Keira Knightley's acting and I felt she played Elizabeth Bennet rather well in this movie. However, as a Jane Austen classic, this is not the best. I would definitely recommend the 1995 mini-series first, but seeing as that one is 310 minutes long, this one will work for your Jane Austen 'fix'. =)Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I don't care if this film is `faithful' to its literary source.  I've never read Jane Austin, nor seen the much-touted BBC miniseries, so I'm fortunate enough to view this film on its own merits.This is an excellent film with wonderful cinematography and a slightly gritty, realistic setting.  The camerawork is elegant and almost Wellesian in its graceful fluidity.  (Such a relief from the normal hyper-MTV editing that presupposes we all have attention deficit disorder!)  The acting, in general, is excellent.  I found the Darcy character to be somewhat bland, or cipher-like, but that reflects probably on the material and not MacFayden's performance (though hard to tell if I haven't read the book).  Maybe it's better to have a blank screen in which to project female desires upon?Ms. Knightley gave a wonderful performance.  Very likeable, passionate and intelligent.  Passionate, in the sense of expressing all her feelings, not just romantic-love yearnings.  She will have an interesting career.  Ms. Knightley displays a wonderful personality on talk shows and seems oblivious to her natural beauty.  She was wonderful in `Bend It Like Beckham' playing a bit of a tomboy, and can obviously play more refined (and costumed) characters with equal charm.  The only thing that can prevent her from becoming the most popular actress in the world within five to seven years is if female moviegoers are more threatened by her beauty than sympathetic to the characters she plays.Final note:  The coda scene.  The producers did not show this scene in England and obviously rate the average English intelligence or taste higher than our American ones.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie has become one of my all time favorite romances. You can really connect with the characters and their struggle to be together. I plan on owning this movie for myself someday because it's that good. I'd watch it over and over and never get tired of it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie has been my personal favorite for years.  I can watch it again and again and never get bored with it.  Every time I watch it, I pick up on new details that I missed before.  It's a wonderful romance for any romantic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My favorite movie of all time!!!! "You have bewitched me, body and soul." - Mr. Darcy Romantics...you must watch this movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: okay, I tried, REALLY tried to like this version... but, I couldn't...  not that it wasn't good, it is just that I've been spoiled by the BBC version.... the one with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth...  but also, the acting wasn't nearly as good...  the leading lady did a very good job, but, the others were quite bad...Darcy - very wooden, not likeable at allThe Mother - annoying, not amusing...The Father - usually, I like Donald Southerland, but, in this picture, he looked like he had to go to the bathroom the entire time.Jane - seemed confusedthe ONLY plus in this version was Wickhim... he was actually handsome in this version...
summary: Don't Bother with this version if you've seen BBC's...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am an avid fan of period dramas, so when I first saw the previews for this movie I couldn't wait for it to come out.If they had a satisfaction guarantee at the movie theater, I would've asked for my money back. This movie is appalling in its complete lack of substance - not to mention its failure to stay in keeping with the actual book.The actors are poorly cast and Keira Knightley in particular struggles under the weight of portraying what is arguably one of history's finest and most complex literary heroines. The worst offense, however, is the absolutely unsuitable, unknown actor cast in the role of Mr. Darcy - a character whose disdain and disapproval of almost everything in life are completely lost on the actor.Perhaps if the cast & director had read the book before embarking on this disaster, we would've all been spared such an abysmal and offendingly bad movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Out of all Jane Austen's literary works Pride and Prejudice is the novel most people identify with her.  It is a story similar to many other masterpieces, as it tells a story of love.  Yet, it is so much more than a mere love story that unites aching hearts.  It brings out the strong patriarchal traditions and social class system that governs the society at the turn of the century between the 18th and 19th century.  Aristocratic women at this time avoided physical labor while prudently sitting still much like well-trained lap dogs in order to attract a proper suitor with high social status, wealth, and refined etiquette.  Thus, love was something secondary, as marriage provided the means for a woman to function with some freedom within in a society with intricate and rigorous rules.  Austen thought differently, and subtly assaulted the establishment with eloquent wit and delicate humor in her tour de force.Joe Wright is not the first director to attempt to provide a cinematic version of Austen's celebrated novel.  Two handfuls of adaptations have retold the story of Pride and Prejudice, yet Wright succeeds in delivering one of the best.  He remains true to the novel (despite its short format), while also capturing the social atmosphere in a genuine manner.  Besides applying the proper etiquette in a convincing manner, Wright makes sure that the film also looks authentic through details of muddy hems and the real class difference between people emerges through the actors' costumes.  Wright also enhances the storyline with breathtaking scenery ranging from dewy dawns at the edge of the forest to death springing cliffs, which helps to artistically reveal the emotional and social situation of the moment.  Much of this is also thanks to the terrific cinematography in the film by Roman Oshin.The opening shot displays the sun emerging above the tree line while the song of birds accompanied by a lone piano aurally enhance the scene.  The dawning obviously suggests in a symbolic way of a new beginning, as Pride & Prejudice is about to take its course.  In the very next shot, Elizabeth "Lizzy" Bennet (Keira Knightley) wanders a meadow while finishing a book.  The contrasting elements in these two sequential scenes provide a slight hint toward Lizzy's delicate rebelliousness, which is augmented by her sisters tendency to remain at home while she gladly roam the outdoors by herself.  The slight social disobedience that Lizzy possesses presents the major reason why the story takes place at all, as all other female characters around them follow the traditional rules that govern them.Lizzy's footsteps lead her home where the story quickly begins to take form, as it becomes known that Mr. Bingley (Simon Wood) has arrived to the Netherfield Park and he collects a substantial annual income.  Along with the wealth he has a high-ranking social status and is single.  The mother Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) rapidly begins to plan for her daughters to meet the gentleman, as her lot in life is to make sure that her daughters get married.  Meanwhile, her husband, Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland), leisurely goes about his business to study plants and insects, as all five of his daughters are preparing to meet the gentleman.  It is yet another subtle illustration of males' acquired superior status due to a chromosome that eventually makes them men.As the story unfolds, Mr. Bingley falls in love with Jane Bennet (Rosamund Pike) and he begins to court her.  At the same time, Lizzy finds her heart crushed by Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen) who plays the status card against her, and Lizzy decides to hate him for all eternity.  Ellizabeth also learns about a family secret between Mr. Darcy and Mr. Wickham (Rupert Friend), which only increases her contempt for Mr. Darcy.  In the process, Elizabeth learns that Mr. Bingley has abandoned his pursuit for Jane's heart and hand.  Amidst of all this, Elizabeth also declines (something unheard of at the time) a marriage with her wealthy and distant cousin.  Instead the cousin marries her best friend, and the plot continues to thicken when she is invited to stay with her friend, as she also meets Mr. Darcy again who seems to have an ulterior agenda.If the viewers have not read the book by Austen, the film will certainly present a deep appreciation for her literary cunningness.  The many side plots keep the audience intrigued while the focus follows whether the truly beloved will find one another.  Yet, underneath this overt love story, Austen presents a true image of a woman's lot in life, which Wright skillfully captures.  Another aspect that makes this story unique is its deep understanding of human cognition besides the social message, which shines through its profound use of generalizations, assumptions, and preconceived notions.  Many of the cast members help bring out the many qualities in the script in a brilliant manner with the performing highlights in Keira Knightley, Brenda Blethyn, and Donald Sutherland.  Keira Knightly received an Oscar nomination her part as Lizzy, but I feel that Brenda Blethyn was robbed from a supporting role nomination, as the energetically scheming mother.  In the end, Pride & Prejudice presents an adaptation worthy of Austen's literary dexterity, which entertains and offers contemplation to those who seek something meaningful.
summary: Eloquent and Witty Adaptation of Austen's Tour de Force...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I had high hopes for this adaptation, hoping that despite the choices in casting, it would be a film of superb visual quality at the very least.  I was amazingly disappointed.  Not only are the performances lack-luster, at best (the exception being Dame Judi Dench who is always remarkable), the costuming was dreadful.  Half of the time I was cringing over the clothing of the wrong time period, and the other half noting clothing that was far beneath the station of the characters. The Bennett girls, and Darcy, always looked a disheveled mess, and Mr. Bingley was the only one with the appropriate hairstyle.  Had the performances been strong, I could have forced myself to overlook these technical flaws. Unfortunately we are left with an Elizabeth Bennett who has no strength, a Darcy who just always seems angry and never changes, and no development of the other characters or their relationships to one another.  The director was, obviously, relying on a viewer who was so familiar with the novel all of the pieces could be filled in your head, rather than on screen.  Overall, don't waste your time, get the 1995 BBC version instead, and enjoy a long, lovely afternoon.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This particular rendition of Pride and Prejudice is outstanding.  Miss Elizabeth is clearly the equal of Mr. Darcy and the major characters were fully explored.  Love it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This adaptation of this beloved novel is the wonderful combination of hot men and characters that we already love.  Every girl wants her own Darcy and if he looks like this Darcy does, you will dare any woman to make a pass at him!!  I love when movies kind of push the envelope just a bit with Austen's men and her beautiful heroines.  I think Matthew and Keira are beautifully matched together in this movie and bring the characters to life in a way that makes me want to know Elizabeth and Fitzwilliam personally.  With all Austen characters, I feel like that I am that girl in the story because Austen wrote stories that happened to real women.  Now, of course, we girls are looking for our Edward (Twilight fans, unite!!), but Darcy will always be our first love.  This is a must see if you are an Austen fan, just have heard of Austen, or just love hot men!!! Enjoy and bring your own hot man to hold you in his arms while you watch this beautiful film.
summary: If you love Hot Men and Mr. Darcy, this is the movie for you!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Probably my all time favorite movie. In my opinion Matthew Macfadyen is the best Mr. Darcy. I also loved Kiera Nightly in this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This presentation of Pride and Prejudice is lovely yet realistic.  I love the attention to details, like the dishes on the table (shown as would appear naturally, not perfectly set), the lighting in the ballroom (candlelight), the gowns (not perfectly pressed).  Keira Knightly is a wonderful Elizabeth - witty, observant, happy and beautiful.  The countryside is unspoilt.  The story is represented much as the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version, but with tweaks in the screenplay.  I found the difference in words refreshing and it is a fresh view of an old favorite.  I recommend this version heartily.  I love all versions of Pride and Prejudice but this is really, really nice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a luscious version of Jane Austen's novel, with compelling performances by all of the lead actors. The soundtrack is moving, costumes striking, and the landscape is breathtaking.  I have watched the film several times, and still swoon when Darcy comes striding across the moors in his long coat. Sigh.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I adore this movie and the book, too! Definitely worth reading/watching! It's a subtle romance and will have you begging for more of this heart throbbing adventure!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a shame to butcher the lovely dialogue, flatten the characters (especially Mr. Bennet), and ruin the storyline of one of the best books of all time.  A pig running through the house, the sharp-eyed, sharp-tongued and very clever Mr. Bennet barely able to put together a coherent sentence in key scenes, and Longbourn and its ladies totally unkempt?  Ridiculous - Jane Austen must be turning over in her grave.  So disappointing.
summary: Seriously???  What a waste of 2 hours!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's was always on TV and I'd catch jut the tail end of it and could never remember the whole story. I'm so glad I purchased it. I've watched the whole thing several times. Great movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The most important thing to say when concerning Pride and Prejudice is that there are many versions of the story, some are better than others.  Of course everyone, especially the devout Jane Austen fans will say that they best version of the story is the 1995 version with Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle.  I have to agree with them, it is the gold standard when it comes to Pride and Prejudice.I was convinced that I was going to hate this version.  At first I could not see Matthew Macfayden as Mr. Darcy, it just did not seem right to me.  Not to mention the fact that it would be a shorter movie so I felt that it probably would not do the book justice.  After the first time I watched it, I thought it was okay.  I found the dialogue fast-paced, and I thought they left some major scenes out. I also thought that people who were not familiar with the story might get confused as somethings were not explained very well or misleading.The second time I watched it, I don't know what happened but it all fell together better and it was like magic.  I fell in love with Matthew Macfayden as Mr. Darcy (he almost peaks Colin Firth in my opinion) and the chemistry he has with Keira Knightley is just electric.  From their first meeting, the atmosphere is so charged with it the audience can feel it. If you step away from the plot, and look at the movie by itself it just shines, even though they stray from the book how they present the story is just lovely, and maybe more relatible to us today.  My heart still flutters at the end of the movie in the early morning when Mr. Darcy comes to speak with Elizabeth again.  I find myself sobbing, even though I have watched it countless times.Even though, the 1995 version is the best made from the screenplay by Andrew Davies to the acting and costume this version starring Matthew Macfayden and Keira Knightley offers a different perspective to the story that is fresh and exciting and is well worth watching.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love the story.  My favorite Jane Austen novel.  Loved the acting, the cinematography and the script.  Can't see it enough!
summary: One of my all time favorite movies

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am sorry, but I really cannot recommend this movie for what it is supposed to be- And that is Jane Austin's Pride & Predjudice.  I am a fan of Austin and of the era.  I am more than willing to accept literary license, and even enjoy different versions of the same story, but it took me 4 tries to sit through this movie until the end.Kneira Knightly is a beautiful women, but she absolutely is NOT Elizabeth. The movie is ok, if you know nothing about Austin, the book, or how the wealthy of that era act and what they will accept. In this movie, Elizabeth is portrayed as a women who appears unkept, sloppy, drab and more than pleased with herself when she slights a wealthy member of society-which is pure hogwash for a woman of her time-no matter how intelligent or sassy she is. Besides, what would Mr Darcy even find to be attracted to, especially strongly enough to cause a minor scandal in marrying her -she looks like a shapeless frump. She has an unexplained smile/smirk on her face most of the time-which is destracting, since it doesn't belong there. I was so disappointed in this movie- and I only made myself finish watching it, because I paid money for it.Go ahead and buy it if, as I said, you have never read Austin or do not know much about history.  You will enjoy it for what it really is. A chic flick that takes place in the early 1800's.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Excellent film over all, well acted.  If you enjoy period films, or are a big Jane Austen fan you will really enjoy this adaptation.
summary: Great adaptation of a wonderful story

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Loved it!  This proves that you can make a powerfully romantic movie without showing inappropriate scenes in the bedroom.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My daughters and I watch this DVD at least once a month. The cinematography, the actors, and the music are captivating! We know most of the scenes by heart. Can't get enough of it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: yes- I am officially a 'chick' who loves a good romantic movie. I had to admit it when I realized I had watched this movie almost every year since it came out. The PBS series with Colin Firth is the full meal when it comes to a more filled out version of Jane Austen's novel, but this version is the more sensuous, visually stunning two hour offering, filled with deeper emotion and feeling, and it seems to present new details and nuances with every viewing. Ahhhhhhh.... absolutely lovely... not to be missed
summary: Fall Deeper in Love with this movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I keep renting it as I just have to see it every few months.  I love this era and the scenery is especially compelling.  Every actor is an excellent performer and I love happy endings!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I went to see this movie simply out of curiosity, for Pride and Prejudice is my favorite book, and I have never seen a movie adaptation of it before.  My goodness, I don't think the director could have mangled the story any better than if he had set out to do it.  There were many jarring factors, especially the inappropriate casting and the incomprehensible alterations of the original plot.My biggest annoyance with the movie was with the cast.  Mr. Bennett comes across as an old has-been hippie (complete with stringy unkempt hair and ill-fitting clothes) who dodders dazedly around his house and farm.  He didn't take much notice of things in the book either, but that was because he chose to ignore them, not because he was totally zoned out.  Mrs. Bennett is way too overdone and excessively silly.  Jane was sweet and beautiful, but was not allowed to fully develop her character on her own- an unwise omission, I thought, since Jane and Elizabeth are very close in the book and Jane is important in keeping the story flowing in several places.  Mr. Bingley- ugh!  He was wimpy and girlish, and I especially detested the vacant, silly look on his face.Of course, Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy are the most important characters, and sadly, the casting for them was no better.  Obviously, Keira Knightley interpreted Elizabeth as aggressive and rude rather than lively and witty.  She has a very unattractive habit of jutting out her jaw and spitting out angry words.  Rather than being proud and "noble," Mr. Darcy is gloomy and cross.  I saw an interview in which Matthew McFadyen said "Mr. Darcy was just shy."  SHY??  Um, noooo..... maybe that's why the book is called PRIDE and Prejudice?!  The transformation of Mr. Darcy's character in the book never materialized in the movie; I think he might have smiled twice the whole time, toward the very end.  Watching Keira and Matt together, I wondered how the director possibly thought their behavior would convice audiences that they have fallen in love by the end of the movie.  What could Darcy see in a girl that glares, pushes her face into his and fairly gnashes her teeth at him?  And what could Lizzy see in a man who acts so dull and lifeless?The other jarring factors in the movie were the pointless twistings of the original scenes from the book, and the addition of scenes or elements that are nowhere in the book and never would have been.  For example, Lizzy goes to Pemberley (an art museum disguised as a country estate, it would seem) and spends several minutes contemplating marble statues.  Nude ones, I might add; I think they were old Greek gods.  The purpose of this long and boring scene is not clear, unless it was put in to satisfy the director's evident enjoyment of nudity.  All the big houses in the movie have enormous murals of nude figures, Pemberley has a huge art museum filled with marble ones, and back at Longbourn (the "estate" that somehow became a dirty, noisy farm in the movie) we are shown a full shot of a trotting pig's behind (and other things) that was completely pointless.  I also wasn't quite sure what the point was behind the "Lizzy on top of the world" scene, besides the pretty photography; or why she apparently spends a whole afternoon staring hollowly at herself in her mirror.  I could go on and on, but why, oh why, were important elements of the book left out, cutting big holes in the story, while many precious minutes were spent on long, artsy scenes that serve little purpose in the plot?And why were practically all the settings for scenes changed too, like Darcy proposing in the rain instead of in Charlotte's parlor? or Lady Catherine paying a visit to Elizabeth in the middle of the night? or Colonel Fitzwilliam whispering info about Darcy to Elizabeth during church rather than while they were out walking?  One thing that really became old, and then irritating, after awhile was the entire gigglesome Bennet family listening at closed doors every single time a private conversation was taking place.  Other reviewers have mentioned other transgressions against the social norms of the day, and I agree with all of them; I will add that the biggest one for me was Lizzy going for a pre-dawn walk in her nightgown.  As I had watched "Pirates" I have to admit that I fully expected that Keira Knightley would wander around in her nightgown at some point, and she didn't disappoint me there.  But there was a twist here; Mr. Darcy shows up in his nightshirt too!  I really don't believe people in those days strolled around the countryside without getting properly dressed first.Well, to sum it all up, I do not recommend this movie, particularly if you enjoy the book and, like me, expect movies to follow the book's plot and accurately portray its characters.  The only thing I liked at all about this movie was the music.  I suppose if you have not read the book, you will think the movie is pretty good, but I warn you that it is a very distorted, and inferior, version of the brilliant plot and captivating characters in the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is truly an excellent film version of Pride & Prejudice.  The scenery is lush, inviting and magical. The actors are perfect in every way.  Keira Knightley brings a new freshness and charm to the character of Miss Elizabeth Bennet through her infectious laughter and fearlessness.  Matthew Macfadyen, as  Mr. Darcy, is distant, frosty, vulnerable  and attractive all at the same time. Their combined energy makes the movie real and believable.  It's easy to become invested in the story and its outcome.  Be warned, however, one viewing of this great film will not be enough, so be prepared to watch it again and again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love, love, LOVE this movie!!!!  The book is awesome and this movie is GREAT!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have never read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice.  I don't know how well this movie follows the book.  If you have read the book and are a stickler for such things, you probably won't like this movie.However, if you are interested in a well made movie with a happy ending, you'll enjoy this version.  I rented it initially and had trouble persuading myself to return the rental.  Then I just decided I would buy my own copy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The characters were lovely, the scenery fantastic, costumes wonderful.  I very much enjoyed this abbreviated version of "Pride and Prejudice".

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The story is so good even in this compact version. It's beautifully photographed. A really good romance movie for those days when you just need to escape.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: K. L Sadler "Dr. Karen L. Sadler"
review_text: This movie has gained a place in my heart. I have read Pride and Prejudice several times. I'm a fan of Jane Austen's books, partly because she seemed to be ahead of her times as concerns the rights of women (she didn't accept the 'place' they were caught in), and she wrote with such a sense of humor. Though I enjoyed the serial with Firth in it also, this 'take' caught her sense of humor, and I've never seen a woman deliver her lines for Elizabeth with such an impish glee as Keira Knightley gave. Yes, there were a few changes in the story...but on the whole I think Austen would have been pleased.It had been years since I'd seen Donald Sutherland play such a good part for him, and do it so well. You can see Elizabeth's frustration with her bookish father's inability to put his foot down to control his frivolous younger daughter. And it comes back to haunt him.It didn't hurt to have MacFayden play the handsome Darcy either, though I'd have a hard time choosing between him and Colin Firth.A great addition to the films from Austen's stories...
summary: One of the most beautiful movies ever made.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Simply the best.  Excellent portrayal of the characters.  I've watched it so many times but I'm still taken by it especially the early morning scene in the end with Darcy and Elizabeth.  Breath taking!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley is wonderful as Lizzie.  All the characters in this story are very well cast.  This version of Pride & Prejudice is one of the best!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Matthew Macfadyen's acting was amazing.  His performance alone makes this movie worth watching.  There was never a dull moment.  The photography, the music, art direction and the supporting cast.. everything about it was spectacular.I highly recommend it to everyone.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was startling initially because of the shabbiness/drabness of the initial setting -- Keira amongst the chickens?  But once you get over this change to a realistic scene rather than one of grandeur and glitz set by past versions, the realization that the changes are for the better grow on you -- The characters are warmer, younger, and what I liked best about it was the change from the one dimensioned silliness of the mom in the BBC version --In the BBC version, you would wonder how one could be attached to so silly and horrid a woman there, but here, the family is portrayed with a warmth that makes the story much more real -- Lizzie's attachment to her family and their plight is more believable as coming from Love rather than just Duty.  And you can see the woman her father fell in love with and had 5 children with -- The biting relationship in the BBC series between the parents made me wonder how they ever had five children when he so clearly despised his wife.The sweaty lively assembly brought to life the energy in social dance.  I loved the movie!  I could only wish there were as many hours to be spent with these characters as in the mini series, but they've done a wonderful job with the movie.
summary: Loved this version though the Colin Firth BBC version is a classic take too

review_text: This did justice to the book.  Some of Mr. Bennett's quips were memorably straight from his dialogue in the book.  I love that.  It adds another dimension to those of us who watch movies (and remakes) made from the classic novels in order to enjoy the activity of compare and contrast.Overall, this was warmer than the 1940 film.  Darcy and Lizzie were classy and intelligent but adorable in their aloofness.  I was glad to see them not appear "dear".  They're not "dear".  They are instead amused by watching the characters around them feign "dearness".  The original characters were perfectly conveyed.

review_text: Horrible, horrible!  This adaptation would have been totally garbage had it not for Judy Dench. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First, I am shocked at how positive the reviews have been for this film. Second, I found that the film had two most egregious errors that changed the heart and character of the book:First is the elimination of the Pemberly scene where Elizabeth sees the change in temparment of Darcy from proud to friendly and charming.  This with the letter is her true change in heart.  The movie makes the love seem more of an obligation for saving Lydia than having solidified prior to the incident.Second is the hack job of dialog making everything explicit.  What is wonderful about Austen is a comedy of subtle manners.  The minute Charlotte Lucas starts yelling at Lizzie, I realized that the spirit and charm of Austen had been lost.  This movie was a complete waste of time.
summary: Missed the charm and joy of the book

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This adaptation of Jane Austen's 1813 novel is one of the best to come out of Hollywood.Austen's novel begins with, "It is a truth universally acknowledged that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife."  In Pride and Prejudice Elizabeth Bennet (Keira Knightley) supplies the prejudice.  The pride comes from Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen) who finds Elizabeth attractive and intelligent but beneath him.  Miss Bennet finds Mr. Darcy a snob.  Both play their parts well.However, Jane Austen novels are set at a slower time and written for people who had the time to read them.  They are leisurely affairs to be read over days.  Therefore, no movie of 129 minutes can adequately capture the depth of her genius.  That is why I have always enjoyed the A&E;/BBC miniseries with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth.  While the miniseries did not have the budget of the movie, it had time, 300 minutes, to develop the plot.  Although the opening scene in the miniseries is not in Austen's novel, whole pages of text are presented verbatim.Another strength of the movie is the excellent cinematography.  The sets and scenes are exquisitely shot.  However, the movie has been criticized for making the Bennet family appear lower in class.  We are never sure from the novel exactly what Mr. Darcy found objectionable with the Bennet family.  I would say that the movie portrays the difference in class between the two families well.  Demonstrating this class difference might even be a weakness of the miniseries.  I am not bothered by the modernization of the dialogue, this helps the modern audience enjoy the movie, but what does bother me is the modernization of etiquette and morals.  Men and women of the time did not casually allow visitors in their bedrooms or when they were only partially dressed.I enjoy and study Regency and Victorian literature and have seen every Austen movie ever made and read her books.  I have both this movie and the miniseries in my collection and enjoy them both.  I have rated the movie four-stars in comparison to the A&E;/BBC miniseries.  For fans of Jane Austen, both are well worth watching.Kyle Pratt

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This book has been done many times and one of my all time favorite series was the one with Colin Firth - a fantastic version of Mr. Darcy. When P&P the 1995 series came out they said England (and especially London) had "Darcy Fever" because Colin Firth so captivated the masses with his smoldering performance.  That said, I really enjoyed watching this movie and even rewatched all my favorite parts, which, for me at least, is proof of an arresting piece of work.  The cast - notably - Keira Knightley, Matthew Macfadyen, Brenda Blethyn, and Donald Sutherland are the type you can't keep your eyes off of when they are on screen.  The manners weren't quite as stiff as portrayed in the series - you could see the familial love and there was actually some awkwardness in Darcy which made the characters warmer and more accessible.  Well done.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The only reason I gave this film two stars is that I thought the scenery and cinematography was beautiful. Other than that, I was very disappointed. I tried watching this with an open mind (OK..it may not be exactly true to the book, but try to judge it on its own merit.) Well I'm sorry this movie had no merit. Acting was lame (even though many of the actors in this movie have done great work in the past), and obviously the writers made no effort to at least try to remain true to the original story at least a little bit. "Pride and Prejudice" is one of my favorite novels, but this film did it no justice whatsoever.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie seemed to be authentic on many fronts: House messy and dirty, mud in the front yard, pigs wandering into the house---but for a family with five girls, two parents and a cook, that was the way people lived (except for the very wealthy) in the late 18th century.  The country pastoral scenes were absolutely beautiful! The wealthy mansions, their art, statues and surrounding grounds were amazing!This movie is a virtual dictionary of miscommunications, misunderstandings, wrong judgements of others, manipulations, power, control, greed, etc.  But on the positive side, also of love, genuine caring for the lives of others, shyness, passion and truth.Happily, all the right people eventually get together after the eleven main characters (each with their own agenda and totally different personalities) are thrown together in the cauldron pot we call "society".  It is more than a love story----that's why men will like this movie--it is a picture--a "snap" in the camera of time of the constant worry of having enough money, of wealth, of position, of high character and low; but also of truth, honesty, patience, lying, deception and manipulation.But the higher virtues of truth, forgivness and love win out over the baser virtues (light is stronger than darkness), and that is why this story is a "classic" and shall remain so for generations.  I see a real life Cinderella and Prince Charming.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being that i love the BBC & A&E; version with Colin Firth i went in hoping that when this comes out on dvd i could add it to my dvd collection right beside my BBC & A&E; version and its worthy, The pride & preduice formula & plot never gets old to meFabulous MovieI absolutley loved this movie. I went to see it in the theatre and would have gone one more time, but unfortuantely it went out of theatres. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD on Feb 28th. I love this movie, and if you watch it you will love it too!I know everyone has their own opinion but sometimes i feel like there are 2 types of people on amazon, the type who really likes something and the type who hates on everyone for liking it, not because they think its bad but because they don't want to jump on the wagon like everyone else and admit its a good movie...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is definitely one of my all-time favorites!
