I'm in the middle of reading the book now, and I love it just as much as the movie. I think Wright did a wonderful job with the layout of different scenes and the original shots were excellent. Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy (don't know the actor's  name) had perfect chemistry! Besides the obvious romance, watching the whole Bennet family in action was so entertaining and eye-opening to the common characteristics found in every family. You have to see this one!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The writers for the film have done a good job at adapting the famous "Pride and Prejudice" novel written by Jane Austen, into a short 2-hour film (I say this in comparison to the 6+ hour BBC series). Needless to say, some of the original meaning and conversations are omitted or altered in the film, or placed in different settings/scenes in order to give audiences as much of the original and full meaning provided in the book. Overall, I think this is done quite well.The Bennett household is a family of colourful characters, the most sensible of which are Lizzy and her sister Jane. Like any normal family, they are not exempt from their fair share of dramas - some of which, pose a threat to the happiness of Lizzy and her family's social-standing.In Lizzy's initial encounter with Mr Darcy, she vows to "loathe him for all eternity", and yet as fate would have it, events lead their paths to cross time and time again, and both must overcome their pride and prejudices in order to find true felicity.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: WARNING:  Plot points exposed in the following review...As a tremendous fan of the 1995 BBC miniseries I was curious as to how well the story would fare in a mere 127 minutes (versus the 300 minute miniseries behemoth).  Though seemingly rushed in places (there are plot points that could have done with more exposition - the character of Lydia Bennet being the most glaring example of this), I was pleasantly surprised!  Many (including myself) consider the BBC miniseries to be the definitive adaptation of Jane Austen's most popular novel, and as such it is impossible not to compare any newcomers to it.  Happily, this film stands up on its own.  At the beginning of the film, I found myself instinctively comparing the two on a line-by-line basis.  I soon found myself simply enjoying this adaptation.  It is small wonder then that Emma Thompson, whose marvellous adaptation of Sense & Sensibility garnered her a Golden Globe, had a hand in revising this screenplay (though she is uncredited for her efforts).  The script shines with her wit.The world of the Bennet family is far grittier than the BBC miniseries, the producers of which made a conscious decision to focus on the family in a sort of benign vacuum rather than placing them in the social context of the times.  The resulting reality of the film characters' lifestyle with pigs wandering to and fro in the yard brings the plight of the Bennet girls into sharp focus.  They simply MUST marry well lest they end farmer's wives with no servants and working themselves into early graves.  Or worse yet, poor single women once they are turned out of their home by Mr. Collins, obliged to depend on the kindness of others in Merryton.The always pleasing Keira Knightley does a lovely job as Elizabeth Bennet.  Rather than portraying her as shockingly pessimistic, she is simply the only member of the Bennet family (save perhaps Mr. Bennet) that does not go through life with blinders on.  Her performance as the conflicted heroine has won her Golden Globe and Oscar nominations, and deservedly so.  Matthew MacFadyen imbues his Darcy with a humanity that makes Colin Firth's Darcy seem wooden in comparison.  Darcy's inward struggle of wills is delicately portrayed with only fleeting glimpses of his utter agony amid the expected reserve of the upper class.  Speaking of wooden, however,  Rosamund Pike's portrayal of the angelic Jane leaves you wanting.  Her "reserve" as they called it, was a bit overplayed and resulted in a less than sympathetic character.  While Jena Malone does not come remotely close to bringing the bratty self-centeredness of Lydia to her scant screen time.  Had I not been so familiar with the character's innumerable flaws, I might have found myself wondering why she would have been so stupid as to go off on her infamous elopement.  To me, this is the major shortfall of this adaptation.  The elopement is the stomach-sickening climax of the novel, and much of the build-up to Lydia's downfall is omitted as is much of the search for the wayward Lydia.  The result is that the viewer is not as aware of how and why she would do such a thing nor truly the extent of the consequences of her actions.  Brenda Blethyn does an admirable job of portraying Mrs. Bennet as an overbearing, pushy mother without taking on the unbearable shrillness of the miniseries Mrs. Bennet.  Donald Sutherland, though I thought him an unusual choice for Mr. Bennet, is able to convey the guilt and shame that Mr. Bennet carries for not providing adequately for his daughters' futures all the while remaining oddly sympathetic.  Dame Judi Dench was the perfect selection for the imperious Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  However, she is much nastier than the miniseries version - to an uncomfortable extent.  Rather than being simply demeaning in that unconscious way that high-born people of her era were to others below their rank, she resorts to out-and-out cruelty.  Unneccesarily, I might add (though this is a shortfall of the screenplay, not Dame Judi).In all, this version of the classic tale is remarkably well done, most especially in the development of the relationship between Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy.  It is in the interactions of these two characters that the heart and soul of the movie resides; in two people so obviously perfect for each other that neither can see it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film adaptation of Jane Austen's novel is certain to become a classic. It is equisitely filmed in the English countryside in an authentic century English home, wonderfully acted by a delightful and scrupulously chosen cast, beautifully produced and directed with resplendent art direction and costumes, and features Dario Marianelli's Oscar-nominated original score that is consistently endearing to the ear, mind and senses.Keira Knightley, one of England's best actors, plays Austen's heroine, Elizabeth Bennet, an Englishwoman of dubious breeding that nonetheless is headstrong, opinionated, domineering and silly. She makes good and bad decisions and is smart enough to change her mind about the bad ones. The story revolves around Lizzy and her four sisters, her parents, the royal beau that will become her husband, and members of his family. A splendid supporting cast including Donald Sutherland, Judi Densch and Jean Malone forms the foundation for Knightley's electric performance in the lead role.Jane Austen (1775-1817) was a peer of Ludwig van Beethoven (1770-1827) and lived during the crossover from the Classical to Romantic eras in music, art and literature. Her half-dozen novels form the basis for the comedy of manners in England's class society of the 1700s. "Pride and Prejudice" is said to be the most romantic book ever written. Even through the script varies from the novel's storyline, this memorable film adaptation mirrors the wit, humor, empathy, love, jealousy and realism of family dynamics portrayed in Austen's novel.A cherry on top is provided by Jean Thibeaudet's rapturuous piano playing in the original score, the best film score I've heard since "The Pianist". While the influence of early Beethoven is clear in the main theme and much of the score is authentic to the period, some of the music is too romantic and belongs to the mid-1800s. This and other minor blemishes aside, this is a remarkable film treatment of a classic novel that provides romance, humor, wonder and satisfaction. Buy, rent or borrow this fabulous film today.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is not a perfect movie (I really would rather give it 4 1/2 stars or so) but it is still excellent. It is by far my favorite adaptation of Pride and Prejudice (and I've seen all the available versions except the Mormon one- 1940, 1980, 1995, and Bride and Prejudice). This movie is very realistic in that it portrays how unclean times were back then (no, it's not dirty or gross or anything, don't worry). Perhaps the filmmakers went a little too far in the case of the Bennet house, but that was done to contrast their situation to those of Darcy and Bingley.The casting is excellent. I was hesistant about Keira Knightley at first (I'd only seen a couple of her other movies and liked her in Bend it Like Beckham), but her Lizzy blew me away. She portrayed the arch, outspoken side of Lizzy as well as her sweet, unoffending nature. She also really showed the character's youth. Matthew McFayden's Darcy was totally different from any interpretation I've seen (shy, puppydog) but I couldn't call it inaccurate. He and Lizzy really have chemistry together. Brenda Blethyn was an amazing Mrs. Bennet- she is annoying and embarrassing but believable not over-the-top. Rosamunde Pike is the beautiful Jane I have been waiting for. None of the other Janes I've seen are even as pretty as Lizzy. Some of the changes people might not like (but that I love)- Bingley is more of a goof, Caroline is a little meaner, Mary is prettier, and Mr. Bennet a more caring father (this one did bother me a little).On top of the great cast, the cinemotography is breathtaking, the music is beautiful, it uses a lot of Austen's own dialogue (but changes some of it slightly), and it's also hilarious. This was perhaps my favorite movie of 2005.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First, I think the actors did a find job with their roles; my issue is with the directorial decisions that made no sense. I had no problem with how the Bennett family was portrayed, and I even liked the rougher more unwashed look of the dancers at the minor balls -- in a world where bathing was a luxury, I can imagine that flyaway hair would be more natural than perfectly coiffed locks.The pacing was much too fast. I realize that it's a lot of story to fit into 2 hours, which is why it perhaps should not have been attempted. Today's life moves at breakneck speeds, but life in the nineteenth century would have been much slower, especially for families of their status.I do not understand the re-characterization of Mr. Bennett at all. In the book he's a quietly powerful figure stuck in a loveless marriage. When he speaks to Elizabeth at the end, he mentions the unhappiness of marrying someone you cannot respect, a direct allusion to his own situation. This movie portrays him as hen-pecked and even shows tenderness to his wife -- completely out of character with the original where he barely tolerates her silliness. To bolster this illustration of Mr. Bennett, some of his best lines are given to other roles. For example, Elizabeth challenges Mr. Collins as to whether his effusions are thought out ahead of time or the result of the moment. Elizabeth would never be so impertinent to a guest at her father's table, especially one with the power to put them out of their house!And lastly, Lady Catherine came calling in the middle of the night? I think not! There is nothing on earth that would have provoked a woman of such strict pride and ostentatious rectitude to arrive at the home of someone so far beneath her in the dark of night. It would be unheard of.If you don't care about the original story or its integrity and/or just want to get through it, please feel free to watch this. But if you want to know the real story, please read the book or watch the BBC production with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A magnificent reproduction of a gone world.Not only a wonderful ambientation and marvelous scenes reflecting the english countryside of the 19th century but also a profound study of that period's moral and way of living with a very rigid society where women were condemned to stay alone if they hadn't a dought to offer, or at least stay poor if they didn't find a rich groom.We are lucky to live in a world with social mobility.Very good actors

review_text: Keira is great; Matthew MacFadyen is better.  He has the rare ability to convey thought and emotion through facial expression alone - tremendously talented actor - the movie is worth watching for his performance alone, but when you take into account the talent and the skill of the other performances, and the breathtaking musical score by Marianelli, with it's goregous use of piano and stirring string arrangements, the film is a must see, which you will want to watch over and over again. summary: A film to watch over and over...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Like most people who love literature I was well aware that Jane Austen could write, but the idea that Keira Knightley can act and hold her own against the likes of Dame Judi Dench was a revelation.  Granted, Knightley has not particularly been called upon to turn in great acting performances in most of her films.  In "Love Actually" she is basically required to look pretty and her best moments are reaction shots rather than dialogue.  She has many more moments such as that in "Pride & Prejudice," but she also proves herself proficient at the witty dialogue.  Knightley filmed this version as her final film as a teenager and the results are comparable to when Franco Zeffirelli cast the teenage Olivia de Hussey in "Romeo & Juliet."This becomes the most romantic version of "Pride & Prejudice" because we are not surprised along with Lizzie when Darcy shows up and makes the most backhanded proposal of marriage in the history of Western literature.  The screenplay by Deborah Moggach (Emma Thompson receives special thanks in the credits, apparently for script doctoring) makes one significant change in the proceedings by simply having the moment when Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen) falls for Lizzie clearly written on his face.  At the Meryton ball she finds the perfect moment to throw the callous words that she has overheard back into his and with the rapier still skewering her victim she turns on her heels and walks away in triumph.When next he sees her she has walked over to Mr. Bingley's house to care for her sister Jane (Rosamund Pike), who has been taken ill because of the matrimonial machinations of their mother.  Lizzie's hair is down and she is positively glowing.  When we see the look of Darcy's face it is clear that he is beyond smitten, even though through the veneer of upper class manners the signs are decidedly subtle.  From that moment on his affection becomes transparent to us, although Lizzie is surprised to learn of its existence.  Joe Wright also creates a motif where the first time Darcy and Lizzie touch, as he helps her into a carriage, resonates by an emphasis at key moments throughout the film of Darcy's hands.Elizabeth Bennett is the most delightful of the Austen heroines because she has the virtue of not backing down.  Indeed, I believe Darcy first takes real notice of her because she stands up to him at the ball.  When she refuses to back down from Lady Catherine De Bourgh (Judi Dench) at the dinner table it struck me that one of the reasons she is so attractive to Darcy is because she is not trying to be.  Certainly Mrs. Bennett (Brenda Blythen) has taught her five daughters it is how to be on their best behavior to catch a husband, and in a world of such propriety her candor is refreshing.  Darcy's curt dismissal of her looks as being tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt him, becomes ironic because for my money it is her brains that make Elizabeth Bennett a real beauty both to him and to us.The screenplay necessitates cutting much of the action to reduce the tale to a two-hour film.  I appreciated being spared the unfortunate incident of Mary at the pianoforte as well as the constructed scene for the final fadeout and my only minor complaint would be that Lady Catherine does not utter her exit line from the novel when she takes her leave of Elizabeth in their final confrontation although I fully understand that the words cannot be uttered under those circumstances and the fact that Lady Catherine shows up immediately on hearing the rumor makes up for being denied the pleasure of hearing Dame Judy declaim that line.I had heard that the Jane Austen Society was less than pleased by Knightley's posture in this film, but one of the strengths of this production is that the Bennetts clearly live in the country.  There are dirt roads that lead to their home, where a large hog wanders through the front door, and when Mr. Darcy and the Bingleys make their first appearances at the local ball the dancing has an exuberance (not to mention slapping of hands) that makes it patently clear that we are far from the hallowed halls of Pemberly or the civilized life of London.  But the outside locations are as sumptuous as the gilded rooms in this film, and cinematographer Roman Osin makes both look gorgeous.For those who consider "Sense & Sensibility" to be the current cinematic benchmark for Austen adaptations I can report that "Pride & Prejudice" is its superior in terms of both romance and comedy by virtue of both crying and laughing more at this 2005 film..  Where Ang Lee's 1995 film comes out ahead is in its depiction of sisterhood, as Jane and Lizzie cannot rival Elinor and Marianne in their bonds of affection, which is understandable since it is more central to that Austen novel.  Even so there is a cute moment of confidences shared beneath the covers and Lizzie's spirited defense of her sister's shyness.  However, this one really is all about Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.I am not at all surprise that Kngihtly received a Best Actress nomination for her performance in this film.  As is invariably the case with such films the cast of supporting players is superb.  Brenda Blethyn's Mrs. Bennett is comically painful, but Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett has a touching final scene with his daughter, Tom Hollander is toadally obnoxious as Mr. Collins, and my wife really wants to slap Jenna Malone's Lydia a couple of times.  The best thing I can say about this version of "Pride & Prejudice" is that I went back to the theater to see it again, and the only other movie I did that for was "Revenge of the Sith" (I was using it for class).  This one was better.
summary: The most romantic version of "Pride & Prejudice" to date

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This nineteenth century setting by author Jane Austen stands as a memorable love story for the ages. Keira Knightley and Rosamund Pike (sisters of the English Bennet family) find their lives intertwining with the men they will marry.The Bennet parents (Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn) struggle to find the right suitors for their five daughters, as the girls discover the ups and downs of the right engagements.Without the reading of the book, I cannot compare but loved the movie and recommend it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have only seen the Firth/BBC version once and couldn't get past the hairstyles... however, I am in love with this Keira Knightley/Matthew MacFayden version from 2005. When I say "in love", I really mean it. I can always watch that movie and never be bored. The score is also amazing. While it does have some creative interpretations on happenings in the book as well as some creative cuts, I think that what they do include in the movie is very well done. There is a lot of chemistry between the actors, which I think is especially well played out in the gazebo scene in the rain. This movie is definitely worth multiple viewings, even if you just pop it in to listen to the beautiful score.
summary: Fabulous rendition of a classic novel

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen, but I am not a purist when it comes to any movie adaptation of a book. The book is always better; that is a given. The films based upon it strive to deserve its title. Cinema and literature are two very different forms of creative expression, and I believe that it is impossible for any film to completely capture Austen's genius of Pride and Prejudice. Yes, the BBC miniseries was excellent. This film is better. By not trying to "be" the book, but "be" the characters, this version of Pride and Prejudice brings new emotions that the BBC miniseries missed. I was never swept away by the miniseries; I love it, but it did not make me wish to be Lizzy, as the novel, and now this wonderful film, does. The director and actors portrayed the Pride and Prejudice of my imagination, and I can offer no higher praise than that.
summary: The pride of all P&P adaptations

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yet another re-release DVD, promising more special features when any regular fan, like myself, already has the first DVD release.About this DVD:1st Disc: Is the exact DVD released prior to this one. It has the widescreen movie version and all the same features on the previous DVD release.2nd Disc: This is the new disc with "extra" special features including...-Fullscreen movie version.-"The Politics of Dating" - A short feature with cast, crew, and director talking about modern vs. P&P; time dating (i.e. dancing, the 'touch', etc).  Most of the interview clips are recycled from what we've previously seen on the first disc special features. And brought little to nothing new to the table and lasted around 7 minutes.-"Galleries of the 19th Century" - Interactive photo gallery. Fun.-"The Stately Homes of Pride and Prejudice" - A small handful of about 5 minute interviews with cast, crew, and director talking about the different locations they worked at. New stuff, but nothing exceptionally interesting that lasts for long.-"Pride and Prejudice Family Tree" - A DVD menu telling us how the characters in the movie are related. It is pointless and useless, nothing interesting or new.-And that's IT.Packaging:It's absolutely gorgeous. I think all the money was spent on the box rather than putting together a decent 2nd disc. The package is made to look and open like a book. It's a great, beautifully designed set that is hard to resist if you saw it in stores.Booklet:A booklet was included in this set with some new, unseen photographs and talk about costumes, characters, and music. It's basically like a scrapbook of images and tidbits of various cast and crew's thoughts.Included:The soundtrack is included in a paper sleeve along with a ticket for director Joe Wright's upcoming film Atonement.Conclusion: If you were hoping for new interviews with the cast and director, unseen behind the scenes footage, deleted scenes, or anything worth shelling out more money to buy another DVD for, then you will be severely disappointed. If you're like me, and already own both the movie and soundtrack this really isn't worth the $28 buy. Because ultimately you're just getting just a pretty box, another copy of the DVD you already own, and a throwaway extra disc. But if you don't have the DVD or soundtrack yet, then I say go for this set because it will be worth the extra money to get both the movie and soundtrack, and flashy box.I give it 2 stars for the pitiful attempt at "exclusive all-new features"
summary: A lackluster attempt at a new P&P DVD release

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I first read Pride & Prejudice at the ripe old age of 9.  In the last 45 years I have read and reread all of Austen's works many times and can be considered something of an Austen authority.  It is risky to try to translate a written work so well known and loved as Pride & Prejudice to a visual medium, but there are folks who can't resist the challenge.  I've seen a few other attempts and must  praise the 2 disc BBC version (with Colin Firth et al) for its beauty and adherence to the text.  Others criticized it for not being as good as much older versions.  Some even faulted that the principals were not sufficiently beautiful or handsome.Comparatively, I felt this film was much more true to the 'facts' set forth in the text, if not to the text itself.  The Bennett women were  appropriately young.  The younger ones were in character and giggly.  Mr. Darcy seemed a bit young to me--not convincingly 30, but very convincingly reservewd.I fully expected to be critical of this effort, and couldn't see how anyone could have another view of the story worth putting forth. s But these producers and writers don't pretend to be true to Austen.  They shift the perspective to her characters.  This P & P shows life more as it might have been in the times about which Austen wrote.  Fans of regency romance are familiar with the term 'crush' as in, "The ball was expected to be the usual crush" (of people).  The dance sequences and balls evoke that very well. Portrayals of home life are also very much more 'realistic'.  Costumes are not as elaborate or as varied.  Sets are more believable--these are interiors to match the status of their owners.  And the sets and scenes and costumes do not draw attention from the actors' work.  The camera focuses on the characters and their facial expressions.This version humanizes the characters:  The men are not smooth sophisticates.  The women are not either buffoons or sophisticates.  The mother's relations with her daughters are more maternal than is evident in other versions or in the original text.  And in this film, the father is a much more sympathetic figure -- more in tune with his wife (foibles nothwistanding) and children.  It is clear he cares for them even as he feels clearly outnumbered by all these women.  But he is not bad tempered about it. Nor does he feel he has made a mistake in marrying a young woman with more beauty than good sense. The Neterfield ball shows him comforting the daughter he had to discipline, and coming to his wife's aid to fan her in the crush of guests.Most all the men come across as males (a common criticism of Austen's portrayals of men is she has no concept of the real thoughts or behaviors of men)--Collins is sexually frustrated, Bingley is tongue tied, and Darcy of course is smoldering, but his shyness comes across more clearly than in any previous portrayals, including the text.  It overrides his hauteur.In short, I didn't plan to like this.  As an Austen fan I should feel outraged at the rewriting of so many of her characters and the cutting out altogether of others.  But where this movie does not imitate art, it does infuse life into the tale and its characters.  The departure was a very bold move and a risky one.  It works.  For that reason alone it deserves 5 stars, but it is also a lovely effort.

review_text: I was excited to find one of my husband's favorite movies on DVD AND Blu-ray at such a low price. AND I could get a digital copy to boot. I don't download from unfamiliar websites and have been hesitate. Also, you have to download the movie to your PC, Ipad or Android/Smartphone. I rarely watch movies on these items, takes up too much memory. I watch my downloads from my Roku, which I thought, wrongly, would be where I would download this movie. I was very disappointed with this deception. No where is the buyer made aware of all this. I advice you to just buy the DVD/Blu Ray from where ever and if you want the download, go to your usually familiar site. This is so unlike Amazon. Not happy with this purchase.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie was absolutely wonderful! Keira Knightley does a wonderful job taking on the part of Elizabeth Bennet!At first it seems to the eye that Mr. Darcy is an awful soul full of bitterness and irritablness. But as you slowly proceed through the movie you learn more about him. And you realize that he's not so bad after all. Lizzie despised Mr. Darcy for his proud and arrogant nature. She thought he was the last soul on Earth that she could ever marry. Her fiery attitude towards Mr. Darcy causes friction among the two. And soon, they are both ashamed of who they were. And grow to become affectionate of one another.He was proud. She was prejudice. This movie is a great view!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Best, most dream-inspiring story ever written and an absolutely wonderful film adaptation.  I own both this one and the A&E; version (also wonderful - I love Colin Firth).  This one was soooo beautifully filmed and well done.  The actors were all very well cast and did their parts incredible justice.Please, no one wake me and tell me that Keira Knightly is not Lizzie and that Matthew McFayden isn't Darcy, or that there is such a man or such a love somewhere in the world.  They were perfect and I want to imagine that they still enjoy each other's beautiful company at Pemberly.If I ever watch this movie and don't have my head cocked dreamily to the side with tears streaking my face as he says 'Mrs. Darcy' over and over at the end, know that my heart has gone cold.When you need to escape, this is the dvd to put in...
summary: Only problem, I watch it too much...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I don't quite understand the negative reviews. Its not perfect, but it does really good job with the essence of the story given the time restraint. To do the story in the book requires more time (see BBC 6 episode version...which is also good). Creating a movie from this book requires some interpretation as we don't really get into Darcy's head. Plus the book often has narrative and not dialogue at key points, requiring screen writers to fill in what the characters would have said. Its interesting to see how the different movie versions (there was an old one with Lawrence Oliver, an 80's version, the BBC Colin Firth version and this one) deal with those narrative sections that needed dialogue.  I can see the complaint about Keira's portrayal being tomboyish, but I found it refreshing compared to other portrayals. Her Elizabeth did seem more frank and forward with her opinion (character traits of Elizabeth). In other versions the actresses said Elizabeth's words, but they didn't really exuded the essence of Elizabeth. I also thought the Bennett home and attire better showed the class distinction between the Bennetts and Darcy than other movie versions. The class distinction as well as the Bennett family's behavior are why Darcy initially objects to Elizabeth. I do love Colin Firth's Darcy, but I thought Matthew did a great job as well. I love the end when he walks across the field and stutters his feelings (which is different from the book, but I love it anyway). My impression of Darcy from the book was that aside from his station (which would make him proud) he was also shy. There are several passages in the book in which he talks about not feeling socially adept. I thought Matthew showed that part of Darcy well. I do wish it was more like the book (especially at Pemberly) but that would have been a longer film. If you don't know the book, I could see how it would be hard to see how these two could fall in love based on the interaction seen in the movie. More focus to Darcy/Elizabeth scenes from the book would have helped. I did like the last scene (in US version) a great deal and wished Austin had ended with a scene between Darcy and Elizabeth at Pemberly.
summary: I keep watching over and over...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've read Jane Austin's Pride & Prejudice twice, seen the A&E; mini-series with Colin Firth (love him!) and I've now seen Pride & Prejudice 2005 (about four times in one week).  This is going to be a comparative between the mini-series and the movie.First of all, I think it is important to note that the mini-series is approx. five hours long and the movie is approx. half that.  This provides the mini-series with an advantage.  The mini-series is SO true to the book in just about every realm.  One has a chance to get to know the characters thoroughly and fall in love with Mr. Darcy right along with Lizzy.However, there is one major thing missing from the mini-series that the movie possessed:  PASSION!  Colin Firth's portrayal of Mr. Darcy was bar none, but the young lady who played Lizzy (cannot recall her name at the moment) lacked the passion to match his own.  She also made Lizzy into far too serious a character.  In my opinion, she lacked the spunk that Lizzy had in the book.  Keep in mind, this was my opinion when I first watched the mini-series and watching the 2005 movie only made me far more aware of this opinion.  When Ms. Austin wrote Lizzy, she intended a character who was spunky, light hearted and very intelligent.  Ms. Knightly's portrayal of Lizzy matched what I had always imagined Lizzy being (and looking) like.Keira Knightly and Matthew Macfayden were by far breathtaking in the portrayals of their respective characters.  I was left breathless many times by the slight looks given by Matthew Macfayden and received by Keira Knightly.  Keira Knightly's performance of Lizzy's obvious hatred/affection for Mr. Darcy seeps through the screen into your own heart!  The passion of the 2005 movie version is undeniable!However, be aware that Hollywood did what Hollywood does best:  Fluffed it up and made it their own.  The mini-series version is so deep and involved with the original story line that it is totally engrossing.  However, the movie version brings the story to life with the passion and resonance that Ms. Austin intended.I would recommend watching both.  The mini-series for the depth of character development and strict storyline and the movie for the passion and moral awareness that this story was meant to portray.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: At the beginning of my review I'd like to state that I am a die-hard Jane Austen fan. P&P; is my favourite JA book. Naturally, I've seen all possible film versions and although the 2005 version is not the best, it's not the worst either.Almost everybody considers the '95 BBC version as the best, as the most authentic, so I would like to defend this version in comparison with the latter.Nobody in their right mind should expect a movie to cover everything in a book, I mean, 2 hours is not 6 hours, right? I am not saying that the script could not have been better, because that would be carrying things a bit too far. Maybe they should've given more opportunity to Emma Thompson who turned the novel S&S; into an amazingly good script.The scenery was very dramatic and beautiful, it could really express how the characters felt and what they were like. I liked the director's down-to-earth approach to the people, costumes and surroundings - ok, maybe the pig wandering through the house was not an indispensable accessory - versus the bit sterile and almost-too-groomed average appearance in the '95 series. Although I must say that the dark brown (YUK!) dress they made Keira wear while visiting Pemberley made me cringe in my seat.Concerning the "most important" character ... Mr Darcy, nobody can beat Colin Firth, that's for sure. However, I found Mathew MacFadyen's awkward and shy Darcy-figure humane and endearing. And I was positively surprised by Keira Knightley's performance as Elizabeth. She was convincingly lively, vivid and fresh. The chemistry between them was obvious (one of the most mouth-wateringly delicious scenes was the first proposal in the rain!) which is a welcome difference compared to BBC's P&P; where Jennifer Ehle sadly failed - not intellectually, but sensually - to respond to Firth's wonderful, sexy presence. I always felt it was a terrible waste. So a stronger attraction on both sides was a welcome change.I liked Rosamund Pike's Jane, Tom Hollander's Mr Collins (David Bamber's performance was not simply bordering grotesque, it was grotesque!) and Brenda Blethyn's Mrs Bennet. Judi Dench as Lady Catherine was too aggressive for me and the younger girls too wild.The most disturbing thing was really the lack of time. When I first saw the film - used as I was to the detailing in the series - I was disturbed by how the events seemed to race by, but on the second show it did not bother me any more.All in all, I think the latest P&P; fresh, delicious and enjoyable despite its shortcomings and worth watching twice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Oh the tension of love and the fear of expressing it. The clash between classes and the struggle between being full of pride and comprehending the depth of personal prejudices fill the screen. These two characters and the families they come from depict the dreams of those lacking and the arrogance of the rich and noble. Also there is a great depiction of the hunger of these two potential lovers have and how their communities lack any fulfillment for their hunger. These star crossed lovers fight through their issues and dismantle the social barriers to find each other. Great lines in this move!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, I'm a huge P&P; fan but I am not going to write a long analytical review here...there are plenty of them already.  I'm also not going to compare this movie to the 1995 version.  Comparing a two-hour movie to a six-hour mini-series is "apples and oranges."  Here's just a few thoughts that come to mind...*  The Bennet estate - What is with the shabby look and the  mud/farm animals everywhere?  In the book, the home is not richly decorated but it was certainly a lot more affluent than portrayed.*  The Bennet girls - Keira Knightley did a very good job portraying Lizzie...not perfect but not bad.  The actress who played Lydia was a little too over-the-top and was excessively annoying.  Rosamund Pike was very good as Jane and the other actresses playing Mary and Kitty were very good.*  Brenda Blethyn was very good as Mrs. Bennet and Donald Sutherland did okay as Mr. Bennet.  He did mumble a little too much.*  The Meryton Ball - What the heck was up with the hair...the women and the men?  Many of the extras (dancers, etc.) looked disheveled and needed a brush/comb at the very least.*  Characters missing - Where were the Hursts?*  Matthew Macfadyen was good as Darcy and the actor playing Bingley did a decent portrayal as well.*  What was the significance of the pig with the large "assets"?*  The scene at Netherfield discussing "accomplished women" was dull and did not add anything to the character development or the attraction between Darcy and Elizabeth.*  Makeup - Knightley wore a lot of makeup.  Did you notice she is the only female who wears makeup?  The eye shadow is obvious as well as the blush.  The actress playing Caroline Bingley might have some makeup on but Knightley's was obvious, especially the end scene in the meadow.  Did they not have enough confidence in her "natural" beauty"?  Also, the gown Knightley wore at the Netherfield Ball - a wonder bra or push-up bra might have helped. Also, when the Bennet's left the ball, Lizzie was not in the carriage.  How did she get home?*  Lizzie visits Pemberly - What's with the nude statues?  A portrait of Darcy alone would have worked nicely.  Also, where did Lizzie's aunt and uncle go?  Lizzie walked back to the village.  Did they leave her behind?  They were all touring the estate together and then the aunt and uncle disappear.*  Judi Dench's (Lady Catherine) hairstyle - Way over the top!!!*  Bingley would never have used the word "ass", especially in the midst of proposing to Jane.*  Lady Catherine would not have visited the Bennets in the middle of the night.*  Darcy's open shirt while crossing the meadow....okay, I have to forgive that one....If Colin Firth can jump into a pond and walk around with a wet open see-through shirt...As a female, I loved both scenes.  Please forgive me Jane Austen.*  Knightley and Macfadyen worked well together and I enjoyed their scenes, especially the declaration of love/proposal scenes and the looks Darcy would throw at Lizzie.  It's the incurable romantic in me.  I also liked the scene at the Meryton Ball where Darcy asks Lizzie the "encouraging affection" question.  Lizzie's reply is perfect.  At Netherfield when Jane and Lizzie are leaving, Darcy's hand reaction to first touching Lizzie was also a nice touch.Overall, it was a decent version.  After 193 years, a little creative interpretation of the book is refreshing.  It is a pity that Hollywood won't spend more $ and make a longer version.  Obviously, there was a lot missing from this version due to time constraints.  In two hours, you can't develop the characters and attraction between Darcy and Elizabeth properly.  If they can make King Kong three plus hours, why can't they make a longer version of P&P...I; know...because it won't rake in as much money as the action and special effects movies do but it's a shame.Ooops...this turned out longer than I thought.
summary: NOT A PERFECT VERSION BUT NOT TOO BAD

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a Christian so I am always looking for movies without violence and sexual content. This movie was captivating and very will done.  Keira Knightley was brilliant and I was transported back into that time period.  It is a perfect kindle movie for a woman.  I could almost watch it again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This 2005 film is really great when depicting the English countryside in the early 19th century.  It's also brings to life the social realities of matchmaking.  The acting, especially by Kiera Knightly is fantastic.  By now you must be thinking that I would heap further accolades on this film based on the Jane Austin novel.  Well, that's not going to happen.  I know this is personal taste, but I just didn't like it.For the past several hundred years, Jane Austin's novels have been the basic theme of romantic novels and films.  There's a high spirited young woman who meets a very rich man.  She's always beautiful and of marriageable age, but he is of a higher class.  At first they hate each other and he seems like a cad.  The insults fly and the young woman shows she knows how to use her words in a clever way.  This impresses the gentleman.  Little by little, the audience and the heroine start to appreciate him.  There are always obstacles.  But in the end these two main characters always hook up.No matter how well this theme is carried out in movies, TV, or romantic songs, I always find it boring.  There are no surprises and there is just so much beautiful scenery and gorgeous ball gowns that I can stand.  Often, too, if it is a British film, I cannot understand much of the dialogue and I yearn for subtitles.Recommended for romance loves only who will love this film.  My mistake was that I was willing to watch the film in the first place.
summary: For lovers of romance stories, but not for me

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Linda Lou "Obsessive reader, 6-10 books a wee...
review_text: I think that I've seen just about every version made of this Jane Austen classic. This is such a great and endearing story that it is hard to mess it up (although the Bollywood bad-acid-trip "Bride and Prejudice" came very close!) But director, Joe Wright, showed that he was up to the task, doing a great job of retelling the foibles of the Bennet sisters. Keira Knightley's Elizabeth is strong and reminscent of a contemporary feminist while remaining true to the mores of the period. Matthew Macfadyen isn't the best Mr. Darcy, but it's hard to come behind the magnificent Colin Firth who played the role in 1995 as if he lived across the road from Jane Austin. Brenda Blethyn (Mrs. Bennet) shines as a mother on a well-planned mission to marry off FIVE daughters. Rosamund Pike (Jane) is the classic English rose while Talulah Riley's portrayal of Mary is not the usual ugly wallflower. Newcomers Jena Malone and Carey Mulligan (Lydia and Kitty) make the best clueless Victorian "hoochies" ever! But the real treat here is Donald Sutherland as the estrogen drowned Mr. Bennet. He has masterfully executed an unexpected role for him, exhibiting a refreshing tongue-in-cheek patience. Dame Judi Dench, always in top form, makes the best Lady Catherine De Bourgh to date. Unlike the previous adaptations, here the viewer is not bounced back and forth between London and the countryside locations and the costumes aren't overly fussy, giving the overall production an understated lushness. I would love to see what Joe Wright could do with "Sense and Sensibility" and "Emma".

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is one of the best movies made.  The story was written back in the 1800's about a family in the 1700's.  its a beautiful love story that everyone in the family can watch.  The acting is superb, the music is lovely as well as the scenery.  Well made.  I never get tired of watching it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Of all the many versions of Pride & Prejudice, I feel this one best portrays the characters as I see them while reading the novel.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a good film but not great.  The best adaptation of Jane Austen's classic book is the 5-hour miniseries created for A&E.;  In my opinion it sets the gold standard and is the version to which I compare every other version.However Keira Knightly makes a very good Elizabeth Bennett and McFadyen's Darcy is definitely worth looking at (I may be a "mom of 5" but my mom taught me that you're never to old to appreciate a fine looking man).  Oh and he has a great voice.This film takes liberties with the story, such as changing event settings.  For instance, in the book, Darcy did not propose to Lizzie in the pouring rain on a picturesque stone gazebo or mausoleum or whatever with a great view in the background.  However, I did enjoy the scene they added of Mr. Bingley and Darcy practicing how Bingley would propose to Jane.Overall I found the story a bit confusing and hard to follow - and I have read the book at least a dozen times.  I can't imagine how someone who never read the book would be able to follow the storyline in this movie.Donald Sutherland seems somewhat miscast as Mr. Bennett.  I guess I'm a purist - they should have cast a Brit.  And every time he laughed he had to put his hand over his mouth - I assume to hold his dentures in.  It was very distracting for me.Overall, this was an enjoyable movie and I recommend it.  But if you haven't already seen the A&E; version, it is a must.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have looked at this movie over a dozen times easily and must say it is a very romantic, interesting movie. The characters are portrayed excellently and has an exceptional cast. This movie is a must for your movie collection.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie was not absolutely horrible, it was alright to watch-if one does not consider it true to the novel Pride and Prejudice.While the cinematography was beautiful and more artistic than the BBC version (they obviously had a higher budget), the storyline was cut - to below the bare minimum. To some who don't know Pride and Prejudice, it can even be slightly confusing, because nothing is elaborated on. (The music was also too loud on the DVD, and often one would miss what they are saying and must read the captions) Pivotal moments like when Darcy comments on not wanting to dance with Elizabeth seem almost trivial in the presentation of the movie. Sometimes things seem to come out of nowhere- especially when Elizabeth finds out about Lydia, one scene she's happy, the next she walks in and sobs (it was rather funny, though it's not supposed to be).The storyline between Jane and Bingly was nowhere near as detailed as it should have been, I didn't feel it's importance. It was like the directors considered any storyline not related to Darcy and Elizabeth to be extraneous.Kiera Knightly does not play a terrible Elizabeth Bennett, though sometimes I found her to say things in a very similar manner to Jennifer Ehle, and other times she would act completely out of character for Elizabeth (though this is probably the screenplay's fault). After Lady Catherine comes near the end, Elizabeth seems completely unreasonable and immature, crying out that she wants to be left alone - this was not how Jane Austen wrote Elizabeth to be.Mr. Darcy is barely shown, and I didn't really feel like he was as important a character as he was supposed to be. Moments where he's spilling out his heart, the camera is instead focused more often on Elizabeth. Macfadyen didn't really play Darcy to what I imagined him in the book, Firth in the BBC version did a much better job.There wasn't the best chemistry between Knightly and Macfadyenand I found myself not really caring that they would end up together in the end.There are numerous other comments that could be made, but the biggest problem with the adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, was that they over dramatized it. Lady Catherine coming at night, Charlotte Lucas running away saying Elizabeth better not judge her, the proposal in the rain. It all turns Pride and Prejudice into a story that doesn't seem unique- it becomes so cliche. Jane Austen was subtle, and the movie didn't capture that at all.For those who have not read Jane Austen or seen the BBC version, the movie is not horrible, but to be honest it isn't a classic either.
summary: 2 stars as pride and prejudice, 3 stars as any old movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Such a treat, to see Pride and Prejudice again! For anyone who knows and loves the book -- and knows and loves the BBC miniseries from 1995 -- this new version is worth seeing. Yes, it is not as genteel as the BBC version. There is a rough quality to the characters' lives that is perhaps more authentic. Here, we see Bennets living in a low-ceilinged house with narrow doorways, candlelight, plank floors and simple furniture. They use more pewter than silver, and their clothing is closer to homespun 18th-century, than 19th-century finery. The language is simpler, less flowery and less faithful to Jane Austen's dialog. So what? I sat in a theatre crowded with women and men who laughed out loud and even applauded when they felt moved to do so. The ending was too sugary-sweet, I will give you that. But this version is not without merit! Austen lovers, don't hesitate to see this version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If one were to watch a condensed version of P&P;, this is the one to watch. If one is a newcomer to P&P; this is the one to watch. If one has watched the A&E; version nine million times, and may want something fresh(despite eight other adaptations out there), this is the one to watch!Granted, I myself, am not an austere follower of Austin, but I have read enough of the novel, and seen the A&E; version enough times, to know what it is supposed to be. Call me romantic(I am), call me an idealist(I am), but no matter what way you look at it, this is the probably the best theatrical (non-television) version we will ever get.It holds true to the spirit of the book, and although there are a number of storyline omissions, and some missing characters, it keeps all the key scenes, and stays true to the characters.  Keira Knightley's Elizabeth Bennet is spunky and refhesing and Matthew McFayden's portrayal of Mr. Darcy holds his own when compared to what is the considered the definitive portrayal of Mr. Darcy; Colin Firth. This coming from an avid Colin Firth fan as well. I love Colin Firth, and he will always be dear to my heart, but Matthew McFayden has earned a place next to him as well thanks to this movie. His Darcy is restrained, yet sexy, prideful and haughty, yet tender and kind of sensitive. He walks a very fine line, as only Firth has been able to walk before, and it is a delight to watch.The other characters, such as Lydia(Played by the always marvelous Jena Malone) and Mrs. Bennet, were not quite as over-the-top annoying as some of the portrayals of them in past versions. The relationship between Mr. Bennet and Lizzie seemed much more clearly defined as well (though the scene where Mr. Bennet apologizes was out of character for him...). Although I did enjoy the A&E;'s Mr. Collins, this one seems more appropriate to the period, and much more believable. Judi Dench is simply wonderful, and is the definitive Lady Catherine (even though they changed some of the scenes from the book, her portrayal of the character itself was fantastic!).The characters in this version seemed much more suited to the era then in the A&E; versions, the contrast between the Bennet's finfancial state and the Upper Class(Darcy & Bingley), was much more obvious, which was nice. The characters know their places, and they act like it. The dances also come off as more real and natural, not so staged as in the A&E; version.If all else fails to entice you, the Scenery is to die for! The English Moors are so beautiful their worth seeing the film for that alone! The scene were Mr. Darcy comes out of the mist to meet Elizabeth has to be one of "The most geourgeous" in cinema history.So my hope for you is this: That no matter how many times you've read the book, no matter how many film(Tv or movie) versions you've seen, you can appreciate this one as well and be able to drink in the scenery, the marvelous music, and the wonderful acting.God Bless ~Amy

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Without a doubt, this is my favorite movie of all time. While the Colin Firth version is beautiful and very true to the book, Matthew Macfadyen is MY Mr. Darcey! Colin Firth NEVER smiles or shows any emotion throughout the film. His character is cold, even when he's trying to woe Elizabeth. He doesn't even smile when she admits her love!!!  Macfadyen's Darcy shows vulnerability and almost desperation as his love for her grows. Also, the Firth version isn't visually as stimulating. There are scenes that are simply breathtaking with the MacFadyen version -- the sun rising when the admit their love for one another could give anyone goosebumps!My suggestion: Read the book and then you will love this beauty of this movie and its passion.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I could watch this movie again and again!  It captured you from the beginning and keeps you enthralled throughout the movie,  Best of all, it leaves you with a smile.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've been a Jane Austen fan for quite some time. I fell in love with the books first, and then dove into the world of the movie adaptations.I must admit, I was a fan of the BBC version, going into this one. I was of course skeptical due to the compressed time and even having Keira Knightley in it.I was quite pleased with this film. I went in understanding that it would only be two hours so of course things would be cut out, issues that could take up a significant amount of time were over in two minutes, and that no movie could ever live up to the book that proceeded it. The actors were the thing that made this movie work, they turned their short-lived characters into people we could grow to love and care about, or mistrust and dislike in a matter of minutes. In fact, I enjoyed a select few of them more than those in the BBC's version.If you're a Jane Austen fan, or just a fan of the movies, this is a great movie if you want to get your Austen-fix as I call it, but don't have the time to watch the other versions that can stretch out for quite a few hours.
summary: A Movie Worthy of Being Watched

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My fourteen year old daughter loves this movie.  The acting is good and music is beautiful!  I bought her the sheet music for her piano also.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, the BBC miniseries is good, but this movie did a wonderful job with the 2 hours it was given.  Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen are brilliant in their roles and you can seriously feel the tension between them throughout the movie.  I rarely see movies more than once in the theater, but I did go to see this one twice and couldn't wait for the DVD to come out.  It's very simply a love story with beautiful scenery, outstanding dialogue, an excellent cast, and some very poignant moments.  What's not to love?

review_text: This is one of my favorite movies.  I already own it on DVD, but had to buy the digital copy to keep on my Kindle Fire.  It is a must see for anyone who enjoys period pieces.

Keira's Elizabeth is witty and sharp.  An enjoyable way to spend the evening.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Lisa Shea "be the change you wish to see in t...
review_text: Let's say up front that the 2005 Pride and Prejudice, starring Keira Knightley as Lizzie and Matthew Macfadyen as Darcy, is not meant to be a 100% accurate adaptation of the book. Trimmed down to a mere 2 hours, the story had to be cut up a great deal. It's also set in the late 1700s - when a 21 year old Jane Austen first thought up the story, instead of the early 1800s, when 38 year old Jane finally finished and published the work.That all being said, this movie is amazingly well done. In some ways, it's much more realistic than other depictions of the story. Many movie versions of P&P; have the characters set up almost like cartoon characters. They are squeaky clean, their world is pristine, and they float through it. While many in the early 1800s had nice manners, their life was certainly not Lysol-clean!It was really nice, then, to see the quiet English town actually appear like a live, working English town. The story clearly has Lizzie show up with a ton of mud on her skirts after hiking across miles of marshy English countryside. In most movie versions, that means there's a hint of brown on her trimly pressed outfit. In this version, it's much more realistic. I've hiked around England - you get muddy!In some ways, the movie is like "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead" - where you hear snippets of dialogue and if you know the story, you realize what is going on in the background. It really does cater strongly to people who know the full story well and don't need all the details filled in. Again, this is to be expected given there are only 2 hours of story here. Many of the backgrounds and details are shaved or missing. The characters, however, are still quite solid and fully done.Lizzie and Darcy of course are the main characters here, and they shine with a freshness that is really great. These aren't "story members" just walking through and trading barbs. You really get a sense that Lizzie is a flesh and blood woman who is feeling the powerful loves, hates, and other emotions. Darcy feels the same passions, reigning them in under his family training. Many of the scenes with the two characters are just amazing - when they are dancing, when they are in the gazebo in the rain.In some ways, I even feel the movie adds to the story, helping to elucidate scenes that might otherwise go over viewers' heads. Often, Charlotte's choosing to marry Collins is seen as a quiet, calm decision made without any emotion at all. I always found this depiction to be unrealistic. In this version, Charlotte makes it clear that this wouldn't be her ideal choice - but what else can she do? Does she really want to be a spinster and burden on her family? She's full of angst, but she's done the best she could with a bad situation.Also, it's always bugged me that in some movie versions, they made a big deal about Lizzie's "revelation" in Darcy's home that she really would have been happy as his wife. She feels this way because his servants love him so much, a sign of a truly "gentle man". However, some movies turn it into a gold-digging Lizzie looking around saying "Wow, I could have lived HERE". I was very happy that in this movie, Lizzie is touched by the gorgeous sculpture and the way Darcy's sister loves him.Even some of the minor characters are done amazingly well. I love Sutherland and Dench, they are simply wonderful. Others are less stellar - Wickham springs to mind as being an "elf lookalike" - but it's hard to expect every single cast member to be stunning.Highly recommended as a must-see for anyone who loves a romantic story full of incredibly fun dialogue.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I don't know how many times one of my daughters and I have seen this movie! We really enjoy it. Yes the romance, chivalry, the costumes, the customs, etc are really enjoyed!If you're in to romance, this is the movie to get!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a purist of book-to-movie adaptations, I had a hard time enjoying the good points of this movie because I got too caught up in the period discrepancies and creative liberties taken with the original story.  First, they made the Bennetts look only a notch above white trash.  Second, Bingley came across as clueless, gullible, and kind of pathetic instead of naive and hopelessly optimistic.  Third (and most annoying in my opinion) they took away much of the formality that existed during that time in society, and between men and women specifically.  That formality is the main source of the humor and irony that makes Jane Austen's stories so entertaining- since people can't say what they mean, or run up to the person of their dreams and plant a kiss, they have to do everything in a more cloak and dagger way.  The dialog has to be much sharper than today's lazy screenplays to convey the same feelings and emothions.  After I stopped fuming over these issues, I decided to see the movie again to see if I would enjoy it more without such specific expectations.  The second time around, I was able to appreciate the acting much more, especially Keira Knightley.  I also found that I actually liked the portrayel of Jane- in the BBC miniseries, she seems a bit blind in her desire to believe the best in people; in this version, she comes across as a bit more aware.  Despite some of the effects of "creative liberty", I did enjoy this movie- not the best adaptation, but very respectable.
summary: Not as good as the BBC miniseries, but still well worth it

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My goodness, most of the negativity about this movie is coming from die-hard BBC-adaption fans. The same people playing Nancy Drew regarding historical inaccuracies(and half of their criticisms are uninformed or misinformed by other period pieces) don't seem to be using the same critical eye to the BBC adaption, which is incredible but has it's inaccuracies as well.If you go into this movie with an open and flexible mind,keeping in mind how the medium of cinema and the medium of television will make COMPLETELY different products(and thank goodness-I didn't want a carbon copy of the BBC version), you'll enjoy it. It does take some artistic liberties, it does condense alot of the story, and it's take is less pretti-fied than most people are use to(compare this version to the more realistic and I think best Austen adaption to date-"PErsuasion"), but what I loved most about it is that it "got" the spirit of the novel, and from that spirit, made new moments to enjoy(the first proposal? great!).And just a side note---if you don't think Colin Firth isn't happy as can be to have someone else tagged as "Mr. DarcY' after 10 years, you are delusional!He's probably thanking his lucky stars....
summary: Colin Firth's feelings won't be hurt if you like this one, people!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Top-notch cinematography.  Sublime acting by the entire cast.  Captivating music. This is simply a beautiful movie. Matthew Macfadyen is perfect as Darcy.
summary: A must-see for Jane Austen fans!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was thrilled with the opening of this movie and have replayed it and all the Darcy scenes many times so far.  The dance scene, while seemingly more Shakespearean and mid-1600s, was enchanting and the Darcy entrance extremely intriguing.  Where this stunning actor has been all these years, I have no idea.  He could do period literature, I'm sure, but has not, to my knowledge.  And to my mind, he's a comparable talent to Daniel Day-Lewis.  His great good looks, terrific baritone, gait and superb acting are a real treat.The direction is obviously brilliant, the proposal scene awesome (except for Keira's jaws-like mouth renouncing poor Darcy.)  With MacFadyen being more Regency England and less Hollywood, credence is added to this entrancing movie.  I fear that this dashing actor is not ambitious or we certainly would have seen more of him in American movies.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I enjoy this version of Pride and Prejudice more than others that have come out. It's one of my favourite movies and Keira Knightly and Matthew Macfadyen are both fantastic.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Enjoyable, bit missing a lot to fit it into the short time frame. More glamorous of a movie, but not nearly as good as the book or miniseries.
summary: Enjoyable, but misses the classic story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is an awesome movie. If you are an Austin fan you must own this movie, it is the best version available of Pride and Prejudice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my favorite adaptation of the Jane Austen classic, and I have had the standard DVD version for several years. However, now that I have a blu-ray player I thought I would upgrade to the blu-ray format, but was concerned that it wouldn't be worth the extra money. Let me tell you, I was not disappointed. The blu-ray edition is vastly superior both visually and musically. I've found that quite often there's really no significant difference between the standard and blu-ray versions. But with a film this aethetically dynamic, I was stunned by the improvement in quality.Overall, whether you're a Jane Austen devotee or you simply enjoy this film, go with the blu-ray version. No contest.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I repeatedly went to watch P&P; when it was released here in Australia, and I loved it! Everything was perfect even if they did change some things...which always happens when you take a story from a book to a movie.The only complaint I have was that after watching the movie I heard a rumour that you guys in the USA got a alternate ending to us in Australia! And that you actually got to see Lizzie and Darcy kiss! Tell me this isn't true! Because if it is I cannot possibly understand why Joe Wright would cut off the story like that!I would much rather see Darcy & Lizzie kiss or even hug at the end of the movie rather than see Donald Sutherland sitting in his study saying his stupid line, "If anyone comes looking for Mary or Kitty show them in....etc"I really hope that this isn't true cause otherwise, and I'm sure I speak for all Jane Austen fans in Australia, when I say that we feel completely and utterly robbed of a 'complete' and more 'satisfying' ending to a story that is so beloved!I would love if someone would tell me whether you guys actually did recieve a different ending and if so...does this dvd version (US version)have the complete ending, kiss included? Because the Australia release doesn't!
summary: I love...I love...I love this movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you are into sweet & romantic movies this is the movie to watch.All.the Actors are awesome Performers.I have viewed it a vew times and i just love it

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie could have been wonderful but was quite horrid.  Jane Austen created some of the best characters in literature and this movie changes just about everybody of importance, removing the wit and turning it into soppy porridge.  Mr. Bennet is one of my favorite characters of all time  and his character was unrecognizable.  Jane was supposed to be sweet and kind and yet she came across as hard and cold in the movie.  Lizzie is intelligent and perhaps a tiny pit pert but not silly and ridiculous as she is portrayed here.  Mr. Darcy was also a sad failure.  He was dour rather than proud and seemed about to cry throughout the movie.  Ish.Plus, I had serious issues with the behavior portrayed in the movie.  Regency women DID NOT run around with their hair down!  Every time I saw that, it infuriated me and pulled me out of the movie.  Darcy and Elizabeth would have never met up in the morning in their night clothes.  This is the equivalent of wandering down the street naked.  To top it off, the director then had Darcy go to ask for Lizzie's hand in the same night clothes, with his collar open and no cravat!  Are you kidding me?!!The manners of everyone in the movie were awful.  Lydia was silly and heedless in the book but Jane and Lizzie were not!  The costuming was also sub-par.  Lizzie's dresses were all wrong.  First, she looked like a servant in dowdy colors and fabrics.  Why dress the lead in such an awful fashion?  Her clothes shouldn't have been as fine as the Bingley sisters but Lizzie was not a poor farm girl.  Second, the waist was much too low for the time period.I was left with the very strong impression that the director felt that he had to distinguish himself by "improving" on the original.  Sad, bad, pompous mistake.  The BBC version was so fabulous that I think he tried much too hard to make this one stand apart from it.  Well, he achieved his goal.  The BBC version is amazing and this one is atrocious.  It could have been great.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I could watch this movie every day! Each character is perfect for their part. It is romantic, without being mushy and silly. It is 'smart' romantic.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Definitely see the BBC version instead.Hated hated hated this version.  Too shallow and 21st century anachronistic in appearance and delivery.  Hated the lame Sixteen Candles, sitting-on-the-table scene at the end of the movie and the vast majority of everything that came before it.  Hated the casual, everything-out emotionalism that characterizes modern times and makes this movie a disaster in its departure from the tone and tenor of Austen's work.Got it as a gift so gritted my teeth through it, watching it with the very thoughtful gifters.  Thank you for making me appreciate, even more than ever, the Colin Firth, Jennifer Ehle BBC version!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you are a PRIDE AND PREJUDICE fan, think you will enjoy this enactment of it.  Although we all love Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy, Matthew Macfadyen plays a delicious Darcy as well.  Keira Knightley is a lovely Elizabeth Bennett.  The scenery and sets seem very realistic and this movie is a visual delight.Other actors who illumined scenes for me are Rosamund Pike as Jane, Elizabeth's old sister and Donald Sutherland as the father.  Of course, Judi Dench as a noblewoman was a welcome addition as well.  I hadn't realized that Carey Mulligan played the youngest Bennett sister.It seemed the movie clung pretty closely to the plot.  To use Chatsworth as Mr. Darcy's home was an inspired choice.The movie is worth watching just for the visual charm.  It seemed realistic, like it was really happening in the 1800's.  That's probably one of the highest compliments one can pay a movie - you don't feel like you are watching a movie.  This is a favorite film of mine - one I can watch over and over again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I wasn't crazy about this version the first time I saw it, but I have grown to love it. I was accustomed to a certain stiffness in other film versions and a (rightful) fixation on the period's rigid social mores. So, the ambiance of pigs and mud and barking dogs threw me at first. When a co-worker asked me how I liked it after my first viewing, I complained, "Too rustic," but had to admit that the lushness and the cinematography are gorgeous. That's what made me watch it again. And again.Some of the narrative choices are a little strange (why does Darcy make his first proclamation of love in a gazebo during a downpour??) and some of the casting doesn't work (Donald Sutherland is so wrong as Mr. Bennet). The actors who play Mr. Bennet, Mrs. Bennet and Mr. Collins in the A&E; version are impossible to outdo. And while a Colin Firth or a Laurence Olivier is probably more physically appropriate as Darcy, Matthew Macfadyen conveys a disarming vulnerability in the character.I'm not usually very moved by romance, but the scene in which Darcy crosses the meadow at dawn to find Elizabeth (yeah, well, it works here) is the singularly most romantic sequence I have ever seen in a film. It's lovely.So I think of this as the "outdoorsy" version of the story. It's worth seeing just for the beautiful cinematography and the unexpectedly charming ambiance.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The strongest parts of this film is the real-life adaptation of the Bennet family.  We see Mrs. Bennet not as the dim-witted mother who is eager to marry her daughter's off but as a real mother concerned over real-life situations in those days.  Yes, back then a woman's ticket to a good life was to marry well but it was even harder to marry for both money and love.But that's not where the movie ends.  We are exposed to breathtaking cinematorgraphy, (Some parts of Britain I never knew exist!) and actors who are molded so well for their parts.  Kiera Knightly shines as Elizabeth Bennet in this adaptation and Jenna Malone and Carey Mulligan are not as annoying as Lydia and Kitty in the 1995 version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.One set back to this movie would be its adaptation.  For those who are exposed to the Pride and Prejudice for the first time may be left confused.  The story moves forward in some parts through narration or dialogue rather than seeing actual scenes , such as Wickham's dealings and his connection to Mr. Dary's sister.  Also, the audience has to pay attention to the background and foreground parts of the film as the story moves forward through background interactions.  This movie is so much more 'open' then previous films that (blending background with foreground)the viewer will need to pay more attention to the dialogue and try and understand the feelings of the characters (ex: Eliza's alienation during the Netherfield ball).BOTTOM LINE:This is a great film with real-life in 19th century appeal.  Mr. Darcy is more of a character to understand in this film and Ms. Bennet shines true.  I think we get more of a sense of Ms. Austen's (author) feminist views (abliet they aren't harsh ones).  Bits of the movie may need more concentration as there is blending of background/foreground.  Also, Austen truists may feel a bit cheated with only an adaptation version of the film.  For those who want a more 'true' and stretched out version of Pride and Prejudice, I recommend the 1995 version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.

title: Pride & Prejudice
