title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: At different times in my life I have read this classic over and over and enjoyed it increasingly. I have seen many of the adaptations and always thought it a bit stogy and rigid. This version has been criticized by some as being a little bit "too down and dirty". I feel the tone was just right in depicting a class who lost their money and are struggling despite all odds to keep their old life together. The mud outside (it is a farm), walls in need of paint and hanging tapestries sets the tone correctly. Just compare it with Mr. Darcy's estate.Keira Knightley is a delight, but I have seen and become inured to most of her coy mannerisms. I think the interest and a bit of rogueness lies with Matthew Macfadyen. Time shows he literally saves the day and the movie with his passion and loving manner. He is a vital part and is the epitome of the selflessness of a gentleman. I would not change any of the cast. I knew I had to have this movie.
summary: Pride and Prejudice  Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I found Pride and Prejudice to be a superbly well adapted film. While the Jane Austen purists may not approved of all the changes in this movie, I thought the script was superbly well thought out and its adopted the book into a well made two hour movie. This movie is basically the director Joe Wright's vision of the book. There is nothing wrong with it. After all, the three Lord of the Rings movies were Peter Jackson's vision of the book, not the book itself.The movie proves to be well directed and well acted. The two key characters, Lizzie and Darcy were well represented by Keira Knightley and Matthew McFadyn. Knightley proves to be the right age and she managed to captured the character of Lizzie superbly well. I thought McFadyn did well but from all I read, Colin Firth from that mini-series hold the gold standard for playing Darcy. Firth must be very good indeed. The movie choose to centered around those two characters and goes from the initial false impression of each other to realization of truth about each other. The supporting cast proves to be quite excellent, both Donald Sutherland and Judi Dench steal scenes during their limited time on the screen. I thought Brenda Blethyn who played the super annoying mother probably did the best job of all. Tom Hollander who played Cousin William Collins also proves to be excellent. Thanks to him, Lizzie's horror of the thought of marrying his character can be made clear for all to see. The production values proves to be very high, costumes fitted the time period of the book very nicely.This movie probably will not satisfied the pure-hearted Jane Austen fans. But for all others, this two hour movie will do quite nicely as it captured the spirit of the book and its two lead characters.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The title of my review says it all. After watching the comments of those involved in writing, directing, and acting in the film it's obvious they didn't understand Austin's plot. They don't understand the customs of the time period. They didn't get the fact that Austin's book is humorous. At one point in an interview the screenwriter says the story revolves around Lizzie's pride and Darcy's prejudice. When in fact in Austin's novel it was Miss. Bennett's prejudice and Darcy's pride that caused their conflict. The screenwriter also didn't get the fact that Mr. Bennett held his wife in total contempt in Austin's story. He made fun of her in front of their children. And it was this element in the Bennett's relationship that drove the two older sisters to insist on marrying for love. They didn't want to be in marriages where they couldn't love and respect their spouses. The scenery in the movie is lovely--but too rustic. I doubt the Bennett's in Austin's novel had a large boar running through their house. And Mr. Bingley was a complete fop in this movie version. Donald Southerland reminds me of Lee Marvin in Cat Baloo. Mrs. Bennett looks and sounds like a fishwife. All in all--I cannot give it a high rating. If you want to see Pride & Prejudice--watch the Colin Firth version. It's a whole lot closer to Jane Austin's original story.
summary: the screenwriter doesn't understand Austin's plot

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Timeless and a joy to watch again and again. The actors are fantastic. Even the lesser characters. Keira Knightly is absolutely marvelous and so is the actor who plays Mr. Darcy. A wonderful love story. Humor, good duplication of the period plus really smart dialogue. I really enjoyed the witty, intelligent repartee. A movie where you can and will enjoy it from beginning to end. This is my favorite pairing of the story. The main characters deliver the best interpretation of their roles.I admired Ms. Elizabeth with all of my heart and I fell in love with Mr. Darcy and found him very sweet and sincere. A lot of great humor and actual reality in the plot. It was just done so wonderfully sensitive that in instances where life was not perfect it was still o.k.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Why the newest adaptation of 'Pride and Prejudice' fails in its attempt to accurately portray Jane Austen's beloved novel.The most famous of Jane Austen's works, 'Pride and Prejudice,' was first published in 1813 and still remains a favorite among many with a love for good literature and well written romance. Ever since movies become popular, companies have tried to produce films that bring Austen's, (and other famous authors') books to life. We enjoy seeing character burst forth from black and white pages into vivid, realistic people thanks to actors and actresses that portray them. Yet, while viewing Focus Feature's 2005 adaptation of 'Pride and Prejudice," I have come to the conclusion that were Jane Austen alive today, she -and other respectable women of the 19th century- would be horrified at the atrocious misrepresentation of Austen's characters.The most obvious change is that of the book's heroine, Elizabeth "Lizzie" Bennet. The first difference that I noticed was her lack of respect for authority. This is first apparent after her refusal of Mr. Collins, when she angrily tells her parents, "I won't marry him, you cannot make me!" and runs out of the house. Also, in the conversation that takes place between Elizabeth and Colonel Fitzwilliam during a Sunday morning sermon, and afterwards, when her mother asks about Lady Catherine de Bourge, Elizabeth screams, "For once in you're life, leave me alone!" Jane Austen never allows Elizabeth to display such a lack of respect and self-control in the novel. The movie also fails to represent Lizzie's complete trust and affection for her sister, Jane. She denies even hearing of Mr. Bingley during her stay with the newlywed Collins, and does not tell Jane of Darcy's proposal. In Austen's book, the two sisters always confided in each other.The changes made in Mr. Darcy's character are equally disturbing. He appears so emotionless and shows almost no change in expression when he speaks that one wonders if he feels anything at all. Jane Austen's Darcy was undoubtedly stern and proud, but the dull manner in which Matthew McFayden expresses -or fails to express- himself is very tiresome, indeed.Furthermore, in Austen's novel Mrs. Bennet is presented as motherly, and often loud and embarrassing; making inappropriate remarks at all the wrong times. In the movie, she goes beyond humiliating and well into vulgar as she dangles her legs off a table she's sitting on during the ball, and sloshes her dessert on an unsuspecting young man.The whole film is filled with frustrating errors. You're extremely fortunate if you can determine which girl is Lydia and which is Kitty before the dreadful elopement with Mr. Wickham. Everyone listens to conversations behind doors and constantly talk over one another. Mr. Bennet always appears to be half drunk, Lizzie giggles after almost every sentence no matter the gravity of the situation which greatly downplays the drama, Lady Catherine arrives at the Bennet's to admonish Elizabeth in the middle of the night when all civil folk are asleep, and Kitty and Lydia wear pig-tails to a ball. The dialogue is so rushed that it leaves you with a feeling of something missing. If you can even catch what the characters said in the first place. If the movie makers were so short on time, they should have foregone the nauseating scene with Mr. Darcy's collection of naked statues which was a completely unnecessary addition.Even in the wardrobe department, the movie went wrong. Mr. Darcy proposes for the second and last time to Elizabeth while they are both in their bed clothes. An idea which would have been scandalous to anyone living in Jane Austen's time period. Caroline Bingley is not even properly dressed at the Netherfield ball. She is shown in a plain, sleeveless gown with very thin straps in a time when lace was all the rage and long sleeves the newest fashion in London. Miss Bingley with her love of pomp and display of social status would never have worm a gown such as the one she wears in the movie. In the film, Caroline Bingley was about 200 years ahead of herself in fashion.I could continue to describe the atrocities of the movie until there was enough to fill a book, but I will end my comparison by saying, that Focus Features does no credit to Jane Austen's wonderful romance in their ridiculous movie. If you want to watch a film that historically and book-wise does justice to Jane Austen, stick to the A&E; version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle who do a marvelous job!
summary: Pride and Prejudice, or Pomp and Partiality?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I purchased this classic DVD for my daughter to view for H.S. AP English class. This way, she could take her time absorbing the story. Well worth buying rather than renting, as it will be seen more than once.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was determined to see it at the movies ever since it came out because I liked the book and saw it. Jane Austen is a funny author and this movie has definitely captured her wit. I liked it better than the BBC version by Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle and I think every version ever made although I've never seen them all.First of all, the circumstances of the Bennett family is very realistic and the characters were very well-chosen, especially Mrs. Bennett and Keira Knightly who judging by her earlier works that she would make a good Elizabeth. (The only character that I wasn't satisfied with was Mr. Bingley.) Then there was Mr. Collins, his worship of Catherine de Bourgh and the ridiculous proposal to Elizabeth was done just right. Charlotte Lucas and Caroline Bingley were just exactly how I pictured they would be and Fitzgerald Darcy looks very arrogant indeed and shows interest in Lizzie in the right places. I must say that I like the rearrangements of places important things happen at, such as the first time Darcy proposes to Elizabeth.The only part that depressed me was the rush of Darcy's letter to Elizabeth, which explained his nervous relationship with Wickham and reveals Wickham's true light. I feel that the elopement of Wickham and Darcy's sister wasn't explained very well and the elopement of Wickham and Lydia did not excite the nerves of the audiences for long. But the ending was a satisfying version of the modern movie required kiss of romance classics and isn't overdone. Overall I recommend this movie for everyone of all age any place in the world no matter you've read the novel or not--I'm sure you'll all like it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Who does not love Jane Austen.  Love this movie.  The characters were so believable.  A must see to all Jane Austen fans.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must admit that it boggles my mind to see so many unfavourable reviews of this wonderful, endearing adaptation of Jane Austen's classic. Cinematic gems are a rare thing these days. We seem to be surrounded by crass, unmitigated tripe (Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen, G.I. Joe, Old Dogs, the Saw series, etc.) that insult the intelligence of the viewer and seek to beat us over the head with special effects and casual violence. These films and many more are worthy of disdain, and yet what do we have here but a legion of people with the myopic effrontery to slam "Pride and Prejudice" with a one-star review!! You people make a mockery of the rating system with your hyperbole. Many (especially old people) seem absolutely obsessed with the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version, which I liked very much as well, but thought was a bit stiff. I agree that the story moves a little too briskly in the newer version (I wish it were five hours long, too), but in all other respects I adore this movie.Keira Knightley is simply beautiful and luminous as Elizabeth Bennett, and Matthew MacFadyen brings real emotion and warmth to the proud character of Mr. Darcy. The chemistry between these two is exquisite. All of the other actors and actresses are excellent, as well, as is the cinematography. The scene in which Darcy proposes to Elizabeth, with the rain-swept countryside in the background, is handled beautifully; the emotions expressed in the faces of the two leads are spot-on and make the scene more heartfelt and engaging than anything in the 1995 version. There is simply more feeling in this version of "Pride and Prejudice" than in any other Jane Austen adaptation that I've seen, which is exactly want I want to go with the wonderful dialogue and piercing social commentary.
summary: My Favourite Adaptation of Jane Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really tried to come to this movie with and open mind. I'm a huge fan of Jane Austen and I thought the 1995 BBC miniseries actually came close to doing justice to her novel. Still, I was looking foreward to seeing a new interpretation. Unfortunately this one seemed to miss the point of the story.Jane Austen had a hilarious way of satarizing the social conventions and mores while being in their midst. This film ignores the social conventions altogether and therefore misses a great deal of Austen's humor. For example an unmarried man and woman would NEVER greet each other in their pajamas. A man would never visit his fiancee while she was lying sick in bed in her nightgown. When these rules of propriety are ignored by the film, how are we supposed to understand or believe that it's a big deal when Lydia runs away with Wickham!? Another example is Lady Catherine. This is a woman who lives and dies by her snobbery and rigorous adherance to social conventions. Yet in this film we see her barge into the Bennet household in the middle of the night and wake Lizzie up to ask a question that could easily waited until morning (when Lady Catherine wouldn't have had to get her carriage driver out of bed to drive several miles in the dark- no streetlights remember- to the Bennet household) Because no one adhere's to societies rigorous, and for the most part arbitrary, rules, the movie misses the opportunies to subtly wink at the audience as it laughs at such things.Another weakness lies in the casting. Granted these actors had big shoes to fill. Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle seemed to embody their characters in the 1995 miniseries, but as I said, there are other ways to interpret and play the characters. Unforunately here everyone seems as if they're reading lines with dramatic inflection- not acting. You can almost imagine Keira Knightly's script having notes saying "insert spunkiness here".While the scenery is lovely, the windswept cliff and farm images seem to recollect the tortured landscape of a Bronte adaptation more than a manacured Austen setting.Overall this film comes off as one big missed opportunity.
summary: Not even an attempt at historical accuracy?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen's famous novel brought to life again with beautiful cinematography filmed on location in the United Kingdom.  This is the 2005 movie version about an elegant young gentleman (Mr. Darcy - played by Matthew McFadden) who was proud and the beautiful young lady  (Elizabeth - played by Kiera Knightly) who was prejudiced.  They spend most of their time hating each other until they find out they discover they love each other.It is charming, ancient romance story and interesting dialogue opens a window on the mores, culture and class distinctions of that time and culture (England near the end of the 18th Century).The cast is superb, Kiera Knightly, Matthew Macfadyen, Donald Sutherland, Brenda Biethyn, Judi Dench and many others.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There's no need for me to retell the plot of this movie.  Others have done that beautifully.  Let me just say that I have now purchased five copies (four to give away; one for me), and here's why:1. Kiera Knightly is incredible as Elizabeth Bennet--youthful but wise, sweet but delightfully sarcastic, beautiful with a great touch of tomboy.2.  Matthew Macfadyen's Mr. Darcy is perfect.  He gives the character just the right blend of pride and insecurity, with eyes so expressive that a sidelong glance speaks volumes.  And his voice...!  Oh my.3.  The Bennet family is every family--a delightful jumble of diverse personalities bound by tears, laughter and love.4.  The music. (I own the soundtrack, too.)5.  The scenery. (Many Kodak moments.)6.  And...the story.  Perfect.  Just perfect.Go, Jane Austen!!!!
summary: I can't get enough of this movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having just read the book, I thought I would be disappointed in the movie, which had to be abridged. To my surprise, it was only a bit compressed; all the essential plot was intact. And the scenery was lovely. The actors did a great job.
summary: A good remake of an old classic

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I went to this film alone (no one to heckle me for getting sucked into the romance) and in the mood for escapism, at 7PM.  I went back and saw the 10PM show the same day.  Ultimately I saw it four times in the theater.Either you like this genre, or you don't; you love Jane Austen, or you don't.  I do.  And I don't hold the good people who put her stories up on the big screen to any particular standard.  I really like the Greer Garson version, I like the BBC series.  This movie is something else.  It's not quite a reinterpretation, but it does add another dimension to the story.  That isn't a problem for me -- it's a different medium; I didn't go to the movie to have someone read the book for me.  The characters in this movie do not all have perfect hair, are not perfectly beautiful, look like they occasionally get B.O.  But you like them.  Alot.The film resonated with me for days and days; I bought the soundtrack, I re-read the book again (not for the first time).Don't be put off by Matthew McFaydden's sterness in the beginning; it's deliberate and by the end of the film I believe that you will agree he was absolutely perfect in the role.  It must be hard play that character for people who in large part already know how the story turns out.  But he convinced me to hate him like Elizabeth does at the beginning, and to love him like she did at the end.
summary: Simply THE most romantic movie made, EVAR

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Certainly this is one of the two most intriguing versions of this movie I have seen.If Jane Austen herself were alive today, I suspect whe would love this version.In the Laurence Olivier version, I thought his Darcy came across as somewhat affected and foppish.  I have not seen the Colin Firth version yet, however I did see his depiction of Darcy in the modern Bridget Jones Diary movies, and he did seem off in his attitude towards Renee Zelwegger's character.  He seemed too snooty, and as if he genuinely disliked her at times for no reason.My other favorite version is the Bollywood version, Bride and Prejudice, a must see totally enjoyable version with the beautiful Aishwarya Rai, and replete with Bollywood conventions including musical numbers.The Keira Knightley version I have seen several times, and even made copious notes about it, because whether you know it or not, many love stories follow the template of this story, and it has become an enduring classic for good reason.The dialogue is simply beautiful, the scenes excellently executed, the lead actor Matthew MacFadyen interplays brilliantly with Keira, offering excellently nuanced scenes.  Finally, a lead actor who truly does justice to the role.Like many love stories it starts out on the wrong foot, when Darcy disses her to a friend.  He does not know she has overheard.  She responds with some later banter putting him in his place, and like the flick of a switch he becomes intrigued with her. Yet as you get deeper into the story, misunderstandings arise, new perceptions, a whole welter of emotions.I especially loved the scene where he proposes the first time and totally screws it up. She is hurt and angry, and turns on him, and yet beneath that anger stirs a passion.  Beautifully done.Mr. Darcy: ...Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your circumstances?Elizabeth Bennet: And those are the words of a gentleman. From the first moment I met you, your arrogance and conceit, your selfish disdain for the feelings of others made me realize that you were the last man in the world I could ever be prevailed upon to marry. [they look at each other for a long time as though about to kiss]I also enjoyed the performance of Collins played by Tom Hollander, the repressed smutty preacher whose small estate adjoins her ladyship's rather large abutment. Love it, the language that is, not the..I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.
summary: It starts with a diss, and ends with a kiss

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Joe Wright was cast to direct the latest version of "Pride and Prejudice". Hmmmm. Joe Wright, directed a couple of forgettable movies, followed by 3 mini-series (the little knowns "Nature Boy" from 2000, "Bodily Harm" from 2002 and a lavish, and well-made version of the life of Charles 2,"Charles II: The Power and the Passion, 2003) for A&E;/BBC. What made the powers behind the newest attempt to film Austen for the big screen choose Joe Wright?Well, Joe got it, right, that is, in many ways. He's made a more contemporary telling of this, my favorite of Austen's tales, and he's done it well. In a run time of less than 2.5 hours, his version will be more easier to digest than the two mini-series of this same work (the stand alone BBC version from 1980 with Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul and the 1993 A&E;/BBC version that most people know the best; with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth). But, as well done as it is, you'll find it wanting vs. either of these fine mini-series, and the film also pales in comparison to the Emma Thompson/Ang Lee run at "Sense and Sensibility" in 1995.If you are an Austen fan, the amount of characterization that has to be cut from the story to fit it in to a 2.5 hour run time, will simply horrify you. In particular, both Mr. Wickam and Mr. Collins, potential suitors for the Bennett bevy, are given very small amounts of screen time. Catherine de Bourg, the patroness whose money flows all over a variety of characters in the film (Darcy, for one, is her nephew) was played by Judi Dench with a particularly elegant stiff upper lip, but was given little to do.Director Wright has given us marvelous cinematography and beautiful settings (notably Darcy's estate at Pemberley). He has the same passion I do for Austen's work, and tried to keep the themes."Pride and Prejudice" is a love story between a young woman in a family stretched with 5 daughters and literally no dowries in 19th century England. In the book, the Bennetts are an upper middle class lot; in this film, in which Wright instilled a sense of real "living on the farm", they are shabby versions of Austen's intent.Mr. Bennett (Donald Sutherland) is a country gentleman beloved by his daughters and befuddled by the antics of his wife. Said wife's main passion in life is making sure the girls are all married off so that they are not penniless when the parents die. Mrs. Bennett (Brenda Blethyn in a comedic performance that is perhaps a little over the top) makes no pretense of her intentions, and they are embraced with different degrees of exhuberance by her daughters. Elizabeth (Keira Knightley) and Jane (Rosamund Pike), the eldest, are a bit embarrassed by their mother's antics and manage to try and ignore her histrionics while building their anxieties over marriage.It is Jane, the loveliest, whose heart is broken by Mr. Bingley from London, and Elizabeth who runs afoul of his dour friend, Mr. Darcy.Before the film is finished, the viewer is as surprised as Elizabeth to learn that Mr. Darcy has fallen in love with her, and having been rejected, Darcy sets out to change Elizabeth's first impression and win her heart by helping her family and by showing how much he cares for his own young sister.Keira Knightley was a good choice for Jane, although the lesser known actresses in both the British mini-series were better in the role than she was. Knightley looks the part as Austen described it, and has a quicksilver screen persona that fits Elizabeth well. If there is not the romance, the chemistry that should have grown on screen between Elizabeth and Darcy, it is not for wont of Knightley's efforts to portray it.Instead, in portraying the difficult Darcy, who, after all, is supposed to be wooden, actor Matthew Macfayden (with an impressive list of British television credentials including the MI5 drama, Spooks) was entirely too successful. He is wooden to a painful degree, and has difficulty turning his cold arrogance into foolishness when he first becomes infatuated with Elizabeth. And he's equally not credible as a "do gooder". The growth of that Austen staple, the love between two people who society has not meant to be together, the growing awareness, the yearning, well, it is missing from this film. It was not missing in the mini-series. Generally speaking, it usually means the director does not know how to capture the essence of love and longing on film, does not know how to invoke it from his characters and bleed it through to the audience. Despite this, I must say, that I did not walk away wishing to see Matthew Macfayden on the big screen again.And thus, we get an interesting movie, with some fine touches, some believable characters, a solid script and beautiful filming, music and costumes. But contrary to the print ads and the trailers, this is not the film of the year, just a pleasing version of an Austen tale that has been done better in the past.Definitely worth a trip to the theater!
summary: Not the movie of the year....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie gets high a rating from me based on one feature, the exchange of dialog among the characters. That said, the movie is probably better suited to the genre with an interest in love stories. However, the dialog just blew me away, especially where there were more heated or intense discussions. One would probably do well comparing this movie with one with the same title.
summary: Standard kind of romantic plot with a very captivating dialog among the characters.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This  movie corresponds well with the book, which to me is one of the most important qualities of any book-based motion picture.  Every one of the cast represents their part faithfully and with obvious enthusiasm--and the homes and mansions used are amazing.  I would recommend reading the book first before seeing the movie--to me it brings the imagined characters much more into focus.  The casting was done to perfection--as always, Kiera Knightley is superb in her role, as are Matthew McFadyen and the  entire cast.  There are no "dull" moments in this period romance.  This is one of the most entertaining,  enjoyable movies I have seen in a very long time.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie.  My 11 year old daughter and I have watched it several times in a week and we still enjoy it every time.  The acting is superb, the dialogue is wonderful and we have fallen in love with the characters.  I highly recommend it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I found this version of my favorite novel to be very touching and romantic, though lacking much of the gently ironic tone that makes Jane Austen unique.  Mrs. Bennet, for example, was beautifully played by Brenda Blethyn, but she was rather more sweetly dithering than the constantly plotting, embarassingly outspoken character in the book. I did like the Bennet sisters' portrayals, though, and I found Darcy quite believable in his reserve and his almost painful discomfort in the rambunctious social milieu of Meryton.  The cinematography is superb, however, and the sets and costumes are flawless.  All told, the film fulfills the director's vision and gives the viewer a wonderfully intimate look at life in early nineteenth-century England.
summary: Lovely film, less Austen than Merchant/Ivory

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a fan of the book and the BBC version of this movie, yet I found this Hollywood version to be quite entertaining.  I thought that Matthew Macfadyen did an excellent job portraying Mr. Darcy.  I wish I could say the same for Keira Knightley but I just didn't buy it. The relationship between Rosamund Pike (Jane) and Lizzie was just not convincingly close as depicted in the book and although this has nothing to do with the movie, . .  Keira always does this weird thing with her lips (trying to make them look fuller while pouting) that really bugs me. I like the way the set design, costumes, and the lack of to much makeup made the movie a little more "authentic", but what I truly loved was the music.  I felt like the music really transported me into that time. I felt like this movie tried desperately to make this movie authentic (much like the 1995 production of Persuasion) but due to time restraints failed to develop the depth of the characters of the book.  The result a slightly enjoyable, entertaining piece of Hollywood film that is entertaining to watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a horrible rendition of the book. It didn't follow the story accurately and the characters were poorly portrayed - they lacked that depth and personality that clearly defines them. The movie was rather dry and boring, with little emotion displayed. I do not recommend this film... especially not as an accurate depiction of this timeless story. If you a true Jane Austin fan, or just enjoy the book, the best representation of this classic story is the BBC one.
summary: Horrible rendition of this classic story

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie. I admit that I have not read the book yet, and therefore cant judge the authenticity of this movie from that aspect. But as an 'ardent' fan of the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehrle miniseries version I was skeptical that I would enjoy this abbreviated one. However, I was so thrilled that the Bennett family are portrayed as such a vibrant and close-knit family with more "country" roots than we are shown in that other version. Even their house, shown as less pristine, makes sense for a middle class home in the country. The girls show more of the natural feelings that a young single woman would feel even at that time, or maybe more so since marriage was the goal of their 'occupation'. Even a sensible girl would be giddy over a handsome man. I enjoyed that Mr. Bennett was endeared to all his daughters and even to his wife more in this movie. It was a joy to see this classic love story told from a new angle.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Amo a Mr. Darcy, pero personificado por Matthew Macfadyen, en esta versión del libro de Jane Austen es imposible no enamorarse de él, además de adorar todo, desde el más mínimo detalle hasta el maravilloso soundtrack, la fina comedia, etc.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A great Jane Austen book brought to life on screen. The actors were fabulous in their parts. I know this movie like the back of my hand, that is how much I love it. If you are into romantic movies, this is a good one to watch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film is a great adaptation of the classical book. I found it flawless, the actors are perfectly chosen, their performances as well as the direction is perfect.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This my favorite of all the Pride&Prejudice; movies ever made.I would recommend this  movie to my friends. The Best!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was so touched by this film that I finally sat down and read the book (which I loved) while I was engaged, as I quoted Mr. Darcy in my invitations! The film is a triumph for director Joe Wright, as he has included the most vital points of the book, but keeps the action moving, and I must say it was also very engaging watching Kiera Knightly's Elizabeth and Matthew Macfadyen's Mr. Darcy. This adaptation explores the melancholy in the last half of the book that makes the ending that much sweeter. The score is brilliant, as I have played the piano pieces and a lady of that time would've performed them as they are difficult but playable. I loved the film and score so much I played the opening track as I was walking down the aisle! Cheers!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've watched this move so many times and each time I fall in love all over again - with everyone! One of my go-to movies if I need something guaranteed to put a smile on my face!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Even though the BBC version is probably more true to the book it definitely feels like a TV movie.  This big-screen version is  palpably richer with gorgeous cinematography and a beautiful score. Many things felt more realistic. The wonderful Bennett country home with the muddy yard, farm animals and laundry hanging. Ballroom scenes with everyone packed in together.I thought it was amazing how every actor made their character uniquely their own especially considering the hard act they had to follow. I especially enjoyed Brenda Blethlyn as Mrs. Bennett.  Matthew Macfadyen and Kiera Knightly had wonderful chemistry. Their pivotal scene together is one for the ages.  My only complaint is that the movie is so short - I would have liked to have seen as much of these actors as I did the ones in the series.  Can't get enough of Pride and Prejudice!
summary: An excellent adaptation of a well-loved story

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: i love the movie and love the price. A timeless love story.I strongly recommend this as one of the great chic flicks.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Sorry to say but was disappointed in the film. It was very very rushed, as I suppose you can understand a movie length version of Pride & Prejudice would be and I felt that a lot of the major scenes were glossed over just to get through the story.As the movie is so rushed, unfortunately you don't get to really know about and feel for each of the characters much at all.Not only that, this movie is Boring. 1/3 of the way through I started yawning and couldn't wait for the movie to be over. When they finally met in the field at the end, couldn't care less if they got together or not. As I have read the book and watch the BBC version, I knew how many scenes had to go, before I could finally leave the cinema. Mr Darcy whoever he is in this movie, definitely can't act. He looks also too young to play Mr Darcy. Every word that comes out of his mouth is rushed like he needs to get through the script or something. Where is the build up? At first, he seems confused with everything. He is just bizarre! It all looks put on.Was trying not to compare to the Colin Firth version but if you love that version, you will most likely be disappointed anyway.The costumes are absolutely shocking. Where are the corsets? I know Elizabeth is poor, but I think she still knows how to dress as some sort of ladylike fashion, and hasn't been brought up in a squaller. Her dresses indicates she might be the poorest peasant in all of England walking around in nothing more than brown rags. Is that what Jane Austen had in mind?I didn't agree with a couple of scenes in the movie in the fact, that I don't think it would be considered proper in that society for men to do such things, i.e for Darcy to walk in (without knocking on the front door - I might add) - in the middle of the night to see Elizabeth and give her a letter??? If he was a gentleman, very unlikely. Secondly, Mr Bingley just walking into Jane's room while she is sick to see if she is okay? Doesn't he have any sense of propriety? Mr Bingley who has wealth and hopefully sense should know better.There is some things that are said that sound too modern for the period this movie is set in, and not at all like Jane Austen. Bingley's character is shockingly done, to me he behaves like a simpleton, not a character to like and respect. Mr Bingley to me was always suppose to be likeable. To me, he is on the same lineage that we would view Mr Collins. What about that laugh of his!!! Wickham hardly has a presence so you don't get to feel at all for the lead up to Lydia taking off with him and Mr & Mrs Hurst and a couple of other characters have no presence at all. Everything feels in sequence but not a smooth flow - feels very jumpy.Didn't see or feel the chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy.Okay I am a fan of the other but was willing to give this a go and knew there would be differences. I guess my biggest disappointment is the portrayal of Darcy and Bingley. Bingley and Jane seemed like a bizarre couple to be getting attached. I didn't think the way they portrayed Bingley would be the type of person that the Jane they portrayed would go for. Again - chemistry?? Questionable.The ending - where is it?? What a bizarre way to end it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am an avid fan of Jane Austen, especially Pride & Prejudice.  A friend loaned me this copy to compare it to the other versions and what I found was a sorry excuse for movie making.  They should have named it, "The Reduced Austen Company's 'Pride & Prejudice' in 20 minutes."  I have never seen movie actors given nothing to work with and then rushing through it in such a graceless, humorless, unmoving way.  Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFayden were a nice looking pair but neither was up to the stuff of Austen.  Did the director not see the wit and wisdom of the film?  They "Hollywoodized" and tortured the soul of the story.  It does not follow the book, they rewrote lines from the novel, making it harsher, more vulgar.  Do we wonder that the British laugh at us when it come to film making?I feel for Dame Judi Dench who was given nothing to work with, no room to move, whose delivery was rushed for the sake of "movie time"  Her talents were wasted in this film.I gave one star for pretty views (considering so many scenes were ridiculously out of doors.)  I'll grant that the last 2 minutes of the movie were sweet, though had almost nothing to do with novel, but it's not worth a rental or even another viewing in my opinion. Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle got it right.  Matthew Macfayden will never be a "true" Mr. Darcy.  Please, please don't bother.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love this movie. I've seen several versions of this book, but this is far and away my favorite. Great cast, can't help but to fall in love with then all!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen this version of P & P as well as the mini series.  Love both of them.  I think they are both equal in talent.  I really can't decide which I favor more.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I didn't see the 2005 version of Pride and Prejudice in the theater, and rented it only when I couldn't find anything more interesting in the video store. I watched it once and was charmed despite my difficulty in understanding some of the dialogue. I watched it again and became captivated. This is a gorgeous version, and I am now a huge fan of Matthew MacFadyen's. He portrayed Mr. Darcy with subtlety and humor. Finally I 'get' the fascination with Austen's Mr. Darcy.Warning: the performances in this movie are so stellar that you'll find yourself watching it over and over again, catching something new each time.
summary: Most romantic movie I've ever seen.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, I admit to being a Pride and Prejudice snob.  I've read the book 14 times in the last three and a half decades.  When I've found the right superlatives, I'll write a review!  And yes, I am probably prejudiced against anything that is not the 6 hour A&E; mini-series (with Firth--I have to say it too!).  But I tried to like this movie.  I even enjoy the books that have been similar to Austen's (like Pride, Prejudice and Jasmine Field).But there were just too many things that I didn't like.  For example, there was very little character development.  Keira Knightley does a well enough job as Elizabeth Bennet but Matthew Macfadyen (whom I loved in MI-5) did nothing but sneer in this film.  I don't know how anyone could form an attachment to someone who did not have any redeeming qualities.  I know that they cast the Americans for the American audience but I also didn't like the casting of Sutherland.  His 5-day stubble annoyed me, as did his American accent during part of the film.  The worst character portrayal though was Bingley.  He was definitely not a buffoon in the book....  In the movie, he acted like a simpleton!I do give kudos to the makers of this movie; trying to recreate the greatest novel ever written (my opinion) is certainly an ambitious undertaking.  The scenery was lovely and the people unfamiliar with the story will probably love this movie.
summary: Because of my Pride and Prejudices!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a fantastic movie. Although it does omit certain scenes from the book, the casting, costumes, and acting are all very-well done. Beautiful movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Absolutely wonderful, and very romantic.  This is Jane Austen at her best.  Matthew MacFadyen is fabulous, I am checking out his other movies.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Video quite good, but the sound has to be turned all the way up in order to hear the audio. Otherwise, great!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is beautiful in every way possible, from the amazing portrayls of Austen's characters by the actors to the breathtaking scenery. You cannot help but be sucked in by the romance of the movie. Beautifully made, beautifully acted, you cannot help but love it. The movie will definetly leave a smile on your face after you've watched it. Everyone should see this movie it is flawless.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While I will admit that I much prefer the 1995 BBC version, this was an excellent movie and only a two hour commitment versus nearly six hours.  All of the important story elements were included and the characters were well cast.  I especially liked Rosamund Pike and Simon Woods as Jane Bennett and Mr. Bingley.  And Jena Malone was very convincingly annoying as Lydia Bennett.  They did take a few creative liberties but I thought they turned out well.  For example, in this movie, Mr. Bennett and Mrs. Bennett do seem to love each other despite their banter. I was okay with that though, maybe others wouldn't be.  I would recommend at least watching it, if not buying it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride & Prejudice is a lovely book and this production does it justice.  In the book, when Mr. Darcy FINALLY takes Elizabeth's hand, our hearts rejoice.  Toward the end of this production, when Mr. Darcy FINALLY walks across a gorgeous English field at sunrise toward Elizabeth, our hearts rejoice.  It's a beautiful scene and, as it should be, all is well!  Having loved the book for so many years and having seen every other production of the book, I am a tough audience, but Knightly is pretty much perfect in the roll of Elizabeth.  After Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy, Macfayden was a bit disappointing at first for me, but he grew on me.  Brenda Blethyn is appropriately irritating as Mrs. Bennett and Donald Sutherland is appropriately scruffy, distant and even somewhat icky as Mr. Bennett.  Apparently the period details are accurate, but I did not see that Mr. Bennett in the book.  The "final" scene was a bit too much and a bit sappy.  However, all in all, no major complaints.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Was a great present for my girlfriend who has been dying to watch it with me. Shipped in a fast manner and no problems playing it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Maybe every generation needs to re-invent Jane Austen for themselves. This  film interpretation of "Pride and Prejudice" stresses the youthfulness of the characters. Elizabeth and Darcy look younger here than they were in the most recent dramatization that featured Colin Firth. I loved the rough and tumble look of the Bennett's home. It's a non-prissy look at life in the early 19th century. The film's expansive outdoor scenes were like a series of Bruegel paintings--the characters' romances became part of larger ongoing drama of rural life. McFayden's Darcy is refreshingly nerdy. He's a nice change from the usual drop-dead handsome Darcys (like Laurence Olivier and Firth). Knightly is equally refreshing as a tomboyish Elizabeth.This is the story of two intelligent young people cursed with embarrassing relatives. Elizabeth has an emotionally disengaged father, a vulgar mother who continuously puts her foot in her mouth and three out-of-control sisters. Darcy's aunt, Lady Catherine, is an ill-behaved snob whose rude behavior is worse than the whole Bennett family put together.This film really conveys the precariousness of the Bennett's financial and social situation more than other dramatizations. We can see why Mrs. Bennett's desperation to get her daughters married off isn't so crazy after all. As in all of Austen, there's a dark undertone to the story--the vulnerability of women who have no money or powerful social connections. Lydia's elopement with Wickham shows how swiftly a young woman can fall from respectability and the double-standard that lets the men involved go scot-free. Elizabeth's assertiveness and integrity stand out all the more given the limited choices she has in her life.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was SO glad I didn't see this dreadful movie in the cinemas.  I don't understand is why on earth anyone would try to improve on an already masterful adaptation (even with it's flaws) of this beloved novel.  The A & E version is the very best do date.Keira Knightly was about as believable as I would be in this role. Her acting is stiff and her facial features (what is up with her mouth?) are too distracting. Matthew Macfadyen is so wooden and doesn't betray any feeling towards Knightly.  There isn't any real tension or chemistry between them.You can skip this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My absolute favorite movie. Every scene is fantastic. The characters are played by incredible actors, particularly Keira and Matthew. Love!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just love this movie. I could watch it over and over. Don't miss a great buy. This is one of them

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice starring Keira Knightly was an excellent update of the classic. Its interpretation is concise compared to earlier versions but just as powerful if not even more effective in delivering the essence of the love story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I LOVE this movie and this book! I think this movie is a great film even though it deviates slightly from the novel! Worth the money!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It was great to be able to stream this from Amazon when my mom came to visit.  We had just listened to the audio book while traveling.  Beautiful story, very well brought to the screen.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Where to begin myself? Well, first off, perceptions regarding fashion derived from the book would be almost nil. Austen is known for not being overly descriptive on such things. Secondly, social mores for the Regency period are usually not well served by most costume pieces.The Regency was dirty, it was smelly, and although there was certainly the veneer of politeness and decorum, underneath was lust, debauchery and gluttony...The reality was far grittier and less pretty than what's presented onscreen or even in Austen's novels1)Re: Bingley entering the bedroom: He confined himself to the anteroom adjoining the bedchamber. This wasn't considered too over the top as long as there was some sort of chaperone there, aka Lizzie. Did it bother anyone when Captain Brandon ACTUALLY WENT INTO the bedroom of Kate Winslet in "Sense and Sensibility?"2) Clothing and Hair: "English Women's Clothing in the Nineteenth Century" by C Willett Cunnington explains fashion for every year of that century, and it justifies the look for the Bennet family just fine. In addition here's a quote from the book since many are dissing Lizzie's hair alot regarding the hair trends of 1800(just three years after the movie is set in):" "The front hair is combed forward on to the forehead and parted in full ringlets, or worn dishevelled. Or cropped short; or 'highly frizzed in the front and turned up behind.'" Dishevelled being the key word.So, I think before others criticize what they perceive as inaccurate Regency period dress and hair and social codes, it's important to realize how large a spectrum there was for various trends and behaviors for this time period-just like our own period today! AND that modern miniseries and movies are not always the best standard to judge accuracy by.Oh, and yes-loved the movie. A more realistic portrayal that isn't so picturesque, and a nice tribute to the original work at hand.PS-re: Cheesy Ending: That ending was tacked on for American audiences only-everywhere else in the world basically didn't get that ending! Basically the distributors over here in the states wanted a kissy-kissy ending to make it more appealing to us yanks. As the director mentioned, it seems we Americans like a "little more sugar in [our] champagne." The director and actors actually do not prefer this ending either....

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a fan of Pride and Prejudice and have been since high school.  I got a copy of the A&E version of the movie for my birthday and loved it.  This one is really amazing, concidering it had to condense everything down from 5 hours.  It's got excellent tension and you love the characters.  I love it and it is a quick alternative to the longer version.
summary: It's not the A&E version, but it's pretty darn good

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Mall of America Gift Card Customer
review_text: I've heard it said that it's just not possible to condense Pride and Prejudice into a 2 hour format. This absolutely proves that wrong. It takes the one thing that's essential to Pride and Prejudice, the story of Elizabeth and Darcy, and sticks to that. Certain creative liberties are taken, deviating from some of the expansive scenes in the novel, but in doing so the spirit of the novel is preserved. What takes chapters of text can be condensed into a few minutes of screen time. I wouldn't suggest watching this if you're trying to dodge reading the book for English class, but as a portrait of the spirit of the book it's a first-rate piece.
summary: Simply amazing, the best rendition yet

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was the best version i have seen. It is such a beautiful movie and i went to see it 3 times at the theater and i cannot wait to get it on DVD so i ccan watch it continously!
summary: ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL ROMANTIC FILM! BETTER THAN ALL THE OTHER VERSIONS!!!!!!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love period films but this one is my favorite of them all!  The chemistry between Knightley and Macfadyen is amazing as well as the spirited dialogues that they share throughout the movie.  I have watched this film over 10 times and still love seeing it all unfold.  The directors commentary is fun to hear as well - and very satisfying to hear that things I saw and imagined whilst watching it were in fact true.  They took a few liberties but bravo for them because they worked splendidly! For those who might be on the fence about buying this dvd - go for it!  You won't be sorry!  Even my husband who is not the biggest fan of period films loves this one simply because of the amazing dialogues!
summary: One of my favorite movies of all time!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Great romance without the smut!  Love it! It was nice to watch movie that was just a beautiful story, simply made.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My continual question to myself while watching this movie was, "Why?"  For spot-on casting and faithfulness of dialogue, I do not think the Ehrle/Firth version can be improved upon.  This version has modern-ish undertones that rob it of the essential Austen reticence and modesty.  True, it isn't as glaringly awful as the Hollywoodized MANSFIELD PARK, but why, since the BBC version captured Austen's spirit so exactly, would one bother to do a remake like this?  Above all, it escapes me how so many Austen fans could overlook the extensive alterations in dialogue, which occasionally made me cringe.  And the scene with the statues--what was the deal with that???It is unpleasant to feel impelled to critique negatively a film so universally praised.  However, I stand by my view that the latest P&P; fails to enhance the public's understanding of Austen's writing and thinking.In giving the film 3 stars, I am tipping my hat to its breathtaking scenery.
summary: A Fan of Austen But Not of this Film

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love the book, which is why i was surprised that I loved this movie so much.  It is one of my all-time favorites, and makes me love the characters, the plot, and Austen's genius even more.  I also teach English, so I appreciate that they kept the dialogue in line with the language of the novel.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Ok i confess  i saw this movie three times in at the movies. The first time i hated it. The last two times I left starry eyed. Then I rewatched the BBC adaption. And now basically I'm over it. The flaws are waving like red flags. I am now starting to hate it. Honestly it wasn't horrible. The music and scenery and cinematography are awesome. But the portrayal of the characters especially Darcy I can't buy.I'm sorry. From the first time I saw it I didn't believe a word he said. It just felt like the writers tried to hard. They were so eager to make pride and prejudice appeal to younger generations that they tried to add humour and romance. There are so many punch lines and I don't know. Jane Austen wrote a wonderful story it doesn't need help. In the attempt to make pride and prejudice more whatever they just killed the book. Of course people will read it, but I have so often seen a movie loved it and hated the book for being different. You have to be very open-mind to read the book after the movie. And even more open minded to like both. It's not awful, but its not what it could or should be. If you haven't watched it yet STOP!!! BBC first, then this one. If haven't read book, it's a must read. Don't judge the book by it's movie, give it a fair shot.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you are looking for Jane Austen's beautiful book translated faithfully to film, this is not the movie for you. But this adaptation `Pride & Prejudice' is wonderfully done. This movie has great casting, good writing and good direction. I did enjoy watching this shorten version of the film even though some subplots do not even exits in this movie. It would be impossible to place all that Jane Austen has going on in her novel into two-hour movie.One thing the director did do is film everything from the view of Elizabeth Bennet, played by Keira Knightly. And the dance hall scenes and social etiquette were accurate for the time period chosen, 1797. You could see what a middle-upper class family had to go through if they had daughters. I also thought that Matthew Macfadyen played a captivating Mr. Darcy and Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet, though looking soft spoken and soft on Elizabeth, and it showed he did marry for love.The scenery and music are highlights of the movie. This is a movie many will see more then once. Though Elizabeth Bennet in this movie seems to have more modern sensibilities then the book gives her, Keira knightly still does well. Especially considering every woman that has ever read this books has her own view on the character. But the chemistry you feel from the screen form Elizabeth and Darcy jumps out at you, there string love suppressed by misunderstandings and preconceived notions.... if I might be so bold as to say, their Pride & Prejudice.This book is a masterpiece and sets the standard for all romantic novels, so no movie could ever stand up to its standard. But for a two-hour entertaining movie, it was very good.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Oh my goodness!!!! I was absolutely bowled over by this movie!  I loved it, loved it, loved it.....Everything about this presentation was done beatifully.  Matthew MacFadyen is absolutely perfect as the aristocratic Mr. Darcy.His acting, to me, did not present a haughty, unfriendly man, but rather a shy, lonely soul who hides behind his class expectations and mannerism.  By watching his reactions, with those very melancholy eyes, (believe me I have watched those eyes a number of times!) you get to truly know him.  He does not need to speak.....his expressions say it all.  Of course, his voice is one of the most beautiful masculine voice I have ever heard!  Bravo Matthew!  Keira is spot on!  She too can convey her feelings with her expressions and mannerism.  I have watched this movie at least 3 times, and will certainly watch it again and again.  Every time I watch it I pick up some more nuances I had missed before.  The rest of the ensemble was just as excellent portraing their characters.  Buying this movie, was certainly money well spent.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The sceneries were beautiful, breathtaking, but the romance was a marathon. One day they didn't like each other well, the next they were in love without all the shenaningas. But the fact that the hero and heroin were so young, in their teens, made this love in a hurry seems believable. It is a good version but the masterpiece in my opinion is still the BBC one with Colin Firth. In that old version Darcy and Lizzie had their slow cooking romance and their chemistry was so palpable that really made me believe them to be in love for real off-screen, the way Collin Firth's eyes shone whenever he was looking at Lizzie, it was so real (especially when she was helping Georgiana at the piano) and the sweet face of Lizzie when staring him back. That scene is unforgettable. Oh my, if I could exchange places with Lizzie, be her...The actors in this version made the most in 2 hours and the wonderful settings made this movie a 2nd best, in my opinion. I love it, though I still prefer the emotional and romantic details of the BBC version.In this version they kept only the basics, even mr. Wickham and Miss Bingley didn't have enough time to show all their conniving dark sides in total splendor.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Plenty of reviews here already address the Movie vs BBC Mini-Series angle (personally, I love both), so I'll just comment on the Blu-Ray itself.As a happy owner of the DVD, I wanted the Blu-Ray for the boost in image, and this release does not disappoint. The picture looks absolutely gorgeous: crisp and clear, with subtle yet rich colors. Pause at any point during the movie and you have a beautiful still on your screen. I don't currently have a set-up that takes advantage of the 5.1 audio mix, but it sounds just fine coming out of my tv speakers.Alas, to get to the movie, one must first navigate the horrendous BD Live system. Not content to stack trailer upon trailer onto a disc, the movie studios now force download a "fresh" trailer every time the movie plays. Skipping it is not an option. The disc allows no interaction until the trailer is downloaded, and even then, exiting the trailer is a nightmare: FF, SCAN, and NEXT are all disabled. If you don't give up easily you can eventually kill it (continuous pressing of "POP UP MENU" is one way), but that's two minutes of your life gone EVERY TIME you start the disc.Once you make it to the menu, prepare to be horrified. Thanks to BD Live there is a movie ticker along the upper right of the screen. Mercifully, this steady stream of marketing can be turned off, but the studios' desire to turn a simple menu into a perpetual commercial is enough to make me abandon Blu-Ray for DVD. The horror doesn't end there. Despite the Jane Austen pedigree, the menu designer opted instead to go with a slick, futuristic interface that looks better suited toFast & Furious, not Ms. Bennet & Mr. Darcy. The DVD release - actually, even the movie website from 2005 - did a better job with the menu.There's a lot to be annoyed at, but at the end of the day, the Blu-Ray treatment of the movie itself is absolutely marvelous, so if you're a fan and you find it on sale, it's worth picking up. Just go pop some popcorn or pour a drink while BD Live force-feeds commercials.
summary: BD Live starts this off on the wrong foot

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, putting aside the gross inaccuracies in historical detail, my main problem with this movie is the complete lack of satire and wit that Austen is famous for. Hollywood made this a chick flick for the masses rather than a deep and hilarious jab at the ridiculous happenings in a society bound by precise codes of conduct. In addition, Austen, in Pride and Prejudice, was making gentle fun of the unbelievable amount of time people spent on making matches, thinking of marriage, and what people look for in a marriage partner. All of that is lost in this silly version.I don't think any of the cast is true to form--no one captures their character and so we are left with yet another flat romance that is meant to coo at you rather than shake you up with its pointed statement. In many respects, I think Hollywood believes audiences are  mindless and unable to tell the difference between a good adaptation of a classic and a travesty.If I had to make an analogy of pride and Prejudice I would say thisJane Austen's original novel = Lobster with butterBBC version = A prime cut steak, perfectly grilled and seasonedThis trite production = Spam in a can

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Marion Marchetto "author of The Bridgewater C...
review_text: What a treat to view this wonderful Jane Austen tale on the screen! Having read the book more than 40 years ago, the details have become fuzzy to me so I won't worry too much about the movie closely following the book.Kiera Knightly was an absolutely perfect choice to play the role of Elizabeth. Headstrong, opinionated - Ms. Knightly does these well. The dark and brooding Mr. Darcy was also played to perfection by Mr. MacFayden, keeping his good deeds under wraps and bearing the brunt of Elizabeth's scorn.I thoroughly enjoyed the romp through the English countryside of yore. The settings were believable and seemingly accurate. Supporting performance by Donald Sutherland as the father of five marriageable young ladies was a touch of delight.I give this movie four stars because it is so obviously a 'chick flick'.Recommended for PG audiences everywhere.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: *** REVIEW FOR THE 2010 BLU RAY VERSION ***In order to have this movie in High Definition, I've had the HD-DVD format of it for a few years now - but it's an America issue and has the controversially modern US ending. Now at last it arrives on BLU RAY in the USA (January 2010) and in the UK (May 2010) and it's just as gorgeous a transfer. It uses exactly the same elements that the HD-DVD did - even the same menus - and the extras from the DVD are all intact also (with the US ending tagged on as an Alternate).The improvement in picture quality is immense over the rather blurred DVD experience. As it opens with a misty dawn and the twitter of birds, we see the young and feisty Elizabeth Bennet (played with a magical touch and staggering assurance by Kiera Knightly) walking with a book. But it's not until she crosses the courtyard of her home that the real quality kicks in - and it's a wow. The picture takes you aback - it wasn't this good in the cinema I can tell you...It isn't perfect throughout by any means though. Because they were going for authenticity, a lot of the early evening and dark night sequences are shot in candlelit rooms (as they would have lived), so you get fuzziness in the definition... But once you get out into the countryside or inside one of the great halls of stately homes - where proper lighting prevailed - the picture quality is beautiful. There is one famous dream sequence where only Kiera's closed eyes fill the screen - she is dreaming of standing on the cliff edge - the clarity is gobsmacking. You also notice the weave of the clothing, the dirt on the hemlines, the ever so slightly unkempt hair - the attention to detail is great.Directed by Joe Wright and released in late 2005, the film version was living in the shadow of the legendary 6-part BBC production from 1995 - so the movie had a lot on its shoulders and admirably rose to the task. Another trump card was Dario Marianelli's lush piano score (Oscar nominated) swirling around the scenes like a graceful swan.In the cinema, it was a delight to look and experience - but sitting at home and watching it in real definition is a far more rewarding and illuminating experience. The acting chops on display is right across the board and apart from a slightly jarring ending, it had the hallmarks of a shoot that was fun and supremely confident in its delivery. I know others will cite the BBC production as definitive - but I think there's more than enough room on my shelf for both.Matthew MacFadyen, Brenda Blethyn, Rosamund Pike, Carey Mulligan, Judy Dench, Tom Hollander - they were a cleverly chosen cast - and Rupert Friend won the heart of the lovely Kiera (which might explain the ethereal beauty of her performance). But it's the stunning adaptation of Jane Austen's novel by DEBORAH MOGGACH that is the real hero of the day. There is a sequence when Elizabeth and Darcy finally face off against each other in the rain - the dialogue is to die for - and should have been Oscar rewarded. As a dabbler in screenplays myself, I can't stress enough just how good the work here is - dazzling stuff.It's under a tenner, the DVD extras are all intact, the picture quality is much improved and in some cases unbelievably so - and its eminently re-watchable.To sum up - if you're a fan of the film, Jane Austen or both - then you must own "Pride & Prejudice" on this format. A Blu Ray gem and highly recommended.
summary: "...So This Is Your Opinion Of Me..."

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a wonderful adaptation of the Jane Austen classic.  It really does a nice job of not going too far over two hours, because with certain movies that don't move as quickly as others, it is very difficult to sit through them when they are too long.  The acting is very wonderful in this, but I am disappointed that the Academy did not consider Donald Sutherland for the supporting actor category instead of maybe Paul Giamatti.  I like Paul Giamatti, but I have a feeling that the Academy wanted to make up for not nominating him for his better role last year in Sideways.  Sutherland does not have many fiery scenes, but his mild manners and his modesty in this film just made me very excited to watch him in this role.  The rest of the acting is pretty good for this remake.  Kiera Knightley does not extremely impress me in this, at least as much as in Domino, but her acting suffices for this.  I shouldn't expect to see her accepting the Academy Award for Best Actress, but we should see her cheer Reese Witherspoon on.  The story is fantastic, and if you enjoy Jane Austen, then you will no doubt love this remake of one of the most popular novels in English Literature.  Very well done. (4 1/2 stars)

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After watching this movie, I'll have to admit that it was pretty good: the acting was done well, the camera quality and shooting were quite good, the character's dress and the sets really matched into there respective time period nicely. These qualities would have made it an excellent movie if it weren't for a few problems. I know that it may seem a little nick-picky, but I think that these are real problems that [most of them] could have been dealt with.The first problem is the actors. I think that the acting itself was done perfectly, great enough to make any director proud; but the main problems are with the actors themselves. Some of them look a little too "modern": for example, I though that Keira Knightley looked a little too modern-aged for that time. She has a slight hint of a model look that fits perfectly into movies about our day an age. But that really doesn't work in a movie set in the late 18th century. Sure, Keira played her character well, but she didn't really have the look for that time period. Some of the other actors look a little "goofy", like Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland), Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), Lydia Bennet (Jena Malone), and Colonel Fitzwilliam (Cornelius Booth),  kind of look out-of-place in the movie setting. In the A&A; production, they had gotten actors that fit the roles and looks of the characters. And here, they get allot of them right, but some of them really aren't looking too good.Another problem is that sometimes, especially when the characters are in the streets of a town of inside a busy room, the dialogue and the background sound of the surrounding activity seem to clash a little bit. Sometimes, when the characters are having a quitter discussion in a more active place, the sounds of the hustle and bustle around them are allot louder than the characters, making it hard to hear them at several points. There will be several times were you will have to keep on adjusting your TV's volume so that you can hear the dialogue clearly. I think that this is a problem that could easily have been fixed before release via a small sound adjustment.And perhaps the biggest problem with the film is this: it's too short. I know that it is two hours long, but I'm not talking about the running length itself. Allow me to explain:Pride and Prejudice is a long book: even with the A&E; production, which was six hours long, several scenes from the book had to be cut out. But they still had enough time to have several smaller events that didn't have much to do with the main plot but didn't take away from the story at all: in fact, I think that those smaller scenes really benefited the whole production immensely. It was easier to connect and care for the characters if you saw more involved with there personal lives that just what you see in the main plot. I know that the makers of this film didn't have six hours to include that many side-scenes from the book, but it still feels a little "tight": pretty much just the main plot from the original story is included here, and even on that they really had to trim it. It just sort of feels in this movie like were zipping from one event to another: one moment the Netherfield Ball is just ending, then before you know it Mr. Collins comes in. There really isn't much time to contemplate on any one event: just as soon as one important even happens, another important one pops up. For example: I didn't think that they gave enough time to the whole Lydia running off with Wickham. That is a very important event in the story. But it seems like, almost as soon as they run off, they're found and brought back. There's no time to realize the seriousness of the situation if it all happens in ten minutes. There are other stuff like this in the movie that didn't get enough time: there wasn't enough time given to the character development of Mr. Darcy's younger sister, Elizabeth's visit to her Aunt and Uncle was too short, and perhaps the biggest hurtle of them all, several memorable characters, like Mrs. Hurst and Sir William Lucas  have been ultimately cut from the film for the sake of time. I know that you can't really blame the makers for these things: they didn't have six-hours to make a theatrical movie like A&E; did. But this still raises a question: does Pride and Prejudice really work out as a two-hour movie? This is still a really good film, I'll have to say; but this problem really prevents it from becoming a brilliant, plain-out really great film. But I know that this is a problem that couldn't really been helped, so I can't really hold it againsed the movie that much.Despite these problems, this still a good film that is really worth watching: even though it may have a few "casting errors" and some sound problems, and that it may feel a little rushed, but it's still a great film that deserves attention. It may not benefit your film collection as much as the A&E; production will, but it's still a film that is sure to be enjoyed.
summary: Good movie, but it could have been better

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's probably impossible to rate this version without comparing it to the 1995 BBC version, which is longer(you get to know the characters), better casted(way better) and more fun.This version is so short that when you are used to the BBC version it just feels rushed and characters and balls have been completely cut out. Lydia is back home almost before she has run away (or so it feels).The casting is not very good. The only one who matches the 1995 version is Mr. Collins. He is really good (although not as fun) in this one.  He is very annoying which is his job :)Many of the lines are delivered in a very flat manor. For example "Are the shades of Pemberly....blah blah". She does not sound REALLY disqusted by the very thought. It's like the line is just read without any feeling behind it.Miss Caroline Bingley is noway as sophisticated and superior as when portrayed by Anna Chancellor. Mr. Bingley is almost too goofy but I have not read the novel, so I don't know if he is supposed to be so goofy. But I don't see why the serious and shy Jane would fall for that silly person.Another thing is the music by Carl Davis which I really missed. In the 1995 version every important character had it's own tune which underlined the character and really helped with the flow of the movie(well episodes).This new version is not wholly bad (hehe). Actually compared to many of the other BBC series like Middlemarch, Wives and daughters it is good. But compared to a masterpiece it fails utterly and completely.2 stars!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must confess--I went into the theater to see this film with so many preconceptions that nothing short of a miracle would get me to enjoy it. An avid fan of the BBC miniseries, absolutely everything was wrong with the movie. Darcy was too moody, Lady Catherine was much too autocratic, and Wickham was entirely to handsome.Whether it was being compared to Colin Firth or just how much he brooded, I disliked Matthew Macfayden passionately. Yet as the movie progressed, I grew more and more amenable toward him until, like Lizzy, I was in love. It was the same with Wickham--here was a boy who was extremely cute (even knowing the evil he would become) and, at one point, I started hoping they would alter the ending just to avoid this unlikeable Darcy. And who can play a better matron than Judi Dench? Why, she made all other Lady Catherines positively frail in comparison.In fact, the only characters I even remotely liked were Lizzy, Jane and Mr. Bennet. I've always been a Knightly fan, but here, she seemed to personify my idea of Lizzy (though at the time, I was still determined to hate her). When Mr. Bennet first appeared on the screen, I couldn't resist his wry quips and his face when he said them. And though it pained me to admit it, this Jane was much prettier and much more how I'd imagined her than the BBC.When I watched my treasured BBC DVD again a few days afterwards, I was surprised and aghast to see how slow moving and almost -dull- it was. The movie didn't leave out any major scenes or characters (with the exception of the married Bingley sister, who was never that essential anyway) and was over in 2 hours. The "teacup time" they cut (scenes where someone is looking out a window, or a sudden zoom on a period-teacup) was not missed.The shots in the movie were simply stunning--the lighting effects and the sheer beauty of the landscape made me catch my breath several times, and the picture-perfect world of the BBC was cast aside for the more realistic mud and rocks. While the BBC did a better job capturing the embarrassment of the family, this movie did a better job capturing the differences in status.As much as it pains me to admit it, I believe the movie is better. The preconceptions from the BBC only served to increase my love of this movie, for I felt exactly as Lizzy must have, meeting these characters for the first time. Set against the gorgeous backgrounds and alongside the period music, it was simply inevitable that I would fall in love. The three other BBC aficionados I went to see it with all needed to wipe a tear away at the end (And while I'm not admitting I cried, the tissues in my purse tell a different story) and the four of us went back to see it a few days later. This is a stunning rendition of Pride and Prejudice and undoubtedly my favorite. *swoon*
