title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have 3 versions of Pride & Prejudice movies--the 1979 version shown on PBS, the 1990's BBC version, and this version.  To me, they each have their strong points and I like them all.The PBS version is much closer to the book than the others and the Bennet sisters are much prettier than in the 2 later movies.  Elizabeth Garvie was an excellent Elizabeth. I thought David Rintoul as Darcy wasn't as good as the later movies--he was too formal and elegant.  That might be closer to how a rich, proud young man might act in that time, though.  I thought the Mr & Mrs Gardiner in the PBS version were by far the best of the 3 movies.  They had more class.  Mr. and Mrs. Bennet seemed to be characterized as they are in the book, as did the other characters.  I thought this movie had the best Mr. Collins and the best Mr. Bingley.  I also preferred this version's Lady Catherine and Anne de Bourgh.The BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle was pretty good and followed the book reasonably well.  Firth's Mr. Darcy seemed more human and more masculine.  I thought Mr. Bennet was pretty good, but Mrs. Bennet was far too cartoonish to be anything but annoying.  Kitty and Lydia argued too much for supposedly being close.  None of the Bennet girls were pretty enough and looked a little too chunky, although that may have been the clothes.  I thought they might have tried to cast Jane Bennet as looking like Jane Austen, but she just looked a little odd--not beautiful.  Mr. Bingley looked a little goofy.  The Gardiners were okay, but Mrs. Gardiner made a couple of remarks about the Darcy family that sounded resentful and/or envious and I do not think that Jane Austen's Mrs. Gardiner would have been either resentful or envious.  The music was a little better in this movie than in the PBS version and the dances lasted longer.  I thought the Mr. Wickham in this movie was the best one.This newer version with Keira Knightley had by far the best music and the best dancing.  I liked this Mr. Darcy well enough, too, but Mr. Bingley was even goofier looking than the one in the BBC version, although I thought Miss Bingley was good--more elegant.  This version did not follow the book all that much--certainly not as closely as the earlier 2 versions.  The Bennet family and the Gardiner family were portrayed as much lower class and poor than I think Jane Austen had any idea of them being.  I did like the softened characters.  For example, Mrs. Bennet wasn't quite so loud and certainly not as cartoonish as the one in the BBC version.  This wasn't really true to the book, but one got the feeling that this Mr. and Mrs. Bennet did love each other.  Other reviewers have mentioned the ridiculousness of the ball scene where everyone stops dancing and makes a path for Mr. Bingley, Mr. Darcy, and Miss Bingley.  I didn't like that either.  Nor did I think that Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner would have gone off and left Lizzy at Pemberley so that she had to walk back to the inn in Lampton.  I didn't like the statue room scene or Lizzy wandering around the house by herself.  However, although this film wasn't nearly close enough to the book, I did love the music and I thought it more romantic in some ways.  There were some parts that were a little weird such as Lizzy staring into a mirror for hours while it went from daylight to dark, and Mr. Darcy letting himself into the Collins' home at night to give her the letter.  And, of course, Lady Catherine's late night visit to the Bennet's home.The PBS version is around 4 hours and the BBC version is around 5 1/2 hours, while this version is a little over 2 hours.  I highly recommend having all three, just to enjoy the different interpretations and portrayals.  Otherwise, rent them first and see which you like best.  The PBS version, I feel, is defintely closer to the book.  The other two have far better Mr. Darcys.  As I said earlier, there is something to enjoy in each version.
summary: Comparison of the Three Pride & Prejudice Movies

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife." Thus opens Jane Austen's book Pride and Prejudice.  This movie adaptation takes us through the lives of the 5 Bennet girls as their mother attempts to marry them off to gentlemen of means.  The protaganist, Elizabeth Bennet, prefers to marry for love rather than security and thus the journey begins.I have read P & P more times than I can count (and every other Jane Austen book).  I have watched the Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle version almost as many times.  Until I watched this film, I considered Firth to be THE Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy.  No more!  Matthew Macfadyen has surplanted him in my mind.  He brings such a charisma and realness to the character of Mr. Darcy that is lacking in all other versions.  While I still love the BBC version, the Keira Knightley/Matthew Macfadyen chemistry makes this the most romantic version to date.  The characters are more human and Knightley is actually the correct age to play Elizabeth Bennet.  Jennifer Ehle and Greer Garson were just a little too old to be realistic as a 20 year old headstrong young woman.While the BBC version is more true to the book, it also had 5 hours to accomplish this feat.  This 2 hour adaptation is absolutely breathtaking from start to finish.  I loved Tom Hollander as Mr. Collins.  While not the correct height for Austen's description of him, he played his role like a giant.  He was the perfect mix of condescension and obsequiousness.  Brenda Blythen was just nervous enough as Mrs. Bennet without being too hysterical.  Rosamund Pike actually showed that Jane Bennet was the beauty of the county.  My only disappointment (and it is a small one) is that Lydia was good, but not as good as the BBC version of her character.  Donald Sutherland puts a different spin on Mr. Bennet and on first viewing, I was not sure if I liked it best or not.  He showed an affection to Mrs. Bennet not really evident in the book, but then he showed the correct amount of affection to Lizzie.  I decided after the 2nd or 3rd time that I liked his portrayal very much, especially the final scene when his love and tenderness are revealed.I have watched the DVD so many times that my husband is becoming concerned about my obsession.  I even pulled out my BBC version (and another A & E version) to compare them all.  All have their merit and are worth watching multiple times, but this version absolutely brings a life to the characters that makes the viewer take ownership.  I will watch it again as soon as I can get my mother to return it to me.Purist will pan this film because it does stray from the book in a number of settings, but one could hardly find a greater Austen fan than myself.  The poetic license used by the director is perfectly balanced with the absolutely magnetic, earthy realism and genuineness of the characters.  Until I saw this version, I would never have called the BBC version slightly antiseptic, but in comparison I must say that it is.  The BBC version follows the book.  This version brings the book to LIFE.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A great story that both my husband and myself love.  Very artisticly shot with beautiful and interesting scenes.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's announced as a collector version but you have nothing more than in the initial DVD version : no deleted scene, no extended version no more about the making of or anything worthy ... I feel truly disappointed !

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Adaptations of this masterpiece have always seemed to me to idealize the period, as if everyone is always perfectly coiffed and nothing is ever out of place or even dusty. This film has filled in the story's background with great depth and color, taking us into a real English country dance, with all of its raucous energy. We see into people's homes with their daily activities, tasks, and yes, even the messes. The dialog feels like conversations that are face to face, not speeches posed across a giant stage. The overall result is a greater feeling of intimacy between you and the movie, almost as if it's not seen on screen but through a window... or even a mirror. I must have seen a dozen or more adaptations of this immortal story, but this time I felt like I was there, and a part of it all.As for the acting, I thought Matthew Macfadyen was the best Darcy I have ever seen. All of the actors were excellent, but I want to make special mention of Talulah Riley's performance as the bookish sister, Mary.  Most adaptations seem to disregard or even ridicule Mary for her social cluelessness. But this movie is brave enough to let us see her in greater depth and compassion, as a girl whose cluelessness is really just an extreme awkwardness, and therefore something we can all relate to. We even see her beauty and vulnerability as I have never seen on screen. In a master stroke of screenwriting, we see her suffer great pain and shame after her embarrassing attempt to be socially adept by performing at the pianoforte, albeit badly, to be publicly humiliated by her mother's loud declaration that "You have delighted us long enough" and her crumbling defeat from it. It is then that we see Mr. Bennet in a rare moment of warmth, comforting his disconsolate little girl, not aloof and sarcastic as usual, but holding her in his arms.  In this way, too, it breathed more life into the story in all of its fullness.That, for me, made this movie feel like the story was finally a part of myself, not just a tale about others.
summary: Not just the story but the age

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice is one of the best romantic movies ever. It is truly moving, and escapes all the bullcrap of the normal Hollywood "Chickflicks" and "Romantic Comedies". These movies are generally just filled with sex, and very little basis for the man and woman liking each other. Pride and Prejudice is a very intellectual movie that deeply explores romance, love,  and attraction. This movie makes you believe love is real, and not just some fake Hollywood thing. The movie is deeply moving. Expect yourself to smile, laugh and cry.
summary: A Good Romantic Movie, Not a Hollywood Fabrication

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I rented this movie knowing that it probably wouldn't be as well played out as the A&E version with Firth and Ehle because of the time frame, but even though, I was dissapointed. If I had never read the book or watched the A&E version, I would've been perfectly happy.  Because of the time frame, the story was so rushed that the little, but important, elements were left out and the romance didn't have a solid ground from which to bloom and grow.  One minute Elizabeth hated Mr. Darcy and then the next minute she loved him.  I was also dissapointed with the little screen time that Mr. Wickam got, whereas he was one of the pivotal characters in Elizabeth's view of Darcy and their romance, he was just another character. The characters themselves did not have enough depth, I was not convinced of Knightley's Elizabeth, Macfadyen's Darcy did not have depth rather he was two dimensional, Wickam was only on the screen for a few minutes to smile or frown, and Bingley became stupid. The one character who became real was Judi Dench's Lady Catherine, Dench just sparkled and was absolutely brilliant, unfortunately she got very little screen time.  The scenery in the movie though, was beautiful and well shot. Overall, if you have never read the book, this movie will be substantial and pleasant.  But if you want a movie that stays true to Jane Austen's book and spirit, I would recommend the A&E version. It brings it to life with breathtaking scenery and superb acting that brings each character to life.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: M. B. Alcat "Curiosity killed the cat, but sa...
review_text: I read "Pride and prejudice" (1813) more than 15 years ago, and I loved it immediately. I didn't know who Jane Austen was, but I risked disappointment and tried a "new" author. Truth to be told, I found a book that became one of my favourites, due to the fact that it is well-written, but also thoroughly entertaining.I must say that I was a little afraid to watch this movie, due to the undeniable fact that literary adaptations can sometimes go sour. Thankfully, that isn't the case in this occasion, because the director, Joe Wright, somehow managed to capture the essence of the book. I suppose the excellent cast must have helped him in that endeavour. All the actors are remarkably good, but some are specially noteworthy. I think I should at least mention Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet, Matthew Macfadyen as the handsome Mr. Darcy, and Brenda Blethyn as the kind of mother you are thankful not to have :)The plot is not overly complicated, and it tackles wonderfully themes such as relationships, love, class distinctions, and of course pride and prejudice, all from the point of view of what happened in 18th century England. The story begins in the small town where the Bennets live. Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) has five daughters, and her mission in life is marrying them off. Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) is an intellectual, who often escapes to his library in search of silence and to avoid Mrs. Bennet's nonsense. The two more important daughters, from the point of view of the story, are probably the eldest, the beautiful Jane (Rosamund Pike) and the second, Elizabeth (Keira Knightley) who is very witty but perhaps too proud.The dynamics of the town are changed when a single man of large fortune, Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), arrives to Netherfield Park, an estate not far from town. Mr. Bingley comes with a friend, Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen), and the Bennets meet both at a ball. While Mr. Bingley immediately caughts Jane's eye, and is considered nice by Elizabeth, Mr. Darcy has not such luck. By sheer chance, Elizabeth overhears him making a negative comment on her, something that hurts her pride and spurs her to consider him a hateful man. But will that change? And if so, how?Discovering that is likely to be fun for the spectator, unless he is a perfectionist looking for inconsistencies between the film and the book. There are quite a few, it is true, but I firmly believe that is not important if the essence of what makes "Pride and Prejudice" a classic is present in the movie. And in my opinion, it is... Highly recommended :)Belen AlcatPS: Of course, if you want to enjoy this film even more, read the book too. Even though the director and the cast successfully captured the essence of "Pride and Prejudice", there is still a lot you will be missing if you don`t do that.
summary: Excellent, but please read the book too...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Just as the "modernized" version of Emma was entitled Clueless NOT  Emma, this movie should have been given another name. It may have nice scenes of the countryside and sweeping music but it is untrue to Austen's intent and the feel of her Pride and Prejudice. The story is choppy and feels rushed, no time for character development- and what you do see of the characters are totally off base from Austen's beautifully written ones.  Aside from a couple of decent performances (Judi Dench for one), the casting, acting, an writing are terrible.  Elizabeth's strong will and stubborness are portrayed by K. Knightly as impetuous temper and Darcy's restrained pride as sullen disdain that becomes pathetic when he inexplicably falls for her. There are SO many problems with this film as P&P- just watch the BBC version to see the difference. I was really excited to see this film and then was extremely disappointed! To those that say that this is a passable film if you don't pay that much attention to the actual story: then call it something else and don't get a P&P lover's hopes up!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just love this movie..the characters, the clothing, the whole time period. The cast is brilliant and the chemistry is almost tangible.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: With the exception of the 1940 Greer Garson version that had the Bennet girls dressed as Bo Peep, this has to be one of the poorest versions of P&P that I've seen.  Why?  The cameraman couldn't get his eyes off Keira Knightley. In the big watershed moments, we go to a larger than life close up of Ms. Knightley and then to a distant view of Mr. Darcy.  How can we feel the strength of the scene that way? Matthew Macfadyen never stood a chance as Darcy.  Too bad. We never really got to see him.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've never read anything by Jane Austen, and I suspect I never will. Thus I have no idea whether Joe Wright's version of Pride and Prejudice is an accurate translation of the novel to film. But I do know that it's one of the best films my wife and I have watched together in a long time. The film was like a breath of fresh air to me; I found something almost shocking about the culture of love and marriage the film depicts. As I watched the movie, I couldn't refrain from contrasting the drama of Victorian courtship with the oversexed, hypersensual culture of "courtship" (so-called) that characterizes today's young people.As for the merits of the film itself, Wright does a fantastic job of whittling down Austen's apparently complicated plot into a coherent narrative. The cinematography is striking as well. When the movie opened up with a slow, Malick-esque reveal of a sunrise over a stand of trees, I immediately knew there was something special going on. There is one shot at a ball where the camera goes from room to room, picking up conversations and characters as they move about, backtracking and picking them up again as they socialize and dramatize. I didn't count, but I think the shot was at least six to eight minutes long. This is a very difficult shot to accomplish, as multiple actors have to hit their lines and their positions in a very crowded area right on time, and if someone flubs their part, that's an eight-minute take that just went down the drain. This kind of shot is the mark of a patient and creative filmmaker.The largely British cast is also phenomenal. I usually consider Keira Knightley to be the queen of overacting, but here her personality is perfect for Lizzie Bennett. I've never heard of the actor playing Mr. Darcy, but I instantly knew I wanted to see him in other films. He has a weighty screen presence about him that's a joy to watch. My wife immediately declared Pride and Prejudice to be one of her favorite movies of all time, and as for love stories, I'd have to agree. It's not only good entertainment, it showcases a picture of love and romance that all young people would benefit from seeing, especially girls. We'll be showing it to our daughter when she enters the dating world as a counterbalance to the false messages about love and romance the world gives her.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Thought it only made sense to give this a whirl as I've read all the Austen books numerous times and seen all the other productions.  I was never a big Keira Knightley fan, but after this . . .  What's worse, I was completely baffled by Donald Sutherland's performance, especially at the end.  The engagement scene between him and Lizzy made it look as though perhaps psychotropic medications had come too late for Mr. Bennet.  There's so little of Jane Austen's intent and so little left of the characters, they basically borrowed some names and an ending.  I was appalled at the shot of the pig testicles, and I knew at that point we had the commercially-mauled version of a classic.  Jane Austen was a phenomenal writer, and her characters were well developed, and this film can not explain ANY of its characters or their actions.  But they were apparently not creative enough to make up their own story and leave Jane Austen's memory in peace.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The actors cast as the Bennet family, of course!  Keira Knightley is wonderfully watchable and Jena Malone has been around forever; Rosamund Pike, Carey Mulligan(!) and Talulah Riley have gone on to do some great things!  Stately Donald Sutherland always delivers and Brenda Blethyn's flibbertigibbet flightiness is perfect as the feckless matriarch.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must admit I was stunned to read the various scathing reviews of this movie, since I absolutely do not agree with them.  I thoroughly enjoyed the film and strongly feel it stood up quite well to the much-lauded 1995 BBC mini-series, even though it seems patently unfair to use another film version (which contained its own fair share of casting mistakes and flaws) as the benchmark to judge another.First, Keira Knightley gives a remarkably convincing performance (reflected by the fact that she received well-deserved Oscar and Golden Globe nominations for this role) as the "not yet 21 [years old]" Elizabeth Bennet.  Knightley was not only physically suited to play the part of Elizabeth, but she absolutely managed to capture some the spirit/petulance that is as much a part of the personality of the Austen heroine as the sharp intelligence and wit that traditionally characterizes Lizzie.  Knightley particularly shines in the well-directed rainy scene in which she lambastes Mr. Darcy, following his reluctant marriage proposal to her; Knightley is articulate and passionate in the scene and clearly demonstrates she is not only a photogenic presence on-screen, but has the chops for acting, as well.I was initially ambivalent about Matthew Macfayden's portrayal of Mr. Darcy, but after watching the movie a second time, I found Macfayden's interpretation of the character to be fresh and compelling. Macfayden's distant, slightly awkward Darcy works well opposite Knightley's fiery Lizzie.  The mutual attraction between the two characters is palpable, but clearly hampered by their strong personalities and the proper decorum dictated by the period.I particularly enjoyed the glimpse into early 19th Century life in rural England that this movie provided.  In other film interpretations of Austen's classic novel, the Bennets lived on a lavish (and hence somewhat unlikely), extremely formal and upscale style, which quite frankly, did not seem consistent with the family's alleged circumstances and situation.  In this particular film version, all of the Bennet girls looked lovely (for instance) when turned out in style (with curled hair and fresh frocks) to attend the ball at Netherfield; however, when the viewer is permitted a peek into everyday life in the Bennet household, the house itself is not only rather topsy-turvy, the Bennet sisters themselves are slightly disheveled--their clothes are suited for doing light housework and their hairstyles are mussed and flyaway as would be suited to the quiet and unpretentious lives they lead in the country.The supporting cast is excellent; standouts would include: Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet; Dame Judi Dench as the formidable Lady Catherine de Bourg; and Rosamund Pike who plays, as well as looks the part of Jane Bennet.  This movie version of the much-loved Austen classic stands well on it own merits and does not disappoint; it is beautifully filmed on location in various parts of England and is definitely well worth seeing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you are a person that likes romantic movies, you will love this one!. I have watched Pride & Prejudice almost a dozen of times and I intend to go for more. Will like to see more movies like this!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a huge P&P fan, and this movie absolutely did it justice! Be sure to read the book first - they skip over a bit and it's a little hard to follow if you haven't read the book. If you have read the book, this highlights all of the best parts! I've even seen the old A&E Colin Firth movie and fully approve of the shortened version. P&P fans, definitely check this out!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: NEVER NEVER NEVER TIRE OF WATCHING THIS MOVIE!!! One of my all time favourites.  I love a good love story and this as got to be one of the best. Not as good as the book as they never are but pretty darn close.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Meesha "I'm A Lonely Angel Stuck On The Slow ...
review_text: I have not read the book.I have not seen any of the previous versions, including the infamous Colin Firth version.I bought this because it was on my wishlist, and we had (and still do have) a special promotion at work, which meant we were uncutting the price of nearly every other shop. So why the hell not?Firstly I was pleasantly surprised. After my disastrous attempts at watching some 'period' movies recently (Emma, Vanity Fair), I was preparing myself not to like this. A girl I work with, who also watched and detested Vanity Fair, also didn't enjoy this. But then I was being told by every customer buying it that they liked it.It took me a while, but I did eventually get around to watching it, although was disappointed to discover there was no trailer on the DVD. Plenty of other extras however.For some reason, Keira Knightley got an Oscar nomination for this (but lost out to Reese Witherspoon), which, upon watching the film, I didn't get, considering she mumbles most of her lines. I had to actually have the subtitles switched on to understand not only her, but the fancy olde English that was used. I had the sound turned right up, but still couldn't make much sense of it.But overall, the film was very good, even Keira! Jenna Malone doesn't get much of a look in, her 'big' part being that she elopes. (Not the done thing in those days.) It's good to see Keira actually smiling for a change, she rarely does. There's plenty of great scenery to detract your attention from the not-so-cute guys appearing on screen. I was really disappointed with the lack of good looking guys in this film. Why? You have Keira, Rosamund Pike, Jenna Malone & Brenda Blethyn, don't the girls need some eye candy?I can't really comment much on this, as it was average, perhaps reading the book, and seeing the previous versions might enlighten me a bit. It's understandable that for Keira and Matthew MacFadyen, it must have been difficult for them to step into their predecessors shoes, particularly the much-loved shoes of Colin Firth.There's an alternate ending, where Mr Darcy and Lizzie kiss, but it brings nothing to the film, except it was aimed at the US audiences. I feel us shivering in the UK got a better deal. The rest of the extras are alright, but not that outstanding.I've got my eye on the old version of Pride & Prejudice now, with Colin Firth. Should be interesting.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Books aren't often translated well into movies, but this is beautifully done.  As an English major, I'm always scared to go see one of my favorite books of all time in movie form, but this time I wasn't disappointed.  Firth is an amazing Darcy and Knightly does a beautiful job as Elizabeth.  They really bring the characters to life.  So next time you are looking for a movie to watch when you are having a girls night in, grab this.  This movie, along with some wine and chocolate, will make for the perfect night.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I highly recommend this dvd to anyone who has not seen this movie or anyone looking to add it to their own collection

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I heard that there was a new version of "Pride and Prejudice" to be made, I was far from pleased. In fact, I was fairly annoyed: A&E;'s version with Colin Firth has been a staple of my DVD collection for an incredibly long time, and I couldn't imagine anyone tampering with perfection. Why mess with genius?Happily, I was wrong in my estimation of the movie. Perhaps it's only appropriate, given the subject matter: the whole story of "Pride and Prejudice" is wrapped up in wrong estimations of character, miscommunications, and partial understandings. The Focus Features version of "Pride and Prejudice" is more of a classic Romance, set earlier in period and filmed against more stunning backdrops than the A&E; version: there were no grand cliffs or windswept heaths in that one, but they work here.The performances are universally excellent: I was appropriately annoyed by Brenda Blethyn's ludicrously inappropriate Mrs. Bennet, and Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourgh is one of the most delicious strokes of casting genius...ever. Donald Sutherland as the bemused patriarch Mr. Bennet holds his own in a largely British cast, and was suitably affectionately distracted in his fatherly role. Simon Woods is amiable and open-faced as Mr. Bingley, and properly deserves Rosamund Pike's delicate Jane.The movie belongs, however, to Matthew McFadyen and Keira Knightley, as it rightly should. The book, however involved its subplots, focused mainly on their sparring, and the film wisely excises a lot of the extraneous matter, tightening its focus and condensing some scenes. Matthew McFadyen is, possibly, an even better Mr. Darcy than Colin Firth (though that pains me to say): his Darcy is sensitive, prone to moodiness and shows of the Stiff Upper Lip, but his eyes don't always manage to keep up the mask, and it is this that makes him amazing. When his eyes do light up, it is stunning, because we have learned not to expect it. He positively smolders with passion, even soaking wet with pleading in his eyes. Or perhaps especially soaking wet. In any case, he smolders. Bosoms will heave, corsets or not, when he's onscreen.Watching Keira Knightley as Lizzie Bennet I was irresistibly reminded of another fiercely intelligent, wide-eyed brunette bookworm: Winona Ryder's Jo March, in 1994's exquisite "Little Women." Knightley conveys the same compelling blend of delicacy and strength as Ryder managed, no easy feat in this world of one-note romance, and one I wasn't sure she could manage, as I've never been a fan. Knightley does a good job, however: her Lizzie is a "fearsome creature," to quote herself, both fiercely loyal and heartily passionate for life, yet always with just a trace of vulnerability; one wonders, at times, if her passionate demeanour isn't as much a disguise as Darcy's cool mask. Perhaps that is what makes their inevitable but much-delayed romance so alluring: here are two people who absolutely should be in love with each other, but manage to think themselves out of it for a very long time.The world of the film is more realistically rural than other adaptations: the ladies' hems are dirty, their dresses are frequently wrinkled, and pigs traipse through the Bennet house as often as visitors do. There are some lovely little touches to the filmmaking as well, such as one scene featuring a distracted Mr. Darcy being circled, predator-like, by Lizzie and the coolly condescending Caroline Bingley; one absolutely feels sorry for the man. I particularly liked the dancing scenes: there is always something going on with someone familiar in the corner of the frame, lending the scenes a pleasant intimacy that suits the material nicely.Ultimately, I love this story so much because its romantic heroes deserve one another, even though they do not always realize it. Theirs is a relationship built not only on passion - although in this version, even more so than the seminal A&E; version, it is decidedly present, particularly in a post-wedding scene at Pemberley featuring (sigh!) a barefoot Mr. Darcy - but on mutual interests and a hearty respect for one another. When Lizzie and Darcy finally marry (as we know they must, long before they do) it is, to steal from Shakespeare (and another Jane Austen movie) a "marriage of true minds." And after all, what could be more romantic than a smart, handsome man in a cravat and a long, windblown coat?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I never write reviews, but after seeing this movie, felt compelled too.  This movie is absolutely lovely.  Keira and Matthew are brilliant, along with an excellent supporting cast, breath-taking country-side make this film definitely worth seeing. I too am a fan of Mr. Firth, but Mr. MacFadyen brings more emotional depth to the role.  There is one scene that makes me melt everytime and that scene is when Mr. Darcy first declares his love for Elizabeth in the pouring down rain.  Those piercing blue eyes, the emotion of the declaration that he's made, makes you feel the emotion.  Makes you believe in fairy tales.  See this movie, you won't regret it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I liked this movie well enough. It's a good version to watch if you're not looking for something terribly deep and like the book, but I would much sooner recommend the '95 BBC/A&E; version, with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. There is too much Hollywood in this version; too much is changed from Jane Austen's original wonderful book. For one thing, the scene in which Mr. Darcy first proposes takes place outside in the rain. That is much too cliched for my taste. And it is just an example of the many rather sickening modernizations in this version.It is not wholly unenjoyable. But it pales in comparison with the previously mentioned '95 version. Compared to the portrayal of the characters in that version, Elizabeth and Darcy and all the rest in this one are a bit shallow, and the original story has been rather disfigured and twisted in an attempt to make it more appealing to the masses (it doesn't work). And the chemistry in this one is not bad, but nothing to that between Firth and Ehle's Darcy and Elizabeth. I say, rent this, watch it, and then go out and buy the '95 version for real enjoyment.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: absolutely wonderful!!  i saw this film in theatres about 3 times, and would gladly pay to do so again!  i cannot say how thoroughly i enjoyed it, and how very delighted i was with the acting.  many critized Matthew Macfadyen's portrayal of Mr Darcy, but I thought it was really the most honest and accurate caricature. if you don't believe me, believe the NY times:"Matthew Macfadyen finds a human dimension in the taciturn landowner Fitzwilliam Darcy that was missing in earlier, more conventionally heroic portrayals. Mr. Firth might have been far more dashing, but Mr. Macfadyen's portrayal of the character as a shy, awkward suitor whose seeming arrogance camouflages insecurity and deep sensitivity is more realistic. Isolated by his wealth, ethical high-mindedness and fierce critical intelligence, Mr. Darcy is as stubborn in his idealism as Elizabeth is in hers. The disparity between his diffidence and her forthrightness makes the lovers' failure to connect more than a delaying tactic to keep the story churning forward; it's a touching tale of misread signals."it's worth it!!!  buy it, watch it, and love it!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just finished watching this DVD and I am so disappointed.  It is not only bad, it's boring.  The so-called "youthful take" on the story results in true tedium.There are a few films which, having been made, beg for the material to be retired because the film is so superlative.  Kenneth Branagh's Hamlet is one; the A&E; version of Pride and Prejudice is another.  Anyone truly wishing to experience a film version of Jane Austen's magnificent book should rent the A&E; version.  No one can hold a candle to Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth, especially these two twits in this movie.Let me say that I like Keira Knightley, just not here.  I can't fathom why she was given an Oscar nomination.  And Matthew MacFayden was painfully dull as Mr. Darchy.  He had one expression - sullen - throughout, and the switch to loving Elizabeth came totally out of left field.  I didn't believe it for a second.  The two had no chemistry.Then there are the period details which are woefully wrong.  The older women like Mrs. Bennet and Lady Catherine were dressed in fashions 20 years out of date, while the younger women appeared to be wearing "early American pioneer" clothes in half the scenes.  And what was up with everyone's hair?  Elizabeth runs around with her hair down, in town!  That NEVER would have happened.  Don't get me started on Judi Dench's hair.  Yikes.  And it appeared that none of the Bennets owned a comb. Also, I know the director was going for realism, but how many shots of muddy hemlines did we need?All in all, I have to wonder why Hollywood bothered.  Was Keira Knightley that keen on butchering the role of Elizabeth Bennett?  Have we really grown so stupid as a society that we require "Jane Austen for Dummies" versions of her books?  Or have our attention spans grown so short that people can neither read the book nor watch the 5+ hours of the miniseries?  If that's the case, than I am sad.  This film was a waste of time, of talent (Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn were underutilized), and of celluloid.  Do yourself a favor and skip it.
summary: Why bother with this film when you can do better?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a huge Jane Austin fan but felt even so this movie was done remarkably well and Keira Knightly gave a brilliant performance.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This book inspired me to create my own novel with 1800s pieces in it. I love the romance and the story. It is the best "Pride and Prejudice" I have ever watched, and it actually has a good looking Mr. Darcy in it. ^_^

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really feel it is unfair that so many people are comparing this movie to the excellent miniseries starring Collin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. You simply cannot fit the same amout of character development and plot detail in a 2+ hour movie that you can in a 5+ hour miniseries. And I think (shock) there are some things that this movie does better than the Firth version. One is (some of) the casting. For example I liked Mr. Collins, Charlotte Lucas, and Mrs. Bennett better in this version, because I think the actors were able to bring empathy for previously one-dimensional characters. Now I won't pretend to compare the lead actors between versions, but I don't think anyone disgraced themselves.Yes there were some things about this movie that were historically inaccurate or not faithful to the book, but again, you cannot fit all the content of a book into a film. Come on, people!! The one thing that really bugs me about this version is the final scene, with its chessy and un-Austen-like dialogue. But other than that, I think watching this film is a most enjoyable way to spend the afternoon. And it might even introduce more readers to Jane Austen who have been intimidated by previous versions. And that would be all to the good, certainly.
summary: My two cents on the ongoing debate

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a very good  movie.  The acting is wonderful, the story is engrossing.  And, of course, it has a happy ending.  The movie strays from Jane Austin's book in that the Elizabeth of the movie seems to be the one who is both proud and prejudice and Mr. Darcy is simply misunderstood.  In the book, Mr. Darcy has a significant pride issue and is not completely undeserving of Elizabeth's disdain.  If you are not very familiar with the book or if you can set foundational differences aside, the movie is very nicely done and enjoyable indeed.
summary: Great Movie, Unless You Love the Book

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although the filmmakers took a few liberties with Jane Austen's classic novel, Joe Wright's version of "Pride & Prejudice" is absolutely exquisite. I am a huge fan of the novel and I usually tend to get very uppity when anything about a book is altered for the big screen, but I ADORED this movie! It is absolute perfection. Keira Knightley is expertly cast as the fiery, headstrong Elizabeth Bennett, and I was blown away by Matthew Macfadyen's portrayal of Mr. Darcy. However, the entire cast is incredible. The film is also beautifully scored and the scenery is spectacular. "Pride & Prejudice" is a powerful and amazing love story, and I was in tears at the very end of the film because it is so incredibly emotional. BRAVO!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw an advanced screening of this film in Boston and was very pleased, it is intelligent in its handle of the material and its fluency in cinematic crafting. Goodbye to dusty, "precious" interpretations of Jane Austen. This cheeky, poetic, even dark new film makes the story youthful with down-to-earth vibrancy and worship of emotion. Here are young people making the mistakes and dreaming the dreams of the young (when it was written it wasn't antiquity, it was life). Lizzie is not a smirking omniscient but a quick witted independent; hotheaded and fiercely loyal to her sister. She is wary of an unfair world and uses her wits to survive. Darcy is not an impenetrable stoic but a shy sensitive soul with high unwieldy social pretensions fending off the outside world. And they are both lonely and have big yearning hearts, so the filmmakers made one great decision -- they let them fall in love the first moment they lock eyes. In a shot we see hearts behind fortified personalities and an instant chemistry that takes a movie's worth of battling with each other and themselves to right itself. It's an earthy move that sets the tone for a film about the people and world behind the antiquated manners, a world not so different from ours.Now set in 1797, when Austen wrote the first draft of the book, the filmmakers committed to main plot points and themes, and astutely represent the Romantic Age and Austen's characters.  The love between Jane and Lizzie is supreme and fuels a desire in Lizzie to tear at Darcy when he separates Jane from Mr. Bingley. She's hurt, she reciprocates the pain, and it is bitter.  Pride and prejudices are drawn clearly: Lizzie searches hard to find fault with Darcy, and Darcy cannot bring himself to let down his guard. Both have their reasons justified, but they foil their own chances at love constantly until they see how wrong they are and are too heartsick to keep going. Class conflict is suddenly personally injurious and vicious. When Charlotte Lucas marries for security, it's a grave matter and she must bitingly sober up a disdainful Lizzie on the realities of their world. The Bennets are too eccentric and improper for their own good. Lady Catherine (Dame Judi Dench, who is downright fearsome) is not just a cold figure for Lizzie to spar with, but someone capable of deeply hurting others. The filmmakers are savvy in their understanding of history. Setting it back 20 years is a remarkable move, because we accept more diversions and variation with the 18th century than the 19th and it presents Austen as a Romantic, which automatically requires the story to be interpreted from a different, very legitimate, perspective. The ideals of the Romantic Age are ingeniously, subtly played here: human equality, gritty realism married with beauty for the sake of beauty, but a beauty which is never elitist or decadent, always grounded, simple, and universal: nature, the human being, emotion.The ensemble and mis-en-scene are electric. The camera spryly edges in and out of rooms and conversations instead of sitting arthritically in a corner. The dance scenes are less about ballet, now rollicking and spirited as characters send signals, flirt, deflect and analyze one another. In true Romantic form (worthy of filling Wordsworth with pride) the aesthetic unabashedly revels in beauty, but always the simple joys of our world: sunrises, dewy landscapes in wide shots, colors everywhere. It has a lovely score, period inspired and without any pomp and circumastance. Simple blocking is caffeinated and given substance, something is always going on in the background. Lively, layered interactions between characters make rich scenes, neither wasting space nor time. Consider a scene with Mr. Collins, played by the magnificent Tom Hollander (a standout here, so delightfully weird. When he jaggedly squirms his way up to someone you want to shriek). He wants to speak to Lizzie, alone, and a bolt of fear strikes through her as she pleads in vain not to be abandoned. The sisters are merciless, Mrs. Bennet delighted, Mr. Bennet at a loss, and Collins prepares. It's all silent and it's hysterical.Suggesting variation to revered characters is a frightful task, but here it's a revelation. The entire cast is brilliant, but the two leads are transcendent in their roles. Keira Knightley is charismatic, random, wonderfully young, intuitive to the bone -- she inhabits Lizzie. Matt MacFadyen is deep, remarkably subtle, but mostly he is soulful. I've long held him as a sympathetic actor, but he shines in this.  The two instill an unexpected exuberance of feeling in their performances.  Neither ever acknowledge the camera exists and make the most of every second they have on screen to project their characters. When you throw them together you get a love story full of emotional subtext, double meaning, and gloriously heavy moments.Because so much dialogue was cut, simple lines have impact and much of the exposition is visual. Epic little moments linger and rain, revealing souls. The thoughts and intentions behind the actors' eyes and words are visible at all times.  This movie understands the power of a shot or glance. Lizzie comes to understand Darcy in how he embraces his sister or smiles (a momentous occasion, indeed). When she talks about love it's stirring because it's finally spilled into the open after we've seen it near the edge many times with half said sentiments and stifled tears. Usually "I love you" comes with extra explanatory prose, but here sincerity kills cliché: parties are fun, a misty field is breathtaking, the dawning of love a revelation, the heartbreak is throbbing.It's a brilliant film. There is something breathless and luminous about it, from its youth and the break from propriety, to the beauty and spontaneity of life and romance, pain and joy, which provide the color.
summary: Oft told tale made soulful, young

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I found every character, down to the smaller ones perfectly cast.I felt a real affection between all the family members.Donald Sutherland was superb. Keira Knightly showed a dignity without pursing her lips up the the the other Lizzie did.I never cared for the Colin Firth version, cute as he is in it, because they all seemed so prissy and their concerns trivial.These actors brought the story to life for me.And the way the camera moved from room to room,  showing the households small activities from the servant singing as she goes up the stairs to the parents in their bed to the girls giggling in their rooms. They employed the same ploy at the ball focausing not only on the leading characters but on small accurances of incidental characters. Brilliant! And the piano work and soundtrack! Magnificent!I've heard some comlain it is too "Wuthering Heights" but that is one of my favorites so ...  Hooray!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this story and I love this movie. My favorite version of all. This movie is very true to the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For a normal feature length film, I think this adaptation stays very true to the story.  There were a few things that I was sad to see change, like the personality of Mr. Wickham, and the more comic aspect of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett.  I do prefer the BBC adaptation a bit because you get the full story and you get more time to get to know Mr. Darcy and see the relationship develop.  But that version is much longer, and has a few less-than-outstanding actors.  If you're looking for a more concise bersion, this is wonderful.  The acting is superb and the original music is gorgous!  It you're a pianist, I highly recoomend the songbook also.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Very disappointing version of P&P. I felt that the actors were rushed in trying to portray an epic movie and there wasn't the fit seen with the previous actors. The only version that I have seen so far that was by far the most timely and consistent to the book was the BBC A&E 1995 version with Colin Firth and Elizabeth Ehle. Although one person wrote that the ages of the actors (Firth/Ehle) didn't seem to coincide with the characters due to their maturity, one must remember the time period in which Jane wrote. People were far more mature for their ages then they are today and I felt the two fit the maturity given of the times. Also the other characters just didn't fit right either. Given that movies tend to go long nowadays, they could have spent more time/length in this one.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just watched this version of P&P; with low expectations, having viewed the definitive BBC version at least 20 times, and assuming this one would fall far short. I was right... although I admit I did enjoy watching it. Cinematically, it is quite beautiful - there is no dearth of luscious landscapes, interesting camera work, and gorgeous people. (The two leads are, perhaps, a bit TOO good looking...) It certainly looks better than anything the BBC could come up with. But in all other respects, it's so inferior as to make comparisons pointless. The story is rushed to the point that major characters and plot points are glossed over, crises unfold and are resolved much too hastily, and personalities are not well developed. Macfaydan, while undeniably GORGEOUS, is no Mr. Darcy. He comes across as quiet, reserved, just there. There is none of the arrogance, the disdain, the contempt that makes the character initially so unlikable, and therefore his big "transformation" doesn't really occur. Knightly is not bad, but her Elizabeth isn't really fleshed out much, either. Her relationship with her sisters, her father, Mr. Wickham, all of these are barely developed. And the two leads don't share enough screen time together to even make their romance believable.This movie is purely for the casual viewer looking for a pretty, romantic period film. For lovers of Pride and Prejudice, the book or the miniseries, it's just another so-so version to add to the heap.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being a Jane Austen fan, and especially a pride and prejudice fan, I was not expecting this movie to be better than the one starring Colin Firth & Jennifer Ehle (which I own and love). In seeing it, I was supremely suprised how much this movie affected me. Me and my friend could not stop talking about the movie for the rest of the day, and I have been thinking of seeing it again in theaters since then. I loved Matthew MacFayden's Darcy, in particular. If it is possible, he made the character more like Darcy than anyone else has. The movie stuck close in dialogue and moved swiftly along, to get to the juicy parts that we all love (the first dance, fighting with Mr. Darcy, etc). My two favorite scenes, which are probably everyone else's are the fight between Mr. Darcy and Lizzie after she has refused him, and they freeze THISCLOSE to eachother, and you understand the passion that they are fighting against; and the scene in the meadow, while they are in their pajamas. I don't care, I am a romantic and this movie is awesome, aswesome awesome!!!! If I could give it more stars, I would...
summary: love it love it love it

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Like so many other people, I approached this film with trepidation because I dearly love the 1995 version and not just because of Colin Firth. Over the course of the months since this film's release, I'd heard vastly different reviews of the film and not inconsequential problems that Austen fans had with the movie. As I sat down to watch, I tried to forget what I'd heard, the 1995 version and tried to be as impartial as possible. However, it was very, very hard to forget the 1995 version.The good (the things that exceed the 1995 version):Rosamund Pike makes an excellent Jane. She's beautiful enough to fit the description of Jane being the most beautiful girl in Hertfordshire, something that Susannah Harker had been unable to do. She also gives some steel to a character that is frequently characterized as soft.The music is absolutely beautiful. It fits in so beautifully with the story. It rivals with Patrick Doyle's "Sense and Sensibility" soundtrack.The O.K. (things on par with the 1995 version)Brenda Blethyn gives a very different performance of Mrs. Bennett from the 1995 version. While wholly different, it is just as good and the character remains just as silly and endearing as ever.Simon Woods is a very good Mr. Bingley. He has the bumbling part down and clearly conveys his feelings for Jane. I particularly enjoy his work when his character says something rather off a nd must put it to rights.Judy Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourgh is wonderful casting. Dame Dench has played this role before and brings the same wonderful imperiousness.Tom Hollander, like Brenda Blethyn, was very different from his 1995 counterpart, but played the role of Mr. Collins admirably. I couldn't help but smile every time he came onto the screen  and laugh every time he mentioned Lady Catherine de Bourgh, Rosings, or made one of his funny little speeches.The Bad (the things that aren't as good as the 1995 version)The setting and costuming looked incredibly off. It seemed as if the people making this movie didn't realize that the Bennetts were pretty well off, as long as they had the estate, with 2,000 pounds a year. The overall appearance of everyone who was not a Bingley, Darcy, or de Bourgh left much to be desired.Keira Knightley is just not Elizabeth Bennett. Most of the movie she acted as if she knew she was remarkably clever, which didn't sit all that well.Matthew Macfadyen definitely does not fill Colin Firth's shoes. He lacks the ability to act with his eyes that helped Firth so much in the earlier version. He is too silent and dour for most of the movie and when he finally does perk up it is far too late.There is a lack of chemistry between the two leads which makes certain scenes like the first proposal scene seem entirely out of place. Any thoughts to attachment beforehand was created by the camera and not the 2 actors. Keira Knightley had more chemistry with Darcy's bust than Darcy himself.Jena Malone, Donald Sutherland, and Rupert Friend try admirably in their roles, but don't suceed. Jena Malone does act silly like Lydia, but with too much calculation. Donald Sutherland makes Mr. Bennett seem a very unfeeling man about anyone, including Elizabeth. Rupert Friend is far too young to be a contemporary of Matthew Macfadyen, plus far too young and eager looking for someone who had led a rake's life.After watching the film I came to the conclusion that I'd rather watch 2 hours of the 1995 adaptation than this film. With that said, the film does succeed as a period piece and as a film is certainly better than most film fare. I recommend it to the anyone excepting the most ardent admirers of Austen and the 1995 adaptation.
summary: Good as a movie, ok as a period piece, not all that great as an adaptation of Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Although I'm a huge fan of the Black and White PRide and Prejudice starring Greer Garson and Sir Laurence Olivier, I have to say that the the director did a great job in creating a cozy atmosphere centering the movie around the Bennett family while keeping the story true to the book. My sister and I have been huge Jane Austen fans since we were little girls and this movie has truly made it to our top favorite movies. A+++++

review_text: While I believe this version of Pride and Prejudice to be the finest ever made,I inadvertantly purchased the HD DVD which I soon learned would not play on my computer or any of my other players.
