title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Of course the blue-ray resolution and sound make this an excellent visual/auditory experience.  But I like the story line, and especially the cast.  They bring a particular time period to life before your very eyes, and the sexual tension and passion between the two main characters is "inspiring"!
summary: TAKE ME AWAY TO A SIMPLER TIME

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautiful movie, great way to show off your HD-DVD system. And Keira is not too shabby either. ;-)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie was well made, well shot, and well told.  Keira Knightley's performance was exceptional.  The score was also amazing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Elizabeth Bennett (Knightley) and Mr. Darcy (MacFadyen) do not impress each other in their first meeting.  In fact, they seem alltogether unimpressed with each other.  Circumstances continually force their paths to cross, and soon their opinions of each other begin to change.  Things are not happily ever after though, as marriage proposals interfere with their possible relationship, but if you know the story, you know how it ends.Yet another adaptation of Jane Austen's "Pride & Prejudice", and I am told that this is a pretty good one.  The story, however, did not hold my interest.  I am not a Jane Austen fan, and was probably doomed from the start to be disappointed.  Keira Knightley does a good job as Lizzie though, being both playful and vulnerable.  MacFayden, as Mr. Darcy, is uninspiring, but Darcy himself is kind of a jerk at times and I found him unlikeable.  This is a movie I would recommend for Jane Austen fans only.  I think they will enjoy the film, but others will not.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I bought this movie because I adored Kiera Knightly in Pirates of the Carribean.At the same time, I purchased the 1995 BBC mini-series. On watching the two back-to-back, there just is no comparison.  The 1995 version is simply wonderful with a great deal of depth.  Of course, you can get deeper in five hours than you can two!Watching the Kiera Knightly version, didn't peak my interest to actually read Pride & Prejudice, but the 1995 version did.I wish that more of Jane Austin had been used in this version of the movie.  Many changes were made to lines to appeal to a younger audience, but not for the better.  Jane Austin's are hard to improve upon.However, The cinematography was beautiful and I did like that Meryton was shown more the way that it might have been at the time.Overall, I found the movie cute and with no depth.  Good try, but if you have time go for the BBC mini-series version!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Amazing dialog.  Very close to the book.  Great acting.  Romantic.  Beautiful period piece.  A great movie for young girls to understand and appreciate how far we have come.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm not a romantic as in, everything ends Happily Forever After. This movie was down to earth with no modern "fairy-tales". This was modern and believable, with just a hint of modern day "reality." Love is never perfect,.love is earned, as in this gripping tale of daydream idealism and finally the forlorn love succumbed, to being, love is surreal,.live life elated, live prosperous, move forward! Aaaahhhwwe, if only.......

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie because of the time period and actors that played in this movie were spectacular.  Especially Mr. Darcy (Matthew Macfadyen ) is so.... handsome and distinquished gentlemen. I want my future husband to look and be this like him.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my absolute favorite movie and I have watched it dozens of times. I had to purchase it again, because I went to watch it one day and couldn't find my copy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have tried to see the other variations of this " Pride & Prejudice" movie to no avail.. I keep coming back to this version. It is just wonderful. It is something to say that I could actually see this movie every week and not get tired of it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of my all time favorite movies.  Sometimes I play it just for the music.  Tho, I wish it was full screen not wide screen.  Lent my widescreen one out and have yet to retrieve it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie; one of my favorites.  The quality of the dvd is poor.  It hesitates throughout the whole movie.  I have yet to return it (life has been very busy) but I intend to.  Because I haven't returned it yet, I cannot comment on customer service.
summary: Quality of the reproduction was poor...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I know, where have I been since I've never read a book by Jane Austen? I have watched a ton of movies based on her books, though, and this is probably my favorite, though I really enjoyed Sense and Sensibility also. The most impressive character was probably the hero, though. He was so stuffy and stoical at first, but as he felt more compelled to get to know the heroine and was drawn to her, he softened up quite a bit. It was aggravating how she doubted him so much, but I was delighted when she started to see that out of love he had helped her family numerous times to save their reputations, etc. Kiera did a great job once again, but I really love the guy who played Mr. Darcy. He was excellent!
summary: Really enjoyed the acting in this movie, but I've never read the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wow!  I am so glad I made this purchase.  I read this book in high school, or was assigned to do so, anyway.  High school to me was a blur and I don't remember a whole lot about it, including the details of this book.  I couldn't appreciate it then.  I picked the book up, again, about a year ago.  I loved it from the start and it got better and better, and it had a happy ending.  I'm not an avid reader but this book will always be one of my favorites.  It's classy, rich, and a must read.I shied away from watching this movie because I didn't want it to destroy the book like so many remakes of any kind sometimes do.  Well, my avoiding this movie was totally unnecessary.  This movie is fantastic!  It captured all the characters very well, in particular Elizabeth and Darcy.  I will say that whilst watching it for the first time and even at the end of the movie it felt rushed, but what do you expect from a two-hour movie based off of a 400 page novel.  It's just because I loved the book so that the movie seemed swift; I wanted every line of the book to be developed.  I can't tell you how many times I've watched this movie after having watched it the first time.  I love movies and it has become my new favorite.  As much as the book is a must-read, this movie is a must-see.  You need to own it.  You won't be disappointed.Long live the classics!
summary: One of the Best Movies of All-time

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I went to see this in the movie theater when it first came out, and I seriously was surrounded by a sea of grown women who were laughing out loud and hooting and hollering everytime Darcy was on the screen. It was hilarious, and what's better, my husband was laughing as loud in some parts along with the ladies!This isn't a purely chick flick-it has alot of funny parts that help men get over the Darcy factor and his power to turn grown women into goofy squealers. And the father-daughter connection between Lizzy and Papa Bennet brought tears to my husband's eyes.But make no bones about it-the power of Darcy lives on in the new guise of MAtthew Macfadyen, and he's adorable. I thought he was sorta ugly at the beginning of the movie actually, but by the end I let out a hoot or two myself! Macfadyen puts his own stamp on Darcy, Keira suprisingly didn't annoy me but came off quite LIzzy like, and this Mr. Collins really will leave you in stitches in some parts-he was a real audience pleaser.If you like a good romantic comedy that includes bonnie lasses wondering all over beautiful English locales, beautiful boys in thigh high boots and tight riding pants, and their repressed desires that entertain you, this movie is for you.
summary: The stuff that turns grown women into giggly teenagers

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautiful! Enchanting! I adore this version of a favorite story! I have watched it over and over and never tire of it. Highly recommended!
summary: This must be my all-time favorite!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While the A&E; version is delighfully over the top, this P&P; is darkly under the top. The main characters are too sweaty, too poor, and too coarse. I often wasn't sure if I was looking at servants or the gentry. Although historically accurate, dirt and sweat are more of a Dickens theme than an Austen. They don't accentuate the story, just make it more improbable.Jane looked the part, the mother was an interesting interpretation of the character, the father bordered on senility, Lizzy came across as an average girl and Darcy had deadpan eyes that made me as bored watching him as he seemed to be with his part.If the A&E; and this version of P&P; were put on opposite ends of a spectrum, the ideal would be somewhere in between. As it stands, watch the A&E; if you can spare the time and turn off this one after Darcy proposes and Lizzy accepts.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Mike J. Rice "'Mike Rice, Cultural Historian"
review_text: Pride and Prejudice has a fantasticallyfast-moving opening at an Upper MiddleClass social gathering and dance.  We'reintroduced to Mr. and Mrs. Bennett and theirfive daughters in the middle of things.The Bennet Daughters are there to capturehusbands like every sensible woman inlate 18th century England.  Thespirited dancing seems to ape theemotions of the Bennet girls asthey wander about.The dance features not the usualsnobbish Brits but rather a free-wheeling group of normal socialites reflectingthe carefree, not posh and not snobbishBennets, their five daughtersand assorted friends.Keira Knightley plays Elizabeth Bennet,Donald Sutherland her besieged, drollrather appalled father.  Mr. Bennet,as in the book, is called Mister evenby his daughters.  Every man is Mister.It makes the movie funnier  contrastingthe formality of  the Misters with theconvivial and fun-loving play of theBennet girls.Mrs. Bennet is a  shimmering pile ofunspent emotional fiery. The girls at anymoment, mother included, are likely tolose their heads at the sight ofa man with 5,000 a year.  That isif they're not having a joke at hisexpense at the time.At those moments, Mr. Bennent retreatsto his study, where he has a new plantto look at.Only Mrs. Bennet is a straight fortune-hunter.  The Bennet girls somehow have foundtime to understand genuine love, thoughMr. Bennet seems as unaware of this asMrs. Bennet.  Mr. Bennet seems to havesense you see.  How the girls learnedof true love is a mystery.Jane Austen's novel is set in apredatory England.  A man with 1,000pounds will stir interest.  A manwith 5,000 creates sheer excitement.Austen predates Dickens and the BronteSisters, but the Director has managedto include visuals lifted right fromthe heather of Wuthering Heights andhas placed Elizabeth in settings that justdo not exist in the somewhat hardscrabbleback yard of the lower middle class Bennets.There is an instance or two of an enormousboar in the house for instance.Elizabeth escapes home with a flock ofducks fluttering about, seeming toimitate her. The image is stolenfrom the thirties David Copperfield andcopied again with great effect inTom Jones.The only true snob in the film is MisterDarcy.  Poor Mister Darcy,he cannot bring himself to speak to mostwomen, considering them trivial.  Heboorishly connives to torpedo Elizabeth'ssister Mary's budding romance with thehandsome though high-haired Mr. Bingley.At the dance opening of the film, Elizabethfinds Darcy odd at first, then turns squarelyagainst him after encountering  hismore offensive traits. The audience knowsthat both are intrigued and Darcy may evenbe smitten.There is Mr. Collins, who, spotting Elizabethat the dance, immediately cocks his hat forher.  Only Lizzy is taller than he, his designson her seem more about money than love, andbesides, he and the film are moving too fast.There's room for one bounder in the shape ofMr. Wickham, who, it develops, knows and dislikesMr. Darcy as much as Elizabeth and tells herso.  A frame or two later he has run off withone of Elizabeth's sisters.  Mr. Collins toohas found matrimonial bliss in Elizabeth's friendwho confides to Elizabeth that she hasn'tattributes enough to wait for love to arriveat her door as Elizabeth has.The new Pride and Prejudice is certain to becompared with the 1995 BBC miniseries starring ColinFirth as Mr. Darcy and Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth.Keira Knightley, who ran away with the movieKing Arthur two years ago, owns this film too.  Un-like the miniseries, she doesn't really have toshare with this Mr. Darcy (Matt McFadyen).Knightley seems to be at once Audrey Hepburnand Winona Ryder.  Judy Dench, almost a necessitynow in every British period film, plays Darcy'shigh-handed and very rich aunt with her usual bombast.Some screen notes say actress Emma Thompson gavethis fast-paced screenplay a touchup that is  un-credited except in end credits.  I laughed moreat this film than I did at the '95 miniseries.I could hear all of Darcy's, Mr. Bennet's, and Elizabeth'slines, but the rest was sometimes too British to understand.Still, one could read body language just as well in manyscenes.  Director Joe Wright pushed the movie along ata torrid pace.  At times his camera moves in and out ofdoors and windows peering at the bewildering contrastsin attitudes of the many lovers and players in justseconds.I recommend that everyone see it.  Its very funny.When Mr. Bennett learns Elizabeth finally wants to wedMr. Darcy after all, he becomes teary when telling hisdaughter why, totally stealing the scene from Miss Knightley.Score one for Mister Bennet.Laurence Olivier and Greer Garson were Darcy and Elizabethin the first 1940 version. An Indian Directress who refilmedVanity Fair in 2004 put out a Bollywood version of Prideand Prejudice early this year.The present version, more than the miniseries, remindsthat Louisa May Alcott borrowed heavily from Austen's Prideand Prejudice to produce Little Women in 1869.  The two novelshave nearly the same structure.  Pride and Prejudiceis a first instance of Chick Lit written in English.Its a story of girls for girls and any male who wantsto learn a few things about them they hadn't known.
summary: Mr. Bennet's Daughters in Hot Pursuit,  their Father, Reserved

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: That's right-a farmer. Says it right there in the book. Pigs would be in the vicinity of his house! The pig wasn't IN his house either, and the movie was filmed on an ACTUAL house that was period-correct and accurate for man in Mr. Bennet's circumstances as a gentleman farmer. As someone mentioned earlier, did it BOTHER any of you when the '95 version showed no signs of a farm?This is a great movie. The people who play Lizzie and DArcy are the right age for the story, which I thought added greatly to the overall tone of the movie. Lizzie's and Darcy's actions make much more sense when you imagine them being 20 and 28, their ages in the novel. It's suppossed to be a story about young love and misunderstanding and missteps you make with that young love, and I think both Knightly and Macfadyen portrayed that brilliantly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay. I absolutely love the book and have read it more times than I should admit, and I love the miniseries which did a wonderful job at capturing the essence of the book, but this movie is just AWFUL. It leaves out detail after detail and rushes you from one event to the next never giving the viewer a full explanation or even time to form any opinions. The characters in the movie do not seem fully developed; they are like chess pieces being moved by a higher power without knowing its or their intention.Bottom line: this movie is a shell of the book. It should never have been made. And I feel the only people who can find true enjoyment in this adaptation are those who have never read Austen's masterpiece.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As someone who likes all kinds of movies, I thought that this selection would be a worthwhile watch. It was good. Save the last scene the BBC version remains #1.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The English literature gives us a new adaptation of Jane Austen's novel Pride and Prejudice, starring Keira Knightley and Matthew McFadyen.In the 18th century, the importance to achieve a good marriage was a fundamental pillar for the English society. For women, in particular, it was more than understandable that to live under that kind of pressure and social restrictions was a frustration, especially for the impetuous Elizabeth Bennet.Second among five sisters, Lizzie could be considered the rebel of the family, the Jo March of England, without a neurotic desire to be married for money or to be exposed to the agonizing rituals of traditional courting that was characteristic in that era.But when her matchmaker mother is aware that exists a remote but weak possibility to marry her older daughter Jane (Rosamund Pike) with a quite eligible bachelor (Simon Woods), Elizabeth trips accidentally with her match, the very observer, quiet, shy and taciturn Mr. Darcy (McFadyen).Darcy obviously sees Mrs. Bennet's intentions and driven by a sincere desire of protection keeps his friend from comitting to the lovely and shy Jane, while he and Elizabeth begin a turbulent relation of attraction and rejection, marked for his prejudice and her pride.One of the sharpest observations of Austen's novels is that the rich were used to judge the less prosperous for trying to assure a advantageous marriage, without realizing that they did exactly the same thing. Nowadays, this history of social acceptance, values, misundertandings and prejudices is as valid as it was in past times.The film had the joyous luck of counting with a terrific cast: from the childish sisters of Elizabeth, her shameless mother (a glorious Brenda Blethyn), the prepotent Lady Catherine (a magnificent Judi Dench) and Donald Sutherland as the absent minded and easy-going patriarch Bennet . Clearly, the stars of the history -Knightley and McFadyen- shine above this group. As Lizzie, Knightley is a bubbly mixture of passion, intelligence, defiance and vulnerability. Mr. Darcy, in turn, finds in McFadyen the perfect mixture of modesty, enigm, volatility, tenderness and dettachment, but simply with one look is capable of lettiing us see that his attitude is only a mask.Who is more proud or prejudiced? It's difficult to decide, since Lizzie and Darcy are so alike, and this is why the romance of these two is so provocative. Is clear that Elizabeth and Darcy are made for each other, and even thought neither of them will recognize it at first, theirs' is a soulmates encounter, and their relation is based on mutual respect, admiration, attraction and above all, a clear vision that love is a lot more than what some pretty words can express.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I ordered this shortly before Christmas and received it in three days.  It was in excellent condition.  I was very happy with the service I received and would highly recommend this seller.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a movie that you can watch over and over again and not get tired of. It's a classic. Keira Knightly and the rest of the cast did a wonderful job.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: from the comments that the Director  makes on the DVD it feels like he misunderstands the relationship between Jane and Elizabeth. I think he also fails to use the letters in the movie to their full extent.  In Jane Austens time as I understand it letters were a very important form of communication, especially when it came to intimacy and I think they have been waved aside in this movie.  The movie could have used the letters to emphasize intimacy between characters and I think that the Director completely misses out on this opportunity. The bonnets were also very important in Jane Austens time especially in terms of a lady's "natural and unblemished [freckle free] complexion" and  eligibility for marriage and yet the director dismisses the Bonnet as a cliché and uses it far less than needed. The Bennet sisters for example have already got strikes against them in terms of marriability why give them another one by refusing them a bonnet? The book also says that by the time that it was written any real affection that Mr. Bennet may have felt for Mrs. Bennet has long since died out.  The movie contradicts this. I also feel as though the Movie version of Mrs. Bennet cares more for her eldest daughters than is indicated in the book, and that she is a far more understanding and sensible woman in the movie than she is in the book and Darcy's objections to marrying Elizabeth therefore carry less weight than they do in the book because she is not as lacking in sense as she is in the book.  The last scene ended a bit abruptly for me.  This movie is based on a love story and I think that the kiss needs to have lasted longer and not been cut off so abruptly and waved away like it was. I am also a bit confused about the commentary about there being no make up available to ladies at this time as some websites indicate that something resembling make up did exist at this point in time. I did like the person who acted out Mr. Collins - very well done, most of the other actors too although I'm not sure about Mr. Bingley's "silly scene" (when Jane is sick) seems a bit out of character. I like Keirra Knightly, and the person who played Darcy. I think the movie could have done without some of the nature scenes.  A bit disappointing really.
summary: Good acting, but misinterpreted. lacks a little in understanding of Jane Austens world.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Nice movie of times gone by. Acting was really good.. Entertaining. Music was too loud in some scenes when they were talking.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a great movie. Have been wanting to watch it for a long time. Keira Knightley is awesome as always. Highly recommend.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'll start by saying, I am no Kiera Knightly fan so I was reluctant to watch it, but under some insistant urging I gave it a try.  Was I surprised.  I was able to overlook Knightly as the lead character because she was actually good!  Matthew Macfayden's Mr Darcy was a very romantic hero.  His blue eyes are incredibly expressive.  The scene where Elizabeth and Darcy are in the rain arguing and suddenly discover their attraction, is great!....I don't know if I would of had the strength to hold back, Mr Darcy is too delicious.  Anyway, this is an impressive watch!  Let's hear how many dry eyes there are when Mr Darcy finally decides to claim Elizabeth toward the end of the movie...oh my goodness, well done!  So grab a glass of wine, your favorite blanket, maybe a box of tissue, and enjoy the show.  Highly recommend!

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Miss A.E. "(College Student and Austen Geek)"
review_text: It might be that I'm a purist, but I felt that there were a lot of things about this adaptation that were just WRONG. When I first saw it, I was determined to give it a fair chance- I came in knowing that there was probably a lot that they would have to cut out so that it would not be 5 or 6 hours long, but I did not expect some of the strange things that they added instead.Elizabeth Bennet just didn't seem right to me- she didn't have nearly as much sweetness as was needed to balance out her "archness". To me, she came off not so much clever and lively as having a 21st century bad attitude.As for Darcy, I was happy that he was a little more sympathetic than he had been portrayed as in the A&E; version, but they also took out so much of his arrogance and pride that it makes you wonder why he was so universally disliked in the first place! Besides this, the second proposal and the final "goddess divine" scene seemed like it was taken straight out of some cheap Romance novel.However, so that I do not seem so incredibly negative, I might also mention that there were some things that I did like quite a lot. The music and the cinematography was beautiful, and some of the secondary characters were just about right- Mr. Collins and Lady Catherine especially, barring the odd scene when Lady C. comes to the Bennets' house in the middle of the night.All in all, it was a pretty good movie- it just wasn't Austen.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie quality was very good. Packaging was in tact, and I enjoyed the movie. Yay. It came in a timely manner.I think it was a great purchase and very happpy with it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must confess to being one of the many doubters, who wondered aloud when the trailers for this P & P came out, Do we need another one? At the time my answer was: We Don't.  After finally viewing it, my opinion remains unchanged.  And it isn't just that the BBC version got it so right that we can't get over it.  It's a lot more: No doubt, there are moments of beautiful film captured here.  But the screenplay, which squeezes the book into just over two hours -- is botched, terribly so.  We know from other Jane Austen films that it is NOT impossible to capture the essence of the novel in a short time frame (when in doubt, please consult Emma Thompson!); nothing close to coherence happens in this film, as anyone who has read the novel and watched it can attest.  Those familiar with the novel will see immediately where scenes have been combined, re-arranged, or re-imagined entirely, often to bizarre effect.  Those who haven't read the novel will be utterly confused.  One explanation will suffice: Wickham's character is not sufficiently developed to make it clear why he departs, and why Elizabeth is so upset when Lydia elopes with him.  All of the important context for this storyline is dropped.  The random modernizing of language serves no purpose that I can find -- either leave Austen's beautiful language alone, or modernize entirely, and update the time as well, whereby Emma becomes "Clueless."  As to characterization, I find no evidence of Lizzy's and Mr Bennet's wonderful relationship (in fact, Donald Sutherland looks bored), I don't see much chemistry between Elizabeth and Darcy, or much chemistry between anyone for that matter.  Costumes are not period appropriate, which again would be fine, if there was some coherence to the choices that were made.  And why is everyone's hair wild and ukepmt?  Finally, I am told that the Bennet's "status reduction" -- whereby Longborn is made to look poorer than the novel suggests -- was done to draw a clearer distinction between Elizabeth's and Darcy's status.  This was hardly necessary, and random flights of geese, chickens and pigs all over the place is completely annoying.  The entire film feels rushed and perfunctory, like the cast is haunted by the ghosts of prior versions, even before the camera starts rolling, and says "Let's just get on with it."  Jane Austen -- and her fans -- deserve better.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yawn. While remaining more or less true to the original, I found the performances and as well as the script of this latest version of Pride and Prejudice lacking. It seemed to move at a snail's pace and I had to keep bumping up the volume to catch the dialogue. The characterizations were lackluster and the performances uninspired.Save your money and buy the BBC version. It's far superior to this one in every way--and even at four hours long, it moves faster than this one.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: i loved this movie! the soundtrack is great, too.  i may be the only one who thinks it is better than A&E's.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is still one of my favorite movies.  The beautiful scenes and performance of the memorable and distinct characters made this movie endearing.  A wonderful story!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am kind of an Austen Purist.I watched this movie trying to be open minded, and if possible, to view it as a separate entity from the book. It didn't really work.As a romantic comedy, it would pass, but as an adaption of Pride Prejudice, it falls rather flat. First of all, the casting is rather week in most areas. Keira Knightly does a tolerable job as Elizabeth, but one can't help but be disappointed in what seems like a lack of depth to her character. Mathew McFadyen doesn't really seem to be acting at all and merely looks morose a lot of the time. Lady Catherine Debourgh (sp) is well cast in  Judie Dench, as is the actress who plays Charlotte Lucas. But that is about as far as it goes.Nearly all of the priceless quotes and speeches that readers love so well are cut out, and by condensing the storyline to two hours, you have very little development of any relationship between Darcy and Elizabeth. The Pemberly scenes are very choppy and all of the beautiful scenes between Darcy and Elizabeth are non existent. The ending is quite week and is a total departure from the book. Add to all of this that her family is all portrayed as a listening behind the door, giggling all of the time group of idiots, without the exception of Jane, or her father, who are supposed to be a great deal more sensible than the rest of her family.Finally, it just didn't really feel period accurate to me. The costumes seemed to vary, and looked as if they were assembled from more than one century,while the sets seemed incomplete and rather empty for the most part.For anyone looking for a faithful adaption of the book, with tremendous actors and amazing quality, watch the BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.
summary: A fairly Poor Adaption of P&P

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Got in a good amount of time. Wasn't told it was only for HD DVD's but that's okay.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The first time I saw the movie trailer for p&p, I thought it would be a fun romantic to go and see. I didn't realize it would be the most romantic movie I have yet to see (from the exception of 'The notebook'). I thought it was beautifully directed, full of wistfullness and anticipation. Keira Knightley has been a favorite of mine for some time, and now I know why. She made an excellent Elizabeth and I felt the warmth for her sisters, the embarrassment  for her mother, and the love for Mr. Darcy. Matthew Macfadyen did a wonderful job of playing the king of romance, Mr. Darcy himself. Never hearing of this actor before, I caught my breath when I first saw him walking to the back of the assembly with Mr. Bingley and his sister, full of resentment for being there and looking down on everyone else, you can't help but be curious about a character as such. Seeing the two fall in love felt like watching something that should be kept private and cherished and to view such a sight felt like an honor. At the end of the movie I cried and smiled and walked out hating men for knowing there will never be anything like a Mr. Darcy or a Mr. Bingley in this lifetime. It is a movie where I went out the next day and bought the book (never having read it before), memorized it, and went and saw the movie again. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD, for I will be one of the first in line. I hope, for today's society sake, on their view of what romance is, and what it ought to be, that everybody go and watch this movie at least once. For I know I have seen it several times since it has hit theaters.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Miz Ellen "all the letters of my real name"
review_text: Jane Austen wrote six of the most sparkling novels ever penned and adapting them to the movies is hard because fans of Austen are passionate, literate and critical and can recite whole chunks of dialog from the novels the same way fans of Monty Python can do the lumberjack song.  And Pride and Prejudice is probably her best loved and most frequently dramatized work.This is the best adaption I have seen.  It is true in spirit and in sense to the original. The visual adaption of the novel is done with lyric beauty, gritty attention to detail and an eye for symbolic clues to the properly restrained feelings of the protagonists.  The scene where Elizabeth wanders through the nearly naked statuary of Pemberly is pure genius as if the artwork is showing us her secret attraction for Darcy.  So much fun--such chic chick-lit!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My favorite version of my favorite novel remains the Colin Firth/Jennifer Ehle version because it follows the book, for the most part, in spirit, manners et al.  The acting, in my mind, could not have been better in that version, especially in the casting of those who played the Bennetts senior - Mr and Mrs., Mr. Collins, Lady Catherine De Bourgh and others.  While I very much like Keira Knightley in other things she's done and I think she does well enough capturing the spirit of Lizzie here (and I very much like the actress here who plays her friend, Charlotte Lucas), I think the way the director and screenwriter strove for naturalism in this version made the Bennetts and their house and grounds in particular, as one other reviewer here has described it, too frumpy and dumpy for what one would expect from what Lizzie describes herself as being a 'gentlemen's daughter.'  There is almost a total LACK of gentility and manners in this Bennett clan - forget impropriety - we've gone way overboard.  Keira Knightley's hair, while more 'sexy' looking as modern standards of beauty go, would have been considered quite unkempt and wild when she goes to Bingley's to visit Jane in this version.  Her skirt is '6 inches deep in mud' but otherwise we can assume Lizzie had some idea of the proprieties, otherwise Darcy would not have exempted her and Jane from his condemnation of the rest of the family for not always following social mores/conduct/propriety.  While the scene with Darcy walking across the field with his shirt open is romantic, it's not in the book and seemingly out of character with the Darcy Austen wrote.  I loved Colin Firth's Darcy, and I also loved Greer Garson and Lawrence Olivier's portrayals.  Knightley and MacFayden do ok - I just term this version the Fabio version of the book.
summary: a different take on the Austen classic

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a sucker for romantic movies.  This is definietly a love story to die for.  I though Keira Knightley played the part well.  But there were moments where i would have been, "Freak you Mr. Darcy!"  She's a great actress, and i thought the moive went a little slow but i think it's meant to be like that really.  The environment was beautiful, the music is absoluely perfect,and.... eveything went well!  The ending was perfect, but i felt it was rushed.  The second time i watched it though, the overall moive went faster and the ending went slower.  Sigh... I want to be Mrs. Darcy...  "You bewitched me, mind, body and soul..."

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I dared watch this movie on DVD with my wife, because my brother assured me it is awesome, despite being a girly movie.  Lo! and behold!  It is not a girly movie, but a work of literature accessible to everyone transferred to the screen with emotion and beauty!!  Wow!!The next day after viewing it, I logged onto my email, and was about to delete all the advertisement emails I regularly get from amazon and other companies without looking at them as usual, when my finger halted, and I then unchecked the box next to an amazon ad saying "new blu-ray releases," thinking to myself, "just in case Pride and Prejudice came out on blu-ray."  I opened that message, and there it was - a sign from heaven.  I purchased it as fast as my finger could click, and watched it again as soon as it arrived two days later!Very convincing acting, beautiful set design and very entertaining story!  Fantastic!Only negative aspect of the blu-ray compared to DVD: title screen is ridiculous mechanized console with ludicrous sound effects -- very opposite the atmosphere of the movie.  Hurry and push play to see as little of the menu as possible.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Maybe I shouldn't be writing a review - after all, I only made it through perhaps the first 20 minutes of this film.  If you have seen the BBC miniseries (as I have), or read the book (likewise), this can be nothing but a disappointment.  I really don't know how it couldn't be.  The movie rushes through the story and I don't know how anyone could follow it.  With the exception of Mr. Darcy (no one could ever be sexier in the role than Colin Firth), the actors here are better looking than in the BBC production, but in the end, who cares?  It's just not worth it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Almost watched it just once but frankly it was only after the second viewing that all of the humor, rich scenes, and depth of the characters really impacted me. Now I'm still enjoying it and still getting something new from each viewing. Haven't seen that kind of quality in a film for a LONG TIME. Had to own it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: For Devotees of the 1995 miniseries who have disected, and can recite the entire thing ... this movie will annoy you slightly, but at the same time it will be a breath of fresh air.  I f you just can't get enough P&P, you will enjoy the new scenery and different take on several of the scenes.  What will annoy you is the much weaker, and more bland actors.  With the exception of Kiera Knightly, who in my opinion carries the entire movie, the actors are altogether less outrageous and entertaining than those in the 95 version.  Being that the novel is a study of human folly, the 95 cast brings humor and outlandish behavior to life, as they were meant to.  In this new film, they are just dull by comparison.  Aside from that, this latest version of the classic novel, has a much more lush and interesting setting, and Kiera Knightly is outstanding as Elizabeth, bringing her own witty and fresh flavor to a heroin that everybody knows and loves. All in all I found the movie to be worth my while, as a new way to experience one of my favorites.
summary: A new perspective for 1995 P&P adicts

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie! It is beautifully acted and filmed and the musical score is wonderful. Yes, it is hard to portray the story in only two hours which leads to a fast pace and changes not completely true to the book. I will admit that until I saw this movie, I had never read Pride and Prejudice or seen any previous film adaptations. I have now read the book and watched previous films and become a Jane Austen fan. Great influence from a movie. Matthew Macfayden is a wonderful, very believable Mr Darcy and Keira Knightley is my most favorite Elizabeth.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It feels like I have owned the BBC version since the beginning. I had it on VHS and I now have it on DVD. I've watched it countless times. Since I am a fan of Jane Austen and the film representations of her work, I try to see as many versions as possible. I may be partial to the BBC version, Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle make me feel like I am truly experiencing Miss Austen's book in real life. Very touching and believable performances.Kiera Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen, on the other hand, have no chemistry and it feels like they are carrying their lines without feeling. Kiera spews out her lines as if she had practiced a thousand times and it was just a job to her. Although I liked her delivery of the dialog when she turns down his proposal, her acting is still not as heartfelt as I would like to see it in this character. Not a convincing passion in her performance.In contrast, Macfadyen is such a cardboard figure without expression that I could not feel anything for him or from him. Especially in comparison to the Firth version who had such a way with that slowly surfacing compassion -- his eyes told the story. He didn't have to say much, but you could tell his heart was touched. Macfadyen's character is a wimp. He has no strength or purpose. Knightley's performance, though still a notch below excellence, steals the stage so to speak and overshadows Macfadyen. This Mr. Darcy needed to show that he was a man of means and true pride. I didn't see that here.Also, it felt like the movie was cut short or chopped to pieces. It was missing some good scenes and scene transitions. I enjoyed the way the Bennet household was portrayed, it appeared closer to the "middle-class" of the times. I was pleased with most of the other cast performances. Too bad the leading couple did not "feel" like a couple.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is usually thought of as a chick flick, but I have to admit that I, a guy, enjoyed it.  There is a lot of very funny and subtle humor that carries over from the original book (a great read).  Bingley and Darcy are very well cast.  Lizzy (Keira Knightly) is way too cute (the book says her strength is her mind, not her looks), but Keira plays it to near-perfection.  There are long dramatic pauses that are unnecessary, and the time would have been better spent on including more of the original storyline.  If you like action, fights, car chases and bathroom humor, try a different movie.  If you can appreciate subtle humor and dialog, you'll enjoy this.
summary: Pretty good adaptation of the book

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film is hands down one of the few most visually and audibly beautiful films I have ever seen.  I watch it over and over and it is almost as if the director uses the natural beauty, power and passion of the landscapes to evoke the emotion of the scenes.  For me, the environment becomes an active feature in the film and I find myself aware of it, not in a distracting but a fulfilling way, throughout.  The proposal in the rain is full of the vital, intense, and overcast nature of each character's emotional state. Very passionate! The scene where Elizabeth meets Darcy at dawn after she realizes she is in love with him is exquisite; the dawn, a perfect time to place her revelation, he walking through the mist with coattails flapping and dressed down to meet her as an equal, the sun rising between their faces as they bring their heads together--just incredibly beautiful.  This film brings together all the artistic collaborators equally, expanding the power, effectiveness and aesthetic beauty of each scene. A work of art.If only the world's political systems could collaborate this way.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I adore this movie (and book). As for getting it on instant watch...quality was great. No sudden pauses for buffering or anything. Very happy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's hard to be better than the BBC version of Pride & Prejudice (the one with Colin Firth)...but this one is still good. There is less chemistry between the two characters in this version but the rain scene is great! The music isn't as good...it reminds me of some kind of river-dance music stomp music instead of English waltz/ball music and is distracting from what was going on at the ball. I also don't quite get why they tried to make Mr. Bingley hideous?!! His hair is teased in this film & he looks really weird! I also think they made the family look too poor in this one with not even a servant which I think is unlikely. Still a pretty good movie but it doesn't surpass the sparks that fly in the BBC version!
summary: Not my favorite version but still good

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I think I watched it ten times in a row; it's that kind of movie. What a fantastic job done by the director and stunning cinematography. The music is some of the best I've ever heard. The acting was incredible! The scenery was amazing! You get sucked right in and never want to leave. I didn't think they could pull off a two hour version but it was so wonderful. I do wish it had been 30 minuets longer so we could see more interaction between Elizabeth and Darcy. But this version gets the point across with such passion it makes you want to melt. I think the casting was great, I especially liked Rosamund Pike and Mathew Macfadyen. I'm not a big fan of Knightley, but it was great casting she did well and I liked her in it. I think Brenda Blethyn cast as the mother was a bit annoying but maybe that was their point. I don't understand why all the book nuts say it has to sick by the book word for word. This is such an entertaining film and I think Jane Austen her self would have really enjoyed it.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've never read the book, never seen the BBC version, never even knew what the movie was about.  It was one of those books they order you to read in high school, but just like Moby Dick and Huckleberry Finn, I skipped that assignment.I saw previews for this movie on TV and had no interest in watching it.  I'm really not into movies set in old times and I'm not a Keira Knightley fan either.  However, one day I happened to flip through the channels and before I knew what the movie was, I was hooked.  Really, one scene is all it took.I watched the remainder of the movie and set my DVR to record the whole thing next time it was on.The story is great.  The acting is great.  The scenery is great.  I've never really liked Knightley, but after seeing this movie, I certainly have respect for her.  She was great in this movie.  I can't think of a single character in the movie that wasn't played well by the actor/actress.  You knew what they were feeling even when they didn't speak.  Matthew McFayden was also amazing in this movie. I had never even heard of him, but he didn't make one false move in this film!Although there were a few things that didn't seem 'quite right', this is still an excellent movie.  It never gets boring, and although you know what's going to happen in the end, it doesn't matter because the story up to the end is just so good, and the ending is awesomely played.I really thought I wouldn't like this movie, and now it's probably my second favorite of all time.  My first is "Office Space".  I know...totally different genres.  Like I said, I didn't think I'd like this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was happy last year because I found Pride & Prejudice.I watched the DVD over 20 times and still counting...The first disk became damaged so I had to buy another one and now it's failing...I'm listening to the music CD almost every day...I read the book for the first time and am reading it once again...(No, I'm not a native English speaker.)I read all the customer reviews of US and UK Amazon.com.I bought and watched the 10th Anniversary BBC series.I even got the 1940 version with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier.Yet, the first impression was the strongest and it's never fading away.We all are biased to our first impression.It's Austen power, but director Wright, composer Marianelli, and stars Keira Knightley and Mattew MacFadyen did a wonderful job, too.They made my life-time favorite movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Everything about this adaptation was wrong, wrong, wrong!!  But the worst part of it was the casting of Keira Knightley as Eliza Bennett!  What were they thinking!?  All Ms. Knightley could do in her role as Eliza was snarl, giggle or make herself so totally obnoxious that I couldn't watch the movie in its entirety.  Elizabeth Bennett was a high-spirited, witty and warm LADY and Knightley's interpretation was anything but lady-like! Don't waste your time with this version of P&P - watch the Elizabeth Garvie/David Rintoul adaptation.  It's true to the book and would've made Jane Austen proud.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version was VERY condensed. In attempting to fit so much into just 2 hrs, I was left with way too many questions. Had I not already seen the MUCH superior version with Firth and Ehle, I would not have been able to connect some of the scenes that moved at lightening speed. Donald Sutherland was a poor choice for Mr. Bennet and the characterizations of Kitty and Lydia were annoying, to say the least. The rest of the cast was good but there was not enough time for the proper character development of so many individuals within the 2 hour time frame. They were left lacking in depth and scenes were rushed and poorly portrayed. For example, when Elizabeth receives the two letters from Jane, she walks around in circles through two doorways and repeats herself. It appears more like a scene retake or 'blooper' than anything else. Mr. Darcy appears rather shallow and immature, as compared to Colin Firth's version, because his emotions alter too rapidly, Jane has no personality whatsoever, she is hardly memorable and Elizabeth shows none of the grace and intelligence Ehle portrayed in the BBC production...AND why does everyone look as though they have dirty hair???

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie drew me in, I was amazed. I was amazed at how ironically unpretentious it was, and I was impressed with the casting and direction. Excellent movie all around for all you romantics out there, and you know who you are.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There are two very fine adaptations of Pride & Prejudice already, the first the 1940 Hollywood version with a script by Aldous Huxley (of Brave New World) starring Laurence Olivier as the definitive Darcy.  The second is the recent BBC miniseries starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth.  Both preserved the wit and verve of the source.  This version has the audacity to try to rewrite Austen's dialogue as if to improve upon the original.  The results are downright cheesy, and worse, boring.  The costumes and sets look cheap, the characters are unsympathetic, and the performances are at best one-note, at worst colorless.  Keira Knightley is posing for a fashion spread, but she's not acting.  Don't bother.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The cinematography, the dialogue, the plot - as a Pride and Prejudice fan, this is the movie I watch when I need a quick fix.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First of all, I should say that I am an avid Jane Austen fan. I think she is one of the greatest authors in the English language. Making a film of this story is a privilege because of the material in the book. I loved the previous two adaptations made in Britain by the BBC, the last one from 1995 being exceptionally good. Colin Firth and Ms. Ehle were outstanding in these roles and apparently lived and breathed Darcy and Elizabeth for a whole summer. This latest adaptation doesn't even come close to the standards in the BBC version. It seemed as though this version tried to be different from the 1995 version, and failed as a result because this required a departure from the book.I found the acting surprisingly awful. Mr. Darcy in the 2005 adaptation lacked conviction, and seemed to be bored with the role he was supposed to be playing, when he wasn't trying to stay awake. Colin Firth was far more convincing. The other characters were almost as bad, including Ms. Knightley. The silly 20th Century smirks and childish behaviour, just didn't translate to the period of time that the book deals with. Jane Austen's great lines and dialogue were replaced with many 21st Century lines which although at times funny, didn't fit with the period. I do not understand why the Bennet family was made to appear very rural and poor. They were not poor in the book, but quite well to do. Like Shakespeare such modern adaptations can work, but this one was difficult to fathom. I look forward to seeing another Pride & Prejudice adaptation, but the 1995 version is the gold standard to which they will need to be compared, and not this version.Some positive points:Great CD with wonderful music. I loved it.Great packaging and extra materials.
summary: Disappointing Adaptation of Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I too have been predisposed to dislike this hack-job of a story, and it did feel a bit uncomfortable to swallow.  Having watched the BBC version of P&P, I felt as though I were being chased through an enormous theme park, with colors and music (a bit too orchestrated IMO) and what felt like scenes being changed quickly just to give us a scent of what it felt like to live in that time.  All that said, the last minutes of the film more than made up for the condensed montage preceding it. Darcy's delivery of the note was, IMO, more romantic that the BBC version, the following early morning's meeting , along with the concent scenes made it truly worth the while.  If you watch the BBC version, you'll know what I mean.  BBC = two dimensions, New version = three dimensions (in feeling).  And sure, read the book.  I just got done watching Bleak House and have begun trying to read the Charles Dickens book (over 800 pages, no less)...and that might take me all year to get motivated to finish it.
summary: The latter part of the film made it worth watching

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After I borrowed this movie from my mom's house I dreaded putting it in. I thought it was going to be a long, drawn out & boring old-time flick about snobby people gossiping about each other. I was PLEASANTLY surprised. It caught my attention from beginning to end. The characters were SO likable. Yes, even the two-faced snobby rich sister, annoying mother & giddy younger sisters! They bugged me but made the movie that much more enjoyable. It was very nice how the script was able to portray the way of life back then. Although the Bennets lived in what we consider a huge house they were considered penniless. 5,000 pounds a year was considered rich. Trying to marry off your daughters to the wealthiest man possible was a goal a mother must bear (at least THIS one).I try to avoid watching Donald Sutherland movies as much as possible. He does so much better with villain roles than good-guy ones. Other than the failed attempt to an English accent, I really couldn't help liking his character in this movie very much. In fact, he was one of my favorites throughout the movie. Especially after he contradicted his wife when choosing sides w/Elizabeth in rejecting Mr. Collins' proposal of marriage.Personally, I don't think Knightley is the hottest fox out there but it fits her role of "nearly tolerable". Yeah, the lips have always bugged me but I looked past that because she's been great in all the roles I've seen her in. What I found most surprising was when Mr. Darcy first appeared, I had wished they'd picked a more handsome actor. His presentation of the role made him out to be SO irresistible and handsome. I loved the rain-scene the best. You were able to see his big blue eyes & he looked sexiest there.All in all, this was a very passionate & romantic movie. It was innocent enough to let young girls watch. Elizabeth Bennet was an intelligent character & a rather good role model for younger audiences. I put this movie up next to the Anne of Green Gables mini-series. Definitely not as wonderful but comparable in values & good storyline.
summary: GREAT!  I watched it twice in a row!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is simply the finest work from Kiera Nightley to date. It proves she is a serious and talented actress. Couple that with an excellent script, cast and OUTSTANDING HD DVD transfer and you have a fine addition to your collection. Buy it!
summary: First rate movie and HD treatment

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Ok, so it's not Colin Firth in the BBC miniseries, but it's still a great movie, I enjoyed every minute of it.It's a beautiful movie in every aspect.  The scenery is absolutely amazing, and when it is put together with the music like it is, the result is breathtaking.  Keira Knightley and MacFadyen are great, and there's great chemistry between the two, and it's all very innocent and pure, which is a nice change.The supporting cast is also amazing, making the movie even better.It's not a slow movie, as in you won't be bored out of your mind at any time, it has a nice pace to it.  But it is slow in the way that it takes its time and it's not hectic in any way, which is exactly how it should be. I think the word to describe the pace would be "relaxing".You'll laugh, cry, smile, it's a beautiful emotional ride, with beautiful music to accompany you through the journey.It might truly be the greatest love story of all time.This movie is a pure gem, and one of the best I've seen.
summary: It truly is the greatest love story of all time.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is so beautifully done! I first watched this only last year and I have fallen in love with the story ever since. I have seen other mini series and films of Pride and Prejudice, and this one is by far THE best! The cast is so beautifully done! title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I didn't really expect much from this movie but was greatly surprised. I did feel the Jane Austen vibe and think she probably would have enjoyed to watch it herself. The Colin Firth version of this book is just as good, only different. Like people have said, this movie does have a more modern twist to the classic Austen novel. But I don't think that the movie is bad, actually, I think it was done very well.The little artistic screen shots presented throughout the entire movie made it appear less "finished" and glossed-over, as in most mainstream movies. The scenery was beautiful and I would LOVE to visit everywhere that was shown.The characters were wonderful and I loved how they actually appeared to be family. Mr. Darcy's character was just as I had pictured him from the novel and although some say the movie caused him to appear pathetically shy, I wonder if Austen had not intended him to be so in her novel? Someone shy can also still have pride, maybe even more so. His pride against the happiness that still came with the inferiority of Lizzie and her family's life? Or pride against having someone not grovel and actually intellectually argue with him? Or whatever...I have watched this movie several times and plan to watch it again. Every time, I find something new that I had not heard nor seen before. Don't expect a movie straight from the novel, but expect a movie that respectably modernizes one of the best books ever.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a fan of Jane Austin's books, Pride and Prejudice being one of my favorites. This movie followed the story very well and maintained a great Jane Austin feeling.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Pride and Prejudice.  It is one of my favourite books and I must have read it at leat 10 times (so far!!!).  The BBC adaptation was just perfect.  This film was just neither here nor there.  I hated the drab set I don't know where they got the idea of the wandering pigs and geese, the Bennets lived on an estate not a farm.  and they were gentle folks not farmers.. their future problems would have stemmed from the estate being entailed after Mr Bennets death not from poverty during his life.  Keira Knghtely was just plain silly and McFadden just a sulk not a proud man.  I hate adaptations that think they know better than original creator... if you don't like Ms Austen's handiwork.. just go ahead and make your own.. just don't call it Pride & Prejudice!!..  Give me the BBC version any time!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: OMG if I have to sit and watch this movie just one more time, I think my head will explode.  I'm not allowed to talk or even breathe during certain parts of the movie the wife loves.  I bought this set to replace the one she originally had that got ruined.  The wife absolutely without a doubt loves this movie and the music.  She blasts the TV while watching it.  She will even sit and watch it again and again each time it finishes.  The wife now has 4 different versions of this story on disc, this version of the movie, the original and 2 different BBC versions and she will watch them all back to back.It keeps her quiet.  Earplugs are a man's best friend.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I actually avoided this movie while in theatres due to my undying loyalty to the 1996 BBC version with Colin Firth. Well, my friends, this is not exactly better, but breathtaking, extremely well written, directed & produced. And if you think/thought Matthew MacFayden is no Colin Firth...  just watch it.  He says more with his beautiful blue eyes and facial expressions than has ever been spoken (in my humble opinion).  It is better in some ways, obviously gets to the point MUCH more quickly without losing all the development of the family characters - and the ending, OH!!!!!!  For me, though I LOVE the '96 adaptation, the ending kind of just didn't get it for me.  This one will satisfy that for you (I couldn't breath!!)Just when you think it can't get any better...
summary: If you think it couldn't get any better than Colin Firth...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a classy movie! This is the successor to the Merchant Ivory movies... Joe Wright does an impeccable job of getting a dense and wordy novel down to the essentials of the story, and still leave time to savour the beauty of England and the cast.The story involves Lizzy and her 4 sisters, following their path to marriage through the minefield of Georgian conventions of 1797 (when the movie was set)and English social mores. The pride and the prejudices come from every angle in this classic and timeless story.There are several ingredients here that simply make this work to perfection. The cast is for the most part spot on, with Keira Knightley in top form as the headstrong Lizzy, looking, sounding and emoting every inch the part. She is surrounded by Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland as her father and mother, Judi Dench as a Lady Catherine to make you wither in your boots (unless you are Lizzy of course), ravishing Rosamund Pike as her older sister and Tom Hollander as the wimpy cleric, amongst others. The only slight let down, and only because the others are so good, is Matthew MacFadyen, who is perfectly adequately brooding as Darcy, but compared to Colin Firth lacks the charisma to make such a character attractive to Lizzy.Therein lies the problem, if any, with this adaptation - it cannot help but be compared to the impeccable casting and pedigree of the BBC version, which is still the definitive version because of its length, which allows it to stick more rigidly and fully to the book. But this movie must be taken on its own merits, and succeeds where the BBC version could not, in the scale and beauty of the photography - England looks absolutely beautiful here. The mud and dirt are all there - this is no stagey drama - but the beauty of the photography illuminates fantastic interiors of houses rich to poor, and most especially the exteriors of Georgian facades, and natures rich greens and majestic moors.I should also mention the music by Dario Marianelli which is a perfect contributor to the movie, beautifully classic while never dull, somewhat like the ivory tinklings of Michael Nyman (The Piano), but not nearly so minimalist, with lush orchestra where appropriate, and lively jigs for the ball scenes making them seem genuinely like something that would have been fun to attend.Overall, I suggest avoiding comparison with the BBC version, and take this movie as the definitive cinema version, at least.- a p.s. there are plenty of extras on the desk fleshing out history and Jane Austen as well as the usual 'making of' stuff, but most interesting is the alternative ending for the US market - this adds a scene of Lizzy and Darcy together cuddling and expressing their love, which seems much more like a Hollywood add on than the original ending, and adds nothing other than some saccharine for those who cannot find the romance in the story but require it spelt out.
summary: Fantastic entertainment for both fans and newcomers to Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: So funny that most the BBC afiocionados not to mention the Jane Austen Society are up in arms over the P&P; 2005 version.  The reviews are as condescending as "Lady Catherine"-- as if the BBC version is above reproach.So if this version is just SOOOO bad and SOOO not Austen, why did it get universal rave critics reviews (critics as we know can be very nasty), got nominations with BAFTA, got Keira Knightley an Oscar nom and Golden Globe nom and is in a quite a few of top 10 films of 2005? Because its a splendid adaptation in cinema form.This is what I don't get with all the gripes against it which I have read.  Movies are a different art on its own, so is TV and so are books.Be thankful that its been well done on the acting level (yes, Keira had moments of being a little too "modern" but overall was outstanding), cinematography is just gorgeous, score was very classy and the camera work was unbelievable.  The "realistic" approach was refreshing as well. When I was watching the movie, I felt exactly like how I felt with the Lord of the Rings trilogy-- I was transported to another world, in this case back in time.Quite a number of the review reeks of condescencion of the highest order.  Get off your high horse.  Appreciate it for the artform that it was adapted in.  Hollywood spews out so much trash that I could not believe that this wonderful romantic film did not have graphic sex and swearing.  We actually need more of these kind of clean wholesome movies.The BBC was good as a literal interpretation/adaptation of the book.  However, it felt like a play (not a hair out of place on any of the characters) and not the form of media that its supposed to be.  In addition, I found Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth's acting wooden, their lines sprung out of the book verbatim.In closing, I love, love, love the 2005 version. Yes, it may be condensed and is not perfect by any means.  But as a form of cinema, its one of those rare movies I will enjoy many, many years from now and will be a classic in its own right
summary: A  few just like Lady Catherine

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While I will admit this is an adequate adaptation of Austen's beloved Pride and Prejudice, I'm afraid that I can praise it no more than that.  Yet again, this is an instance of Hollywood production and direction and the overtness of both overriding the subtle nuances of this keenly written novel and its themes of love and possession.I won't comment on the actors' performances here because, again, the only word I can use to describe the ensemble cast is adequate.  I will note, however, that Kiera Knightely shines as Lizzie Bennett, albeit a little too giddy for my taste, and that Matthew McFayden's Darcy is more somber bordering on depressed than haughty or proud.In attempting to amplify the unsuitability of Lizzie as a match for Darcy, the producer of the film opts to place her family in relative squalor and, by doing so, completely subverts the delicate relationship and definition between the classes in Regency England.Although the film follows Austen's narrative quite closely, it departs from it often in terms of dialogue and action.  How inappropriate would it have been for Darcy to come bursting in the door of Lizzie's bedroom!  Lizzie says things like "I have no idea."  "I haven't the smallest idea" or "I haven't the slightest idea" would have been more correct.  "I have no idea" is a more contemporary phrase, and should not be made to feel at home in any movie which claims to be based on Austen's work.Those scenes in particular which veer from the manners and mannerisms of Austen's England just make the film a little too pedestrian for my taste.  "You have bewitched me body and soul"?  Hardly.  Although it may have been said of Darcy, it is not something that Austen's Darcy would have uttered.  What utter tripe and nonsense!  Even Charlotte Bronte, author of "Jane Eyre", was not a fan of Austen's because of what she believed to be a definitive lack of passion in Austen's writing.  It's not so much that passion is lacking, more that it is restrained, so for Darcy to exhibit that sort of passion would be completely inconsisent with the character Austen created.  I actually cringed my way through the last fifteen minutes.  "'Godess Divine' on Sundays'"?  Don't make me laugh.  There is such a thing as leaving some things to the imagination.  It is a pity that some movie producers just haven't mastered that fine art.All in all, if you view the film as simply a movie NOT based on the book, then it's enjoyable.  If you're a purist, as I am, take my advice and rent this one, don't buy it, and take it for what it is.  If you want to see Austenian adaptations at their finest, RUN AND BUY the A&E; production of Pride and Prejudice instead, or Persuasion, starring Ciaran Hinds and Amanda Root.
summary: Best movie of the year?  Hardly

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I realize this film takes some liberties with the actual book by Jane Austin.However, considering the number of "more faithful-to-the-book" film renditions of this title already produced,this particular presentation of the story line -- with a bit more modern interpretation of events -- both myhusband and I found riveting and refreshing.  We feel the actual spirit of the original work by Austin has beentreated with honor.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The Acting.  The drama.  The special attention to every poised detail best describes and places this remake-masterpiece into it's proper frame.  Sometimes excellent productions do require more funding and this one had it.  Make no mistake, the kids of today know little of exceptional cinema and what it is, or, use to be; but, from time to time one still comes shining thru on occassion.  The beleivability is stunning and memorable, describing to kind of ongoing love we all wish for.  See for yourself.  Walk emotionally into the screen itself and live afresh and be renewed.  Not all have this kind of destined love, though, for us that do, we relish the thoughts of this heavenly blessing!!
summary: Wonderful--Modern or Old makes no difference--Outstanding

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Just had to add my two cents on this film....I, too, have seen the previous versions.  The mini-series does stick to the book more closely than this new movie, but with the time constraints of a two-hour film, the movie-makers had to make some decisions about Austen's story. The basic story is all there. Some reviewers have complained about the changes in scenery with regard to certain plot points, the casting, the costuming, etc., but, unfortunately, these reviewers have made these complaints without any consideration to the movie-makers' well-considered reasons for their decisions.  This movie is meticulously thought-out and it takes an exploration into the making of this movie to judge its merits fairly.  This is an adaptation of a much-loved love story that offers a little different twist to the characters, and a little different feel to the period of the story. Why not offer something a little different this time?The scenery is exquisite, the music is SO beautifully done, and the casting could not be better.  As much as I enjoy the mini-series, and as much as I appreciate that its length allows for more character development, it still has the feel of a TV mini-series.  As much as I enjoy Colin Firth's Darcy, and I much as I enjoy his other work, his Darcy really doesn't compare to Matthew MacFadyen's interpretation. MacFadyen's Darcy projects much more depth of emotion....if you TRULY pay attention to the acting, it is simply brilliant.  Just with his eyes alone, MacFadyen brings so much more human sensitivity and vulnerability to the role than Firth does. Even a wealthy upper-class gentleman is human. The rest of the cast is phenomenal, as well....so much so that I find it laughable that any reviewer of this film would suggest that the casting/acting in the mini-series is better.  It is good, but there's just simply no comparison.If you do choose to see this film, or have seen it, watch it a second time on DVD with the director's commentary. It's very interesting.The only issue I have with this adaptation of such a timeless and beloved story is that it isn't longer.  A truly wonderful film.
summary: I've read all of the reviews...now here's mine

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Nancy E. Merrill "Lit lover in Utah"
review_text: Aside from that, this is a lovely adaptation. As to the complaints about cuts and re-working of scenes, the film makers didn't have the luxury of five hours to tell the tale verbatum. I took my two nephews (age 16 & 14) to see this, and they both liked it. The older one is an avid reader who had been told by an older brother that Austen was dry and boring, so he expected to hate the movie going in and didn't. Now he's reading Austen and enjoying it. So where is the harm in knowing this is an adaptation and won't be completely faithful to the book? If you want a completely faithful version of the book, read the book.As to the particulars about my choice of rating: Keira Knightly is lovely as Elizabeth without outshining Rosamund Pike in beauty as Jane. Matthew Macfadyen does an outstanding job of showing us what Mr. Darcy is feeling and thinking. There's no other way to portray it in a movie; in the book, Austen puts us into his head so he doesn't have to show it. Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn shine as Mr. and Mrs. Bennet, presenting them as warm, real human beings rather than charactures. And Tom Hollander gives an amazing and completely different read on Mr. Collins. Usually played as a complete buffoon, here he is an ackward misanthrope who seems aware of the fact that there's something not quite right with how he comes across. It would have been nice if Judi Dench's scenes as Lady Catherine hadn't been cut so much, but there's that time restraint coming into play. Plus, you can't have everything.As to this DVD: Nice rendering. Good picture. Lovely sound. I only wish that the extras were a little more beefed up. I was sad to find no deleted scenes. However, the behind-the-scenes and interviews with the cast and crew are extensive and well done.Also recommended DVDs: BBC version, North & South (Elizabeth Gaskell), Wives & Daughters (also Gaskell), Sense and Sensibility (Emma Thompson version)
summary: If it gets people reading Austen, what's to complain about?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: it is a truth universally acknowledged ... that no other film adaptation can ever measure up to the 1995 adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, at least according to austen purists.  and i agree.therefore, i will not attempt to compare this film to its predecessors but rather just review it on its own merits.i like this new adaptation.  it is quite a different take of the novel.  it is a grittier rural england that gives the story a bit more realism.  unlike other period adaptations that tend to be very picturesque and clean depicting a very ideal world, the setting, particularly of the bennet household, gives it a more genuine feel.keira's lizzie & matthew's darcy have such a wicked chemistry when they're together, that alone is worth buying the DVD.  knightley's performance is a bit stilted in some scenes but overall, she conveyed a delightfully strong-willed and witty lizzie.  macfadyen, who had very big shoes to fill, i think did a good job with the material he was given.  he brought a vulnerability to darcy, played quite well by macfadyen ... man, that voice ...  mr. collins, who was always one of my favorite characters, was delightful.a lot of liberty was taken transforming lizzie's character from a very open character throughout the novel to one of an open but gradually secretive character in the movie.  but still, it is consistent with the particular flavor of this adaptation.the film certainly lost a lot of the witty dialogues that made the novel the literary work of art that it is.  however, there was enough to still carry the movie through.i would have loved to see more scenes that showed darcy becoming more attracted to lizzie and vice versa, but i suppose it was effectively maneuvered & compensated by the two actors by making the viewer feel that whenever they were together, they seem to be only aware of each other.one of my disappointments is mr. bingley's character.  i thought mr. bingley could've been portrayed better.  same goes for mr. wickham's character.  although rupert friend's acting was barely tolerable, so i suppose i should be thankful that i was not forced to see more of it.  also, the two youngest girls annoyingly overdid their giggles, most likely due to the fact that they had nothing much to say throughout the entire film.all in all this is a delightful movie.  i watched it expecting to be disappointed but was pleasantly surprised that i liked it.  i may yet watch it again.
summary: this movie is wicked ... despite its flaws

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Maybe by putting the symbol "&" instead of the word "and" they were trying to tell us something!!  I've read this book so many times I have many scenes memorized by now!  The A&E (Firth version) was good!  The old 1980 BBC version was COMPLETELY the story right out of the pages of the book!  And when I close my eyes and imagine Darcy, I see David Rintoul!!  However, this movie is NOT Pride and Prejudice by any stretch of the imagination!  Perhaps, if they had given it a different title and not tried to pretend that it was Pride and Prejudice, I could give it more stars in its own right!
