title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Of all the cinematic versions of Jane Austen's novel, this one comes closest to realizing the reader's mind's eye. While the book is still better, the movie is a delight.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightly brings Elizabeth Bennett to life as she weaves her way through the stifled structure of the early years of 19th century England. The movie's great vitality draws the viewer enter the world that Jane Austen vividly depicted. While her sisters manage to get themselves married, Elizabeth refuses to adhere to the "rules" of polite society.  Her pride matches the prejudices of the world in which she finds himself.  Her relationship with Mister Darcy appears more like a fencing match than a romance. Along the way, she gets into a jaw to jaw verbal fight with Judi Dench that is a joy to behold. In the end, everything works out as it is supposed to, but not without twists and turns and a surprise ending. This is a movie well worth owning because you will want to watch more than once.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I cannot believe anyone rated this movie with more than 2 stars.  I also can't believe that anyone other than a marketer of the film would say that it is "easily on a par" with the BBC version.This version is thin and shallow.  No character gets developed.  Many that are present are protrayed incorrectly.  Mr. Bennet seems to actually respect his wife.  That alone is unbelievable.  Then the writers can't seem to decide how to play the dialogue.  Characters alternately use a more natural style of english and then suddenly lurch back into the more formal language of the book.  They would have done my ears a service by choosing one way or the other.And some of the artistic license is amazing.  That Lady Catherine would travel 50 miles in the middle of the night to confront Elizabeth in front of her entire family.  Or Mr. Darcy delivering his explanatory letter to Elizabeth also at night by appearing almost as an apparition in her room.There are more items I could mention but to get to the point, I thought this version was laughable.  Anyone who does not know Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice and watches this, has not seen Pride and Prejudice.  They will have hardly even seen an imitation of the story.  Do yourself a favor.  Read the book and stay away from this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I bought this DVD when it just came out.  I watched it and did not like it.  I just finished reading the book - again - and watching all the DVD's I own.  I give top rank to the 1995 BBC version with the 1980 BBC version a close second.  I have to say that the Hollywood version with Olivier was not that good and had several big flaws- I would not even rank it.  Unfortunately,  I watched this 2006 version  from beginning to end and, again, I did not find much to like.  The scenery and music were wonderful; however, the characters are not developed well with Lizzie being  a big disappointment - she did not behave ladylike, she seemed to just giggle and had no wit.  Mr Bingley  appears as a foolish young man without much going for him - can he be Mr Darcy's closest friend?  Can Jane fall madly in love with him?  Mr Bennet does not strike me as gentleman like - he was a landed gentleman with an adequate income, but a spendthrift wife.  I like Mr. Darcy, but he is still in third place.  I would have liked to see more of Mr Wickham - but we don't get to know him, and consequently cannot dislike him as we should.How improper to have Mr. Bingley go into the room where Jane is in bed with a cold - they seem to have copied the scene from the Hollywood version.  Did Mr. Darcy sneak into the Collinses house to give Lizzie the letter or I got that wrong?  If so, it would have been unthinkable behavior for Mr. Darcy.If this movie would have been presented with a different title and in a modern setting, I may have given it at least four stars.  I will keep the DVD and maybe I will watch it again in a few years - I may change my mind, but I doubt it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must admit I was excited to hear about another Pride & Prejudice, however, I was sadly disappointed.  I know that it's impossible to do a thorough job like the A&E; version in just 2 hours, but it was horribly watered down.  Elizabeth was frumpy looking and dressed poorer than she should have been and Mr. Darcy . . . well McFayden isn't a bad actor but it was annoying to see him pouting through the whole movie looking close to tears in some parts.  He just didn't have the essence that was needed.  Liberties were taken and the movie (although not a bad one in itself) falls miserably short.  If you want to see an interesting version of Pride & Prejudice that is funny and it's amusement adds to the fact it follows the book loosely, check out Bride & Prejudice.Poor Georgiana and Whickam died the death of a thousand deaths.  Their parts were dramatically cut and could have added more depth to the story line.  My friends and I were disappointed that by the end of the movie you had no idea why Elizabeth married Darcy.  You didn't see a real evolution of feelings.  Plus that ending was annoying and entirely too cheesy.
summary: Good if you aren't a fan

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I thought it wouldn't measure up to the BBC and I was right.  To be fair, a 2 to 2 and a half hour limit brings its restrictions and really, the film shouldn't have been attempted.  Colin Firth runs rings around MacFadyen who can't act to save his life.  Dressing Donald Sutherland up to look the part was not enough to take his acting beyond that of school play proportions.  That said, Rosamund Pike was delightful as Jane and would potentially have fitted just as well into the BBC production.  The cinematography is excellent and the music is breath-taking.  I trust the producers lost money on this project which, coming so relatively soon after the definative BBC production, was nothing more than an effort to cash in.  I am grateful that none of the BBC actors and actresses took part.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My item came very quick and I used standard ground shipping.  It also came packaged very well.  I am a new member to Amazon, this was my first purchase, but not my last!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When I first saw this movie, I had no expectations. I had never seen any other version of Pride and Prejudice, nor had I read the book. The visuals were stunning, the story was good, and although the acting was not perfect, it was good enough. I was impressed enough to look it up later and not only purchase this version, but also got the older, BBC version with Colin Firth.Although I have since watched the BBC version multiple times and fallen in love with the story and the actors in that version...I can still look kindly upon this version. Although parts were missing and this story is nowhere near as in-depth as the BBC version or the book, and although I feel that Kiera Knightley is too charged (her emotions are all very extreme. She comes off as rude, angry, and overemotional to me.) and too self-conscious (again, with her overdone reactions to things...it makes her seem self-conscious and nervous.), I think this version is much more accessible to the public. People are more willing to sit down to a short movie filled with beautiful people than they are to begin the 5 hour of the BBC version or read "stuffy old novels". As well, despite the historical inaccuracies, the filming was well-done and I believe the story is as good as it could have been after being condensed into such a small package. While many would be angry that this movie isn't "as good" as the BBC version, I still think this movie is better than many others in the last few years.However, I would highly recommend that anyone who watched and was impressed with this movie go out and rent the BBC version. You will not be disappointed.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: so much enjoyed this version. the plot is essentially the same. but the characters are brought alive with these portrayers. was quickly drawn into the story. will watch again and again!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off I will admit that I do not care for Keira Knightley in the first place. But I was willing to give the film the benefit of the doubt and at least watch it.I turned it off with in the first five minutes. I was horrified! I did however sit and watch it all the way through a few weeks later with some friends. (I think they had to tie me down to keep me from leaving) The acting was terrible, the characters were not faithfully presented at all. This is one of my favorite novels and it was butchered! Ms. Knightley did not make a good Elizabeth Bennett, she came off as a silly air head with no wits at all, rather than the smart, witty, prejudiced Lizzy we all love. Mr. Bingley was portrayed as an imbecile who only knew how to laugh and smile. I could go on but I think you see my point. Many key parts were left out of the film. I was very disappointed. I don't see how any Austen fan could enjoy this at all.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a great film! I loved the score, I loved the cinematography, and I loved the casting.Kiera Knightley made a wonderful Elizabeth Bennet, and Matthew Macfadyen was a superb Darcy. Both of their performances were great. Macfadyen seemed to understand that, at first, Darcy had to be quite an unlikable character. However, as the movie progresses, the viewer (as well as Lizzie) learns more about him and grows to like him. It seems that, sometimes, actors are afraid to fully embody those unlikable characters unless they know they are playing the villain. But there are plenty of unlikable people in everyday life who are not villains. They are just cold, or boorish, or rude, or whatever. There are LOTS of folks with no bad intentions who are just plain draggy to be with.I really enjoyed how the movie stayed true to the spirit novel we've all known and loved, without become a slave to the book. (After all, movies and books are quite different mediums, and audiences change drastically over time.) I haven't seen much else that Joe Wright, the director, has done, but you can bet I'll be keeping an eye on him for the future.Near the end of the film, Darcy comes walking out of the morning mist, long coattails flapping in the breeze, to tell Lizzie that she has bewitched him, body and soul. Now, why on earth hasn't anyone said that to me lately? ~sigh.~

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film, I must admit, was my first experience with "Pride & Prejudice."  And because I didn't know the story line, everything was a pleasant surprise.  I was so incredibly moved by the touching romances and the simplicity of the time (when just the touch of a hand was so electric), and it was a film that truly made me believe in happiness ever after.  Watching the relationship between Elizabeth and Darcy develop from disdain and contempt to unconditional love against all odds was emotional and inspiring and a journey I thoroughly enjoyed witnessing.  And now that I have the DVD and have watched it several times, I am still swept away every time.  I absolutely love Matthew MacFadyen's performance, especially in the climactic scene when he tells Elizabeth, "I love and love and love you," getting choked up on the final "love you."  Now who could resist that?  Although I enjoyed Keira Knightley's performance as well, I felt that she didn't appear quite as genuine as she should have in this same critical scene.  But that wasn't enough to take away from the powerful moment.Overall, I can't praise this movie enough.  Yes, it is very condensed compared to some other versions, but I love everything about this film, and I think they kept the best parts of the plot line in.  In fact, now having seen three other versions, this is still my favorite by far.  This film ranks as one of my top five all-time favorites, and I don't think it will ever get bumped!  Like another reviewer said, "It's the perfect movie" and "I will probably watch this film a million more times before I die."  My sentiments exactly!  Another aspect I enjoyed, I might add, was the music -- I even bought the soundtrack.  It's beautiful and adds so perfectly to each scene.If you fell in love with this film like I did, I highly recommend two other Jane Austen stories:  The Emma Thompson version of "Sense & Sensibility" and the Gwenyth Paltrow version of "Emma."
summary: One of my all-time favorites!  Never get tired of it!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I had seen this movie previously in digital and there were so many details that are missed in that version.  Near the beginning, you are aware that the Bennett family is not well to do just by looking at the porch of their house.  It's a wonderful story and the outdoor scenes are magnificent looking.  Keira Knightley has a face born to be in the movies and hd does very well by her.  If you like this film and have an hd dvd player, I strongly recommend you add this to your library.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being a huge fan of period dramas, literary adaptations and Keira Knightley, I was delighted by the latest adaptation of Jane Austen'sPride and Prejudice. It is everything a movie should be, and then some. Great storytelling, an amazing soundtrack, an innovative director and a splendid soundtrack, it is definitely a movie you should own.It tells a classic story of Elizabeth Bennet, a smart, boyish heroine who meets the handsome Mr. Darcy, and judging solely on first impressions, believes he is "the last man on Earth she could ever possibly be prevailed upon to marry". Of course, it wouldn't be a Jane Austen adaptation if it wasn't for numerous plot twists, complicated character connections and humorous plays on words.Keira Knightley is perfect as Elizabeth, the role which not only propelled her to stardom, but also earned her an Oscar nomination in 2005. She is everything a classic heroine should be - sensual, expressive and beautiful, maybe even a little more than she should have been. On the other hand, there is Matthew Macfadyen, who makes a great, darker Mr. Darcy. Also in the all-star cast are veterans Donald Sutherland and Dame Judy Dench.Director Joe Wright did an incredible job. Not only did he play with the source in a very respectful, yet creative way, he used many tricks to make us care for these characters and believe their plights are just as well possible today. He also uses the stunning British countryside a number of times, and it is one of the film's best props - it is able to, accompanied by a great soundtrack, reflect the characters' emotions and send chills up and down one's spine."Pride & Prejudice" is definitely one of the best romantic movies and literary adaptations of the century, and one you should have on your shelf for sure.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not a devoted fan of Jane Austin, but I am certainly familiar with her work and respect it's overall merit.  I watched this movie after reading a number of reviews about it; the most critical reviews tend to focus on the way this version deviated from the written works and it's rather less glamorous visual presentation.  I cannot comment on the first criticism, because I never read this particular one of Austin's works.  As for the second, I must disagree wholeheartedly.  In fact, I think the presentation of the Bennet's home, clothing, and personal foibles was probably a lot truer to the actual history of the period that many other "prettier" historical fictions.The relationship between Lizzie and Mr. Darcy unfolds in a refreshingly "real" way as well.  They aren't petty and catty with one another up to a moment when they experience some pivotal change of heart.  Instead, they just seem to start off unsure and distant and grow to see more in each other.  The acting required to pull this off must be subtle and genuine, and I think both actors accomplish this.  This is one of those rare love stories that attempts to capture sincerity, and it succeeds.  Mr. Darcy is not a loveable, and warm-hearted prince charming; he is "locked away" and seemingly frustrated by the society he sees around him.  He seems to genuinely seek something altogether different than he is routinely offered, and yet he doesn't fall for the crazy romantic girl (too cliche).  For Lizzie is no such girl; although not afraid to speak her mind, she is not silly and trite.  Rather, she is still a girl of the times--eager to find at least a practical husband.  Again, this is much more the way I imagine the heroines of this "romantic" period of history to be--spirited but not reckless.I also liked the way they incorporated the music of the day not only into the film score but into the story itself.  And the characters were all well-played, if not always well-liked.  How unfortunate a mother, with her shameless gossiping, eavesdropping and meddling?  And the cinematography was beautiful, without being overpowering.  It captured the visual beauty of this more simple time--both inside and out.  It is not hard to imagine why this landscape was the source of a renaissance of romantic art.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I remember sitting in the theater watching this film and waiting to be charmed.  The visuals were great, the costuming appropriate, the details superb.  But where was the humour, the charm, the wit and the wondeful characters that makes me read the novel again and again?  Some of the things that I love about Jane Austen is her social satire and her explication of human foibles, which have not changed all that much in three hundred years.  All you get with this film (presumably in an effort to make it "relevant" to modern viewers) is a lot of noise/yelling, bad acting (even from Dame Judy Dench!!), and the overwhelming feeling that the majority of the actors were miscast. The makers of this film stripped away all the humour of the novel and left me dissatisfied and suffering from a bad headache.  If you really want to experience a version of Pride and Prejudice with the spirit of Jane Austen gloriously intact, search out the 2004[?] version with Colin Firth.  That film is an  absolute delight.
summary: How To Kill Jane Austen In One Uneasy Lesson

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a wonderful adaptation of Austen's book. The quality of the film and theatrical aspect were beautiful and very well done. I thought the casting was perfect. I preferred the darker, brooding Darcy played by Matthew McFadyen in this version. I felt that each actor fit their character in looks better than some other adaptations. Rosamund Pike (Jane) was actually pretty, unlike the actor who played Jane in the BBC/A&E; version.I was disappointed by all the holes in this movie. It really didn't give enough information for someone not familiar with the book to understand the background of the characters and the traditions of that time. They made it seem as though Bingley and Jane didn't spend much time together as well as Darcy and Elizabeth. I felt that it was almost hard to believe that in the very little time Bingley spent with Jane, there was no way he could have already been in love and the same with Lizzie and Darcy. But I understand that they couldn't have a theatrical adaptation last for many, many hours to show each and every time they encountered each other. The artistic changes made in this movie were worthwhile. The scene in the rain with Darcy proposing to Lizzie was wonderful, and Catherine de Bourgh showing up at night was fun too.All in all, a very good movie, done very well. I am very pleased with it and will watch it over and over again. Even if it didn't follow real closely to the book, the important parts of the story were there and the emotions of the characters were still conveyed perfectly. I am quite satisfied and anyone who is an Austen fan should add this to their collection.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is very close to the book except for the too-modern ending.  The casting is perfect, the English settings are lovely.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, let's start with the positive when discussing the film: the cinematography really was quite nice, and the film has a lovely musical score. And... wait a moment, I've just run out compliments. In general, I thought this was a terrible adaptation of the Jane Austen novel. There were so many things wrong with it that I hardly know where to begin, and it would make tiresome reading if I were to list all of the film's faults. However, in brief...The film is hampered at the get-go by its very abbreviated running time of just over two hours. This is far too short to do the book any kind of justice, my opinion being that the best way to adapt classic novels on film is in the form of a television mini-series, where the producers can spend three, or four, or six hours to tell the story properly. Far too much material was condensed or cut entirely in this film, for it to be a satisfactory adaptation in any way.But that's just the beginning... another major problem is that nearly every character is portrayed in a way that is absolutely contrary to their personalities as depicted in the novel. Some examples... Mr Bingley, with his moronic grin, complete inability to carry on a simple conversation, and bizarrely wild hair-style, seems primed to take up the office of village idiot (that, or he may be slightly insane; either way, it's difficult to see why Jane admires him). Elizabeth comes across as rude and shrewish in several scenes, and Mrs Bennet (while dead common) appears to be a rather sensible and practical woman, instead of a featherbrain. Mr Darcy is melancholy and brooding, instead of proud and arrogant, and Mr Collins is dull and studious instead of obsequious and ridiculous. Miss Darcy is outgoing and vivacious instead of shy and retiring---etc., etc...Scenes containing important bits of dialogue have been transposed to incongruous locations that are ill-suited for the purpose, and there are many period details that are utterly incorrect. (Let's not even discuss the unattractive costuming; Keira Knightley goes through much of the film looking like she's wearing an assortment of ill-fitting sacks.)Okay, I guess you may have guessed by now that I really disliked this film! I'm frankly astounded by the fact that it has gotten a fairly positive response in general, with many people saying that it's a fine adaptation of the novel. I don't know how to respond to that attitude, other than to wonder if these people have actually read the book, or seen the film in question. I don't even recommend this one as a rental, unless one is determined to see every film adaptation of Pride and Prejudice that they can.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie really had it tough. When you go up against one of the favorite movies ever, you have to be brave. Imagine making a new version of Gone with the Wind, or if someone decided to do Titanic Two. I remember when I saw this in theaters, everyone was whispering comparisons between this and the Colin Firth version. So, how is it?On it's own, it's great, actually. I've never been a fan of Kiera Knightley, but she does well here. I do think she played the part a little more teenage and a little less snarky than it was meant to be, but I'm sure the director was behind that 100%. This is, after all, aimed at the young audience. It's screaming, "I'm new, I'm fresh, I'm just like you!". Matthew MacFaden seems a little bored, to be honest. When he proposes the first time, it sounds like he's reading a phone book. Of course, I may be just comparing him to Firth because actually he and Knightley are good together. The real star here, though, is Tom Hollander. He play Mr. Collins in an entirely new way, a way nobody else had thought of. He is pitch perfect in his part and if you watch it for no other reason, watch it for him.[...]
summary: Had a Hard Battle to Fight

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It is my sincere wish that Jane Austen readers and non-readers  not miss a big screen viewing of Joe Wright's "Pride & Prejudice" because they let themselves be influenced by negative comments from the Ellen Jamesian sect of the Jane Austen society.  Particularly odious are those presumptuous enough to declare that Austen herself would consider the film a disservice.  Attempting to discourage potential viewers in this manner reveals not just a staggering conceit, but an utter cluelessness about how to read a film and about the power of a visual medium.This film adaptation of Austen's classic is the first one to fully capture its essence within the economical and efficient package of a two-hour feature film.  And it does so in a technically proficient way (cinematography-production design-editing); with perfect physical casting, excellent directing and scene staging, and fine performances from the entire ensemble.  In isolation it is simply the best film ever made, but because it is not an original screenplay the critics have downgraded it a bit from A plus to A minus (their acknowledgement of the debt it owns to Austen).Jane Austen once said,  "an artist cannot do anything slovenly".  Joe Wright's film is not perfect but it is the least slovenly in cinema history.  I was reminded of this by the film's treatment of Georgiana, Darcy's sister.  Georgiana was a minor but extremely important character in the book.  Elizabeth's point of view observations of Darcy's tender treatment of his shy little sister is how Austen shows Elizabeth's first realization that Darcy is worthy of her love.  Initially I was disappointed that Georgiana only has two brief appearances in the film, but on reflection I realized that the scenes had been staged and scripted so well that they said everything  needed about the relationship dynamics of the three characters.The film successfully brings Austen's ironic (insert comic here) observations of character and manners to the screen.  As the title proclaims, this story has a double theme, the pride of the aristocrat prejudicing the middle class heroine against him.  But as Elizabeth explains to her father in my favorite scene, she and Darcy are the flip sides of each other as her pride has long blinded her to Darcy's efforts to overcome the prejudice of his class to hers.The film also captures the more critical macro element of Austen's novel, the idea of a generous humanness that can transcend the motivations of social class.  Society is imperfect and while the social order encourages foolish prides and mean prejudices, it also enables kindness, affection, and courage.  In the film's movement of events there is a modulation between vices and virtues in which the latter more than mitigates the former.  This was Jane Austen's primary "value" which I think  would have formed the basis of her judgment and ultimate approval of the film.Then again, what do I know?  I'm only a child.
summary: Why I Think Jane Would Have Approved

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie slaughtered a beautiful book. Keira Knightly resembled nothing close to an Elizabeth Bennet and the story was so rushed and sugar coated that only someone who has never read the book, or even heard the plot, could have enjoyed it. It was an absolute heartbreak.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I don't claim to be an expert on the novels of Jane Austen and don't judge this adaptation according to the original story or any previous versions. Focusing on this 2005 film version starring Keira Knightly as Elizabeth, I found it filled with beauty, romance, music and breathtaking scenery. The casting is nearly perfect as each of the characters comes to life in a highly believable manner. Knightly does an extraordinary job at expressing her love of her sisters (even the kooky younger girls) and her father, along with her initial distaste for Darcy.I particularly enjoyed the peformances of Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennett, and the appearance of Dame Judy Dench. It's a championship moment when Elizabeth stands up to her in the middle of the night--as good as her romantic scenes with Darcy.Everything about this film make it a period piece that completely capsulizes a point in time and a classic work of fiction. I will watch it again and again and again.
summary: Beauty, Romance . . . What's Not To Love?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Since I haven't read the novel (but have read a couple other Jane Austen novels), I went in with no real expectations - and my wife and I enjoyed the movie quite a bit. Keira Knightly definitely earned her Oscar nomination, and the cinematography of the English landscape captured the essence of the Jane Austen style of writing. The best thing I can say about the movie is that now I need to download the novel for my Nook/Kindle!
summary: My wife wanted to see this - and I enjoyed it quite more than expected

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a huge fan of this book, so I was surprised at how much I loved the film. Normally movie adaptations of books are more than pitiful.My only problem with the movie was that it was not long enough. There was so much more that could have been put in that was not. Though, what was put in was almost perfect. There were some historical inaccuracies as well as book related inaccuracies. Some of these inaccuracies helped show the degree of emotion or importance, like when Lady Catherine calls on Lizzy in the middle of the night, it shows the urgency of her manner.This movie was well casted. Keira Knightley was absolutely perfect for the part. Matthew Macfadyen and Keira Knightley have great chemistry and a believable passion for one another.I highly recommend this movie to everyone.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Thanksgiving eve I went on a Jane Austen binge. Among other movies based on her books I watched three different versions of Pride & Prejudice. This one is by far my favorite. Keira Knightley works her customary magic. Matthew Macfadyen was quite a surprise. He plays against character with his massive physical presence combined with the subtlety of his acting. His character's discomfort in social situations is acute, making the ending superb. Overall the movie is very well cast, especially Donald Sutherland.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I LOVE this movie. I love everything about it, the music, the actors and actresses, the scene, the story line...Since I bought it I watched it every other day. I can relate to the main characters so much. I like the fact that so many lines are kept what Jane Austen used in the book. Keira is the perfect Ms. Bennet, and Matthew is the perfect Mr. Darcy. He is so handsome in this movie! I am not a romantic person, but this movie just amazing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I know, I know it is very obvious but in this case I really do not care.  Jane Austen's books are amazing and this movie has almost the same dialogues as the book, only a few changes in the characters but the plot remain the same and that is why I love it.  It is romantic, lovely, passionate and emotional, what else... ah, I love it.In some part it is a little bit dark, but it only last a minute or so.Keira Knightley, Matthew Macfadyen did an excellent work.
summary: Most romantic movie of all times!! Unless for me.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I thought that this version/adaptation of Austen's novel was excellent overall and would strongly recommend viewing to anyone (rent or purchase).I've seen most of the previous versions and agree that the BBC Ehle/Firth outing is indeed still much loved, however, I found this simply more realistic - from the grittier, grubbier lives of our heroines, played more girlish and younger than previously - to a much more 'real' portrayal of Darcy. Shy, vulnerable and as such, aloof.The real strength for me though was the true family that Sutherland and Blethyn create. The girls feel like real sisters, not literary ones, led by the extraordinary Knightley and Pike. Both quite luminous on screen and both embodying the spirit of the age.Special kudos must be given to Knightley though, who here just radiates a feisty lovability and who's capture of Darcy seems completely natural, as if any man who met her Lizzie would fall madly in love.And as such, McFayden embodies a Darcy that I can actually imagine falling in love with a girl, well below what he and his own family expects, and his struggle with his feelings and responsibilities.All in all, a great film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: 2005 movie adaption with Keira Knightley was a master piece introduced me to Jane Austen world.  If Jane is alive today and lived thru our century that time measures in millisecond.  I can imagined she be proud and approved this movie for her contemporary audience.  After watched the movie and then read the book more than 10+ times each. I had to say the movie adaption is truly great in matching the casts and the personalities in the book. It is really picture worth a thousand words.  The cinematic effects, the dialogs and the sets were beautifully created in such brilliant art form; so pleasing to the eyes and so much touching of the heart.Keira carried the whole movie fantastic well; she was alive with the character of Elizabeth Bennett. Her personality, her dark eyes matched Lizzy in the book well. Her expressions and the looks to Darcy were so real to live. Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy was great as in the book; I grew to the character more in re-watch. They had great chemistry. For a modern generation, this movie bridge to the classic. The ages of the actors were very well match to the stories. Not like the BBC TV series or 1940, somehow their age like 30s years old from today looks. Jane's story portrayed Lizzy at 20 years old when the stories began and Lydia at 16. This 2005 movie made a relatable youthfulness of younger people today.After the movie, I can read the book (free download from Amazon Kindle) with a little ease since this was my first classic from high school 30 years ago. The book was detail and added dimensions to that of the movie.  I re-watch the movie and saw the depth of the director and actors painstaking performances on each scene to create the original mood of each setting. The flow of the story is really well as book to movie goes. Many of the scenes were fantastic creations of the word / feeling from the characters in the book. With the music, our human visual & audio senses were flooded with emotions that the book can't. Then I did research on the internet and got the 18th century England Regency period to expand the depth of this story. That again adds depth to the feel of the movie and the book. Especially those forgotten terms like "Gentleman", "Amiable", "Agreeable" that we were brought up in such a faint echo of the early 18t century.Jane Austen thru her book and this movie has re-educated me the hidden Pride & Prejudice in me and how that affected me in many of my life. I surely didn't expect that that much of gains after a light hearted download from Amazon Video to my Tivo.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie!  It is lively, animated, and seems more naturalthan previous versions.  Matthew Macfadyen is so unaffected as Mr.Darcy, and seems to get beyond the arrogance to portray him assomeone uncomfortable reaching beyond his own class.  KeiraKnightly is beautiful as Lizzie.  The supporting actors are goodas well.  Donald Sutherland is great as the long-suffering Mr. Bennetttrying to cope with a houseful of women.  Tom Hollander is superblydroll as Mr. Collins.  The scenery, the music, the costumes enhancethe story beautifully.  A  must see!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love the story of Pride and Prejudice, and I really enjoyed this version.  The acting, scenery, costumes, etc. are superb.  The only reason I didn't give it five stars is that I only give a five-star rating for a movie that I feel is "profound" in some way, e.g,, Schindler's List.  This version was also a bit longer than the one I've seen on TV, which was fun too.  You won't be disappointed if you rent this movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Every few months I pull this movie out and watch it like 2-3 times! I can't get enough of this movie. It's so well done and the cinematography is amazing! Most of the writing is straight out of the novel and just can't be written any better! It's not sexual or crude or inappropriate... just amazing story of a strong woman who learns a great lesson about herself and love. Plus she's witty and smart in a time when women weren't appreciated for those qualities. Love Jane Austen and love this version the best!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: How can anyone even compare this to the BBC version? The characters were not developed, Darcy's heartfelt first proposal to Elizabeth sounded like he was rattling off his shopping list for the day, totally void of the inner conflict you feel in him in the BBC version. Please, don't be duped and sucked in to this two-hour mockery of this beautiful story. Order the BBC version and actually travel back in time and yes, it will take some time, but it is soooooo worth it. This is a must have for your DVD library. Colin Firth is the only Darcy I could ever imagine in this role. It's like someone else trying to play Rhet Butler, it just can't be done.
summary: No Character building, no Emotion and no Romance!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film seems created by people familiar with the storyline of "Pride and Prejudice" but with little sense of Jane Austen's times or, indeed, her characters. The plot is essentially correct but the tone is frequently and incomprehensibly off.The general excellence of the actors, the dreamy cinematography and music, and the obvious care lavished on this movie make its flaws even more apparent and confusing. The Elizabeth and Jane Bennett described by Jane Austen would never listen at keyholes or shout at their mother or giggle at a feeble marriage proposal.  Mr. Collins was written as a comically pompous character; here he is so meek and awkward his romantic attempts are more pathetic than amusing and make the sisters' reactions seem cruel.The costumes and hair are inexplicable--Kitty and Lydia are dressed as if they are from a generation past, when they are the ones most concerned with fashion and are always buying new bonnets and gowns, and Elizabeth walks about with her hair down and in bare feet.  In reality, this would have been considered absolutely vulgar--akin to spitting tobacco--and never something a well-bred girl would do, no matter how high-spirited or independent.The Bennetts live in a place so ill-kept the animals wading across the yard look in danger of drowning in mud.  The Bennetts don't have the wealth of Bingley or Darcy, but they are supposed to be respectable, established gentry; Jed Clampett wouldn't own a place this slovenly.Despite all these missteps, this version of "Pride and Prejudice" is worth seeing for Keira Knightley's lively, if over-giggly, portrayal of Elizabeth and Matthew Macfadyen's interesting take on Darcy: he's more shy and subdued than actively arrogant (though his stuttering proposal at the end seems all wrong.  Love makes Darcy MORE eloquent, not less). The proposal scene in the rain is a highlight, and the plot stays true enough to the original for viewers to enjoy a cinematic vacation to Jane Austen's world.For the truest version of P and P, on all levels, definitely check out the BBC Jennifer Ehle/Colin Firth version.  It's wonderful!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie. It makes you feel good about happy endings and love conquers all. Loved the actors and and the screenplay. Matthew MacFadyen was a perfect Darcy. Tall, dark and handsome. Keira Knightley is always beautiful. I enjoyed Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn. They are fantastic as usual. Darcy is so difficult at the beginning that it was great watching him falling for her and how he made such a mess when he proposed. It was difficult to see him say all the wrong things and not be aware he was so insulting. Great ending.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I debated whether I should give the picture 3 or 4 stars.  I obviously chose 3.  The problem with the production is simply it is too short to give full credit to Jane Austin's book.  That said, it is well executed, which is why debated between the two ratings.The first problem is for those who have no prior familiarity with either the book or at minimum the two relatively recent much more lenghty mini series (the BBC-A&E; version with Colin Firth of 1995 and--in my view, the better--BBC-Australian version with Elizabeth Garvie of 1990).  So much is cut from this version that the nuances of what Austin was trying to convey are simply missing.  The three younger Bennet daughters are hardly differentiated, mostly they giggle and it is even hard to figure out which one is which.  I have just seen Carey Mulligan as a wonderful Ada in Bleak House, and it took me most of the movie to recognize her as Kitty, the second youngest daughter.  Eventually Lydia becomes recognizeable but only because she gets married to Wickam.Wickham appears only briefly at the beginning and though he tells Lizzie of Darcy's alleged mistreatment of him, one never realizes from this movie that Lizzie is unduly intrigued by him and is in danger of succumbing to his false charms.  We do hear of his falsity from Darcy's famous letter, but nothing more is provided to flesh out Wickham's perfidy until he "elopes" with Lydia.  (In particular, the wise words of the housekeeper at Pemberley, a neutral source, on the perfidy of Wickham, an important fact for Lizzie, are simply missing.)Although Charlotte appears early in the film, her significance is almost unnoted  Thus, it is unclear why it is of significance (to those who don't already know the book) that Mr. Collins marries her.  In general the repellant nature of Mr. Collins is seriously underplayed. He is almost a minor character.Mr. Bingley's married sister and her shiftless husband are entirely missing.  The Bennet manse is presented almost as farm, not a gentleman's small estate.  On the other hand, Chatsworth one of the grandest estates in England, the seat of the Duke of Devonshire, is presented as Pemberley.  This is much grander than Fitzwilliam Darcy would likely to have.  Darcy is not a Duke, and not even a lord.  (The movie script suggests that Darcy owns half of Derbyshire, and nothing in the book remotely suggest this, and if he has "only" 10,000 [pounds] a year--the only sum mentioned in the movie or book--it is highly unlikely that he owns more than a few thousand acres of Derbyshire.  Even the extremely wealthy Duke of Devonshire doesn't own more than a small fraction of Derbyshire.I won't go on with the faults.  Why do I give it 3 stars and even consider 4 stars?  Mainly because the most central points, the evolution of Elizabeth Bennet, full of prejudice and Fitzwilliam Darcy, full of pride, are reasonably well developed and are extremely well acted--particularly well developed for Elizabeth Bennet.  A number (though not all) of the key scenes of this relationship are well presented (though in somewhat truncated form which was necessary for fitting the whole movie into an approximate two hour length required for commercial movies).  Lady Catherine de Bourgh's ill-fated attempt to derail the budding romance between Lizzie and Darcy is well done (though also a bit truncated).  Mrs. Bennet's hysteria was dealt with sympathetically.I have read the book a half dozen times, seen the 1995 (Colin Firth) mini-series version a couple of times and the earlier Elizabeth Garvie mini-series version a dozen times, and so I know the story well enough to fill in for all of the important missing details.  With this prior knowledge, the plusses made it worthwhile for me to watch.  For someone is not particularly acquainted with Jane Austin's book (or last read it in high school many years ago) the movie provides a pleasant love story, even if it is seriously lacking in the subtlety of the original.  Knightley as Lizzie is a delight to look at and Macfayden may be the best Darcy on film--at least as far as the script allowed.But, at best, it is the "highlights" of Pride and Prejudice and is no substitute for the book, or at minimum, one of the mini-series.  As I indicated above the Elizabeth Garvie version of 1990 is, in my view, the best.  Elizabeth Garvie is incredible, she simply "is" Elizabeth Bennet.  This version also adheres closest to the text of the book, and is now available on an inexpensive DVD--which, incidentally, is more complete than the earlier VHS version.  (However, the Lawrence Olivier movie of the 1940s is, in my mind, a complete travesty to be avoided like the plague.)

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: P. Brown "Admitted Addicted to Love Stories"
review_text: I am a fan of Jane Austen and while this film does it's best to stick to the reality of the book it does omit characters and takes the liberty of adding scenes or altering them completely.  This does not bother me as I know that seldom do movies follow an author's intention.  Having said that, this movie is a pure delight!  Decidedly, Elizabeth Bennet is the most well rounded character in English liturature! Keira Knightly does her justice although I think with plenty of help from Max Factor!If you have never read Pride and Prejudice, do so!  It is a must!  Then buy the movie and enjoy the breathtakingly beautiful escape it is!  The love story, the scenery, the wonderful characters! Mr. Collins is so utterly annoying you can't help but feel for Lizzy's dear friend, Charlotte for marrying such a self-important baffoon.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having finished reading Amazon's complimentary e-copy of Pride and Prejudice on my Kindle, I was ready to watch the movie adaptation of this delightful story. I knew that the BBC 1995 version was the golden standard having watched snippets of both the 1995 and 2005 versions on Youtube. One night, while surfing through the tv channels, I caught the second half of this 2005 adaptation. I've enjoyed it very much and decided to purchase the dvd + digital product.This was not a 100% faithful adaptation of the book. It took poetic license in capturing Jane Austen's witty observations. The fireworks between Mr. Darcy and Lizzy Bennet were there. Kiera Knightley's portrayal to some might represent the same old "I am tough" mentality but it brought to live Lizzie's wittiness and intelligence when she stood up to Darcy and his aunt, Lady Catherine. One could felt the loving bonds between Lizzie and her father (Donald Sutherland) towards the end of the  movie when she declared her love for Mr. Darcy. Of course, the American ending was a bit "saccharine" as observed by the actor Matthew Macfadyen  (Mr.Darcy) in his interviews.The cinematography was simply beautiful. It was noted in the DVD commentary that one of scenes was filmed next to a 500 years old tree.I was able to download the digital copy from Itunes using the provided complimentary code and watch the digital copy.This movie has 2.8 million likes on Facebook. Those statistics speak for the popularity of the movie.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightly's interpretation of Elizabeth Bennet was ridiculous.  She made Lizzy out to be sort of a snot.  Elizabeth would never have disrespected her mother the way Knightly's version did in this movie.  It was not true to the book, to the character, or to the period.  Perhaps it was bad directing & not completely the actress's fault but that totally ruined the movie, for me.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a great adaptation.  The acting is great and is the directing.  This story is the classic " Pride and Prejudice" story as told by Jane Austen once you've cut out all the exasperating and inconsequential details.  This movie gets right to the point without diminishing the theme or plot of the story.It is the classic tale of Elizabeth.  Elizabeth is smart, but loyal to her sisters.  Jane, Elizabeth's older sister, falls in love with Mr. Bingley.  Mr. Darcy is Mr. Bingley's best friend and insults Elizabeth, but is unaware that she can hear him.  Elizabeth is enchanted by Mr. Wickham.  Elizabeth meets Mr. Darcy and through a series of misunderstandings on both their parts they end up misjudging both each and others.  Elizabeth finds out that Mr. Darcy encouraged Mr. Bingley not marry Jane because he believed that Jane didn't love Mr. Bingley.  Mr. Darcy tells Elizabeth that he loves despite himself.  Elizabeth clears up the misunderstanding that Mr. Darcy had about Jane and she also tells him off.  Mr. Darcy writes a letter and explains the truth about Mr. Wickham and what a leech he is.  Elizabeth's feelings towards Mr. Darcy start to change.  Then Elzabeth's youngest and most foolish sister, Lydia runs off with Mr. Wickham.  Mr. Darcy uses his vast fortune to make certain that Mr. Wickham marries Lydia.  He also gets Mr. Bingley and Jane back together.  Elizabeth finds out about both of these things.  Both she and Mr. Darcy start telling each the truth about how they really feel about one another.  It is not hard to deduce what happens next.All in all this is a great romantic film.  Jane Austen, tends to beat around the bush too much.  This film takes out all unneccessary running around and it gets right to the point without changing the plot.  However if films where the primary focus is romance are not your thing I would advise against you watching this film.  If a person loves a good romance then I would highly recommend this film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After reading so many one-star reviews that called this film rubbish, I was curious to watch it and try to find out if this is really such an awful movie. Well, it is.  In fact, "awful" is too mild a word. "Abominable" is more like it.Everything in this film is appalling. All the characters were badly cast. Mr. Bingley was a teenaged idiot. Mr. Bennett seemed to be on drugs most of the time or just senile. Mrs. Bennett looked and behaved like a fishmonger's wife, no manners whatsoever. Mr. Collins was humorless (capital offense!). Lady de Bourg looked like Marie Antoinette who had somehow escaped the guillotine and talked just like M. Keira Knightly spent 50% of her screen time trying to be cute, and the other 50% to be sexy by keeping her mouth half open in a clearly orgasmic expression (she was supposed to be Ms. Elisabeth Bennett, my goodness, who was anything but a sex-kitten!). But the worst of all was Mr. Darcy:  he couldn't act for the life of him, and he looked like a cross between a hound and Peter Lorre! In fact, all the moments of comic relief in this movie came from this non-entity of an actor. I laughed out loud when I saw him walking across the field in his open shirt, looking like Keanu Reeves in Constantine or in The Matrix, and I laughed again when he spat out from ONE corner of his mouth the line "You have bewitched me body and soul."  Yuck!I know somebody might argue that it is unfair to compare this film with the 6-hour A&E; version, but then, with all the money that was available to them, they should have tried to match, if not surpass, some of the pivotal scenes. Try comparing the wonderful Netherfield ball scene in the A&E; version, so charged with sexual tension, with an almost insolent yet refined Jennifer Ehle sparring with the love-sick Firth  and weaving in and out of the other dancers, with the same, but anemic one in this film, and you'll know what I mean. Worst yet: the liberties that both the director and the screenwriter took to "improve"on the original story were just preposterous and bizarre to say the least. For example, the very first scene showed Lizzie reading a book upside down WHILE walking (it was fortunate she did not walk into a pond or a tree); the first proposal became a shouting match with Lizzie working her mouth like a pump; Lizzie starting a conversation during church service and licking her fingers at table; Lady de Bourg visiting at night; Mr. Darcy entering Lizzie's room to deliver his letter, etc. And what was that scene with the pig with inflamed organs? And the room with nude sculptures? Clearly, they were trying to sex up the story. I wouldn't be surprised if their next project should be a porn version of Snow White. Oh, I forgot, someone did that already.The whole film has the feel of a two-hour commercial for Nissan cars or Prada products, with the camera focusing almost obsessively on  Keira Knightly's face and CGI effects added to "enhance" the scenery (the flying geese in the pond scene are clearly one of such doubtful achievements).A waste of time. Not the worst movie I have ever seen, but a pretty good runner-up. As to money, I congratulate myself for having to pay only 9 bucks for a previously-viewed copy from Blockbuster. Even that was too much for such a lousy film. The screenwriter should be banned from making another "adaptation" of any classic of literature for life and the director from making any new movie for ten years, until he acquires the good sense that only age can provide.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: P&P; is one of the jewels of English literature. It's very robust in that it is so open to different slants on it. This movie is a new slant and adds beautifully to the Ehle/Firth BBC interpretation. It's the more moving. Jennifer Ehle was my own perfect embodiment of Lizzie but Keira Knightley adds a dimension of extraordinary unfolding of the internal turmoil of Lizzie and her kindness -- the scenes with Jane are so subtle in their deep love for each other. Matthew Mcfadyen is a completely different Darcy from Colin Firth's but far more resonant. It is interesting to see Judi Dench in the film as the dreadful Lady Catherine. I am an old Brit who saw her in many performances on stage -- I think Keira K signals in this film that she is in the same league and on the same growth path.Critics of the film point out that it plays around somewhat with the tone and storyline of the novel. True, but it also enhances one's perspective on this great work. The movie is too kind to Mrs. Bennet but does articulate the truly desperate issue of marriage as the only career chance for young women. Donald Sutherland is a little underplayed especially in not showing his contempt for his wife but brings out so well his love for Lizzie. This is also the best portrayal of Jane I know of.And so on. Yes, this is not the literal adaptation of P&P; but it really is a superb accompaniment to and enhancement of it. Jsne Austen was in no way a romantic but a shrewd and cool observer. She is Mozartian in that the cool and controlled surface is moving in that the depth of feeling their work hides but dignifies is so intense. Only in her last and apparently semi-autbiographical novel, Persuasion, does one get a sense of the depth of her regrets and the pathos of her short life. I think that the main contribution of the Keira/Matthew combination is to bring P&P; closer to Persuasion and unpeel Austen's deep insights into and regrets about love in an age where feelings were so rarely expressed.This is a lovely and loving film. It is almost Chekovian in its style. I hope Knightley doesn't get nominated for an Oscar for her portrayal. It's far too good for that. I also hope she will pick scripts that help her grow beyond the Oscar-ready stuff.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Several years ago, I was involved with a lady who told me that I needed to see this movie, as she thought I reminded her a lot of Darcy. (We both HATE to dance, among other things) I was, shall we say, reluctant to believe her, but curiosity got the better of me. After all, I had to see what she was talking about.Now keep in mind that I was supposed to read this book in high school and as a seventeen year old male, I refused on sheer principle. What did I care about some romance book about a bunch of girls who want to marry rich. Who cared?All that said, this movie is a GREAT adaptation of the book (which I have since read, again out of curiosity) It makes the characters both modern and classic without diminishing either quality. The supporting cast is understated, but outstanding. Both Sutherland and Dench deliver superlatively without taking the limelight from Knightly or Macfadyn, to whom the film truly belongs.Even if the thought of having anything to do with Jane Austin makes your skin crawl (as it did with me), give this a try. Guys, if nothing else, this is two hours of the always watchable Kiera Knightly. You could find worse uses for your time.
summary: A period piece romance that even a guy can enjoy

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austin's Pride and Prejudice is a comedy. A romantic comedy. This was not.1. The BBC version was probably the best version of Pride and Prejudice. It remains true to the characters and to the tone of the book. It would remain the flagship and reference point for all other P&P; based movies.  I am certain that Jane Austin would have loved it. *****2. I also saw Bride and Prejudice (An adaptation). Although, it was far removed from the BBC Classic, It actually remained true to Jane Austin for the most part. A Comedy. A romantic comedy and very delightful. The Jane Austen Society was so enthused and ecstatic after sitting through a screening, they offered Chadha a lifetime membership. . On my first watch, I was expecting a serious classic and hence was disappointed. But on subsequent viewing, I thoroughly enjoyed the light humorous take on P&P.I; would wager that Jane would approve of Bride and Prejudice. ****3. This version? Well.. It is a romantic movie...but it is not a romantic comedy. It was way too serious more like Bront. Many of the characters were downright loathsome (Lizy's mom and Collins).  In that sense it was not Jane Austin,  But nevertheless it was not too bad. If you are not familiar with the book or the BBC version, this movie stands on its own as a serious romantic movie and very very enjoyable ***I enjoyed all three, in the order I mentioned them,Greatest love stories ever told on film:http://www.amazon.com/gp/richpub/listmania/fullview/R2KA5HYKSJ862R/ref=cm_pdp_lm_title_1
summary: Not sure if Jane Austin would approve!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austin has long been an author beloved for the romance of her novels.  This movie certainly does the novel justice portraying sweeping landscapes and grandeur among the every day lives in the English countryside.  Knightley's portrayal of the well read thoughtful Elizabeth gives the role the true passion and charm it deserves.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There are so very many things wrong with this incarnation of the novel that it is difficult to know where to start. Austen's classic is butchered and it's wretched carcass thrown to the crows in this miscast and poorly directed adaptation. Avoid.
summary: It is a truth universally acknowledged that a film in receipt of a fortune must be in want of a remake

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I knew that I wasn't going to like it, and still I watched it. I tried! They got it all wrong on so many accounts that I am trying to figure out where to begin. I really didn't care for this portrayal of the characters, they made the mother look like a sweet little lamb just trying to get her daughters married, Mr.Bingley like a bumbling idiot,and the three youngest girls act like children! Keira Knightley is beautiful, but a woman with that kind of flat chest would have been considerd deathly skinny, and not a man would have wanted her because she has no figure. They also portrayed the Bennets as being poor. Which is incorrect because the man didn't expect to have five daughters and therefore didn't make provision for there dowries.They were actually supposed to be upper middle class people. Lydia Bennet bothers me as does the relationship between Lizzie and Her father. They are supposed to be close, but through out the whole movie there relationship seems strained until towards the end where her father says that he will miss her.Boom! Right out of no where. And Lidia Bennet is supposed to be tall and good looking for her age, that's why she can attract the officers like flies. She flirts and looks cute. But no! The actress that plays her looks like she is a tall twelve year old. And speaking of looks, were they trying to go ugly when they cast Darcey? I thought he was supposed to be rich AND handsome. And if the guy that played Mr.Wickham would have wanted me to run away with him, I would have cried from insault! But, on a lighter note, they did cast Mr.Collins well. He is about as creepy as a little man can get. And this movie has some great cinematography. But the cons definantly weigh out the pros. I almost winced whenever Lizzie or Darcey spoke their lines, their delivery was awful. If you want to see THE BEST adaptation of a truely great story, stick to the unmolested version. Stick with Colin Firth and the BBC version.
summary: Oh! Is Hollywood Really This Bad?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a longtime Austen enthusiast I looked forward to this film.  But at least in my view it is not at all true to her wonderful novel.  The best of the dialog is lifted from the book, but the actors deliver it at a flat, hasty manner.  The rest of the dialog is anachronistic and stupid, with too many panderings to 21st century conceptions of romance.  The pauperization of the Bennett parents was completely unnecessary to point out the particular situation of their daughters. A few comments about the entail would have been sufficient.  In addition, the parents (the most amusing characters in the novel) are totally miscast in this film.I made the mistake of buying the DVD.  I would suggest that Austen fans try before they buy.

I would have preferred a little bit more characture and story development but what the film makers decided to include is so well done all is forgiven.  A very beautiful version of a classic story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride & Prejudice is one of my favorite books, I've read it at least a dozen times.  This film version is very faithful to the main storyline and the important side stories as well.  Brenda Blethin (sp?) does a fantastic job as silly, vapid Mrs. Bennett and Donald Sutherland is spot-on as snarky Mr. Bennett. Keira Knightley is not a favorite actress of mine but she does a fine job as heroine Elizabeth Bennett.  Matthew McFadyen is a smoldering, tense, and prideful Darcy.  When he finally relaxes and smiles, your heart melts!  Simon Woods and Rosamund Pike do a beautiful job portraying sweet and affable Mr. Bingley and Jane, respectively.  Caroline Bingley is snotty, proud, and gorgeous.  Dame Judi Dench as Lady Catherine is superb.  She is derisive and arrogant in full measure.  When she confronts Elizabeth...watch out!I ordered the digital copy of this as well as the dvd copy.  The scenery, settings, and music are just lovely.  You will want to watch this film again and again.  And then probably once more.  =)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I made the mistake of paying two bucks to rent this. I don't know how anyone could give it more than 1 star, or how Knightly got an Oscar nomination. This was miserably miscast, misdirected, and poorly acted.The script follows the novel only loosely, omitting so much of the story that I doubt someone unfamiliar with P & P would even know what is going on. Instead of showing the Bennets as gentlepeople, this version has them living in a farmyard with a pig wandering into the house. The historical detail is a mess, too. This film has Darcy proposing to Elizabeth at dawn in a field with both of them in their pajamas.A real travesty of one of the finest novels in the English language.
summary: Ghastly. Awful. Like viewing a corpse of Pride & Prejudice.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This will go down as one of my most favorite movies.  I cannot compare this version to the previous.  They are both portrayed by different sort of people.  The acting in this version is superb and I recommend it to anyone single, looking to feel good all over.  Or to that housewife who is lonely, this kind of movie makes you feel so much better.The digital copy is a huge bonus!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Like most of the reviewers below, I liked this version a lot -- again, not as good as the BBC version, but it came mighty close.  I particularly liked the dance scenes, which I felt had so much life and passion to them that was missing in the BBC version -- the BBC scenes were much more genteel.  The main actors were wonderful (particularly Keira Knightley).  The close ups of Dame Judi Dench were a little hard to take on the big screen, and I felt she played it over the top. My only other complaint was the last scene (I won't give it away) -- but it was way too modern for my taste and didn't seem to fit the period.  But all in all, a wonderful movie, I do recommend it highly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Pride and Prejudice Rules (The book and 2005 ...
review_text: This movie is the best movie I have ever seen. The actors are great, specially for Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfellen. I think that the movie gave a totally new look at the story. Whenever I watch old or set in older times movies I always think, ah! That looks so fake! Oh, its boring! But with this movie, after a while, you get observed in it, and practically believe that it IS the 1800s. Everything has such a great, fresh look to it, unlike the 1995 BBC version, where its all chocolate boxes instead of real life settings. The portrayal of Mr. Darcy is perfect as Matthew Macfellen! He totally shows what my idea of Mr. Darcy was! Colin Firth (no offence), to me, seems more like not gay, but different from what Mr. Darcy really is.I always thought Mr. Darcy as a manly man, like Mcfellen. I LOVE the way he looks at Elizabeth and how he can show everything he is feeling with his eyes. I'm really happy that they decided to keep the characters to their Austen ages because I hate it when I watch movies and they show people like really old or really young. I think that Knightley did an awesome job as elizabeth, just like i imagened her. The 1995 BBC series Elizabeth totally doesn't fit my image of her.I love how the movie ended because I really liked the book but when I read it, I thought that the only thing it lacked was, exactly, a kiss. At least its better than Colin's 1800s wet t-shirt contest contestant scene!!Overall I LOVE this movie and this adaptation. Its greatly acted, great scenery, great costumes, and great portrayal of characters. Also it does a great job of adapting the book because the script really sticks to the book. A lot of people don't like the movie because its 2 hours long and they claim that it should be longer and that it cuts a lot off, but I think its great! You can watch it with your family, friends, etc. etc. If you really want to know everything, you should read the book instead of watching a chocolate box, wet t-shirt contest adaptation because you shouldn't be lazy and sit with a bowl of popcorn getting fat for 5 hours because you don't want to read the book! Read it! Also, the 2005 p&p; is MUCH better than the sucky 1995.Go watch and buy the Dvd for pride and prejudice!:)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I would have loved to live back in those times.  Women acted like women & were modest & respectful.  They treated men the way men should be treated & waited for a husband, instead of running around with different men. Families were involved in the choosing of a spouse.  What has our culture turned into now? Also, Mr. Darcy was a VERY attractive man.  Such a manly man with his attire & whole demeanor..& the way he reserved his emotions towards Elizabeth until the end.  I love a good love story & would definitely recommend it!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I like this version of Pride and Prejudice because it is so unlike the BBC version and also the book.In a word, it's wilder.Also earthier.Lizzie is much more interesting as a fey gamin who loves to tease people--and this is exactly what Kiera Knightley supplies.  Her shock at Mr. Collins's proposal is palpable.But the real revelation is Darcy.  Instead of the prig he usually seems, here he seems a smoldering, volcanic presence more like Mr. Rochester.Also the setting is smashing--Romantic lush outdoor scenes, very untypical of Austen.Also the earthiness is sublime.  Pigs cavort in the Bennets' house--reminding us WHY Mrs. B. is trying to marry her daughters off: the rigid class system that prevents them from owning land, and prevents them from working.

review_text: I don't think any person who participated in the making of this movie has ever read the novel.I like Keira Knightley as an actress, but her portrayal of Eliza was too wild. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Where is the Austen in this Austen "adaptation"? Little from the original, beyond the names of the characters, remains in this sorry attempt; characters are altered, society is turned on its head, and custom is thrown to the wind - in short, everything that made Pride and Prejudice the masterpiece that it is is discarded in favor of dramatic flare and overblown romantic nonsense. Which is all too bad - Knightley is a capable actress, and, with a script that was worthy of the name, would likely have made a very interesting Elizabeth Bennett. Alas, but this version is to Austen's novel (and previous film interpretations) what a preschooler's scribble is to the Mona Lisa.One of the beauties of Jane Austen's works was her depiction of social reality - the austere social boundaries, the condescension with which those who crossed them were met, the petty grievances and wiles of social climbers, etc., etc. The decision makers behind this film, however, apparently found that all far too tedious, and, in their wisdom, opted instead to introduce a host of classic elements of refined society, such as pigs in the house and a family full of eavesdroppers congregated about every door. While her family was mingling with the swine and fixing their ears to the nearest entryway, this Lizzy, unlike the intelligent but flawed Elizabeth of the book, preferred to simper and smirk more than anything else. Poor Mr. Darcy, however, fares no better, and wanders about aimlessly in this film, seeming at times as if he suffers more from bowel discomfort than symptoms of the heart. The rest of the characters fall into this pattern, seeming little more than absurd caricatures or parodies of the original.The scenarios are no less appalling than the characters. Gone are the societal strictures that governed life, and, in their favor, the annoying banalities of the ludicrously dramatized romance novel. The tedium of proposing in a parlor is traded for the excitement of proposing in the rain; the monotony of social calls made according to the custom of the day abandoned in favor of dramatic confrontations. In short, the authors of this script attempted to apply the formula of the trite, forgettable modern romance novel, with all of its absurd scenarios and fanciful gestures, to a masterpiece of historical social commentary, and a love story worthy of the name. In doing so, they failed to make either a compelling Austen adaptation, or even a tolerable romance.1/5 stars...try to understand the source if you're going to make a film about it...
summary: A cheap, overly dramatized romance masquerading as Austen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Don't waste your time with this nonsense.  The story is altered to the extent that none of the characters' actions make sense, none of the original ideals are portrayed, and no understanding of the novel's intent is achieved.  The A&E production was of such high quality that I easily recommend it to those who don't wish to read the book; there's simply no improving on that one, and this piece of trash should be forgotten by the movie-going public.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, first of all I'm a huge Jane Austen fan, as many are.  I've read everything she has written and have watched every movie I can get my hands on that is even loosely based on her novels.  Having said that, I'm not one to get into the realism of each scene and whether or not it was historicaly accurate.  I loved the movie.  Until the end.  I loved the cast and thought they did a brilliant job.  Until the end.  Was I the only person who was left in the theater going "That was the end?  Are they kidding?"  There was no kiss, no joyous words of love exchanged, nothing. You wait the whole film to see the end and they just cut it off, like they ran out of money or time and had to end it right there.  I'm all for leaving things to the imagination, but that was just mean.  How could they not kiss?!  There's no culmination of the love that has been built between them.  I left this movie feeling like something great had been built up and then just ripped away. Am I the only one who felt this way?  I can't imagine I am, but  I was disappointed when I left. So, great movie, bad ending. Or, lack of an ending, really.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: That being the case. I will always love the 1995 BBC mini series. I could not wait until Keira Knightley's version came to America. However, I do agree that it was shorter and left you wanting.  It was over too quickly and you felt sort of cheated.  I must say I thought the actor that played Mr. Wickam was much better looking than the Mr. Wickam of the mini series.Also, Judi Dench's Lady Catherine lacked character and was not a very good role for her so I was very disappointed. I'm a fan of Judi Dench's. And I really missed Colin Firth. Oh no one plays Mr. Darcy like Colin!  NO ONE.  So, Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth as far as I'm concerned still rein as the only true Lizzie and Mr. Darcy.I might add my sister is a great fan of the BBC version of Pride and Prejudice. She also was just getting over a treatment of chemotherapy for breast cancer and my niece and I decided to have a Pride and Prejudice Birthday party for her.  It was wonderful.  We all dressed in long skirts or dresses, white gloves, hats and we each brought a beautiful tea cup and saucer to the party.  At the end we drew numbers and whatever number was on the bottom of the saucer that matched ours we got to take home.  My sister was overwhelmed and very happy that we did that for her.  We also blew up a photograph of Colin Firth (whom she loves) signed it and framed it for her.  We put that beside her place of honor at the table which was ladened with scones and tea cakes, muffins and teas.  It was great and we plan to do it again this year!  It doesn't have to be anyone's birthday to have a Pride and Prejudice Party!  Step out of this world and into Lizzie's!
summary: Pride and Prejudice-No Other Love Story Matches It.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The BBC version is the definitive Pride and Prejudice. In this they try to second guess the master of prose by re-writing Jane Austen's superlative writing. It can't be done and the result is total garbage. Don't waste your time or money.
