title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Colin Firth's Darcy versus Matthew MacFayden's Darcy is a matter of taste and endurance.  Colin, Jennifer Ehle, and A&E; articulate all the nuance possible for Jane Austen's text.  Matthew, Kiera Knightly, and director, Joe Wright cut through the fat and get to the meat, which is a good thing.  I have seen both versions (mini series and movie) and like them both.  It's a good thing that there are so many versions of this story available; this is a testament to the value of the basic story.Some may have problems with Joe Wright's 2005 movie version, but it is refreshing to see this interpretation/adaptation of the story.  The Bennets are brilliant cast as very rural gentry, which is what they were.  Moreover, Darcy and Bingley are not overly fastidious, as urbane gentlemen.  Judy Dench, of course, nails aristocratic Lady Catherine.  These are three levels of English society.  Social caste was critical during that time, so it is important that Wright emphasize levels such as aristocracy, urbane gentility, and rural landed gentry.  It is very credible in either version that these city boys (Darcy and Bingley) would prefer country girls rather than too polished city girls, as sometimes the artifice must stop.If pigs in the country offend, or museum-quality mansions on the other side of the country seem cold and unlivable, then stick with the A&E; version, which sticks very close to Jane Austen's book.  This 2-hour movie is refreshing, brief, and "artistic."

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First off, the casting: Keira Knightley was a good choice for Elizabeth Bennet. She would not have been my first choice after the lovely job by Jennifer Ehle in A&E;/BBC's 1995 version, but Keira played the part very well and I believed in her Elizabeth from start to finish! Matthew MacFadyen as Darcy: all I can say is WOW! MacFadyen is a relative unknown (I know him only as the gambling loser Felix Carbury in Trollope's "The Way We Live Now"): his portrayal was passionate, gritty, determined, loveable, heartfelt and moving: I was completely convinced and fell in love (as other Colin Firth fans will likely do so shortly). Added to these two top-notch choices is some other great talent: Rosamund Pike (Lady Harriet Cumnor in "Wives & Daughters") as Jane Bennet, Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet, Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet, Tom Hollander (Osborne Hamley in "Wives & Daughters") as Mr. Collins, and Judi Dench as Lady Catherine de Bourg: the only somewhat puzzling choices were Rupert Friend as Mr. Wickham and Simon Woods as Mr. Bingley...they seemed to make Mr. Bingley's character incredibly nave and almost silly in this film (which I must admit, did add some nice comic relief), whereas the 1995 P&P; chooses to make him only too apt to believe the best in everyone too easily influenced by others. Mr Wickham was only slightly likeable to me, and was not given enough screen time for us to truly believe why Elizabeth defended him so much to Darcy. The cast was rounded out with Jena Malone as Lydia Bennet, Talulah Riley as Mary Bennet, and Carey Mulligan as Kitty Bennet, as well as a few others.The overall storyline and feel: I thought they did an excellent job condensing the storyline into a theatrical movie-length version. I was mighty impressed with the screenwriter, and was not surprised to find out that Emma Thompson (who wrote the screenplay for 1995's "Sense & Sensibility", as well as giving an Oscar-winning performance as Elinor Dashwood) did an un-credited and unpaid rewrite of the new "Pride & Prejudice" script: she is given a special thanks in the end credits. The cinematography of the film was well done, with gorgeous scenes and imagery created: the soundtrack score is excellent, soft and unassuming, but seems to blend perfectly with the film: highly recommended. There is little that I would like to change overall: a few content issues (as described below), and otherwise, my changes would be: 1) the final scene: it is a bit too modern-feeling, and not true to Jane Austen as it should be 2) one scene where Lizzie reads a letter: she is upset & crying, only I thought it felt a bit stilted and not quite credible 3) Lady Catherine's speech to Elizabeth: I felt it could have been stronger, and have more "umph" behind it. Set design and costumes: the costumes work perfectly with the mood and feel of the film: at first I was a bit disappointed that they put Elizabeth in so much brown, but it works very well with the grit and feel of the film (and makes it seem much more real), and there are times (like at the Netherfield Ball), when you get some gorgeous white & light-colored costumes on the characters (including a beautiful snow-white dress on Elizabeth, with a lovely upswept hairdo). I thought the set design was very well done, and loved the very realistic feel of the film: the comparison between the Bennet house and Pemberly is quite drastic and added to the credibility of Darcy's wealth.For those of you interested in "family-friendly" remarks, read this paragraph, otherwise you can skip to the next one. Content: There is one scene with a character walking through a room full of white, marble statues, mostly nude, and admiring them: mostly the shots show behinds, though some naked breasts are shown as well in a ceiling painting. There is one use of a*s, and little else in the way of language. There is some dialogue that alludes to the fact that an unmarried man & woman ran off together, not necessarily with any plans to get married, but it is eventually resolved; there is some cleavage shown, but nothing too drastic. All in all, the content is kept to a minimum.This beautifully-filmed and well-acted movie is well worth the time & effort of going to the movie theatre, in a day and age when there is often little that does such. The romance they created in a few scenes was, I felt, beyond compare. For those of you who loved & enjoyed A&E; and BBC's 1995 version of "Pride & Prejudice" with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, you are in for a treat: there are enough differences in the movies to make them both loveable, but enough similarities in dialogue that you don't feel you are missing anything. This new film & soundtrack is highly recommended (I bought the soundtrack from Amazon UK a month ago, as it is being released Nov 15th in the USA): this movie will also end up being a must-add to any woman's DVD collection!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A little over two hours is not enough time to fit the whole story in....but I enjoyed it.  Still prefer the Colin Firth version though.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, Emma, and Sense and Sensibility.  She rivals Shakespeare as the greatest artist of English literature.  Both writers were concerned with basic human motivation, but Austen limited her observation to what she knew best, the courtship of 18th Century men and women of all classes.  She particularly enjoyed matching rather struggling middle class girls with the Bill Gates of their day, the local nobility.Keira Knightley makes a lovely Elizabeth Bennet.  She's has every virtue and flaw that her love match, Mr. Darcy possesses, and there is the problem.  They are so alike, they are blind to each other's virtues initially, obsessing upon their human foibles instead, mostly their unmitigated pride.  But what smitten couple of any century is any different.  Ah, Austen is universally appreciated since she spotlights what most Earthly inhabitants will encounter one or more times in a lifetime, love.I think I may prefer the Laurence Olivier version made in the 1930's.  After all, his Darcy is superb, never to be duplicated, but this newer version uses modern color cinematography to advantage.  Jane Austen is always worthwhile.  This is an excellent rendition.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is such a great movie. I have always loved the book since I ever read it and when I watched the movie, thought it was such a lovely piece of work acted out well. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I sat down to watch this movie tonight and was blindsided by an obnoxious marketing gimmick called BD-Live. The DVD automatically downloaded a preview of "Get Him To The Greek" from the internet and started playing it. There was no option to access the DVD menu or skip the preview. What does a raunchy comedy about rock music have to do with "Pride & Prejudice"? Why is this DVD downloading software to my computer without my permission?I purchased this movie on SD DVD years ago and I looked forward to enjoying the better picture and sound quality of Blu-ray. Since I can't find any way to disable BD-Live in my Windows Media Center preferences I am returning the Blu-ray copy of "Pride & Prejudice" as defective merchandise.

review_text: Jane Austen's book is so amazing that it can be made into a movie over and over and still not be boring.  I have watched this particular version many times and I love it!  This is one movie that will not sit on the shelf.  This is a classic romance story which is exquisitely acted by the entire cast.  If you love English period movies, then this is perfect for you.
summary: fabulous remake of a classic novel

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I absolutely adore this movie and it's characters, so I purchased the video as I do with the ones I would like to see more than once.I strongly recommend this video for the romantic in everyone.  Matthew MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy is just delicious, from his looks to his voice he's just dreamy.  20 year old Keira Knightly us unbelievably adorable and beautiful as Lizzy -- Miss Elizabeth Bennett, Mr. Darcy's love interest.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While the screenplay had to be adapted to fit the time constraints of a feature movie, the screenplay preserves the Austen dialog in most major scenes. The acting is superb and very believable; it gives more depth to the characters. Jane Austen, herself, critiqued "Pride and Prejudice" after it was published, by saying it lacked shadows or depth. Director Joe Wright did a fantastic job at creating those moments between Elizabeth and Darcy, so the movie takes the viewer on a roller coaster ride that is very believable. Brenda Blythe and Donald Sutherland do outstanding jobs in their roles as Elizabeth's parents. One last thing: the music is out of this world. It's far superior to any previous adaptations.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have always loved this Jane Austin book and the original movie with Greer Garson.  Although this movie takes license with the story, the chemistry between the main actors is stirring.  Great to watch on a rainy night with a glass of wine.
summary: Bought it to watch when I am in a romantic mood.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I give this movie a five star rating because the acting was superb, the story very close to the book, and the scenery and music was beautiful. There was not enough time in the movie for full character development, but the plot was played to perfection.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: How can you not love a movie when it starts off with a woman reading a book, completely distracted by her intellectual pursuits? Then imagine this woman walking with vibrant piano playing in the background and her dress flowing in the breeze. Put her in an idyllic country setting and then set up an impossible romance. Then surround her with four lively sisters who love to dance and live for the faintest moment of romance. There are so many scenes in which these women amusingly listen at doors or giggle while discussing men. It is simply made even more intoxicating when these women engage men in witty banter. Truly, Elizabeth is a radiant delight. There is one scene where she expresses her utter disdain for Mr. Darcy and they almost kiss. The tension is unbearable but I completely adored every minute of it. To top it all off, this movie is so superbly filmed it makes other movies pale in comparison. The timing in every scene is impeccable and the precision is an absolute wonder to behold. This is now my all-time favorite movie. It is just indescribably beautiful. This is truly a movie I will enjoy again and again. Thank you to the friend who sent this to me for my birthday! What a lovely surprise. If I could give this movie 100 stars I would!~The Rebecca Review

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: beautiful scenery... sweeping vistas but it does not give a good representation of the original work. I rate it just ok.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The only thing between Elizabeth and Darcy is their tender egos (pride) and misconceptions of each other (prejudice). A simple story based on the timeless theme that you truly come to know yourself through the eyes of the one you were destined for. Lizzie has her eyes on everyone around her, noting their flaws, and has a very small circle of people she believes in. Through Darcy she is able to see that she doesn't know everything, that she has faults and makes mistakes, but that she is still a person of integrity and worthy of love.
summary: I Love, I Love, I Love You

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It came on time and was in great shape! The movie was protected and there wasn't any problems at all. Great service and I would use them again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Anytime I want to feel better, I watch this movie. I could watch this movie a million times (Really!) and not get bored. When I was in high school, I read Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice". It was honestly one of the few books I've read in my entire life (and I've read many books in my life) that literally had my heart beat and race at a fast rate. I couldn't put the book down. Jane Austen was one of the best writers of all time. You truly feel, sense, and live through her writing when you flip each page of her books. Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfayden do an excellent job in this film. The whole cast is great, but it is Keira and Matthew's acting that make this film so beautiful and emotional. If I had a fantasy romance, I would want it to be like this film's version of "Pride and Prejudice". I've seen all the movie versions of "Pride and Prejudice", and this is absolutely my favorite version. I highly recommend this movie to add to your movie library. It's a true classic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was one of the worst interpretations of a classic novel that I've ever seen. If you have seen the Collin Firth - Jennifer Ehle characterizations of Darcy and Elizabeth, you'll probably not even sit through this DVD.  The leads of this abbreviated version of Pride and Prejudice are just not believable.  Knightley giggles her way through the Elizabeth role and doesn't really seem to understand the character at all. The script is choppy.  If you didn't know the real social commentary of the novel you certainly wouldn't get it out of this movie.  Don't waste your time!
summary: If You're a P & P Fan This Isn't Even Worth Renting...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This film is beautiful and highly enjoyable. The adaptation from Jane Austen's novel is very good. The casting was very good. Keira Knightley was an excellent Elizabeth Bennet and she carried the film. I daresay she's one of the most talented young actors of our time. Matthew Macfadyn's performance as Mr. Darcy was a little wooden compared to Keira Knightley's lively Lizzy. But I believe Mr. Darcy himself is a bit wooden so the portrayal is accurate. The lines were delivered wonderfully and I can't help but quote them from time to time. The score is beautiful as well and puts me in a very relaxing mood. I highly recommend buying the soundtrack. I now play it for my 16 month old daughter when I put her to sleep. It helps her to relax and wind down.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The American ending is just perfect!  The scene is the rain is superb!  Both lead actors really"become" Jane Austen's characters.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I hadn't read the book or seen the BBC version when I first saw this film, so I could only compare it to the old Garson/Olivier version. I think it is an improvement to have younger actors playing Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy (even though I'm a major Greer Garson fan). I definitely felt the chemistry! It might help that Kiera Knightly and Matthew MacFadyen are so lovely to look at.I'm thoroughly impressed with the director of this latest version. I was moved by the small gestures, glances, and lingering looks that said so much. Also quite taken with Matthew MacFadyen's grace and elegance contrasted with his awkwardness at times. He did an outstanding job portraying a sense of superiority as well as depicting his confusion and love for Elizabeth without words, though his deep sonorous voice has bewitched me....I agree, it was a more contemporary take on the time period, with informalities we would never have seen in those days--but easily overlooked. Beautiful cinematography, charming costuming, and pleasing soundtrack. The only thing that gave me trouble was the incredible quick pace. The diaglogue was often delivered too rapidly. This did not, however, diminish my appreciation for this beautifully directed, superbly-acted, utterly romantic film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After hearing sterling reviews, I decided to find out what all the fuss was about. I am SO glad I did. The music lets you know right from the beginning that this is a love story/epic, and uses period-style melodies that draw you into the narrative. The attention to period detail hasn't been so impressive since Polanski's "Tess". And the acting couldn't be more pitch-perfect. Indeed, Keira Knightly was the headstrong yet vulnerable Lizzie, and Matt MacFadyen managed to get better looking as the film went on, to the point that it was almost a distraction. We are seeing Darcy through Lizzie's eyes. Wonderful supporting performances from Brenda Blethyn, Donald Sutherland, and a particularly bitchy Dame Judi Dench, as well as everyone else, certainly add to this most pleasurable film experience. I'm hoping the Academy won't write this off as just another adaptation of a classic. This film can stand on its own as entertainment right alongside any of 'em. The DVD is terrific.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The main character in this movie is a person of few words and blunt statements, which is the opposite of what the main character of the novel is.  She should love language, revel in banter -- everything the film version does not offer.  Without this love of spoken language, the character is unbelievable when she actually speaks the lines of the novel's character in important scenes.  Suddenly, her speach becomes elevated and exacting, whereas she normally just grunts responses.  In fact, this is about the worst script version of the story have seen.  It seems that the makers of the movie didn't believe that a modern audience could appreciate a literate character, so they dumbed her down.
summary: This Production Dumbs the Main Character Down

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Richard W Little "I am a maple leaf on the wi...
review_text: I quote Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. Last month my fiancee and I went to see the film, starring Keira Knightley and company.Any period piece film adaptation draws an inevitable comparison against its novel roots. I have to say that, for the most part, the film does well with its translation. I had been concerned with the casting of KK in the lead heroine role here, but she does a good job with the material, and the emotional range she conveys with her facial expressions rather caught my attention. The rest of the main cast are solid choices as well, and it is nice to see a fellow Canadian, Donald Sutherland, continuing to find work at his age! I was left wondering if Dame Judi's character was supposed to be so one-dimensional, as it has been a long time since I've read the book, but it's only a little nit, nothing more. Matthew MacFadyen, does an excellent job with Darcy, leading us to see a complex character from a distance, literally, as the characters' pride keeps the two main characters apart so often.My main complaint is with the ending. If the movie had ended with the novel's ending, it would have been perfect. The "Hollywood ending", with "the big kiss", sticks a dagger into the spirit of the times, and of the writing--romantic love was supposed to be implied, not shown. Not sure what the movie makers were thinking--did they think this would be a big box office draw? Ah well.I do recommend the movie though. It's well acted, and well produced, and shot in spectacular scenery. It's, uh, safe for kids, but they'd better be able to keep up with "fancy talking"!
summary: "For what do we live, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our turn?"

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am old enough to be Matthew Macfadyen's mother but I am in love with him and his acting skills, not only in this movie but also his portrayal of all his characters.  Kiera Knightly is enchanting as Elizabeth Bennett along with great casting of all the other actors and actresses.  It might not encompass all the storylines in the book but it has captured the essence of a great love story.  I can't watch it enough!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must first confess that I am the typical man. True to my kind, my favorite movies heretofore tended to be triumphant accounts of victory such as “Miracle”, “Invictus”, “Secretariat” and of course “Gladiator”, coldly avoiding romantic movies as a waste of time!I only watched this film because Mrs. Douglas, my high school English teacher, required my class to read the book.  However, either I didn’t read it well or as a result of my failing memory I couldn’t recall what it was about.  I did, however, recognize the title as I clicked through the cable guide.  So, on a whim, I began watching it and shortly after the beginning I found myself captivated, frantically hitting the record button!I adore this 2005 interpretation of Jane Austen’s novel.  Keira Knightly is divine and Mathew MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy compliments her charming yet feisty portrayal of Miss Lizzie Bennet perfectly.Though previous renditions of Jane’s novel may be more faithful to the story line, the 2005 film boldly strays, offering a story deliciously saturated with laughter, riotous gaiety, humor and, of course, seething emotion.  I feel Jane herself would not have objected.  This version skillfully contrasts the grandeur and spectacle of Georgian England society through its display of the fictional estates of Netherfield, Rosings Park, and Pemberly to the earthy likes of Longbourn.  I know many criticize how Longbourn was represented in the  movie, but I felt it deepened the theme of the story.  So get over it!As for my avoidance of romantic stories, I’ve been so blind.  This movie has bewitched me, body and soul.  It’s an entrancing film, most completely and perfectly and incandescently wonderful.  As for the number of times I’ve watched it, guilt ridden, I can hardly be expected to own to it.It rises to the very top of my list!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have watched this so many times.  It is incredibly well-cast, and well-performed.  Undoubtedly the best version and makes the book a more enjoyable read.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautifully acted love story - very real - very touching ending!  It would be wonderful if all life stories could end this way!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I did think I would like this version as I love the A&E mini-series; however, I was surprised and find the are both equally enjoyable.  The scenery in this movie is beautiful the actors did a wonderful job playing their characters....can't wait to watch it again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have always loved this movie.  If you have not seen, I would recommend it to anyone.  Keira knightly is wonderful in this role.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The acting is decent, though the leads are not at all in the league of Ehle and Firth, from the BBC miniseries. The real problem, however, is that it is an adaptation that tries to shoehorn Pride and Prejudice into a two-hour film. The "set up" for  many situations is weakened or virtually eliminated, so many scenes lack the punch they should have. I think somone coming to Pride and Prejudice for the first time would be bewildered as to what the 200+ years of fuss have been about. Another serious problem is that this drastic condensing eliminates a lot of the comedy in Austen's novel (that the BBC miniseries preserved) -- the character of Mr. Collins is one example, as is the visit of Lydia and Wickham after their marriage. And the close relationship between Elizabeth and her father just doesn't exist in this one. I'm afraid the BBC miniseries still rules, hands down!
summary: Two hours can't do it justice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While this adaptation was not entirely disagreeable, I cannot understand why anyone would alter the best thing about Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice...the language, the dialogue.  I enjoyed the slightly grittier portrayal of a country gentleman's lifestyle, but the wholesale trashing of the beautiful language and dialogue used by Jane Austen is a tragedy.  Often times it seems like the screenwriter could not come up with words for the character.  Word of advice...use Jane Austen's original words.  They are perfect.  It seems like scenes were cut short in order to show Lizzy spinning on a swing, looking at a sunset, etc... Though these scenes were pretty, they did not justify cutting out classic scenes.  It seems like the director wanted to do a stylish film, and it succeeds to a degree on this level.  But, this adaptation falls flat on so many levels.  The definitive adaptation of Pride and Prejudice is still the A&E version with Colin Firth.
summary: Don't mess with Jane Austen's use of Language and Dialogue!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I loved the movie. It gives flesh and bones to the book and to see the emotions played out in the movie makes the book come alive for me.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I want to start by saying I loved this movie.  It was not really true to the book, however.  I hadn't read the book in over 20 years and so pulled it off the shelf to reread it.  They certainly used many quotes from the book, however it was rarely the correct character who spoke them.  Still, it was a lovely movie.  They made Mr. Darcy seem more awkward and nervous than haughty.  He was definitely not as sweet in the book.  He was a snob.  That doesn't seem as obvious in this adaptation.  I hope many people enjoy the film and will read the book as well.  Both are a delight!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie so closely followed the novel that I enjoyed re-reading the novel.  Also enjoyed the natural and more historically accurate scenes -- the laundry, the servants, the dining scenes and the simplicity of the clothes.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My wife picked up this title (from amazon) and I was actually surprised that I liked it.It's one of those titles that a person like me would do a pass on, and that is often a shame.  I'm sure I'm missing many films that are quite good.The acting is excellent, the sets are very British, the whole movie is actually very well done.As for the story...well done as well.  I'm not a fan of Jane Austin so I had no idea how things would work out, but i figured they would work out and they did.I can draw a line from this narrative to movies like Love Actually or Four Weddings.enjoy.
summary: Hey, I liked it, a lot

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In the past week I have seen a movie that I thought I was going to love but ended up disliking and a movie that I thought I was going to dislike but found myself loving.  The former was BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN, which I found physically beautiful to look at, but whose characters I found to be uninteresting and bland.  The latter was PRIDE AND PREJUDICE.  The reason I thought that I was going to dislike it was the existence of an absolutely superb BBC mini-series, which seemed to me to be the last word on what could be done with Jane Austen's masterpiece.  I was wrong.  Not only is there room for a truly great six-hour television version but also for an excellent two-hour cinematic version.I still prefer the BBC version.  There are two reasons.  First, there probably will never be a better Mr. Darcy than Colin Firth.  Laurence Olivier might have had a shot in the 1940 Hollywood version, but that film was destroyed by an almost inconceivable rewriting of many of the key elements (the worst being making Lady Catherine de Bourgh into a matchmaker between Darcy and Elizabeth).  Matthew Macfadyen is an extremely capable Darcy, but it was as if Colin Firth were born to play the part.  The other advantage of the BBC production is time:  there is simply no way that a two-hour movie can do as good a job of adapting the novel as a six-hour production.  In watching the BBC version, one gets the sense that almost nothing of importance gets left out, whereas with the movie I found myself constantly regretting parts of the story that had of necessity to be left out.Nonetheless, there is no questioning the excellence of this new movie version.  Simply because the series does a fuller job of telling the story does not mean that this movie cannot excel in a shorter time span.  The film definitely feels abridged, yet one also feels that most (though certainly not all) of the most important bits have been retained.  With most adaptations of a novel this might not have been such a problem, but PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is one of the best known and beloved novels in the English language (I have read it five times, see the Garson-Olivier version twice, and the BBC version three times).  Given the time restrictions, I believe the movie did as good a job as is possible.The film does have some advantages over the television version.  First, it is remarkably gorgeous to look at.  Whether we are beholding household interiors or shots of the countryside, this film was a delight to behold.  Also, with the exception of Jena Malone as Lydia and the aforementioned Colin Firth, most of the performances in the film version are a bit stronger.  I wouldn't say Keira Knightly is better than Jennifer Ehle, but she is definitely a different Elizabeth.  Let's just acknowledge that both are superb.  I recently saw Kelly Reilly (actually, all of Kelly Reilly) in the wonderful MRS. HENDERSON PRESENTS.  Here is plays Miss Bingley and does a fine job.  Rosamund Pike is excellent as Elizabeth's slightly more beautiful sister Jane.  Well, she isn't noticeably more attractive than Keira Knightly, but she'll do.  Two supporting performances stand out.  First, Tom Hollander was superb as a completely different kind of Mr. Collins.  In all other versions, Collins is presented as an utter buffoon.  In defense of previous versions, Mr. Collins is a buffoon in Austen's novel.  But it is nice to see him as slightly less absurd.  And Brenda Blethyn, one of the great actresses of her generation, manages to make Mrs. Bennett into more than merely a silly cartoon.  In his book ASPECTS OF THE NOVEL, E. M. Forster makes a distinction between flat and round characters and argues that Jane Austen loves to mix the two types.  His example of a flat character is Mrs. Bennett.  And while it remains true that Ms. Blethyn isn't able to transform her into a deep character, she does keep her from being the silly twit seen in previous versions.  The one other character that did not appreciably improve upon the BBC production was, surprisingly, Judi Dench's Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  Part of the problem is that most of her scenes were shot in a somewhat subdued manner; partly she obviously decided not to play the role as a broad character.Finally, the movie works in very large part because of the chemistry between Keira Knightly's Elizabeth and Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy.  Though one genuinely misses the many big scenes early in the story in the BBC production where Darcy's pride is made manifest and Elizabeth forms her prejudices, in the romantic portions they are great together.  Also, Knightly is one of the few actresses to play the part and be the age that Elizabeth is actually supposed to be.  All in all, they click onscreen.So, I guess this should be a lesson that you shouldn't prejudge a film.  You actually can be surprised.  In fact, in the past couple of months, the two films that I most enjoyed in the theater were two that I didn't expect to like, the other being KING KONG.  So I suppose this is a lesson previously learned that has now been reinforced.
summary: A movie I loved that I truly expected to dislike

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you're an Austen newbie, this film may be acceptable, but as one who has read all of Austen's books numerous times and seen many film versions of the movies, I found this version to be very common, low-class.  It has none of Austen's charm and wit.There wouldn't have been enough smelling salts in the early nineteenth century to revive Jane Austen if she saw the pendulous pig testicles that somehow became a part of this tale.  I think that shot somehow set the tone for the movie.Mr. Bennett is not a common farmer, and he is not a drunk, although he looks like one here - he is unshaven, unkempt and wears a vacant expression throughout most of his scenes, with the exception of the near-end scene when Elizabeth and he discuss her engagement to Mr. Darcy.  Until that scene, the script all but ignores the fact that Elizabeth is his favorite daughter and that they have a close relationship.  Then, after largely remaining distant from his family for nearly the entire film, he suddenly turns emotional, tearing up, pressing his fingers to his lips and putting a hand to his chest like a teenaged girl.  This is the first time I've disliked a performance by Donald Sutherland.The other problem that stood out for me were the Kitty and Lydia characters.  These girls are silly young women, but they were not raised by wolves.  The depictions were way over the top and completely socially misrepresented the period in which this movie was set.  Their constant raucous laughter and total lack of social decorum would have fit better with modern-day 12- or 13-year-olds.My final criticism of this film is that with the exception of Jane and Mary Bennett, the girls' hair looked ratty throughout the film.By way of small compliments, I will say that this film did a couple of things better than the A&E; version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.  First, it toned down the irritation factor of the Mrs. Bennett and Mr. Collins characters, which could have been acted more subtly in that version.  Second, it at least gave us a handsome George Wickham, which he is meant to be.  (A&E;'s version of George Wickham vaguely resembles my imagination's Ichabod Crane, and it was barely believable that Elizabeth Bennett or any other woman would have been attracted to him.)Overall, if you want to have an Austen film experience that captures the spirit of Jane Austen's amusing and genteel - not common - book, you're much better off with the A&E; version. While much longer, it captures the details that are so essential to the story.  And maybe that's another small part of the problem with this version - trying to cram this rich of a story into the typical feature-length movie format:  For me, this film felt like the script was written by someone who'd barely skimmed the Cliff's Notes.
summary: If You're an Austen Reader, Skip It

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The first time I saw this movie I thought it was boring but had not seen it from beginning to end. I love period movies so it kept my curiosity up and I watched it again, and again, and again because I could not get enough of it. Sometimes first impressions are not correct!  I love to watch Kiera Knightly in just about anything and also became a fan of another great actor, Matthew McFayden whose voice is absolutly mesmerizing. His charachter in this movie is, at first, unlikable but you see the chemisty between him and Knightly develop and then all is forgiven. This is a beautiful love story set in the day when a woman's main mission is to find a husband at all costs and a time when husbands were chosen for daughters. In this movie 5 daughters were raised to be free thinkers and were able to choose the husband of their choice but if a suitor were to come along and proposed but was rejected by one of the girls, then the mother was beside herself. Knightly's charachter is ver strong and will not settle for just anyone and wants her heart to be the judge and jury when it comes to a husband,  A beautiful love story and highky recommended!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have now seen every filmed version of this, the Jane Austin masterpiece, and have loved almost every version, because no matter the actors, the love story, as it overcomes pride and replaces prejudice is eternal. The original film was the only big disappointment--but my father, who was an English teacher, loved it.  The "insufferably noble Greer Garson" as Pauline Kael called her looked more like Mrs. Bennet than Lizzie, but Sir Laurence Olivier certainly made a handsome if somewhat earnest Mr. Darcy.  In one BBC version, Judy Parfitt played the most imperious Lady Catherine and in the last BBC performance Colin Firth made men's and women's hearts beat as the truly inscrutible and mysterious Darcy.  However, this film has its own blessings.To begin with the Bennet household looks more like the eighteenth century truth of country living than the prettier versions.  Jane is truly vapid in appearance while sweet and trusting on an intimate basis and deserves the incredibly rich and awkward Bingley.  The other Bennet daughters are irritatingly silly and Brenda Blethyn is good--although I have seen more harried and neurotic performances.  But the Lizzie of Keira Knightley and the Darcy of Macfadyen are such that there can not be a dry seat in the house at the film's conclusion.  The impish nature of Knightley and the incredibly haughty disdain of Macfadyen make the final pairing something to long for, since it seems so unattainable.  Their youthful sexuality and the characters' cast iron personalities are lusty and appealing and their "climax" scene, in the pouring rain, in a verdant English garden is charged with emotion and longing--especially on the part of the viewer.  It should be pointed out that they are standing in a palladian "folly" in the garden which makes a delightful subtitle to their recognition scene.  Judy Dench chews up everything and everyone except Keira and is unfortunately denied some of her best lines when she has her final confrontation with Lizzie.  She would have delivered them in full throat throttle.  But these are insignificant notes to a beautiful production.  Lizzie and Darcy meeting on a foggy meadow is the stuff of romance and with these two actors the sexuality crackles like lightning.If you have seen the other versions of this film, please see this one to make the experience complete.  If you have never seen a version of this film, this is a great film to begin with--and then work your way backwards.  As for me and Jane Austin, Lizzie says it best when speaking of her obsequious cousin who is living on Lady Catherine's gifts: "I am sure that her blessings could not have been bestowed on a more grateful subject."
summary: Never is there enough pride and prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: ***1/2It seems like every time we turn around these days some filmmaker has been hard at work producing yet another adaptation of Jane Austen's most beloved novel "Pride and Prejudice."  And even though some of the versions have been quite good actually, one can still wonder if this glut is really all that necessary.  The book's two most recent incarnations came in the form of miniseries produced by the BBC, the first in 1980 and the second in 1995.  However, since 1940, there has not been a "straight" (i.e. set in the proper time period) version of "Pride and Prejudice" designed specifically for the big screen.  Well, now we have one, written by Deborah Moggach, directed by  Joe Wright and starring Keira Knightley in the lead role.This latest version is distinguished from the earlier efforts primarily by its grittier, grimier and grungier depiction of life in early 19th Century rural England.  With its peeling paint and dusty furnishings, the film certainly has a less prettified and more lived-in look than we are accustomed to seeing in movies based on Austen works.  Yet, perhaps because we have been spoiled by the marathon lengths of those earlier miniseries, this film, at a mere two hours and seven minutes, feels hurried and rushed as it attempts to cope with Austen's complex tale of the five Bennett sisters and their mother's frantic efforts to marry them off.  We are moved so quickly through the story that some of the more subtle details of character and theme get lost along the way.  Still, it's quite remarkable just how much of the plot Moggach is able to cram into a little over two hours, so that even the staunchest of Austen purists will have little to complain about on that score.What they may have reason to complain about is the fact that the film fails to capture much of the unique humor that distinguishes the novel.  For the most part, the scenes are played much too seriously and "straight," particularly those involving the odious Mr. Collins and the insufferably condescending Lady Catherine de Bourg, who together supply some of Austen's most bitingly witty commentary on the superficiality of England's class-conscious society.  Tom Hollander gives a spiritless, leaden performance as the sycophantic minister, and Judi Dench plays Lady Catherine as if she were taking a stab at Lady MacBeth instead.  The same goes for Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett, whose pivotal role as the droll, dry commentator on the absurd Mrs. Bennett's matrimonial obsessions seems to have been lost on the actor.  Matthew Macfadyen fails to make an impact as the haute Mr. Darcy, although Brenda Blethyn hits the right notes as the grating mother driven to despair at the prospect of her daughters ending up old maids.In the coveted role of the high-minded, strong willed and extremely judgmental Elizabeth Bennett - certainly the most brilliant and fully realized of all Austen's creations - Knightley clearly means well but doesn`t seem quite up to the task.  Her annoying giggle and epicene expression make her far too silly and modern to successfully portray the rational but often misguided 19th Century heroine Austen intended Elizabeth to be.Yet, despite all these weaknesses, "Pride and Prejudice" makes for a reasonably entertaining film, thanks, primarily, to the strength of the original source material and the liveliness of Wright's direction (the ball scenes are exceptionally well done).  The film moves quickly and does a decent job telling its story.  Perhaps if we didn't have better versions to compare it to, this "Pride and Prejudice" would stand up better on its own.  It's far from a failure, but watching this condensed version instead of the two BBC miniseries is a bit like reading the Cliff's Notes instead of the actual novel.  You may be able to get the general gist of the thing, but not that wonderful flavoring that makes the original so special.
summary: gets the plot details right but misses much of the humor

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Considering that a large majority--if not all--of the negative reviews given to Joe Wright's adaptation of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is based on their comparison to the ever-popular BBC version, I must defend the other half that finds this movie an absolute delight.First comes the matter of Wright condensing the novel to a point where it all seemed, I suspect, not enjoyable to many fans of the novel. But the fact is that Wright had two hours to portray Austen's rather lengthy novel as compared to the BBC version, which was a miniseries and, I believe, went through every single scene and detail of the novel. Not that I'm saying that there's anything wrong with that, but as a major movie fan, seeing Austen's book basically copied and pasted from the pages to a movie script, to me, lacks originality. Wright had his own original way of capturing the main plot of the movie in two hours, without dulling the characters in Austen's novel. Quickly going on a tangent, I will say that Wright's addition of the scene with Darcy and Elizabeth kissing was exceptionally romantic and it absolutely was consistent with their characters. But going back to the topic at hand: yeah, if BBC fans were disappointed that Wright seemed to rush everything, the truth of the matter is, he only had two hours. And yes, he could have included every little detail if he wanted to make the movie 5 hours.Concerning the issues regarding Keira Knightley's role as the ever-proud Elizabeth Bennet and Matthew McFadyen's role as the timid Fitzwilliam Darcy, from the negative reviews I have read, viewers are complaining that Knightley and McFadyen did not do the characters justice. However, I must strongly disagree. Knightley, the wonderfully talented actress that she is, fulfilled Elizabeth's role to the fullest extent that any person could. Elizabeth's proud and stubborn nature was fully portrayed by Knightley and I can't think of any other reason to be dissatisfied. Although, yes, Knightley might be a bit too beautiful to play the role of the more comely Elizabeth, that is just about the only possible flaw with Knightley's role as Elizabeth.As for McFadyen's role as Darcy, one reviewer stated that Darcy seemed "dull and generally uninterested in what's going on." Again, I must defend how Darcy was depicted in the film. To me, McFadyen acted out Darcy's role as his character is; initially, when the viewer is introduced to Darcy at the ball, he is seen as "dull and uninterested," which is mistaken by others--mainly Elizabeth--as pride and conceit. That was how the reader originally felt about Darcy in the book, and that is how the viewer originally felt about Darcy in the film. Others stated, "Austen's Darcy was well-spoken, proud and elegant, not in need of a Prozac." However, is it just my lack of memory, or was Austen's novel not written from Elizabeth's point of view? Therefore, as Elizabeth found out about Darcy's true character, so did the reader. Wright, I believe, tried to depict Darcy's actual character to the viewers throughout the entire movie, rather than have him portrayed based on Elizabeth's prejudices. Also, Wright's version of Darcy is `well-spoken, proud and elegant,' so I don't know why one would say otherwise. As for the remark on the Prozac, is Darcy's character not clearly revealed to the viewer when he is with Georgiana in his home? I don't know what else there is to say about that. And then there's the infamous comparison between Colin Firth's acting abilities as Darcy as opposed to McFadyen. I, myself, have only seen bits and pieces of the BBC version, and from what I can tell, Firth does seem like a worthy actor to play the part of the loveable Darcy. However, I found McFadyen to not only fulfill the role as Darcy incredibly well, but I also think that McFadyen's appearances are far more handsome than Firth.The next problem many viewers had was the lack of `spark' Knightley and McFadyen seemed to have on-screen. First of all, I don't think that Wright could have picked a better couple to play the parts of Elizabeth and Darcy; not only were Knightley and McFadyen's acting abilities flawless, but their compatibility on-screen was simply amazing. One reviewer even claimed, "[a]t the end of the mov[i]e they don't even kiss..." which is entirely wrong. In fact, it should be switched around; Elizabeth and Darcy aren't mentioned to have kissed in the novel, but kiss at the end of Wright's film.Wright's adaptation of Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is not only original, but also highly romantic and enjoyable. For the most part it follows Austen's novel, but for the parts that it didn't, so what? It is it's own individual movie and is an `adaptation,' not an exact replica of the book; if it were, it would just be boring. I think that if people would stop comparing Wright's movie to how off it is from the book or other adaptations, viewers would actually enjoy and appreciate Wright's brilliant piece of work.
summary: A thoroughly original and absolutely wonderful adaptation

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There has been some comment about Matthew Mcfayden not potraying Mr. Darcy as well as Colin Firth  , but I totally disagree with that . title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've never read Austen's book. For that matter, I've never seen the 6-hour BBC miniseries production, so I can't presume to say whether this is a great or faithful adaptation, I can't talk about what was left out (obviously, a lot must have been) and what was changed.All I can do is talk about this as a film. And, in a word, it's great. The directing, specifically, stands out: usually adaptations of classic literature like this is shot in a flat, stuffy, unimaginative way, but Joe Wright really uses the camera to illustrate the power and emotions in the underlying material. It's never showy, but there's a mastery at work here than I haven't seen in a literary adaptation since Scorsese's "The Age of Innocence." It's hard to believe it's his first feature.The acting is superb, and don't get caught up (as some others have been) about the minor moments in which this film isn't literally faithful to the book. Wright and his collaborators were obviously primarily concerned with making the film work on its own, and it does, wonderfully.This film is simply a moving, beautiful story, compellingly told. I can not rate it highly enough.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Sorry if the title of this review seems frivolous. As a male of the species I will get flack for this review. I am adding my bit just in case others like me like characters that are supposed to be principled individuals. The lead female Knightley and the lead male are both written in such a way, even if only on a superficial level.Still I think two parts of these characters really stand out. The leading males (Mr Darcy) somber attitude rings true of a man with a conscience and drive for ethics. This was really displayed well in the scene were he delivers an explanatory note of his actions, of how he dealt with the luitenent character, to Elizebeth (Knightly). His grave demeanor and desire to make her understand that his actions were ethically based was compelling.Second is the strong willed nature of the lead female. Displayed well in several scenes by Knightley. One of the best was when she learned Mr Darcy had broken up his sister and the doctor. She leaves the gathering and is followed by Mr Darcy, who in awkward fashion, tells her of his feelings toward her. She confronts him with the knowledge of his actions (breaking up the doctor and her sister). I can't think of many scenes as compelling. Two exceptional actors, performing to near perfection. Later Knightley is confronted with Denches character (expertly portrayed). Another scene done to near perfection. The most important scene of all, at least to me, is when she is visiting darcy's mansion, under the mistaken information that he is not there. She and her companions are walking through an art gallery on the premises. They stop at a marble bust (a likeness of Mr Darcy). Her companions ask if it is a good likeness. The brilliant acting skill of this young actress is perfect in this scene. Just in case someone of Objectivist persuasion reads this: Her characters obvious worship and respect for the man, who has proven his character to her, is displayed perfectly by Knightley.Though not the greatest plot, the acting by most of this cast is as good as it gets.Now I must watch some football.
summary: Chick Flick Invader (rare acting skill displayed)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I believe this is the best version of the beloved novel. The actors were spectacular, from Keira Knightley, Donald Sutherland, and the lesser known English actors; all wonderful.The settings were beautiful, the emotions expressed will leave you wishing you could have such a romance. And the ending is so powerfully sensual, without any need for the graphic, all skin-baring scenes in most modern films. Simply terrific.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was extremely disappointed in this version of Pride and Prejudice. If you are a fan of the book you will be in for a shock; there is a lot of "Artistic License" taken in this film.Kiera Knightly is a very pretty girl but, let's face it, she can not act.  She is constantly giggling in this movie in an obvious and over-acted way. It is very obnoxious. She is an extremely poor actress. They make Elizabeth out to be bookish and unkempt. In the book Elizabeth said herself that she is "Not a great reader" but that is exactly what they make her out to be in this film.She is not the only one in this adaptation that seems to struggle. Every time the girl who plays Lydia came on to the screen I wanted to throw something at it. She had a very over-acting-extremely-fake-British-accent. Someone really needs to tell her that overacting belongs on the stage. On Screen it is supposed to look like you are not acting.I was most disappointed that they destroyed the relationship that Elizabeth had with her sister Jane. In the book they were very close and in this movie they are no more than roommates.There are two redeeming things in this movie; which is why I gave it two stars instead of none. 1)Tom Hollander does a fabulous and hilarious job of being Mr Collins. He knows how to act, in fact he is a fantastic actor. 2) Mr. Darcy. In this version he is much more passionate about Elizabeth than in any other version I have ever seen.If you can stand it; see the film and watch the two leading men shine in their roles.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is not the most faithful adaptation of Jane Austen's book, but it is one of my favorites. I think it does a very good job of keeping to the main themes and events of a beloved book while still restricting itself to a feature movie length. In fact, I didn't really miss anything that was cut out, though it does seem to speed through time rather quickly.All of the Bennetts were cast well. Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennett is quite good. I felt she captured the right personality and mannerisms. Matthew Macfadyen is very good as Darcy as well. Loved Bingley and Jane, too. The music, scenery, lighting is all done well. Excellent version - definitely worth purchasing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is breathtaking, moving and exquisite. All the performances are perfection. Bravo a million times over.Yes the A and E production is the gold standard--a truly remarkable achievement in every way--but this film grabbed me even more. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Reflections upon First Viewing:*very beautiful film, wonderful color*satisfying melding of the common and the great: landscapes, housing, costumes, etc., allows for the disheveled as well as the pristine*satisfying cast*distracted somewhat by previous knowledge of both the book and the earlier BBC version; so difficult to avoid comparison*extraordinarily quick pacing in dialogue, gestures, behaviors and changes of scenery*Keira Knightley as Elizabeth Bennet a fiery personality*Sound Track understated, even sparse; a decision most agreeable*assumption that we know the story*presents as good abstract or condensed version of book (despite artistically based alterations)Reflections upon Second Viewing:*Elizabeth deliciously sultry at times*Jane Bennet (Rosamund Pike) quite the `babe'*crowd scenes so densely populated*Caroline Bingley (Kelly Reilly) - "weaned on a lemon"*Chapt 6 - removal of the crowd for a few moments at the dance a telling moment*Mr Collins (Tom Hollander) so satisfyingly smarmy*Chapt 9 - if ever eyes were incongruent with words . . .*Sisters delightful whether bonding or squabbling*Charlotte Lucas character (Claudie Blakley) nicely done*Dame Judi as Lady Catherine her usual delightful pedantic and dour self*Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennet not the usual immaculate stuffed shirt/neither his bookroom*a wondrous study in facial features (what if film in B & W?)*Chapt 11 - ArtWorks at Pemberley most revealing, as are Lizzy's reactions*Chapt 14 - Lizzy and Jane's bedtime conversation telling*Chapt 14 - Lizzy and Lady Catherine's heated dialogue some of the best writing and acting in this film*Chapt 15 - Lizzy's final conversation with Father most satisfactory*Chapt 16 - not bothered by the `kissing' scene/the Americanized romantic closure we crave*lack of printed DVD chapter list, cast list, etc., a shortcoming*Trailer on DVD Extras?*well considered, well produced and legitimate addition to the Austen VideographyReflections upon Third Viewing:*appreciative of why Lizzy would seek out and enjoy solitude and silence*adjustments being made, pacing more agreeable*development of secondary characters?*so much revealed to us without words!The film is worth your time, perhaps even in multiple viewings. I think you'll pick up far more that way, if you're willing.Four Stars, I think.Russell de Ville14 March 2006

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Even as abbreviated as it is, this version of Austen's classic story is a revelation -- for once, we have a real sense of the Bennets as a middle-class country family, with pigs and chickens in the garden and crowded, energetic rustic dances for amusement.  The Bennet girls' hair is disheveled, their clothes are plain and unadorned -- in short, they're real.  I had my doubts that both Knightley and MacFadyen would be suitable in their roles, but in the end they are the most purely romantic, emotional Elizabeth and Darcy ever (and yes, I'm a great fan of the Ehle/Firth version).  This is the only version that has ever made me cry!  I just love it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: After having watched the BBC's mini series, I din't expect anything else to even come close to it.But this movie was a pleasant surprise. Although some of the dialogues were cut short due to time contraints , the movie is a very faithful adaptation of Austen's classic.Keira Knightly is convincing as Elizabeth Bennet. The scenary of 18th centaury England was well captured. Mr Bennet and Mrs Bennet surpassed the perfomances in the BBC mini series. I shall be watching this over and over again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I felt that the crux of the movie was to be how much Elizabeth and Darcy did not like each other and how that changed over time. I never bought into that in this movie. I got the impresion they always liked each other from the start.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I LOVE this movie.  Not only is it true to the feel of the novel (be prepared for some slight variations, but nothing too disturbing!!!), but it was WONDERFULLY shot.  There are all these really beautiful, quick shots of the countryside and little details that make the story more real--lovely!  The movie, like the book, is quite funny at parts (enter the ridiculous Bennett sisters and mother . . .) and entertaining as heck!Finally, I just have to say, Matthew MacFadyen is my FAVORITE Mr. Darcy ever--he pulls off awkward-rich-guy very well and likeably from the very beginning, whereas other Mr. Darcies made me want to vomit, they're so arrogant.  And he's just adorable.A+ movie and well worth the money!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Simply put, this production of Pride and Prejudice is just lame. Mr. Bennet has not the wit, nor Darcy the charm, nor Elizabeth the grace of the characters in the book. There is hardly any romantic chemistry between Elizabeth and Darcy in this film; the movie relies on skillful editing instead of skillful acting to capture the audience. The brevity of the film and the resulting omission of parts of the original story leave this film flat. A much more charming, captivating, and true-to-the-original (albeit much longer) production is the BBC/A&E production, and I would recommend that one instead.
summary: The is production of P&P falls flat

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When a coworker told me that a new version of Pride & Prejudice was in the works, I took interest.  She then said that Keira Knightley would be in it.  I innocently asked, "Who will she play?"  "Elizabeth, of course."  "But," I protested, "she's too pretty to play Elizabeth." I was thinking that unless the screenwriter excises Darcy's offensive comments about Lizzie's looks, this casting choice would be unconvincing.  In the 1940 version (with Aldous Huxley as screenwriter), Darcy (Lawrence Olivier) says that he has no time to humor the middle classes, sparing Greer Garson the evaluation of being "tolerable, but not handsome enough..."This movie has many great qualities. It is far "earthier" than the A&E;/BBC 1996 production, as swine roam both outside and inside the Bennet's house, and the characters look like they've worked up a good sweat at the country dances. I also like how much more tender Mr. Bennet's character is than in the book and other productions.  Granted this is an apocryphal character interpretation, but I really liked it just the same. Donald Sutherland's take on Mr. Bennet is one of his finest performances of my awareness. Instead of continuing to chide Mary that the other ladies need a chance to exhibit their musical talents, he comforts his sobbing daughter.  Another point that I liked is that the characters really look their age.  Though I love and still prefer the A&E;/BBC production, all of the Bennet girls were played by grown-up women well into their twenties and beyond.  In this production, Lydia does look like a 15-year-old girl and Lizzie like a girl who's not yet one and twenty (with four younger sisters out, your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own my age).Due to time constraints, this movie didn't get the opportunity to really fine-tune character development and relationships. The A&E; Adrain Lukis' Wickham was so dastardly charming, yet Lizzie's initial attraction to (Rupert Friend's) Wickham and later repulsion towards him was put on fast forward and barely developed due to the movie's two hour time frame. And the man who played Mr. Collins in the A&E; production was brilliant--he apparently was cast because he was the only actor who could keep a straight face while saying some of "the most fatuous" lines Jane Austen ever penned. Also, Colin Firth is the hottest Darcy yet on film. Not to disparage Matthew Macfadyen, but Firth's Darcy is an impossible act to follow (though in his own right, Macfadyen did a good rendition).I enjoyed this movie and enthusiastically recommend it.  However, I still prefer all five hours of the 1996 version.
summary: Even w/o Colin Firth, still an enjoyable adaptation

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This one was ok.  It wasn't nearly as good as the one from 1996 with Colin Firth.  I think it might've been because this one was too short.  Mr. Darcy in this one didn't cut it, but I liked Kiera Knightly's take on Elizabeth.  She added some spunk to it, which was neat to see.
summary: Not as good as the one from 1996

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love the BBC version and I went into this movie knowing that nothing could compare to it.  Plus, there is no way you can take a 5 hour long movie and condense it to a 2 hr movie without losing something.  That aside, I really didn't care for there casting.  The chemistry between Elizabeth and Darcy was good, but I was really disappointed in the father.  He is supposed to be a witty, sarcastic man and in this movie he almost acts sluggish, brainless man who has very little thought.  I also didn't like the fact that they made the family look like they were poor with there drab dresses and run down house.  It almost made it look unbelievable that they would every even be seen associating with Mr. Darcy or Mr. Bingley.Darcy and Elizabeth were however very cute together, and while the movie seemed like it tried to pack all the high points in, which made it seem a little rushed, it was still a cute love story.  It's not the Pride and Prejudice most know and love, but it was still worth watching.
summary: This wasn't BBC but it was ok

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I wasn't so sure I'd like this version of the story, since I love the BBC production so much. But despite my reservations, I went ahead and watched it anyway. How I regret that decision. If I could it less than one star, I would. The story was rushed, and not just so they could trim it down to standard feature film length. The characters were portrayed all wrong, and I winced at their delivery on many occasions. The casting was okay, but how Keira Knightley received an Oscar nomination, and a BAFTA award, for this lackluster, uninspired portrayal of Lizzy is beyond me. She was dreadful. The writing was equally as bad, as they cut out many of Austen's original lines and scenes in order to put in their own weaker ideas. The scenery and cinematography were the only good points of the entire film. If you've never read the book, you'd probably enjoy this. If you have, don't bother. Skip it and watch the best adaption: the BBC miniseries with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: A condensed p&p, slightly adapted, still done very well. Nice cinematography.  Will watch again! Was missing the Hursts, not sure why?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Simply the best. The chemistry between Keira and Matthew was incredible and palpable. Donald Sutherland was at his best too.
summary: The BEST love story there is!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a Jane Austen Fan, but I am also a Colin Firth fan and a Keira Knightly fan.  I have yet to see Colin Firth's version of Pride and Prejudice, and am sure I will love it.  However, there is something about this movie that captures my full attention each time I put it on.  Every movement, facial expression, the complete immersion into the countryside and the period are rapturous for me.  Donald Southerland as I have never seen him before makes a wonderful father.  All of the girls are so much in love with each other and their family, yet each of them looks to the future with such hope in their own respective ways; although Lizzie's straightforwardness and honesty putting the appropriate people in their proper places at the proper times makes one wonder if she will end up the way her mother blatantly claims her best friend will, "a spinster in the making".  Each character seemed born to play their respective parts! It's just a coaster ride of emotions and engnnrossing film work, costumes (the ribbons) and dialogue that sweeps me up and I hate to see the ending draw nigh each time I watch.  I hope you get the enjoyment from it that I did, and cherish it for years to come.
summary: Every movement by every character engrossing and hypnotic

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must warn all who are considering this movie that are a Jane Austen fan and a purist, that this movie is NOT exactly the same as the book. However, though it is not exactly the same, I still find that this a lovely version of Austen's popular novel. Definetly one of my favorite movies in my collection so far.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is one of my favorite love stories. I can watch it over and over again and never get tired of it. Kiera does an amazing job too and has become one of my favorite actress to watch. She's got a great future ahead of her. I've seen other versions of Pride and Prejudice and I think this is the best hands down!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What a truly accessible adaptation this is.  P&P is one of my all-time favorite novels, so I'll be the first to admit that there is great license taken with some of the original content, perhaps particularly where characterization is concerned, but overall I think any changes made were reasonable and well-considered, and I can't quibble with them.  Most of the acting is excellent.  The cinematography is gorgeous.  The more "rustic" take on country life in Georgian England works very well , in my opinion.  This version is much less precious than any others I've seen, and of any others, this one alone does a decent job of portraying the attraction between Elizabeth and Darcy that is the center of the story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Yes, it's not the A&E; version....but who cares?  I am a long-time Jane Austen fan and own the DVD A&E; series, but I have to admit, the newer version tells the story in its own way, with its own interpretation.  Relax and enjoy.  I applaude them for their insight and ability to find the actors and actresses that placed a new spin on the story and the characters.  If you want the purist version, only watch the A&E;, but remember it has a good five hours to tell its story, where the movie had only two hours, and did the best it possibly could in that time allotment.There were vast differences from the original storyline, but I found it entertaining and refreshing.  I will purchase the newer version as soon as it is released.

title: Pride & Prejudice
