title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The current version of "Pride and Prejudice" starring Keira Knightley is a travesty. Do not see it in a theater, buy it, rent it, or watch it on television. It was a waste of time and electricity to make, and will be a waste of your time to see.There was a full-length version of "Pride and Prejudice" filmed in 1995, starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth, that remains not only unsurpassed but unequaled. It is perfectly adapted, cast, directed, acted, costumed, filmed, and scored. It preserves not only Jane Austen's intent, but the dialogue she wrote. Buy it and watch it instead.When she starred in the 1995 film, Miss Ehle did not have the blandly "beautiful" features or skeletal body of a model. She was, nevertheless, captivating as Elizabeth Bennet. The beauty--spiritual, intellectual, and physical--of the character she portrays increases in our esteem as we get to know her, just as it does in Darcy's. Elizabeth, as written by Austen and portrayed by Jennifer Ehle, was a mature and fascinating young woman, not a giggly,  petulant teenager with an eating disorder.Keira Knightley looks desperately in need of nourishment, and the "lollipop-head" figure does not work for the character she is playing. It's hard to believe that a girl of Elizabeth Bennet's time, place, and social class could have grown up so emaciated, unless she had a tapeworm.And, finally, there are many, including prominent professional critics, who commend this adaptation of "Pride and Prejudice" for its "realistic" portrayal of dirt, unkempt clothes and hair, farm animals wallowing in the living room, etc. In fact, it is not only historically unauthentic, it is false to Jane Austen. There were no such scenes of squalor included in the novel. To the contrary, Austen wrote a passage in which Elizabeth Bennet sets out on a long walk after a rain storm to visit her ailing sister, during which she soils the hem of her skirt with mud. This slight soiling results in a small amount of embarrassment for Elizabeth, who tries to let down her outer garment to hide it, and a great amount of derision behind her back by two nasty female residents of the house she is visiting. Had dirt and shabbiness been the norm in households like Elizabeth's at the time depicted, it is unlikely a little mud on the edge of a skirt would have attracted anyone's notice or rude commentary, and these events in the book would have made no sense. The fact that Austen wrote such a scene and had the characters behave as they do indicates that cleanliness and neatness of dress were normal and expected at that place and time, among that class of people.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Story lines moves to quickly. I keep comparing it to the bbc version and was very dissapointed. I'd rather watch the 6 hrs. version where you see the character develop. Besides, the Bennet household is portrayed as a pretty poor family which is not faithful to Jane Austen's novel.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The Jane Austen novel is one, that in my opinion, everyone should read. The first time I read this novel was when i was 8 years old, and though at first the colorful language of the story was difficult to comprehend, I must say, it was well worth the struggle. Now a 16 year old, I have read the book several times, and most recently, I have refallen in love with the story through the most recent production of Pride & Prejudice.Some say that they do not think that Keira Knightley being cast as Elizabeth Bennet was wise, but I think that she brought elegance to the role. She is beautiful, which differs with the book, but she does true justice to Lizzie. Her unique style of playing her is one of the reasons I was drawn to the film. I also believe that Matthew Macfadyen did a delightful job with Mr. Darcy. As the movie progressed, his softer side was revealed. Macfadyen and Knightley had chemistry that made the love passionate and real, without them, I doubt that I would truly be as fond of the film as I am.However, I must mention that I have not to this day seen the 5 hour BBC production, which I have heard is wonderful. I believe that the film is a great interpretation, and the young actors bring the passion of the romance to life. Like most have said, the socio-economic level of the Bennets could have been depicted better, and the entire Wickham story line was significantly shortened. Although despite these aspects, I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed the film. The locations used along with costumes, music, and cast created a masterpiece that I can guarentee you I will buy. I was disappointed when Knightley didnt get the Golden Globe for this movie, yet I guess that's all I can expect, for she is still a young British actress in an American society. However, Mark my words, her day will come!To this day, I have seen Pride & Prejudice 3 times, and only three because it became too costly to see it at the movie theaters. This fantastic movie quickly became one of my favorites, and I am confident that it will remain one.
summary: One to buy for the DVD collection

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The 2005 version of Pride & Prejudice is a great movie, to be sure, to help connect modern audiences with this masterpiece. Indeed, I hated Jane Austen for 23 years, the time between high school British Lit class and that when I first saw this film in 2006.A couple of notes on the version. Macfadyen is not quite the actor that Olivier was, but he seems very real as Mr. Darcy. In fact, when he appeared in Frost/Nixon, I silently exclaimed, "it's bleach-blond Mr. Darcy!" The role sticks to him as if he were superglued to it.Mr. Collins is rather serious, almost to the point of mean spirited, whereas Jane Austen's version (and 1940 and 1995 screen versions) paint him as comic relief, a buffoon.Keira Knightly is perhaps the most adorable Lizzie of all, certainly one whom viewers can easily relate to and even befriend. Donald Sutherland is in the middle of the pack as Mr. Bennett overall, but his father/daughter relationship with Lizzie is rather warm indeed!Cinematographically, a bit too modern... two camera elements should be used more judiciously: Zoom/Perspective, and camera angle. In the former, there's no aesthetic benefit to seeing such frequent close-ups of characters when they speak. The two zoom close ups of Mr. Darcy's hand after it had touched Elizabeth's were obvious, nearly to the point of offensive to this viewer.As for the latter, perhaps a bit too much camera acrobatics... in a few scenes, I thought the camera was a supporting actor jealous of the attention given the star, trying to seize the spotlight where it could. The camera was a bit too dramatic at times in angle and movement.The classic (1940) employs both of these techniques, but they are so subtle as to be moving and effective, without distracting the viewer by causing their stomach to jolt with constant gritty emotion. Pride and Prejudice is a fine experience, not a visceral one.I'm compelled to point out one instance where zoom was properly used. At the end of the film, where Darcy and Elizabeth finally declare their love for each other, the use of restrained zoom on the couple was a rather moving as it created a romantic portrait. I felt sparks fly all over my body (as opposed to jolts in my entrails).Despite what I consider cinematographic shortcomings, I love the 2005 version of Pride and Prejudice. It opened the door to Jane Austen for me. Nevertheless, it took a first viewing of the Olivier (1940) version five years later to finally pull me in entirely, to hook me on Jane Austen, deeply and permanently.
summary: Great performance of P&P, accessible to modern audiences

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: How does one steal a movie that sees both Donald Sutherland and Judi Dench hit high notes as supporting characters?  Keira Knightley does it by (a) playing one of the best roles in Western literature in Elizabeth Bennett and (b) nailing it.This adaptation of Jane Austen's beloved "Pride and Prejudice" is a bit more scruffy (and therefore realistic) than its natural complement, Emma Thompson's adaptation of Austen's "Sense and Sensibility."  Everyone looks gorgeous, or course, but they also don't look like they had Hollywood hair stylists, either.  This helps the movie, as it underscores Austen's theme - England was a dangerous place for young ladies unable to get married.Indeed, just as with "S&S;," marriage is the peril and promise for all the characters in the story.  Does a woman grab what she can and hope to make the best of it?  Or does she hold out for true love?  And what do two lovely parents (Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn) do when they are relatively poor and (gasp!) unconventional but have five daughters they need to send into wedlock?One is to be delighted when a rich young man rents the nearby manor and brings along his dark friend, Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen of "MI-5" fame).  Lizzie and Darcy fall for each other immediately, but are compelled by circumstance as well as Lizzie's pride and prejudice (you knew they'd turn up somewhere) to go through one of the greatest love stories of all time.This is a gorgeous, funny movie with several thrilling ball and dance scenes, and the camera quietly does yeoman's work as it wanders through chambers and down hallways to keep the large cast in play and the viewer well-grounded in the story.  Of course the camera also knew to linger often on Ms. Knightley's beauty just often enough!  But she is no mere adornment - this is an excellent acting performance worthy of watching on its own merits.  Watching Lizzie how head-to-head with the rich society dame who hates her (Dench) is worth the price of admission.I have not read "P&P;," so I cannot respond in detail to those who complain that the filmmakers have rewritten the story somewhat.  All I would say is that there are plenty of other "purist" adaptations of this story as well as the book itself, and that judged on its own merits, this is one heck of a film.
summary: Keira Knightley steals the show in wonderful adaptation

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My wife had already seen the movie when I decided to purchase it. she loves the movie, probably watches at least weekly.
summary: Great movie! gift for my wife

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The 2005 film version release of Jane Austen's timeles tale Pride and Prejudice does a far better job of representing the original novel than the old Laurence Olivier B&W; version. It lacks the thoroughness of the A&E; miniseries from the mid 1990s but fits admirably into a two hour time frame.What struck me most about this version was the depth of the characters. Unlike the A&E; rendition, these are all believeable people. The younger girls of the story especially portray characters of the maturity of someone at those ages. Although Kiera Knightly is not what I would picture as Miss Elizabeth Bennet, her skilled acting performance more than justified her selection for the role. In my opinion, she deserved the Academy Award for Best Actress. Tom Hollander as Charles Bingley is also terrific in his social affability yet someone young, naive and unsure of himself in matters of the heart. The characters of Mrs. Bennet and Mr. Collins were more believable while preserving their foibles intact. The elimination of inconsequential peripheral characters such as the Gardner children or Bingley's other sister and her husband contributed to a taut story.The film is not without flaws. When Miss Elizabeth encounters Mr Darcy unexpectedly at Pemberley, he offers to escort her back to town. She declines, preferring to walk. The next, brief scene shows her doing just that. Lost in the shuffle are her aunt and uncle, who presumably would never have just left her stranded at Pemberley. Again toward the end of the movie, the climatic meeting of the hearts between the two protagonists rests on contrived and forced assumptions about Lady Catherine de Bourgh's visit to Longbourn. Perhaps the result of overzealous editing to fit into a two hour time frame (2:02 of actual story, with credits 2:09), their respective references to the offended Lady Catherine's tirade just does not fit terribly well. The filmakers would have done better to add a few more minutes to make the proper connections so that this crucial scene works better.All in all, in my opnion this was one of the top two films produced in 2005. King Kong perhaps deserved more the Oscar for Best Picture (and won the British version of it) but Pride and Prejudice was a close second.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Have been a Pride and Prejudice fan for 20 years, this is the best remake yet!! My sister and I literally call each other up and say I need P&P; therapy...  We curl up with wine snacks and pop it in. Great cast, Keira Knightly and Matthew Macfayden are a perfect Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy, Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn are a hilarious Mr. and Mrs. Bennet...Best chic flick ever...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was the first blu-ray disc purchased for our brand new Sony and first ever blu-ray player (Sony BDP-S590 3D Blu-ray Disc Player with Wi-Fi) and I couldn't be happier with the choice. Thanks to Amazon Prime, I've been using our new smart blu-ray player to stream episodes of "Downton Abbey," "Gosford Park," "The Forsyte Saga," and "He Knew He Was Right" (Netflix only for now), but hadn't actually seen anything on Blu-Ray.  So continuing the never ending pursuit of British costume dramas, I purchased P&P; and probably have watched it about five times in the first week of owning it, including the director's cut. I'd only seen the film once in the theater when it came out but was blown away by Keira Knightley's beauty and snappy repartee; the quiet, smoldering masculinity of Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy; and one of the most romantic happy endings ever put to film.Add to all that the lush scenery, the beautiful costumes, and the sumptuous interiors, and you have the makings of an absolutely gorgeous film that would make anyone want to move to the beautiful English countryside, even for the Bennet's deteriorating working farmhouse, itself a National landmark in England. Not having had the pleasure (yet) of seeing the Colin Firth version and never having read the book (egads!), I couldn't help but be captivated by Keira Knightley as the witty Elizabeth. She more than holds her own throughout, but most especially in the confrontation scene with Dame Judi Dench's Lady Catherine, which is no small accomplishment for a young actress sharing the screen with such a legend.For those of us in the DVR age, having the ability to rewind and make sure to hear exactly what's being said is what blu-ray discs/DVDs are made for with films like this.  The pleasure in watching it is making sure to get the language that is being employed to move the plot forward or to slice and dice another character. Everyone is in complete control of his or her word choices and has the enviable ability of making feelings perfectly known but with subtlety. Don't we all wish we had such writers in our heads!I look forward to seeing Keira Kightley as "Anna Karenina" in Joe Wright's upcoming film adaptation this fall, their third collaboration. He may be going a bit Baz Luhrmann for that film from what I've seen so far, but with  P&P; (and "Atonement"), he created such a gorgeous film, especially in scenes like the one where Lizzie stares at herself in the mirror, facing the possibility that she was overly harsh in letting her own prejudices fillet Darcy in one of the film's most sensuous and electric scenes. The score, just as in "Atonement," is a leitmotif throughout the film and I'm almost tempted to buy the soundtrack. This is one beautiful piece of filmmaking that may supplant my two favorite movies of all time. (Sound of Music vs. West Side Story if you care to know but I can never decide which is number one!)
summary: Not an Austen fanatic but a lover of English period dramas for sure!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I rarely form such a bad opinion of a movie. But this is an awful rendition of P & P. Costumes, casting, sets, almost all bad. They set the Bennets in squalor. The casting is terrible. Knightly, while a good actress, is really not suited for the part. Better as Jo from Little Women I would say. Mr. Darcy is not at all a romantic lead and does not pull off the arrogance he is supposed to have had. Mr. Bingley is beyond ridiculous. Even Judi Dench who I always look forward to seeing did not make a very good Lady Catherine. She appeared almost nice! The performance made Elizabeth's wit not justified but impudent.Above all they were not faithful to the story: adding, omitting, and totally garbling scenes and lines. An example being Mr. Darcy's first proposal: one of my favorite scenes from the book was totally changed, in location, weather, words, etc.Everyone I've talked about the movie with disliked it. All in all it may be a good movie in it's own right but has no claim to being Pride and Prejudice.The BBC/A&E; series is much to be preferred. Even the black and white movie is better!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When nothing is on regular TV programming, I watch this movie!!  The music is so relaxing and I always find something new with all the characters.  Jane Austen stories are one of my many favorite movies to watch anytime!!  This production is done so well compared to others.  The actors/actresses are so believing, funny, outrages and just good!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While this adaptation of the book on film may vary a bit more from the book than the 1995 version of P&P, one can't help but agree that this version is an absolutely stunning film based on Austen's most loved book. I love both the movies and the book and believe that all three of them have something different and unique to offer. This one, I believe, displays so much of the beauty and warmth of the time period and Austen's characters. I loved it and at such a great price on Amazon...it's a steal you just can't resist. :) I hope others who are skeptical will give it a chance! You'd be missing out. :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Well, I didn't mind that the Bennets lived on a farm - I minded that they were then called the Bennets. I didn't mind that Bingley was a fool, but the fact that they called him Bingley. I didn't mind that Elizabeth clearly liked Darcy from the beginning, but I did mind that they called her Elizabeth.Really, I didn't mind this movie at all. What I did mind is that they called it Pride and Prejudice. It was NOT Pride and Prejudice, it was only loosely based on that book. Elizabeth would NEVER tell Darcy to call her Goddess Divine or any one of the other names. Mr. Bennet would NEVER show such affection for his wife and daughters so openly (with the exception, of course, of Jane and Lizzy). Mr. Darcy would NEVER have gone walking toward Elizabeth's house in the middle of the night in only his night clothes (and, for that matter, his aunt would never leave her mansion in the middle of the night, especially not to visit him and Elizabeth)Still, the movie had some great parts. The scenery was amazing. The scene in which Darcy and Elizabeth first touch hands, beautiful. Maybe if it had a different name, I would have given this movie more stars. It's just that they called it Pride and Prejudice, and it was not, so I can not.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I ordered the Keira Knightley version of Pride and Prejudice along with the Firth/ BBC versions because I love this Jane Austin story and because of "Toomuchtimeonmyhands" review. I have not yet played the Firth/ BBC versions, so I will review them later. I was so disappointed when I opened the Keira Knightley DVD and found sticky goo all around the center opening on both sides of the DVD! I am trying to return it now, but so far the return links do not work. I am awaiting an email reply for resolution. Check your products carefully as soon as they arrive, since the vendors obviously do not.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Many of Jane Austen's books have been through the process of adaptation from the book to the screen.  A personal favorite for Pride and Prejudice is the ministries made by BBC. Of course, many purists will object to the lack of adherence to the book in this particular adaptation however they seem to miss out on one word in the description, "based." The movie is BASED on the book. No matter if you've never read Pride and Prejudice in your life and are seeing the film for the first time, or you've read all of Austen's work and own many adaptations that you yourself enjoy, this version is just as charming and profound, odd as those two words sound in a sentence. The imagery and music certainly make up for the lack of certain plot devices and characters. The on-screen chemistry between the lead actors, Keira Knightly and Mathew MacFayden, is dynamic in many scenes.I would highly recommend this movie for anyone who enjoys a good romance and learning a lession or two along the way!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I for one had never read the book, so I had no expectations regarding the film. Simply put, it was lush, romantic, funny and beautifully shot. Definitely a woman's movie!  I have since read the novel and loved every page of it. I must say though that I like the changes they made for the film. It just worked better visually. The soundtrack is lovely too. I love this collector's edition...it reminds me of one of Austen's books. The behind the scenes extras were interesting and brought much understanding to the time and culture as well.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice is almost a necessity for any lover of literature.  It is, perhaps, her most famous piece and has been adapted a number of times.  This latest adaptation does not disappoint.I absolutely love the BBC edition - I've watched it in one whole day a number of times, to the point where I can recite the lines as the actors say them.  I was tentative about this new Pride and Prejudice, worried that it would bring Austen's world crashing down to the ground with bad, flashy acting.  However, the story still holds the same lovely charm of Austen's story, without being too similar to the BBC movie or too far removed.My biggest criticism is that the movie was too short.  For lovers of the BBC movie, this can be a large drawback.  Things happen so quickly (although the movie is 129 minutes long) and there seem to be so many gaps left.  Wickham, for instance, is only seen once or twice, his character completely undeveloped in the movie.  However, this new Pride and Prejudice was meant to cater to the general public and a five hour re-enactment may have weared a number of the viewers.Matthew Macfadyen and Keira Knightly are both different from Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle, yet they still maintain the original charm of the character they are playing.  Knightley's biggest dissimilarity is the fact that she is stick thin, whereas gentry in Austen's time were of a more stout constitution, since a rounder woman meant the family could afford to be well fed.  Her acting, except for a crying scene, is almost flawless.  Macfadyen plays a different Darcy from Firth's haughtier take on the character; Macfadyden is more shy than he is proud.  But he does a good job, and the scene between him and Knightley in the rain is one of the most romantic scenes in any movie.The film, moreover, does not have the glamorize the story, but the house is dirty, hair is messy, things are out of place and imperfect, adding a whole new sense of reality to the movie, something I think the BBC production might have missed.For any lover of Pride and Prejudice, I do no think you will be disappointed in this rendition.  Or, if you are, it will merely be because so much of the story had to be omitted.  For me, I felt between Knightley's Elizabeth and Firth's Darcy, the world of Pride and Prejudice was well rounded and remained true to what Austen had dreamed up.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a big fan of the 1940 version of Pride and Prejudice staring Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier. Maybe it's due to the fact that it was the first version I saw, but it's always been a favorite. (Who couldn't fall in love with Greer Garson?)I'm not sure if I wanted to like this version or not... but in the end, it won me over. So much so that I seem to watch it over and over again.Keira's performance is outstanding, she had me hooked in the first scene. For some reason it took me longer to warm up to Matthew as Mr Darcy, then again, his character does appear cold and aloof at the beginning of the film. In the end, it would be hard to imagine another playing the role; he won me over, just as he did Elizabeth. The supporting cast is just as strong, so no issues there.Setting aside the great acting and wonderful story, this is - plain and simple - one of the most beautiful movies to watch. Between the breathtaking scenery, as well as the lush score, it's hard not to just let the Blu-ray keep playing on repeat mode.In the end, though, it's Keira's performance that elevates this movie to excellence. She just doesn't strike a wrong note in this performance.
summary: Gorgeous release of a classic movie

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When version first came out, I watched it with great anticipation for liking it.  I love Jane Austen, have a Jane Austen related web site, and I am pretty easy to please when it comes to Jane movies.  But I really disliked it.  This past week I thought I would give it another try, and watched it again.  I still really really disliked it. I just think it was poorly portrayed. The Bennet family is made to look excessively poor, grimy and shabby, and not portrayed as the gentlemen's family that they were. Kitty and Lydia were just foolishly, cartoonishly ridiculous, to the point of absurdity. The ball scenes were frenetic and overly crowded, again to the point of absurdity. Keira Knightley's Elizabeth was not likable in any part of the movie - her portrayal was too modern. The entire pace of the movie was too fast - the dialogue was so fast to the point of not being able to understand it at times (and I am not old and I watch British period dramas frequently and so am used to the language). Mr. Bingley seemed a buffoon, which he is not. Mr. Darcy was just never appealing. Their eventually romance seemed implausible.  The whole thing just seemed forced. Jane Austen's subtle humor was never fairly portrayed.It seemed like they wanted give these characters a modern feel while keeping them in early 19th century setting, and it just didn't work. I'm all for modernizations and retelling of Pride and Prejudice, and am a HUGE fan of the Lizzie Bennet Diaries on YouTube.Of course, by far the best Pride and Prejudice portrayal is the Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth 1995 BBC version. Well worth the $4.99 on Amazon Instant Video.Episode 1
summary: I guess I'm one of the few that really dislikes this version

review_text: I was skeptical when this movie came out, I had seen the great  A&E version and just could not imagine why anyone would try to top that..also I thought Keira Knightly was just too hot and contemporary to play Elizabeth Bennett, but much to my surprise I was blown away by this film, Knightly in particular; she was fantastic.  The actor that played Darcy got better as the film wore on, but let's face it there is only one Darcy, but I liked this take on Darcy, he has a kind face and that wears on you..in a good way.  I really liked Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennett, his scene at the end with Knightly really got to me, it was perfect.  The period costumes where also well done and they well deserve their Oscar nomination.  The DVD extra's are wonderful, especially the background on Austen...so sad she never found her Darcy, but alas, that's probably what made her such a great romantic writer, dreams are often better than reality.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a really engaging and quite authentic production of Austen's great work. There is less of the frothy romaticising of the time and much more of gritty determination to represent the period and the evidence of class division. Equally, Austen's great wit and simmering sarcasm are brought to life more vividly. I have been given to be a little harsh about the artisitic ability of Keira Knightly in the past, but here she utterly redeems herself and shows a level of talent that is confidant and appealing. She injects into Elizabeth Bennett, the fiesty and forthright nature, out of tune with the requirements of her time, that I believe Austen intended her to have. The relationship between Knightly and Pike (Sisters Elizabeth and Jane) is girlish, affectionate and charming. Brenda Blethyn is perfectly dotty and anxst ridden as Mrs Bennett is intended to be and Donald Sutherland is world weiry whilst dotishly  parental.The simmering romance is evident and heartfelt and for all that people have long adored Firth's Darcy, Macfadyen injects this awkward and snobbish, cold-fish with a sense of heartbreaking tenderness and vulnerability not before seen; and it is all the better for it.Dench is utterly and obnoxiuosly brilliant and the Grand and Judgemental de Borg. And the sets are magical and actual representations of great English homes of the period. Well worht the effort and thoroughly well done for it's quality of acting, sense of action and pathos and departure from the frothy nostalgia of so many classic novel, film versions.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is reason enough to contemplate burning the book.  Although Jane Austen's original work was not the best, this movie is the epitome of monotony.  Nothing interesting happens at all.  It is essentially one of the most generic and boring styles of cinema: a love story with no twists and no added elements of suspense or uncertainty.  Again, Hollywood fails to do anything more than reprint a book on screen and bore us all to death in the process.  Make no mistake:  the book itself had many flaws, and though considered a classic work of literature, it was incredibly slow-paced and left the reader searching frantically for adrenaline to keep his or her heart beating.  Nevertheless the movie falls into this trap in a far worse way than the book; by the end, you seriously wonder what happened to the last two hours of your life.  The conclusion is unfulfilling at best.  You know precisely what will happen from about twenty minutes in, and it never changes.  No surprises whatsoever.  Even by today's low standards for cinema, this is pathetic.  I honestly cannot see why anyone would want to see this movie, and I've been pondering the positive reviews on amazon.com for hours.  It is not nearly as good as everyone else believes and certainly not worth eight dollars.
summary: A Travesty for the Body, Mind, and Soul

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've seen all the filmed versions of Pride & Prejudice, and found each one to be enjoyable in its own unique way.There is no reason to remake a film if it is going to be exactly like the one before, and with this latest version of  P&P;, director Joe Wright, who is quite a young man, was obviously unwilling to create just another clone. Instead he has chosen to shock us a little by his attention to realism in the settings and activities surrounding the characters - using social documentary, circa 1797, to emphasize the differences in social status of the family groups in the story.I particularly like the scene where the Bennet ladies visit Netherfield when Jane is sick.  They all sit on the sofa in their best, but dated "provincial" Georgian clothes, while Caroline Bingley is dressed in the height of fashion in an elegant high-waisted Empire gown.Life in an English country manor 200 years ago was far from palatial. Even Great Houses were dark and drafty and often dirty.  There was no indoor plumbing, electricity, washing machines, drycleaning, cooking ranges, refrigeration, vacuum cleaners, or central heating. Fireplaces smoked, floors creaked; roofs leaked; water and wood and coal was carried in; ashes and slops were carried out. Livestock was everywhere and flies followed them. There were not even any commercial soaps or cleaning materials - you had to make your own from caustic chemicals.  New furnishings, drapery and carpets were expensive, and hand-me-downs were valued, even if threadbare and faded.Austen mentions only 2 indoor servants at Longbourn - the cook and Hill, the maid of all work, and both would have worked long hours. The daughters would have had to make up the slack, although Mrs Bennet makes it clear cooking was beneath them.  Even the family's riding horses must do double duty on the farm. Life at Longbourn would not have been up to the standards of Rosings and Pemberley, which though they were palaces, would have suffered the same housekeeping difficulties as Longbourn -  but would have more servants to throw at the problems.Jane Austen devoted few words to descriptions of houses and housekeeping. She expected her readers would be familiar with life in various social milieus. We have been reading between the lines, and our reading has not always been accurate, if one is to judge from the disappointed comments of some viewers.This version will never replace the earlier versions, but it does add another point of view, as the film "Clueless" did for "Emma". Wright has taken some liberties with the characters, making Mrs Bennet more sympathetic.  I found the dialogue was rather mumbled, but,like most Janeites, I  know it  by heart so it didn't matter very much.  I expect the film's biggest audience will be Janeites who already know the story & appreciate a fresh look at it.  Just think of all those versions of Shakespeare's plays & no one has got tired of doing another after 400 years.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First of all I must say, I LOVE the BBC version of this story with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. They set the standard for the telling of this story, hands down. Now having said that, I must say that watching this version, I had to adjust myself to the thinking that this is a different retelling of this story. This is a more primitive, faster paced telling than the BBC version. Now personally, I think that cheats the story, rich as it is, and the portrayal of Bingley being a dolt-that seemed uncalled for. But that being noted, it's not bad. It's watchable if you think of this as the MTV version of a classic, revised and motivated to attract minds with the attention span of a gnat, not a faithful portrayal of JA's story for the masses. The masses need to watch the version with Firth and Ehle. I bought this with an open mind, and other than a few slight annoyances (did everything have to look so dirty?), I wasn't disappointed.My test of approval is "Will I watch it again"? Yes, I will...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Ok, for starters, let me just say that I knew this movie would not be BBC's 5 hour long movie which in my opinion is the best version out there, and I knew that it would be much more condensed. I was fine with that, really. I teach British Lit in high school and I was really looking forward to being able to show my students a Pride and Prejudice movie, instead of just small clips.But after the first five minutes of watching this, I knew there was no way I was going to show this in class. The list of reasons for that is so long, I won't be able to list them all, so I'll try to do a better job of condensing them than this movie did.1. The characters themselves were not true to the book at all. Elizabeth Bennett is probably my favorite character of all time. She's lively, finds humor in just about everything, extremely intelligent considering she had virtually no schooling, and a natural wit that could rival any scholar. In the movie, she's a hissing, snarling bad-tempered thing with a chip on her shoulder. The writers seemed to take her propensity to find humor in others' ill behavior and twist it into making fun of just about everyone.And then there was Mr. Darcy...ok, I knew going into this that I probably wouldn't like this rendtion more than Colin Firth's, but I had an open mind and was willing to give him a chance. And he wasn't all that bad, but paired with Keira Knightley's portrayal of Elizabeth, this movie just spun off into a ditch.Mr. Bennett is a private, well-humored man stuck in a bad marriage. He is not whipped as he appears to be in this movie. The fact that the writers changed up a lot of the lines he had in the book to "modernize" the movie, did nothing to aid his character in the least.2. The movie moves along way too fast. Again, I know it couldn't be five hours, but this was just ridiculous. The actors spoke so fast that even I, a hardened P&P; veteran who could quote just about any line in the book had a hard time following the dialogue.For instance, the scene at Rosings when Elizabeth, the Collinses (and Maria Lucas if her character had not been cut from the movie) are dining with Lady Catherine, the dialogue went so fast I almost got whiplash. Judi Densch had the potential to be the best Lady Catherine of all time in fact I was really excited about seeing her in this movie, but her screen time was cut so short, her lines so diluted that it's extremely easy to forget her. And believe me when I say that Jane Austen did not write Lady Catherine de Bourgh in a way that would make her so easily forgottten.3. They cut out too many supporting characters, ie Mr. and Mrs. Hurst (Mr. Bingley's sister and brother-in-law), The Forsters, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips (Mrs. Bennett's sister and brother-in-law), and Lady and Maria Lucas. Again I know that time was a constraint, but all of these characters actually do play a vital role in the book.4. And finally the BIGGEST complaint I have about this movie is Darcy's first proposal scene. Not only is not in Charlotte's Parlor and in the middle of Hunsford's grounds in a random gazebo structure in the rain (I guess to make it more "dramatic"), Mr. Darcy goes on to explain everything right then and there. Which I tell you right now is something Fitzwilliam Darcy would NEVER have done. He's too prideful, hence the title of the book/movie.There was no letter, no suspense as the audience watched Elizabeth come to realize that everything she knew about Wickham was wrong and what everyone seemed to think of her family's behavior in general. One of my favorite parts of the book is where Mr. Darcy storms out of the Collinses parlor and Elizabeth is left fuming. And then there's the awkwardness with which he delivered the letter to her. Instead, I was the only one left fuming as I watched Elizabeth practically throw herself at Darcy after his explaination and by that point I actually shut off my DVD player and took a break. I could not believe that anyone could butcher such a great book so effectively.In conclusion, this movie is HORRENDOUS! The only thing this movie did better than the BBC version is that characters are actually much more pleasing to look at, but that's it. Jane Austen is probably rolling around in her grave right now because these people just ripped her work to shreds.And the worst part is, I now have students coming in every year that think they know all there is to know about Pride and Prejudice, but when they actually start to read the book they start asking questions like... "Wait, who's Maria Lucas?" and "What happened to the Gazebo?", and "Where the hell did this letter come from?" and "Wait, Bingley has another sister?" and my absolute favorite, "Why is Elizabeth so nice?" It's gotten to the point where I have to give a disclaimer at the start of each year, telling them that in no way shape or form should they watch this movie if they haven't already, and if they have they should forget everything.Do not let your children watch this movie. Please. You'll be doing a favor to every English teacher out there. You want to watch a Pride and Prejudice movie that isn't 5 hours long, but still relatively accurate, watch the 1970s version or even the 1940s version. Acting's not quite as good, but they still top this movie about 100 times over. If I could've given this movie 0 stars and still reviewed, I would have.
summary: Not for true fans of Jane Austen's works

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This pride and prejudice is the finest I've ever watched.The Mother  is not overdone at all but is still her same old self.Lidia is not over done like she is in the A&E version with Colin Firth. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Wonderful story.  These actors seem so suited to each other.  Miss Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy do a fabulous job of portraying a love-hate relationship.  I like the other movie of P&P, but this is by far my favorite.  Please give it a try if you have not seen it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a fan of both the book and the 1995 BBC version, I have to say this was a wonderful effort by both the cast and director.The 1995 version is faithful to the novel, but then again, it had 5 hours to tell the story.Time restrictions on this film of course lead to the omission of various scenes and characters but the director gives you enough to understand the story fully.Visually, it's a beautiful piece of film. The sets were awe inspiring. And that sunset scene at the end--oh my, was so glorious.Macfadyen is simply breathtaking as Mr. Darcy. He is easy on the eyes. One thing I loved is that he seemed to really show, by way of his mannerisms, Mr. Darcy's awkwardness and insecurities. When he grabs Elizabeth's hand, that first instant of skin to skin contact, his reaction is heartwarming. In another instance, when he enters the room and surprises Elizabeth, the way he just played with his gloves was amazing and it really gave you insight as to what Mr. Darcy was feeling at the moment. Colin Firth was exceptional as Mr. Darcy but Macfadyen gave him a good run for his money.Kiera did a nice job as Elizabeth. A wonderful effort on her part.All in all, the film was a fine effort. I thoroughly enjoyed it and although I prefer the 1995 version (because of its wholeness and Mr. Colin Firth), the film is a visual stunner, and worth seeing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I believe Eliza and Mark are one of the greatest romances ever written, because of the honesty and truth of their story. I love Matthew Macfayden and think he was the best possible choice for Mr. Darcy.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a Jane Austen freak. I love her novels.I am ALSO a HUGE fan of the Pride & Prejudice mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle. It has to be one of the most watched sets of DVDs in my collection.That said, I was expecting to go into this movie and be disappointed. I mean, it was hard enough to adapt the novel into a nearly 6 hour mini series. How in the world would they get it down to 2 hours and 7 minutes? Would it be Jane Austen on speed?I must say, though I was not thoroughly pleased (though I expected I would not be), I was most certainly not disappointed either! :o) All the acting was well done. It was interesting to see different takes on the Bennett girls. After time, I adjust to Keira Knightley's portrayal of Elizabeth Bennett. McFadden wasn't broody enough in my opinion. He just seemed shy more than proud. I must give much credit to my enjoyment of the acting to Mr Bingley. He was PERFECT. :) Yadda yadda yadda. You'll all form your own opinions.My only qualms with the film was the beautiful shots of the country/Lizzie. They were too long! Beautiful, but too long. I think SO much character development/relationship development could have been helped if they would have taken a few less of those shots, and had another family scene. I really missed Lizzie and Jane's relationship. Wickham was nearly cut out! I missed the culture of the time! The lack of showing this really destroyed a lot of Jane Austen's disdain for the upper crust of society.So I'm rambling, but that's how I feel in a nutshell!
summary: Avid fans won't be too disappointed.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The most recent rendering of Jane Austen's masterpiece "Pride and Prejudice" is not the A&E; version that I own and adore, but it stands well on its own.I'll admit, being a Colin Firth as Darcy fan, and a huge fan of the A&E; version, I was prepared to dislike this movie, and dislike it intensely.  While it was not as good as the A&E; version, I did enjoy the film.My biggest problems?  First, and perhaps most importantly, the length.  A&E; did a five hour masterpiece, with wonderful character interpretations, dialogue and a general overview of Austen's cultures and times.  This version, coming in at 2 hours, requires certain characters and plotlines to be abbreviated, or left out entirely.  Which leads to problem number two.  Lizzy's Uncle and Aunt Gardiner are barely represented here, although they play a huge role in the book (and the A&E; version).  Bingham's sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Hurst, have been axed.  Caroline Bingley has few scenes.  We never see her meeting up with Jane in London.  Mr. Collins and Charlotte have very few scenes. You are not left with the impression that Charlotte and Lizzy are good friends, but maybe just acquaintances.  Lady Catherine de Burgh (played wonderfully icy by Judi Dench)appears in perhaps two scenes.The Bennets themselves, with the exception of Mr. Bennet, are woefully underrepresented.  Despite the loveliness of the actress playing her, you don't get a sense of Jane's modesty, shyness and affection for Bingley.  You also don't get a sense of the close bond that Lizzy and Jane shared.  Mrs. Bennet in this version lacks the hysterics and dramatics that the A&E; Mrs. Bennet possessed - - to the detriment of this film, in my opinion.  Mary, Kitty and Lydia seemed to be simply secondary characters, at least until Lydia runs away with Wickham . . but even then, the viewer may not have the impression of what a huge lout Wickham is, nor how precocious Lydia was.  All in all, having to tell such a beloved love story, with so many characters, is a daunting task, but a very difficult one in two hours or less.  As a result, this version feels rushed - - there is no feeling that nearly a year has passed since Bingley has seen Jane, or since Darcy and Lizzy first met.Now, what is good about this version?  The two lead actors are wonderfully endearing.  No, Keira Knightly is not Jennifer Ehle and Matthew MacFadeyn is not Colin Firth.  But they are very sweet together and have definite chemistry.  When I heard that Knightley was cast as my favorite literary character, originally, I was horrified.  But I have to say that she does a very credible job.  Again, she plays Lizzy very differently than Ehle does, but it works in this film.  The scenery is absolutely beautiful and the music is absolutely perfect for a timeless love story.All in all, I enjoyed this film.  If I had to choose, I would take the A&E; version over this one - - just because Firth and Ehle are impossible to top, and the five hour mini-series was simply magnificent, in casting, direction, sets, etc.But for a 2 hour Jane Austen fix, this movie is worth a watch.
summary: Not the A&E/BBC version, but still worthy

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen both the 95' version with Firth and Ehle and this one with Keira and Matthew. I have to say that I liked the 2005 version much better. I just didn't feel the chemistry between Firth and Ehle. And they seem a lot older than the characters in the book. Colin Firth too I felt was too stiff faced and did not bring out the emotion or torment he felt. He keeps staring at Ehle like he wants to hit her.I thought Matthew Macfayden was a real find in this movie. He really seemed to bring out all the range of emotions he felt. Keira knightly too was very good in her role.The movie though I felt was short and had some scenes I would have liked to see cut out, was a wonderful adaptation of the novel itself.The rain scene where Darcy proposes and the last scene where he comes at dawn to talk to Lizzie was spot on. I couldn't have asked for a better adaptation there.On the whole if you have read the book this movie is a must see.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Pride and Prejudice is an old favorite of mine.  Austen has a knack for writing about relationships.  There is a fine subterranean stream of masked sexuality contrasting with the formal social necessities of her era that create a wonderful tension in her novels.  The director picked up on this element and created a wonderful movie.Pride and Prejudice was gorgeously and authentically filmed.  The period was pre-regency--in the early Napoleonic wars--one not so commonly portrayed. The men pose in outfits that evoke some of the portraits of Napoleon.  All of the locations are stunning making the most of ancient trees and beautiful mansions.The film portrayed the ramifications of what it meant to be the daughters of poor gentry in this era.  The girls simply must marry in order to survive.  Yet they were looked down upon for their aspirations to marry well.  Also, their lower social status made them prey to men who might exploit these women for sex.  In most cases marriages were simply financial transactions--merging of assets.Matt McFayden was the perfect choice to play the proud man who is humbled by his love for a woman impossible for him to marry because she is not in his social class.  When he decides that his love for her is so great he cannot be without her, his pride and a series of misunderstandings cause Lizzy (Keira Knightly) to reject him. McFayden and Knightly play the star-crossed lovers with the restrained intensity called for by the social manners of the time. In particular McFayden is devastating as the heart-broken lover.This movie succeeded visually, as a psychological portrait of a social era and most importantly as a great romance.
summary: Hot and sexy, in a mannered English drawing room style!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: No, really, and I've seen them all. Of course this is my learned opinion so read at your own risk. Keira Knightly - excellent. Actually most of the cast (Bingley was a little too goofy) were terrific.For the critics that say Macfayden was a little too wooden,they had a point in two or three places at most. But it doesn't detract from his overall portrayal. He never looked maudlin or sappy even once - unlike Colin Firth at the last third of the A&E; version. No trashing me now, I love that one too. But Macfayden came across as a real, believable person. So did Donald Sutherland and I was prepared to dislike him from the first. Instead,I was charmed!Indeed, I'm one of those dedicated little P&P; fans who has the book memorized. I can say with all true feeling that Matthew Macfayden is better then the Darcy version that's lived in my head for the last 30 years.And that's sayin' somethin'.  :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Being fully aware of the backlash stating my take on the most beloved of the works of Miss Jane Austen I shall attempt to be as brief as possible, by purely stating my own opinion.First of all I will admit that this adaptation of the darling tale does speed through a bit faster than to be desired, but one must remember that this version was made for the cinema, and therefore does not have the advantage of the BBC mini series. On the other hand the fact that it is shorter in length makes it much more feasible for the hundreds of viewings I have endured blissfully.However in nearly every other category I prefer this rendition. I honestly find very little fault in absolutely anything in this movie. The principle actors portray each of their characters in the most beautiful, poetic manor. Particularly I adore Simon Woods as the nave Mr. Bingley, his eyes sparkle and I find myself believing every little word he speaks.Joe Wright did the most admirable job directing such a fantastic film, finding romance and tension in the smallest of actions between Elizabeth and Darcy. When Darcy offers his hand to help Elizabeth into the carriage, the moment is just breathtaking. Not to mention the cinematography and scenery are gorgeous scene after scene.Movie aside, the soundtrack encompasses some of the most beautiful music I could imagine; Most of the tracks by Jean-Yves Thibaudet are in high rotation on my itunes, my personal favorite being `Liz on top of the World.'.It's surreal. One of my most favorite, romantic, timeless films I have ever seen.
summary: What are Men Compared to Rocks and Mountains?

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen's novels and wasn't sure how well I'd like this film version. But I was pleasantly surprised. If you are a purest, you may be a little frustrated by what is omitted in order to fit this into a feature film length, but by and large I couldn't really disagree with the director's choices here.  My favorite film version for fidelity to Austen's text is still the BBC version made in the 1980's staring Elizabeth Garvie. But this one is worth your time because it tells the stories of characters you love from a new perspective. This telling is focused on making the Bennets, as a family, believable in their interactions with one another, even if it means softening the flaws of each character a little. For example, traditionally inattentive Mr. Bennet is shown comforting Mary who breaks into tears after her musical performance is rejected at the Netherfiled ball.  I also thought Kira Knightly did a nice job of portraying Elizabeth as someone who really does love to laugh.
summary: Fun Perspective on a Favorite Story

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Granted that no film can capture an entire book, but rather its essence, this film interpretation of Austen's perennial classic does not live up to the novel on which it was based.  Instead of going for the light, clever, witty world Austen created in her novel, Joe Wright chose to turn Pride and Prejudice into some sort of heavy-handed, proto-Brontean melodrama.  It ignored the iconography of several scenes which are of critical importance to the story (for example, Darcy's first proposal is filmed outside, in the rain! which means that the difference between Elizabeth being cornered inside during the proposals she rejects and outdoors when she finally accepts is no longer present), and some of the lines ("You have bewitched me, body and soul..."--give me a break!) are just plain cheesy.There are also several glaring socio-historical errors in this screenplay, not the least of which is Mr. Bingley nursing an ailing Jane back to health; a young gentleman would NOT be in a young woman's bedchamber (who was not in his immediate family, which Jane is not), especially when she was in a state of undress.  The lack of concern for nuances of etiquette between characters, lack of awareness of difference of behavior between classes, etc. also evinced a general ignorance of or concern for accuracy in portraying a book written by an author for whom such manners formed the basis for much of her works' humor.  Watching incidents like these are frustrating just plain painful to anyone who has spent any time with Austen.That being said, there were a few aspects of the screenplay which are worthy of note.  The liberties taken with Charlotte Lucas (in which she goes into some detail about her reasons for marrying Mr. Collins) are well-done and point out to modern audiences the plight of the spinster in Regency-period England.  Likewise, a softer, gentler Mrs. Bennett is different from the 1995 BBC version (which is the standard by which P&P; interpretations will CONTINUE to be judged, thanks to this overall mediocre silver screen version), but not necessarily unwelcome.  However, several secondary characters are missing from the cast, and their loss, although not of central importance to the plot, does diminish the overall impression which is present in Austen's novel, and is yet another unfortunate aspect of this version's screenplay.  They completely dropped a sister; without the bookish Mary, there is no foil to contrast Kitty and Lydia's reckless and unrestrained foolishness, two extremes of feminine behavior.  The other omission is of the Hursts (Bingley's other sister and her husband), as is their contribution to the picture of married life presented in the book (there is only one married couple in Austen's book which appears to be genuinely happy: the Gardiners, Elizabeth's aunt and uncle, and thank goodness the writer(s) at least had the good sense to at least keep them in!).Aside from the flaws in the screenplay, the acting by two of the main "Big Name" acting draws of this film, Keira Knightley as heroine Elizabeth Bennett and Judi Densch as Lady Catherine de Bourgh, is unremarkable.  While Densch gives merely an indifferent performance of her part as British actress "of a certain age" (rather than bringing any particular vitality to her character, an overbearing aristocrat and self-styled "patroness"), Knightley's acting is actually flawed; at no point in the film is she actually convincing in her part--she was too busy playing Keira Knightley in a long, old-timey dress.Although the cinematography and costuming in this picture are beautiful and beautifully done, they is not enough to save this lukewarm interpretation of a wonderful book, and I have a feeling the only reason it has been as warmly received as it has is because not many people bother to read the original anymore.  Nobody involved with the making of this film (excepting, perhaps, those competent few who were in charge of wardrobe and props) ought to be allowed anywhere NEAR Austen's works again.
summary: Pretty film, but didn't really "get" Austen...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you must have a video version of Jane Austen's classic work, then the 95 BBC adaptation is for you.  It is truer than any other adaptation (and I've seen them all) to the spirit, wit, and characters Miss Austen created centuries ago.This version, on the other hand, while it has some redeeming qualities making it worthy of a rental viewing - the scenery, cinematography, and score are uniformly excellent - it is a very poor rendition of P&P.;  Although I agree that the youthful energy shown by all 5 Bennet girls is an interesting take on the story, there are so many flaws and wasted opportunities in this work that I cannot in good conscience recommend a purchase.  A short list of the flaws in the script includes:1.  Judi Densch has been deprived of an opportunity to truly shine - I was so looking forward to her rendition of Lady Catherine, which I have no doubt could have been exceptional.  The script eliminated Lady C's best line (" I am most seriously displeased"), and pretty well hacked out the entire character.  This was a HUGE disappointment.2.  Mr. Bennet, as written, is more of a soft, whipped character, instead of the sharp, although disappointed in marriage, character that Jane created.  Why change the brilliant line in response to Mrs. Bennet's news about netherfield - "You wish to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it", to "You wish to tell me, so I suppose I have no choice".  Seems subtle, but this changes the flavor of the character.  And the tears at the end when Lizzie accepts Mr. Darcy seemed completely foreign to the character I knew from the book.3.  Wasted opportunities for character development.  I know that when trying to make a 2hour movie from a novel, that certain subplots must be sacrificed, so I was able to live with the elimination of Mr & Mrs Hurst from the story.  However, when every minute is a premium, why, after Elizabeth hears about Charlotte's engagement, are we subjected to a large chunk of time watching Elizabeth swinging?  That time could have been far better spent.  Also there was a wasted scene at the Netherfield ball showing Mr. Bennet consoling Mary after having asked her to stop playing.  Hello - you're trying to CUT story, not ADD to it.4.  Mr Bingley, in this rendition, is not someone you can see Jane Bennet really falling in love with - the character is rather soft-brained, instead of good-natured.  Again, the scene at the end that is ADDED from the story, showing Darcy helping Bingley to prepare to propose to Jane, very much diminishes his character.  Wasted film time that could have been employed far more profitably.5.  The whole handling of Charlotte's engagement was ham-handed.  Why cut a classic line, when Jane says to Elizabeth, "Lizzie, you are not accounting for differences in situation and temperament", as Elizabeth tries to reconcile herself to the news.  Instead, we are treated to an out-of-character tirade by Charlotte, with the breathtakingly inappropriate climax of "Don't you dare judge me, Lizzie".  *sigh*I don't think of myself as a purist who objects to any changes in the story in order to adapt it.  It's just that with very little effort, this film could have been far superior, and that is what I find the most disappointing.
summary: Rent - do NOT buy - this rendition

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was surprised when this version of Jane Austen's masterpiece was released - after the magnificent BBC mini series, I really didn't think that anyone would try and match the unmatchable so soon.However, as this is supposed to be a review of this latest version of Pride And Prejudice I'd better get on with it. Keira Knightley is mesmerizing as Eliza Bennett and I look forward to seeing a lot more of her work in the future.I also loved Matthew McFayden as Mr Darcy,Brenda Blethyn as Mrs Bennett, and Rosamund Pike captured the very essence of Jane Bennett, the eldest of the Bennett daughters.Dame Judi Dench gave a good performance as the interfering Lady Catherine De Bourg but Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennet left me wondering at both his characterization - dirty unkempt hair and slovenly appearance - and how this portrayal in any way came even close to the witty,intelligent and amusing Mr Bennett of Jane Austens creation.At present, Director Joe Wright has teamed up again with Keira Knightley and Belinda Blethyn to make Atonement and I hope his ability to transfer a fine novel to the screen is more successful this time around.Pride and Predujice is so perfectly written, so precisely mapped out by Miss Austen, that any change is noticeable and the changes in story line are NEVER an improvement on the original.The wonder of classics like the books of Austen,the Bronte sisters, Thomas Hardy, George Elliot,is that they teach one about the lives of people in another century, the houses,the customs,the language, the fashion of the day and so forth.So efforts to update or "modernise" should be kept to a minimum.I enjoyed the latest P&P; version, but as a film, not as an adaptation of Jane Austens finest work.
summary: Keira Knightly - Captivating as Eliza Bennett.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was very satisfied with the DVD.  It was as described.  Would definitely do business again with this company.  I apologize for not responding sooner but I thought I already had.Thanks very much.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In the interest of full disclosure, I must admit I am a Literature major, an Austen fan, and a general book addict. That said, I LOVE this movie! The cinematography is beautiful, and the essence of the book is completely maintained in this particular adaptation. My one critique would be that the accents can be difficult to understand at times (and this comes from a girl who studied in London). Put the captions on the first time you watch it and that should take care of any words you miss when you aren't completely paying attention. Overall great movie that captures the emotion of Austen's classic!
summary: Wonderful adaption, does the novel justice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Great version of P&P. Love the scene in the rain! Keira Knightley & Matthew Macfadyen are marvelous as Lizzy & Darcey.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The only redeeming thing about the this movie is the beauty of the pictures themselves. Keira Knightley is NOT a good Elizabeth. However they did get Jane right in this one compared to the A & E version. The story telling from the director was flawed and left much to be desired. No NO No.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I quite enjoyed this adaptation of Pride & Prejudice.  It keeps much of the main plot & key points from the novel & sprinkles in a few more overly romantic scenes.  Only necessary to make the story seem more romantic for the majority of the populace who are not familiar with the decorum of the 19th century.While Keira Knightly looks the part of Elizabeth, something in her performance niggles at me & I'm just not convinced with her.  However, I'm very satisfied with the rest of the cast, most of all Mr. Darcy.  In fact, it's Matthew Macfadyen's performance that just pulled me into this movie.  I actually makes me wish, in this case, the story was told from his POV & not Elizabeth's.There are several instances where we have these "introspective" moments with Elizabeth's character, but as we don't hear any narration or speaking on screen, just music, we're left in the dark on what exactly she's thinking.  We have an idea, since we know what is going on in the story, but really we can only speculate.  Some of these are fine in places, but others just seem a bit pointless & could have been left out.  Especially if the time could have been used to keep in any left out portions of the book.I do love the original story & while this movie isn't the truest version it certainly looks beautiful & has a pretty solid cast.  Some folks may find the movie slow or boring, but not every movie needs explosions to be good.  No, I'd say most anyone who is a fan of the novel or is curious as to what they may find within it's pages will be pleased with this movie.
summary: Good adaptaion with a solid cast

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: LOVE THIS MOVIE

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: When this first came out in the theater, I have to admit, I had absolutely no interest in seeing it.  I only read the cliff notes version of Pride and Prejudice in high school and couldn't remember anything about the story.After this came out, I went on a business trip to Asia and was stuck on a plane for 15 hours.  This was one of the movies I could watch and I swear, after seeing it once, I watched it again two more times before my plane landed.  It's absolutely one of my favorite movies ever!  It's romantic, sweet, funny.I bought the book right away and read that and as soon as I got back to the US, I bought the DVD!  And then when Blu-rays were getting popular, I bought the Blu-ray because I needed it in even better quality.  I've even bought this for a few friends to.It's simply one of the best romance movies out there!  You will love it!
summary: One of my absolute favorite movies!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: My main complaint about this movie is the ridiculous pacing. But what can you do when you are condensing a very long book into 2 hours? Although the acting is credible...you just don't believe that Elizabeth and Darcy hate each other or that they then like each other. The screenplay makes it seem as if the whole story takes place in about a month. I really wish I like it more...there is room in my heart for a million P&P versions...as long as they are good.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have probably watched this movie about 1,000 times! The music is incredible and the imagery is amazing as well- the opening scene is breathtaking. This is the perfect girls' movie and leaves me with butterflies in my stomach every time I watch the last scenes with Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. If you have any question about how much I love this movie, I named my daughter Charlotte Elizabeth!!
summary: My perfect movie- exquisite storytelling and imagery

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is an all time classic. Great for all ages. It is one you can watch over and over again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I resisted seeing this movie for a long time, thinking who needs another P&P;?  It's been done many times, and quite well (BBC miniseries and the Greer Garson, Laurence Olivier versions stand out).  Cynically, I thought this is just another Hollywood grab for some sure dollars.However, I found this version to be refreshing and inspired.  Many people have commented on the youthfulness of the characters, the transposition to more rural as opposed to drawing room settings, and the more unrestrained atmosphere, as opposed to the buttoned-up proto-Victorian image of versions past.However, what I liked about it, was that it had a very clear grasp of the central relationship between Darcy and Lizzy, from the first attractions of their mutual chemistry, to the unfolding and appreciation of their respective characters.  In other hands, the attraction between the two would have been unfathomable, particularly where the dialogue is harsh, but Keira Knightley does a great job conveying the conflict between her head and heart, and the scenes between the two lovers are charged with enough emotion to thrill the heart of any romantic.Because of the intense focus on the central relationship, the other characters sort of fade into the background, and I don't think Mr. or Mrs. Bennett are done as well as in some other versions.  However, Collins and "his patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourg" are done very well, and the last interview between Lizzie and Lady Catherine is re-cast very well, and is more coherent.In other words, I think this wasn't just made to make a buck, but made from a sense of trying to draw out some of the themes and relationships and show the characters in a fresh light.I was enchanted.  This is definitely a buy.
summary: Not the same old Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The ultimate romance movie. If you love period material, this one is superbly done. It captures the social culture of a time which has passed on. The scene in the rain between the two main characters is classic. Not to be out done. They need to make more movies like this one.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I took a date to see Pride and Prejudice, and I expected to sleep through the whole thing.  The girl I took was a huge Jane Austen fan, but I never was.  My parents love the A&E version, but I never could get through it.  I went in with the same expectation and was completely wrong.  Keira Knightly's performance is her best to date.  If she doesn't get at least an Oscar nomination, something is wrong.  The film is bright, cheerful, and funny.  The supporting cast is wonderful, but Rosamund Pike and Donald Sutherland stand out.  Guys, don't worry.  I usually hate chick flicks too, but this is one that guys could handle taking dates to.  So don't have too much pride or predjudice, judge it for youself.  And I will buy this one on DVD.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I think not. Nor, is he in fact, dead. I loved his masterful portrayal of Darcy, as I have loved everything he does, including Love Actually, but it did not prevent me from devouring this gorgeous adaptation.To me, Knightley was a revelation, and this beautifully crafted adaptation is a showcase for her genuine versatility. When you can hold your own against a goddess of stage and screen such as Dame Judi Dench, you've got something going on. Likewise, in her beautiful interaction with a superb Donald Sutherland, when she is speaking to him about Darcy's marriage proposal. Both actors are just stunning.I love this version equally with the Colin Version, and everything from the cinematography to the casting, production and direction all conspire to make this movie a delight for the senses. Being a fan of solo piano, I also loved the soundtrack (Dario Marianelli), especially the exquisite cascading ripples of pieces such as Liz On Top Of The World.At the heart of this delicious interpretation is Austen's disturbing portrayal of the sheer madness of a blinkered patriarchal society in which females, even brilliant, beautiful and gifted females, could never inherit property. Brenda Blethyn's delightful performance as a mother anxious to get her divine daughters married off, is based on this shameful reality.Even though I had heard many good things about the Knightley Version, it actually exceeded my expectations by a quantum factor, and I cannot recommend this DVD highly enough.
summary: Colin Firth... rolling in his grave?
