title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am not worthy of writing a review of this film, but I MUST try.It seems like only yesterday Codemaster Talon (my genius sister and fellow Amazon reviewer) and myself were sitting in a darkened theater watching previews before some film or other, and saw a fleeting glimpse of yet another Jane Austin inspired film. That was my initial reaction, "Oh no, not ANOTHER one...". And yet, within that short time I was intrigued. The acting looking competent, and the cinematography absolutely breath-taking. "I'll see it for the cinematography alone," I commented to my companion.Now I don't pretend to be half the Jane Austin fan that Codemaster Talon is. I don't pretend to be some kind of literary higher critic or the absolute authority on historical accuracy and proper period acting. I do however, know a good story when I see one. Pride and Prejudice as a story in all it's versions holds a very special place in my heart. You see at it's core it is the story of two very similar personality types who are monstrously incompatible on the surface, and perfect compliments deep down.Elizabeth Bennet is an introvert who acts the extrovert, a whimsical person who is practical deep down, a genius who cares more about her friends' happiness than impressing others, and wishes for true love more than riches. She's a young woman who uses her feelings to deal with the world but most treasures her intuition. Darcy is a person who has all his feelings buried deep down. He's an introvert who keeps to himself unless compelled to action. He's logical and analytical, but treasures his feelings above all. He's blunt with his feelings, because so few people understand them. He's arrogant and proud, but courageous, and noble. In short he's the exact opposite of Elizabeth in every way save one. They are both people who live in their own universe separate from the rest of the world. And they are both VERY stubborn and judgmental.I've seen the old version of this story with Sir Laurence Olivier as Darcy and Greer Garson as Elizabeth. I've seen the gold-standard A&E; version which caused such an uproar with it's amazing dialog and acting. I have never seen anything like this. Never before has the true heart and soul of Liz and Darcy been on display. Never before could I see clearly expressed WHY  they fell in love with each other. In fact, never before could I see a real sign that they HAD fallen in love with each other. Now I see it.A movie is more than just acting with some music and sound effects tossed in, captured through a hand-held camera (despite what Indy film buffs may have told you). A real movie uses the acting to further the dialog, the dialog to further the action, the music to further the moment captured by the lens. Everything pushes  to express feelings and emotions that grab a hold of you and don't let go. I mentioned that the preview for this movie intrigued me because of the cinematography, but I had NO IDEA what was yet to come.Painting with Color, Drawing with LightThe title of this movie appears in a ray of sunlight. The first few minutes take us inside of the Bennet house with a genius that reminded me of the camera-work of The Magnificent Ambersons' greatest shot. And it only gets better. This is not showy camera-work for it's own sake. Everything has a point in this movie. Those opening minutes told multiple stories at once. Those first time I saw this movie beginning made me think first of the  standing of the household (as the lived-in and somewhat decayed nature of the estate was quite apparent), then of the personality of the main character (carrying a book and inside her own world despite all the hustle and bustle around her), and then of the personality of everyone else inside the house, as each person's body language, voice and activity summarized their personality in a snapshot.As the film progressed I witnessed a country party quite unlike anything I've seen in a Jane Austin film before. The party was lively and ecstatic and looked like FUN. And when Darcy and his friend came to the party we could quite quickly see how everyone else was a country bumpkin compared to them (something that was never so clear to me before). More than that, again the use of camera angles and body language spoke beyond the dialog to hint at things unsaid. "Interesting," I thought. "This movie is going to be interesting." Then came the first scene where I honestly was mentally agasp with the question "How did they do that?". Liz and Jane are having a sister-to-sister conversation under the bed covers late at night and the perspective of the camera is the the arm of one sister, then it switches back to the other sister's perspective. "Where's the camera?", was all I could think. Not good camera use, GREAT.There were three moments in this film that  took my breath away (and while it was certainly impressive and added enormously to the picture, the dance between Darcy and Elizabeth where everyone else disappears {an effect executed marvelously here} is not one of them). The moments were these:The ProposalFirstly, Darcy's famous proposal. Normally portrayed somewhat arrogantly on Darcy's part, here it is played with passion, and we can see his heartache. Nay, we can FEEL his heartache. The whole scene happens in the rain, outdoors, with Liz and Darcy starting somewhat apart, and, as he proposes and she rejects him with more and more fury, they gradually get closer and closer until by the end of the scene their faces are nearly touching. I could FEEL the magnetism between the characters. I could SEE for the first time, that it was not HIM that she was rejecting (though she thought she was) but his ACTIONS. Despite her words, she was clearly drawn to him, absorbed in his personality. Though for so long she acted indifferent toward him, seemingly not caring, she was in fact almost obsessed with him. Yeah, I got all that from one scene.On top of the WorldOkay, this was it, the moment when I knew that I didn't just like this movie, I had fallen head-over-heels-in-love! While there are many splendid moments of wide-screen wide-angle shots (YES!), and some super-nice super-close-ups (the beauty is almost too much for my eyes!), this scene truly takes the cake. It starts with Lizzy in a carriage, the camera  on her eyes as sunlight and shadow dance across them. Then, the camera cuts to a STUNNING  shot of Elizabeth standing at the edge of a cliff with the wind blowing against her. The music swells and... GOODNESS. I'm glad I have ears and eyes and life within me to witness spectacles like this.Your Hands Are Cold.I've always loved Darcy as a character, for the same reason I loved Colonel Brandon in Sense and Sensibility. To me he's always been a hero, a great man just waiting for a chance to prove his strength and courage. This is perhaps the most powerful scene of the movie. After a terrible confrontation with the Lady Catherine, Lizzy gets up early in the cold morning and walks out into the hills. Just as the sun is coming up, who appears but Darcy, walking up with his jacket billowing in the wind like a hero's cape, sad, noble, and with depth of emotion to bring you to tears. It's like a hero coming back from a war. As he and Lizzy talk, they draw close together just as the sun is coming up between the two of them. That's what I live for. It's a moment that's so romantic and larger than life that it belongs alongside the greatest from Gone With the Wind and Casablanca. I don't know what else to say.The FilmWhat can I say about the acting of this film? For the first time in ages I forgot I was watching ACTORS and felt like I was watching a story unfold in front of me. I haven't felt this way since I was a kid. I forgot anyone was acting. For the most part, the characters in the film simply WERE. In other words, I smell Academy Awards.Knightley's Elizabeth is sharp, sensitive, sweet, and strong, a fully fleshed out acting job that simply makes us believe she IS the character. Matthew Macfadyen's Darcy is so sincere, so from the heart, that we cannot for one moment doubt his sincerity. He brings new depth to a new interpretation of a classic character. Rosamund Pike's Jane is simply overflowing with sweetness and good nature (and the scene of her leaving to pursue her love in the back of a carriage is feminine beauty personified). Even the so often portrayed as unbearably oily Mr. Collins gets a new spin as played by Tom Hollander. I actually felt SORRY for the guy a few times (trapped as he is in his own ridiculous world and never realizing how absolutely pathetic and silly he seems). Also wonderfully done are the Bennet parents played by Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland. Mrs. Bennet comes across more as a misunderstood sweet parent than a hyper-annoying flibbertigibbet. And Mr. Bennet just has more emotional resonance than in any previous version I've ever seen. Just about everyone is perfectly played in this movie.The music is sparing, but used to great effect. Never overwhelming the action, but rather pushing it, the soundtrack is quite good (I have it). There are moments of supreme beauty to be heard, but on the whole the soundtrack is rather sparse (comes to little more than half an hour).Some reviewers on the Net said that this production was by-the-numbers. I can understand that...if you happen to be color-blind, tone-deaf, and wouldn't know a good script if it smacked you upside the head. This film deserves to sweep the Oscars in every category. So perfect is the camera-work ( I have seen nothing like it since the days of Ford, Cardiff and Kurosawa), the score (heart-breaking), the acting (I love ALL the characters), and the script (it reaches straight into your heart) that EVERYONE should enjoy this film. Like the story that inspired it, it is a perfect marriage of the Male and Female personalities combining the Epic feel and strength of a man's film with the delicacy, beauty, and wit of a woman's film. I had thought long ago that the two great miracles of film-making would be to make the ordinary seem Epic, or the Epic seem ordinary. This film makes the ordinary, the lives and loves of people, into something as Epic as the end of the world or the blazing of new frontiers. I for one shall never be the same. After seeing this film I look at the world in a different way, and perhaps always shall.If this movie has one major flaw it is this: it is FAR too short at 2 hours. This is simply too big a story with too many characters to tell in that short a time. As such a lot of things things had to be spelled-out, and entire scenes and characters got the chopping block. And another reason I wish it were longer: I enjoyed every moment of this film so much I never wanted it to end.  My first words at as the end credits rolled were something like "I can't wait for the director's cut." You could wait for it to come out on DVD, but then you'd have to buy a big-screen TV and a surround-sound system to experience it's full glory. And to see this one on pan-and-scan would be to cut it's head off with a guillotine. In short, THIS is the film that EVERYONE has been waiting for.I tried to write a review. I really did. Words failed me. Please see this film in the theater. Please.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my favorite Pride and Prejudice. Others don't compare with these two actors. The visual affects and costumes were exceptional.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Having been a fan of Jane Austen's literature since first studying it during my school years, and having just about every filmed adaption of her novels in my collection, I awaited this version with high expectations.  To my mind, it is both good and bad in about equal proportions.Good from the cinematography angle, with the scenery and beautiful,gracious homes used being quite extraordinary.  Bad from the point that much of the language and intent of the book is lost, when the storyline is condensed down to such a short time.  When you choose to make a movie of a book, especially one so well loved as P&P;,I really think that you have a duty of care to hold the book close and stay true to it, not change things to suit your whim.I do believe that this movie was aimed at an audience who have a short attention span, and those who have never read Jane Austen's books.  Who else but the American market would expect a specially made soppy ending (which fortunately is an 'added extra' here) and would willingly accept so many omissions and deleted characters that causes much of the point of Austen's writings to be entirely lost.  For instance, there is no explanation of how Mr Collins came to propose to Charlotte Lucas - she just appears out of the blue and makes the announcement.And Lady Catherine arriving at the Bennet home in the middle of the night - no way, and it's not in the book.Mr Darcy's initial proposal in the rain, not in the Collins' house as should have been, was rushed and muddled.And he just walked straight into the house in the middle of the night to deliver his letter? Hardly - he was waiting in the woods for Lizzie who walked there.Did anyone else notice that when Lizzie first goes to Pemberley and comes across Georgiana playing the piano, that there is a mirror above her as she plays, and yet when LiZzie and the Gardiners arrive next day, Mr Darcy is standing in front of the piano underneath that superb painting on the wall of the other room?  ?Continuity?With regard to the actors chosen, they are for the most part extremely good, although I did not like the choice of Donald Sutherland for Mr Bennett at all.  Brenda Blethyn as Mrs Bennett, the indomitable Dame Judy Dench as Lady Catherine,and the luminous Rosamund Pike joining Tom Hollander again following their roles in the BBC series of 'Wives and Daughters', were quite outstanding.  Keira Knightley glows as Lizzie, although sometimes I found her a little lightweight,and Matthew Macfadyen (well known in Australia from his starring role in the TVseries 'Spooks') speaks volumes with just one look, and broods stylishly, although the racing speed with which he delivers his proposal was most unfortunate.While this version of Pride & Prejudice has scenery and music to enrich your senses, I will continue to prefer the A&E; version with Ehle & Firth, however the BBC version with Garvie & Rintoul remains the closest word for word capturing of Jane Austen's writings.Not a bad attempt, but should have been much better.
summary: Close - but should have been better.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love, I love, I love this movie. It is the only movie I can watch again and again. It is superbly cast and beautifully presented. Matthew Macfadyen truly IS Mr Darcy - he has bewitched me body and soul. I am sorry I can only award five stars for it is worth at least ten!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my all time favorite movie! I have watched it too many times to recall and yet it thrills me each and every time. The actor's portrayal of these beloved characters is simply delightful. You can't help but fall in love with Mr. Darcy and hope that Lizzie will too. The beautiful scenery and music makes it even more of a pleasure to watch. The rain scene is one of my favorites. I wanted them to kiss and realize they were meant for each other. The ending is absolutely perfect in every way. I highly recommend this movie and would give it more than 5 stars if I could.
summary: Best version of Pride and Prejudice I've ever seen

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was sort of off put with this adaptation of Pride and Prejudice.  I never thought I would watch a screen play of Pride and Prejudice where Lizzie grows up in a pig farm.  Having grown up south of a good ol' Iowa pig farm, I find it very hard to believe that aristocrats could overcome the odors long enough to propose marriage.  I was also surpised to discover the Bennet family living in what looked like a very large city dumpster.  And last, but hardly least, I was very distracted in the second marriage proposal scene, by poor Matthew Macfadyen's bushy eyebrows appearing very assymetrical.  Although, granted, the director might have been making a plot point with Darcy's uneven, bushy eyebrows, as early on, in Miss Jane Austen's novel, Mr. Darcy notes Elizabeth's failures of perfect symmetry of form.  I don't know though.  Also, I did not care for Donald Sutherland's lisping and simpering.
summary: Rather odd interpretation of Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: Susanna M. Wolf "(Susie Rosso Wolf) Author of...
review_text: Although it's been around for a while now, Pride & Prejudice with Keira Knightley and Matthew Macfadyen is the best version of this Jane Austen classic that has ever been filmed. Donald Sutherland is amazing as Mr. Bennit, as well as the rest of the cast playing their perspective characters. But the energy between Knightely and Macfadyen is one of silver screen legends. I continue to purchase this DVD to give as gifts to anyone I know who hasn't seen it and it never fails to please. Watch it once and soon you will hear yourself saying under your breath..."Mrs. Darcy, Mrs. Darcy, Mrs. Darcy...Mrs. Darcy!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie was certainly an adaptation.  The characters were not as I envisioned in my head when I read Jane Austen's novel.  I think that because so much was cut it was hard to see how characters developed so quickly.  Some of the actors were downright obnoxious.  I have not seen the A&E version yet but I think I would have preferreed it over this one.  Although this review seems harsh, I think it is a decent movie for someone who has not read the book first. I wish I rented this instead of buying it.
summary: Movies just don't compare to books.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm another devotee of the 1995 BBC production of P&P; but I looked forward to this very much.  I accept that this shorter version can only hope to catch the flavour of Austen's work and I never expected that it would follow the novel slavishly.  However, here is what I liked and did not like:I liked most of the production values - the settings were wonderful and it was great that Chatsworth House was used for Pemberley.  The costumes and hairdressing were good:  not at all artificial and probably very much portrayed life in the 1790s (when the novel was actually written) - people sweat, the ladies' hairdos come undone.  The assembly and ballroom dancing scenes were well done and the room they were set in was wonderful.  The photography was excellent and the music charming.  There were some continuity errors, however, that are pretty annoying; others here have pointed them out.I did not like:  Matthew MacFayden came across as shy and immature rather than proud and the master of a huge and wealthy landed estate.  He just did not ring true; he seemed to be floundering around in both his own and Elizabeth's worlds.  Mr Bingley, Simon Woods, came across as androgenous to me - in fact I wondered if he was a cross dresser at times.  He was so annoying - I just could not see how the local belle, Jane, could find him even remotely attractive.  Yuck! And, finally, Donald Sutherland as Mr Bennett:  No, No, No, No, No, No.  The casting, probably a sop to the US audience, was completely ridiculous.  And the scruffy beard????  I think Austen meant him to be a little more refined and sophisticated than the gentleman farmer we see chasing pigs through the kitchen.Silliness:  A complete waste of Dame Judi Dench.  What was Lady Catherine doing visiting the Bennetts in the middle of the night?Nonetheless, it's still P&P; and worth watching although I think I need to revive myself with the Firth/Ehle version again before I view this once more.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I've hesitated on reviewing this for several years now even though I've owned the dvd since its release. I guess I wanted to give it couple attempts to change my mind. Unfortunately, I still feel the same way about this adaptation. It's still the most deplorable adaptation of Pride and Prejudice that I've seen even though I really wanted to like it. There are just too many things that were done incorrectly in this adaptation including casting, wardrobe, dialogue, etiquette, and so on. There were too many cringe-inducing scenes and dialogue to allow me the luxury of enjoying it.While I like Keira Knightley as an actress, her portrayal of Elizabeth was simply wrong. Her Elizabeth erred more on the side of petulant rather than witty. I won't even talk about some of the things that her Elizabeth said and did that Jane Austen's Elizabeth would never say and do because they would be considered improper. I also had a problem understanding Keira Knightley. She spoke her lines way too fast and I was often forced to use the subtitles to understand what she was saying. The rest of the cast I easily understood. I also like Matthew MacFayden. I've seen him in Little Dorrit and The Way We Live Now. However, his portrayal of Mr. Darcy was far too timid. There was nothing confident or supercilious about his attitude; he was therefore unconvincing. The only character portrayal that I liked was Rosamund Pike's Jane. The rest also missed the mark for me.Overall, I was really looking forward to this adaptation when I heard a new Pride and Prejudice was coming out. Unfortunately, this just didn't cut it.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is, in my opinion, a thoroughly satisfying rendition of the beloved novel -- or, at least, it's the film version that I prefer. The acting is outstanding, from bit parts right on through main characters; the settings evocative of place and period; the sets are visions of color, lighting, details that entrance and convince that this is authentic (or, at the very least, a "reality" that satisfies)! Revel in the beautifully chosen colors and luscious tints of walls, gowns/costumes (whether plain or dress formal) and then glory in the sweeping countryside shots...There are some memorable scenes in this one -- enjoy!

The story of predjudice towards different classes of people is changed when to people fall in love with each other, but it takes awhile for the two main actors to find each other.  This is what is appealing to me. Kira and her "Mr. Dorcy" are two really fine actors and do a superb job in this movie. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As many people here have said, Jane Austen's wonderful book is one of my favorites. I haven't seen the Colin Firth mini-series, but I have seen and loved the great BBC version. One problem here is that people are comparing the two five hour (approximately) mini-series with the two hour movie. Necessarily things are going to be left out of the movie. Naturally the character development has to be shortened. No one is going to sit in a movie theater for five hours. I think the story came across intact considering the time alotted.The way I see it P&P; 2005 is a modern version complete with modern cinematography, modern actors and a beautiful, lush soundtrack. I thought the actors did a fine job, especially the very expressive Darcy. I agree that the Bingley character was a little goofy, but I thought that made him endearing. Elizabeth was smart and independent and I enjoyed the rowdiness of her family. I realize that these same traits bothered other people, but they give this version it's own style. Those who want to know more about Austen's satirical look at society can pick up the book.I think the most important review on these pages was the one from a woman with no prior interest in Austen, who happened to catch the movie on a plane flight. She was delighted and went home and bought the book, read it and saw both of the mini-series. A fan is born and that, to me, is the important thing here. If this movie brings more people into the Jane Austen fold, more power to it. On the other hand, if people see it and that's the only exposure to Jane Austen they get, I'm sure they will get along just fine.I must add that I resent people saying it was dumbed down for American tastes. Isn't it possible to write a review without insulting a whole nation?
summary: It's a movie, not a mini-series

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have read all Jane Austen writings(going beyond the six major novels and reading all her letters, unfinished works, minor work - juvenilia, etc.)and have read Jane Austen's masterpiece Pride & Prejudice many times in the past 20 years.  I found this adaptation very disappointing and at times corny because this movie does not capture the true spirit of the book ("light and frothy") and the sharp and irresistable wit of Jane Austen. I wonder what Jane Austen would have thought of the closing scene (no such corny provision made in the book) where Mr. Darcy plants several kisses on Mrs. Darcy while calling her Mrs. Darcy each time.  One such kiss would have been tolerable, I suppose.Moreover, Mathew McFayden's portrayal of Mr. Darcy is quite disturbing because Jane Austen did not intend Darcy to be shy or unsure of himself or wooden or awkward.  Rather, Darcy is supposed to be a little over-confident, arrogant and uncomfortable to be out of his environment and among peasants (at the beginning of the book).  Keira Knightly's acting fares no better.  She did not do justice to the most beloved character of English literature, Elizabeth Bennet who is witty, feisty, vivacious but never forward or desparate.  Nowhere in the book, she asks Darcy if he likes to dance or kissed or would have kissed Darcy's hand, etc.  In addtion, several of the main characters are miscast, notably Mr. Bennet, Mrs. Bennet, Mr. Collins, Charlotte Lucas.The best, and truest, adaptation of Pride & Prejudice is still the 1995 BBC production with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth with excellent cast, no deviation from the witty sparkling spirit of Jane Austen, and with a perfect Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: There's two ways you're going to approach this movie. Your options are:1. I want to watch a fun romantic movie that happens to take place in 1800 England.2. I want to watch a faithful production of a Jane Austen book.If you approached the movie from the first criteria you probably enjoyed it. If you approached it from the second criteria, you probably didn't enjoy it.I have no arguments against the movie as a romantic comedy. It's fun to watch, there's enough sparks to keep you interested and it ends well. What more do you need?But if you're looking for a faithful adaptation of not only Austen's book but an accurate portrayal of the lives of the landed gentry of the time, you probably found yourself annoyed, even angry and disgusted.I've read through several pages of reviews on this movie and there seems to be two common themes regarding the accuracy of the movie's setting.1. Some people thought it was more realistic than the 1995 product but I beg to differ. The Bennets were not farmers. They were not gentlemen farmers. They were landed gentry. The landed gentry lived on estates that comprised of tenanted farms rented out and the family lived off the income. They did not directly engage in farming. The concept that there would be livestock, including pigs, wandering through the manor house is ridiculous, if only because regular farmers certainly didn't let livestock run through their houses either! In the book Mr. Bennet spent his time shooting, reading and drinking wine. Mrs. Bennet boasted about the servants they had and that the girls never needed to cook or clean. They were the idle rich, if not as rich as Darcy or the Bingleys. The Bennets had an income of 2,000 pounds a year at a time when the typical laborer's income was 25 pounds a year. Think about that very carefully before deciding that the relatively impoverished portrayal of the family in this film was historically accurate.2. People liked this movie better because there was more emotion involved between the main characters. I can see where this is coming from. Certainly compared to the 1995 production Darcy and Elizabeth are more physically emotional and one sees more "sparks". That's fine. It's fun to watch. Then again it's not necessarily historically accurate either. Judging the behavior and attitude of characters from 1800 by 2005 standards is wholly misleading. The British upper classes to which the Bennets and the Darcys belonged prided themselves on a very strict set of rules governing public behavior and social conduct, after all they gave birth to the entire concept of the "stiff upper lips." Elizabeth Bennet would not have shouted at Darcy as she did in this movie, to do so would be a sign of bad breeding and bad behavior, which she went great pains to avoid because other members of her family were already badly behaved. Jane Austen makes clear that characters who were too publicly emotional and who couldn't constrain themselves with proper decorum were looked down upon or suffered badly - such as Mrs. Bennet who is held in contempt or Lydia who's a ridiculous character deserving little sympathy and whose behavior almost ruined her sisters' chances for a good marriage. It may be difficult for a modern audience to struggle with this concept but the rules governing behavior in 1800 England was very different from today and very strict by modern day standards. If a real family like the Bennets as portrayed in this film were around in 1800 England, they'd have been shunned and despised by their neighborhoods much as we might look down on "trashy" people for loud, vulgar and coarse behavior, lack of neatness of dress or unshaven faces.On the whole it was a fun and entertaining movie to watch if you didn't take it too seriously. It's still too "2005" as too many modern influences from behavior to hair styles and even clothes crept into the film to make it realistically accurate. The 1995 production is so accurate that it's become timeless - you really can't tell if it was made in 1975 or 1985 or 2005 or today.
summary: Depends on what you're looking for

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Austen races through time in her novel but this movie version skips many good details sadly. This is just, "Rich man falls in love with poor woman." Obviously the star is Knightley but in the original BBC movie (still the best) and the book it is both Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. The lines were so fast here it was like having a finger on the fast forward. The Bennet's were not so poor that they had pigs in their living room; they were upper middle class so this version is just an "updated" fast forward through Cinderella-type story lines. Key lines were said so quickly there was little enjoyment. Better to read the book or - still better - go get the 1995 version with Ehle and Firth. Far, far, far better and much more realistic and true to Jane Austen. I'd hate to see this cast do other books that require time - Gone with the Wind or War and Peace. Ghastly.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I must admit that I honestly hate the book Pride and Prejudice.  The story seems to drag on for an eternity and I lose interest long before the book concludes. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I might be the very last hopeless romantic to lay eyes on this movie, but just in case I'm not, let me tell you how much I LOVED it.  I just got done watching it on DVD and I can honestly say I loved every minute of it.  All throughout this movie, you get to see how people must have acted back in that time.  All the women curtsey to everyone they meet and people are just formal in general.  The landscape of this movie was beautiful.  There were also very slight, but very funny little moments between the sisters, the mother, the father and the upper class of this movie.  I started out not even liking the main male character in this movie, and ended up loving him at the end.  It's like you were able to witness Lizzie and Mr. Dausey fall in love, every step of the way.  This movie made me laugh and cry and want it to never end.  It was one of the most romantic movies I have ever seen.  If you're a woman and you haven't seen this movie yet - you better get your butt to a movie rental store and rent it right away!
summary: One of the MOST romantic movies I've ever seen!

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Read the book, didn't like it, why would I like the movie? The story of a family whose English countryside home and property must pass to the next male heir, just rubs me the wrong way.  There are five daughters in the family, and the mother's goal is to get them all married off advantageously (in case her husband drops dead and they are all kicked out).  I don't remember all the chickens, pigs and goats being all around the house, nor the wash hung on the line. Of course none of the girls, mother or father had to do a lick of work, they had servants for that...the father thanked one of them once for serving the food.  One maid hums as she passes out the clean laundry, so we're supposed to infer that as servants, they were content with their lot in life.Kiera Knightly plays Lizzie Bennet, who is supposed to be not very attractive, but very intelligent and witty. This is not convincing.  Ms. Knightly displayed a disturbing habit of wrinkling her nose and baring her overlapping incisors at the camera at almost every opportunity. In fact, I think her teeth should have gotten second billing.The rest of the story is basically the same as the novel and all following Harlequin romance stories - distant man, girl can't stand him, learns more about him, falls in love (especially when she sees his house), he falls in love with her, oh happy happy joy joy. The mother gets to brag on daughters, keep house, keep servants. Absolutely no contribution to society is necessary. Get what you can, survival is everything.
summary: I Just Don't Like This Story

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen, always have. And I have seen, I believe every version of P&P that's out there (including the 1930's version and the Bollywood-like 'Bride and Prejudice'. While I love the BBC miniseries version, this one to me, goes in tone and feeling where I don't think BBC had the scope for. I saw this movie not 1,2,3 but 4 times in the theatre. I never got tired of it, but i stopped going because the theatre staff were starting to recognize me on site. This movie is now in the top 5 of my all-time genre-crossing films. I was moved every time I saw it, no matter how the audience was, or who I was when I was watching it. If you haven't seen it, go buy it, because renting it will only cost you more in the end, after you rent it for the fifth time. An instant classic!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride and Prejudice is what got me to pick up Austen's book in the first place.  Since then I have watched the BBC version a number of times and rewatched this version countless others.  I have come to the conclusion that a blend of the two would be perfect, but since that won't happen this is my first choice.  There is no correct or incorrect way to interpret literature so there can be no correct or incorrect way to produce a film based on Austen's book.This version is my favorite because it was able to create a chemistry between the characters which, from my viewing, is completely missing in the BBC version.  Again, that was my interpretation of it.  Don't not view/buy this movie because reviews criticize its lack of authenticity.  If you want complete authenticity read the book.  If authenticity to the written word was required for every film Hollywood and every film producer would be out of business..

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It's so rare to find a satisfying romance at the movies that I nearly dissolved into raptures of delight to discover not one but two of them this weekend! On Friday I had the distinct pleasure of going to see the new theatrical version of PRIDE AND PREJUDICE with Keira Knightly and Matthew MacFadyen. To be honest, I was prepared to be disappointed. I had seen the rather murky looking trailer that made even the gorgeous Keira Knightly look washed-out and blotchy. Plus as we all know, every version of P & P must now be compared to that platinum standard of the 1995 BBC mini-series with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle.But I found the new movie to be thoroughly delightful and exhilarating! At just a little over 2 hours long, it couldn't cover quite as much ground as the mini-series (Wickham and the two younger sisters had very minor roles), but it beautifully captured the romance and robust good humor of Austen's story. I was caught off guard by several laugh-out-loud moments.Keira Knightly embodied Elizabeth Bennet's intelligence and wit. (Her portrayal also reminded me a little of Jo March in LITTLE WOMEN.) One glimpse of her smile and you knew why Darcy's heart was captivated. MacFadyen as Mr. Darcy won me over in the moment when I realized his voice had the exact same timbre as Alan Rickman's. The murkier cinematography actually ended up making the movie seem more vital and historically accurate. The gritty images of daily life are contrasted with breathtaking shots of the English countryside, including one of Mr. Darcy striding out of the mist that almost rivals Colin Firth's rising up out of Pemberly's pond on the female gasp of appreciation scale. (Yes, this is an actual scientific device. I have one in my office.)(Originally published on the website of author Teresa Medeiros[...])

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightly has finally stopped getting collagen injections on those lips of hers, and it's quite an improvement in this somewhat decent movie.The acting on Knightly's part wasn't bad, and neither was Donald Sutherland's, but the rest of the cast was annoying.And although the music was very good most of the time, it was drowned out by the terrible cinematography.  That cinematography!The lighting was very pretty, although whenever the characters in the movie would take a stroll in town, you could tell that the "town" was a set.And why did Elizabeth (Keira Knightly--no, I'm not confusing it with Elizabeth in "Pirates") stand on the edge of that cliff in the first place?  Why did she wish to be there?  Was she dreaming?  If not, where in the world was she?  How did she get there?  How long did it take her to get home?  What's the point in having that in the movie, seeing as it made no sense?Altogether, this movie was just so-so.  But if you can tolerate obnoxious cinematography, things happening for no reason and annoying co-stars, then I'm sure this is the movie for you.T.K., 14

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is addictive!  Can't wait to read the book now!  You get to know the Bennet family to the point where you feel like you're one of them.  You feel all the feelings Lizzy feels in this rollercoaster ride of emotions towards Mr Darcy.  They fall in love at first sight but Lizzy's pride and Darcy's missunderstood awkwardness keep them apart.  All scenes with Darcy and Lizzy together you can FEEL their passion for one another.  The one thing I hated in the movie was the ending......because I wanted more!!!!!  I am being a bit greedy!  It was a good ending.....I'm just addicted to the Darcy/Lizzy romance.  All of the actors were perfect for their parts and the cinematography/settings are beautiful!  2 thumbs up on Pride & Prejudice!
summary: By far the best movie I've ever seen!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: O.K., I never really thought I'd like these type of movies/genres but let me tell you that I was pleasantly surprised! I loved it and enjoy watching even more after the first few times. I love Kiera's quirky expressions; I couldn't imagine another actress playing "Elizabeth" so well. The actors are so believable, I wish I had a father like Mr. Bennett and Mr. Darsy is so handsome! title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is a must to add to your collection. Whether you've read the book or not, it is truly a classic story that engages you throughout and stays true to the story line.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I can still remember being 18 and watching the BBC mini-series for the first time. The chemistry between Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth was breath-taking. Over the years I have worn out one VHS set, replaced it with the DVD set, and re-read the book so many times I had to replace it as well. I was excited when I heard that a new version was being made until I actually had the misfortune of watching the adaptation(and I use that term loosely). For anyone aquainted with the mini-series or the book, this version is little more than a sprint through the rich world that Jane Austin created and it does not remain faithful to much of anything.In this world, any man besides a doctor would never enter the sickroom of a lady under anything but the most dire circumstances and that would usually result in an offer of marriage to save her reputation, but Mr. Bingly wanders in without even knocking. A gentleman would not consider venturing downstairs in his own home without a cravet and coat on and yet Mr. Darcy is shown wandering the countryside in little more than a shirt and pants. The language is too modern, Elizabeth is too childish and don't even get me started on the ridiculous scene in which Lady Catherine comes to personally pound on their door in the middle of the night.If your looking for a true adaptation of this amazing classic novel, stick to the mini-series. This movie doesn't even come close.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love the book; I love the movie!  Yes, the longer BBC version is wonderful and follows the book more closely, but this movie is outstanding, too! Joe Wright really captures the essence of the book and its characters in such an artistic way! Even the music is phenomenal! I have read and reread every Jane Austen book more times than I care to admit so I am pretty critical of most movie renditions. I would say this version and the BBC version with Colin Firth are my favorites. Make sure you have quiet when you are watching this movie because there are many small details that you need notice. Enjoy.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The DVD was perfect. This is one of my favorite movies of all time. I could watch it every day. The music from the sound track is amazing.I would recommend it for everyone. Ordering from Amazon.com is really simple to do.
summary: cd for Pride and Prejudice from AMAZON

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautiful movie but more reminiscent of the Romantic era versus Regency England.  More Jane Eyre and Mr. Rochester or Catherine and Heathcliff than Lizzy and Mr. Darcy.  And I would have preferred that they left off the "kissing" ending that Americans saw in theatres and on the DVD.  In Britain they left it out because people started laughing in the theatres and I must admit that I had to stiffle a giggle myself.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The movie is great--it is actually a remake of the original film, but I happen to like this version more! Keira Knightley is great, and the rest of the cast is awesome, too!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Those reviewers who criticize the imperfect portrayal of the characters, fancying themselves to be pro Jane Austen, need to go back and read the book again to get it right. They missed a lot of things which the movie picks up beautifully. yes, there isn't time for complete character development in a 2 hour movie. yes, some scenes are combined, which wonderfully serves the purpose of retaining the emotion and atmosphere one gets from reading the book. keeping the scenes strictly by the book, and then cutting it down to 2 hours, would give a watered down version of the overall tone. these people who call themselves fans of Jane Austen seem more to be the narrow minded prejudiced snobs that she abhors. The costumes are different styles, because certain people would be able to have the lastest fashions, and others not. There is a lot of reality in this film that many  peple are overlooking, and much of the original dialogue is incorporated. And who cares that Georgiana is a little extroverted?  The BBC version, BTW, didn't stick strictly with the book - they added things that weren't in the book, like the "most beloved" lake scene.  (What would Jane think about that?)  I think Jane would appreciate all these versions as compliments to the book's timeless popularity and introducing it to new generations. It's interesting that some parts of the film, while not necessarily in the Austen book, are very similar to scenes from P. Aidan's trilogy about the whole story from Darcy's viewpoint. Interesting read to go along with a great movie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was my first introduction to this story, never having read the book or scene other productions. I absolutely loved it. I was heart-broken with Elizabeth when she realized she had lost a man she truly was able to love, and relieved and overjoyed with her when it turned out that his love endured even after her initial rejection. I totally believed that they had fallen in love with each other and would be happily married after the film's end. And I wanted that happiness for them both so very badly. That to me is as much success as a romance story can ever hope to achieve, so 5 stars.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen.  I hate when her books are done on film and they are not true to the orginal story.  This film version left a lot to be desired.  Kierra Knightly as Elizabeth Bennett?  I don't think so.  The BBC has a great version of this story on DVD (Collin Firth as Darcy) and it is many times over better than this.  I may be a purist but if you are going to tell a story, try to stick to the book it is based on and don't cut corners to try to appeal to the those who don't even know who Jane Austen is.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: What I really liked are all the visuals in the movie,  From the start, the dancing scenes were far more realistic (county and Bingley's house were different in nature), but the hints the director left were great.  Darcy's second take when he first laid eyes on Elizabeth; her nervous giggle after she saw him; the long scene at the dance where Elizabeth went from room to room, and Darcy flowing through one scene, the dance where at the conclusions it was just the two finishing the dance.But the killer scene was their argument in the rain.  After she carved him a new one, the physical attraction between them was palpable, and they almost kissed.  Simply fantastic camera work capturing a great actress and a good actor.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is such a well-made movie, the type you end up watching over and over again and never getting tired of in the process.It is filmed so well and in such great locations it just makes you want to jump through the screen and take a walk around for a year or a lifetime.The acting is superb and the screenplay is masterfully done.The lines are delivered so well with such perfect timing, which is so important when adapting a literary masterpiece that radiates with mischievously clever dialogue.Lastly, the soundtrack is just fantastic, I could watch this movie with my eyes closed and still love every minute of it.
summary: A film that will never end up in your garage sale pile.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautifully crafted take on a classic literary piece that is well worth seeing! I like it enough to want to own it as it's one of those films that you enjoy seeing often.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version and the BBC version starring Colin Firth are quite simply my favorite, next to the novel itself. The soundtrack is spectacular.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: ****Aah, Jane Austen. The "Harry Potter" of the independent theater chains. Always reliable to pack the theaters. And you can count on a new film based on one of her books every few years.Mrs. Bennet (Brenda Blethyn) is in a state, her family of five daughters is living on borrowed time. She and her husband Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) live on their current estate as the guests of family members, and it has seen better days. With five growing daughters, she feels it imperative to begin marrying them off, hopefully to rich suitors who can then help provide for Mr. and Mrs. Bennet and the unwed daughters. When word arrives that a nearby estate has been rented by Mr. Bingley (Simon Woods), a rich man from London, she becomes anxious that he meet her eldest daughter, Jane (Rosamunde Pike), scheming for them to spend every available moment together. At the local ball, Jane meets Mr. Bingley and Elizabeth (Keira Knightley), the second oldest of the Bennet children, meets Mr. Darcy (Matthew MacFadyen), Mr. Bingley's friend and guest. Just as Jane and Bingley seem to be headed to the altar, Mr. Bingley leaves the estate causing Jane to become distraught. Elizabeth learns that Darcy may have been responsible and her hatred grows. Yet, every time they meet, Elizabeth finds herself more and more attracted to Darcy. But is the feeling mutual?Just when it seems another film based on a Jane Austen book, especially one already made into a film or miniseries at least six times, not counting the numerous other takes on the same material ("Bride and Prejudice", a recent example), could be excessive, this version of "Pride" pushes the envelope, offering something new.One of the best things this film does is cast more authentic looking people in the lead roles. From Knightley on down, all of the actors have a rougher appearance, which seems entirely appropriate for the time. Some previous film adaptations of Austen's work have cast the most beautiful American (Aaaah- Gwyneth Paltrow - choo!) or British actors in the roles. Every time they appeared on screen, it looked like they just walked out of their make-up trailer. Sure, they looked beautiful, but it isn't believable. "Pride" strives for and attains a more accurate depiction.Keira Knightley is very pretty, but she isn't glamorous. Too skinny, which may be the one aspect of her that doesn't fit the period, she otherwise seems like a pretty girl. Her features are not perfect and this helps her seem to be a natural fit for the English countryside. Also, there are many scenes in which she has just come in from a walk, or the girls are laying about reading books, etc., and they don't appear perfectly groomed; hair may be out of place or there may be mud on the hem of their skirt. It works. In one scene, Dame Judi Dench arrives at the Bennet home. Irate, her hair is not perfect, because she has just arrived on horseback. Matthew McFadyen is also very handsome, but he isn't movie star handsome. He isn't as good looking as Colin Firth or Hugh Grant and it seems more appropriate for the role, the setting and the time.Director Joe Wright also does some interesting things with the camera, which may seem strange or obtrusive on paper, but actually make the experience of watching the film more interesting and enjoyable. In one scene, the camera follows Mrs. Bennet through a ball hosted by Mr. Bingley. She passes certain people throughout the filled rooms. When the camera spots one of the Bennet girls, it stops briefly, allowing us to hear their conversation. After we have heard what we need, it picks up and follows another character, past another conversation. Soon, the camera spots Mrs. Bennet again as she finally reaches the outdoor patio for some fresh air. In another, the camera roves across the windows in the Bennet home picking up pieces of conversation in each of the bedrooms, starting with Mr. and Mrs. Bennet. This gives us the feeling we are watching a book come to life, as though we are turning the pages as we read. It is an effective technique, aiding the look and feel of the film.All of the performances in the film are very good. Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen are very believable as the unrequited lovers. Knightley conveys Elizabeth's intelligence, pride and passion, at turns, throughout the film. She is low key, but very interesting. When she initially meets Darcy, she claims her hatred for him and his attitude. Later, as she tells her father she really loves him, he doesn't understand, yet we do. Matthew MacFadyen conveys Darcy's boredom, growing attraction and passion as well. There are more than a few instances when their attraction to one another is palpable, yet because of their misunderstandings, or misconceptions about one another, are unable to act. It seems as though they take shifts; in one scene Elizabeth is in love with him. In others, he loves her. Throughout, reciprocation is prevented by an outside influence of some sort. The final scene is also very romantic.All of the supporting characters are equally believable. Brenda Blethyn is a little over the top, but it works to see her running around, insinuating her daughters into the lives of every eligible bachelor within ten miles. Donald Sutherland is great as the father who is much quieter than his wife, yet he exudes a quiet admiration for his partner. He is also the more level headed member of the family providing calm and serenity to his somewhat overbearing wife. Judi Dench is also memorable as a member of the aristocracy who tries to control the lives of some of the people involved.I don't think we can ask for more in a film adaptation of a book; the characters, their persona, the setting and the feel of the period are all correct creating an engrossing film worthy of any book.
summary: Yet Another Jane Austen Film?... Oh, Yes!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The 1995 version of this movie with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehrle was the most beautiful production, filmed b ythe BBC and shown on the A&E; channel. The scenery was luscious, the acting was convincing, and the period of the drama seemed more authentic than this version. Also the cinamentographer had breathtaking views. Also, this 1995 version is light, breezy, and easy comedic drama. I believe this is the movie catapulted Colin Firth's career.  For me, he will always be "the" Mr. Darcy.Now, regarding this 2005 remake, for the film has been remade many times, it was a very drab. I love Keira Knightly, and I thought Brenda Bleven played her part well; however, Allison Steadman, who played the mother in the 1995 version, was very irritating but funny too. I didn't like Donald Sutherland portrayal as the father. To me, he seemed somewhat aloof as the father. Of all the sisters, Jena Malone, who portrayed Lydia, was the most miscast as was the actor who played Mr. Collins. If you get the 1995 version, watch how David Bammer who played this role just makes you laugh at his portrayal of this character. In my opinion, the main fault of this movie, along with the casting, should not have been squeezed into two hours. The 1995 version, on two discs, was just over 5 hours.Andrew Davies, the British screenwriter, really caught the nuance of Jane Austin's book. I'm sure this is the movie that help catapult Colin Firth's film career. In my opinion, he's never had a better role even although he's gone on to have been nominated as Best Actor for "A Single Man", then later won the Oscar for his role in "The King's Speech."  So, please, please see the 1995 A&E; version with Colin Firth, please see it. It is a wonderfully made.
summary: Boring version. See 1995 version with Colin Firth; It is EXCELLENT!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Amazing movie that always leaves warm fuzzy feelings at the end. :) Of course they left a lot out of Austen's original story, but this movie was excellently done and condensed in a way that I felt absolutely did justice to the book. It covered every main point without being rushed, and the main actors are phenomenal!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Simply put, this is the best movie of the year.If you're an Austen fanatic you might have some difficulties, but if you simply like entertaining movies, you will love this film.Great acting, great scenery, great story-what else could you want?This is one definitely not to be missed!
summary: The best movie of the year.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: At least the 1940 movie had a superb cast (Most notably L. Olivier as Mr. Darcy) while this version has nothing, absolutely nothing to justify it. Cut to bleeding chunks Austen's witty novel appears like a Rosamunde Pilcher novel set in Regency Times. Which brings me to my next point. Regency. People of that standing did not scamper around in sloppy and non-period clothes at the time, esp. not in England! Wrong hairstyles, utterly wrong and garish colours do not stand for "natural" but for lousy costumes & make-up and no understanding of the time-period. The most horrid faux pas was what both wore in the kitschy and trashy sunrise scene that subsituted the truly sweet and charming second proposal moment of the novel. They rewrote not only that but cut important things, added useless stuff & dialogue! And the acting? Keira Knightly, for all her looks, was just annoying as Elizabeth. Her giggling wasn't charming but ridiculous, her impertinence with Darcy came off more as petty rudeness than anything else and her lack of elegance, wit & grace was appalling. Lizzy never would let Darcy almost kiss her in the first proposal scene or yell like that while showing her teeth as if to bite him! McFayden neither has the handsome looks nor the mystery & arrogance needed for Darcy. He portrays him as weak, sweet and misunderstoof from the start, yech! It's "Pride and Prejudice" not "Bitchy & Misunderstood"! The beautiful process of Darcy coming around because of love is destoyed completely because of this. We are left with an utterly bland romance, a defanged Jane Austen & P&P; robbed of its wit, charm, fun and true love so that we may see a soapy, second class romance novel movie that is pretty useless.Stick with the BBC Miniseries with the supreme Jennifer Ehle and Mr. Darcy himself: Colin FirthOr even the other BBC Miniseries with Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen fans will love to see this wonderful story come to life with such life and passion.  Matthew McFadyen makes a wonderful Darcy - tortured yet strong, stubborn yet tender.  Kiera Knightly is wonderful as Lizzie and brings heart and poignancy to the part.  Even if you know the story, bring your box of tissues...
summary: My favorite Jane Austin novel comes to life!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Great love story. Excelent actors. Great Blu Ray image and sound. And an extra scene that blew me off!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: If you're a fan of Sense & Sensibility or maybe Room with a View.... or Belle (a new movie out this year, 2014), any period piece romances -- then you will absolutely love this!  If you've never tried a love story from the time period before (England around 1800).... but  you love romance... then definitely try this -- love is love... the feelings are the same, so the time period doesn't change that. If you love fairytale romances.... soulmates, true love.... you will NOT be disappointed! Bonus: The Cinematography is beautiful.
summary: If you loved Sense & Sensiblity, you will LOVE this, too!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie!  I think it is better than the book.  The characters are beautiful.  I watch it every chance I get.  It has that deep love that makes your heart pound.  It's one of those movies that you don't want to end.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have always loved this version, and I am spoiled to anything else. Perfect example of how people's assumptions and actions can potentially ruin lives. There is nothing like explanation and honesty...spoken nicely, of course. Smart-alek retorts are for the birds.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The Best Pride and Prejudice yet to be produced.  Artists and music lovers this movie is a rare delight.  The cast seemed picked by Jane Austen herself. If you think Colin Firth is synonymous with Mr. Darcy then Matthew Macfadyen will make you re-think your loyaty.  Mr. Macfadyen has captured Jane Austen's Darcy, not hollywood's Darcy.  Keira Knightley eyes are as fine as Lizzie's.  Donald Sutherland's last scene as Mr. Bennet with Lizzie in his study is perhaps one of the most genuine performances that I have had the joy to watch.  I watched it over and over again.  Rosammund Pike is the perfect, most beautiful Jane- just as Jane Austen wrote she's the most beautiful of the sisters. She embodies Jane's purity and innocence, her endearing qualities shine through.  I have not enjoyed a "Jane" yet -til now.  The use of light and darkness, the constant use of black and white the art and sculptures are beautiful, beautiful, beautiful. There is a scene at Pemberley in the art gallery.  The staute of the veiled woman took my breath away!  It was just gorgeous.  The timing in the sunrise scenes are a visual dream! Breathtaking locations, views and beautiful music and acting!  Bravo!!!  And to top it all off--the world famous pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet plays all the piano music.  This presentation of the most beloved love story appeals to us visually, audibly and emmotionally.  Well done!- a must have!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Love the movie but it can't compare to the book; too much plot is missing. It's still a fun movie to watch though!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I hated this version from beginning to end. Keira knightly's jutted out mouth and her fake accent makes me cringe. And Mr Darcy was completely stiff and I agree with one of the reviewers questioning why he was like a brooding Heathcliff. Ugh, although I agree with everyone that the A&E/BBC version was much better  I still don't like the fact that Elizabeth is always portrayed as the prettier sister instead of her sister which is suppose to be the beautiful and sweet one. I might be nit picky but I just find that aspect of the book to make Elizabeth seem more charming and the story more movable that a plain, tom boyish, intelligent girl wins a mysterious, handsome, wealthy man. I so wish James McAvoy agreed to be Mr. Darcy. It would have been much better with him in it and probably win more awards. He was stupendous in Atonement and so was Keira Knightly. Ugh!!!!! What a waste of film.

title: Pride & Prejudice
reviewer_name: T. Noever "Author of the TETHYS series"
review_text: First of all, I enjoyed this version; I really did. What it got right is a more distinct sense of the darker and chaotic side of Jane Austen's worlds. There's a lot of melancholy here, which wasn't rendered in the preceding TV series. The Brits--though this time contaminated by French input, which didn't help at all; it seldom does-can do Austen very well indeed when they put their midns to it. The BBC version of Emma with Kate Beckinsale was so much superior to the boring Paltrow cinema version.Where does this latest production of P&P; fail?The first problem coming to mind is the script. Adaptation is an art all of its own, and while the TV series had time to plot out most of the significant narrative strands of the novel, two hours of film doesn't. Purely from a scripting point of view, significant characterizations--'significant' in the sense that they contributed to the explication and bringing-to-live of the central characters--were far too 'pro forma', almost as if they were thrown in because the writer felt that they needed to. The result was that many of them had no function at all, and cluttered up the action and diffused the narrative focus.The second problem had to do with direction. The first half, with the aid of the muddled script, was confusing, unconvincing and occasionally annoying. I loved the deconstruction of the decorous superficiality that adhered to the TV series, and the occasionally chaotic social occasions; but in the end it got too much, and the interactions of the main characters were lost, instead of, as the director presumably intended, contextualized. Also, the sound was awful. The deliberate toning-down and made-hard-to-hear-above-the-din of individual conversations may have had an element of realism, but the strain of the listener, having to work out just exactly what was being said, didn't help one's becoming engrossed in the tale. The vacuous sisters and mother and their hysterical carry-ons also became annoying and were overdone and for too long.Third problem: Keira Knightley. She's a cool actress, who fits perfectly into King Arthur, Pirates of the Caribbean, Love Actually--but here she was very much miscast. If the producers had had any guts they would have cast the incomparable Rosamund Pike in that role, instead of wasting her in the nearly-invisible part of Jane Bennett. Rosamund was the saving grace among the women of Die Another Day, and here, too, she basically stole the show without even trying hard whenever she appeared, whether she said or did much or, as was the case for the most time, not. Keira, by contrast, needs to act-by-effort since she doesn't as yet have enough depth of personality. Too much 'star' and not enough 'character'; quite unsuitable for this part. She battled her way through it valiantly, and I admire her for that, but it just wasn't 'right' for her. The mis-casting was rivaled only by the casting of Katie Holmes in Batman Begins.Fourth problem: just about all the male characters, except for Donald Sutherland, who can do no wrong. That the film should fade out with a shot of him was an unexpected stroke of genius. I wonder if it was scripted that way or a directorial decision. (I never saw the alternate ending, which I probably would have loathed; so let's go with this one and pretend that the other never was).Having said all these basically negative things, I'd like to finish on a positive note, which is that in the second half, when the 'busy-ness' started to abate, the film actually acquired depth and became quite touching. The final scene between Elizabeth and her father was the crown, and if an ending is what makes a movie, it makes me forgive many other mistakes.But just imagine if, instead of Keira Knightley it had Rosamunde Pike who had been doing that scene with Sutherland. It would have been near-perfection.It was meant to be FOUR stars (I entered five by mistake!) and that solely because of the second half and a great attempt to take the saccharine edge off the movie-incarnations of Austen's novels.Till Noever, owlglass.com, Author: KEAEN, CONTINUITY SLIP, SELADIENNA

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is beautifully filmed. Excellent costumes and locations. The acting and directing are right on. I recommend this movie to everyone. Much more than a love story.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: We greatly enjoyed seeing the new adaptation of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. Jane Austen's stories are rich romances, featuring strong and spirited women who seem like they won't get the man they deserve, and the men are often not what they seem at first blush (both good and bad), but character always triumphs over class and money in her endings. In this story, protagonists Lizzie Bennett and Mr. Darcy spar engagingly like Beatrice and Benedick until the inevitable reconciliation. Keira Knightly is perfectly cast as the spirited Lizzie, and Matthew MacFadyen is marvelous as the brooding and taciturn Darcy. The story has been very nicely adapted to the screen by big screen newbies director Joe Wright and writer Deborah Moggach (though rumor has it that Emma Thompson had some hand in the dialogue; she is credited on the film with "special thanks"), in a sensitive handling that focuses on the romance and the character judgments (and mistakes) that people can make. Beautiful shots of English countryside, together with some very subjective camerawork contribute to the story. (One memorable scene: when Lizzie and Mr. Darcy are dancing at a crowded ball, and for a moment we see the scene as Lizzie does, as if they are the only two in the room, providing a nice depth of feeling in contrast to her seemingly aloof repartee.) The cast are all excellent, but especially notable are Donald Sutherland as the loving father Mr. Bennett (who truly wants his daughter to marry for love), Tom Hollander as the mousy and obsequious Mr. Collins, and of course Judi Dench as the imperious Lady Catherine de Bourg. The costumes, settings, and even the blocking (all that courtly bowing) perfectly recreate the texture of the period. The superb 1995 adaptation of Sense and Sensibility was a hard act to follow, but Pride and Prejudice lived up to our great expectations.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this version of this classic! Great movie what else can you say about it...If you like classics, get this one!

review_text: While rating a movie can be very personal by nature of one's tastes, likes, or dislikes I rated this movie a Five based on script, acting, music score, and authenticity of costumes, scenery, and subject matter for that time period in history. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: That this masterpiece of film making is not rated five stars speaks more to the dim witted audience than to the film. Too many big words and not enough sex and violence for today's vacuous viewers.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Austen's novel is based on sharp observations on human nature.  In particular, Elisabeth's attraction to the opposite sex is not so much her beauty but the beauty of thought and the ability to engage others with witty verbal exchanges. The fast and intense fireworks between Elisabeth and Darcy have been partially destroyed by the film's script, which assume movie viewers cannot understand or follow their long verbal duels.  It is sad how the new script have cut or shortened these exchanges.  The music and the scenary tries to compensate for its loss but the result is never fully satisfying!
summary: Pride & Prejudice without Austen's verbal exchanges

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, I am a rabid Frith and BBC fan of the miniseries, but I was very impressed with this adaption and found it refershing in it's grounded, youthful take on the story.For starters, there is a very grounded nature to the presentation of the story. Some Austenites got their knickers into a twist because they thought it made the family and their circumstances too drab looking. But I loved it! The Meryton Assembly basically sets the stage for this grounded approach-the dancing looks a little heavy footed, the girls look sweaty, and you can't help but think that someone needs to open a window cause it looks awfully sweaty! But at the same time,it made the story come alive, like you were a fly on the wall, peeking in on Lizzy and Darcy and the rest of the gang.Lastly, I loved the youthful take on the story. I LOVE Firth and Ehle as the '95 leads. They had this chemistry and sensual tension that was electric! But their take was definitely from a mature standpoint-like the way I'd act now as a 33 year old woman. Whereas Macfadyen and Knightley? Theirs is a more youthful, innocent, first love take that I just took to. Great chemistry, Lizzy's a little less cocksure, Darcy's a bit more unbalanced by this attraction, and it felt right in terms of age and stage of development with the actual characters in the book.Great adaption, brisk storytelling, and a wonderfully irreverent tone by a fun director who knew it was a good idea to knock the pedestal off from under our Lizzy and Darcy, and let them be seen in a more grounded light. And ps-I thought Macfadyen, even though he doesn't have that big of a part, was a great Darcy!
summary: I'm a Firth/BBC fan, and I still loved it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This item was a gift. It is one of the best all time love stories. It is a great movie. Best all time love story
summary: One of the great love stories

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Keira Knightley is the PERFECT PERSON for these flicks ,,, If you like this movie try "The Duchess" very good too

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Granted, if you already own the single disc and the soundtrack you might not care, but there are a lot of people out there who still don't own this beautiful film and they will most likely enjoy this set.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: With the Colin Firth-Jennifer Ehle BBC version still fresh and available, why anyone thought that making an abridged theatrical version with anachronisms and insipid acting is beyond me. It's illiterate to confuse the srong-willed and unconventional Austen character of Elizabeth Bennet with a modern-day liberated feminist, which she was not and could not have been. The BBC version understood that; this version was silly and superficial, not to mention that there was no chemistry at all between the leading characters. The idea of Mr and Mrs Bennet as a loving couple is completely contrary to the original story. There was no presentation of the absolute necessity for a young woman with little money to have to marry well, and many other essentially interesting plot points were eliminated.  This Mr Darcy isn't haughty and rude, we're supposed to feel sorry for him because he's shy?  Films are different from novels, but if you're going to change the essentials of the story, you might as well update it entirely to the present day, and call it something else, but not Jane Austen's.
summary: Well, I suppose a little Austen is better than none.  Maybe not.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have always loved this story and even though some people may not like this new version I appreciate how it was done.

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I admit it, all right, I liked this movie more than I expected to.  When I first heard that they were making a new version of Pride and Prejudice, I was excited.  Then when I heard that Keira Knightley was playing Elizabeth, I was put out.  Understand, please, that while Knightley is just fine as a pirate-movie chick, I do not believe she has the acting props or even appreciation of the character she is playing (don't take it to heart, Elizabeth Bennett is, you know, the most complex and thoroughly likeable, believable female character in literature.).  She was ok, a little better than I thought she would be, but I did not recognise Lizzy Bennett in her.  Matthew MacFayden I liked more the second time through, but really thought basically the same of him as of Keira Knightley, that he was more a pretty face to put on the screen than a serious competitor for the "perfect" Mr. Darcy.Perhaps my favorite part of the movie was Jane Bennett, who is played very well by an actress whose name I don't know, but who loks and acts the part sublimely.  Sometimes it's hard to like Jane in the book, because she's just too perfect, but she makes you realize why it is that everyone likes Jane, and it was a joy to watch her performance.As for the soundtrack, it was very pretty, but I kept on thinking to myself, "if you're going to sound exactly like Chopin, why not just use Chopin?  He's dead, he's not going to care."Anyway, it was a very enjoyable movie, I went to see it twice and liked it both times, but when you're dealing with a classic like P and P, I think a little more care would be in order.  I have certainly seen worse ruination worked on a book in a screen version however, so some credit goes to the director for restraining himself as much as he did.
summary: Lovely as a movie, ok as an interpretation of the book

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: DO we need another `Pride and Prejudice'? When we have already the excellent 1995 BBC TV mini-series? It depends solely on this - Elizabeth Bennet and Darcy. Without the chemistry between these endearingly headstrong characters, there is no point in making a new film, no matter how much money you spend on the sets and the costumes.The newest version of Jane Austen classic (`Pride & Prejudice') will be met with skepticism, but as far as Keira Knightley's portrait of this feisty heroine goes, it is a perfect success. Forget her terribly miscast role in `Domino,' and enjoy the film's spirited heroine who learns a thing or two about romance in the late 18th century England.Compared with her, Matthew Macfadyen who plays the laconic Mr. Darcy is less advantageous from the first. We have seen impeccable portrait from Colin Firth (and another impeccable one from Laurence Olivier), and who can forget them? Surprisingly, Macfadyen's Darcy turns out a convincing one, the aristocratic image of a person with something repressed deep inside. Unfortunately, he is not allowed to do much in this running time.[MODERN TOUCH ALL AROUND] I personally do not find the modernized dialogues exchanged between the characters so irritating as some viewers say. I know the film focuses the original book's romantic side, and gives less attention to the class structure of the Regency Britain. But if you have to make a 2-hour film, something must go. If romance must go, then ... what is the point of making this film anyway?But I thought first-time director Joe Wright did some missteps during those two hours. He uses too much showy camera works (there is a long one-take sequence in which the camera glides on the dancing floor) while more orthodox way of shooting the scenes are more effective. As to the portraits of the Bennet Family, some might find the eldest sister Jane (Rosamund Pike) is less impressive than she should be, and I for one thought Donald Sutherland, amusing as he is, might be too old for the role of Mr. Bennet.I know `Pride & Prejudice' should not be compared unfavorably with the previous versions though I was, and am, tempted to do so. Still I heartily enjoyed watching this beautifully-shot, well-acted film, and Ms. Knightley's Elizabeth is genuinely lovely and vivid.
summary: As Mr. Collins Says, This Is a "Very Agreeable Alternative": Pleasant Austen Adaptation with Keira Knightley's Vivid Portrait

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I share something w/ many of the previous reviewers--e.g. I am female and love Jane Austen novels; however, I am aware that movie interpretations of her book tend to be more of the 'chick-flick' category; this was the first movie I have ever gone to see by myself (because I wanted to spare my boyfriend the experience, given above 'prejudice'); I thoroughly enjoyed the experience together w/ an equally enthused diverse full house; AND it is the only movie I have ever paid for to see an unreasonable 4 times in the theater, which brings me to something I have in common with ALL the previous reviewers:  I ABSOLUTELY LOVED this movie.A big fan of Firth myself, I actually prefer this version to the A&E; series.  Despite the liberties taken, it aspires to be a much more real, down-to-earth vision of the novel, without the stuffy glorification of Britain's Romantic Era.  Firth is a natural Darcy (see other roles such as in Bridget Jones), but I loved the fresh youthful take of Knightly and McFaydden that brings modern relevance to this beloved classic and the growing pains of its timeless characters.Male/female, old/young, Firth-fan and Austinphile or not so much--this film is delightfully light-hearted, witty, and beautifully shot with a superb-cast!
