title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I never saw this movie at the theater, but I purchased a full screen DVD version and absolutely love this movie. I have watched it countless times. Now I realize how lucky I was to get the full screen version. Recently, I borrowed a copy of the widescreen version from my local library just to see how much I was missing. For some reason, though, I didn't enjoy the widescreen version like I did the full screen version. I then used two computers to run both versions at once, cued at the same time, on side by side monitors and then it became glaringly obvious that the widescreen bars were cutting off immense amounts of important parts of the picture. Yes, the widescreen gives the wider shot, but most of composition of the focus of the scenes is not widescreen in nature, so you're not gaining a lot of important imagery from the widescreen format, but you are losing A LOT from the top and bottom that you get with the full screen format. This really surprised me. I've always assumed that widescreen versions were the full picture shown at the theaters. If the widescreen DVD version is the version shown on the big screen at the theater, then the theater audience missed a tremendous amount of the pleasure of watching this film. I have a hard time believing that this could be the case. THERE IS SO MUCH MORE VISUAL PLEASURE WITH THE FULLSCREEN VERSION. For instance, in the scene at Netherfield where Lydia asks Bingley to host a ball, in the shot of Bingley, Darcy, and Caroline, in the widescreen version, Caroline is cut off at the stomach by the lower bar, while on the fullscreen version of the same shot, you see her near fully sitting on the couch in a way that is very expressive for the scene. Frankly, I pity those who have only seen this movie on the widescreen DVD. What a great shame! How can this be? They don't know what they're missing and their appreciation of this film might be greatly improved by watching the fullscreen version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this version. I think Keira Knightly makes a wonderful Lizzie. And while I am fan of Colin Firth-Matthew Macfadyen IS Mr Darcy to me.The cinematography is beautiful. I especially like the scenes when Lizzie is traveling with her aunt and uncle in the coach and also the scene in the field where Lizzie & Darcy meet early in the morning.And Mr Collins is both annoying & humorous.Lastly, Judi Dench is quite intimidating as Darcy's aunt Lady Catherine de Bourg-except to Lizzie!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: ...and at first, it WAS handsome enough to tempt me...i even bought the DVD.Now I ask myself, "why?" I've watched it only once. I really can't stand it, sorry to its avid fans. But, when one has watched Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth and a 6-hour, faithful-to-the-book adaptation, this really pales in comparison. A LOT. I really don't know what they were thinking when they cast Keira Knightley as Elizabeth. Instead of being a spirited young woman, she seems to be an egoistic teenager who can't keep her mouth to herself.Matthew McFadyen as Darcy was alright, but I agree he was rather wooden- Colin Firth spoke with his eyes, and through this we saw every unshaped thought and desire of his. It really disappointed me how so much of the book was cut (although more could not be expected from a movie), and the unfaithfulness to Austen's time period was simply shocking. When Jane was sick, Mr Bingley should NOT have walked in to see her! It was highly inappropriate and although I sound like a pedant, such small details ought to be considered in making the movie more memorable. Mr Bingley looked like a lovesick teenager, which was irksome too. *Sigh* maybe I expected too much...but is it wrong, when high-quality, endearing literature is in the mix?In its favor; the music and scenery. Both were exquisite, and (to others) patched up the movie's faults. Sorry to sound so harsh, but that's the way I felt.
summary: It was JUST tolerable, I suppose...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a big fan of Jane Austen and all of her work. I have actually taken a college class that dealt with all of her work- all 6 novels, her novella, and her unfinished novel Sanditon. I have always had a soft spot for Pride and Prejudice, and LOVE the A&E version (and Colin Firth). The only thing I didn't like about this new movie is a few historical inaccuracies. These, however, are easily passed over and you can see how wonderful this movie really is. Both Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen did an excellent job. I agree with someone who said in a previous post that they acted more along the lines with the ages of Elizabeth and Darcy. I really liked how they portrayed that sweet, soulful love that I understood Lizzie and Darcy to have. Also, that ending... what more could a P&P fan ask for? :)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version is an insult to Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice.  I absolutely loved the novel and this movie did not come close to capturing the romance, charm and character of it.  It was as if the director hadn't even read or understood the novel.  There was no depth to Darcy's character.  The most vital points about his honorable character and integrity were left out. Elizabeth's discovery of this was poignant to her falling in love with him.  The scenes of their meetings were rushed (probably due to time constraints) one after another when in the book, months go by before they see each other again.  The portrayal of the Bennet family is exaggerated.  While Austen captures the heart of a woman with the slow and deliberate even agonizing wooing between Darcy and Elizabeth, this movie misses the mark.
summary: If you loved the novel, this will be a big disappointment

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I liked Matthew McFadden very much as Mr. Darcy.  Though stiff and aloof, he seemed to almost quake with sublimated passion.  It made me think of the many times in personal relationships that you try to convey your feelings--only to end up completely misunderstood!  I also enjoyed Donald Sutherland as Elizabeth Bennett's good-natured but concerned father.My favorite scene was the last--where Mr. Bennett speaks with Elizabeth in his study as he tries to understand how her feelings for Mr. Darcy were able to change so dramatically.  I was very moved but their interaction in this scene--and the joy that came with the understanding of how truly she now loved Mr. Darcy!
summary: An aloof Mr. Darcy's sublimated passion and an affable but concerned Mr. Bennett

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: about all of the versions that I like...Laurence Olivier and Greer Garson, Elizabeth Garvie and David Rintoul, Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth and this one.  If I had to pick a favorite it's a tie between the Olivier version and this one.  I love all of them; but these two movies, I just think the chemistry was really right between the major stars.  I did like the new take on it also.  Of course in these theatrical versions a lot of the back story has to be cut as they have to move the story along; that's where the Garvie/Firth versions comes in and makes the story very enjoyable also.  My only quibble about the Olivier version, is that I think Greer Garson is just too old.  She's marvelous, but that little bit throws me off about the production.  As for my Darcys...Olivier, McFayden, Firth, Rintoul.  Elizabeths...Garson/Knightly (tie); Garvie, Ehle.  But all of the actors in all of the productions are good.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This was a great movie and relatively faithful adaptation of the book. I just finished re-reading Pride & Prejudice about a week ago and wanted to watch the film, so I rented this and absolutely adored it. It is always tough to make a great book into a movie, but they did a great job with this one: they stayed relatively close to the original, simplifying a few plot lines to keep the story concise and focused. People who have read the book will know there is a lot more to Wickham's story, but you can definitely see why they would limit his time.I think the movie did a fantastic job of portraying the Charlotte/Collins relationship, which in turn highlights the really miserable life options women had in this time frame. As Charlotte says, "I am 27 years old. I am already a burden on my family..."Costume, hair and makeup were all excellent in this film. Casting was wonderful. Cinematography, fantastic.There was so much to like about this movie that renting it just wasn't enough. I want to have a copy for my collection so I can watch it again and again.I have a total book-characer crush on Mr. Darcy, and Keira Knightley did a wonderful job of showing just why Mr. Darcy would fall in love with her. Not only is she beautiful in a very natural way, she is sassy and she doesn't take any garbage from anyone, which was an extremely unusual trait in any woman of her time.Mrs. Bennett was just as fabulously inappropriate as she was in the book.My one disappointment with the movie is that they don't include any of the information that Jane Austen shared at the end of the book about how everyone's lives turned out later on--ie, what is life like for Lydia, Mary, Kitty and everyone else in the family five years down the road. I also thought they could have spent a bit more time highlighting the extremely awkward experience that Lydia's homecoming should have been. It is difficult, with our modern perspective, to really appreciate how just how completely inappropriate Lydia's behavior was.Still, one of the best great-book-to-movie adaptations I've seen.
summary: I rented it, now I'm going to buy the DVD

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love this movie.  Now I have heard that the BBC version is better and the characters are more developed, and they should be for a six hour production.  I would like to see that rendition some day soon.  I have read the book twice so far and love it.  However, I am a mom of four year old twins and I don't have 6 hours to watch a DVD right now.  I think the Keira Knightley Pride and Prejudice is very well done.  They did not butcher the book at all like some do. I give it five stars.  It's absolutely delightful!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Besides Sense and Sensibiliy, this is probably my 2nd fave period film, as well as Jane Austen film. It has just the right amout of drama and humour, all balanced out flawlessly. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I finished watching this new production of Pride and Prejudice today with a bad taste in my mouth.  The characters in this movie were simply not built upon; as a family, the Bennets, were close and loving but you see none of that here. Mr. Collins character was not enlarged upon so you really don't get to see the odious little man he truly was.  In watching the "Behind the Scenes" special feature, several actors mentioned that Mr. Darcy was shy and that's the reason he was so aloof. Not so! Mr. Darcy was arrogant, proud and snobbish, all the characteristics that made Elizabeth fall in love with him, despite these failings.  He softened in her presence and she could see underneath his veneer, while others only saw the indifferent manner he displayed. The portrayal of Jane Bennet and Charles Bingley was ludicrous. These two people were not stumbling, bumbling idiots. They were kind, endearing people who loved each other on sight. There were times, I felt lost and I have two other versions of this love story. Judi Dench and Donald Sutherland were badly miscast.  Lady Catherine would have never made an appearance in the middle of the night to confront Elizabeth.  That scene was idiotic and again failed to show Lady Catherine's true character. I failed to connect with the characters nor the actors who played them.  I feel they were shortchanged by bad direction. My favorite production is the 1940's B&W version with Greer Garson and Laurence Olivier. Although the '90's version with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth was quite good.  Give Jane Austen another chance to impress you.  This version will not.
summary: This "adaptation" forgot to "adapt" much of the book.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This version of Pride and Predjudice is an excellent one.  The music tied well with the movie and the actors/actresses all did a wonderful job of portraying the characters.  The reason I gave it only 4 stars though is because there were scenes in the older film version (from 1995 I believe) with Colin Firth that I would have loved to seen in this movie.  Also, the character of Mr. Darcy in this version didn't really have much to say which was disappointing.  Despite these two faults this is still a movie I will watch over and over again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: No female writer has ever written a story quite like Jane Austen, and so, with every release of the newest interpretation of "Pride and Prejudice" I hold back to see whether or not the filmmaker stays true to the story. Jane Austen wrote from the perspective of the upper class of her time. Though this interpretation lacks that wonderful British English from Jane Austen's pen and plays a little more to an earthy feel, it captures the story, the differences in Darcy's and Elizabeth's situations in life and is a "must see" for any Jane Austen enthusiast. The cinematography is wonderful. Keira Knightly runs away with the show.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: As a 2 hour movie, it removes the character development that Austen has in her book. The best versions of this story are in the mini series versions...so the dislike and the eventual admiration of EB toward Darcy can actually develop and be felt by the viewer.  When EB learns that her sister and family's reputation were saved by Mr. Darcy...that scene was hurried and overlapped by other story parts to get it all in. The best version of this story is the 1995 version with Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy.

Very artistic ( for current standards) and naturalistic acting in all players. Excellent Adaptation. Very good direction. Don't pay attention to those people who say that this is a bad or mediocre adaptation haven't romantic or sensitive spirit so better they read the novel to criticize this movie. Great romance.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I bought both versions at the same time the Firth 1995 and the above. Which to watch first was my initial dilemma. I decided on the above shorter version first and it was the right decision after having now watched watched both versions. Unlike any devout P&P; fan and not having seen either versions before, I at least can watch it for what it is without any pre-conceived notions. It wasnt long into watching this version which I will call the Knightley version, that I noticed a problem with the sound. I couldnt work out if it was me, the player or the transfer. Five to ten minutes in and I said to myself I cant the heck make out what theyre talking about. Dialogue was drowned out by over-powering background music and ran so fast. I had no choice but to start it again and put the subtitles on which as pointed out by another reviewer were often 3 liners and placed which was a nuisance. For that alone I had to drop 1 star when I would have awarded it 5 stars.Sure there was 'Poetic License' taken in this Knightley version. Like theyre manor was more like a farmhouse and very rough and hardly an upper middle to high class. Donald Sutherland though a great actor imho didnt suit his part, he hardly resembled the English Gentleman of his time, more like Colonial America civil war period. These things aside I found this version to be more dynamic then the Firth version. This version gave more goose bumps, lumps in throat and emotional tears. Knightley was perfect in her role she was more dynamic and head strong then in previous version. What you didnt see in this 2 hr.version I saw in the Firth version to fill in the gaps. Which is why I decided on the right version to start off my viewing. So all in all, dont miss this version, it was beautiful even with some of its flaws. It is as I say far more dynamic then the previous Firth version. I also preferred Darcy in this version.UPDATE:Well after seeing the 5 hr. Firth version I could not resist in watching this Knightley version yet once again. It was as moving as the first time I watched it. Only this time I added to my title review the words 'Magical and Etherial' for it truly is as such. Furthermore re the sound short comings. I viewed it this time without the annoying subtitles and came to the conclusion that whilst the production starts almost with a ball which drowned the dialogue I thereafter was able to go along with the dialogue as I say without the subtitles and was better off for it. One still may miss some dialogue as it is still an imperfect sound, but better to take in all the splendour then concentrate on reading every word of the subtitle. My main gripe is that this production should have been longer with at least 3 hours. Especially missing is a wedding scene in its finale and makes ruse with dialogue depicting post marriage. Nevertheless truly magical and NOT to be missed.If you found this review helpful at all please vote on it. Thanks. Pleasant viewing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am a huge fan of the novel and the BBC production so I went into this movie not expecting much. I was pleasantly surprised by the cast and the new more youthful adaptation. I loved that this version dives a little deeper into the central relationship of Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy. My only complaint is that I wish they showed more of this relationship. Other than that, this is a lovely adaptation. The casting is good and the scenery is wonderful. Highly recommended for all Austen fans.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm NOT by any means an Austen purist, but really!  Turning the Bennet home into a hovel, where huge pigs roam freely and laundry suffocates the yard, and an unkempt, filthy-looking Mr. Bennet is perhaps a misguided attempt to make Darcy look far, far superior to Elizabeth, and makes his descent to her level perhaps more accessible to those who don't read and don't have an understanding of the time.  Yikes.  There were parts I enjoyed, and I liked Matthew Macfadyen as Darcy.  Kiera Knightly is very one-note as an actress, don't like her.  Very unsatisifying.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen affected a sea change in the novel in the early 1800s. Before that time the novel was limited to rather farfetched adventure stories like Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe. In the early 19th century, writing about everyday events was quite out of the ordinary, and Jane was the first to successfully portray the behind the scenes workings of the ladies and gentlemen of the English countryside.Watching a new adaptation of a Jane Austen novel is like seeing Shakespeare's Hamlet, there are no surprises in the final outcome. Rather the entertainment comes in the particular adaptation, actor's skills, and production qualities. Austen's Pride & Prejudice is one of her most popular novels, and each time it has found it's way onto the big screen and into DVD it's created a lot of passion for and against the adaptation.Universal's production has had a number of disappointed viewers as evidenced by many an online review. This disappointment typically seems to stem with having something to do with the casting decisions and the perceived lack of chemistry between the principal players. Conversely, some felt there was too much chemistry, or not enough propriety in the manner in which the Bennet's conducted themselves. Or that the Bennet's were incorrectly shown to be struggling financially and therefore didn't live or dress up to the idealized version of English gentility.To the chemistry of the actors, I believe the casting in Universal's version was excellent. Matthew Macfadyen perfectly portrayed the aloof, shy, yet emotionally caring Mr. Darcy. Keira Knightley is a surprise in this role, for she is able to capture the strong-willed, hastily opinionated and yet free spirited Elizabeth Bennet quite well. But more importantly, this adaptation develops the full picture of the Bennet Family, with all five Bennet girls, with their individual personalities vying for the best dress, or introduction. Both Brenda Blethyn as Mrs. Bennet, and Donald Sutherland as Mr. Bennet are superb in their timing, and comedic needling of one another. Judi Dench as the controlling Lady Catherine de Bourg, is pleasingly condescending wicked.Screenwriter Deborah Moggach portrayed the Bennet family in a very real and grounded environment. While she may have packaged Austen's novel in a less glamorous light than is typical; she was able to reflect the troubling circumstances people of that time had to deal with.  After all, the financial fix and worry of having five girls with no inheritance in 18th century England was the very point of view and experience that Jane wrote from.Between Director Wright and screenwriter Moggach, this version of Pride & Prejudice is deeply thought-provoking, and portrays the ups and down, moral questions, dilemmas, and hardships of being in society in the 18th century.
summary: Full Picture of the Bennet Family

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Read by all, watched by many, you can't go wrong having this in your library. Nothing else needs to be said, A Classic!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It has taken two years for me to bring myself to see this movie. On first viewing it, I picked it to pieces and was quite upset, being a purist, but something about it got to me.  By the third viewing I had fallen in love with it, much to my surprise.  Everyone keeps referring to the BBC version starring Colin Firth, but that is the A&E version, which also took some liberties.  The definitive Pride and Prejudice was done by the BBC in 1980 and stars David Rintoul.  He IS Mr. Darcy and that version is completely faithful to the book.  If you have never seen, you must.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While I love this movie for the story, the cinematography is exceptional and viewing in blu ray quality is a must.  The actors are marvelous and the chemistry of the cast is fabulous.  Best version of this classic I have seen.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love Jane Austen's stories.  The acting in this is good, the story is wonderful, and I liked the ending.  I think any film based on a Jane Austen book is well worth the cost.  See more at vyctorynotes dot blogspot dot com.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I love everything P&P, but I was so disappointed with this version.  The BBC version was so much better.  I can watch this one but I prefer the Colin Firth version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is admittedly gorgeous on almost every visual level, a weak script and strange interpretations by both director and actors mar this otherwise enjoyable film. Joe Wright directs this adaptation of the Jane Austin classic that pairs a country girl lacking looks but loaded with prejudice - played by Keira Knightley - with a city gentleman short on personality but full of pride - played by Matthew Macfadyen. While Wright is true to the period as far as look, he is utterly clueless as far as the manners and customs of the people.So many things that happened left me scratching my head. For example, would the Bennet family really have left their laundry hanging on the line at the beginning of a rainstorm while they stood at the window watching? This may say something about the impracticality of the Bennets; but the way it was handled, it says more about the naivete of the director. Also, people walking in and out of other people's houses and bedrooms unannounced; the grandest lady of the county, Lady Catherine, dropping by unescorted in the middle of the night - and sunburned, no less; a gentleman showing up at dawn to propose, and on foot; everyone getting up from a meal so two people could talk instead of sending them into the parlor: people were more formal and considerate than that in the late 1700's and early 1800's. These types of faux pas break down the credibility of the film and make it less than it could have been.My biggest problem was with the two stars. While Keira Knightly was winsome enough as Elizabeth Bennet, her mischievous smile reminded me of a cat or rat. And since she smiles a lot in the film, I had a hard time warming up to her. Most disappointing, though, was Matthew Macfadyen's downright wooden portrayal of Mr. Darcy. I do believe there is a way to play a character lacking personality without becoming a moribund oaf. Neither actor is particularly attractive in this production, and their odd expressions and mannerisms make them even less so. And their lack of chemistry - even though their relationship is supposed to be alienating and strained - is almost painful. Again, there is a way for two people to act like they dislike each other and still show the telltale signs of a growing attraction. When their love for each other is finally revealed, it seems very unlikely. It certainly isn't emotionally explosive the way the revelation of love between Edward and Elinor in SENSE AND SENSIBILITY was. The supporting cast members give far more interesting performances than the stars, and, in most cases, outshine them.The most redeeming aspect of this film is visual, especially the cinematography, which is stunning. There is one tracking shot at the party which is very clever, and makes us feel we are part of it. It begins with Mr. Bennet closing the keyboard to the piano on Mary who had been indiscreetly singing away, continues through the various rooms and conversations, and ends with Mr. Bennet and Mary making up, with a final tag of Elizabeth outside by herself. The entire shot lasts 3 minutes - it seems longer - and is masterful. Another noteworthy shot - less clever because of its self-consciousness - is one of Elizabeth on a swing in the barn, and we are spinning with her, watching the different scenes outside the barn change as they go flying past. While the technique is interesting, it is disruptive, because we are no longer lost in the story, but have suddenly become aware of the camera and what it is doing - an unforgivable sin in cinematography. Other shots of the sumptuous interiors and breathtaking landscapes are wonderful.Overall, this is a fun and enjoyable film, if you can get past the disconcerting anachronisms. It doesn't rank with Ang Lee and Emma Thompson's SENSE AND SENSIBILITY, which had a far better script, far better acting and very few if any anachronisms. But it is good for what it is: a visual feast.Waitsel Smith
summary: GORGEOUSLY MOUNTED, BUT LACKING THE DRAMATIC DEPTH OF SENSE AND SENSIBILITY

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This horrible movie is the worst version of Jane Austen's classic ever.  The screenwriters managed to take out all of the substance of the book,  leaving Elizabeth and Darcy panting for each other.Besides a horrible screenplay, the settings, costumes and styling are not authentic Regency period--at all.Kiera Knightly's hair alone is an abomination.  She is styled like an Elizabethan charwoman.  No gentlewoman would have left the house with those ridiculous bangs. Longbourne was NOT a dirty chicken farm.All of the humor and intrigue is gone from the story.  What is left is insipid, predictable and absolutely nothing like Jane Austen's classic.
summary: The worst version of P & P,  butchers this Masterpiece

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I guess I'm in the minority among reviewers, but I'll stick with my opinion that this is a travesty of Austen's matchless novel.  (I'd give it no stars if the system allowed.)  Virtually every production detail -- the costumes, the hair styles, the number of people at the balls, failure to show Darcy's attraction to Lizzy from the first, behavior of individual characters (Bingley's entering Jane's room in the night, Lady Catherine's pounding on the door for a night time visit), the ludicrous sculpture gallery at Pemberley etc. etc. -- is wrong.  The abilities of such actors as Judi Dench and Donald Sutherland are wasted by a script that essentially gives them nothing worthwhile to do.  They are reduced to being little more than set decoration.  A single feature film cannot include everything in the novel, of course (the much praised 1995 BBC production left things out, too), but a better script would more truly reflect the original, and none of the production details listed can be explained as necessary because of the limitations of adaptation.  Even the old Greer Garson-Laurence Olivier film, which is pretty bad, is a better adaptation than this one.  If you want "Pride and Prejudice" in video form, get either of the BBC adaptations for a version far closer to what Austen wrote.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was very prepared to like this film. I wanted to like it. I'd been warned about the liberties it took.  I'd already heard that it had played havoc with Austen's language, pacing and intent.  I'd heard about the pigs, the period inappropriate behavior of the characters, the idiosyncratic scenes such as the midnight arrival of the great Dragon Lady, the bursting into ladies rooms, the list is endless.  I was prepared for all these absurdities, but had also heard that it was cinematically lovely, took chances and the characters were age appropriate. Yet still I was appalled by the reality.In all fairness we've been spoilt by the last 1995 tremendous miniseries adaptation by the BBC. And a 2 hour movie by its very nature cannot do justice to Austen's matchless prose and wit. But it was horrifying to watch an Austen film stripped of subtlety, wit, pace, delicate but biting social observation (there was nothing hinted at here, it's thrown in your face like slop at a pig!) and almost completely denuded of that sublime Austen language.It's difficult to say at whose feet lies the blame for the terrible acting choices, the horrible editing, the nonsensical exposition. Even the music, which at times I enjoyed as it was very reminiscent of Chopin/Beethoven/Mozart is almost too wall to wall and syrupy and turns Austen into mush.I am making a mad dash for my 1995 BBC version to cleanse my palate and am only thankful that I only rented this version.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I watched both the 2005 film and the 1995 A&E; version close together in time; both are wonderful - the film manages to achieve almost the same effect in just under half the time. Both are respectful of Austen's novel.The new film version is very very fine. The biggest difference between the two is the space allowed to develop various aspects of character and plot (i.e., in the `95 TV series we see the developments from Lizzie's AND Darcy's points of view, we see them in flashback, sometimes multiple times). But the new film version does an excellent job of conveying the book, even if some scenes must necessarily be omitted. The flashbacks of the A&E; version are an easy way of telegraphing a character's second thoughts, but a really good actor can convey doubt and complexity without this assistance.The hardest character for an actor to portray in Austen's novel is Mr. Darcy. Is he a prideful and arrogant aristocrat who changes -- that is, is he a bad character who grows, develops, and becomes good? Or is he a good character who, from the outset, is at least partly misunderstood? There is evidence to support both interpretations. As we learn, all his family, including his servants, who have known him for his whole life admire his integrity and his kindness. But he certainly gives Elizabeth Bennet reason from the outset to find him cold, distant, and even snobbish. However terrific Colin Firth is in the A&E; version, his representation of the character comes down pretty strongly for change and growth, while Matthew MacFadyen, the hero of the recent film and the sweetest Mr. Darcy you would ever want to meet, keeps the question open. His reserve at the beginning could easily be chalked up to shyness. Both Darcies have much to recommend them. Even though Firth leaves more of the impression of confidence and sharpness that I got from Austen's novel, I think I actually prefer the sweetness of MacFadyen, who does a better job of convincing us that he actually finds Elizabeth attractive from the beginning.I'm not a fan of the actress who plays Elizabeth in the 2005 film -- Keira Knightley (her name rhymes with sprightly, only too conveniently) -- but she does credit, in her odd and energetic way, to Lizzie Bennet, and Donald Sutherland makes a surprisingly good Mr. Bennet (though perhaps not quite so true to the book as Benjamin Whitrow in the A&E; version). As much as I admire Brenda Blethyn in other films she is not great here; she is nothing to the earlier BBC Bennet mother Alison Steadman, who more perfectly captures the mother's hysterics. And I don't think Judi Dench is well cast as Lady Catherine de Bourgh (in the movie); she is just too regal and admirable in her own right; Lady Catherine needs a certain reptilian quality, which Barbara Leigh-Hunt in the A&E; production manages very capably. Also, I must admit that Tom Hollander's Mr. Collins in the 2005 does not hold a candle to the simpering skin-crawling performance of David Bamber in the BBC version of that part. Despite these quibbles, however, the makers of this film had their wits about them. Most importantly, they were not afraid of emotion. Both versions end with a very satisfying and un-Austenlike kiss.The music in this film is lush and engaging; the landscape, notwithwithstanding the opinion of other reviewers, captures the constrained circumstances of the Bennets while remaining appropriately Anglophilic in its attachment to the British countryside and country houses. In short, this new movie manages to convey the essence of the book nearly as well and just as movingly as the excellent A&E; series, which is twice as long.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: "Pride and Prejudice," Joe Wright's adaptation of the Jane Austen classic, is peculiarly radient in that these sort of adaptations (for instance, the same novel's '95 television miniseries) are always done with an air of leisure, which is, unless handled well, simply another word for intense boredom; not to say director Wright cheapens the novel in any way. In fact, his luminosity only deepens what societal subtext there is, exciting and intriguing the senses with every frame. We can all from here on out exhale with relief at the thought of a period piece that does not meander but instead distills a piece of art to its exuberant soul while also providing an expansive emphasis on society, in this case Victorian-era Britain. Never are the bounds of marriage forgotten, or the lack of money, or the ridiculousness of romanticism in the context of Austen society (Charlotte, heroin Elizabeth Bennet's good friend, at some point says "I can't afford to be romantic" when defending her marriage to the sycophant Mr. Collins, a line that is all the more poignant coming from the fantastic Claudie Blakley).Perhaps what most distinguishes this version of the well-known tale of the Bennet sisters is the casting. I wholeheartedly call it perfect, with each daughter containg their aesthetic qualities and personality quirks as described in the novel. As with most British costume dramas, the supporting cast is pitch-perfect throughout, including Brenda Blethyn and Donald Sutherland as Mr. and Mrs. Bennet. Matthew McFayden plays Darcy convincingly, which is important considering the emotional arc he's called the portray. The biggest surprise, however, is most certainly Keira Knightly, who I expected to be nothing short of a mess but instead gives off the sharp, modest beauty inherent in Elizabeth Bennet.In my recent essay on the novel "Pride and Prejudice" for AP Literature, I concluded in saying that above all Austen makes the point "that all people deserve to love and deserve to be satisfied with who they are and who they grow to be." Joe Wright's largest accomplishment is making me believe said message all over again. Even if the accomplishment is rather minor in terms of cinema (though major when considering that it's a debut), it compells on every level, a quality in film that's been missing for most of the year.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a phenomenal movie! I have seen every adaption of this film, and this is by far my favorite version of this movie! The acting is great! I love the end scene in this movie as well!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It comes with a DVD and a Blue Ray, which is great. Unfortunately, the digital copy has expired so it can't be downloaded!I will be contacting them to get it worked out.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The most basic description of Jane Austen's book, "Pride and Prejudice", is that it is a humorous, romantic satire about the hypocrisy of class distinctions among the landed gentry. That is to say, it's about "rich" vs. "poor" (where the poor aren't really all that poor). In England, in the early 1800's--the setting of this book--there was a great deal wrong with system of money and property transfer, which was very patriarchal, and terribly unfair to women, and the behavior of the so-called elite towards those who weren't fortunate enough to be born into wealth. Part of the humor and genius of P&P; is how refined, polite and kind the lower-class Jane and Elizabeth behave as compared to Lady Catherine, Miss Bingley, and Mr. Collins, all of whom possess all the appearance of class while being as rude and insulting as possible. Jane Austen was making a tart social statement as well as delivering a heady romance.So what on earth is going on in this film? The Bennets aren't so much landed gentry as flat-out peasants. They all behave abominably. The language isn't playful and dripping with hidden meaning; it's ultra-modernized and dumbed down. As far as the total reinterpretation of the story, I am guessing that the writer and director don't even know what this story is all about or threw it aside in favor of making this into a bodice-ripper.  Mr. Darcy, a member of the highest possible social rank, might look down on Elizabeth as a potential wife for being born to a family with less money, but there is NO way that a man of his stature would EVER propose to someone who lives in squalor and has no manners, as this Elizabeth is portrayed. It's as if they were all blowsy Americans, as opposed to stiff-upper-lip Britons.As far as the performances go, the actors here are dreadful. Keira Knightley is the same character in every single movie she's done--either open mouthed and wide-eyed like a deer in the headlights, or with a pinched and vacant smile. Matthew McFayden has as much range as a saltine cracker. The rest of the Bennet girls are indistinguishable from one another, and in fact, I kept getting Charlotte confused for one of them, because they all looked and acted identical to one another. There was wayyyy too much giggling.The period details are all out of whack. Why is Lady Catherine wearing a hairstyle that was popular around the time she would have been born? Why does Caroline look like a character out of a contemporary sitcom? The whole fast-and-loose approach with the styles, mannerisms, and language of the period make it impossible to mentally inhabit the period they're portraying. The behavior, language, clothing and set design are so completely wrong for the period that the only way this film would work would be as science fiction. They should have avoided doing a period piece at all.
summary: Would have been better with zombies

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Very good adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, showing some feminist bias against an original Austin reading (ie. Lizzy telling Jane about Wickham settling for less that ten thousand per year rather then Mr Bennett).The HD-DVD is well worth having over the regular DVD (I have both). I'd rate the transfer as 90% as some scenes aren't quite perfect.  It did remind my wife as to why we moved from England as the transfer shows the uneven workmanship and daily grime that is so English.Recommended.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I received the Blu-Ray version today and was totally unprepared for the audio track. The musical sound is exceptionable. The transfer is top notch. Clear and bright. I have owned other releases of this and this is by far the best one. All the actors are invested in their role. I especially like Kiera Knightly's efforts. Brenda Blethyn as nearly insufferable Mama. Donald Sutherland as long suffering Papa. Jena Malone's turn as the silly fifteen year old sister. When Elizabeth escapes to the, what should I call it, shelter near a lake during a rainstorm and Mr. Darcy follows her and they argue was a great scene. Judi Dench and Kiera's rapid fire repartées are beautiful to behold. At the end when the view of Mr. Darcy's home across the lake was shown, there were swans swimming about. Was this a reference to Swan Lake? A suggestion that Elizabeth was a "swan" who needed love to become human? Well, who doesn't need that?  I doubt that I can improve on other's reviews so I won't try.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I watched both the Colin Firth and Keira Knightly versions.  This one is a truncated version of the miniseries.  They cut down some of the sub plots that were featured in the miniseries. However the main story of Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy is essentially the same. Beautifully acted and the chemistry between Mattew Macfadyn and Keira Knightly is palatable. Matthew Macfadyn pretty much lived up to the shadow cast by Colin Firth.It was an enjoyable movie. I was sorry to see it end!
summary: Just as Good as the BBC miniseries

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: In watching this version of Jane Austen's classic novel of love, marriage, and class distinctions of Regency England, all I could think of was that, while pleasing to the eye, Keira Knightley and Matthew MacFadyen were less playing Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet than versions of Heathcliff and Catherine in Emily Bronte's "Wuthering Heights".Knightley's Elizabeth struck me as self important, dramatic, and smug rather than intelligent and full of life. Why was she always snarling, smiling, or generally baring her teeth? MacFadyen's Darcy, rather than proud, alternating between shyness and simply looking like he wanted to cry. Where was the pomposity? The disdain for others around him? I saw none of that.This is not even touching the appalling additions of such things as pigs in the living room and the generally unkempt appearance of the Bennets and their living situation. Mr. Bennet was a bookkeeper, a gentleman. The book states that the Bennets were "not too poor" and still managed to appear well mannered and well groomed despite the lack of funds. So the dirt and the farm animals were unneeded and had no point relevant to the "Pride and Prejudice" I have read. If they were that poor, what would be the point of the fuss made over Lizzie getting her skirt inches in mud on the way to visit Jane? There'd be nothing to remark on, because it would be the norm. And it is not.But back to "Pride and Prejudice" meets "Wuthering Heights". I get the idea was likely to appeal to the greater masses. But the Harlequinesque declarations and outright lack of propriety shown in the film - the flowing hair, the over the top emotion, the schmaltz - is counterproductive to the novel. I could buy the sap in "Wuthering Heights" because Heathcliff and Catherine were both so dramatic on their own that their romance and doom were highlighted by such actions. Mr. Darcy and Lizzie were more circumspect. No less passionate, but their passion lay in their mannerisms and their verbal sparring, not walking around in bare feet, nightgowns, or half-done shirts. No, no, no. Leave that to Emily Bronte, not Jane Austen.As for the rest, no way would single men visit sick single women when they are alone. Reputation, as was one point of the novel, meant everything. Such an action would be scandalous back in the day. A woman would NOT be seen with her hair down. Lizzie would not giggle endlessly and lick her fingers and act as silly as Lydia. No way would Mr. Darcy EVER deliver that letter in the way he did. And the first proposal: the book mentioned Charlotte's parlor. It should have been left at that. The rain was, again, more dramatic, but it did not fit for these characters, especially not at that juncture of their acquaintance. And no way would Lady Catherine go to Longbourn in the dead of night to have it out with Lizzie over her intentions for her nephew. It's all wrong.I am glad for those who enjoy this version, but if the filmmaker wanted over the top romance, he should have left Jane Austen alone and gone with the more lushly romantic aforementioned Emily Bronte. The Bronte-ization of "Pride and Prejudice" left me cold and diluted Jane Austen's observations about love, marriage, society, and money and turned the story into just another romance flick. Give me the A&E; miniseries, please.
summary: Pride and Prejudice is not Wuthering Heights!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Set in a time period in which love and marriage were often two very separate things for a variety of reasons (mostly societal), this movie is surprisingly romantic as well as empowering--a must see for those who believe that money doesn't necessarily buy happiness and that true love really does conquer all.  Great story, superb cast, beautiful sound track!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is truly my favorite movie of all time!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm an avid book reader so I know anytime a book I love is made into a movie, I will probably dislike some portion of it. You can never get everything from a book into a movie & books leave room for imagination. The reader will form a vision of the character in their minds, so when a fan of a writer or a particular novel finds the actor didn't fit that vision, they are unhappy. So I don't doubt that avid Austen readers will find problems with the movie.Looking at it purely from a movie objective. I loved it. I thought it was well acted and written. It very much reminded me of "Sense & Sensibility", which I also loved. I was fortunate, I guess you could say, that I have never read "Pride & Prejudice" so I was left in suspense as to whether Mr. Darcy & Elizabeth would ever be together. This certainly added to my pleasure of the movie. The movie allowed me to get to know all the characters. It definately drew out the romantic dreamer in me and I was crying at the end. I plan to read the book now, and I am sure I will have some opinions as to how the book compares to the movie, but for those that just love a good romantic movie.... watch it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I have seen this version and the much lauded 1995 version, and in my opinion I find this to be the best version.  Keira Knightley turns in her best film performance here!  The supporting cast is excellent, and the settings sumptuous.  I enjoyed the 1995 version, but this version is flawless!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Over time, I have purchased 3 copies of the DVD.  In our family it is the ultimate movie and love story.  Jane Austen's sense of love, family and the times is perfectly reproduced by Keira and Matthew.
summary: Keira K and Matthew M - STARS

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Many reviews compare this version of the movie to the television mini-series.  I would encourage audiences to take the film on its own merits, though as a Colin Firth fan, I will admit that can be a difficult thing to do.  Give Matthew Macfadyen a chance.  I like this role and other work he's done.This is an enjoyable film.  While some of the locations are changed, and it doesn't use the exact language of the book, I think it keeps very closely to the spirit and plot of the book. The Mr. Wickham story is severly compressed, but I think that they get the point across.  Besides, with the shorter time allotment, I would rather that was clipped than some other sections.  Especially enjoyable was the treatment of Mrs. Bennett.  Some versions make her so vapid and silly one wonders how she functions in society at all.  This Mrs. Bennett was more balanced while still fiting the character of the novel.Also memorable is the look of the film.  The sets, scenery, and costumes all feel realistic, and yet they are not so real and gritty that they lose their beauty.Overall, this is a fine film and well worth watching.
summary: Take It on Its Own Merits

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I bought this DVD as soon as it came out, having heard raving reviews of the movie. To say I was bitterly disappointed is a supreme understatement!! There was absolutely NOTHING i liked about it.It was altered dramatically from the beautiful funny and heartwarming book Jane A wrote, into a commercial, inaccurate, and brash Hollywood version. I felt like every bit of character Jane A infused ito the book had been bleached out. Perhaps the most disappointing thing was the casting of Keira K as Elizabeth. There was very little of Elizabeth in her performance in fact I really disliked her character (and I love Elizabeth!!). I suppose after watching the A&E; verion the standard is very high and this scraped the bottom of the barrel!!!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This movie is really captivating. It takes you on Elizabeth's journey through life. She is a young girl born into a family of five daughters. Her fanatic mother wants them all married because if their father dies they would have nothing. This is because in this time period females can't inherit. The setting is set in an older time period. This tale will surely touch your heart. I'm not one for crying while watching movies but this one makes me cry every time I watch it. This is truely a great movie that no other romance can stand up to.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It is August 2011, and this is the first time that I have watched the 2005 Joe Wright-directed "Pride & Prejudice". In MY pride and prejudice, I believed that the 1995 BBC version with Colin Firth to be the definitive adaption of the Jane Austen novel, and I refused to even give this movie a chance; that's how certain I believed it would be inferior, HAD to be inferior to the production I loved.  I now believe that this latest version may be the most romantic film of all time, bettering 'Casablanca', 'Gone with the Wind', 'Dr. Zhivago' and in it's comic way 'Moonstruck'. This film is cinematic Art. Every second of this film is a study in lighting (mindful of a Vermeer), costume, direction, and the score is lush, as opposed to over produced. Throughout we have a piano evoking every feeling, every desire and every longing on a summer's day, a walk through moors, a dance with delight as it soars with the love that is growing between Lizzie and Mr. D'Arcy. Every scene of this film has meaning; nothing is superfluous, and not a second is spent wasted in tedium. Keira Knightly is luminous, yet tactile, bright, sharp with wit, and vulnerable with adolescence. There are a couple of scenes with Mathew Macfayden which positively crackled on screen with such eroticism, such intense yet discrete sensuality that they linger in the mind. One is where he simply and surprisingly puts his hand under Lizzie's to assist her climbing onto a carriage. The touch is unexpected by her, and her look is one of offense, and passion simultaneously. It is just a brief part of a second, and yet as Mr. D'Arcy walks away, his hand opens and practically trembles from the electric shock of that skin on skin contact; a horse snorts as he walks quickly away from his assault: he HAD to touch her. The film is photographed to perfection, from  English countryside landscapes with birds singing in the trees, to the inner rooms of the Bennet household, alive with the frolic of having five girls in the house creates. The characters are not stuffy recreations, but real people, and we relate to their relationships, and to their status and to their family life. It all leads up to a scene with Mr D'Arcy walking across the fog-misted moors before dawn to make an hopeful quest for Lizzi's heart. Mathew Macfayden seduces anybody who watches that scene, as the camera catches him from afar and stays right on him as he looms larger and clearer and dearer to Lizzie the closer he gets. One of the best, if not the best film of all time. A MUST SEE.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This must be at least the fourth film version of the book that I've seen, and I also saw a stage version back when I was a child, 50 years ago. I never actually read the novel, but I think this production is pretty good. It has younger actors than one usually sees in P and P adaptations, and I found that refreshing, even if the quality of the acting might be less than perfect. I thought it got off to a bit of a slow start, but raced to a fine finish. And lead actress KK is simply irresistable.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I like this version of Pride & Prejudice and love Kiera Knightly, but it honestly can't hold a candle to the 1995 BBC production starring Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle now also out on Blu Ray.  That newly restored HD release is simply breath taking (and I'm not that big of chick flick fan!).  To each his or her own obviously, but I recomend the five hour BBC version!
summary: Good, but not the definitive version!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Good rendition of an old thick book.  The family and characters were brought off the pages by fine professional actiing.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I believe Jane Austen's initial tittle for the book on which this movie is based was First Impressions. To me that tittle better conveys the theme, that our first impressions of others are often grossly mistaken. Lizzy's first impressions of two of the men in her life were wrong. One for the better and one for the worse. My first impression of Lizzy was also wrong. At the beginning of the movie, I was disappointed to find Lizzy as a shallow, giggly girl looking to marry a rich man, but as the movie goes on (slowly at times) I was pleased to learn Lizzy was the complete opposite of my initial impression.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I first read this book in college and loved it, so I have seen all the versions from the silly Lawrence Olivier version to now. My favorite still remains the 1995 Colin Firth version, but this one is also a keeper. Kiera Knightley is wonderful as she has been so far in everything she has played. The scenery alone is well worth the price of the DVD. The settings give you a real flavor of the time - early 1800's - and the muddy way that people lived. No wonder the upper class were revolted by country manners - with a pig that size in the house? Brenda Blethyn does a wonderful job as Mrs. Bennett, as do the four sisters. But, for those of us who know the book by heart, this version is a disappointment. I miss many of the lines I love - they are either missing or thrown away in a mumble. The hair stylist should have done more research as should the writer - I agree that the 'faux pas' - Elizabeth running around in her nightgown - Darcy waltzing into the Collins' whenever he feels like it - are GLARING. It disrupts the reality for those of us who know the manners of that time better. But the real problem with it is Darcy - Darcy has to be cold and haughty, warm and shy, and sexy. MacFayden does angry and appalled, and little else. The director said that he did not want to cast someone too handsome and he certainly has followed through on that. MacFayden could have been cast as one of the farm hands much more easily. Love stories have to be believable - you have to believe that someone as great as Kiera Knightley is going to fall for the guy. With Orlando Bloom this works. But not here - such a shame. Lastly, although I like Donald Sutherland, he plays Mr. Bennett as though he on the edge of senility - Mr. Bennett has a lot of great lines in this story but I'm not surprised that other viewers didn't value them because Sutherland threw them away if he got to say them at all. Read the book, it's funnier.
summary: great scenery, but jane austen is funnier

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I just cant get enough of this movie. Love the era. Love the actors. Just plain love it to pieces.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: While I am a huge fan and appreciate the quality and content of many BBC productions, this movie is quite possibly the greatest romantic film ever made.  Even though Jane Austin purists may think it is subpar, I advise taking it for its own qualities and strengths.  This rendition of Pride and Prejudice is simply a masterpiece!  Kiera Knightley should have won best actress and this film should have won best film of the year.  The acting by the two leads is exceptional, the musical score is moving, the choreography is beautiful, the storyline terrific, the humor is engaging, and the romance inspiring.  This film holds you in its grip and does not let go.  It is a movie to watch over and over again.  Joe Wright did an outstanding job directing.  (This is far superior to the movie Atonement, by the way).  If you are truly a romantic at heart you cannot miss this movie or deny its intensity.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I had not read Pride & Prejudice before watching the movie.  I had tried many times but I always ended up putting it down.  After seeing the movie (many, many times) I could not get enough of the story...and Mr. Darcy.  I picked up the book again and read it straight through -- twice.  It is a love story that all women (and men) should see (and read).

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I'm a lifetime Austen fan and this is my all time favorite adaption of Pride and Predjudice. Each character was perfectly cast, each detail was perfectly executed. The entire movie is sheer entertainment.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is a great version of the well known story.  The movie is enchanting and takes you to another world.  Love to stick this movie in while working around the house.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was skeptical in the beginning, then I read the great reviews as well as some first hand accounts of how good this movie was and I had to see it. In fact, I was pretty excited about it.As we started watching the movie, we were like, "Why can't we understand what they're saying." The first half-hour seemed muffled, then they spoke more clearly.On the movie, I thought it was just OK. This version didn't need to be made. A much better version exists out there and that's the 1995 A&E; version. Too many scenes were shortened to accommodate for time and I think it hurt the movie. I don't think there was chemistry between Lizzy and Mr. Darcy. Lydia's character should have been expanded on as well as Mrs. Bennet to understand these characters. Mr. Wickham was barely there and you don't know how terrible his unless you've read the book. By the other characters telling us his story doesn't help us loathe him the way we should. I could go on but there isn't enough space.On the positive side: the Cinematography was very good and the ending, though completely fabricated, gave it a nice ending, hence the two stars given.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I really enjoy this movie.  It's a very good adaptation taking a more realistic view of the Bennet family than you usually see.  But . . . well there's this other version that I really like more with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth.
summary: A really good movie - but not the best based on the material

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Why is it that Keira Knightley always has this look on her face like something smells really, really, horribly, bad? As if that isn't bad enough, this version is terrible. If you have any interest in Jane Austen's literary masterpiece, don't waste your time on this drivel.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: First, to all of the Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth lovers (of which, I am one), we will always have that remarkable masterpiece.  Therefore, we should be able to judge any new versions freely.  Having said that, this version is great!This movie is quite shorter than what we're used to for P&P; adaptations and at first it seemed to me that the dialogue was rushed, but after the first 15 minutes it either slowed down or I ceased to notice it, until Darcy's proposal scene anyway, but it worked quite well there.This film is also much more of a comedy than the two BBC versions.  There were minor changes with dialogue but none of the changes lessened any of the characters or the spirit of the story.  Instead, it probably enhanced the feelings the audience shared with the characters. In fact, I think that everything left out of the two previous BBC versions were added to this one so you still get something new from the same story.One major change is the loss of Mr. and Mrs. Hurst.  In a two-hour movie there just isn't enough time to do their characters justice.  The rest of the cast is so marvelous though that we barely notice they're missing and it makes the movie flow more naturally.The actors chosen are wonderful in their parts.  I didn't think I'd be able to accept Keira Knightley as Elizabeth but after the first five minutes I was completely taken in by her.  She pulls off Elizabeths witty dialogue like, well... Elizabeth and just as Jennifer Ehle added some distinctive traits to Lizzie, so does Keira.  She wonderfully manages to show us Lizzie's love of a good laugh without making it seem as though she was a giggling loony and every time she smiles, we smile with her.I won't critique all the performances but I have to add that Donald Sutherland really does a spectacular job as the head of a household of silly women.  The last scene with him and Lizzie had me in tears.Not to say that this movie was perfect, what adaptation can be without some faults or silly alterations?  None are too serious though.  The first is at the Meryton ball, when Darcy, Bingley and Caroline walk in, everything stops.  The music, the dancing, all conversation and the crowd parts to offer them a path.  I thought for a second the crowd had mistaken Mr. Bingley for royalty.  It just seemed a bit over the top.  But it passed quickly enough.  The other was actually Darcy's proposal scene which was done in the rain.  I thought it silly that he would follow her outside in such weather to propose, but one can accept that in view of the other changes that turned out so well.I give this movie 5 stars because I wouldn't want to miss it and I don't think any P&P; fan should.All in all, if you have a good sense of humor and aren't afraid to laugh, like Elizabeth, you will just enjoy the story as it is played out.  Remember, afterwards you can always put Jennifer and Colin Firth back in the DVD player.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The girls giggle too much. The character of Lydia does not speak clearly when she is at the dinner table after she marries.  The  background sound over powers the actors so you are forever adjusting the volume. Could they have found any more dull and dowdy clothes? The overall film is far more dreary than the other versions. Also, do we need to see so many farm animals? It gives the film an appearance that the Bennet family were poor farm tenents. The scene with the huge pig was ridiculous. This version lacks the elegance of the other two older versions. Based on this version it is difficult to imagine Mr. Darcy ever being interested in Elizabeth. There was nothing noteworthy in the actress portraying Elizabeth.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: This is my all time favorite movie. I could watch it again and again, in fact I do. on any rainy day i just pop it in and do my chores while it plays in the background. I love love love it!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen. Need I say more? This has become my favorite Jane Austen movie. Characters are interesting, fun to watch and if I were an actress I would love to play Elizabeth Bennett. I have watched every version of Pride and Prejudice I can get my hands on. I own 3 different ones. Each time the actors/director interprets the book differently while maintaining the integrity of the story. I like them all but this version is my favorite. The actors (even the family) have chemistry. You grow to love them. There is a passion that Kiera Knightly and Matthew Macfadyen bring to the screen that makes your heart race. Do watch it without interruptions and you will be delighted.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: yes pride and prejudice more than exceeded my expectations!! I love that movie it literally gives a sense of what life was like before! Jane Austen had a gift for capturing life moments, truly gifted young lady!! I watch this movie over and over! Simply love It...

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I am willing to admit it, I am a shallow woman because Darcy and only Darcy made this movie so magic for me! His vulnerability, his shyness and reserve I found extremely attractive. This is the best version and adaptation of my favorite book. Chemistry between the actors is just unbelievable!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I finally purchased this DVD to add to my collection of favorite movies. I was torn between the full screen format or widescreen, and opted for the latter. I really detest the black screen above and below the video, however was concerned over images being cut off by the full screen format.  Anyhow, this is the background that led me to purchase this movie.I'm rather embarrassed to admit that I had never read Jane Austen's masterpiece, nor was aware of the story line. I happened to be flipping through the TV channels one evening and this movie was on. I watched and absolutely fell in love with the story and the characters, particularly that of Mr. Darcy played by Mathew McFayden. It was entertaining to see him transform from the condescending snob at the initial ball to a sexy romantic in the final scene; one of the best love stories I have ever witnessed. The movie had me and I viewed it several times on TV.Then, I happened to catch the BBC miniseries version one evening with Colin Firth. Luckily all episodes played simultaneously, so I spent 6 hours watching these new characters and altered story line of what I was accustomed. Admittedly, it was disheartening to watch these new actors initially . There could never be a better Mr. Darcy than Mathew McFayden, and Colin Firth did not quite fit the bill, IMO. However, by the 4th episode, my feelings gave way and I actually enjoyed the development of all the characters. Although the contrast of Keira Knightly and Jennifer Ehle as Lizzie Bennet is quite evident, I rather liked both. Additionally, it was quite enjoyable to watch a young Colin Firth (I knew him only from "The King's Speech"). I recorded these episodes to my DVR and have watched several times. Colin Firth's Darcy definitely comes off as more proud and conceited than the 2005 version, and the intimacy of that momentous kiss at the end lacked luster. However, the story line in whole still captures my heart and it is nice to go back and forth between the 2 versions.I happened to discover and watch a third version, another BBC miniseries made in the 80's. Since my evaluation of these movies are based upon my interpretation of Mr. Darcy's character, I must confess that David Rintoul's physical appearance was too thin and not sexy enough. I observed some differences in the 2 miniseries, from the more elaborate costumes, the enhanced vulgarity of Mrs Bennett and her younger daughters, and the more even- tempered attitude of Darcy.By now, I had become enamored with Pride and Prejudice. I discovered yet another version made in 1940 with Laurence Olivier as Mr. Darcy. I disliked him even more than David Rintoul's interpretation. I equally disliked the gaudy costumes, the limited scenes (although this would be expected in 1940), and the fact that Lady Catherine de Bourgh schemed with Darcy to influence Lizzy's decision to marry him. Although I hadn't read the book, I knew that the scene could not have been part of the original story  because it just didn't make sense.And so, I decided to read the book and see for myself which version was more accurate. It took all of 48 hours to complete and it is now one of my favorite novels. I must admit that the 2 miniseries most correspond to the novel, particularly the one that was made in the 1980's. Also, I now see that the 2005 version was a hurried and condensed adaptation of the book, however this is still my favorite and Mathew McFayden will forever be my Mr. Darcy :-)

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I thought I would hate this movie because no one else can be Mr. Darcy like Colin Firth can. But I fell in love with the movie (and the new Mr. Darcy) about one minute into it. It was a wonderful movie! I can't wait for the DVD.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: The casting was just about perfect, in my opinion. Everything was simply wonderful and it is one of the few movies I watch again and again over the years.
summary: One of my all time favorite movies

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Beautifully shot, this is an enjoyable movie, although true Austen fans may find it outragous sometimes. For instance, the custumes for the Bennetts look very shabby; the interior of the Bennett's house looks like a French country house; the first dance scene (when Darcy shows up) is very country-side like (are these people really gentlemen and ladies, I almost wondered out loud) ......But overall, I still enjoyed watching it multiple times. You have to remember this is a Hollywood rendition of a much loved story. Don't be offended by its lack of authenticity.
summary: If you're a true Austen fan, you may find this movie odd

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Jane Austen is timeless, as is proven by her popularity as much today as it was in almost 200 years ago!  Her choice of subject matter of human nature will always appeal to people.  This movie is an artist's perspective of one of the greatest novels ever written.  The mood, the use of a muted color pallet and musical score create a visual image of beauty, which portrays the novels theme perfectly.  I am convinced that if Jane Austen were alive today, that film would have been her chosen form of artistic expression and this movie one of her creations.  Kiera Knightley lends an almost luminous quality to Elizabeth Bennet, with a slight edge of mischievousness.  In my opinion the best P&P ever!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Excellent movie if you have not seen it yet I would highly recommend it. The blu ray version makes it that much better.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: It shows you that sometimes things are not what they appear to be if we just look a little deeper

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I saw this movie the first time in 2005, and LOVED it. I enjoyed this movie so much that I decided to read the book, and to be honest I'm wasn't a fan of classical romance or any kind of romance ( and I'm girl) but that all changed after P & P. I love Matthew Macfadyen as Mr.Darcy.He was born to play Mr.Darcy.And Keira Knightley is a excellent actress and she did a superb job as Elizabeth. I recommend this movie to everyone I know because it made a great impression on me.This movie really makes you feel so many emotions, you'll cry, laughed, and at the end you will truly believe in true love.P.S.: I tried to watch the 1995 BBC P & P but in my opinion the actors portraying the characters are so bland and boring, but again that's MY opinion.

review_text: I had always heard wonderful things about this movie. I finally got around to watching it on Amazon streaming. I loved the movie and will watch it again.

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I was a bit disappointed that there wasn't at least a 2-Disc Special Edition of this movie. The movie is entertaining and gives another depth of the forever told story. It has also brought a lot of fans to Ms. Austen.I've been quite a fan of Jane Austen's books for quite a long time and have gotten to see the most beloved version of this story with Colin Firth. title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: I watched this 2005 adaptation of Pride and Prejudice some years ago and then forgot all about it. I guess I wasn't really paying attention to it, and decided to give it another go last night. Now, I am an ardent fan of the BBC adaptation starring Colin Firth as Mr. Darcy and Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth Bennet,Pride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996), and the other adaptation I have a fondness for is the one starring David Rintoul as Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Garvie as Elizabeth Bennet,Pride and Prejudice (BBC, 1980). Both are faithful adaptations of the novel and I've worn out my DVDs watching them over and over whenever I have the time.This 2005 adaptation is a film version, so it is predictably an abridged version. It stars Keira Knightley (who does well in period dramas, e.g.The Duchess, andAtonement (Widescreen Edition)) as Elizabeth Bennet, and Matthew McFadyen as Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy. Long-suffering Mr. Bennet is played by Donald Sutherland, and Mrs. Bennet is played by Brenda Blethyn. The other daughters are played by Rosamund Pike (Jane), Jena Malone (Lydia), Carey Mulligan (Kitty), and Talulah Riley (Mary). Elizabeth's best friend, Charlotte Lucas is played by Claudie Blakley (who went on to do an amazing job as Emma Timmins in the beloved BBC series Lark Rise and Candleford.So how does this film version measure up to the full-length BBC series? There is truly no comparison. Many liberties have been taken with the storyline such that the essence of the story is there, but many of the finer nuances of Austen's writing and social commentary is quite lost in translation. Both Knightley and McFadyen deliver credible performances, though Knightley's giggly and bewildered looks do tend to get a tad tiresome after awhile. Mr. and Mrs. Bennet are sufficiently adequate in their roles, but the actors portraying them fail to capture the true essence of these two ridiculous characters, especially in Mrs. Bennet's case. Jena Malone also fails to convince as the flirty, silly, and impulsive Lydia Bennet (she really can't compare to Julia Sawalha's infuriatingly convincing performance in the 1996 BBC adaptation). The actor portraying Mr. Collins delivered a tepid performance. Luckily his counterpart in the movie, Charlotte Lucas nee Collins as played by Blakley, is compelling. Lady Catherine de Bourgh, the snobbish wannabe mother-in-law to Darcy, is well-played by Dame Judi Dench (who never fails to deliver in any of her roles).Despite these flaws and the liberties taken with the plot, I did like this adaptation because of several things. The two leads beguile viewers with their strong chemistry. There's a sexual tension between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy that practically simmers on-screen and draws viewers in. The love-hate relationship and longing that is so evident is credibly portrayed by the two leads, each look, gesture, etc. The cinematography is breathtaking. When I first saw Pemberley in this movie, it just about took my breath away (though the Pemberley featured in the 1996 BBC adaptation will always be my favorite). My favorite outdoors scene in this movie was of Elizabeth standing on the cliffs with the haunting music playing the background...it was just transcendent! Then there's the amazing score. The music is so perfect for this period drama, and Dawn is one of my favorites. The music is memorable and can very well be a classic, just as the score to the 1996 BBC adaptation is.All in all, I was glad I watched this again, and will add this adaptation to my Pride and Prejudice collection.
summary: 3.5* - Many liberties taken here, but the chemistry between the leads sizzles!

title: Pride & Prejudice
review_text: Okay, here's the deal: if you have read Pride and Prejudice and loved it, do NOT watch this movie unless you want to go on an unrewarding emotional journey: first you will hoot laughing, and then cry in despair,  and then become angry and hurl insults (and possibly rotten garbage) at your dvd player. If you are not a reader and are not a fan of Jane Austen, then you might find this somewhat amusing. I guess. I wouldn't know because I was so outraged by this "adaptation." I like to think of it more as an abomination, because that's what it is. The costumes are awful, the writer's and actors' interpretations of the characters is dreadful, and the whole thing is a hideous mess of a movie.Keira Knightley is fine in movies like "Bend it Like Beckham" and "Pirates," but she cannot carry a true period drama. (By the way, is anyone else distracted by her mouth? It is CONSTANTLY open -- watch for it in "Pirates" as well). Darcy, Bingley, and the Bennett parents barely resemble the characters as Austen wrote them, and Wickham is hardly present! There is NO chemistry between Lizzie and Darcy either. Ugh, the whole thing is just terrible.Do yourself a favor and watch (or re-watch) the A&E; BBC version with Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. Okay, so they made up the scene with Darcy at the pond, but it's a pardonable (and saucy) addition to an otherwise extremely faithful and beautiful rendition of Pride and Prejudice. If you haven't seen the BBC version, by all means skip the Keira Knightley debacle and go straight to the real thing!
